BC-Japan-Sex
Survey: Nearly one in every two Japanese men admit buying sex
TOKYO (AP) _ A survey of Japanese men released Wednesday found that nearly one in every two admitted to having paid prostitutes for sex at least once. The findings were made in a survey of about 2,500 adult males across Japan between August and October of last year that was conducted by the Asia-Japan Women's Resource Center, a civic group handling women's issues. Of the 2,500 respondents, 46.2 percent said they have paid for sex, while 51.3 percent said they have never done so. ``It shows they (Japanese men) are very nonchalant about paying for sex, as thought,'' said Yukiko Tsunoda, a lawyer for the group. Like other Japanese polls, the survey provided no margin of error. And Tsunoda cautioned that the men surveyed included acquaintances of group members and were not picked entirely at random. As many as 61.1 percent of those who said they had paid for sex also said they think it desirable to have a society without prostitution, the survey showed. Prostitution was officially banned in 1956, but the sex industry remains prosperous at loosely disguised ``soup land'' brothels. Japan has come under international criticism as a growing number of Southeast Asian women complain of having been lured to Japan with promises of jobs only to be forced into prostitution by the ``yakuza,'' Japan's mob. (km)

BC-Japan-Contaminated Water
Toxins found in ground water near Toshiba plant
TOKYO (AP) _ Local environmental agency officials have found high concentrations of a toxic chemical in water under a Toshiba Corp. plant in the central Japanese city of Nagoya, a spokesman for the city's Environment Protection Agency said on Wednesday. Ground water under the factory contained 470 milligrams per liter of trichloroethylene, or TCE, 15,670 times the level the environmental agency considers safe, according to the agency official who spoke on condition of anonymity. TCE causes cancer in laboratory animals, and studies indicate it may be the cause of lupus erythematosus and other connective-tissue and immune-system diseases. The city does not use ground water for drinking water, the official said. Nonetheless, the city will offer physical examinations to residents who request them from August. Environmental officials in Nagoya are so far not blaming Toshiba for the contamination, saying they are still investigating the source and extent of the spill. They have questioned 13 businesses in the area and found that a nearby metal-products factory used TCE from 1988 to 1990. According to the agency official, the factory said it properly disposed of the TCE it used. For its part, Toshiba claims it has not used TCE in the area in the last 15 years, according to company spokesman Keisuke Ohmori. Ohmori said the company ``suspects it came from other facilities.'' Toshiba's plant in Nagoya, 269 kilometers (168 miles) west of Tokyo, makes home appliances. In a previous incident, a former Toshiba plating factory that had been located nearby was blamed as the source of toxic substances including TCE found there in October. The environmental official said his agency did not believe the plating factory was also the source of the newly discovered contamination because it was some 350 meters (yards) away and ground water between the areas was not polluted. Toshiba said it is working with Nagoya city to investigate the contamination. (tz)

BC-SKorea-Labor
Militant South Korean labor group to go ahead with strike plans
By PAUL SHIN Associated Press Writer
SEOUL, South Korea (AP) _ A militant labor group said Wednesday it will go ahead with plans for a nationwide strike next week, citing a breakdown in talks with the government aimed at halting growing layoffs. The decision by the maverick Confederation of Korean Trade Unions raised concern that labor unrest may persist in South Korea in the midst of its deepening economic crisis. It also chilled President Kim Dae-jung's hopes of attracting foreign investment during his visit to the United States next week. Kim has stressed the importance of labor peace to his efforts. ``The government is too much uncompromising, especially on layoffs,'' said Chung Sung-hee, a spokesman of the confederation, which claims a membership of 500,000 in car, shipbuilding and other heavy industries. Chung said overnight talks with the government to avert the strike broke down because of what he called the government's unwillingness to accept the confederation's demand for a halt to widespread layoffs. He said the strike, the second in two weeks, will begin on June 10 as scheduled, joined by 130,000 car workers, shipbuilders and office clerks from state-run companies. The group organized a similar two-day strike last week. Government figures show that the number of jobless people has doubled to nearly 1.5 million and will likely top 2 million by the end of the year. Chung said his confederation also will stay out of a government-sponsored committee that was to begin meeting later Wednesday to discuss layoffs and other labor problems. Its 15 members were drawn from labor, management and government. A similar committee, formed in January, agreed to make South Korea's rigid labor markets more flexible. That subsequently led to the adoption of a law that makes layoffs easier. The new committee is supposed to follow up on what was agreed on in January and adopt additional measures, including how to speed up a restructuring of bloated, family-oriented Korean conglomerates, or chaebol. In accepting a dlrs 58 billion bailout from the International Monetary Fund in December, South Korea agreed to liberalize its labor market and force the restructuring of the chaebol to make them more competitive. The new committee includes delegates from the Korean Federation of Trade Unions, a pro-government group that has generally avoided labor strife. The government regretted the confederation's decision to stay out of the committee but said it was optimistic that the group would eventually change its position. ``From now on, our efforts will be directed at creating and systemizing a South Korean model of a social contract to overcome our national crisis through harmony and compromise,'' said Kim Won-ki, who heads the committee.

BC-Guyana-Elections,0445
Long-awaited audit says Guyana election was fair and president.
Eds: RECAPS pvs and UPDATES with comments from opposition leader By BERT WILKINSON Associated Press Writer
GEORGETOWN, Guyana (AP) _ In a blow to Guyana's main opposition party, a Caribbean Community audit team declared fair December elections that touched off race riots in the South American country. Former President Desmond Hoyte said Tuesday he accepted the results of the audit released that day, but added that that did not mean his party would accept Chicago-born Janet Jagan as president of Guyana. Hours after the audit was released Tuesday, Hoyte still claimed there was fraud. Audited results varied ``only marginally'' from official results of the Dec. 15 election, which was won by Jagan's People's Progressive Party, Caribbean Community team leader Ulric Cross said. Hoyte said, ``If the integrity of the boxes was compromised, as the People's National Congress contends, a recount of the votes would reflect the same number of votes that would have been irregularly put in the box.'' Hoyte said his party was not sure they would take up their 24 seats in the 65-member Parliament. But he also called for the government to speed up constitutional reforms _ a move that requires a two-thirds majority of votes that would have to include the opposition. Jagan's party won the parliamentary elections by 60,000 votes, a margin of about 14 percent over Hoyte's. In an address to the nation, Jagan said it was time for Guyana's 733,000 people to ``move on'' knowing their leaders were fairly elected. ``This is not the time for victors and losers,'' she said. Race is at the root of most conflicts in Guyana, a former British colony. Jagan's party is backed by the majority population of East Indian descent, while Hoyte's draws support from the 40 percent of people of African descent. The audit was part of a peace agreement brokered by the Caribbean Community on Jan. 17. The deal also calls for new elections by 2000 and constitutional reform to help balance power between the ethnic groups. Dozens were hurt in race riots in December and January that closed down schools and businesses. Fearing more vandalism, some merchants in downtown Georgetown boarded up their shop windows Tuesday. But no trouble was reported. Hoyte's party governed for 28 years until 1992, through elections that were largely fraudulent. Independence leader Cheddi Jagan won the first democratic elections but died in office a year ago. His widow, 77-year-old Janet Jagan, vowed to continue his legacy.

BC-World Bank-India,0297
World Bank postpones two more loans for India
RECAPS pvs. By HARRY DUNPHY Associated Press Writer
WASHINGTON (AP) _ The World Bank has postponed two more loans to India, bringing to more than dlrs 1 billion the amount held up because of the South Asian nation's nuclear tests. Tuesday's step by the bank's executive directors postponed dlrs 206.4 million in loans. Last week, the bank delayed four loans totalling dlrs 865 million after the United States, Japan and Canada urged no action on the money. The loans _ dlrs 130 million for an agriculture project and dlrs 76.4 million for a health care project _ were scheduled to be discussed by the bank's executive board Tuesday. But ``in response to requests from several executive directors, consideration of the loans has been postponed to a date to be determined,'' a World Bank official said. Officials familiar with bank operations say that once loans get postponed, it can take several months and perhaps longer for them to be reconsidered. The moves followed India's nuclear tests last month, which drew bilateral economic sanctions from the United States and other industrial countries. Under the sanctions, U.S. officials were required to vote against Indian loans but didn't have the votes for a veto. If they choose, they can try to gather other countries' support for disapproval. India was scheduled to get roughly dlrs 3 billion in loans from the World Bank this fiscal year that ends June 30. Some dlrs 1 billion had already been approved before the country's nuclear tests. The postponements mean India will have to scale back the projects for which they were intended or try to raise the money from private banks at a far greater cost.

BC-Vietnam-Drought
Vietnam drought called officially over
HANOI, Vietnam (AP) _ Vietnam's worst drought in a century is over, thanks to the onset of the delayed rainy season, official media reported Wednesday. Power cuts, imposed because of falling reservoir water levels at crucial hydroelectric power plants, have been dropped. The drought caused an estimated dlrs 385 million in damage, the English-language Vietnam News quoted the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development as saying. Most of the damage was to the country's two main cash crops, rice and coffee. But storms now are exacting a toll. Five people were killed and two others were injured by lightning in the Mekong Delta province of Vinh Long in two separate incidents Sunday and Monday. Two other people were killed by lightning in the Mekong Delta province of Can Tho on Sunday. A heavy thunderstorm knocked out power to parts of Hanoi on Tuesday night. Most of the city's traffic lights were still off Wednesday morning.

BC-Sports-Baseball-AL Roundup, 2nd Add,0260
BLATIMORE: three hits. Angels 7, Royals 5
In Kansas City, Missouri, four beanballs and two bench-clearing brawls led to 12 ejections in Anaheim's victory over the Royals. Seven players, both managers and three coaches were ejected in the AL's second ugly incident in recent weeks. A fight between the New York Yankees and Baltimore Orioles on May 19 resulted in five suspensions. The problems Tuesday night started in the top of the seventh, when Anaheim's Phil Nevin was hit in the back by Kansas City pitcher Jim Pittsley. Nevin, who was also hit in his previous at-bat by Chris Haney, charged the mound and tried to tackle Pittsley, but the pitcher wrestled Nevin down and appeared to throw some jabs. Both benches emptied, but apparently no other players threw punches. Nevin, Pittsley, and Kansas City coaches Rich Dauer and Jamie Quirk also were ejected. Rich DeLucia hit Kansas City's Dean Palmer with the first pitch in the bottom of the eighth and was immediately ejected along with Anaheim manager Terry Collins. Kansas City pitcher Scott Service and Royals manager Tony Muser were ejected in the top of the ninth after Service hit Darin Erstad with a pitch. There were four more ejections in the bottom of the ninth following a bench-clearing brawl that started after Royals leadoff hitter Jose Offerman was hit by Mike Holtz. Tossed were Mike Holtz, Anaheim coach Joe Maddon, Angels infielder Frank Bolick and Royals infielder Felix Martinez.

BC-Thailand-Closing Down
Thai government to close down 35 overseas offices to save money
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ Thailand will close or merge at least 35 government offices in 16 foreign countries to save money amid the continuing economic crisis. The Cabinet approved the closures Tuesday, deeming them necessary despite previous budget cuts of 683 million baht (dlrs 17 million) in the foreign service this fiscal year. A recent audit of Thailand's 275 overseas offices in 65 countries found they were both too scattered and that there was too much overlap from the 10 ministries with foreign postings. Representation will be affected in Australia, Austria, Belgium, Britain, China, France, Germany, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Italy, Japan, Malaysia, the Philippines, Saudi Arabia, Singapore and the United States. The ministries of finance and agriculture will each be forced to shut down seven offices, while the Foreign Ministry will suspend the postings of 73 diplomats and cut short the tours of 140 by one year. Other affected ministries include education, labor, commerce, industry and defense. The Civil Servants Commission will close eight offices abroad and the Public Relations Department four. Representatives of the Tourism Authority of Thailand, which is mounting a major campaign to bring in badly needed foreign exchange, will share offices with state-owned Thai Airways International.

BC-India-Heat Wave,0168
Heat wave toll crosses 1,000 in India
NEW DELHI, India (AP) _ Severe heat claimed another 100 victims, taking the total number of dead this summer to more than a 1,000, according to local news agency reports Wednesday. United News of India reported 100 heat-related deaths Tuesday, most in the southeastern state of Andhra Pradesh and the northeastern state of Bihar. Temperatures have ranged from 43 to 50 Celsius (110 to 122 Fahrenheit) across India over the past month, making it the hottest summer in 50 years. The seasonal monsoon rains have already hit the coast of southern India, bringing respite. The rains will take another month and a half to reach the plains of northern India that have been hardest hit by the heat wave, but pre-monsoon rains are already having an effect. In the western desert state of Rajasthan, where temperatures hovered around 48 Celsius (120 Fahrenheit) two weeks ago, the heat has lessened slightly.

BC-China-Polluted Yangtze
Pollution in Yangtze harming health, power plants
BEIJING (AP) _ Pollution along China's Yangtze River is harming the health of residents and clogging a crucial power plant, state media reported Wednesday. The National environmental Protection Agency and the ministry overseeing shipping along the river launched a month-long publicity campaign Tuesday to get boats, businesses and people from treating the Yangtze like a garbage dump. In reporting the campaign, China Daily described the river, the world's third longest, as a ``muddy stream plagued with rubbish of every conceivable kind.'' It called the condition ``deplorable.'' Few of the 27 ports along the 6,400-kilometer (3,800-mile) river have garbage collection or disposal facilities, the newspaper said. Ships alone dump 8,000 tons of garbage, 100 million tons of sewage and 5,000 tons of waste oil into the Yangtze every year, China Daily said. It added that factories and tourist restaurants were also to blame. The health of people living along the river is suffering and the pollution is affecting the operation of the Gezhouba power plant, the newspaper said without elaboration. No mention was made about pollution's possible effects on the Three Gorges Dam, the world's largest hydroelectric project, being built in the middle reaches of the Yangtze. When completed 11 years from now, the dam will hold back a 600-kilometer (350-mile)-long reservoir touching on its western end the heavily industrialized city of Chongqing. Environmentalists have decried the project's lack of sanitation facilities and fear the reservoir will become little better than a large, open sewer.

BC-Vietnam-Media Award
Government criticizes award to jailed journalist
HANOI, Vietnam (AP) _ Vietnam on Wednesday criticized the World Association of Newspapers for giving an award to a jailed Vietnamese journalist. ``We ... hold that WAN's conferring of the Golden Pen of Freedom award to Doan Viet Hoat, a prisoner who is serving his sentence, is a mistake,'' a Foreign Ministry statement said. ``(It) absolutely will not enjoy the support of the Vietnamese public opinion and will affect the prestige of the awarding organization.'' Hoat, serving a 15-year prison term for publishing pro-democracy newsletters, was honored Monday for his commitment to a free press. He has spent much of the past three decades in re-education camps and prisons for calling for greater civil rights and democratic reform in Vietnam. He continues to call for the changes from his prison cell. The World Association of Newspapers represents 15,000 newspapers around the world.

BC-Hong Kong-Economy
Hong Kong focuses on economic woes with high-level meetings
HONG KONG (AP) _ Hong Kong officials took aim at a worsening economic and employment picture on Wednesday in a pair of high-level meetings aimed at finding ways to limit the damage from a looming recession. Financial Secretary Donald Tsang convened the first government task force to discuss the labor market, review retraining programs, and create more government jobs. Unemployment is officially at a 14-year high of 3.9 percent, although unions say the figure is much higher. It is expected to increase as Hong Kong, which avoided the worst of Asia's economic crisis for nearly a year, settles into a protracted battle with low stock and property prices, and joblessness. The economy contracted 2 percent in the first quarter of the year, and one senior official said late Tuesday that it would likely shrink in the second quarter, too. That technically would put Hong Kong in recession. More than 80 people demonstrated outside the government building where Tsang convened the closed employment meeting, demanding cuts in taxes and government fees to encourage business and employment, Hong Kong Radio reported. At the same time, representatives of the seven political parties that won seats in May 24 legislative elections held a separate meeting to seek a common stance on improving the economy. The meeting included critics of Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa, who took office after the handover to Chinese rule last July 1, pro-business parties, and grassroots parties that back Beijing. News reports said proposals on the table would include pushing ahead government infrastructure projects, tax cuts, lowering public utilities charges and government fees, and assistance for small and medium-size businesses that form the backbone of the Hong Kong economy. The meetings come on the heels of an announcement Tuesday by Hong Kong Monetary Authority chief executive Joseph Yam Chi-kwong that the territory's economy is likely to slide further. ``If you define a recession as negative growth in two successive quarters ... it seems we may see it,'' the South China Morning Post quoted Yam as saying in London, where he is at a symposium for central bankers. He is the first senior official to suggest that Hong Kong is heading for recession. ``The second quarter is not particularly good, and if you look at the second quarter of last year ... the second quarter is also likely to report negative growth,'' Yam said. Yam said that the contraction of 2 percent in Gross Domestic Product during the first quarter, the first such contraction in almost 13 years, was a surprise to Hong Kong officials, though they had anticipated some sort of slowdown. ``We felt a slowdown would occur, but the slowdown is quite sharp,'' Yam was quoted as saying. ``The second quarter will be quite bad ... we will have to wait until the second half of the year (for a recovery).''

BC-Thailand-Helicopter Crash
Air current blamed for helicopter crash that killed queen's aide
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ An investigation into the crash of a brand-new helicopter last year that killed 14 people, including the private secretary of Queen Sirikit, has been blamed an air current that caused loss of control. The government's Public Relations Department disclosed the air force investigation results in its weekly news bulletin and noted that the air force had since revised safety procedures. The report said a down draft created a vacuum that caused the Super Puma helicopter to lose control and crash Sept. 19 in southern Thailand after the royal delegation left a development project. The queen was aboard another helicopter that had taken off minutes earlier. The accident set off a minor furor in Thailand due to the danger presented to the revered royal family. Pilots have now been instructed not to fly in low visibility areas and to take extra precautions when flying at low altitude in mountainous terrain.

BC-Bougainville
Papua New Guinea agrees to withdraw troops from Bougainville
PORT MORESBY, Papua New Guinea (AP) _ Papua New Guinea's government has agreed to withdraw its troops from central Bougainville in a show of good faith to rebel fighters on the Pacific island. Key rebel negotiators had demanded the troops' withdrawal prior to signing a cease-fire agreement on April 30 to end the 10-year secessionist conflict. Prime Minister Bill Skate said Tuesday night it was the most significant ``on the ground development'' in the current peace process. Under the cease-fire agreement, the troops would withdraw from Bougainville on the condition that a civilian police force was gradually installed to replace them. Skate said the rebels must also give an assurance that they would withdraw their fighters from the central island area around Arawa and not take advantage of the situation. ``As the cease-fire agreement makes quite plain, any decision to change the status of Arawa would require recognition by all parties, the government looks forward to receiving the required assurances without delay,'' Skate said in a statement. He said 35 Bougainvillean cadets had already graduated from auxiliary police training. Arawa is located near the giant Panguna copper mine majority owned by Anglo-Australian company Rio Tinto, which is blamed for triggering the conflict a decade ago. Land owner and royalty disputes arising from the mine escalated into a full scale war for independence from Papua New Guinea. Up to 20,000 people are thought to have died on the copper-rich island, the largest in the Solomon Islands archipelago and 800 miles (1,300 km) northeast of Papua New Guinea's capital, Port Moresby. Despite the current peace process on the island, the rebels' political leader, Francis Ona, is opposed to the cease-fire and the presence of a 300-strong Australian-led peace monitoring group on the island. Ona is still entrenched in his rebel stronghold at Guava village near the mine, but his support is estimated to now number only a few hundred. A leaders' meeting is planned for later this month between the Papua New Guinea government and the rebels where the critical issue of independence for Bougainville will be formally addressed for the first time.

BC-Philippines-Trade
Philippine export growth slows in April
MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ Philippine export growth slowed in April, dropping to 10 percent on an annual basis from 24 percent in March, the government said Wednesday. Previously, the Philippines had been able to avoid the export growth slowdown that has plagued much of Asia since the currency crisis struck last July. On a month-to-month basis, exports actually fell 7.3 percent in April to dlrs 2.29 billion from dlrs 2.47 billion in March, the National Statistics Office said. Exports in April 1997 totaled dlrs 2.08 billion. Electronics and components continued to dominate Philippine exports, accounting for 53 percent of total shipments. Garments, which continue to face stiff competition from other countries with lower production costs, were next, followed by computer parts. From January to April, the country posted a 20 percent growth in exports to dlrs 9.10 billion from the year-earlier dlrs 7.59 billion. The United States was the top market for Philippine exports, purchasing dlrs 780.7 million worth of goods in April and accounting for 34 percent of total exports. Japan was second, cornering some dlrs 323.6 million worth of goods, or 14 percent. Imports are announced separately by the government each month. The country's trade deficit narrowed to dlrs 140 million in March from dlrs 934 million a year earlier, largely because of a continuing decline in imports. The weaker peso, which has fallen about 32 percent against the dollar since last July, has made imported goods more expensive.

BC-Sports-Baseball-NL Roundup, 1st Add,0492
MILWAUKEE: hitless inning. Diamondbacks 9, Rockies 3
At Denver, David Dellucci went 4-for-4 and had three RBIs, and Matt Williams and Karim Garcia each homered as the Arizona Diamondbacks drubbed the Colorado Rockies. Brian Anderson (3-6) went six innings, limiting Colorado to three runs on five hits, including homers by Neifi Perez and Vinny Castilla. Anderson's win dropped Colorado's record against left-handed starters to 3-14 this season. Russ Springer pitched two hitless innings and Felix Rodriguez pitched a hitless ninth as Arizona's relievers combined with Anderson to hold Colorado without a hit after the third inning. Garcia and Travis Lee each had two RBIs for Arizona. Cardinals 7, Dodgers 4 At Los Angeles, Brian Jordan hit a two-out, three-run homer off reliever Jim Bruske in the eighth inning, giving the St. Louis Cardinals a victory over the Dodgers. The Cardinals, who snapped a three-game losing streak, played without slugger Mark McGwire, who leads the majors with 27 home runs. McGwire is expected to sit out the three-game series at Dodger Stadium because of lower back spasms he suffered Monday night in San Diego. Willie McGee, pinch hitting for winning pitcher Kent Mercker, started the winning rally with a one-out single off loser Darren Dreifort. After Ron Gant struck out, Delino DeShields drew a walk, prompting Dodgers manager Bill Russell to make a pitching change. Jordan then hit a 1-1 pitch into the left-field seats for his ninth homer, giving the Cardinals seven straight runs. Giants 4, Reds 2 At San Francisco, Darryl Hamilton hit his first homer of the season and Danny Darwin pitched 6 2-3 strong innings as the Giants won their fifth straight game. Darwin (5-3) settled down after giving up a two-run homer to Eddie Taubensee in the first, holding the Reds scoreless on two hits over the next 5 2-3 innings. He gave up a total of four hits, struck out three and didn't walk a batter. Robb Nen, the last of four San Francisco pitchers, worked the ninth for his 15th save in 16 chances. The Giants pulled within 1 1/2 games of first-place San Diego, the closest they've been since April 8. Astros 4, Padres 3 At San Diego, Tony Eusebio hit a two-run single in the seventh inning when Padres relievers were hurt by walks, and the Houston Astros rallied to beat San Diego 4-3. Shane Reynolds (6-3) gave up three runs and eight hits in eight innings. Billy Wagner pitched the ninth for his 15th save as he and Reynolds combined to retire the final 13 batters. Reynolds, 4-0 in his last five starts, has allowed only nine earned runs in 38 2-3 innings. Trailing 3-1 in the seventh, Padres reliever Carlos Reyes (2-2) loaded the bases on a single and two walks. Brian Boehringer came on and struck out Tim Bogar before walking Carl Everett to force in a run.

BC-Australia-Uranium Mine
New uranium mine edges closer to construction
By ROHAN SULLIVAN Associated Press Writer
SYDNEY, Australia (AP) _ The opening of Australia's first new uranium mine in a decade continues to inch closer, despite the latest vow Wednesday by Aboriginal landowners to block the development. Energy Resources of Australia Ltd. said it expects to begin digging at the remote Jabiluka mining lease in the Northern Territory this month, after the territorial government on Tuesday signed authorizations allowing work to begin on the mine's entrance and shaft. But the company may be left with nothing but a hole in the ground, as it goes ahead without having formal approvals to either build a processing plant or to truck ore to an established mill at its nearby Ranger mine. ERA has been forced to consider building a second mill just 13 miles (22 km) from Ranger by Aboriginal landowners' refusal to accept its preferred option, to transport the ore. The owners of the Jabiluka lease oppose the mine, claiming it will cause environmental and indirect cultural damage. But they are bound by a 1983 contract approving the mill-on-site option. Representatives of the Mirrar Aboriginal clan said Wednesday they will seek a court order blocking the territorial government's approval until an environmental approval process for the on-site mill plan is completed. ``We believe the minister cannot make a thorough decision without considering the environmental assessment for the milling option,'' spokeswoman Jacqui Katona told Australian Broadcasting Corp. radio. A similar injunction was last week lifted by the territory's Supreme Court. Philip Shirvington, chief executive of ERA, a subsidiary of North Ltd., said there was only a ``small risk'' the company will not receive the remaining environmental approvals. ERA has identified more than 90,000 (metric) tons of uranium oxide at Jabiluka, one of the largest untapped high-grade uranium ore bodies in the world. The mine will add U.S. dlrs 3.7 billion (Australian dollars 6.2 billion) to Australia's gross domestic product over an about 30-year mine life, it says. Australia has about 30 percent of the world's recoverable uranium reserves, but has only about 14 percent of the world market. For more than a decade until 1996, government policy prevented the opening of new uranium mines. Currently there are only two, ERA's Ranger and Western Mining Corp. Ltd.'s Olympic Dam. ERA's success at Jabiluka is considered a litmus test for at least a dozen other potential uranium mine projects in Australia.

BC-Thailand-Polluted Schools
Children at risk from pollution at 1,153 primary schools
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ At least 1,153 primary schools scattered across Thailand are located in polluted areas and many of their students and teachers risk lung ailments, a survey said. The Bangkok Post newspaper Wednesday reported the results of the survey by the government's primary education commission, which showed that hundreds of schools are blanketed by dust from roads, quarries, mines, mills and factories. Hundreds more endure stench and noise emitted by factories and 25 are exposed to smoke from burning wood and rubbish. Teachers and pupils at various schools suffer lung problems ranging from shortness of breath to increased likelihood of tuberculosis. Thailand has industrialized rapidly over the past two decades and factories and construction sites have sprouted up around schools with few safeguards. In one heavily industrialized coastal area last year, primary school students were forced to wear gas masks.

Report: Father arrested for beating stepson
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia (AP) _ Police have arrested a trucker who whipped his 4-year-old stepson with a belt and an electric cable because the boy threw a tantrum over dinner, newspapers reported Wednesday. The boy was admitted to a hospital in the northern Malaysian town of Butterworth with bloody bruises and welts on his back and other parts of the body, the Sun daily said. Police arrived at the house on Monday night after neighbors, alarmed by the boy's screams, called them. The boy's mother told police that her husband lost his temper after the boy started to throw his food. The 36-year-old trucker could face up to five years in jail and a fine of 10,000 ringgit (dlrs 2,560) if convicted of child abuse under Malaysia's Child Protection Act. Police said they were investigating whether three other children in the household, including a five-month-old baby, were also abused by the man.

BC-Indonesia-Habibie Interview, 1st Ld-Writethru
Habibie: Concentrate on the future, not past abuses long he may remain in power, that Suharto is ignoring him.
Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Habibie telling New York Times how
JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ President B.J. Habibie says cash-strapped Indonesians should not try to take back the wealth of former leader Suharto, but instead concentrate on the new government's economic and political reforms. ``My role here is to bring in the shortest time possible the economy back and to improve the democracy,'' Habibie said in an interview that CNN broadcast Wednesday, adding that the sweeping changes must be made in accordance with the constitution. In a separate interview with The New York Times, Habibie said his proposal for parliamentary elections next year could leave him in power until at least 2000. The Times interview also said Suharto appears to have turned his back on Habibie, who replaced him last month. Suharto, who ruled for 32 years, refused to meet Habibie before stepping down and has not communicated with him since the handover, he said. Critics have accused Suharto of allowing his family to amass fortunes and to build massive business empires through nepotism and corruption. The government this week launched a broad probe into state corruption, but many want a specific investigation into Suharto's wealth, estimated at between dlrs 20 billion and 40 billion. Some want that money to be taken back by the state so it can use it to help fix the country's worst economic crisis in decades. The Times quoted Habibie as saying Indonesians should not indulge in ``Wild West'' justice by trying to seize the former president's assets. Habibie defended his own family's wealth, saying its members are highly educated and talented, and earned their money fairly. Habibie, 61, has known Suharto since boyhood and was a Suharto Cabinet minister for 20 years. Despite this close links to the old government, Habibie said he had no problems bringing in reforms. In the CNN interview, Habibie urged Indonesians to look forward, not back toward past corruption and military abuses. ``You have unlimited problems in the past. Where are you going to stop? Five years ago, 10 years, 20 years, 30 years, 40 years?'' he asked. ``The future is almost unlimited. ... So I think it is not worthwhile to dip into the past. I have to look to the future and create a better life...for the people.'' Habibie, who took power when Suharto resigned following riots and protests last month, declined to say whether he would run for re-election after parliamentary elections are held next year. He said most of Indonesia's 202 million people are suffering badly from an inflation rate of more than 50 percent and soaring unemployment. He said that many don't care who is the president but instead worry about ``their rice bowls, their homes, to live in peace, the future for their children.'' Habibie, a civilian and Suharto's friend and former deputy, was confident the powerful military, which played a key role in Suharto's departure during the unrest, would maintain its support for him as it ``always follows the constitution.'' Already he has promised the election and freed some political prisoners. He likened his newfound role as a reformer to that of leaders Boris Yeltsin in Russia and Zhu Rongji of China who brought sweeping reforms to their countries despite being part of old authoritarian regimes. Habibie said he had no option but to reform Indonesia's battered economy while introducing sweeping political change, saying both were interlinked. He estimated that the current Parliament will have drafted new electoral laws by August and that these would be enacted four months later. He said a new session of the People's Consultative Assembly, made up of lawmakers and government appointees, would then set a date for the election. After the ballot, the assembly could then choose a new president. At least 500 people and thousands of buildings and homes were damaged during riots in May. But despite simmering discontent over the economic crisis, Habibie played down the possibility of further violence on the streets. He said Indonesians wanted reform but not on the basis of ``destroying everything they have built in 30 years.'' He described the International Monetary Fund, which is now revamping a dlrs 43 billion economic bailout package for Indonesia, as playing an important and supportive role. He also praised a team of economic ministers in his Cabinet, saying: ``They are the best sons and daughters of the country.'' One issue that Habibie indicated would change was the fate of East Timor, the former Portuguese territory invaded by Suharto troops in 1975 and annexed a year later. Habibie said East Timor must remain an integral part of Indonesia.

BC-Thailand-Economy
Baht rises; Thailand to move slowly on selling bank licenses
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ The Thai currency regained some lost ground Wednesday due to a hike in short-term interest rates, while the central bank announced that it will move slowly on selling the licenses of four seized commercial banks. The Bank of Thailand increased short-term interest rates through the bond repurchase market Tuesday in a bid to stabilize the baht, which had weakened from about 39 to the U.S. dollar last week to close Tuesday at 42.05, its lowest level in 12 weeks. The baht strengthened to 41.70 in early trading Wednesday, but the rate hikes sent the Stock Exchange of Thailand index down 2.13 points to 311.51. Thai firms struggling to survive the current economic crisis are desperate for lower rates. The crisis-stricken financial sector, plagued by bad loans, has been reluctant to lend fresh money to businesses. Earlier this year, the government seized four small commercial banks deemed to be too ridden with debt to continue operations. Chatu Mongkol Sonakul, the bank governor, said Tuesday that only one of the licenses from the seized banks will be sold this year in an effort to ensure the government receives a fair price. The other three licenses will be sold over the next three years. The U.S. investment bank J.P. Morgan Inc. is advising the Bank of Thailand on how to handle the banks' assets. It is scheduled to submit a proposal to the central bank later this month.

Indonesia's military chief wants end to condemnation of Suharto With Indonesia-Habibie Interview
AP Photos staffing By CHRISTOPHER TORCHIA Associated Press Writer
JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Student protesters shouted ``Hang Suharto'' outside Parliament on Wednesday as Indonesia's military chief appealed for a halt to ``out of control'' condemnation of the ousted president. Suharto, a former army general who turns 77 this month, faces growing demands that he surrender riches accumulated during three decades in power. In a television interview, new President B.J. Habibie urged Indonesians not to dwell on the country's corrupt past and to focus on economic recovery. With the economy expected to shrink by at least 10 percent this year, the task is a daunting one. Student protesters who helped dislodge Suharto accuse him of deepening Indonesia's financial crisis by exploiting state wealth. The authoritarian leader quit May 21 amid campus demonstrations and riots over price increases. About 2,000 banner-waving students rallied outside Parliament on Wednesday, demanding that Suharto be put on trial for economic crimes. Soldiers with rifles kept an eye on the crowd from inside the gates. Chanting ``Reject Habibie,'' the protesters scoffed at their new president's pledge to hold general elections in 1999, saying he was a corrupt lackey of Suharto and should step aside. A close ally of Suharto for decades, Habibie is bowing to popular demands for democratic reform. Gen. Wiranto, the armed forces chief, said the nation of 202 million people should pardon Suharto because he boosted economic growth and averted chaos by relinquishing power. ``Lately, condemnation and harassment against the former president and his family have been exaggerated and, in some cases, have gotten out of control,'' said Wiranto, a former personal aide to Suharto. ``The armed forces will take necessary measures to stop it,'' Wiranto said without elaborating. The military is the most powerful institution in Indonesia, which is beset by uncertainty about its political future. It is doubtful that Habibie, who has a shaky power base, would make any policy decisions without the backing of Wiranto. In an interview with Cable News Network that was broadcast Wednesday, Habibie argued against a painful investigation of misdeeds that could divide the nation. ``You have unlimited problems in the past. Where are you going to stop?'' Habibie said. ``So I think it is not worthwhile to dip into the past. I have to look to the future and create a better life ... for the people.'' In a separate interview with the New York Times, Habibie said Indonesians should not indulge in ``Wild West'' justice against the former leader. State prosecutors have launched an inquiry into corruption under the old government, including complaints that Suharto's family abused its influence to build huge business empires. However, critics doubt they will aggressively pursue the former president. Earlier this week, opposition leader Megawati Sukarnoputri urged people to stop denouncing Suharto, who rose to power in the 1960s by edging aside her father, Indonesia's founding President Sukarno. Still, sentiment against Suharto was strong among about 200 supporters of Megawati who joined students outside Parliament to demand government action to help the poor. ``Everybody knows he's corrupt so the case must be processed legally,'' said protester Daulat Sidautar. ``It will give an example for the future of Indonesia.''

BC-Bosnia-War Crimes,0305
Bosnian Serb suspect pleads innocent to war crimes charges
AP Photos DHG101,102 By JENIFER CHAO Associated Press Writer
THE HAGUE, Netherlands (AP) _ An alleged Bosnian Serb prison chief has pleaded innocent to charges of war crimes against Muslims and Croats at a notorious detention camp. The Yugoslav war crimes tribunal charged Milojica Kos with 11 counts of war crimes and crimes against humanity for alleged atrocities at the Omarska prison camp in northwestern Bosnia. Kos, 35, faces up to a life sentence if convicted. The U.N. court did not immediately set a trial date. Asked by judges if he had anything to tell them, Kos responded Tuesday: ``I have faith in justice and God, nothing more.'' Kos' indictment alleges he was a shift commander at Omarska, overseeing camp guards who ``regularly and openly killed, raped, tortured and beat'' prisoners. Kos and other camp leaders ``knew or had reason to know'' that their underlings were committing these crimes and failed to stop them or punish the perpetrators, the indictment said. Omarska was a makeshift prison camp established after Serb forces took control of the Prijedor district of northwestern Bosnia in May 1992. About 3,000 Muslims and Croats were rounded up and taken to the camp. Three other suspects linked to atrocities at Omarska _ Miroslav Kvocka, Mladen Radic and Zoran Zigic _ are already in tribunal custody in The Hague and awaiting trial. Kos was arrested by NATO-led forces last week in the northwestern Bosnian town of Banja Luka. He is the 27th suspect in custody out of 74 publicly indicted by the court. The tribunal's two most-wanted suspects, former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and his wartime military chief, Gen. Ratko Mladic, remain free.

BC-Taiwan-Virus
Virus claims 26th victim, schools closed in control effort
By CHRISTOPHER BODEEN Associated Press Writer
TAIPEI, Taiwan (AP) _ A virus that attacks small children particularly hard claimed its 26th victim on Wednesday, and officials closed some nursery schools and kindergartens in central Taiwan in an effort to control it. Enterovirus 71 hits Taiwan each summer. Although there are no firm numbers with which to compare, the Health Department said this year's outbreak appears to be particularly severe. It said almost 7,500 cases had been reported, but the outbreak appears to have peaked, and that the number of new cases should start dropping. A 6-month-old boy in central Taichung city died Wednesday morning, local health officials said. He was the 26th fatality. Another 122 infants and small children have been hospitalized for complications from the virus. In one hospital alone, Changhua Christian Hospital in the central city of Changhua, nine children have died since mid-May. Complications from the virus, spread by physical contact, can include encephalitis, meningitis, and acute inflammation of the heart muscle. Early symptoms are similar to the flu, including fever, headache and vomiting. Later, ulcers or blisters in the mouth and a rash on the hands and feet can develop. Anxious parents flooded a hotline set up by the Health Department's communicative diseases department, seeking advice on treatment for their children. Nursery schools in parts of Changhua and Tainan counties were ordered closed for a week, and nursery schools and kindergartens in other parts of central Taiwan were being given the option of recessing. Parents were being advised to avoid taking small children out in public, and urged to be sure children washed their hands frequently and had clean changes of clothing. The virus has struck hardest in central Taiwan, where the warm, wet climate is considered most conducive to its spread.

BC-Thailand-Hitler Potato Chips
Hitler potato chip ads will be withdrawn, Israel says
By PATRICK McDOWELL Associated Press Writer
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ Israeli diplomats said Wednesday that an advertising agency has agreed to immediately stop airing commercials using images of Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler to sell potato chips. Avi Nil, charge d'affaires of the Israeli Embassy, praised the Thai office of the Chicago-based Leo Burnett agency for killing the ads once they became aware of how offensive they were. ``We're happy with this action,'' Nil said. ``If they had realized the real meaning to people like us and other victims of the Nazis, they would never have started in the first place.'' Nil said that he had received verbal and written assurances from Leo Burnett Bangkok confirming that commercials featuring Hitler would be pulled off Thai television immediately. Removing similar placards from thousands of three-wheeled motorized taxis plying Bangkok's streets was expected to take until Sunday due to technical reasons, Nil said. ``We have achieved our goal, the case is closed,'' Nil said. ``The vigorous response shows there was really no bad intention.'' Leo Burnett representatives were not immediately available for comment. Israeli officials viewed the ads as morally unacceptable, saying Hitler should not be used as a means to make money. Hitler unleashed World War II in Europe and killed millions of people, including 6 million Jews, he considered subhuman, the worst genocide the world has ever seen. The commercial for X potato chips, targeted at Thai teen-agers, depicts Hitler giving a Nazi salute and cuts to a woman who casts a spell on him as he eats the chips, hoping to change his evil ways. A Nazi swastika turns into the product logo as the transformation is completed. Leo Burnett said the ads, shown only in Thailand, were meant to show the world would be a better place if happiness prevailed. The chips are made by Food Processing Co. Ltd., a Thai firm. Leo Burnett Bangkok apologized for the ads Sunday and had been discussing the campaign with its client for the past few days. Nil has said the controversy should raise awareness about Hitler among Thais. Consciousness about the Nazis is somewhat less in Asia, where their armies did not reach, than in the West. Thailand has in the past expressed outrage over the use of people dressed as Buddhist monks in advertisements. Buddhism is the country's dominant religions and monks are generally revered.

Dollar edges lower, stocks fall in Tokyo
Eds: UPDATES with closing stock, mid-afternoon currency, bond; ADDS trader comment in 12th graf, byline By MARTIN FACKLER Associated Press Writer
TOKYO (AP) _ The U.S. dollar edged lower against the yen Wednesday amid speculation about possible intervention by world central banks to prop up the Japanese currency. Tokyo stocks fell. The dollar bought 138.41 yen in mid-afternoon trading, down 0.84 yen from late Tuesday in Tokyo and below its late New York level of 138.83 yen overnight. The benchmark 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average shed 207.45 points, or 1.33 percent, to close at 15,347.00. On Tuesday, the index gained 233.42 points, or 1.52 percent. The dollar slipped as traders speculated that the Group of Seven major industrialized nations will jointly intervene to help stem the slide of the yen. On Monday, the Japanese currency reached a seven-year low against the dollar as pessimism about the outlook for Japan's economy prompted investors to shift funds out of yen and into the U.S. currency. U.S. Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin stoked speculation about joint intervention Tuesday when he confirmed that there will be a G-7 meeting ``sometime early next week.'' Rubin also told reporters that Washington shares Tokyo's concern over the yen's weakness. Pessimism about Japan's economy also drove down Tokyo stock prices. The decline by the benchmark index wiped out most of the previous day's gains. One reason for the lack of buyers: Government money that had boosted stock prices the day before wasn't there Wednesday, traders said. Japan has used government-controlled pension savings recently in brazen efforts to keep the Nikkei 225 above the psychologically important 15,000-point level. ``There was a price-keeping operation Tuesday. Today, it has completely stopped,'' said Sachio Ishikawa, a managing director at Chuo Securities Co. Investors were also discouraged by an overnight fall on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average tumbled 31.13 points, or 0.35 percent, to 8,891.24. The broader Tokyo Stock Price Index of all issues listed on the first section was down 7.64 points, or 0.63 percent, to 1,205.33. The TOPIX rose 16.27 points, or 1.36 percent on Tuesday. The benchmark No. 182 10-year Japanese government bond edged up to 1.140 percent from Tuesday's finish of 1.130 percent. Its price fell to 112.51 yen from 112.59 yen. (mef-kgo-km-dj)

Central bank employee sues former branch manager over sexual harassment
TOKYO (AP) _ A 28-year-old employee of the Kyoto branch of Japan's central bank has sued her former boss over alleged sexual harassment, seeking compensation and an apology, a court official said Wednesday. In the suit filed Tuesday with a local court, the woman is seeking a total of 21 million yen (dlrs 152,000) in damages from both the former branch manager and the central bank. A spokesman for the Bank of Japan in Tokyo said the bank could not comment on the suit because a written complaint had yet to be made available. He spoke on condition of anonymity. The 51-year-old branch manager resigned voluntarily from the bank at the end of March, this year, without mentioning specific reasons, the spokesman said. The official at the Kyoto District Court, where the suit was filed, said the names of the defendant and the plaintiff could not be made public at present. He also spoke on condition of anonymity. In the suit, the woman says that she was sexually harassed by the former manager at a private nightclub in Kyoto on the night of Nov. 19 after she was invited there by him to ``try to establish better mutual understanding'' on the job, the Yomiuri newspaper said. The former manager kissed her and touched her against her will at the club, the report said. The paper also said he had repeatedly tried to lure her out for meals, despite being turned down at the central bank branch in Kyoto, 374 kilometers (234 miles), southwest of Tokyo. Sexual harassment is a fairly new concept in largely male-dominated Japan, where such conduct was largely tolerated until recent years. The nation's first sexual harassment lawsuit wasn't filed until 1992. Last year, Japan's Parliament adopted a law that requires corporations to take steps to prevent sexual harassment. Last month, a court in western Japan fined a male university professor 1.7 million yen (dlrs 12,300) for sexually harassing a woman student. (km)

BC-Australia-Asia-Economy Forecast
Economists see some joy for East Asia in 1999
SYDNEY, Australia (AP) _ It may be a gloomy year for Asia but a recovery, or at least a stabilization, is in sight, according to the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council and The Asia Foundation. In a report entitled ``1998-1999 Pacific Economic Outlook'' the PECC panel of economists looked at the growth forecasts of 20 East Asian, North American and Latin American economies. At a regional video link-up Wednesday, three of the economists indicated they expected a moderate recovery for the Asia Pacific region in 1999. The report forecasts an average growth in GDP of only 2.6 percent for the Asia Pacific region in 1998, down nearly 2 percentage points from 1997. However, it said there was a strong chance that ``the Asia-Pacific region would achieve relative financial stability in the second half of 1998, and the real economy will begin to recover by the end of 1998 or beginning of 1999.'' ``If that is the case then 1999 could be a recovery year, with real GDP growth for the region advancing to 3.5 percent,'' said project coordinator Professor Lawrence Krause. The panel attributed much of the hoped-for turnaround to the success of the latest stimulus package from Japan's government and expected that while that country will have a growth rate around zero this year it should be up and running near 2.5 percent in 1999. ``The Japanese will take steps to accelerate their economy,'' said Dr. Saul Hymans, professor of economics at the University of Michigan. He noted that it was crucial that the fiscal expansion included new measures of tax cuts and expenditures. ``There is evidence of real fiscal expansion in Japan,'' he said. Dr. Steve Parker, chief economist with The Asia Foundation, said a recovery in 1999 with Japan's growth running at 2.5 percent was predicated on successful fiscal stimulus. He said other nations in the region would have a hard, slow battle back from the brink. Nevertheless, he noted positive signs in South Korea and expected that its economy would bottom this year. There was cause for optimism as export volumes were heading higher and the current account was expanding, he said. The basket case in the region remained Indonesia, due primarily to social unrest and political instability. Along with Indonesia and Japan, Thailand and South Korea are also expected to sustain zero growth rates this year. However, with the exception of Indonesia, they are expected to recover next year.

BC-Pakistan-Economy,0372
Pakistan looks to austerity to offset threatened sanctions
By KATHY GANNON Associated Press Writer
ISLAMABAD, Pakistan (AP) _ Pakistan ordered new austerity measures Wednesday, moving fast to protect its fragile economy from economic sanctions threatened in response to its decision to test six nuclear devices. In a Cabinet meeting a day earlier, the government sought to find ways to minimize the impact of sanctions, most notably from the United States and Japan. The government plans to cut spending overall by 50 percent, but the details will be worked out over the next 24 hours, said the independent daily newspaper, The News. ``Specific measures with respect to austerity and efficiency in missions abroad have also been approved,'' said an official announcement following the Cabinet meeting. Immediately after Pakistan tested its sixth nuclear device on Saturday, President Rafiq Tarar used his constitutional authority to declare a state of emergency and freeze all foreign currency accounts. Accounts were frozen because the government feared a panic withdrawal would devour its foreign exchange reserves, currently about dlrs 1.3 billion. Finance Minister Sartaz Aziz said the government has a three-pronged plan to counter sanctions _ increase exports, decrease imports and conserve revenues. Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif is to address the nation on Thursday to provide the details of his austerity program. He also is expected to make another strong pitch for restraint and belt tightening, something he did in his speech to the nation last week following Pakistan's first round of nuclear testing. In Tuesday's Cabinet meeting, the government decided to reduce imports of such items as tea, cooking oil and milk _ all staples in the Pakistani diet. In its first show of restraint, the government moved out of the palatial 400-room Prime minister's secretariat. The move is meant to give the impression that the government is leaving behind extravagance and embracing moderation. Analysts expect sanctions will hurt the poorest in this country of 140 million people with a per capital annual income of just less than dlrs 400.

BC-Indonesia, 1st Ld-Writethru
Indonesia's military chief wants end to condemnation of Suharto in Jakarta riots, more than double previous estimate, grafs 5-6; With Indonesia-Habibie Interview
Eds: UPDATES with human rights commission saying 1,188 people died soldiers closing off road at Parliament protest, graf 7 AP Photos staffing By CHRISTOPHER TORCHIA Associated Press Writer
JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Student protesters shouted ``Hang Suharto'' outside Parliament on Wednesday as Indonesia's military chief appealed for a halt to ``out of control'' condemnation of the ousted president. Suharto, a former army general who turns 77 next Monday, faces growing demands that he surrender riches accumulated during three decades in power. In a television interview, new President B.J. Habibie urged Indonesians not to dwell on the country's corrupt past and to focus on economic recovery. With the economy expected to shrink by at least 10 percent this year, the task is a daunting one. Student protesters who helped dislodge Suharto accuse him of deepening Indonesia's financial crisis by exploiting state wealth. The authoritarian leader quit May 21 amid campus demonstrations and riots over price increases. A government commission, meanwhile, said the death toll over several days of riots in Jakarta in mid-May was 1,188, more than double an estimate by the military. Many victims were looters trapped in buildings set afire by arsonists. In a report released Wednesday, the National Commission on Human Rights also criticized the armed forces for failing to take prompt action to prevent rioting. About 2,000 banner-waving students rallied in a major highway outside Parliament, demanding that Suharto be put on trial for economic crimes. Soldiers closed off the road. Chanting ``Reject Habibie,'' the protesters scoffed at their new president's pledge to hold general elections in 1999, saying he was a corrupt lackey of Suharto and should step aside. A close ally of Suharto for decades, Habibie is bowing to popular demands for democratic reform. Gen. Wiranto, the armed forces chief, said the nation of 202 million people should pardon Suharto because he boosted economic growth and averted chaos by relinquishing power. ``Lately, condemnation and harassment against the former president and his family have been exaggerated and, in some cases, have gotten out of control,'' said Wiranto, a former personal aide to Suharto. ``The armed forces will take necessary measures to stop it,'' Wiranto said without elaborating. The military is the most powerful institution in Indonesia, which is beset by uncertainty about its political future. It is doubtful that Habibie, who has a shaky power base, would make any policy decisions without the backing of Wiranto. In an interview with Cable News Network that was broadcast Wednesday, Habibie argued against a painful investigation of misdeeds that could divide the nation. ``You have unlimited problems in the past. Where are you going to stop?'' Habibie said. ``So I think it is not worthwhile to dip into the past. I have to look to the future and create a better life ... for the people.'' In a separate interview with the New York Times, Habibie said Indonesians should not indulge in ``Wild West'' justice against the former leader. State prosecutors have launched an inquiry into corruption under the old government, including complaints that Suharto's family abused its influence to build huge business empires. However, critics doubt they will aggressively pursue the former president. Philippine government lawyer urges reversal of Imelda Marcos graft conviction
MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ The government's chief lawyer said Wednesday he has asked the Supreme Court to reverse a 1993 graft conviction of former first lady Imelda Marcos and spare her from a possible 12-year jail term. The surprise turnaround is a potential victory for the widow of the late Philippine strongman Ferdinand Marcos, but there was no indication how the court will treat the recommendation. In the past, the court has rarely reversed a decision it has upheld. Solicitor General Romeo de la Cruz said he became convinced there was no strong evidence proving Mrs. Marcos was guilty of the graft charge after a review of the case. The case is the only one in which Mrs. Marcos, 68, has been convicted of graft, although she faces numerous other criminal and civil cases related to the 20-year rule of her husband. She and her husband have been accused of stealing billions of dollars during his presidency. They were ousted in a 1986 ``people power'' revolt and Marcos died three years later in exile in Hawaii. Mrs. Marcos was convicted of having granted leases on government-owned land at improperly low rates to the Philippine General Hospital Foundation, which she headed. The land was then sublet to another company at much higher rates. De la Cruz said there was no evidence proving that the land was leased at improperly low rates, except that it had been later sublet at a higher amount. He said they also found that the land lease deals were entered into by former transportation chief Jose Dans, Mrs. Marcos' co-defendant in the case, who was earlier acquitted by the Supreme Court. Mrs. Marcos _ who insists she did not personally benefit from the deal _ said the money gained from the leases helped finance construction of the Philippine Heart Center. Prosecutors did not challenge this, but maintained that the foundation should have been charged more. A five-judge Supreme Court panel upheld her conviction in January, but ruled that she could appeal one more time to the entire court before going to prison. It sentenced her to nine to 12 years in prison and ordered her to pay 189 million pesos (dlrs 4.9 million) in damages to the government. She appealed in February and the court asked de la Cruz's office to provide an opinion on her appeal. The Supreme Court has up to two years to decide the appeal. President-elect Joseph Estrada has indicated he may pardon Mrs. Marcos if the conviction is upheld.

With BC-Indonesia; BC-Indonesia-Habibie Interview By ALI KOTARUMALOS Associated Press Writer
JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Indonesia's main human rights watchdog Monday said at least 1,188 people died in rioting that led to the resignation of autocratic President Suharto last month. The figure is more than twice as high as official estimates made by the military, which the National Human Rights Commission, or Komnasham, accused of doing too little, too late to quell the violence and save lives. ``Komnasham has received quantitative reports that there was an excessive material loss because of the riotings, including ... the killings of 1,188 people and 101 injuries along with some cases of rape,'' the commission said in a report. It said 40 shopping centers, 2,479 shop-houses and 1,604 shops were attacked, burned or looted, along with 1,119 automobiles, 1,026 private homes and 383 offices. The commission did not provide a breakdown of the death toll, but said it was based on reports in Jakarta and other parts of the country from May 12-25. It noted that security forces had failed to anticipate signs that rioting would erupt. Moreover, when the violence started ``there were no signs of serious efforts by the security forces to prevent the spread of the rioting.'' The 25-member commission urged the government of new President B.J. Habibie to ``thoroughly investigate security apparatus for letting, not preventing or immediately dealing with the riots.'' It also called for an inquiry into allegations that much of the violence had been the work of ``well-organized groups who started the rioting and burnings.'' In a three-page statement, the commission noted that members of the ethnic Chinese community were frequent targets in the unrest. Although Chinese make up only a fraction of Indonesia's 202 million population, they dominate commerce and industry, and have been made into scapegoats for the country's worst economic crisis in three decades. The commission was set up by the Suharto regime but has earned a reputation for independence in its investigation of human rights abuses.

The huge lake is the center of a valuable nature preserve and home to several rare species. The damaged containers leaked 1,700 kilograms (3,400 pounds) of sodium cyanide into the river and some of it reached the lake. Kumtor has also sought to downplay the damage, saying it posed ``no serious threat to people, animals or agriculture.'' However, fish and cattle were killed near the site of the spill and some 600 people have sought medical treatment for poisoning, of whom about 100 have been hospitalized. Farmland has also been contaminated by villagers unaware of the spill who used water from the river on their crops, officials said. (vi/mr)

By JONATHAN DRAKE Associated Press Writer
SINGAPORE (AP) _ Singapore released figures Wednesday showing a dramatic increase in layoffs and unemployment during the current economic slowdown, and predicted harder times ahead. Labor department officials said there was also less work available, while the entire job picture worsened ``significantly in the first quarter of 1998, as impact of the regional economic and currency crisis sank in.'' The report from the Ministry of Manpower, as the labor department is officially called, is the latest sign that the nearly year-old Asian economic turmoil is taking a heavy toll on this usually prosperous city state. The report said layoffs reached a record high for any quarterly figure at 7,131, while the number of job openings dropped to 26,148, 44 percent lower than the same period last year. The ministry added that demand for new workers is likely to fall further and unemployment will rise as local graduates enter the work force in the next few months. The first-quarter job losses equaled 73 percent of all layoffs last year, affecting primarily workers in manufacturing, the sector hardest hit so far. Seasonally adjusted unemployment rose to 2.2 percent at the end of the quarter. A union leader said earlier this week that layoffs in Singapore this year will likely rise to an all-time high as the country edges towards economic doldrums. Lim Boon Heng, chief of the National Trade Union Congress, said the number of workers losing their jobs will probably exceed the peak of 20,000 during the 1985-86 recession. Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong cautioned earlier this week that some private analysts predict unemployment rising to 4 percent by year end. In their bleak outlook for the current quarter, the ministry said expectations were ``less favorable especially in the manufacturing sector,'' with further declines in the electronics, engineering and other manufacturing businesses. Singapore's work force totaled nearly 1.9 million people out of a total population of 3.1 million, according to the latest government statistics for last year.

U.S. alarms industry by demanding drug profits from offshore bank
AP Photo By ROBERT HOFFMAN Associated Press Writer
ST. JOHN'S, Antigua (AP) _ A landmark U.S. lawsuit aimed at forcing an offshore Caribbean bank to surrender millions in drug profits is unnerving a secretive banking industry that thrives on lack of scrutiny and perceived inviolability. The case dates to the 1980s, when two Massachusetts brothers ran a large-scale marijuana business in New England. Once convicted, they fingered their money launderer, who confessed and promised to forfeit dlrs 7 million to the U.S. government. The effort went awry when the man, John E. Fitzgerald of Boston, died before handing over the money. Now the U.S. Justice Department wants a Boston court to order the Antiguan bank where Fitzgerald said he deposited the money to pay up. The case against Swiss American Bank Ltd. and its non-offshore sister Swiss American National Bank of Antigua Ltd. is now being heard. Local critics see the lawsuit as bullying of small island states by Washington, which already had pressured its Caribbean neighbors into allowing U.S. law enforcers to take their war on drugs into their territory. The Antiguan government, feeling both its sovereignty and its prized offshore banking industry threatened, sent a diplomatic protest urging the United States to withdraw the action. Undaunted by the protest, Washington is looking for tougher legislation to close ``loopholes related to foreign banking secrecy laws,'' a U.S. State Department official said. In addition to asset seizure and forfeiture laws, U.S. officials want to use ``foreign-based crimes'' such as fraud against foreign governments to justify U.S. money laundering prosecutions, the official said. For Caribbean offshore bankers, who contribute significantly to the region's economy, it is an unwelcome assault at a time when Britain is pressing them to release secret account information for the drug fight. That, they say, would destroy the industry by scaring away legitimate clients. ``We will not stand by and allow them to kill off our business,'' said Neville Grant, managing director of the Cayman Islands Monetary Authority, which controls about 500 banks and companies, second only to Switzerland as an international banking center. Analysts estimate that up to 10 percent of the $5 trillion held in offshore centers worldwide is laundered money. Some governments voluntarily repatriate drug money to the United States, which shares it with the cooperating government. Antigua, which has been tarred with allegations of drug-related corruption, shut down five offshore Russian banks last year under U.S. pressure. But the government is supporting Swiss American Bank's argument that the United States has no jurisdiction over an Antiguan bank. The dlrs 7 million was promised the U.S. government by Fitzgerald, who pleaded guilty in 1993 to racketeering and money laundering. However, Fitzgerald concealed the true ownership of the money a little too well _ failing to prove his link to the string of shell companies that held it. Complicating matters, the bank now claims that one of its managers, who was authorized by Fitzgerald to manage his account, took dlrs 2 million and disappeared. The remaining money was given to the Antiguan government in 1994 under a law about frozen accounts with no clear owner, the bank said. The United States says the bank had no right to touch Fitzgerald's _ now the U.S. government's _ money. And Washington has a big stick to wield: The offshore bankers depend on U.S. banks to make investments, including treasury bonds.

EDS: LEADS throughout with political parties reaching consensus on By PRISCILLA CHEUNG Associated Press Writer
HONG KONG (AP) _ Major Hong Kong political parties told the government on Wednesday that it wasn't doing enough to stimulate the recession-bound economy, and reached consensus on their own six-point program. The announcements were made after a special meeting of parties that won seats in the new legislature elected a week and a half ago. It included government critics, pro-business parties that generally support the government, and grassroots pro-China parties. Their ability to bridge differences could mean that, despite being controlled by pro-business and pro-China elites, the legislature may give Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa and his government a hard time on economic issues. ``The government is wealthy,'' said Allen Lee, chairman of the pro-business Liberal Party, who chaired the meeting. ``It's the citizens who don't have money.'' Lee said the package aims to boost consumer spending and create a better business environment. While the parties were meeting, Financial Secretary Donald Tsang convened the first government task force to discuss the labor market, review retraining programs, and create more government jobs. Unemployment is officially at a 14-year high of 3.9 percent, although unions say the figure is much higher. It is expected to increase as Hong Kong, which avoided the worst of Asia's economic crisis for nearly a year, settles into a protracted battle with low stock and property prices. The economy contracted 2 percent in the first quarter of the year, and one senior official said late Tuesday that it would likely shrink in the second quarter, too. That technically would put Hong Kong in recession. More than 80 people demonstrated outside the government building where Tsang convened the closed employment meeting, demanding cuts in taxes and government fees to encourage business and employment, Hong Kong Radio reported. After the party roundtable, representatives told reporters that they want the government ``to put money back into people's pockets.'' Their proposals include cuts in public transportation charges and government fees, and more assistance to small- and medium-sized businesses that form the backbone of Hong Kong's economy. They also want a review of a system that requires pre-payment of taxes, and asked the government to return pre-paid taxes. To create more jobs, they say the government should push ahead infrastructure projects and provide more social services. The government also should find ways to hold down interest rates, which have remained high to defend Hong Kong's link to the U.S. dollar, the representatives said. Lee said the parties would back a deficit budget next year if neccessary. ``In a rainstorm, the government should lend the citizens an umbrella,'' Lee said.

APEC draft: Fair, cheap, easy cross-border communications
AP Photos SIN101 By LAURINDA KEYS Associated Press Writer
SINGAPORE (AP) _ Fair and transparent rules that support competition are crucial to opening telecommunications markets, according to the draft declaration prepared for a Pacific Rim ministerial conference that opened Wednesday. Developing countries in Asia and Latin America earn a lot of money from monopoly telephone services and have resisted letting market forces set the prices for cross-border voice and data transmission. They also worry about controlling foreign companies' hookups to national networks of telephone poles and fiber-optic cables. More developed countries say some of these concerns are merely excuses to limit competition. ``Ministers recognize that it is crucial to establish fair and transparent interconnection and access arrangements to support competitive service provision,'' said a draft of ``The Singapore Declaration,'' to be adopted when the meeting ends. While some delegates to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) meeting of telecommunications and information ministers continued to call for flexibility and consensus in setting prices and rules, the draft declaration indicated that they were ready to agree that fair competition benefits users. The draft also calls for an action plan to promote electronic commerce within APEC, and adoption of the first agreement whereby telephone manufacturers can test their products once, and have the certification accepted by importing countries without further charges and delays. The draft declaration, obtained by The Associated Press, directs officials of the 18 APEC countries to create ``a flexible, non-prescriptive framework'' of interconnection arrangements ``that promotes fair and effective competition in the market and delivers benefits to users.'' The 25-member commission urged the government of new President B.J. Habibie to ``thoroughly investigate security apparatus for letting, not preventing or immediately dealing with the riots.'' It also called for an inquiry into allegations that much of the violence had been the work of ``well-organized groups who started the rioting and burnings.'' In a three-page statement, the commission noted that members of the ethnic Chinese community were frequent targets in the unrest. Although Chinese make up only a fraction of Indonesia's 202 million population, they dominate commerce and industry, and have been made into scapegoats for the country's worst economic crisis in three decades. Developing countries in Asia and Latin America earn a lot of money from monopoly telephone services and have resisted letting market forces set the prices for cross-border voice and data transmission. More developed countries say some of these concerns are merely excuses to limit coends. While some delegates to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) meeting of telecommunications and information ministers continued to call for flexibility and consensus in setting prices and rules, the draft declaration indicated that they were ready to agree that fair competition benefits users.
