The draft declaration, obtained by The Associated Press, directs officials of the 18 APEC countries to create ``a flexible, non-prescriptive framework'' of interconnection arrangements ``that promotes fair and effective competition in the market and delivers benefits to users.'' The United States has said it will unilaterally set low prices for international telephone and computer transmissions if there is no global agreement soon. The draft also directs APEC officials to identify price benchmarks and negotiation time frames. The issue involves a foreign or multinational company trying to connect to the communications network in another country to provide new, better or cheaper services than national providers do. ``Enabling interconnection is really about enabling competitors to enter the telecom market,'' said William Kennard, head of the U.S. Federal Communications Commission. The FCC chief had been scheduled to attend the session in Singapore, but canceled because of urgent business in Washington. APEC comprises Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States. Candidate countries that attend the meetings are Peru, Russia and Vietnam.

But no sooner did they hold off Wednesday than prices came tumbling right back down again. ``There was a price-keeping operation Tuesday. Today, it has completely stopped,'' said Sachio Ishikawa, a managing director at Chuo Securities Co. Trading was thinner than average, with an estimated 358 million shares changing hands on the first section. Declining issues outnumbered gainers by more than 2-to-1. On the currency market, the dollar slipped below 138 yen for the first time since May 28. At one point in the afternoon, the dollar traded as low as 137.45 yen, down from an intraday high of 138.94 yen during morning trading. The dollar tumbled as traders speculated that the Group of Seven major industrialized nations may jointly intervene to help stem the Japanese currency's slide. U.S. Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin added to that speculation late Tuesday when he confirmed that there will be a G-7 meeting ``sometime early next week.'' Rubin also told reporters that Washington shares Tokyo's concern over the yen's weakness. On Monday, the yen had hit a seven-year low against the dollar as pessimism about the outlook for Japan's economy prompted investors to shift funds out of yen and into the U.S. currency. Moreover, the ruble has been steady in recent days without major support from Central Bank, which says it has plenty of reserves left to prevent a run on the currency. All together, the Russia's stock market is down about 50 percent from the beginning of the year _ the world's worst performance and a sharp change from the previous year's record growth of 98 percent. The new treasury bills offered Wednesday are designed to raise quick cash so Russia can keep up with payments on its existing debt and reassure investors that it will not default. The government has a serious cash flow problem, largely because it has been unable to create an effective tax collection system. As a result it has borrowed heavily to finance the resulting federal budget deficit. Nonetheless there has been too little cash in the system to pay state workers and pensioners on time, a situation that led to a wave of labor strikes last week. The government has blamed those strikes, combined with lingering nerves over the Asian financial crisis and a drop in world prices for Russia's main exports of oil and gas, for triggering last week's stock collapse. Speculation is growing that Russia will need a rescue package from the International Monetary Fund or its colleagues in the G-8. Deputy finance ministers from the so-called Group of Eight industrialized democracies were to confer on the issue by telephone Wednesday. But Kremlin officials have insisted that they would prefer to fix their problems themselves, by reducing government spending and improving tax collection. Wednesday's auction is the first time Russia has ever offered one-week treasury bills _ an extremely short term. Most Russian treasury bills are for several months or a year, while terms in the West can reach 30 years. While the auction may help Russia's financial health in the short term, analysts say the only long-term solution is to strengthen the entire revenue system, especially tax collection. Russia has no taxpaying tradition and its stiff tax rates have increased incentives for both companies and individuals to evade them. Last year, only 5 million of the nation's 147 million citizens paid taxes. (mr)

Supervisory board proposes new head for central bank
HELSINKI, Finland (AP) _ The Bank of Finland's supervisory council on Wednesday proposed Matti Vanhala as the bank's new governor, to succeed Sirkka Hamalainen who joined the European Central Bank. The supervisory council, which is appointed by Parliament, voted 5-4 in Vanhala's favor. The government is expected to propose Vanhala's appointment for President Martti Ahtisaari's approval Friday. Philippines, Singapore, South Korea and Thailand. Some of these stories also moved earlier today as separates.
Eds: Contains items from Australia, Hong Kong, Japan, the
SEOUL, South Korea (AP) _ A militant labor group said Wednesday it will go ahead with plans for a nationwide strike next week, citing a breakdown in talks with the government aimed at halting growing layoffs. The decision by the maverick Confederation of Korean Trade Unions raised concern that labor unrest may persist in South Korea in the midst of its deepening economic crisis. It also chilled President Kim Dae-jung's hopes of attracting foreign investment during his visit to the United States next week. Kim has stressed the importance of labor peace to his efforts. ``The government is too much uncompromising, especially on layoffs,'' said Chung Sung-hee, a spokesman of the confederation, which claims a membership of 500,000 in car, shipbuilding and other heavy industries. Chung said overnight talks with the government to avert the strike broke down because of what he called the government's unwillingness to accept the confederation's demand for a halt to widespread layoffs. He said the strike, the second in two weeks, will begin on June 10 as scheduled, joined by 130,000 car workers, shipbuilders and office clerks from state-run companies. The group organized a similar two-day strike last week. ___ HONG KONG (AP) _ Major political parties from across Hong Kong's spectrum told the government on Wednesday that it wasn't doing enough to stimulate the recession-bound economy, and reached consensus on their own six-point program. Held only a week and a half after elections, a special meeting included parties that won more than two-thirds of the seats in the new legislature. It included government critics, pro-business parties that generally support the government, and grassroots pro-China parties. Their ability to bridge differences could mean that, despite being controlled by pro-business and pro-China elites, the legislature may give Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa and his government a hard time on economic issues. ``The government is wealthy,'' said Allen Lee, chairman of the pro-business Liberal Party, who chaired the meeting. ``It's the citizens who don't have money.'' ___ SYDNEY, Australia (AP) _ The opening of Australia's first new uranium mine in a decade continues to inch closer, despite the latest vow Wednesday by Aboriginal landowners to block the development. Energy Resources of Australia Ltd. said it expects to begin digging at the remote Jabiluka mining lease in the Northern Territory this month, after the territorial government on Tuesday signed authorizations allowing work to begin on the mine's entrance and shaft. But the company may be left with nothing but a hole in the ground, as it goes ahead without having formal approvals to either build a processing plant or to truck ore to an established mill at its nearby Ranger mine. ERA has been forced to consider building a second mill just 13 miles (22 km) from Ranger by Aboriginal landowners' refusal to accept its preferred option, to transport the ore. The owners of the Jabiluka lease oppose the mine, claiming it will cause environmental and indirect cultural damage. But they are bound by a 1983 contract approving the mill-on-site option. Representatives of the Mirrar Aboriginal clan said Wednesday they will seek a court order blocking the territory government's approval until an environmental approval process for the on-site mill plan is completed. ___ MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ Philippine export growth slowed in April, dropping to 10 percent on an annual basis from 24 percent in March, the government said Wednesday. Previously, the Philippines had been able to avoid the export growth slowdown that has plagued much of Asia since the currency crisis struck last July. On a month-to-month basis, exports actually fell 7.3 percent in April to dlrs 2.29 billion from dlrs 2.47 billion in March, the National Statistics Office said. Exports in April 1997 totaled dlrs 2.08 billion. Electronics and components continued to dominate Philippine exports, accounting for 53 percent of total shipments. Garments, which continue to face stiff competition from other countries with lower production costs, were next, followed by computer parts. ___ SINGAPORE (AP) _ Unhappy with China's pace of developing a jointly owned industrial park and township in Suzhou, the Singapore government has set a five-year deadline to complete transfer of technology and knowhow to Chinese managers, state-run television reported Tuesday. The report did not specify what would happen at the end of the deadline. The decision follows a visit last week to China, led by Deputy Prime Minister Tony Tan, and including some of Singapore's top U.S. business friends and investors in the China-Singapore Suzhou Industrial Park. The announcement on government-run television indicated the Singaporean delegation did not get the cooperation they were expecting from meetings with the Chinese last week. The Chinese had already surprised Singapore and its investors by opening a rival industrial park in the same underpopulated and undeveloped area, and charging lower prices for land. Four years into the project, there are concerns that the park _ 65 percent owned by Singapore and 35 percent by the Chinese _ is not commercially viable. Less than half of the 106 projects are operating, although dlrs 3.2 billion has been invested. ___ BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ An advertising agency Wednesday terminated a TV-and-poster campaign using images of Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler to sell potato chips following protests that the ads were repugnant. Leo Burnett Bangkok, the Thai office of the Chicago-based Leo Burnett agency, issued a statement reiterating apologies over the ads and said they were ``never intended to cause any ill feeling.'' Commercials will be withdrawn from television immediately and the more complicated removal of posters from thousands of tuk-tuks, the three-wheeled motorized taxis plying Bangkok's streets, will be completed by Sunday. Avi Nil, charge d'affaires of the Israeli Embassy, praised the agency for killing the ads once they became aware of how offensive they were. ``We're happy with this action,'' Nil said. ``If they had realized the real meaning to people like us and other victims of the Nazis, they would never have started in the first place.''

BC-Japan-Nuclear Forum
Japan's premier proposes nuclear non-proliferation forum
TOKYO (AP) _ Japan will propose convening an international forum on preventing the spread of nuclear weapons in the wake of recent nuclear tests by India and Pakistan, a Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman said Wednesday. Foreign Minister Keizo Obuchi will formally announce plans for a meeting of experts from around the world on the non-proliferation issue in a speech scheduled for Thursday, the spokesman said. Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto preempted that announcement when he mentioned the proposal early Wednesday while appearing before an upper house of parliament ad hoc committee. Preparations will begin soon on convening the forum later this summer, possibly in the city of Hiroshima, Japanese newspapers said. Japan, the only country ever to suffer a nuclear attack, has been among the harshest critics of India and Pakistan after those nations carried out nuclear weapons tests last month. It has punished both countries by suspending economic aid. The foreign ministry official, who declined to be named, said that the site and date of the forum has not been decided yet, but indicated it may not be held until autumn. On Tuesday, forty-six countries in the Conference on Disarmament, including Japan and the United States, demanded that India and Pakistan immediately cease testing nuclear arms and join in the global move to eliminate the weapons. BC-Air France-Strike, 1st Ld-Writethru
Tough talk ahead of second-round negotiations Wednesday
Eds: UPDATES with comment, TRIMS; talks resume at 3 p.m. (1300 GMT) AP Photos PAR106,109 of June 2 By CECIL ROUX Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Threatening a long and devastating strike, Air France's leading pilots' union was talking tough after the first round of negotiations in a three-day-old walkout already disrupting some World Cup preparations. The strike at state-owned Air France _ the World Cup's official carrier _ was a serious embarrassment to the French government, which also faced a Paris transit and national train strike Thursday. Talks were resume at 3 p.m. (1300 GMT) Wednesday, seven days before the championship begins. No progress was reported after the first round Tuesday. In the meantime, Air France said its Wednesday schedule included only 17 percent of its usual long-distance flights, 30 percent of its short and medium-distance routes from Charles de Gaulle Airport and 43 percent from Orly. After 5 1-2 hours of negotiations Tuesday inside Air France headquarters at Charles de Gaulle Airport, union leader Jean-Charles Corbet said the dispute ``will probably be long, it will probably be tough. ... and devastating for the balance sheet.'' Corbet, head of the SNPL union that represents most of the airline's 3,200 pilots, accused the airline's president, Jean-Cyril Spinetta, of ``contenting himself with renewing his demands'' during the talks. While faced with a slated two-week walkout, Spinetta on Wednesday morning said he remained ``firm on my objectives'' but that ``on the means to reach them, we can and must discuss them.'' For the pilots, among the highest paid in the world, the company wants to give them stock in exchange for 500 million francs (dlrs 83 million) in pay cuts. But it's offered to eventually do away with a two-tier salary schedule that pays less to new pilots. Spinetta told Europe 1 radio he was ready to spend ``the afternoon, the night and beyond'' to reach an agreement. ``I can't imagine that the pilots, at the moment where the world's eyes are turned to France for this great celebration that is the World Cup, will paralyze the country,'' Spinetta said. The carrier, which managed to report a profit in the last two years, was set to lose 100 million francs (dlrs 16.7 million) per day during the strike that was forcing tens of thousands of people worldwide to look for other ways to travel. France's interior minister criticized the ``lack of civic-mindedness'' of the pilots, saying he felt ``sadness, almost shame.'' Because of the strike, Jean-Pierre Chevenement told Radio Monte Carlo, France could show itself as a nation that can't organize a world event anymore.'' The walkout disrupted training for the French national team, said coach Aime Jacquet. The players had been given a three-day weekend to visit their families and were supposed to resume training Tuesday. ``Yes, indeed a lot of players will arrive late because of the strike. It risks turning our whole day upside down,'' Jacquet said. Air France is committed to transporting teams to the 10 competition sites around France and would probably use outside carriers to meet its obligations if necessary. But the U.S. Soccer Federation, heading to France on Thursday, said it is flying its team to Paris on American Airlines, connecting to an Air France flight to Lyon. As a backup, the Americans have rented buses in France. (cb-parf)

BC-Malaysia-Opposition Protest
Opposition leader slams police ban on public gatherings
By ALVIN UNG Associated Press Writer
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia (AP) _ Warning that Malaysia could plunge into ``a new dark age,'' the leader of the main opposition party Wednesday slammed the police for banning three public meetings over the past four days. ``Has Malaysia suddenly descended into a police state in a matter of days?'' said Lim Kit Siang, head of the opposition Democratic Action Party. In a statement, Lim alleged that police in riot gear Tuesday disbanded a meeting organized by the DAP in village in the central state of Malacca. The party had applied for permission for the Pantai Kundor gathering on May 22, Lim said, but the request was rejected one day before it was scheduled to commence. Police broke up the gathering while DAP was hosting a dinner for its panel of speakers _ comprising leaders from four opposition parties. It was not clear whether DAP had planned to go ahead with its meeting. On Tuesday, Kuala Lumpur police suddenly withdrew permission for a meeting of residents to discuss the city's severe water rationing. Over the weekend, police had disbanded a gathering of lawyers at a city hotel, saying organizers hadn't obtained a permit. Lim and his son were to speak at that meeting. ``These high-handed and undemocratic police actions are ominous signs that Malaysia is heading toward a police state,'' said a joint statement by eight opposition leaders condemning the disbanding of Tuesday's village meeting. The police bans have been criticized by the opposition and human rights groups. ``We're just amazed at their paranoia,'' said Hamdan Adnan, president of the Federation of Malaysian Consumers Associations. Nearly 2 million residents of Kuala Lumpur and its suburbs have faced water rationing for three months as the reservoirs hovered at critical levels. Authorities have blamed the water shortage on scant rains, but residents say it was a crisis caused by mismanagement. ``The right of consumers to assemble and discuss matters that concern their day-to-day living is the most basic of democratic rights in a civil society,'' said Ramdas Tikamdas, president of the National Human Rights Society. Lim, the opposition leader, urged the government to move toward greater democratization in view of the recent developments in Indonesia that led to President Suharto's ouster. ``Malaysian government leaders are afraid of the Indonesian contagion, but they must draw the right lessons.'' Police cited security concerns for disallowing the meeting, but did not elaborate. ``They are operating under the police act, section 27. If the police chief has a strong reason to stop the meetings, he can,'' said police spokesman, Samsuddin Ali.

BC-Indonesia, 1st Ld-Writethru
Indonesia's military chief wants end to condemnation of Suharto With Indonesia-Habibie Interview, Indonesia-Riot Toll
Eds: UPDATES with military blocking downtown intersection to stop protesters, graf 9 AP Photos staffing By CHRISTOPHER TORCHIA Associated Press Writer
JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Student protesters shouted ``Hang Suharto'' outside Parliament on Wednesday as Indonesia's military chief appealed for a halt to ``out of control'' condemnation of the ousted president. Suharto, a former army general who turns 77 next Monday, faces growing demands that he surrender riches accumulated during three decades in power. In a television interview, new President B.J. Habibie urged Indonesians not to dwell on the country's corrupt past and to focus on economic recovery. With the economy expected to shrink by at least 10 percent this year, the task is a daunting one. Student protesters who helped dislodge Suharto accuse him of deepening Indonesia's financial crisis by exploiting state wealth. The authoritarian leader quit May 21 amid campus demonstrations and riots over price increases. A government commission, meanwhile, said the death toll over several days of riots in Jakarta in mid-May was 1,188, more than double an estimate by the military. Many victims were looters trapped in buildings set afire by arsonists. In a report released Wednesday, the National Commission on Human Rights also criticized the armed forces for failing to take prompt action to prevent rioting. About 2,000 banner-waving students rallied in a major highway outside Parliament, demanding that Suharto be put on trial for economic crimes. Soldiers closed off the road. Chanting ``Reject Habibie,'' the protesters scoffed at their new president's pledge to hold general elections in 1999, saying he was a corrupt lackey of Suharto and should step aside. A close ally of Suharto for decades, Habibie is bowing to popular demands for democratic reform. Later the military blocked off a major downtown intersection to stop a convoy of about 20 busloads of protesters from staging a demonstration at Jakarta's National Monument, adjacent to the Presidential Palace. Gen. Wiranto, the armed forces chief, said the nation of 202 million people should pardon Suharto because he boosted economic growth and averted chaos by relinquishing power. ``Lately, condemnation and harassment against the former president and his family have been exaggerated and, in some cases, have gotten out of control,'' said Wiranto, a former personal aide to Suharto. ``The armed forces will take necessary measures to stop it,'' Wiranto said without elaborating. The military is the most powerful institution in Indonesia, which is beset by uncertainty about its political future. It is doubtful that Habibie, who has a shaky power base, would make any policy decisions without the backing of Wiranto. In an interview with Cable News Network that was broadcast Wednesday, Habibie argued against a painful investigation of misdeeds that could divide the nation. ``You have unlimited problems in the past. Where are you going to stop?'' Habibie said. ``So I think it is not worthwhile to dip into the past. I have to look to the future and create a better life ... for the people.'' In a separate interview with the New York Times, Habibie said Indonesians should not indulge in ``Wild West'' justice against the former leader. State prosecutors have launched an inquiry into corruption under the old government, including complaints that Suharto's family abused its influence to build huge business empires. However, critics doubt they will aggressively pursue the former president. Earlier this week, opposition leader Megawati Sukarnoputri urged people to stop denouncing Suharto, who rose to power in the 1960s by edging aside her father, Indonesia's founding President Sukarno. Still, sentiment against Suharto was strong among about 200 supporters of Megawati who joined students outside Parliament to demand government action to help the poor. ``Everybody knows he's corrupt so the case must be processed legally,'' said protester Daulat Sidautar. ``It will give an example for the future of Indonesia.''

BC-Caribbean-Summary,1110
An overnight summary of Caribbean news GUYANA: Long-awaited audit says election was fair
By The Associated Press
GEORGETOWN, Guyana (AP) _ In a blow to Guyana's main opposition party, a Caribbean Community audit team said Tuesday that December elections which touched off race riots in this South American country were fair. Audited results varied ``only marginally'' from official results of the Dec. 15 election, won by President Janet Jagan's People's Progressive Party, said Caricom team leader Ulric Cross. Guyana's elections commissioner had declared Mrs. Jagan, a U.S. expatriate, the winner with 56 percent of votes to 42 percent for ex-President Desmond Hoyte's People's National Congress. Hoyte denounced alleged vote fraud, and opposition street protests after the elections led to race riots that shut down schools and businesses. Dozens were hurt. BAHAMAS: Chairman of disgraced gold company hospitalized TORONTO (AP) _ David Walsh, the disgraced president and chief executive of Bre-X Minerals Ltd., iss hospitalized after he suffered a heart attack during the weekend, the Canadian Press news service reported. Officials with Doctor's Hospital in Nassau confirmed late Tuesday that Walsh was registered as a patient, but refused to give any other details. Earlier, a Reuters report said the former Calgary mining promoter was in critical condition. Walsh, whose now-infamous company rose to fame on the strength of an Indonesian gold find that was exposed last year as a fraud, moved to the Bahamas after the scandal broke in March 1997. The scam cost investors more than dlrs 3 billion. UNITED STATES: Cruise line will pay dlrs 9 million in fines MIAMI (AP) _ The world's second largest cruise ship company apologized Tuesday for illegally dumping oily bilge water from its ships into the oceans and for trying to hide the crime by lying to investigators and falsifying records. Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd. agreed to settle charges filed by federal prosecutors in Miami and San Juan, Puerto Rico, accusing the cruise line of routinely dumping oil-contaminated water at sea. The company agreed in federal court to pay dlrs 9 million in fines _ the largest environmental fine ever against a cruise company _ and to serve 5 years of probation in which it will be subject to a court-monitored environmental plan. NICARAGUA: President restricts offer to take Cubans MANAGUA, Nicaragua (AP) _ A war of words between Cuba and Nicaragua's fiercely anti-communist president is continuing to heat up _ with Cubans trying to leave their homeland trapped in the verbal cross fire. President Arnoldo Aleman repeated Monday night that his government is willing to accept 191 Cubans who fled by raft to the Bahamas, but were then returned to Cuba last month. But, he said, Nicaragua would not automatically accept other Cubans. Cuba, meanwhile, has said it would allow anybody to go to Nicaragua _ anybody but those specified by Aleman because they had violated the law by leaving without government permission. VIRGIN ISLANDS: Customs agents, wholesaler convicted in gold import scheme FORT LAUDERDALE, Florida (AP) _ Two U.S. Customs Service inspectors, a Miami jewelry wholesaler and three of its employees were convicted of smuggling Italian gold smuggled into the United States through the Virgin Islands. A federal jury on Monday found all five people, and the wholesaler _ New Ilan of Florida Inc. _ of trying to avoid millions in import duties. Sentencing was set for Sept. 15. Federal prosecutors charge the smuggling operation snuck into this country about dlrs 14 million worth of jewelry _ through the Caribbean, without paying import duty fees _ during a 22-month period. Imported gold is subject to a 6.5 percent import duty. UNITED STATES: Coast guard stops cruise ship to Bahamas from sailing PORT CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) _ The Big Red Boat to the Bahamas was kept in port along with more than 1,000 angry passengers when the U.S. Coast Guard could not verify the Premier Cruises ship met new fire codes. The Coast Guard suspended cruises on the vessel Monday until it is inspected. The 32-year-old ship was getting ready to sail to Nassau and Port Lucaya in the Bahamas. Inspectors were expected to examine the ship Wednesday and the earliest it would be able to sail was Friday, Coast Guard spokesman Tim Kaminski said Tuesday. Premier Cruises officials were offered passengers free flights home and vouchers for other cruise lines or future cruises. The cruise line also offered to pay for rooms in area hotels. UNITED STATES: Lawyer defends company selling cheap Caribbean trips PITTSBURGH (AP) _ The lawyer for a telemarketing company accused of duping customers about cut-rate vacations told a judge Tuesday that most people are satisfied with their trips to Florida and the Bahamas. The Federal Trade Commission has accused Commonwealth Marketing Group Inc. of Hopwood, Pennsylvania of promising customers luxury hotel rooms and cruises but delivering worn rooms and five- to six-hour ferry rides on unsteady boats. ``We've all seen telemarketing cases where people are selling air,'' defense lawyer William Manifesto said. ``This is not that case, or we wouldn't have an 80 percent approval rating.'' Consumers in 29 states, Mexico, Canada and England have complained to authorities about CMG. Manifesto asked U.S. District Judge William Standish to lift a restraining order that has temporarily shut down the company. U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS: Government eases barge rule CHARLOTTE AMALIE, U.S. Virgin Islands (AP) _ The government on Tuesday relaxed a proposed rule that prohibited commuters from accompanying their cars on the ferry trip between two of the U.S. Virgin Islands. The rule, approved by the Public Services Commission last week, outraged residents of St. John who commute to the larger island of St. Thomas. The ruling required drivers to put their cars on a cargo ferry, then board a separate passenger ferry. After a meeting between Gov. Roy Schneider and commission chairman Walter Challenger on Tuesday morning, Schneider spokeswoman Jeanette Millin said the rule had been changed to allow the driver and one passenger to accompany each car. Commission members said they were trying to prevent travelers from packing into cars to save money on tickets.

AP Photos FBD101-104 By PHIL GOODWIN Associated Press Writer
SHARI BASURKH, Afghanistan (AP) _ As survivors in the remotest regions still waited Wednesday for help to arrive, Afghanistan's deposed President Burhanuddin Rabbani said the international response to the deadly earthquake was too slow. Rabbani went by helicopter to Shari-Basurkh -- one of the hardest hit areas -- on Tuesday to see the devastation caused by Saturday's magnitude-6.9 quake and to settle a dispute among rebel commanders who control the region. On Wednesday he said 3.5 tons of medical supplies were to be sent to Faisabad from Pakistan. Much of the area is inaccessible by road. The quake struck during the late morning when most of the men were in the fields, which is why aid workers say the bulk of the wounded are women, old men and children -- all of whom had been in their homes at the time of the temblor. In a makeshift clinic set up in an elementary school, 60 of the injured lie side by side. A baby on an intravenous drip screams next to a woman whose face is covered in yellow bruises. Most people here haven't eaten since the earthquake hit. Afraid to stay inside, they are terrified that another killer quake could be on the way. Saturday's quake follows another deadly earthquake that struck last February killing as many as 2,300 people and leaving thousands more homeless. Earlier fears by the U.N. of a fuel shortage for their three borrowed helicopters were alleviated after they discovered 20 barrels of fuel in Faisabad. At the airport in Faisabad helicopters were being loaded up with plastic sheeting, bamboo splints, cakes of soap, food and water.

BC-Sports-Soccer-World Cup-Fontaine's Record,0459
Just Fontaine's record 13 goals looks daunting 40 years later
By RAF CASERT Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ A lot will happen at the biggest ever World Cup, but Just Fontaine need not worry, just yet. Despite Ronaldo, Batistuta, Shearer and a slew of other prolific strikers, it is unlikely his record of 13 goals in one World Cup tournament will fall. Forty years after setting the record at the 1958 World Cup in Sweden, Fontaine is a star all over again. ``I'd better enjoy it, because the next time it's in France, I'll be in my coffin,'' the 64-year-old Frenchman said. It is also increasingly likely his record like that will survive him. No one has come close since and the top-scoring title is now regularly going to a striker who gets a half dozen goals. And to think he wasn't even considered the best French forward going into the 1958 tournament, where France lost to eventual champion Brazil in the semifinals. He even scored them all with a pair of soccer boots on loan because his shoes fell apart days ahead of the finals. And even with million-dollar apparel endorsement deals and custom-made shoes, Fontaine knows no one will get close to him because of three reasons. First of all, ``in my days the record didn't mean a thing. No reward, no golden boot, nothing whatsoever. Up to the point that during the last game I didn't even shoot the penalty. Just didn't think of it.'' ``So there was no pressure,'' he said. Now, being top scorer has become one of the most prestigious titles at the World Cup. Secondly, it means scoring almost two goals a game, with the final four teams playing seven matches over the 32 days of competition. ``In days like these you cannot be optimistic. How could you be optimistic?'' Third, and perhaps the most convincing argument, is a defender's knowledge of the striker. Six months ahead of the World Cup, Fontaine needed surgery and, for his comeback, he was a mere substitute. ``So, no one knew me,'' he said. ``And by the time they knew me, it was all over.'' Now, there is not a defender at the World Cup who doesn't know every move of Ronaldo. There is not a single coach who doesn't have a strategy to contain him. They might not stop him totally, but allowing him to score 13 goals in seven games? ``In my time, teams didn't even have spies to check out opponents,'' said Fontaine. Now, every match is scouted and some coaches spend weekend sitting video sessions of all potential opponents. So, what was his secret? ``You had to smell where the ball would end up and allow you to score.'' rac-rjm

Russia's top judge urges death penalty repeal
MOSCOW (AP) _ Russia's top judge urged his nation Wednesday to abolish the death penalty in accordance with its international obligations. ``We have signed the European convention, ratified it and must fulfill the obligations taken,'' Russian Supreme Court's chairman Vyacheslav Lebedev said, according to the Interfax news agency. Prosecutor General Yuri Skuratov backed Lebedev, saying that Russia should keep its pledge to abolish capital punishment. However, newly-appointed Justice Minister Pavel Krashennikov said last week he considers it premature for Russia to ban the death penalty taking into account ``both the criminal situation and moral aspects of the problem.'' Russia promised to halt the death penalty in January 1996 when it joined the Council of Europe, the continent's leading human rights organization. Nonetheless, 92 people were executed before President Boris Yeltsin imposed a moratorium later that year. The government says there have been no executions since August 1996, but Yeltsin's efforts to outlaw executions have been blocked by hard-liners in the Russian parliament who argue that the death penalty is needed to keep soaring crime under control. Polls show a majority of Russians support capital punishment. Earlier this year, parliament's lower house, the State Duma, ratified the European human rights convention with exception of a death penalty ban. With no ban in place, Russian courts have continued handing down death sentences and about 1,000 people are now on death row, according to the Amnesty International human rights group. (vi/mr)

BC-EU-Mediterranean
European Union reaches out to its Mediterranean partners
Eds: Meeting begins at 1600 GMT By JEFFREY ULBRICH Associated Press Writer
PALERMO, Sicily (AP) - The European Union comes together with its Mediterranean partners Wednesday, trying to get the economic cooperation process back on track after last year's derailment by Mideast issues. A year ago in Malta, the EU's 15 foreign ministers gathered with their 12 Mediterranean colleagues to talk trade and investment, only to see their meeting blown away on the turbulent winds of the Mideast peace process. Even at the inaugural meeting of the Euro-Mediterranean conference in Barcelona in 1995, heady ideas also fell victim to disputes, that time over human rights. The Palermo meeting is an informal session with no set agenda. Organizers hope it will bring the conference back to its original idea of creating a European-Mediterranean free trade and security zone by 2010. Last year, Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat and then-Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy were the stars of the show, agreeing to resuscitate the moribund Middle East peace talks. Today, those talks are still stuck, and neither Arafat nor Israel's foreign minister plans to turn up here. ``This meeting is aimed at providing a new momentum to the Barcelona process,'' EU foreign ministers said in a statement. Mediterranean nations sell half their exports to EU countries and provide the EU with 20 percent of its energy supplies. At the same time, half of the Mediterranean nations' imports come from Western Europe. The EU's per capita income is a dozen times higher than most of the North African and Mideast nations. Ministers here are continuing efforts to come up with a Euro-Mediterranean Stability Charter and to establish confidence-building measures for the region. Italian Foreign Minister Lamberto Dini said the EU wants to have this completed by the Euro-Mediterranean meeting in Stuttgart, Germany, next year. On the economic side, the 27 were to discuss support for economies in transition, private investment in the non-European Mediterranean countries and eventual realization of the free-trade zone. Depite the wish to move on, however, it's not possible to contemplate security and stability in the Mediterranean without peace between Israel and the Palestinians; Israel continues to occupy a piece of neighboring Lebanon; stability is impossible without a stop to the ceaseless killing in Algeria; no Mediterranean security plan can be complete without Libya, absent here; and Turkey's long battle with the Kurds shows no sign of resolution. Joining ministers from the European Union are officials from Algeria, Cyprus, Egypt, Jordan, Israel, Lebanon, Malta, Morocco, Syria, Tunisia, Turkey and the Palestinian Authority. (ju/vls)

BC-Russia-Mir
Mir flying without a hitch on eve of docking with U.S. shuttle
By VLADIMIR ISACHENKOV Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ Mir was ``flying without a hitch'' Wednesday on the eve of a docking with U.S. space shuttle Discovery _ the ninth and final American hookup with the Russian space station, an official said. Discovery is scheduled to dock with Mir at around 9 p.m. Moscow time (1700 GMT) Thursday and remain linked to the station for four days. It will bring home astronaut Andrew Thomas, the seventh and last American to live on Mir. The shuttle flight faced a possible delay because of a three-day failure of Mir's central computer that paralyzed its automatic steering system and made the station too unstable for the docking. Cosmonauts Talgat Musabayev and Nikolai Budarin finally fixed the skittish computer on Monday and quickly reactivated the steering system which has held Mir steady since then. On Tuesday, they switched on Mir's 11 gyroscopes, the station's preferred, fuel-free orientation system. ``All Mir's equipment is now running without a hitch and the station is fully ready for the docking,'' Mission Control spokesman Valery Lyndin said Wednesday. Mir's main computer operates the station's motion control system, and when it fails, the station's energy supply dwindles since it can't rotate to keep its solar panels in full alignment with the sun. Mir's computer repeatedly failed last year, prompting Russian space officials to send up a replacement on a previous shuttle flight in January. The new computer worked well until it broke down Saturday, and cosmonauts replaced it from the station's supply of spares. The crew was busy Wednesday packing up U.S. scientific equipment for return aboard Discovery. Officials said there was no room to bring home personal belongings left behind by Thomas' six NASA predecessors. All the same, Musabayev is hoping there will room for his guitar, which arrived on a Russian space ferry earlier this year, Lyndin said. The Russian crew returns to Earth in a tiny Soyuz landing capsule which is barely large enough for the cosmonauts, let alone any cargo. (vi/mr)

BC-ARTS-US-Garcia Lorca Centennial, 2 Takes,0896
Federico Garcia Lorca in New York _ `a feast of pneumatic drills'
AP Photos NY305-306 By VERENA DOBNIK Associated Press Writer
NEW YORK (AP) _ New York City's tough skin masked ``a river of tender blood,'' Federico Garcia Lorca once wrote. It was a city that both shocked and seduced him. Spain's greatest modern poet aimed his verbal lens at the metropolis where he fled in 1929 to escape deep depression. ``New York, slime. New York, wire and death,'' he wrote. ``What angel is hidden in your cheek?'' June 5 marks the centennial of Garcia Lorca's birth, and he's being remembered in the city where he wrote ``Poet in New York,'' one of the most influential and disturbing books of 20th-century verse. Farrar, Straus and Giroux is printing a new edition based on the original manuscript, which was rediscovered last year in Mexico. Already famous at 31 for his poetry, art and music, Garcia Lorca became a Columbia University student who lived in a dormitory and tried _ without much success _ to learn English. What he wrote in his native language later made him the most translated Spanish poet ever, and a thorn in the side of the Fascists, who executed him during the Spanish Civil War. ``Like Walt Whitman, he created the figure of a poet in New York. He created this Prometheus, this prophet who wrote the New York poems,'' says Garcia Lorca scholar Christopher Maurer. ``He let his hair down as a poet here, in a howl of metaphysical loneliness. ``The actual, flesh-and-blood Garcia Lorca who wandered around the city was having a great time. He was fascinated by the place.'' Maurer recently introduced a reading of Garcia Lorca's work at the 92nd Street Y by American poets Robert Bly, Philip Levine and Galway Kinnell, and Spanish poet Angel Gonzalez. At home in Spain, Garcia Lorca, son of a prosperous farmer from Andalucia, had focused his artistic microscope on himself and a rural Roman Catholic society. New York shook him up. Cut off by the language barrier and often writing home for more money, he roamed the big city seeking ``the earthworm in the landscape of fire escapes.'' The iron stairs hanging from buildings became his metaphor for the city. ___ ``Dawn in New York groans on enormous fire escapes searching between the angles for spikenards of drafted anguish.'' ___ Walking streets that were a ``feast of pneumatic drills,'' he watched people working, a mass of toiling automatons that ``drowns itself in machinery and lament.'' He humanized them: ``I denounce everyone who ignores the other half, the half that can't be redeemed, who lift their mountains of cement where the heart beats. ... The other half hears me, devouring ... flying in their purity.'' The poet witnessed the merciless power of the new industrial society during the stock market crash of 1929, rushing to Wall Street to watch the trading. He decried ``the cruel silence of money,'' reflected at night in ``the conspiracy of these deserted offices that radiate no agony.'' ``New York awoke his social consciousness,'' says Charles Saliba, a Columbia student who grew up in Garcia Lorca's region of Spain and who lived in the poet's old dorm room last year. On a recent Sunday morning, Saliba led a walking tour of the neighborhoods and buildings that were home to Garcia Lorca during the academic year 1929-30, when he helped teach Spanish literature while taking courses. Stopping in front of a Harlem project a few blocks north of the university, Saliba read ``King of Harlem,'' a poem about a popular, strong-willed man stuck in a menial job: ``Ay, Harlem,'' Garcia Lorca called out in Spanish to the primarily black neighborhood. ``There is no anguish like that of ... your grand king, a prisoner in the uniform of a doorman. ... Cooks, waiters, and those whose tongues lick clean the wounds of millionaires seek the king in the streets. ... Ay, Harlem, threatened by a mob of headless suits! I hear your murmur.'' Garcia Lorca was incensed by injustices like the ``whites only'' rule that excluded black guests from big-time clubs where they were often the star performers. He spent many nights partying in Harlem, discovering jazz and the blues, and making friends using his charm and lively piano playing. He shared with them his love of flamenco, the music of Spain's persecuted Gypsies whose songs about death, lost love and betrayal are echoed in the furious rhythms of Garcia Lorca's New York verse. On another day at the 92nd Street Y, Spanish music by composers Garcia Lorca knew and admired, including Manuel de Falla, was performed by guitarist Sharon Isbin and mezzo-soprano Denyce Graves. Soprano Ana Maria Martinez sang Garcia Lorca's arrangements of five Spanish songs. It was the type of folk music that had inspired his earlier poetry. In New York, Garcia Lorca dipped his poetry into new ethnic groups and cutting-edge lifestyles, carousing with friends like poet Hart Crane. conform to digest Deposed Afghan president says aid too slow to quake victims
RETRANSMITTING to correct writethru sequence and to fix slug to AP Photos FBD101-104 By PHIL GOODWIN Associated Press Writer
SHARI BASURKH, Afghanistan (AP) _ With earthquake survivors in remote regions still waiting Wednesday for food to arrive, Afghanistan's deposed president criticized the international response as too slow. Burhanuddin Rabbani went by helicopter to Shari-Basurkh _ one of the hardest hit areas _ on Tuesday to see the devastation caused by Saturday's magnitude-6.9 quake and to settle a dispute among rebel commanders who control the region. The northern-based alliance established to stop the Taliban religious army from consolidating its hold on Afghanistan has been fraught with internal disputes. Several of them have turned violent. The feuding comes as residents of the area were trying to dig themselves from the rubble caused by the deadly quake that killed as many as 5,000 people, wiped out entire villages and left as many as 60,000 people homeless. The United Nations and the Red Cross have been coordinating relief efforts, attempting to make several many helicopter runs a day from the provincial capital, Faisabad, to remote villages to pick up the wounded, and to drop off blankets, plastic sheeting and tents. ``We are trying to get in more helicopters ... this is where the bottleneck has been,'' said Philip Spoerri, a Red Cross spokesman in neighboring Pakistan. The priority has been to get the wounded out and medical supplies to the hardest hit areas and it hasn't been easy. On Wednesday, he said 3 1/2 tons of medical supplies were to be sent to Faisabad from Pakistan. Much of the area is inaccessible by road. In Shari Basurkh, near the epicenter, half the village was flattened by the violent shaking that residents said lasted four minutes. The quake struck during the late morning when most of the men were in the fields, which is why the bulk of the wounded are women, old men and children who had been at home at the time of the quake, aid workers say. In a makeshift clinic set up in an elementary school, 60 of the injured lie side by side. A baby on an intravenous drip screams next to a woman whose face is covered in yellow bruises. Most people here haven't eaten since the earthquake hit. They are afraid to stay inside, fearing aftershocks that have rattled the region almost daily since the quake struck. The United Nations has put out an appeal for helicopters worldwide saying it has the aid ready to distribute to the victims of the earthquake but limited means to get it to them. The rugged mountain region has no roads leading from the Badakshan capital of Faisabad to Shari Basurkh or scores of other villages that lay in the quake's path. ``Shari Basurkh is one of the hardest areas to reach,'' said Spoerri. Saturday's quake follows another deadly earthquake that struck last February killing as many as 2,300 people and leaving thousands more homeless.

BC-El Nino-Weather
World meteorologists say El Nino disruptions coming to an end
By JONATHAN DRAKE Associated Press Writer
SINGAPORE (AP) _ There was good news Wednesday from the world's weather forecasters: the massive disruptions caused by El Nino are coming to an end. The World Meteorological Organization said the current round of El Nino ``is in its dying stages,'' but conceded there was considerable uncertainty ``about the rate of weakening.'' El Nino, a disruptive weather phenomenon that returned in 1997, has been blamed for flooding in Kenya, drought in Indonesia and heavy snow in the southwestern United States. It has even been credited with lengthening the days on Earth by slowing its rotation. Unlike previous episodes which lingered for years, the current El Nino ``is showing clear signs of weakening,'' said the World Meteorological Organization, a U.N. agency. The organization's update said the four conditions typical of the weather phenomenon are becoming less pronounced. Those conditions are warming in the eastern Pacific Ocean; shifting of precipitation from the western to the eastern Pacific; slowing of trade winds; and changes in sea level. El Nino causes reversals of normal weather patterns, resulting in drought in usually wet locales and flooding in arid areas. It also helps trigger some man-made disasters. For example, fires set by farmers and plantation owners in Indonesia in 1997 and 1998 swept through unusually dry forests, shrouding much of Southeast Asia in thick haze. The World Meteorological Association (WMO) said it is difficult to predict just when this round of El Nino will come to an end. ``One model has conditions moving rapidly towards normal by mid-1998, and another has El Nino lingering on towards the end of the year,'' the report stated. During a press conference Tuesday, the organization's secretary-general Godwin Obasi, of Nigeria, said he expected the former scenario, with El Nino tapering off by the end of this month. Such a development could be followed by the so-called La Nina effect, which could reverse some of the effects of the current disturbances and, in Southeast Asia, help curb some of the forest fires. However, the international weathermen said it's far from certain whether La Nina will occur. The U.N. weather agency predicts drier-than-normal conditions over Indonesia, Micronesia and southern South America during the next two months. Wetter conditions than usual will continue over the central and eastern equatorial Pacific and over southeastern South America. John Miller, chief of the environment division at WMO, told The Associated Press that the forecast was a conservative prediction that discounted the possibility of an immediate end to El Nino or a La Nina episode. This was despite growing evidence to suggest such an occurrence, because forecasts rely on a consensus of results in the computer predictions.

Tough talk ahead of second-round negotiations Wednesday from transit and train officials; talks resume at 3 p.m. (1300 GMT)
Eds: CORRECTS train strike set for Friday, UPDATES with comment AP Photos PAR106,109 of June 2 By CECIL ROUX Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Threatening a long and devastating strike, Air France's leading pilots' union was talking tough after the first round of negotiations in a three-day-old walkout already disrupting some World Cup preparations. The strike at state-owned Air France _ the World Cup's official carrier _ was a serious embarrassment to the French government, which also faced walkouts among Paris transit workers Thursday and national railworkers strike Friday. Talks were resume at 3 p.m. (1300 GMT) Wednesday, seven days before the championship begins. No progress was reported after the first round Tuesday. In the meantime, Air France said its Wednesday schedule included only 17 percent of its usual long-distance flights, 30 percent of its short and medium-distance routes from Charles de Gaulle Airport and 43 percent from Orly. After 5 1-2 hours of negotiations Tuesday inside Air France headquarters at Charles de Gaulle Airport, union leader Jean-Charles Corbet said the dispute ``will probably be long, it will probably be tough. ... and devastating for the balance sheet.'' Corbet, head of the SNPL union that represents most of the airline's 3,200 pilots, accused the airline's president, Jean-Cyril Spinetta, of ``contenting himself with renewing his demands'' during the talks. While faced with a slated two-week walkout, Spinetta on Wednesday morning said he remained ``firm on my objectives'' but that ``on the means to reach them, we can and must discuss them.'' For the pilots, among the highest paid in the world, the company wants to give them stock in exchange for 500 million francs (dlrs 83 million) in pay cuts. But it's offered to eventually do away with a two-tier salary schedule that pays less to new pilots. Spinetta told Europe 1 radio he was ready to spend ``the afternoon, the night and beyond'' to reach an agreement. ``I can't imagine that the pilots, at the moment where the world's eyes are turned to France for this great celebration that is the World Cup, will paralyze the country,'' Spinetta said. The carrier, which managed to report a profit in the last two years, was set to lose 100 million francs (dlrs 16.7 million) per day during the strike that was forcing tens of thousands of people worldwide to look for other ways to travel. France's interior minister criticized the ``lack of civic-mindedness'' of the pilots, saying he felt ``sadness, almost shame.'' Because of the strike, Jean-Pierre Chevenement told Radio Monte Carlo, France could show itself as a nation that can't organize a world event anymore.'' The walkout disrupted training for the French national team, said coach Aime Jacquet. The players had been given a three-day weekend to visit their families and were supposed to resume training Tuesday. ``Yes, indeed a lot of players will arrive late because of the strike. It risks turning our whole day upside down,'' Jacquet said. Air France is committed to transporting teams to the 10 competition sites around France and would probably use outside carriers to meet its obligations if necessary. But the U.S. Soccer Federation, heading to France on Thursday, said it is flying its team to Paris on American Airlines, connecting to an Air France flight to Lyon. As a backup, the Americans have rented buses in France. Paris subway drivers with the Communist-led CGT union were to walk off the job Thursday, but the Paris transit authority RATP said it expected no effect on service since the union represented only a minority of the employees. At the national railway SNCF, conductors with three unions were to strike beginning Friday night though Sunday evening. The railroad said it was assessing what effect the walkout may have. (cb-parf)

Nationalists leading the party oppose returns of Serb or Muslim refugees and other aspects of the Dayton accord. A similar split in the Bosnian Serb leadership last year marked one of the biggest breakthroughs in Bosnia since the 1995 end of the war. Western powers used that chance to support Serb moderates and sideline the old hard-line leadership. The dominant Muslim SDA party also has had to deal with much stronger opposition from two Social Democrat parties in the Muslim-Croat federation. MOSCOW (AP) _ A sodium cyanide spill which sickened 600 people and polluted an ecologically important lake in the former Soviet republic of Kyrgyzstan claimed its first fatality on Wednesday, officials said. The woman, whose identity wasn't given, died in a hospital in the town of Karakol near Lake Issyk Kul, one of the largest bodies of water in Central Asia, the Interfax news agency reported. Interfax quoted doctors saying that the patient had died of sodium cyanide poisoning that exacerbated her previous illness. Kyrgyz President Askar Akayev discussed the incident on Wednesday with Michel Bernard, the visiting chief of Canada's Cameco company, which operates the gold mine for which the cyanide was headed. Cameco, the world's largest publicly traded uranium company, operates the Kumtor gold mine through its subsidiary, Kumtor Operating Co. With dlrs 500 million in the project, Cameco is a major foreign investor in the impoverished Central Asian country. On May 20, a truck carrying 20 tons of highly toxic sodium cyanide powder to the mine veered off a mountain road and crashed into the Barskaan river, which feeds into Lake Issyk Kul. The huge lake is the center of a valuable nature preserve and home to several rare species. The damaged containers leaked 1,700 kilograms (3,400 pounds) of sodium cyanide into the river and some of it reached the lake. Kyrgyz officials have said the river and the lake were not expected to suffer any long-term damage. Cameco's Bernard, speaking to reporters in Kyrgyzstan's capital Bishkek on Wednesday, insisted the spill was minor and posed no serious threat to people or the environment, Interfax reported. He said the chemical fell into a small bay in the lake for little more than one day, which couldn't seriously affect such a large body of water. Lake Issyk Kul covers 6,200 sq. kilometers (2,400 sq. miles) and is 670 meters (2,210 feet) deep. However, local officials have said fish and cattle were killed near the site of the spill and some 600 people have sought medical treatment for poisoning, of whom about 100 have been hospitalized. Farmland has also been contaminated by villagers who used water from the river on their crops, officials said. World Health Organization experts have recommended that local residents avoid produce grown in the area, Interfax said. (vi/mr)

BC-Philippines-Spratlys
Estrada to pursue diplomatic solution to Spratlys dispute
MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ President-elect Joseph Estrada will pursue a diplomatic solution to the territorial dispute in the South China Sea's Spratly Islands, but will reinforce the country's military to back up its claims, an official said Wednesday. Orlando Mercado, the defense department's secretary-designate, said there was no indication violence would erupt in the contested areas in the near future but added that they remained a source of regional tension. Estrada was proclaimed winner of the May 11 presidential elections by Congress last Friday and will be inaugurated on June 30. The disputes have often strained ties between countries that lay claim to the islands, although all have vowed to resolve the issue peacefully. China has claimed the whole of the Spratlys, which it calls the Nansha Islands. Vietnam and Taiwan also claim all of the Spratlys, while Malaysia, Brunei and the Philippines claim some of the islands, which are believed to be rich in oil and natural gas. The Philippines occupies eight of the islands, which it collectively calls the Kalayaan Island Group. It has been holding elections in the biggest island, called Pag-asa, to reinforce its claim. The Philippines has one of the weakest armed forces among the claimants but has started to modernize its military.

BC-Hong Kong-Stocks
Stocks rebound on technical buying
HONG KONG (AP) _ Stocks rebounded in Hong Kong on Wednesday after the key index shed 900 points, or about 10 percent, in the previous seven sessions. But traders were skeptical about the rally's staying power. The main Hang Seng Index was boosted by a stronger yen, a fall in local interest rates and short-covering in the futures market, traders said. It rose 221.05 points, or 2.6 percent, to finish at 8,819.22. Volume was 5.72 billion Hong Kong dollars, up from 5.53 billion Hong Kong dollars in the previous session. The index edged up in the morning, and then began a steady rise through the afternoon, when it caught up with the futures market. ``The strengthening of yen has triggered some short-covering and bargain hunting,'' said Percy Au-Young, sales director at DBS Securities. Other traders were quick to call Wednesday's rise a purely technical rebound, with big investment houses covering their positions after pocketing a profit from the recent market downturn. Leading the advance Wednesday were property shares, which have taken a beating on the market in recent weeks. The property subindex rose 336.51 points, or 3.3 percent, to end at 10,449.55. Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd. rose 1.00 to 40.70; Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd., another giant developer, gained 1.40 to 36.80; Henderson Land Development Co. ended up 1.15 at 27.95. British bank HSBC Holding gained 5.50 to 190.00; its affiliate Hang Seng Bank shed 75 cents to 52.00.

BC-Arabs-Summit
U.S. asks Arabs to delay summit by one week
AMMAN, Jordan (AP) _ The United States has asked Jordan and Saudi Arabia to postpone by one week a proposed Arab summit on the faltering Middle East peace process, a government official said Wednesday. The official, who requested anonymity, said the request was made Tuesday by Thomas Pickering, an undersecretary of state for political affairs. Pickering met with King Hussein and other government officials. He also met with Saudi Crown Prince Abdullah, who was visiting Jordan in preparation for the summit. ``The U.S. requested that the summit be postponed by one week to give the United States enough time to declare the success or the failure of its efforts to revive the peace process,'' the official said. He declined to say what the Arab response was. But another official, also insisting on anonymity, said he expected the U.S. request to be heeded to ``since more preparations are needed for the summit.'' The Clinton administration has proposed that Israel make a further 13.1 troop withdrawal from the West Bank. Israel rejected, saying it can only pull out from 9 percent of the land. The United States has reportedly given time to Israel to reconsider its position. Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, who accepted the U.S. proposal, has called for the summit to map out a unified Arab strategy on the stalled peace process. But the Arabs appear to be divided over the agenda of the summit, which Syria insists it should put an end to Arab normalization of ties with Israel in order to punish it for its hard-line peace policy. Arab diplomats say Syria also wants to host the summit and exclude Jordan and the Palestinians in retaliation for their peace treaties with Israel _ which left Damascus and Lebanon out in the cold. jjh-sf

BC-China-Tiananmen
Dissidents warned, detained as 9th Tiananmen anniversary nears
AP Photos
BEIJING (AP) _ Police have warned a key dissident to keep a low profile as China neared Thursday's ninth anniversary of the armed quelling of the Tiananmen Square demonstrations, a rights group reported. Police surveillance and detentions of dissidents, stepped up every year since the June 4, 1989, military assault, have gained added urgency. Authorities don't want any trouble to mar a China-U.S. summit late this month or spark unrest among millions of workers laid off from decrepit state factories. Their fears have come to the fore in Xi'an, a grimy industrial center in central China where U.S. President Bill Clinton will visit. Police beat one of the thousands of onlookers watching a sit-in on a busy road by 200 workers from the No. 1 Construction Co. to protest layoffs on Tuesday, the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China reported Wednesday. The onlooker incited the police by calling out to the protesters, and the beating left him with injuries to many parts of his body, the group said. A police spokesman in Xi'an denied that the protest or the beating occurred. On Monday, Xi'an police went to the home of influential democracy campaigner Lin Mu, who led 11 others in sending a bold open letter recently calling for democratic reforms and an inquiry into the 1989 military assault and ensuing nationwide crackdown. Police warned Lin not to do or say anything that might cause chaos, the Information Center said. Lin was the secretary to a leading reformer of the 1980s, Communist Party General Secretary Hu Yaobang. Party elders ousted Hu in 1987 for having failed to stop an earlier wave of student-led protests. His death in April 1989 sparked the demonstrations that eventually brought more than 1 million people to Beijing's Tiananmen Square. Under orders from Chinese leaders, the military fought its way into Beijing early on June 4, 1989 to end the six weeks of demonstrations. Hundreds if not thousands of people were killed. Thousands more were arrested in a nationwide crackdown. Plainclothes police kept watch on Tiananmen, in central Beijing, in greater than normal numbers Wednesday. The Information Center reported at least two more dissidents are believed to be in police custody, in addition to the 20 or so detained in the past two weeks to prevent any commemorations of the deaths in 1989. Longtime democracy activist Xu Wenli has been missing since Friday when he left Beijing to visit friends in the southern city of Shenzhen. Liu Lianjun, an activist from eastern Shandong province, was last seen in Beijing Friday. Dissidents have repeatedly appealed for the government to investigate and divulge the death toll. Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhu Bangzao ruled out Tuesday any inquiry saying that the party and government had reached the correct conclusion.

BC-Greece-Bank Protest
Workers continue strike despite government concession
ATHENS, Greece (AP) _ Employees of Greece's fourth-largest bank refused Wednesday to scale back a three-week strike despite the government's concession to one of their main demands. Ionian Bank workers walked off the job May 8 protesting government plans to sell off the state-run bank, part of a broad plan to streamline the economy in view of European monetary union. Socialist Premier Costas Simitis initially insisted no concessions could be made and that Ionian's privatization was an essential part of plans to trim the inflated public sector. But the government backed down to one of the unionists' main demands Tuesday _ providing current Ionian employees with a guaranteed job until the retirement age of 62. National Economy Minister Yannos Papantoniou was quoted by Greek media saying a clause will be included in the bank's sale contract that forbids the new owner from firing Ionian workers. Speaking after a meeting with unionists, Papantoniou said the new proposal should not create any problems in the bank's privatization prospects. He added that ``everything will be solved when the bank begins operating normally,'' local media said. But Ionian workers' union president Yiannis Markakis vowed the strike would continue until the government revoked the sale plan altogether. Any further concessions in the sale plan could jeopardize the government's efforts to join the EU's single currency club by 2001. ``If there is not progress in these sectors, the markets will grow concerned about the government's ability to implement its reform program,'' said central bank governor Lukas Papademos in an interview with the Sunday Eleftherotypia newspaper. The sale of Ionian will ``accelerate the restructuring of the banking sector and the creation of a competitive environment'' Papademos said. ``That is the reason why it's necessary to sell the bank before the end of the year.'' BC-Iran-Bombings, 1st Ld-Writethru
Second bomb explodes in Tehran, no injuries reported opposition claim of mortar attacks, newspapers reporting higher casualties. TRIMS.
Eds: UPDATES throughout with 3 killed in Tuesday's explosion, By AFSHIN VALINEJAD Associated Press Writer
TEHRAN, Iran (AP) _ Tensions mounted Wednesday, a day after bomb attacks on government sites killed at least three people. State-run radio reported a bomb explosion at a government building in northern Tehran late Tuesday, but did not say if there were any casualties or give the cause of the blast. It did not identify the government building. But the Iraq-based Iranian opposition, Mujahedeen Khalq, said in a statement Wednesday that it carried out two mortar attacks late Tuesday on military facilities in the capital. Earlier Tuesday, a bomb exploded at the Revolutionary Prosecutor's office in Tehran, in which official sources, speaking on customary condition of anonymity, said at least three people were killed and two injured. The Mujahedeen, the largest Iranian opposition group, also claimed responsibility for that bombing, saying the attacks were in retaliation for the killing of its members in recent months by the Iranian government. The group said it launched two mortar attacks late Tuesday on the Central Command Headquarters of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps and an hour later on the Defense Industries Organization. ``In the surprise attack (on IRGC headquarters), several Revolutionary Guards were killed or wounded and the headquarters' buildings were damaged,'' the group said in a statement faxed to The Associated Press in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. It did not claim any casualties for the attack on the defense industries building. However, Iranian radio said that an attempted attack by ``saboteurs'' at the headquarters of the IRGC Tuesday was foiled by security men, but gave no other details. It said the perpetrators fled. The three victims of Tuesday's explosion, including an Armenian named Wilhelm Vigen who worked as a technician at the government building, were buried Wednesday following funeral services in Tehran. Newspapers reported contradictory casualty figures, with one paper saying that five people were killed in the mid-morning blast and another reporting that nine people also were injured. The Gozaresh'e Rooz daily said that two women and three men had been killed. Meanwhile, sources said that police evacuated guests and staff at the Ferdowsi Hotel in central Tehran early Wednesday following a bomb threat made by a caller. No bomb was found at the hotel, which is close to the Foreign Ministry and military offices. A police official at the scene said the explosion at the Prosecutor's Office was caused by a bomb placed in a briefcase. The official Islamic Republic News Agency said Tuesday's blast was caused by explosives and indicated that the material was being brought to the court as evidence in a case under investigation when it went off accidentally. But Tehran television and radio only reported an explosion, without specifying if it was a bomb or saying whether there were any casualties. Bombings are rare in Tehran where security is tightly controlled. The last reported bombing in Tehran was four years ago when two devices went off in a commercial district but caused no fatalities. Those explosions remain a mystery. av-fsa-af-sf

BC-India-Nuclear,0463
Iran urges India and Pakistan to resume dialogue to ease tensions
By ASHOK SHARMA Associated Press Writer
NEW DELHI, India (AP) _ Iran on Wednesday urged India and Pakistan to talk to reduce tensions created by the nearly dozen nuclear tests they have conducted, striking a conciliatory note after earlier praising Pakistan's ``Islamic bomb.'' India has said its offer of talks with Pakistan has been on the table for weeks, but neither country has made a serious effort toward reopening peace negotiations begun under a previous Indian government. ``We believe in a nuclear weapons free zone in the region,'' Iranian Foreign Minister Kamal Kharrazi told reporters after meeting with Indian Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee in the Indian capital. Kharrazi is the first foreign dignitary to visit the region after India conducted five tests May 11-13 and Pakistan responded two weeks later with what it said were six tests. Predominately Hindu India and officially Islamic Pakistan have fought three wars since they won independence from the British rulers 50 years ago, and skirmishes still often breaks out across their border. Two of the wars were over the control of the disputed northern Himalayan territory of Kashmir. A top Indian foreign ministry official said India was ready for bilateral talks with Pakistan but found international concerns about the situation in South Asia were exaggerated. ``Life is normal. There is no ground for exaggeration and dramatizing the situation,'' said Foreign Secretary K. Raghunath, who attended Kharrazi's meeting with the Indian prime minister. The Indian foreign secretary said New Delhi sees no need for other countries to get involved in the Kashmiri dispute. Western leaders meeting Thursday in Geneva to discuss how to defuse nuclear tension between India and Pakistan may take up the question of Kashmir. Iran, Kharrazi said, has been very concerned about developments in South Asia following nuclear tests by India and Pakistan. But he welcomed the Pakistani tests. ``The development of a nuclear bomb by a Muslim country can act as a deterrent for Israel,'' he said. No Arab country is now believed capable of making a nuclear weapon, while Israel is considered an undeclared nuclear power. Iran has repeatedly denied U.S. and Israeli allegations that it is close to building a nuclear weapon. Kharrazi has said Iran's nuclear facilities are open to international inspectors. Kharrazi has said Iran was a signatory to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty and supported global disarmament. Kharrazi arrived in New Delhi on Tuesday after meeting with Pakistani leaders in Islamabad.

BC-Afghanistan-Quake-Relief,0339
UN and Red Cross trying to get food to hungry quake victims With Afghanistan-Quake, Afghanistan-Fighting
AP Photos By JUDITH INGRAM Associated Press Writer
FAISABAD, Afghanistan (AP) _ U.N. and Red Cross helicopters carried plastic sheeting and emergency food supplies to earthquake-shattered Afghan villages on Wednesday, in some cases to feed people who had not eaten in nearly five days. Piles of tent poles and tarpaulins, cakes of brown hand soap, stacks of flour and stretchers lay across the airstrip at Faisabad that has become the local headquarters for the rescue and relief effort following Saturday's deadly 6.9 magnitude quake. As many as 5,0000 people are believed to have died when the violent tremor shook the earth triggering landslides and collapsing entire villages. The extent of damage was still being assessed using helicopters to locate devastated villages that had not even been on the map. The surveying and relief efforts have been hampered by a severe lack of helicopters and fuel. The aid agencies got 20 barrels of fuel for helicopters on Wednesday, after putting out an emergency appeal for both fuel and helicopters. However it was still in Duchambe in neighboring Tajikistan. The helicopters were pressing on Wednesday into northern areas that had not yet been surveyed, said Juan Martinez, the Red Cross spokesman said. The helicopters dropped emergency supplies, aid workers quickly assessed further need and loaded the most badly injured on to the helicopters for delivery to the hospital in Faisalabad. In the town of Shari Basurkh many of the injured had not eaten since the quake hit on Saturday. Medical volunteers, who have been traveling in to the mountains each day, said there was a desperate need in many other places for food and water. As well there still were several villages accessible only by horse or donkey that aid workers have not been able to see from the ground.

BC-Philippines-Subic
Estrada to remove chairman of Subic freeport
MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ President-elect Joseph Estrada plans to replace the chairman of the Subic Bay Metropolitan Authority, one of the Philippines' most succesful economic ventures, when he takes office June 30. Estrada said Tuesday that Richard Gordon, a former mayor, will be among the officials he will replace after his inauguration. Gordon is credited with transforming the Subic freeport from a volcano-ravaged former U.S. naval base into a bustling trade, industry and tourism center. ``He has no monopoly on leadership,'' said Estrada, reacting to news reports that Gordon intended to resist the ouster. Gordon has refused to comment on Estrada's plan. Estrada said he will replace Gordon with former Congressman Felicito Payumo, a known critic of Gordon. Estrada was proclaimed winner of the May 11 presidential elections by Congress last Friday. Gordon, former mayor of Olongapo City, outside the Subic base, had fought fiercely against Philippine senators, including Estrada, who voted in 1991 not to extend the U.S. lease on the base. The naval facility was closed the following year. The base's closure caused more than 44,000 Filipinos to lose their jobs and dealt a severe blow to the economy of surrounding towns, including Olongapo, which provided services and served as red-light districts for U.S. servicemen. Subic had served as the largest U.S. naval base outside the United States and was a major supply and training base for its naval forces in the western Pacific. The 1991 eruption of nearby Mount Pinatubo hastened the departure of the Americans. After the Americans left, Gordon, backed by hundreds of volunteers worked feverishly to transform the 62,000-acre base into an industrial complex, free port and tourism center. Gordon, 45, is the grandson of an American who came to the Philippines when U.S. troops seized the islands in 1898. Several major international firms, mostly Taiwanese and Singaporean, have set up operations such as a container port, textile and electronics manufacturing and other enterprises at Subic. Gordon and Estrada had once been friends, having studied in the Jesuit-run Ateneo de Manila University. They were also among the mayors removed by former President Corazon Aquino in 1986 following a purge of officials who had worked with the late President Ferdinand Marcos.
