BC-Thailand-Hitler Potato Chips, 2nd Ld-Writethru
Ad agency withdraws Hitler potato chip commercials, posters
Eds: UPDATES with no decision about new screening procedures, financial details confidential, 8th graf. By PATRICK McDOWELL Associated Press Writer
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ An advertising agency Wednesday terminated a TV-and-poster campaign using images of Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler to sell potato chips following protests that the ads were repugnant. Leo Burnett Bangkok, the Thai office of the Chicago-based Leo Burnett agency, issued a statement reiterating apologies over the ads and said they were ``never intended to cause any ill feeling.'' Commercials will be withdrawn from television immediately and the more complicated removal of posters from thousands of tuk-tuks, the three-wheeled motorized taxis plying Bangkok's streets, will be completed by Sunday. Avi Nil, charge d'affaires of the Israeli Embassy, praised the agency for killing the ads once they became aware of how offensive they were. ``We're happy with this action,'' Nil said. ``If they had realized the real meaning to people like us and other victims of the Nazis, they would never have started in the first place.'' Nil said that the company's ``vigorous response shows there was really no bad intention.'' Israeli officials viewed the ads as morally unacceptable, saying Hitler should not be used as a means to make money. Hitler unleashed World War II in Europe and killed millions of people, including 6 million Jews, he considered subhuman, the worst genocide the world has ever seen. Simone Wheeler, a spokeswoman for Leo Burnett, said financial details of the contract were confidential. No decision has been made on how to replace the ads or on new screening procedures to avoid a similar mistake in the future. The commercial for X potato chips, targeted at Thai teen-agers, depicts Hitler giving a Nazi salute and cuts to a woman who casts a spell on him as he eats the chips, hoping to change his evil ways. A Nazi swastika turns into the product logo as the transformation is completed. Leo Burnett said the ads, shown only in Thailand, were meant to show the world would be a better place if happiness prevailed. The chips are made by Food Processing Co. Ltd., a Thai firm. Leo Burnett Bangkok apologized for the ads Sunday and had been discussing the campaign, originally set to run through June, with its client for the past few days. ``The agency acknowledges Hitler as one of history's most despicable dictators and never intended to suggest otherwise,'' the statement said. Nil has said the controversy should raise awareness about Hitler among Thais. Consciousness about the Nazis is somewhat less in Asia, where their armies did not reach, than in the West. Thailand, a predominantly Buddhist country, has in the past expressed outrage over ads using actors dressed as monks.

Chen said China may be able to withstand pressure to devalue its currency as it continues to record trade surpluses and attract more foreign investment. Since Taliban troops threw out the former military chief Ahmed Shah Massood from Kabul in September 1996, the city of barely 750,000 people has been relatively peaceful. While Massood and Afghanistan's President Burhanuddin Rabbani ruled Kabul between 1992 and 1996 the city was under almost constant siege by rival Muslim groups who daily lobbed rockets into the city. It is estimated that 50,000 people -- most of them civilians -- died during that period when Rabbani was battling rival groups, led by Gulbuddin Hekmatyar and former communist general Rashid Dostum.

In desperate bid to raise cash, Russia offers rare treasury bills auction results, EDITS, TRIMS.
Eds: UPDATES throughout with market rallying higher, treasury AP Photos planned By MAURA REYNOLDS Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ The Russian government issued rare one-week treasury bills Wednesday in a desperate attempt to refill its drained coffers and stabilize its turbulent financial markets. The move is one of a number of measures the Kremlin hopes will resolve Russia's financial crisis, which was marked by a steep drop in the stock market last week and threatened to trigger a costly devaluation of the ruble. However, the stock exchange has regained significant ground in the past two days, rising 12 percent Tuesday to wipe out the previous day's 10 percent drop. That climb continued Wednesday, with the market climbing another 9 percent by early afternoon. Moreover, the ruble has been steady in recent days without major support from Central Bank, which says it has plenty of reserves left to prevent a run on the currency. Altogether, the Russian stock market is down about 50 percent from the beginning of the year _ the world's worst performance and a sharp change from the previous year's record growth of 98 percent. The new treasury bills offered Wednesday are designed to raise quick cash so Russia can keep up with payments on its existing debt and reassure investors that it will not default. The government sold most of the issue by midday, agreeing to one-week yields of an average 40 percent. ``This indicates reasonably strong demand,'' said Robert Devane, head of fixed income at Moscow brokerage Troika-Dialog. Devane said rumors of an international aid package for Russia have soothed the markets. Longer-term treasury bills were also offered during the weekly auction, which the government hoped would raise about dlrs 16.5 billion. Russia's government has a serious cash flow problem, largely because it has been unable to create an effective tax collection system. As a result it has borrowed heavily to finance the resulting federal budget deficit. Nonetheless there has been too little cash in the system to pay state workers and pensioners on time, a situation that led to a wave of labor strikes last week. The government has blamed those strikes, combined with lingering nerves over the Asian financial crisis and a drop in world prices for Russia's main exports of oil and gas, for triggering last week's stock collapse. Speculation is growing that Russia will be offered a rescue package from the International Monetary Fund or its colleagues in the G-8. Deputy finance ministers from the so-called Group of Eight industrialized democracies were to confer on the issue by telephone Wednesday. But Kremlin officials have denied requesting such aid, saying they would prefer to fix their problems themselves by reducing government spending and improving tax collection. Wednesday's auction is the first time Russia has ever offered one-week treasury bills _ an extremely short term. Most Russian treasury bills are for several months or a year, while terms in the West can reach 30 years. (mr/ml)

BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo, 1st Ld-Writethru
Kosovo Albanians flood over border. hiding in mountainous border region; trims.
Eds: UPDATES with reports of refugee influx continuing, 50,000 said AP Photos By MERITA DHIMGJOKA Associated Press Writer
PADESH, Albania (AP) _ A major Serb assault on ethnic Albanian villages in Kosovo drove a new wave of refugees into Albania and sent thousands more seeking the safety of border highlands, news reports said Wednesday. Albania's state-run ATA news agency said between 1,500-2,000 refugees crossed overnight into Albania, and another 3,000 were approaching the border. A refugee ATA did not identify said as many as 50,000 more were on the Kosovo side of the hills separating the Serbian province from Albania. They were also walking toward the border, said the report, which could not be independently confirmed. Local authorities in northeastern Albania, site of most of the crossings, said that with more refugees arriving by the hour, the 25 tons of aid sent Tuesday by the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees was not sufficient to feed the masses. The refugee influx first began growing late last week as Serb police and the Serb-dominated Yugoslav army stepped up their campaign to crush the pro-separatist Kosovo Liberation Army. The militants have been gaining in popularity and numbers after years of heavy-handed rule by Serbian authorities in the secessionist southern province, where ethnic Albanians represent 90 percent of the population of 2.2 million. Trekking over the mountains for up to two days, refugees fleeing to neighboring Albania described artillery bombardments that forced out entire villages and house-burnings they said were clearly intended to drive them out. There have been no reports like those in Bosnia of massive civilian roundups or massacres in the Kosovo campaign, which the Serbs insist targets guerrillas. But attacks on villages, the exodus of civilians and the deaths of women and children have prompted increasing comparisons to the ethnic war in Bosnia and its atrocities. More than 200 people have been killed in the province in the past three months. The growing violence has sparked alarm among Western powers that the fighting could spill over into neighboring Balkan nations. U.S. President Bill Clinton told a visiting delegation of ethnic Albanians in Washington last week that the United States ``shall not tolerate another Bosnia in Kosovo.'' But the West repeatedly has failed to get Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic to halt the Serb crackdown in Kosovo, and has yet to devise a strategy for how to resolve the worsening conflict. A NATO official in Brussels, Belgium, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the alliance was ``preoccupied'' with Kosovo and would debate what to do at a NATO Council meeting Wednesday. Those concerns prompted NATO last week to consider possible troop deployments in Albania and Macedonia. But Russia said Tuesday that NATO cannot post troops in Albania without the approval of the United Nations. Based on information from the refugees and ethnic Albanian officials in Kosovo, the latest campaign is concentrated in the western region of Decani, where the Serbs deployed thousands of additional paramilitary forces and are pulverizing 10 towns and villages with artillery. The town of Decani, with a population of about 20,000, was in ruins with no sign of life, according to the pro-Albanian Kosovo Information Center. Dead cattle littered the streets, the center said. While the Kosovo Liberation Army controls as much as a third of the province, several refugees said they saw no sign of it in the sealed-off area under siege by Serb forces. Communications with western Kosovo remained cut off. But a monitor for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe who spoke on condition of anonymity said on Tuesday military action in the area around the border appeared to have declined. Ethnic Albanian leaders publicly acknowledged the existence of the Kosovo Liberation Army for the first time Tuesday, noting that the ``massive Serb aggression is meeting heavy resistance'' from the people and the KLA. Hong Kong focuses on economic woes with high-level meetings thruout
Eds: LEADS thruout to add details of government meeting; TRIMS By PRISCILLA CHEUNG Associated Press Writer
HONG KONG (AP) _ Faced with a united demand for action from Hong Kong's political parties, the government on Wednesday announced a 12-point program to create 100,000 jobs and stimulate the recession-bound economy. Politicians, economists, business leaders and labor unionists all said they doubted whether the program was enough to get the economy moving. And the official who announced the package cautioned Hong Kong not to expect too much. Political parties from across Hong Kong's spectrum reached consensus on their own six-point program in a separate meeting. With unemployment at 14-year high and the economy shrinking for the first time in nearly 13 years, the parties said the government should ``put money back in people's pockets.'' Financial Secretary Donald Tsang told reporters after the first employment task force meeting that the government will push ahead infrastructure projects and expand maintenance, as well as social services. It also will improve education and employment retraining, he said. The task force, including government officials, academics, and representatives from business and unions, will meet regularly, Tsang said. In keeping with the government's view that there is only a limited amount it can do to improve the economy, Tsang told the public to not expect immediate relief. ``We cannot create jobs just for the sake of creating jobs,'' he said. ``We must ensure the international community and (Hong Kong) that the ... government has not abandoned financial prudence.'' Unemployment is officially 3.9 percent, although unions say the figure is much higher. It is expected to increase as Hong Kong, which avoided the worst of Asia's economic crisis for nearly a year, settles into recession. The economy contracted 2 percent in the first quarter of the year, and one senior official said late Tuesday that it would likely shrink in the second quarter, too. That technically would put Hong Kong in recession. Cheng Yiu-tong, chairman of the Federation of Trade Unions, a task force member, said the government package was a step forward, but ``too small and too powerless.'' Another member, clothing retailer Michael Tien, said he was satisfied with the package, but added that ``the government can't help much in a crisis in a free market.'' Impatient with the government, seven major political parties held their own economic summit. The meeting included government critics, pro-business parties that generally support the government, and grassroots pro-China parties. Together, they won more than two-thirds of the seats May 24 in Hong Kong's new legislature. Their ability to bridge differences could mean that, despite being controlled by pro-business and pro-China elites, the legislature may give Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa a hard time on economic issues. ``The government is wealthy,'' said Allen Lee, chairman of the pro-business Liberal Party, who chaired the meeting. ``It's the citizens who don't have money.'' The parties' proposals included cuts in public transportation charges and government fees, and more assistance to small- and medium-sized businesses that form the backbone of Hong Kong's economy. They also want a review of required tax prepayment. To create jobs, they say the government should push ahead infrastructure projects and provide more social services. The government also should find ways to hold down interest rates, which have remained high to defend Hong Kong's link to the U.S. dollar, the representatives said. Lee said the parties would back a deficit budget next year if neccessary.

Cambodia's King Sihanouk meets with former Khmer Rouge nemesis
By KER MUNTHIT Associated Press Writer
PHNOM PENH, Cambodia (AP) _ Cambodia's King Norodom Sihanouk granted an audience Wednesday to Ieng Sary, a former high-ranking Khmer Rouge leader who was his jailer in the late 1970s. A palace source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that the king cordially received Ieng Sary, whom he reluctantly pardoned in 1996 to ensure the breakup of the Khmer Rouge, for an hour at his palace in the northwestern town of Siem Reap. Ieng Sary oversaw the house arrest of the king during the Khmer Rouge's genocidal rule. In the past, Sihanouk has called Ieng Sary a ``psychopath'' and shown contempt for his uncouth manner and failure to show respect when Sihanouk was a nominal ally of the Khmer Rouge in the early 1970s before he became their prisoner. Ieng Sary, for his part, has described how the guerrillas used an alliance with Sihanouk to help win power, once likening him to a ``water buffalo who will help us cross the river.'' At least 14 of the king's relatives and children died under Khmer Rouge rule. Details of the meeting were not available. Ieng Sary was accompanied by Ei Chhean, his second-in-command at stronghold of Pailin in western Cambodia, the source said. The audience was the first meeting between the king and Ieng Sary since Sihanouk granted him amnesty in 1996 for crimes against humanity. It was a political deal undertaken to ensure the eventual defection of some 10,000 war-weary Khmer Rouge guerrillas to the government. The defections marked the beginning of the end for the Khmer Rouge, which is now down to a few hundred guerrillas along the Thai border. Their longtime leader, Pol Pot, Ieng Sary's brother-in-law, died of a purported heart attack April 15. Pol Pot had been deposed as leader by other guerrillas last year. His death has spurred new calls by human-rights groups and some Western governments, led by the United States, for the trial of remaining Khmer Rouge leaders. Ieng Sary, who was foreign minister under Pol Pot and a member of the group's inner circle, is likely to stay protected because of the 1996 amnesty. He has offered to stand trial knowing he will probably never face a court hearing. Sihanouk was toppled by a U.S.-backed coup in 1970 and lent his support to the Khmer Rouge, then a small band of jungle guerrillas, against the new government. But he quickly became their pawn. After seizing power in 1975, the Khmer Rouge turned Cambodia into a slave labor camp and caused the deaths of as many as 2 million people. A Vietnamese invasion overthrew them in 1979, but they continued to wage guerrilla warfare against successive central governments.

AP Photos Available By LEON BARKHO Associated Press Writer
Al-NIBAI, Iraq (AP) _ U.N. weapons inspectors on Wednesday searched through reeds and sand dunes for missing missile parts in a bid to verify Iraq's claims that it has buried all its biological and chemical missile warheads. Some 27 experts, under German Jean Jano, split into three groups early in the morning _ some wearing protective suits, masks, boots and gloves _ and began a probe for the missing missiles pieces. Others supervised an earth-moving machine as it uncovered the nose cone of a missile warhead. ``This belongs to a conventional warhead,'' shouted an Iraqi engineer. Al-Nibai is 45 kilometers (28 miles) north of Baghdad. In 1991, Iraq chose to destroy a great number of its long-range missiles and bury them there rather than declare them to U.N inspectors. ``We hope that this work will help to settle some of the still outstanding issues concerning the missile warheads,'' Jano, 61, told The Associated Press. The area where Iraq unilaterally buried its missiles instead of declaring them to the inspectors is vast and the experts have with them latest metal detectors to determine where exactly the parts lie. ``We've with us some of the latest state-of-the-art high-tech equipment,'' Vincent Murphy, a U.S. geophysicist told the AP. Experts with magnetic and electro-magnetic sensors nailed small, red flags on the ground to determine where the next digging should be. ``It is all digitally recorded. The data is brought back in the recorder to one of the vehicles and downloaded to the laptop,'' said Murphy, a 69-year-old geophysicist from Boston. He said the advanced equipment is needed because no aerial photography or satellite images will penetrate the type of soil at al-Nibai. Jano, an aerodynamics expert, said inspectors have found ``for instance, aluminum canisters that are used for chemical agents and some stainless steel canisters... used for biological agents.'' But he would not say what they have collected so far is sufficient to verify Iraqi claims. He said another team of experts will arrive in Baghdad soon to analyze the findings, now stored at Taji, a military camp 20 kilometers (12 miles) north of the capital, Baghdad. Accounting for special warheads is one of the main hurdles in Iraq's efforts to declare itself clean of prohibited missiles with ranges beyond 150 kilometers (90 miles). Senior Iraqi officers looked on as the experts, in white protective suits, moved around. The Iraqis refuse to wear safety gear, saying there is nothing toxic about the pieces of scrap underground. U.N. monitors' suits are burned every day. Inspectors are also under instructions to wash their hands and feet in a bleach solution before leaving the site. Jano would not say how many missiles and warheads Iraq buried in Al-Nabai. He would also shun questions on whether the current excavation scheduled to end on June 18 will remove U.N. doubts about the warheads. But Jano said he hoped to do all that is required from him by the end of his mission in the light of ``excellent cooperation'' he has been receiving from the Iraqi side. At the United Nations, Iraqi officials tried Tuesday to convince the Security Council that Baghdad had met the terms for ending economic sanctions by destroying all illegal weapons. U.S. and British diplomats said they remained unconvinced. Destroying all long-range missiles and chemical, nuclear and biological weapons is the main condition for the council to end the crippling sanctions slapped on Baghdad in 1990 after President Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait. lb-sf

Eugene de Kock arrived under guard in an armored personnel carrier in a police convoy at the courthouse, where the former president is on trial for refusing to appear before a panel probing apartheid crimes. The case has turned into an examination of Botha's possible complicity in state-sanctioned killings and violence when he was head of state from 1978-1989 and presided over the State Security Council, which coordinated the crackdown against opponents of white rule. Standing in the witness dock just 10 feet from Botha, de Kock was asked by prosecutor Bruce Morrison for his interpretation of the words ``eliminate'' and ``neutralize,'' used in State Security Council meetings in reference to how to deal with opponents of apartheid. ``In the terminology that they used it means killing,'' said de Kock, whose ruthlessness earned him the nickname Prime Evil. When Morrison asked de Kock how he felt about serving two life sentences plus 212 years for murder and other crimes while the leaders of the apartheid-era governments were free, de Kock voice quivered with anger as he spat out his response. ``They want to eat lamb but they don't want to see the blood and the guts,'' de Kock said ``They are cowards. They will remain that.'' Botha, wearing a grey business suit, looked on impassively. De Kock, a decorated former commander of the Vlakplaas police unit that assassinated black activists, did not mention the 82-year-old Botha by name. But the implication was clear. De Kock also recalled receiving the Police Star for Outstanding Service for bombing the London headquarters of the African National Congress in 1982. De Kock testified that the medal was normally only awarded to generals, and that only the head of state _ Botha at the time _ could authorize it. Aiding the case against Botha could earn de Kock points in his own amnesty application with the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, the panel which Botha refused to testify before. If Botha, by snubbing the panel, had intended to avoid public scrutiny of apartheid-era atrocities, it has backfired. Earlier testimony on his trial this week focused on the 1988 bombing of Khotso House, the Johannesburg headquarters of the South African Council of Churches, which opposed apartheid. A former head of South Africa's police has testified that Botha ordered the bombing. De Kock testified that he placed the bombs in the basement of the building. Asked by Morrison if the government had disapproved of such actions, de Kock said: ``No they did not. They actually encouraged it.'' Apartheid-era government leaders claim such attacks were the work of rogue operatives. Early Wednesday, Botha's defense team cross-examined two witnesses to the Khotso House bombing: security guard Welcome Ntumba and the former leader of the Methodist Church in South Africa, the Rev. Peter Storey. Defense attorney Lappe Laubscher, who had opposed the calling of the witnesses as irrelevant to the charges, declined to ask any questions. Storey, who lives in Delaware, Ohio, asked the court to pursue whoever was responsible for the attack. ``I have come a long way to give evidence here and I hope that there will be clarification about who stands accountable for the explosion,'' he said. ``It was in my view the most violent act by the apartheid state against the church of God.'' Botha denies he ordered the bombing. The trial is being held in the southern coastal city of George, near Botha's retirement home. Apartheid ended after Botha's successor, President F.W. de Klerk, negotiated with the ANC, which had been waging a guerrilla campaign against apartheid. The talks culminated in the nation's first all-race elections in 1994, which the ANC won. (ph-aos)

BC-Iran-Bombings,0524
Second bomb explodes in Tehran, no injuries reported
By AFSHIN VALINEJAD Associated Press Writer
TEHRAN, Iran (AP) _ Tensions mounted Wednesday, a day after bomb attacks on government sites killed at least three people in northern Tehran. State-run radio reported a bomb explosion at a government building in northern Tehran late Tuesday, but did not say if there were any casualties or give the cause of the blast, nor did it identify the government building. But the Iraq-based Iranian opposition, Mujahedeen Khalq, claimed responsibility for a bomb that exploded Tuesday at the Revolutionary Prosecutor's office in Tehran. In a statement Wednesday, the Mujahedeen, the largest Iranian opposition group, said it also carried out two mortar attacks late Tuesday on military facilities in the capital. At least three people were killed and two injured in the prosecutor's office explosion, according to official sources speaking on customary condition of anonymity. The Mujahedeen said the attacks were in retaliation for the killing of its members in recent months by the Iranian government. The group said it launched two mortar attacks late Tuesday on the Central Command Headquarters of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, where ``several Revolutionary Guards were killed or wounded, and the headquarters' buildings were damaged,'' the group said in a statement faxed to The Associated Press in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. An hour later, it attacked the Defense Industries Organization but did not claim any casualties, it said. However, Iranian radio said security men foiled an attempted attack by ``saboteurs'' at the headquarters of the IRGC on Tuesday, but gave no other details. It said the perpetrators fled. The three victims of Tuesday's explosion, including an Armenian named Wilhelm Vigen who worked as a technician at the prosecutor's office building, were buried Wednesday following funeral services in Tehran. Newspapers reported contradictory casualty figures. One said five people were killed, another reported nine people also were injured. The Gozaresh'e Rooz daily said two women and three men were killed. Meanwhile, sources said police evacuated guests and staff at the Ferdowsi Hotel in central Tehran early Wednesday following a bomb threat made by a caller. No bomb was found at the hotel, which is close to the Foreign Ministry and military offices. A police official at the scene said the explosion at the prosecutor's office was caused by a bomb placed in a briefcase. The official Islamic Republic News Agency said the blast was caused by explosives and indicated the material was being brought to the court as evidence in a case under investigation when it went off accidentally. But Tehran television and radio only reported an explosion, with no further details. Bombings are rare in Tehran where security is tightly controlled. The last reported bombing in Tehran was four years ago when two devices went off in a commercial district but caused no fatalities. Those explosions remain a mystery.

A summary of financial and business news from The Associated Press at 1100. Stories carry ``f'' or ``i'' category codes and move on this circuit in expanded form: HONG KONG (AP) _ Most Asian stock markets recovered slightly Wednesday on a stronger yen and a technical rebound after heavy recent losses. But stocks in Indonesia slid amid concern over the domestic economic and political situation. Despite the rallies in many areas, market players remained pessimistic as foreign funds continued to pull out on concerns over Asia's dismal economic prospects. Most countries have reported a contraction in their economies in the first quarter as a result of the regional financial crisis. Meanwhile, more student demonstrations Wednesday hurt market sentiment in Indonesia, dealers said. Jakarta's benchmark JSX composite index suffered a 1.7 percent drop to close at 392.608 points. In Tokyo, stocks also fell amid lingering pessimism in the outlook of Japan's economy, after the 1.52-percent rally the previous day. The benchmark 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average shed 207.45 points, or 1.33 percent, to close at 15,347.00. (ASIAN MARKETS) MOSCOW (AP) _ The Russian government issued rare one-week treasury bills Wednesday in a desperate attempt to refill its drained coffers and stabilize its turbulent financial markets. The move is one of a number of measures the Kremlin hopes will resolve Russia's financial crisis, which was marked by a steep drop in the stock market last week and threatened to trigger a costly devaluation of the ruble. However, the stock exchange regained significant ground Tuesday, rising 12 percent to wipe out the previous day's 10 percent drop. That climb continued Wednesday, with the market rising more than 5 percent by mid-day. Moreover, the ruble has been steady in recent days without major support from Central Bank, which says it has plenty of reserves left to prevent a run on the currency. (RUSSIA-ECONOMY) SEOUL, South Korea (AP) _ Hyundai Electronics Co. temporarily stopped making computer memory chips Wednesday to help ease a global supply glut and shore up falling chip prices. The move by Hyundai, South Korea's No. 2 chip maker, was expected to be followed by Samsung and LG. The three South Korean firms supply 40 percent of the world's memory chips, called Dynamic Random Access Memory (DRAM) chips. Hyundai said its plant outside Seoul will remain idle until next Tuesday. The company normally produces 19 million 16-megabit DRAM chips and eight million 64-megabit DRAM chips a month, or 10 percent of the world supply. Samsung Electronics Co., the world's No. 1 DRAM chip maker, said it also was considering cutting production. LG Semicon Co., South Korea's third largest chip maker, also had cutback plans but refused to disclose details. South Korean chip makers have suffered sharp drops in prices that have eroded their earnings. (SKOREA-CHIP MAKERS) SINGAPORE (AP) _ Singapore released figures Wednesday showing a dramatic increase in layoffs and unemployment during the current economic slowdown, and predicted harder times ahead. Labor department officials said there was also less work available, while the entire job picture worsened ``significantly in the first quarter of 1998, as impact of the regional economic and currency crisis sank in.'' The report from the Ministry of Manpower, as the labor department is officially called, is the latest sign that the nearly year-old Asian economic turmoil is taking a heavy toll on this usually prosperous city state. The report said layoffs reached a record high for any quarterly figure at 7,131, while the number of job openings dropped to 26,148, 44 percent lower than the same period last year. The ministry added that demand for new workers is likely to fall further and unemployment will rise as local graduates enter the work force in the next few months. Chatu Mongkol Sonakul, who is spearheading a shakeup of the Thai financial sector since taking office a month ago, refused to provide details on the offering for state-owned Krung Thai Bank. The Manager, a local business daily, reported Wednesday that the bank plans to raise 70 billion baht (dlrs 1.7 billion) in new capital this year to prop up liquidity. The move would mark the second time Krung Thai Bank has been forced to raise capital since the Thai financial crisis erupted last July and triggered a chain reaction of woes across Asia. In a Cabinet meeting a day earlier, the government sought to find ways to minimize the impact of sanctions, most notably from the United States and Japan. The government plans to cut spending overall by 50 percent, but the details will be worked out over the next 24 hours, said the independent daily newspaper, The News. India has said its offer of talks with Pakistan has been on the table for weeks, but neither country has made a serious effort toward reopening peace negotiations begun under a previous Indian government. Kharrazi is the first foreign dignitary to visit the region after India conducted five tests May 11-13 and Pakistan responded two weeks later with what it said were six tests. A top Indian foreign ministry official said India was ready for bilateral talks with Pakistan but found international concerns about the situation in South Asia were exaggerated. (INDIA-PAKISTAN) JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Student protesters shouted ``Hang Suharto'' outside Parliament and staged a rowdy protest in a main street on Wednesday, ignoring an appeal by Indonesia's military chief to halt to ``out of control'' condemnation of the ousted president. Suharto, a former army general who turns 77 next Monday, faces growing demands that he surrender riches accumulated during three decades in power. About 2,000 banner-waving students rallied in a highway outside Parliament, demanding that Suharto be put on trial for economic crimes. Soldiers closed off the road. The protesters scoffed at a pledge by new President B.J. Habibie to hold general elections in 1999, saying he was a corrupt lackey of Suharto and should step aside. A close ally of Suharto for decades, the new head of state is bowing to popular demands for democratic reform. In the meantime, Air France said its Wednesday schedule included only 17 percent of its usual long-distance flights, 30 percent of its short and medium-distance routes from Charles de Gaulle Airport and 43 percent from Orly. BAGHDAD, Iraq (AP) _ A plane carrying 40 tons of medicine and medical equipment arrived here Wednesday from the United Arab Emirates. The aid was ordered by Emirates President Sheik Zayed Bin Sultan Al Nahyan, said Saeed al-Mansouri of the Emirates Red Crescent Society, ``They (the goods) will be flowing from now on. There will be more shipments... These are the orders of the president,'' al-Mansouri told reporters. Sheik Zayed is the most vociferous among leaders of the Gulf Arab states to normalize ties with Baghdad ruptured after Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait. ``This present is an expression that the people of the Emirates want to take part in alleviating the suffering of the Iraqi children, women and the sick,'' al-Mansouri said. He said another plane carrying an additional 40 tons of aid will arrive Friday. The goods were collected by the Red Crescent Society, the Islamic equivalent of the Red Cross, which has sent more than 22 million dirhams (dlrs 6 million) worth of aid to Iraq since 1996. The charity organization has said it plans to open an office in Baghdad by the end of the year to coordinate the distribution of humanitarian aid. The Emirates has sent six planes to Iraq in the past six months carrying food, medicine and clothing, the official Emirates News Agency said. Iraq has been under U.N. sanctions since its Kuwait invasion. The sanctions bar it from exporting oil, except for a limited quantity under U.N. supervision, and also prohibit direct flights to the country. The United Nations has to approve humanitarian flights. Arab states have recently increased their shipments of aid to Iraq, reflecting widespread opposition to the sanctions among their populations. The U.N. Security Council says the sanctions will not be lifted until Iraq has eliminated its weapons of mass destruction. The Iraqi government says at least 1.5 million deaths during the past seven years have been caused by shortages brought about by the sanctions. The U.N. Children's Fund says that 960,000 Iraqi children are suffering from malnutrition. lb-fsa-sf

England goalkeeper Seaman says other players were also drunk
LONDON (AP) _ Paul Gascoigne wasn't the only drunken England soccer player the night before coach Glenn Hoddle announced he was dropping Gascoigne from the World Cup team. England's No. 1 goalkeeper David Seaman said ``quite a few'' other England internationals were also drunk at a team party at their training base in southern Spain. Hoddle cut the 31-year-old midfielder Sunday because he said he was out of shape, setting off a controversy about whether one of England's best midfielders should have made the team. Gascoigne later admitted he was drunk at the party and then said he was drinking beer during a golf game Sunday just hours before Hoddle gave him the bad news. ``The party was for everyone to let their hair down _ all the players, all the staff,'' Seaman said in Wednesday's tabloid Mirror newspaper. ``Paul, like the rest of us, hadn't had a drink for a week and he got drunk pretty quickly because of it. But we were all having a few drinks. It wasn't a wild night, there was no one else in the bar apart from us. ``Quite a few of the other lads were drunk too, it was not an issue. He wasn't the worst offender by any means. Paul was pretty relaxed, pretty calm, the drink just went to his head a bit.'' Gascoigne, who became almost a cult figure after leading England to the semifinals of the 1990 World Cup in Italy, has had more downs that ups since then. He's been frequently injured, lambasted for an erratic personal life that included hard-drinking with celebrity friends, and was forced to apologize after newspapers 18 months ago reported he'd beaten his wife. Since he was cut Sunday, public opinion seems to have landed on the side of Hoddle. Meanwhile, the British tabloid press _ devouring its favorite kind of story _ continues to play the story as front-page news. ``England's Official Beerleader,'' read the tabloid Sun's Wednesday headline, with another headline promoting Gascoigne's open letter to his teammates and friends. ``I feel I've let youse down, lads,'' said Gascoigne, who is reported to be paid by the Sun for his contributions. ATHENS, Greece (AP) _ Four strong earthquakes shook central Greece on Wednesday, but caused no injuries or damage. The temblors, with preliminary magnitudes between 4.5 and 5.2, occurred between 11:36 and 11:49 a.m. (0836 and 0849 GMT) with an epicenter under the sea bed 210 kilometers (131 miles) north of Athens, the Athens Geodynamic Institute said. The quakes were felt in parts of central Greece and the northern province of Halkidiki, as well as on the Aegean island of Limnos, the institute said. Seismologists said it was too early to judge whether the four quakes signaled an increase in the area's seismic activity, although the 5.2 temblor appeared to be the main quake. The strongest quake in the area, with a magnitude of 7.2, occurred in 1981. A quake of moment magnitude 2.5 to 3 is the smallest generally felt by people. A quake of magnitude 4 often causes slight damage. Magnitude 5 can produce moderate damage. Magnitude 6 causes severe damage under a populate area, while a magnitude seven indicates a major earthquake capable of widespread, heavy damage. (eb)

Apartheid death squad commander testifies at former president's trial
Eds: ADDS color, possible sentence Botha faces if convicted AP Photos staffing By PAUL HARRIS Associated Press Writer
GEORGE, South Africa (AP) _ The apartheid state's most notorious killer testified Wednesday in former President P.W. Botha's trial that white-led governments had ordered black activists killed and denounced his former leaders as ``cowards.'' A major problem came home to roost for Botha when former police Col. Eugene de Kock arrived under guard in an armored personnel carrier in a police convoy at the courthouse, where the former president is on trial for refusing to appear before a panel probing apartheid crimes. The case has turned into an examination of Botha's possible complicity in state-sanctioned killings and violence when he was head of state from 1978-1989 and presided over the State Security Council, which coordinated the crackdown against opponents of white rule. Standing in the witness dock just 10 feet from Botha, de Kock was asked by prosecutor Bruce Morrison for his interpretation of the words ``eliminate'' and ``neutralize,'' used in State Security Council meetings in reference to how to deal with opponents of apartheid. ``In the terminology that they used it means killing,'' said de Kock, peering at the packed courtroom benches through thick-lensed rectangular spectacles. When Morrison asked de Kock how he felt about serving two life sentences plus 212 years for murder and other crimes while the leaders of the apartheid-era governments were free, the decorated former policeman's voice quivered with anger as he spat out his response. ``They want to eat lamb but they don't want to see the blood and the guts,'' said de Kock, whose ruthlessness earned him the nickname Prime Evil. ``They are cowards. They will remain that.'' Botha, wearing a grey business suit, looked on impassively. De Kock, a former commander of the Vlakplaas police unit that assassinated black activists, did not mention the 82-year-old Botha by name. But the implication was clear. De Kock also recalled receiving the Police Star for Outstanding Service for bombing the London headquarters of the African National Congress in 1982. De Kock testified that the medal was normally only awarded to generals, and that only the head of state _ Botha at the time _ could authorize it. Aiding the case against Botha could earn de Kock points in his own amnesty application with the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, the panel which Botha refused to testify before. If Botha, by snubbing the panel, had intended to avoid public scrutiny of apartheid-era atrocities, it has backfired. Earlier testimony on his trial this week focused on the 1988 bombing of Khotso House, the Johannesburg headquarters of the South African Council of Churches, which opposed apartheid. A former head of South Africa's police has testified that Botha ordered the bombing. De Kock testified that he placed the bombs in the basement of the building. Asked by Morrison if the government had disapproved of such actions, de Kock said: ``No they did not. They actually encouraged it.'' Apartheid-era government leaders claim such attacks were the work of rogue operatives. Early Wednesday, Botha's defense team cross-examined two witnesses to the Khotso House bombing: security guard Welcome Ntumba and the former leader of the Methodist Church in South Africa, the Rev. Peter Storey. Defense attorney Lappe Laubscher, who had opposed the calling of the witnesses as irrelevant to the charges, declined to ask any questions. Storey, who lives in Delaware, Ohio, asked the court to pursue whoever was responsible for the attack. ``I have come a long way to give evidence here and I hope that there will be clarification about who stands accountable for the explosion,'' he said. ``It was in my view the most violent act by the apartheid state against the church of God.'' Botha denies he ordered the bombing. The trial is being held in the southern coastal city of George, near Botha's retirement home. He faces up to two years in prison and unspecified fines if convicted of contempt of the Truth Commission's subpoenas. Apartheid ended after Botha's successor, President F.W. de Klerk, negotiated with the ANC, which had been waging a guerrilla campaign against apartheid. The talks culminated in the nation's first all-race elections in 1994, which the ANC won. (ph-aos)

BC-Hungary-Viagra
Viagra on the black market; officials seek ad ban
BUDAPEST, Hungary (AP) _ Newspaper ads in Hungary are illegally touting Viagra, the much-hyped but unauthorized new impotency pill, prompting new warnings from Hungarian officials. ``Until someone dies, all we can do is ask that the law on advertising and regulations on commerce in drugs be enforced,'' Dr. Tamas Paal, head of the National Pharmaceutical Directorate, was quoted as saying by the daily Magyar Hirlap on Wednesday. Several newspapers have advertised the pill in violation of the law, Paal said. A single pill can fetch 2,000 forints (dlrs 10) on the black market, according to a doctor on a state-run radio call-in show Wednesday. The average monthly income in Hungary is dlrs 280. Paal said authorization for the commercial sale of any imported drug takes from six months to up to three years. Dr. Endre Juhasz, a urologist, warned in the daily that before taking Viagra, the patient must undergo a medical examination as potency disorders may have a variety of causes. (ab/dc)

Amway plans to offer financial services in Thailand
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ The Thai affiliate of the U.S. multi-level marketing firm Amway plans to offer mortgage and leasing services, the Thai company's general manager was quoted Wednesday as saying. Amway (Thailand) general manager Preecha Prakobkit said his company expect to finalize within two months a strategic partnership with a foreign bank in order to begin providing financial services, the newspaper The Nation reported Wednesday. He did not name the bank. Amway has already moved into financial services in other countries, providing home mortgage and auto leasing services in the United States and Australia, and a credit card payment system in Japan, Hong Kong and Taiwan, The Nation said. In Thailand the company plans by the end of the year to launch a credit card payment system which could be used by its 140,000 sales representatives and their customers. Amway's sales in Thailand last year totalled 4.8 billion baht (dlrs 114 million),the newspaper reported. The Michigan-based Amway Corp. reported record worldwide sales of dlrs 7 billion for the fiscal year ending Aug. 31, 1997, a 3 percent increase over the year before. The privately-owned company, based in suburban Grand Rapids, sells more than 400 products _ from soap to vitamins to cosmetics _ through independent dealers around the world.

BC-Sports-Tennis-Kuerten's Tantrum, 2nd Ld-Writethru,
Kuerten apologizes for throwing racket at umpire AP Sports Writer
Eds: UPDATES with Kuerten apology By ROB GLOSTER
PARIS (AP) _ Defending French Open singles champion Gustavo Kuerten apologized Wednesday for throwing his racket at an umpire, saying he hopes the incident ``will make me a more mature guy.'' Kuerten, voted by the media last year as the player they liked best, was disqualified in a doubles match Tuesday night for throwing his racket at umpire Bruno Rebeuh. The racket hit a fan sitting behind Rebeuh, but the fan apparently was not hurt. ``I'm so sorry for what happened and I regret what I did,'' the Brazilian said in a prepared statement. ``I know that this will make me a more mature guy and will make me grow. I want to make it clear that I never had the intention of hurting anyone on or off the court.'' The outburst by Kuerten, who faces a fine, evoked memories of a racket-throwing tantrum that led to John McEnroe being tossed out of the 1990 Australian Open. Kuerten, who made a storybook run to the men's title last year as an unseeded player and became a fan favorite at Roland Garros, was knocked out in singles last week in the second round. He was teamed with fellow Brazilian Fernando Meligeni in a doubles match against Sweden's Jonas Bjorkman and Australia's Patrick Rafter on the Suzanne Lenglen Court on Tuesday evening. ``At the end of the first set tiebreaker, he threw his racket that went just past the chair umpire and went into the stands, hitting someone in the stands,'' said Stefan Fransson, a Grand Slam supervisor, who witnessed the incident. ``He threw it from around the service line.'' There had been disputes about line calls during the tiebreaker, which the Brazilians lost. ``Fernando and I were playing good tennis, even after the mistakes the chair umpire made,'' Kuerten said. ``I tried to relieve my tension by throwing the racket in the direction of my chair. It escaped and went toward the chair umpire. I know I made a mistake and that the racket's place is in my hand.'' Tournament referee Gilbert Ysern said he was unsure whether Kuerten could be suspended for throwing the racket at Rebeuh, who was not available for comment after the incident. ``Hopefully, we can give him the benefit of the doubt and think that he didn't really aim at killing the chair umpire by throwing the racket at him,'' Ysern said. Ysern said the fan hit by the racket apparently was not hurt. Witnesses said the fan was hit in the shoulder. ``He lost his mind a little bit,'' Ysern said. ``The chair umpire could have been hit, maybe hurt by the racket. It's obviously a serious situation. It's a serious case.'' At the 1990 Australian Open, McEnroe was disqualified for throwing a racket, an incident that led to $6,500 in fines. McEnroe only threw his racket to the court, however. At Wimbledon in 1995, Rebeuh also was involved when American Jeff Tarango stormed off court in the middle of a match. He accused Rebeuh of favoritism, and Tarango's wife slapped Rebeuh. That incident resulted in a fine and a one-year suspension from Wimbledon for Tarango. Germany's Carsten Arriens was defaulted from the 1995 French Open when he threw his racket on the ground and it bounced up and hit a line judge. Benjamin Deshayes, an usher at Tuesday's doubles match, said the incident happened moments after the end of the tiebreaker. ``Kuerten threw his racket at the umpire, but the umpire ducked and the racket went into the audience,'' Deshayes said. ``Kuerten got the racket back from the audience and threw it on the ground.''

Eritrea says Ethiopia troops attack Eritrean territory
Eds: UPDATES with more quotes; ADDS location; ADDS photo numbers. AP Photos ASM101-103 of June 2
ASMARA, Eritrea (AP) _ Eritrea charged that Ethiopian troops used tanks and heavy artillery to attack Eritrean positions in southern Ambesete Geleba early Wednesday. Foreign Affairs Ministry spokesman Andemicael Kahsai said no details were immediately available on casualties in the village 140 kilometers (90 miles) southwest of the capital, Asmara. The ministry called the attack ``a new and dangerous escalation'' of the border crisis between Eritrea and Ethiopia and said it was the fourth attack in less than two weeks on Eritrean positions. ``Unfortunately, the Ethiopian government persists in its intransigent position of launching a full-scale war unless Eritrea withdraws unconditionally from territories that are indisputable Eritrean,'' the ministry said in a statement. The Ethiopian government had no immediate comment. On May 13, Ethiopia first made public the border dispute, calling on Eritrea to withdraw from occupied Ethiopian territory. Eritrea has consistently denied it has moved into Ethiopia and on Wednesday repeated a call for a total demilitarization of border areas and outside mediation to solve the dispute. Andemicael called the Ethiopian demand that Eritrean troops withdraw from disputed territory ``a stumbling block to any progress.'' (js/sl-kjd)

BC-Iraq-Warheads,0572
In protective gear, U.N. experts search for Iraqi missile warheads
AP Photos planned By LEON BARKHO Associated Press Writer
Al-NIBAI, Iraq (AP) _ United Nations weapons inspectors searched through reeds and sand dunes Wednesday for missing missile parts in a bid to verify Iraq's claims that it has buried all its biological and chemical missile warheads. Wearing protective suits, masks, boots and gloves, some 27 experts, under German Jean Jano, used metal detectors and other equipment in their search at Al-Nibai, 45 kilometers (28 miles) north of Baghdad. Others supervised an earth-moving machine as it uncovered the nose cone of a missile warhead. ``This belongs to a conventional warhead,'' shouted an Iraqi engineer. In 1991, Iraq chose to destroy a great number of its long-range missiles and bury them rather than declare them to U.N inspectors. ``We hope that this work will help to settle some of the still outstanding issues concerning the missile warheads,'' Jano, 61, told The Associated Press. The area where Iraq unilaterally buried its missiles is vast. Experts with magnetic and electro-magnetic sensors placed small, red flags on the ground to determine where the next digging should be. ``We've with us some of the latest state-of-the-art high-tech equipment,'' said Vincent Murphy, a 69-year-old geophysicist from Boston. ``It is all digitally recorded. The data is brought back in the recorder to one of the vehicles and downloaded to the laptop.'' The advanced equipment is needed because no aerial photography or satellite images will penetrate the type of soil at al-Nibai, he said. Jano, an aerodynamics expert, said inspectors have found ``for instance, aluminum canisters that are used for chemical agents and some stainless steel canisters... used for biological agents.'' But he refused to say how many missiles and warheads were buried in Al-Nabai nor would he divulge whether what they have collected so far is sufficient to verify Iraqi claims that all its long-range missiles and chemical, nuclear and biological weapons have been destroyed _ the main condition for the U.N. Security Council to end the crippling sanctions slapped on Baghdad in 1990 after President Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait. The current excavation is scheduled to end June 18. Jano said another team of experts will arrive in Baghdad soon to analyze the findings, now stored at Taji, a military camp 20 kilometers (12 miles) north of Baghdad. Accounting for special warheads is one of the main hurdles in Iraq's efforts to declare itself clean of prohibited missiles with ranges beyond 150 kilometers (90 miles). Senior Iraqi officers looked on as the experts searched. The Iraqis refuse to wear safety gear, saying there is nothing toxic about the pieces of scrap underground. U.N. monitors' suits are burned every day, and inspectors must wash their hands and feet in a bleach solution before leaving the site. Jano said he hoped to do all that is required by the end of his mission in the light of ``excellent cooperation'' he has received from the Iraqi side. At the United Nations, Iraqi officials tried Tuesday to convince the Security Council that Baghdad had met the terms for ending economic sanctions by destroying all illegal weapons. U.S. and British diplomats said they remained unconvinced.

Portuguese Premier to ask Britain's Blair for help on East Timor
LISBON, Portugal (AP) _ Prime Minister Antonio Guterres was to travel to London on Wednesday in search of British Prime Minister Tony Blair's help in resolving the dispute between Lisbon and Jakarta over East Timor. The resignation of Indonesian President Suharto last month triggered a Portuguese diplomatic push to persuade foreign leaders to pressure Jakarta into softening its stance on the disputed territory. Indonesia invaded East Timor in 1975, a few months after the departure of Portugal's colonial administration, annexing the half-island the following year. The United Nations does not recognize Indonesian rule in East Timor and has been brokering negotiations between Lisbon and Jakarta. Guterres will ask Blair to lobby Jakarta for the release of East Timorese political prisoners held in Indonesian jails, a government spokesman said on customary condition of anonymity. The Portuguese prime minister is specifically campaigning for the release of Xanana Gusmao, the jailed leader of the armed separatist movement inside East Timor, the spokesman said. A phone call from Guterres last month prompted Blair to send his deputy foreign minister, Derek Fatchett to Jakarta to visit Gusmao in prison and publicly urge his release. Lisbon wants a referendum to be held in the territory, but Jakarta has repeatedly ruled out such a move. Indonesia's new president B.J. Habibie said in a CNN interview broadcast Wednesday that East Timor must remain an integral part of Indonesia. (bh/jt)

At least 20 dead in high-speed German train crash train, previous crashes
URGENT Eds: RAISES number of injured to 200 from 100; ADDS background on
HANOVER, Germany (AP) _ At least 20 people were killed Wednesday when a high-speed passenger train slammed into an automobile that had plunged off a bridge onto tracks in northeastern Lower Saxony state, officials said. State officials said at least 200 people were injured. The auto had crashed through the guardrail of a bridge running over the train tracks, officials said. The Hamburg-bound train struck the auto at 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour as it approached the station in Eschede, 50 kilometers (35 miles) north of Hanover. At least 13 cars derailed, crashing into each other and the base of the bridge, police said. At least two of the rail cars were destroyed, a state spokesman said. Part of the overpass collapsed onto the train. There was no immediate information on the driver of the auto. The German border patrol sent helicopters and 80 personnel to help emergency workers free passengers trapped inside the rail cars. Officials feared many inside were dead. The accident closed train traffic in both directions. It was the worst train collision in Germany since 1975 when 41 people were killed in the head-on collision of two express trains in Bavaria. The high-speed ICE train, which went into full service in 1991, is Germany's fastest train, connecting all major cities at speeds up to 280 kilometers an hour (175 miles an hour). Federal Transport Minister Matthias Wissmann and German railway executives were en route to the scene. (cb-aet)

Sudanese rebels capture strategic garrison town
Eds: UPDATES with Sudanese government comments, grafs 4-6.
NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) _ Sudanese rebels captured the garrison town of Ulu, on the road to a dam that provides most of Khartoum's electricity, a spokesman said Wednesday. The rebels defeated two government brigades in a daylong battle Tuesday for Ulu, 455 kilometers (280 miles) southeast of the capital, said George Garang, spokesman for the Sudan People's Liberation Army in Nairobi. At least 72 government troops were killed, he said. No figures on rebel casualties were provided. In Khartoum, the military forces issued a communique Tuesday night saying that ``fierce battles are currently going on in Ulu area.'' It made no comment on the battle Wednesday. The pro-government newspaper Al-Rai Al-Aam said, however, President Omar el-Bashir ``declared general mobilization in all parts of the Sudan and called on all sectors to move to the military training camps, and then from there to the operation zones.'' El-Bashir was quoted by the daily Al-Gomhuriya as saying the rebels had recently received ``additional assistance from the enemies of the homeland,'' but he did not specify from whom. Ulu is 150 kilometers (90 miles) south of the city of Damazin and the Roseires dam, which provides 80 percent of Khartoum's electricity. The dam is about 500 kilometers (315 miles) southeast of Khartoum. In Cairo, SPLA representative Daniel Kodi Angelo said the rebels' next target was a government oil exploration operation at Khor Adar, 52 miles (83 kilometers) west of Ulu. The SPLA has been waging an insurrection since 1983, demanding greater autonomy from the Islamic-dominated government for the mainly Christian and animist south. More than 1.5 million Sudanese have died in the fighting and consequent famines. (cai-kjd)

BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo, 2nd Ld-Writethru
Kosovo Albanians flood over border. by Serbs; reported firing of Serb policemen for refusing to fight in Kosovo; U.N. refugee figures, comments; trims.
Eds: UPDATES with Albanian reports say several villages wiped out AP Photos By MERITA DHIMGJOKA Associated Press Writer
PADESH, Albania (AP) _ A major Serb assault on ethnic Albanian villages in Kosovo drove a new wave of refugees into Albania and sent thousands more seeking the safety of border highlands, reports said Wednesday. A spokesman for the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees said 2,000 refugees had crossed overnight into Albania. The spokesman, Kris Janowski, said that a total of 3,700 Kosovo Albanians had fled to Albania since the Serb assault was launched late last week. Most are women, children and elderly who are ``exhausted mentally and physically,'' Janowski said in Geneva. The refugee agency assumes many more are hiding in the rugged, hilly border terrain, and ``we reckon with many more people crossing over,'' Janowski said. Albania's state-run ATA news agency said about 3,000 more refugees were approaching the border. It cited an unidentified refugee as saying as many as 50,000 more were on the Kosovo side of the hills separating the Serbian province from Albania. They were also walking toward the border, said the report, which could not be independently confirmed. Local authorities in northeastern Albania, site of most of the crossings, said that with more refugees arriving by the hour, the 25 tons of aid sent Tuesday by the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees was inadequate. Janowski said that shelling in the border region appeared to have died down. But the Kosovo Information Center, close to the ethnic Albanian leadership, spoke of heavy shelling Wednesday morning in the Decani region west of Pristina. It said some villages had been wiped out by air and rocket attacks. The center said that makeshift medical care was unable to deal with the many wounded civilians in the region. Up to 10,000 villagers may be in nearby woods regions, cut off by Serb forces. In another unconfirmed report documenting growing reluctance to die for Kosovo, the daily Telegraf, published in Belgrade, reported that about 100 policemen had been fired for refusing to go fight in the province. The refugee influx first began growing late last week as Serb police and the Serb-dominated Yugoslav army stepped up their campaign to crush the pro-separatist Kosovo Liberation Army. The militants have been gaining in popularity and numbers after years of heavy-handed rule by Serbian authorities in the secessionist southern province, where ethnic Albanians represent 90 percent of the population of 2.2 million. Trekking over the mountains for up to two days, refugees fleeing to neighboring Albania described artillery bombardments that forced out entire villages and house-burnings they said were clearly intended to drive them out. There have been no reports like those in Bosnia of massive civilian roundups or massacres in the Kosovo campaign, which the Serbs insist targets guerrillas. But attacks on villages, the exodus of civilians and the deaths of women and children have prompted increasing comparisons to the ethnic war in Bosnia and its atrocities. More than 200 people have been killed in the province in the past three months. The growing violence has sparked alarm among Western powers that the fighting could spill over into neighboring Balkan nations. U.S. President Bill Clinton told a visiting delegation of ethnic Albanians in Washington last week that the United States ``shall not tolerate another Bosnia in Kosovo.'' But the West repeatedly has failed to get Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic to halt the Serb crackdown in Kosovo, and has yet to devise a strategy for how to resolve the worsening conflict. Those concerns prompted NATO last week to consider possible troop deployments in Albania and Macedonia. But Russia said Tuesday that NATO cannot post troops in Albania without the approval of the United Nations. Based on information from the refugees and ethnic Albanian officials in Kosovo, the latest campaign is concentrated in the western region of Decani, where the Serbs deployed thousands of additional paramilitary forces and are pulverizing 10 towns and villages with artillery. BC-Ukraine-Vatican
Vatican's secretary of state meets Ukrainian president
AP Photo KIV101 By SERGEI SHARGORODSKY Associated Press Writer
KIEV, Ukraine (AP) - The Vatican's secretary of state, Cardinal Angelo Sodano, met Wednesday with Ukrainian President Leonid Kuchma and noted the warm welcome extended to him in the former Soviet republic. Relations between Ukraine and the Vatican have been troubled by the country's church rift and the government's reluctance to invite Pope John Paul II for a long-awaited visit. The subject was expected to come up during Sodano's five-day visit. The cardinal, who held a service at Kiev's main Roman Catholic church Tuesday, also was due to meet with premier Valery Pustovoitenko and other officials and to inaugurate a new Apostolic Nunciature office. Eds: UPDATES with Corretja advancing to semifinals By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ The predictable almost never happens at the French Open. So it shouldn't be a surprise that Marcelo Rios, the consensus favorite on the men's side, was ousted in the quarterfinals. But at least one predictable phenomenon remains on course: the onward march of Martina Hingis, the world's undisputed best woman player. Hingis defeated Venus Williams on Tuesday with such ease that it put to rest any talk of a great rivalry _ at least for now. Hingis next faces a newly inspired Monica Seles, a three-time champion here, in one of Thursday's semifinals. No. 2 seed Lindsay Davenport plays two-time champion Arantxa Sanchez Vicario in the other. On the men's side, Rios, the No. 3 seed from Chile, blew his chance to overtake Pete Sampras as the world's No. 1 player when he lost 6-1, 2-6, 6-2, 6-4 to Carlos Moya. Rios held that spot for a month earlier this year, and could have reclaimed it with a quarterfinal victory. On Wednesday, 14th-seeded Alex Corretja defeated Filip Dewulf 7-5, 6-4, 6-3 to reach his first Grand Slam semifinal. He became the third Spaniard to reach the men's semifinals, joining Moya and Felix Mantilla. The fourth semifinalist was to be determined later Wednesday, with France's Cedric Pioline facing Hicham Arazi of Morocco. With Davenport and Seles advancing, there are two American women in the French Open semifinals for the first time since Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert reached the final four in 1987. But there were none of the hoped-for echoes of Evert and Navratilova when Hingis and Williams took the court for their much anticipated match. In a swirling wind that hampered both players, Hingis used her deft touch and uncanny court sense to dictate play throughout. Never in the 6-3, 6-4 victory did the Swiss star appear out of control, off balance or rushed. Williams, for her part, hurt herself with 38 unforced errors. ``I don't think I was as patient as I should have been. I guess everyone knows I like to hit,'' Williams said. ``I suppose I got a little too excited, really wanted to hit a winner.'' Hingis came into the match with a 5-2 career record against the eighth-seeded Williams, but the two 17-year-olds were 2-2 this year. The match promised to be an intriguing battle between power and smarts. Despite her far greater experience, Hingis actually is 3{ months younger than Williams. But, just as in their only previous Grand Slam tournament encounter _ a 6-0, 6-4 win by Hingis in the U.S. Open final last summer _ the match turned into a one-sided affair. ``It's probably good for me to lose so I can really see what I'm doing wrong and really look at myself and say, `Venus, you're not there,''' she said. Moya, seeded 12th here, is ranked 12th in the world, but has been as high as fifth. He's hoping to crack back into the top 10 this week. He became the talk of the tennis world at last year's Australian Open _ for both his dashing good looks and his talent. He upset defending champion Boris Becker in the first round, then went straight through to the final, where he lost to Sampras. But except for that tournament, the 21-year-old Moya had never gone past the second round of any Grand Slam event. And here at Roland Garros, he hadn't gotten past the second round in two previous visits. Moya was at the top of his all-court game Tuesday. A crucial moment came in the fourth set at 4-4, 15-15, Rios serving. Moya, leading two sets to one, hit a shot and Rios let it go, thinking the ball had bounced twice on Moya's side. But the referee said it hadn't. Rios lost the point, the game and his concentration. ``Maybe if I won that game, the match would have been different,'' he said. Now Moya, who faces Mantilla in Friday's semifinals, is the highest seed left in the tournament. Mantilla and Moya are buddies. ``We're going to be friends until Friday,'' he said. ``When we get to the court, I will try to kill him.'' The day's action ended on a sour note when Gustavo Kuerten, the defending champion who lost in the second round, was disqualified in doubles for throwing his racket at the chair umpire and hitting a fan in the stands, but apparently not causing injury. ``I'm so sorry for what happened and I regret what I did,'' the Brazilian said Wednesday in a prepared statement. ``I know that this will make me a more mature guy and will make me grow. I want to make it clear that I never had the intention of hurting anyone on or off the court.'' Kuerten, who won last year as an unseeded player, is well liked by fans, players and the media. In fact, he won this year's Orange Prize, voted by French tennis writers for the player they like best. There's also a Lemon Prize, for the player they like least. The winner, two years running, has been Rios.

He said the situation remained ``pretty volatile'' despite U.N. attempts to implement the 1994 Lusaka peace protocol. ``Hostilities were likely to resume any time and both sides remained skeptical of each other's intention,'' he was quoted as saying by Zimbabwe's national news agency ZIANA. Last week, U.N. special envoy to Angola Alioun Blondin Beye declared that his efforts were fruitless and that he was ready to give up. ``If he decides to resign because he sees no hope, then you could say we are headed for serious problems,'' Sibanda said. Both the former UNITA rebel group and the government contain those who favor ``a military solution'' to their problems, Sibanda was quoted as saying. ------ CAPE TOWN, South Africa (AP) _ The unemployment insurance fund could run dry next year if the demand on it continues to increase, according to the unemployment insurance commissioner. ``If things get worse we might go to Cabinet to ask for rescue,'' Shadrack Mkhonto said Tuesday, after the fund's 1997 report showed a deficit of 254 million rand (dlrs 49 million). Mkhonto said he did not believe the fund would last even to 2000. The deficit was caused mainly by the general increase in unemployment. Joblessness figures for 1997 had been up 71,000 on 1996, and in the first half of this year alone the formal sector had shed 62,000 jobs. ------ JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (AP) _ Taxes on corporations and individuals earning huge salaries should be increased, says the South Africa's largest labor federation. The Congress of South African Trade Unions said Tuesday that demands for a reduction in corporate taxes were based on a false assumption that South African companies paid high rates of tax. COSATU deputy general secretary Zwelinzima Vavi said South Africa's tax revenue as a proportion of national income was lower than comparable countries. ``This means that South Africa's poor are paying higher effective tax rates than other sectors of the population, and that the lower and middle income groups bear a disproportionate share of the tax burden.'' ------ ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (AP) _ Telecommunications officials from 30 African nations sat down Wednesday with representatives of the world's leading private cable and satellite operators to discuss how to connect the continent to the global information superhighway. On the agenda, according to organizers, was the need to reform and privatize telecommunications in Africa which remain dominated by inefficient, state-run monopolies. Some 300 participants in the three-day conference on Global Connectivity for Africa were discussing the type of needed regulatory systems, tariff revisions and enhacing regional cooperation. The groups were also to discuss the kind of cable and satellite links most appropriate for Africa where there are currently only 14 million telephones for 700 million people. The gathering, which began Tuesday, is sponsored by the U.N. Economic Commission for Africa, the World Bank's Information for Development Program, the International Telecommunications Union, the African Development Bank and the Government of The Netherlands. Private sponsors include the WorldSpace Corp., Siemens, Teledesic, Iridium and Rascom. ------ BLANTYRE, Malawi (AP) _ Close to 900,000 ``healthy looking Malawians'' are carrying the human immunodeficiency virus that leads to AIDS, Health and Population Minister Harry Thomson says. Confirmed cases has reached 50,975 but this was believed to be only a small proportion of those infected among Malawi's 12 million people, he said. ------ MONROVIA, Liberia (AP) _ Liberia has called for United Nations and West African peacekeeping troops to be deployed on the country's volatile northwestern border with Sierra Leone. Information Minister Joe Mulbah said late Tuesday that a peacekeeping force was necessary to prevent fighting in Sierra Leone from spreading across the border. ``Having come out of a civil war, Liberia is interested in improving security with neighboring countries including Sierra Leone,'' Mulbah said. He denied Sierra Leone's claims that a group of Liberians had joined rebel factions committing atrocities against civilians in rural Sierra Leone. Relations between the two countries have been cool since Sierra Leone President Ahmed Tejan Kabbah was restored to power by a Nigerian-led West African intervention force in March. The representatives of the FLEC-Renovada guerrilla army which seeks independence for Angola's oil-rich Cabinda enclave were detained May 21 and are in a Kinshasa jail, the Portuguese news agency Lusa reported. Congo President Laurent Kabila is a close ally of Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos and last year promised to crack down on Cabindan rebels operating inside Congo. ------ ACCRA, Ghana (AP) _ The government said Wednesday it supports legislation in Washington aimed at increasing U.S trade rather than aid in Africa. BC-Thailand-Problem Loans
Thai central bank makes rule to encourage debt restructuring
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ Seeking to relieve commercial banks from onerous reserve requirements, the central bank has relaxed loan-classification rules to encourage them to negotiate with borrowers to restructure problem loans. Thailand's 16 commercial banks and 48 non-bank lenders have an estimated 1 trillion baht (dlrs 23 billion) in problem loans, equal to one-fifth of the country's gross domestic product. An economic downturn last year plunged the country's financial sector into crisis, exposing dozens of finance companies and several banks as being virtually bankrupt. In response, the Bank of Thailand toughened capital-adequacy standards, requiring all institutions to raise fresh capital and boost loan-loss reserves. The continuing regional economic turmoil, however, has made it difficult for most institutions to raise that capital. The central bank said Wednesday it would permit banks and finance companies to upgrade loans now classified as ``doubtful'' by persuading borrowers to repay as much of their loans as possible. Doubtful loans involve borrowers who are less than one year late; reserves must be equal to 50 percent of such loans. Under the new rules, which took effect Tuesday, once part of the loan is repaid, the loan can be reclassified as ``substandard,'' and be subject to lower reserve requirements. If, after the restructuring agreement, the borrower makes payments for three consecutive months, the loan can be considered ``good,'' removing the need for reserves. The lender will have to write off as losses the amount the borrower cannot repay. The plan would allow the lending institutions to trim the large amounts of money they must set aside as loan-loss reserves.

BAGHDAD, Iraq (AP) _ A plane carrying 40 tons of medicine and medical equipment arrived in Baghdad on Wednesday from the United Arab Emirates. Emirates President Sheik Zayed Bin Sultan Al Nahyan ordered the aid, said Saeed al-Mansouri of the Emirates Red Crescent Society, ``They (the goods) will be flowing from now on. There will be more shipments... These are the orders of the president,'' al-Mansouri told reporters. Sheik Zayed is the most vociferous among leaders of the Gulf Arab states to normalize ties with Baghdad ruptured after Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait. ``This present is an expression that the people of the Emirates want to take part in alleviating the suffering of the Iraqi children, women and the sick,'' al-Mansouri said. He said another plane carrying an additional 40 tons of aid will arrive Friday. The goods were collected by the Red Crescent Society, the Islamic equivalent of the Red Cross, which has sent more than 22 million dirhams (dlrs 6 million) worth of aid to Iraq since 1996. The charity organization has said it plans to open an office in Baghdad by the end of the year to coordinate the distribution of humanitarian aid. The Emirates has sent six planes to Iraq in the past six months carrying food, medicine and clothing, the official Emirates News Agency said. Iraq has been under U.N. sanctions since its Kuwait invasion. The sanctions bar it from exporting oil, except for a limited quantity under U.N. supervision, and also prohibit direct flights to the country. The United Nations has to approve humanitarian flights. Arab states have recently increased their shipments of aid to Iraq, reflecting widespread opposition to the sanctions among their populations. The U.N. Security Council says the sanctions will not be lifted until Iraq has eliminated its weapons of mass destruction. The Iraqi government says at least 1.5 million deaths during the past seven years have been caused by shortages brought about by the sanctions. The U.N. Children's Fund says that 960,000 Iraqi children are suffering from malnutrition.
