U.S. ambassador: announcement on U.S. peace initiative in days
By DINA KRAFT Associated Press Writer
TEL AVIV, Israel (AP) _ The United States expects Israel to reach a decision on a West Bank troop withdrawal within days, not weeks, as suggested by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, the U.S. ambassador to Israel said Wednesday. Ambassador Edward Walker said that while the United States has not given Israel a deadline to accept a U.S. proposal for a troop withdrawal from 13 percent of the West Bank, ``there is a very short time frame.'' Netanyahu told lawmakers Tuesday that he expected to have made a decision on an Israeli troop pullback by the end of July, before parliament goes into summer recess, according to legislator Yehuda Harel of the centrist Third Way party. However, far-right coalition partners have warned Netanyahu that they would bring down his government over a 13 percent troop pullback, and Netanyahu is reluctant to accept the U.S. plan. Walker said Wednesday that the United States will soon make a decision on whether to pursue its peace iniative. If a failure is announced, Israel would bear the brunt of the blame because the Palestinians have accepted the U.S. plan. ``It (the decision) is in a matter of days rather than weeks, but precisely what day and what hour and so on I have no idea exactly. It depends how the progress goes,'' Walker said. Last month, Israel ignored one U.S. deadline. Palestinian Higher Education Minister Hanan Ashrawi said Wednesday that Washington displayed ``a lack of will to stand firm in the face of Israel's intransigence.'' On Tuesday, U.S. envoy Thomas Pickering asked Jordanian and Saudi Arabian leaders to delay plans for an Arab summit for another week to allow the American initiative to play itself out. The Palestinians are pushing for an Arab summit that would conclude with an announcement that the Arab world is suspending the normalization of ties with Israel as long as Netanyahu does not carry out the peace agreement already signed. Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat traveled to Oman on Wednesday to lobby for support among Gulf State leaders to convene an Arab summit. Palestinians have said that they will push for the summit even if Israel does accept the U.S. proposals. In London, U.S. Mideast envoy Dennis Ross met Wednesday with two top Palestinian officials to discuss the troop withdrawal. According to Maariv, Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai and Infrastructures Minister Ariel Sharon declined an invitation to attend the meeting because the government has not yet decided on the scope of a troop pullback.

BC-Germany-Train Derails, 6th Ld-Writethru
At least 20 dead in high-speed German train crash of ICE trains
Eds: ADDS Byline, RECASTS lead, RAISES past accidents, ADDS details By CLAUS-PETER TIEMANN Associated Press Writer
HANOVER, Germany (AP) _ A high-speed passenger train derailed Wednesday in northern Germany after it crashed into an automobile that had plunged off an overpass onto the tracks. At least 20 people were killed and 200 injured. The Hamburg-bound train struck the auto going 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour as it approached the station in Eschede, 50 kilometers (35 miles) north of Hanover just before 11 a.m., officials said. The accident was the worst on Germany's premier high-speed ICE line inaugurated in 1991, and the most deadly rail crash in Germany since 1975 when 41 people died in the head-on collision of two express trains in Bavaria. A Lower-Saxony state spokesman said the death toll was likely to climb. At least 13 cars derailed, crashing into each other and the base of the overpass. Two of the rail cars were destroyed and part of the overpass collapsed onto the train. Officials said the auto had crashed through the guardrail of the bridge running over the train tracks, plunging to the rails. There was no immediate information a driver of the auto or of possible passengers. The German border patrol sent helicopters and 80 personnel to help emergency workers free passengers trapped inside the rail cars. Officials feared many inside were dead. The accident closed train traffic in both directions. Federal Transport Minister Matthias Wissmann, Lower Saxony state governor Gerhard Schroeder and German railway executives were en route to the scene. The ICE train is Germany's fastest, connecting all major cities at speed up to 280 kilometers (175 miles) an hour. The train travels from Munich to Hamburg, covering a distance of more than 950 kilometers (about 600 miles), in 5 hours and 37 minutes. Regular train service takes more than eight hours. The high-speed trains carry more than 65,000 passengers daily. (cb-aet)

BC-Air France-Strike, 2nd Ld-Writethru
Tough talk ahead of second-round negotiations, other strikes loom (1300 GMT)
Eds: UPDATES with other strikes threatened; talks resume at 3 p.m. AP Photos PAR101-3 By CECILE ROUX Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ New strikes threatened French air and rail service one week away from the World Cup on Wednesday, while Air France sought to end a three-day-old pilots' walkout already disrupting some of the event's preparations. The strike at state-owned Air France _ the World Cup's official carrier _ was a growing embarrassment to the French government, which also faced walkouts among Paris transit workers Thursday and national railworkers Friday. Air France mechanics and French train engineers were also threatening their own strikes. Talks at Air France were resume at 3 p.m. (1300 GMT) Wednesday, after no progress was reported from the first round Tuesday. In the meantime, Air France said its Wednesday schedule included only 17 percent of its usual long-distance flights, 30 percent of its short and medium-distance routes from Charles de Gaulle Airport and 43 percent from Orly. Union leader Jean-Charles Corbet said after the talks Tuesday that the dispute ``will probably be long, it will probably be tough. ... and devastating for the balance sheet.'' Corbet, head of the SNPL union that represents most of the airline's 3,200 pilots, accused the airline's president, Jean-Cyril Spinetta, of merely repeating his offer. While faced with a slated two-week walkout, Spinetta on Wednesday morning said he remained ``firm on my objectives,'' supported by the government, to cut costs. For the pilots, among the highest paid in the world, the company wants to give them stock in exchange for 500 million francs (dlrs 83 million) in pay cuts. But it's offered to eventually do away with a two-tier salary schedule that pays less to new pilots. Air France pilots average 1 million francs (dlrs 160,000), ranging from 240,000 francs (dlrs 40,000) for new pilots to 1.2 million francs (dlrs 200,000) for 25 years' seniority, the airline said. The carrier, which managed to report a profit in the last two years, was set to lose 100 million francs (dlrs 16.7 million) per day during the strike. Spinetta told Europe 1 radio he couldn't imagine that the pilots, ``at the moment where the world's eyes are turned to France for this great celebration that is the World Cup, will paralyze the country.'' France's interior minister criticized the ``lack of civic-mindedness'' of the pilots, saying he felt ``sadness, almost shame.'' Because of the strike, Jean-Pierre Chevenement told Radio Monte Carlo, ``France could show itself as a nation that can't organize a world event anymore.'' The walkout disrupted training for the French national soccer team, said coach Aime Jacquet. The players had been given a three-day weekend to visit their families and were supposed to resume training Tuesday. Air France is committed to transporting teams to the 10 competition sites around France and charter other carriers to meet its obligations. The airline's mechanics threatened on Wednesday to walk off the job over pay differences between Air Inter and Air France, which have been merged. No date was set. Paris subway drivers with the Communist-led CGT union were to walk off the job Thursday, but the Paris transit authority RATP said it expected no effect on service since the union represented only a minority of the employees. At the national railway SNCF, conductors with three unions were to strike Friday night though Sunday evening. Its engineers announced plans for a June 10 strike, the day the World Cup opens. ELDORET, Kenya (AP) _ The armies of Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania began their first joint exercises Wednesday in a U.S.-funded operation dubbed Exercise Natural Fire '98. U.S. Marines will also participate in the exercise that brings together about 700 troops. The Defense branch of the Office of Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi said the exercise is aimed at giving troops practice in the planning and execution of ``conflict prevention measures ... and how to handle volatile politico-military, economic, humanitarian and ethnic problems in a typical African situation.'' On June 15, the exercise moves north to Lodwar near Lake Turkana for several days of field exercises. ------ NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) _ Three men have been charged with killing a prominent Rwandan exile and his driver in Nairobi, police sources said Wednesday. The accused, David Akiki Kiwanuka of Rwanda and Ugandans Charles Muhinji Wamuthoni and Christopher Lubanga Mlonda were arraigned in a Nairobi court Tuesday but were not required to enter pleas. They are charged with the May 16 shooting deaths of Seth Sendashonga, a former Rwandan minister and member of the Rwandan Patriotic Front and his driver Jean Bosco Nlingiyubu. Sendashonga had been living in exile in Nairobi. Police said the Rwandan was the son of a businessman who had confessed to ordering Sendashonga's killing to avenge the death of his father over a bad business deal with Sendashonga. Police said the businessman's son claimed Sendashonga, who served as Rwandan interior minister in 1994-1995, ordered his father killed after the two stole dlrs 54 million in Rwanda. Sendashonga was a member of the predominantly Tutsi RPF that ousted a Hutu extremist government in Rwanda in July 1994 after a three-month genocide campaign that killed more than 500,000 people, mostly minority Tutsis. Sendashonga and several other government officials were dismissed from their posts in 1995 after they protested the reprisal killings of Hutu civilians by Tutsi soldiers.

DAMASCUS, Syria (AP) _ Finance Minister Khaled Mahayni has presented to Parliament this year's budget of 237.3 billion pounds (dlrs 5.2 billion), an increase of nearly 12 percent over last year, the official Syrian Arab News Agency reported Wednesday. SANA said the new budget listed current expenditure of 117.7 billion pounds (dlrs 2.58 billion), compared to 102.43 billion pounds (dlrs 2.4 billion) last year and 119.6 billion pounds (dlrs 2.62 billion) for investment. Mahayni, who presented the budget to Parliament Tuesday, said the new budget will create 86,275 jobs. SANA did not say how much of the budget will go to defense. In the past 40 percent was allocated to defense. Parliament is expected to approve the budget within the next few days, SANA said. Mahayni said Syria's economic and financial policies helped achieve remarkable progress in the fields of agriculture, irrigation, industry, energy, tourism and services. He said the major targets of the national economy at this stage are set to tackle major issues and to continue economic and social developments. SANA's report said Syria's gross domestic product reached dlrs 15.3 billion last compared. It was 7 billion pounds (dlrs 15.3 million) in 1970. ___ KUWAIT (AP) _ Kuwait and Britain are to sign an agreement to avoid double taxation before the end of the year, a senior official said Wednesday. Fawzi al-Qassar, assistant undersecretary at the Finance Ministry, told the Kuwait News Agency the two countries have finalized the agreement after three rounds of negotiations. He said the agreement covers all types of income taxes. Aside from investments by private Kuwaitis, this oil-rich country has invested billions of dollars in England, part of a state fund for future generations estimated at around dlrs 40 billion. Taxes on revenues of foreign companies operating in Kuwait could reach 55 percent, but the government has promised to cut them in a bid to attract foreign investments. ___ BEIRUT, Lebanon (AP) _ About 150 Jordanian truck drivers staged a sit-in on the Lebanese border Wednesday to protest a Lebanese ban on the import of some 2,780 metric tons (3,058 tons) of watermelons, newspapers reported Wednesday. Some 100 refrigerated trucks have been held up at two border points on Lebanon's frontier with Syria since May 19. Under an agricultural agreement, Jordanian watermelons receive duty free access to the Lebanese market from May 1 to June 10 every year. But Agriculture Minister Shawki Fakhoury said he banned the Jordanian watermelons after they exceeded the annual quota of 4,000 metric tons (4,400 tons) that is allowed under the agreement. The leading An-Nahar daily said Wednesday the standoff threatened to damage Lebanese-Jordanian relations, citing reports that Jordanian authorities have banned the entry of Lebanese fruits, including truckloads of cherries, in retaliation for the Lebanese ban. The drivers called on the Lebanese authorities to lift the ban, saying the watermelons were already rotting. The market price for watermelons in Lebanon has nearly doubled since the ban was imposed. ___ DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) _ French telecommunications giant Alcatel Alsthom has signed a dlrs 26 million contract with United Arab Emirates' telecommunications company to expand the GSM mobile system in the country's capital, the daily Gulf News reported Wednesday. The deal is the fifth of its kind by Alcatel in the Emirates, the English-language paper said. The latest contract with Emirates' Etisalat telecommunications company will cater for future needs from expected rising demand in Abu Dhabi. Etisalat maintains a modern GSM mobile system covering the entire country. The current GSM system in Abu Dhabi provides service to 100,000 users, the paper said. BC-Ukraine-Miners
Ukrainian miners continue protests, striking miner dies
AP Photos Planned By SERGEI SHARGORODSKY Associated Press Writer
KIEV, Ukraine (AP) _ Hundreds of striking miners banged their helmets and plastic bottles on the pavement outside the president's office Wednesday, and union leaders said one miner died after taking part in another protest rally. The miners also demonstrated Wednesday in front of the parliament building, chanting, ``salary, salary!'' to the constant drumming of their helmets. Similar demonstrations have been held in conjunction with scattered strikes that have idled dozens of mines in coal-producing eastern Ukraine since last month. The miners are demanding the payment of overdue wages _ estimated at up to 2.2 billion hryvna (dlrs 1.1 billion) _ salary increases and more government funds for their struggling industry. The Independent Miners Union said one protester died Tuesday in a hospital in Dnipropetrovsk, after catching pneumonia during a protest that involved marches and days of sitting on sidewalks. Ihor Tyryntsev, 28, also had a stomach ulcer that was aggravated by the stress of the protest, the union said. The government last week called on miners to show ``wisdom'' in a joint search for a solution to the coal industry's problems. It also blamed some industry leaders for failing to ensure prompt wage payments to the miners. Ukraine's coal industry is also plagued by safety problems and outdated equipment. Accidents this year have killed about 170 miners. In the latest accident Tuesday, fire broke out at a mine in the Luhansk region, the Emergency Situations Ministry said. There were no injuries among the 127 workers in the mine at the time, it said. (sms/ls)

BC-Italy-Nicholas Green
Prosecutor asks for long prison terms in slaying of American boy
CATANZARO, Italy (AP) _ The prosecution asked a court Wednesday to sentence one man to life and another to 30 years in prison in the 1994 highway slaying of a 7-year-old American boy. The prosecution wrapped up its case in the appeals trial in this southern city of the men acquitted in January 1997 of slaying Nicholas Green during a robbery attempt as he and his California family drove down a Calabrian highway while on vacation. The lower court jury had ruled there was no evidence to convict Francesco Mesiano, 23, and Michele Iannello, 28, of murder, attempted murder and armed robbery, but Italian law allows the acquitted to be retried by an appeals court for the same crime. Prosecutor Salvatore Murone said Iannello should be convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment -- the maximum under Italian law -- and Mesiano to 30 years. The prosecution contends that the discoverfy of a pistol in the home of Iannello's mother after the first trial questioned the credibility of the defendant, who had testified he had no other weapons. Nicholas Green's parents donated his organs in an act that saved seven other lives and inspired a temporary surge of organ donations in a country where many relatives of accident victims, especially of children, refuse to allow removal of organs. Italy has one of the lowest donor rates in Europe. Mesiano and Iannello had denied involvement in the death, even though Iannello admitted to four gangland murders. The prosecution said statements recorded by telephone taps implicated the pair, but the defense disputed the meaning of the conversations in dialect. (vls-fd)

BC-Italy-EU Treaty
Italy approves EU Treaty of Amsterdam
ROME (AP) _ Italy on Wednesday ratified a European Union treaty regulating immigration policies and paving the way for the union's eastward expansion. The Amsterdam Treaty, which must be ratified by all 15 EU states, would give the EU authority over the visa and asylum policies of its member nations. Foreign Minister Lamberto Dini, in an address to the Senate, said the treaty was ``an important step forward for the growth of the EU.'' ``This confirms that the EU is built on the judgment of the people; that it is not a product of high-level summits, but an expression of collective will,'' Dini said. In Denmark, the treaty was put to a popular referendum after many there expressed concern that a greater EU might not represent the country's best interests. It was ratified after the majority voted ``yes.'' Germany and Sweden have also ratified the treaty. (vg)

BC-Thailand-Economy, 2nd Ld-Writethru
Second-largest Thai bank to recapitalize; baht rises
Eds: UPDATES with baht closing lower in grafs 5-7
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ Thailand's second-largest commerical bank plans a second round of capital increases to cope with rising non-performing loans, the central bank governor said Wednesday. Chatu Mongkol Sonakul, who is spearheading a shakeup of the Thai financial sector since taking office a month ago, refused to provide details on the offering for state-owned Krung Thai Bank. The Manager, a local business daily, reported Wednesday that the bank plans to raise 70 billion baht (dlrs 1.7 billion) in new capital this year to prop up liquidity. The move would mark the second time Krung Thai Bank has been forced to raise capital since the Thai financial crisis erupted last July and triggered a chain reaction of woes across Asia. On Tuesday, the Bank of Thailand increased short-term interest rates through the bond repurchase market Tuesday to stabilize the baht, which had weakened from about 39 to the U.S. dollar last week to close Wednesday at 42.20, its lowest level in 12 weeks. The baht had strengthened to 41.70 in early trading Wednesday from Tuesday's close of 42.05, but the dollar regained strength against the baht in the late afternoon after the earlier rising yen started to show weakness again, dealers said. As of Wednesday's close, the baht had dropped 38.7 percent against the dollar since the Thai government abandoned its fixed foreign exchange system last July 2. The interest rate hikes and profit-taking on bank and finance company stocks sent the Stock Exchange of Thailand index down 0.43 points Wednesday to close at 313.21. Thai firms struggling to survive the current economic crisis are desperate for lower rates, but the crisis-stricken financial sector has been reluctant to lend fresh money. Earlier this year, the government seized four small commercial banks deemed to be too ridden with debt to continue operations. Chatu Mongkol Sonakul said Tuesday that only one of the licenses from the seized banks will be sold this year in an effort to ensure the government receives a fair price. The other three licenses will be sold over the next three years. The U.S. investment bank J.P. Morgan Inc. is advising the Bank of Thailand on how to handle the banks' assets. It is scheduled to submit a proposal to the central bank later this month.

BC-NATO-Kosovo
NATO accelerates plans to boost Albanian, Macedonia borders
With BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo By ROBERT WIELAARD Associated Press Writer
BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) _ The NATO allies agreed Wednesday to accelerate plans to help Albania and Macedonia seal their borders with Kosovo where Serb security forces are crushing a separatist movement. As of thousands of refugees fled the violence in Kosovo, the allies said again they will consider deploying combat troops in Albania and Macedonia, but the prospect of that happening soon were dim. ``We all agreed we cannot proceed (with an allied force) until we have solid, well-thought out military advice,'' said a NATO official, who asked not to be named. The official said Kosovo was discussed by the ambassadors of the 16 NATO nations who agreed ``we first of all want to have good, detailed military advice.'' Getting that ``would take several days,'' said the official. It will then have to be reviewed by the NATO defense ministers who are to meet here June 11-12. In the meantime, the allies accelerated a package of immmediate measures. This includes bringing forward technical and military assistance for Albania and Macedonia to help them secure their borders with Kosovo. The first miliary advisors are to leave in a matter of days. Also, previously scheduled small-scale joint military maneuvers in Albania and Macedonia were given more priority and NATO's civil emergency and planning section was told to extend immediate cooperation with U.N. officials dealing with the exodus of Kosovo refugees. ``There is a great sense of urgency to get these things organized,'' said the NATO official. The deteriorating situation in Kosovo served drew comparisons with Bosnia which spiraled into civil war in the early 1990s as the NATO allies bickered over how to contain that Balkan crisis. But officials rejected suggestions NATO was again slow off the mark by taking a cautious stance on deploying a large alliance force in Albania and Macedonia. ``NATO ... cannot do things which are not guaranteed to be successful. We are going quickly but we recognize there is a need for substantive military work'' before a decision to deploy many thousands of troops is taken, said the NATO official . There have been no reports in Kosovo like those in Bosnia of massive civilian roundups or massacres by Serb forces. But attacks on villages, the exodus of civilians and the deaths of women and children have prompted comparisons to the ethnic war in Bosnia. More than 200 people have been killed in the southern Serb province where 90 percent of the population are ethnic Albanians. NATO's Kosovo policy is guided by the belief the province should not become independent but be given back the autonomy it once had within the Yugoslav Republic. (rw)

BC-Media-Belarus
Anti-censorship group accuses Belarus of tightening media controls
LONDON (AP) _ An international organization campaigning against censorship accused Belarus on Wednesday of tightening restrictions on the news media and ``flagrant violations of international standards of freedom of expression.'' The group Article 19, named after the provision in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights guaranteeing the right to freedom of expression, demanded the abolition of a series of measures introduced this year by authorities in the former Soviet state. In a report called ``The Noose Tightens,'' the London-based voluntary organization said the latest measures throw Belarus' democratic transition into reverse. Belarus President Alexander Lukashenko has drawn international criticism for his crackdowns on independent media, including shutting down critical newspapers. Last month, a U.N.-affiliated group named him as one of the world's 10 worst enemies of press freedom. His latest measures include a ban on the non-state media's access to official information, creation of a government-appointed council with censorship powers, and a requirement that anyone distributing information about laws, government decrees and other legal measures be licensed by the government. New amendments to Belarus' already restrictive Law on Press include more stringent requirements for registration of newspapers, authority for a state committee to suspend publication of a newspaper or periodical for up to three months without a court ruling, and a prohibition on publication of ``information damaging the honor and dignity of government officials.'' Article 19 said a correspondent for the independent newspaper Narodnaya Volya who attempted to determine how many people involved in emergency work in the contaminated zone around the Chernobyl nuclear reactor after the 1986 catastrophe were still alive was told by the Ministry of Emergencies that non-state newspapers could be refused access to any information. ``This has particularly disturbing connotations in the light of past cover-ups of information on Chernobyl by the Soviet authorities, with disastrous results for peoples' lives and health,'' the group's report said. BC-Russia-Chechnya
Chechen official: Professional army nearly formed
MOSCOW (AP) _ Chechnya has almost completed the formation of a professional army, a news agency said Wednesday. More than 2,000 people have qualified to enlist since Chechnya began forming an army from disjointed field units a year ago, Chechen national guard commander Magomed Khambiyev said, according to ITAR-Tass. He refused to say how big the army will be when fully formed. Beside physical health, the criteria for enlistment included ``moral qualities, such as faith in Allah, and political dependability,'' Khambiyev said. ``In the long run, it will be a well-organized and technically equipped force capable of carrying out any tasks to protect the state from foreign aggression,'' he said. Chechen separatists had dealt a humiliating defeat to Russia's much larger but demoralized and underfinanced army two years ago, forcing Russia to withdraw its troops from the mainly Muslim region. The key issue of Chechnya's political status was left unresolved. Chechnya insists it is an independent state, even though no country, including Russia, has recognized its sovereignty. (ad/ls)

BC-Sports-Soccer-World Cup-Del Piero
Italy's star cautious on injury recovery
ROME (AP) _ Alessandro Del Piero, pegged as Italy's leader at the World Cup, said Wednesday he is only halfway to top form but will not rush his return from injury. The Juventus of Turin star was included on the 22-man roster even though a lingering right thigh strain has kept him away from the team's practices for two weeks. ``It's true I feel good, but on a scale from 1 to 10, right now I am at 5,'' Del Piero told reporters. ``It is clear that to play I have to be in good form. I don't want to take risks. There is no room for false steps,'' the striker said. ``The World Cup is long; it certainly does not end with the game against Chile.'' Italy, the 1994 runner-up, departs for France on Friday and opens Group B play against Chile at Bordeaux June 11. Del Piero will work one-on-one with the team trainer Thursday. ``The healing process is going well. It's all going according to plan,'' said Del Piero, 23. ``But I can't say any more than that. We'll wait until the work intensifies and we will see how I hold up.'' A healthy Del Piero, who scored a career-best 31 goals for Juventus this season, would start in attack alongside either Christian Vieri or Fabrizio Ravanelli. Del Piero was injured in the Champions Cup final May 20. (hjf)

BC-Japan-Nuclear Forum, 1st Ld-Writethru
Japan's premier proposes nuclear non-proliferation forum
Eds: RECASTS; UPDATES 8th graf with additional background material.
TOKYO (AP) _ Japan's prime minister proposed an international forum on Wednesday to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons in the wake of recent nuclear tests by India and Pakistan. Speaking before a Parliamentary committee, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said Japan should take the lead in convening a meeting of non-proliferation experts from around the world. Japanese Foreign Minister Keizo Obuchi will formally announce the proposal in a speech scheduled for Thursday in Tokyo, a foreign ministry spokesman said. Japan, the only country ever to suffer a nuclear attack, has been among the harshest critics of India and Pakistan after those nations carried out nuclear weapons tests last month. It has punished both countries by suspending economic aid. Preparations will begin soon on holding a non-proliferation forum later this summer, possibly in the city of Hiroshima, Japanese evening newspapers reported. The foreign ministry official, who declined to be named, said the site and date of the forum has not been decided yet, but indicated the experts meeting may not be convened until autumn. On Tuesday, forty-six countries in the Conference on Disarmament, including Japan and the United States, demanded that India and Pakistan immediately cease testing nuclear arms and join in the global move to eliminate the weapons. Foreign ministers from the U.S., Japan and six other leading nations plan to meet in London on June 12 to coordinate efforts to bring nuclear activities in India and Pakistan under international supervision. CIVIL servants will get the lowest pay rise since 1983 this year, with senior staff getting slightly more than lower-ranked staff despite calls for parity. The Civil Service Bureau yesterday recommended 5.79 per cent for middle and lower-salary bands among the 190,000 civil servants, and 6.03 per cent for upper-salary band and the directorate. The salary increases, if approved, will cost the government an estimated $2.48 billion extra a year. Secretary for the Civil Service Lam Woon-kwong announced the pay offer following discussions with Executive Council members and union representatives. The offer for the upper- and middle-rank civil servants was made in line with the recommendations by the Pay Trend Survey, which reflected the average salary increase for private sector employees last year. The survey also suggested a pay rise of 5.01 per cent for lower-band civil servants. Civil service unions had earlier requested an adjustment of 6.03 per cent across the board. Mr Lam said the offer was ``fair and reasonable'' and consistent with the system used in the last two decades when salary increases for upper-level staff were higher than those of the lower ranks. Last year, pay adjustments were 6.81 per cent for middle and lower-band staff, and 6.9 per cent for the upper ranks. The pay rise for lower-band civil servants would be adjusted to be on a par with that of the middle band, and would be higher than proposed by the survey, Mr Lam said. Chan Cheung-yee, chairman of the Model Scale 1 Staff Consultative Council, said he was disappointed with the offer, while the other three consultative councils said it was ``acceptable''.. Mr Chan criticised the government for not considering existing economic difficulties and the widening salary gap between upper and lower-level civil servants. He said members would discuss whether to present a counter-proposal to the authority, but he ruled out the possibility of any industrial action. Leung Chi-chiu, of the Senior Civil Service Council, said the offer was ``generally acceptable''. Junior staff of the Hong Kong Chinese Civil Servants' Association are to discuss the offer tonight. Counter-proposals are to be presented before Saturday, and the Executive Council will make a final decision later this month. Meanwhile, The Frontier, which will have three seats in the new legislature, said it would vote against the proposed pay rise, convenor Emily Lau Wai-hing said. ``We are against the gap of pay rise levels between the senior and junior civil servants. The lower-ranked civil servants should get more in face of the economic downturn,'' Ms Lau said. Hong Kong Confederation of Trade Unions (HKCTU) chairman, Lau Chin-shek, said last night the union was undecided on its voting directions.

A 38-YEAR-OLD female police officer and her two daughters remained in critical condition late last night after apparently giving their dog mouth-to-mouth resuscitation. They were trying to save their dog after it collapsed during an anti-tick shampoo treatment. Veterinary surgeons said the shampoo contained the highly-toxic insecticide Amitrax, normally used to rid farm animals of ticks, or blood-sucking parasites. Ms Chong Tak-ying, 38, and her 16 and 14-year-old daughters Lee Wai-chung and Sau-chung, all suffered respiratory problems and confusion when they were admitted to Prince of Wales Hospital about 3 am yesterday. Their condition deteriorated rapidly and they were moved to the Intensive Care Unit when they lapsed into unconsciousness. They recovered consciousness about 10.30 pm, but their condition remained critical late last night. The dog, a mixed breed, was found dead at their home in Sai Kung. Dr Cheung Wai-lun, chief of the hospital's Accident and Emergency Service, said they were trying to save the victims by providing breathing support and heart strengthening injections. ``We know from friends of the victims that they had used a drug called Amitrax _ a flea-killing wash _ on their dog. And the victims' symptoms match possible side-effects of the drug. But we had to wait for the police test for confirmation,'' said Dr Cheung. The family, who live in Kwun Hang Chuen in Sai Kung, were reported to have been given an anti-flea chemical by a friend. They applied it to their dog on Monday night. According to Ms Chong's brother, the family had called a friend about the use of the chemical when they discovered there was something wrong with the dog. They were told to give the poisoned dog water, but it soon collapsed. They then tried to revive it with mouth-to-mouth resuscitation. They felt discomfort afterwards and immediately called the police for help. Dr Cheung said Amitrax was a commonly used insecticide made of highly concentrated chemical solutions which should be diluted in 500 to 600 times of water before use. He warned that a few grams of the chemical could be dangerous if improperly used. He said drinking it or leaving skin exposed to the chemical could be harmful to pets and humans. He said the chemical could suppress the function of the central nervous system resulting in dizziness, cramps, coma, and lower heartbeat and blood pressure. Neighbour Ms Lui said she heard someone crying about 3am before the police arrived. The dog's carcass was taken away by the police for examination. Pet-shop owner Ms Kwong said she would not recommend the use of concentrated chemicals for flea treatment as it could be poisonous. ``Any overdose could be fatal to the pet and human,'' she said. She said there were less-concentrated anti-flea shampoos for dogs and also flea controlling pills. The main purpose of the shampoo and drug was not to kill the fleas but to stop its ability to breed.

THE picture which appeared in the New Straits Times on May 6 showing the carcass of a rare whale shark in Dungun port, Terengganu, surrounded by fishermen who had sold its fins and tail, churned many a stomach. To some, it was just one less fish in the sea. Why should anyone care if we have put marine life in our oceans in peril? Why should we be concerned that wasteful fishing practices, result in the trapping of non-commercial species which would ultimately lead to their depletion and extinction? Is anyone even aware that 1998 has been declared the Year of the Oceans by the United Nations? A whole can of worms was opened with that story which was front-paged in the NST. Besides the general indifference shown by Malaysians, (fishermen in particular), towards marine conservation, the authorities appeared to display apathy bordering on a lack of responsibilty towards the incident. When contacted by NST, Fisheries Department chief enforcement officer Kapt (R) Wan Fatah Wan Omar had said the department would not take action against the fishermen as ``they had caught the fish accidentally''. The whale shark is the largest known species of fish and can grow to 20 metres in length. Harmless and a plankton feeder, the gentle giant dwells in oceanic and coastal waters of tropical and warm temperate areas. It has no commercial value. Department of Fisheries, Marine Parks Section head Kevin Hiew was later asked to provide an explanation for Wan Fatah's response, which had raised the ire of the public and conservationists. His answer shed light on the incident and was perturbing, to say the least. The law does not afford protection to whale sharks which have been classified by the World Conservation Union's Red List as a species known to be ``endangered, vulnerable or rare''. Section 27(1) of the Fisheries Act 1985 (amended in 1993) states: ``No person shall fish for, disturb, harass, catch or take any aquatic mammal or turtle which is found beyond the jurisdiction of any state in Malaysia.'' The penalty for contravening this section is a fine not exceeding RM5,000. However, the whale shark, according to Hiew is a ``fish'' and thereby not covered under this section. Hiew also added that no state in the peninsula afforded protection to fish such as the whale shark if caught within three nautical miles of its jurisdiction. In short, the laws in the country concerning marine conservation are inadequate, Hiew said. Maritime Institute of Malaysia's senior analyst Mohd Nizam Basiron added that Malaysia's marine protected area system should be extended to include the open seas. This notion, he said, was being proposed by scientists who considered entire oceans and seas, such as the South China Sea, as a large marine ecosystem. Despite the overwhelmingly gloomy outlook, the Fisheries Department is in the midst of formulating a regulation under the Act which would afford protection for aquatic animals not covered by existing legislation. For the sake of these ``unprotected species'' and the peace of mind of conservationists the world over, the sooner the regulation is drawn up, the better. Meanwhile, what are we doing to make people understand that exploiting wildlife in the deep sea or overfishing is perilous to our own well-being? An international World Wide Fund for Nature (Malaysia) report presents the grim facts. At least 60 per cent of the world's 200 most valuable fish species are either overfished or fished to the limit. Some such as the Atlantic halibut and bluefin tuna have been fished to the brink of commercial extinction. In some estuaries, more than 80 per cent of key nursery habitat has been lost to development. Less than one per cent of the oceans and coasts have been designated as protected areas. Scientific officer with the Malaysian Nature Society Melissa Renganathan said there should be greater efforts to educate the public on the presence of rare fish and other marine creatures. ``When people are more aware of the importance of our marine ecosystems, only then can we progress towards conserving our marine ecosystems,'' she added. The Fisheries Department has taken a step in the right direction. Targeting the fishing community, Hiew said the department had carried out regular dialogue sessions with fishermen on why there was a need to gazette marine parks which fishermen felt were a threat to their livelihood. ``We have held talks, slide shows and shown videos on why certain marine animals like turtles have to be protected,'' he said. He added that youths were taken scuba diving in an effort to cultivate an appreciation for marine life at a tender age. ``We hope that by seeing for themselves the beauty the sea possesses, they will be more concerned about its protection,'' he said Is there more to be done? WWF scientific officer Mohd Nasir Abdul Salam offered some suggestions. The establishment of protected areas, including sanctuaries and buffer zones, are important for conserving critical habitats in their natural state. The construction of artificial reefs in inshore waters can contribute greatly to the replenishment of our diminishing fishery resources and also protect the inshore waters of traditional fishermen from encroachment by trawlers or other commercial fishermen. Highly-selective fishing equipment should be developed and promoted in order to minimise the capture of non-commercial fish and immature commercially-important fish. The time for change is now. Let there be a resounding call for action.

BC-Britain-Missing Uranium
Missing uranium causes upset, but plant says it's a mere technicality
DOUNREAY, Scotland (AP) _ Reports that enough uranium to make a half-dozen nuclear warheads is missing from Britain's Dounreay processing plant provoked outrage Wednesday, but authorities said it was a mere technicality and that the material was never there. The United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority confirmed that an internal inquiry listed 170 kilograms (374 pounds) of uranium as missing, mostly from processing work in the mid-1960s. But it said that was due to a 1 percent overestimate in the amount of material that went into the plant then. ``The question that you could have 170 kilograms still inside the processing plant is absolutely preposterous. The plant simply couldn't continue to operate. It would be detectable,'' the authority's chief executive, John McEwan, said in a BBC radio interview. The controversy, which prompted demands for a judicial inquiry, was only the latest at the plant in northern Scotland. In April, Dounreay attracted international attention when 4.3 kilograms (9.46 pounds) of highly enriched uranium and 0.8 kilograms (1.76 pounds) of spent nuclear fuel were shipped there from Georgia, a restive former Soviet republic. Prime Minister Tony Blair said Britain accepted the shipment to prevent the threat of nuclear proliferation The Scottish National Party, which has long demanded that Britain scrap nuclear weapons unilaterally and opposes Dounreay in principle, urged a South African-style truth commission to examine the matter of the missing uranium, with staff past and present exempted from official secrecy rules. ``We are now in the ludicrous situation where we are hoping that the uranium was used to make British atom bombs because the alternatives are even harder to stomach,'' party spokeswoman Roseanna Cunningham said. The missing material was listed in a recently published inventory of the contents of a reprocessing shaft. Inquiries in 1963 and 1973 found that the missing material was likely due to uncertainty in estimates of the uranium input to the plants. (mj-kg)

PARIS (AP) _ French police on Wednesday arrested three more suspects believed linked to Muslim militants plotting a terrorist attack around the World Cup. With BC-SOC--World Cup By HOWARD CAMPBELL Associated Press Writer
KINGSTON, Jamaica (AP) _ Jamaica is likely to be the novelty act of the World Cup, just as Cameroon was in Italy in 1990. It also wants to emulate Cameroon's performance by reaching the quarterfinals. At 1,000-1 odds to win the World Cup, Jamaica is given scant chance of even making it to the second round. But the underdog tag is something the ``Reggae Boyz'' have used to their advantage. Relying on stingy defense, Jamaica has been anything but pushovers for soccer giants like Brazil and up-and-comers such as the United States. In their qualifying campaign, the Jamaicans amassed an unbeaten home record of 30 matches over three years. Coach Rene Simoes, a Brazilian import, insists his team isn't built around stars. But the Jamaicans have more than their share of individual flair. In Deon Burton, who plays for Derby County in the English Premier League, they have a goal-hungry forward with opportunistic instincts. Overlapping fullback Ricardo Gardener, who scored in a 1-0 upset win over Colombia last August, could be a sensation in France. With a reggae theme song and even a Jamaican tourism campaign built around them, the ``Reggae Boyz'' certainly are colorful. Offensive-minded they are not, scoring two or more goals only five times in their 20 qualifying games. Still, Simoes is credited with transforming Jamaican soccer and making the nation capable of becoming the first Caribbean team to reach the finals since Haiti in 1974. A youth coach in Brazil, Simoes became Jamaica's technical director in late 1994 and courted businesses to get his program off the ground. Jamaica's fortunes rose in 1995 when wins over higher-rated opponents like Zambia and Mexico earned it FIFA's Best Mover award. That type of form paid off in October, when a 0-0 tie with Mexico earned Jamaica the third qualifying spot in the CONCACAF zone. Jamaica won nine of its last 16 matches, beating Mexico, El Salvador and Costa Rica along the way. Jamaica also tied crucial away games against the United States, Canada and Honduras. The pre-Cup run peaked in February, when Jamaica held defending world champion Brazil to a 0-0 tie in the Gold Cup. Jamaica has stumbled since, producing no fireworks against Iran, South Korea and Macedonia. At home, Simoes was harshly criticized for giving eight spots in his 24-man lineup to England-based players of Jamaican heritage, including defender Danny Maddix of Queens Park Rangers and Chelsea wingback Frank Sinclair. ``I don't care what people think. Once they are good players and can fit in they will play,'' Simoes said. ``If the squad that I have does not improve, I have to look elsewhere.'' Jamaica plays another first-timer, Croatia, on June 14 and has two-time titlist Argentina and another debuting team, Japan, to contend with. Simoes says his squad will be ready. ``We're not going there to promote tourism,'' he said. End Adv for release any time

THE government plans to create tens of thousands of jobs by bringing forward short-term and medium-term infrastructure projects. Projects would be launched ahead of schedule over the next 22 months, sources said. The measure is part of a concerted effort to put the economy _ which recorded 2 per cent negative first quarter growth and has unemployment at a 14-year high _ back on track. Financial Secretary Sir Donald Tsang Yam-kuen is to discuss measures to create jobs with senior government officials today. Secretary for Works Kwong Hon-sang said yesterday the number of jobs to be created by the scheme immediately would not exceed 40,000. But a source said the total number of jobs to be created in the next 22 months would ``not be too far off'' that figure. Mr Kwong said the plan would be limited by complicated works procedures such as public consultation and land resumption. ``There are more than 1,000 public works projects. Not all can be scheduled to start early,'' he said. ``But all relevant departments have received instructions to study whether their projects can start as soon as possible.'' Mr Kwong said it was wrong to believe that fewer jobs from infrastructure projects would be available after the completion of Chek Lap Kok airport. ``In the past two years, we have spent more money on routine works projects than we have spent in the airport core projects,'' he said. Such routine projects have cost the government more than $20 billion in the last two years. Pending infrastructure work included rail and housing projects, Mr Kwong said. In the next five years more than $235 billion is slated for infrastructure spending, far exceeding the $155 billion spent on the airport in the last few years. ``On top of these investments, there will certainly be works from the private sector which, for the past years in Hong Kong, contributed to a very large proportion of our annual total construction investment,'' Mr Kwong said. ``There will definitely be a lot of jobs.'' Hong Kong Construction Association secretary-general Patrick Chan Wing-tung said the government should study three factors carefully. ``Skilled workers take time to train,'' Mr Chan said. ``Not only do unskilled and inexperienced workers affect the quality of work, their safety could also be at a higher risk.'' The government must also schedule projects carefully, he said. ``Different types of workers are required at different stages,'' he said. ``Some types of workers may still be out of work at certain stages . . . The government must therefore carefully schedule these projects.'' Mr Chan said the government might be able to solve unemployment among construction workers, but he believed most of those out of work were not from the construction field. Chan Yuen-han, Federation of Trade Unions spokesman and legislator-elect, said the government should help jobless workers go into the construction sector. Ms Chan said retail, catering and transport workers were finding it hard to achieve ``lateral movement'' in the job market because the government failed to help.

HISTORY is being slowly erased again, as we speak. This time, dikir barat, an age-old art which has long been part of the Malaysian society -and Kelantan people in particular - is facing a certain threat of being phased out. It started on May 28, when the Kelantan State Government decided to ban dikir barat performances with immediate effect. All local authorities were also ordered to withdraw permits issued for any dikir barat performance in the State. The decision was apparently made on the grounds that some quarters had abused the permits issued to them. Instead of just holding dikir barat performances, the organisers included other forms of entertainment which ``contradicts Islamic teachings,'' Kelantan Menteri Besar Datuk Nik Abdul Aziz Nik Mat was reported to have said. Point taken, that if someone breaks the rule, action should be taken and the person should be penalised appropriately. Much as one applauds the Kelantan Government for its ``swift action'', one cannot help but be dismayed by its repercussions of a blanket ban. It reminds one of an old Malay saying marahkan nyamuk, kelambu di bakar (loosely translated as ``burning the entire mosquito net when you're merely annoyed by the mosquitoes''). Back to the matter, if indeed there were organisers who used their permits to stage more than just dikir barat, then by all means punish the bad boys - warn them, fine them, reprimand them, whatever. But stamping out the art altogether is being hasty. But looking back, phasing out art forms in the name of religion seems to be a favourite pastime of the Kelantan government. Over the years, it has already applied similar pressure on its people's art like the traditional puppet theatre - wayang kulit (the performers were advised to ``modify'' their puppets and the method of storytelling) and dance dramas menora and mak yong because they were deemed as not being ``in line with Islamic teachings''. Due to that, the number of ``practitioners'' has dwindled. It has interfered with the passing down of the arts, which has been done in the State through many generations. This is certainly a sad situation, especially when dikir barat, wayang kulit, mak yong and menora could be viewed as very important tools in disseminating information. They are entertaining (and rather safe) and most importantly, educational. In the case of dikir barat, humour and the spirit of ``comradeship'' are the main elements, and they are blended with a certain storyline, usually with a very strong message at the end. Dikir barat, while maintaining its basic characters and style, is dynamic as it could also be very contemporary in its content. The tukang karut (the storyteller) uses his wit to dissect any current issue, which could turn out to be a rather strong form of social comment. Could this be the thing which has made those in office paranoid? That the dikir barat people and their followers are using the art for ``diabolical'' purposes? (Remember Indochine, the French film on the history of Vietnam where theatre people influenced their countrymen through their mobile ``opera'' performances?) If we have to be paranoid, then a little control will definitely be a better way rather than destroy. At least the ``net'' could still be used to ward off the mosquitoes. Plainly, the authorities could keep show organisers in check by making sure they don't abuse the permits for dikir barat shows. The drastic action of banning affects people across the board. While dikir barat performers are deprived of making a living, its people the entertainment, non-Kelantan folk will never know and understand the State and its people through their rich cultural imprint and heritage. And don't even think of its touristic potential. Are we supposed to revert to the 70s when the ``Kelantan experience'' was only mainly savoured through special programmes and slots on radio and television? (Dendang Rakyat was one of the main outlets). There were (still are) also recordings of dikir barat performances on cassette tapes, but that is not the same as experiencing the live performance. Well, whatever it is, the ``strangulation'' of artistic expression is something that saddens us the most, and this does not only apply to just Kelantan. When everyone around us is talking about preservation with a high level of adaptability, we seem to be more intent on burying something that is still alive and well. The question is: How can we be sure of our existence, if we keep rejecting everything (harmless) that has always been part of us?

Eds: RECASTS, UPDATES with comments by Tehran Governor, newspaper By AFSHIN VALINEJAD Associated Press Writer
TEHRAN, Iran (AP) _ An outlawed Iranian opposition group claimed responsibility for a bombing and two mortar attacks Wednesday on government facilities that killed at least three people. A bomb exploded Tuesday at the Revolutionary Prosecutor's office in Tehran. Official sources, speaking on customary condition of anonymity, said at least three people were killed and two injured. The official Islamic Republic News Agency earlier denied the bombing was the work of the Mujahedeen Khalq, but Tehran's Governor General Mohammad Reza Ayatollahi said Wednesday that the group was behind the attack, Tehran television reported. In a statement Wednesday, the Mujahedeen said it also carried out two mortar attacks Tuesday on the Central Command Headquarters of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps and the Defense Industries Organization in the capital. The Mujahedeen said the attacks were in retaliation for the killing of its members in recent months by the Iranian government. The Farda daily reported Tuesday that 50 fighters from the outlawed group had sneaked into Iran from the porous border with Afghanistan. State-run radio reported only a bomb explosion Tuesday at a government building in northern Tehran, but gave no further details. Also Wednesday, police evacuated guests and staff at the Ferdowsi Hotel in central Tehran following a bomb threat made by a caller, sources said. No bomb was found at the hotel, which is close to the Foreign Ministry and military offices. In a statement faxed to The Associated Press in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, the Mujahedeen said that in its ``surprise'' attack on IRGC headquarters, ``several Revolutionary Guards were killed or wounded and the headquarters' buildings were damaged.'' It did not claim any casualties for the attack on the defense industries building. However, Iranian radio said security men foiled an attempted attack by ``saboteurs'' at IRGC headquarters Tuesday and the perpetrators fled. It gave no other details. Newspapers reported contradictory casualty figures in the explosion at the prosecutor's office. One newspaper said five people were killed, while another reported that nine people also were injured. A third said two women and three men were killed. A police official at the scene said a bomb in a briefcase caused the explosion at the prosecutor's office. However, IRNA said the explosion was caused by explosive material being brought to the court as evidence in a case under investigation when it went off accidentally. Bombings are rare in Tehran where security is tightly controlled. The last reported bombing in Tehran was four years ago when two devices went off in a commercial district but caused no fatalities. Those explosions remain a mystery.

BINTAN ISLAND, Riau (JP): On a warm May afternoon above a forested cliff, Ria Bintan Club Med Resort executives gathered to celebrate the resort's first summer season with 150 corporate clients and 230 journalists from around the world. General manager Mehdi Serrour and Club Med CEO Philippe Bourgougnov played hosts to the guests enjoying the resort's lush grasslands, clear waters and above all, the complimentary three-day, two-night stay at the resort. This included fine wine and dining at any of the resort's four restaurants, a circus school, a multitude of activities from trying trapeze acts, archery, windsurfing, scuba diving to animation theater, and staying in luxurious rooms, most of which have a sea view. The resort, opened on Oct. 24, 1997, is Club Med's newest addition to its current 120 villages in 36 countries worldwide, along with one in Cuba that also opened last year. At the gathering, Serrour would not say what the extravagant Club Med cost to build, but a corporate client figured that the cost could have reached more than Rp 15 billion. The Ria Bintan Club Med Resort (RBCM), built on 20 hectares, has guests enjoying a nearby 218-hole golf course, which does not belong to Club Med, an exclusive beach, beautiful architecture and aquamarine waters of the South China Sea. With Singapore less than an hour away by boat, day trips or two to three-day trips are available from Bandar Bentan Telani Ferry Terminal, Bintan Resorts. The resort has 308 rooms and two heated swimming pools. According to Serrour, the resort comprises 15 percent of the S$3.5 billion investment pie significantly baked by the widely diversified Salim Group and Singapore's Keppel Group. The Salim Group developed Bintan Beach International Hotel on 23,000 hectares in a consortium comprising Riau's provincial administration, the Indonesian Navy and a group of Singaporean investors. The Indonesian group owns 60 percent of the project and the rest belongs to Singaporean investors. The consortium has managed to turn the swamps and jungle along the island's northern beaches into a posh tourist resort. Its hotel list includes the Rasa Indah, Sedona Bintan Lagoon, Bintan Lagoon Beach and Resort, RBCM, Banyan Tree Bintan, Mana Mana Beach Club and the Nirwana Garden Resort. Despite a debilitating economic crisis and the heated political situation, RBCM can still afford luxuries. Target When asked about cost-cutting measures, Serrour shrugged. ``We have a chairman who believes a lot in brands. It wouldn't be Club Med if we cut costs. I'd say we'll see more and more of the Club Med logo... the same all over the world,'' Serrour said. ``There are usually two choices. Cutting cost or doing our all to fill up the resort by having more people coming in, even in low season. Cut costs or make incomes better. We chose the latter. Again, it is not about throwing money out the window.'' With strong rumors pointing at a 50 percent occupancy rate as the cause of the extravaganza to entertain media and corporate clients, Serrour said a 70 percent occupancy rate was the target. ``We are more or less achieving what we had wanted to at this point of the year. We may have less Koreans or less Indonesians (Asians in general) than expected (due to the crisis),'' Serrour said. ``We have, however, gained from the European side. Last week, we had 250 French people who stayed two weeks, which made all the difference. A lot of Japanese in the same week stayed for three days. ``Europeans, because they come from so far off, take full advantage of their time and vacation here.'' Weekday room rates cost an adult Rp 1.2 million, a child between four and 11 Rp 780,000, and a child between a few months old and three years Rp 165,000. Weekend rates cost an adult Rp 1.5 million, Rp. 960,000 for children between four and 11, and Rp 210,000 for infants. High season room rates differ and cost about Rp 300,000 more for adults and children between four and 11. This excludes lunch, dinner and sports activities costs. Serrour reiterated that Club Med was not currently focusing on finance. ``How can we... when you have just started something, you don't expect to make money tomorrow or the day after tomorrow,'' Serrour said. He said the resort was currently trying to improve in terms of service and staff. ``Simply by listening and watching the life of the resort (the guests), we are going to see in terms of operation what we are going to propose to our guests. ``For instance, sports. Are we going to talk mainly in terms of land sports (golf) or water sports ...'' The staff at RBCM comprise 66 expat general organizers (full-fledged entertainers and helpers) and 350 Indonesians. The whole staff represents 37 nationalities and 26 languages. It was also ``a little impossible'' to cut down on staff, Serrour said. ``The people who perform in the night shows are the same who take care of the kids, the bar, the same who teach you windsurfing. If they are fired, how are we to fulfill our promises to our guests?'' He explained that almost all of them enjoyed being trained to be jacks of all trades. ``You have to understand that all of them are living out a concept,'' Serrour said. ``They (general organizers) are 20 to 25 years of age, positive about life. They get to live near the beach and live the lives of teenagers... work all day and all night, party all day and all night, eat the quality of food that they eat here... what reason would they have not to be happy?'' This might be true to the last word. However, the service staff complained of being underpaid. Sam (not his real name), said that the ``French chef nicely pockets Rp 24 million every month'' while the ``Indonesian chef'' makes close to ``Rp 1 million only''. Sam pointed out that even if the Indonesian chef was not ``of the same level... or not as qualified or not holding a position equal to that of the French chef, the gap is still too wide''. Club Med around the world boasts 76,000 beds, 12 villages in Asia, 89 in Europe and 17 in North America. At the press conference on May 9, Bourgougnov, Club Med's CEO, said 14 percent of Club Med's business came from Asian general managers. ``Almost 92 percent of the GMs vacationing in Indonesia come from the Asia-Pacific region,'' Bourgougnov said. ``Seventeen percent from Australia, 20 percent from Japan, 5 percent from Singapore, 14.5 percent from Korea and GMs from the remaining Asian countries contribute 34.8 percent,'' Bourgougnov said. He lists the facilities worldwide -- among them about 14,000 service staff, 40 different sports and 950 sailboats. Then there are over 200 restaurants, 30,000 annual parties and an average of 27 million meals served a year.

Fun and frolicking in these times is hard to imagine, but not at the Ria Bintan Club Med Resort, located on the north coast of Bintan island. Club Med, celebrating one of its first holiday seasons in Bintan since its opening last October, invited journalists from several countries for a promotional trip from May 8 to May 10. The Jakarta Post was represented by Yogita Tahil Ramani, who wrote the following stories. BINTAN ISLAND, Riau (JP): A beach can leave a deep impression, especially if it's on the premises of Club Med Ria Bintan on the South China Sea. Considering the situation in Jakarta -- with people stressed to the hilt -- a few blessed reporters decided to see what Club Med had to offer and report on it. Period. Winda, a radio broadcaster, said: ``They (most people) cannot afford it (happiness). We are journalists. Let's just be that, add color and get it over with.'' A bus trip out of Hang Nadim Airport Batam changed this frame of mind. We passed forests of sprawling, untamed greenery and bald bark parched white from the heat during the 10-minute ride to the Telaga Punggur Ferry Terminal. The roads were almost empty. A 30-minute ride took us to Bandar Bentan Telani Ferry Terminal, Bintan Resorts, and from there, in two words, Club Med. The first thing that humbles the newcomer here is the tranquility of the sea. The blue vastness is given a backdrop of celestial skies. The water is clear, enabling you to see its seabed of fine sand. In the afternoon, we swam like children waiting for gigantic waves to hit us again and again. There were vast stretches of pepper-colored sand inviting people to play in it. Daydreaming in the evening. More people played in the sea than on the beach. Some flaunted skin-colored bikinis, while a few others dared to flaunt even less. Night show After a rich dinner, things started with the night show. The theater where it was held could seat more than 400, but people seemed to be sprawling all around. Aside from an exotic Brazilian snake-dancer, pirouetting to a ballad and executing Janet Jackson steps on stage, the evening's highlights included ballet-dancing to Whitney Houston's I Will Always Love You by a Moroccan Club Med general organizer (GO), Aziz, and the chef, Vivi. Aziz exhausted all of his admirable efforts in getting his arms in perfect ballet position -- his padded chest, his blond coiffeur of a wig and his tutu in place. Vivi was the picture of a gurgling seal, flapping his arms left and right in sheer white tights. Usually the night shows are followed by what Club Meders call Crazy Sign. The entire place was lit with burning lamps, lining the swimming pools and gardens. People gathered around the pools, while general manager Medhi Serrour requested guests to join him in recognizing the kitchen staff, the front-desk employees, housekeeping and other employees lined up on the stage. Lights focused on a huge, central symbol pasted on the outer portion of the building, the classic trident with a dot -- the symbol of Club Med. Amid the applause, a realization dawned on us. These people have built a city within the island. A city populated with more Europeans than Asians. A city where the only signs of Indonesia emerge from nature's sights and sounds and of course, the service staff. It is so detached from reality, and yet, a reality. A dreamland. It did not seem to be part of Indonesia. Crazy Sign brought us back to earth. People rushed to line up in rows and dance to a euphoric beat, following the dance steps of those onstage. They sang, folded hands and twirled hips to Un Dos Tres, Ale Ale Ale and danced zombie-style for Free From Desire. Songs ranged from YMCA to the disco version of My Heart Will Go On. All of a sudden, confetti started raining on us. Next thing we knew, we were forming a locomotive, dancing all the way to the main lounge. Here, everybody, including the CEO and other chef-de-villages of other countries, were doing the swing, salsa, lambada and all sorts of dance steps to I Feel Good, Shout and other great oldies. The crowd later shifted to the nightclub. There is something so deliciously daring, so becoming of people to appraise one another in a crowded scene. Particularly, on a dance floor. A trapeze swinger who had no sense of rhythm on the floor, stomped songs away while he danced. Hips swung in and circled the air, hands chopped them, bodies became entangled around others and there were eyes that felt but refused to see. They all danced. Quitting time was 4 a.m., only after some managed to do the Jaipongan, a traditional West Javanese dance, to a heavy-metal number.

European Union reaches out to its Mediterranean partners
Eds: UPDATES with Palestinian quotes By JEFFREY ULBRICH Associated Press Writer
PALERMO, Sicily (AP) - The European Union comes together with its Mediterranean partners Wednesday, trying to get the economic cooperation process back on track after last year's derailment by Mideast issues. A year ago in Malta, the EU's 15 foreign ministers gathered with their 12 Mediterranean colleagues to talk trade and investment, only to see their meeting blown away on the turbulent winds of the Mideast peace process. Even at the inaugural meeting of the Euro-Mediterranean conference in Barcelona in 1995, heady ideas also fell victim to disputes, that time over human rights. The Palermo meeting is an informal session with no set agenda. Organizers hope it will bring the conference back to its original idea of creating a European-Mediterranean free trade and security zone by 2010. Last year, Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat and then-Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy were the stars of the show, agreeing to resuscitate the moribund Middle East peace talks. Today, those talks are still stuck, and neither Arafat nor Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu plans to turn up here, but Mideast peace remains an unavoidable issue. ``We want a clear statement which shows the Europeans stand in support of the process of peace and expresses their willingness to revive the process,'' said Farouk Kaddoumi, head of foreign affairs for the Palestine Liberation Organization. ``And they have to refer to those who stand as a detriment to this process.'' Israel views the EU as pro-Arab and wants no significant role for Europe in the peace process beyond supplying funding. ``France and Britain have supported Israel since its creation,'' Kaddoumi said. ``Now, they claim the Europeans are friends of the Palestinians. I hope that is true ... and that they cut all economic assistance to the Israelis.'' No direct Palestinian-Israeli contacts are expected here, however. EU foreign ministers said in a statement that ``This meeting is aimed at providing a new momentum to the Barcelona process.'' Mediterranean nations sell half their exports to EU countries and provide the EU with 20 percent of its energy supplies. At the same time, half of the Mediterranean nations' imports come from Western Europe. The EU's per capita income is a dozen times higher than most of the North African and Mideast nations. Ministers here are continuing efforts to come up with a Euro-Mediterranean Stability Charter and the establish confidence-building measures for the region. On the economic side, the 27 were to discuss support for economies in transition, private investment in the non-European Mediterranean countries and eventual realization of the free-trade zone. Joining ministers from the European Union are officials from Algeria, Cyprus, Egypt, Jordan, Israel, Lebanon, Malta, Morocco, Syria, Tunisia, Turkey and the Palestinian Authority. (ju/vls)

DIAGNOSING the cause for the huge drop in Japanese tourists to Hong Kong will be high on the agenda for the Chief Secretary when she leaves today for Japan and the United States. Speaking after yesterday's Executive Council meeting, Chief Secretary for Administration Anson Chan Fang On-sang said she would meet Japanese tourism representatives to figure out what had discouraged Japanese travellers from visiting Hong Kong. ``We will try to find out what the problems are and hope to come up with measures to attract more Japanese to visit Hong Kong,'' Mrs Chan said. YOGYAKARTA (JP): Free forms of three-dimensional objects fill the modest gallery with various sculpting and engraving techniques. One which especially catches the eye is Gentle Seduction, a wooden statue two meters high. It reminds people of a three-legged creature in science fiction films. There are bends like joints in the wooden legs which seem to present an unsteady standing position. The three wooden legs support a ceramic cluster of forms suggesting something that is growing. This is the work of Japanese sculptor Shigeyo Kobayashi, 41, whose exhibition at the Cemeti Gallery here through June 3 is his second. The graduate majoring in metal arts at the Bunka University in Sapporo, Japan, was a student at the Indonesian Arts College in Denpasar, Bali from 1994 to 1995 -- which may explain locals' familiarity with some of his works. Kobayashi combines both organic and nonorganic materials in a strongly decorative style. He uses forest wood, clamshells, coral, seeds, brass and aluminum. He processes all the material into imaginative forms to give a message which the layman might not always easily be able to share. One serial work, Listening for a crack, is composed from forms resembling split, gigantic peanut shells in colorful hues. Growing buds are seen in the open shells. This work reflects Kobayashi's frequent theme of the relationship between nature and man. He is apparently much inspired by the process of the growth of plants which in their turn produce very esthetic forms. He says one source of his inspiration is his birthplace in Sapporo. ``I always remember my grandmother's story of how plants absorb the energy of the earth and the sun when in growth. If the energy is not sufficient, plants will take it from man. That is why many people become crazy when plants reappear toward the coming of spring,'' he said. For Kobayashi the mythology has become a fact. In Sapporo he used to feel weak and shaky, but in Bali where he settled for some time, he said he feels strong. He said he learnt to make use of natural material but always tries to avoid using too much of it, and combines his creations with unnatural material. The resulting exploration is striking and even provocative works. Bright contrasting colors, decorative beads made of seeds or metal and exotic spiral forms constitute the dominant esthetic language in his works. The tendency toward such a decorative style is influenced to a certain extent by the traditional Balinese style. Kobayashi seems to have freed artistic skills from the functional element usually attached to traditional art; his sculpting and engraving techniques are only efforts to attain his ideas of imaginative forms.

Indonesian students drive through Jakarta in protest convoy With Indonesia-Habibie Interview, Indonesia-Riot Toll
Eds: RECASTS for AMs; UPDATES throughout with more color AP Photos staffing By CHRISTOPHER TORCHIA Associated Press Writer
JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Standing on bus roofs and hanging out of car windows, about 1,500 triumphant students who helped oust President Suharto cruised down Jakarta's main thoroughfare Wednesday in a rowdy protest against his successor. Shouting ``Hang Suharto,'' they ignored an appeal by Indonesia's military chief to stop berating the former leader, who faces growing demands that he surrender riches accumulated during three decades in power. It was the largest protest since soldiers evicted students occupying Parliament on May 23, two days after Suharto resigned amid campus rallies and riots over price increases. Student protesters said Wednesday that Suharto should be tried for economic crimes and urged the ouster of his successor and longtime protege, B.J. Habibie. Earlier, in a television interview, the new president implored Indonesians not to dwell on the country's corrupt past and to focus on economic recovery. With the economy expected to shrink by at least 10 percent this year, the task is a daunting one. There are fears that riots may erupt again as more layoffs and price rises loom. In a report released Wednesday, a government commission said the death toll from riots in Jakarta last month was 1,188, more than double an estimate by the military. Many victims were looters trapped in buildings set afire by arsonists. The National Human Rights Commission also criticized the armed forces for failing to take prompt action to prevent rioting. Students scoffed at a pledge by Habibie to hold general elections in 1999, saying he was a corrupt lackey of Suharto and should step aside. A close ally of Suharto for decades, the new head of state is bowing to popular demands for democratic reform. ``Reject Habibie,'' chanted the students, who meandered in their protest caravan from the gates of Parliament to a major downtown intersection ringed by five-star hotels. Dozens spilled out of the packed vehicles, singing and skipping around a plaza fountain and waving red and white Indonesian flags as hotel guests peered from curtained windows. Some students shook the hands of soldiers in berets and camouflage uniforms who stood by, blocking roads leading to the city's main square and presidential palace. Some passing motorcyclists and bus passengers gave thumbs-up signs to the raucous protesters. Accusations have been building that Suharto aggravated Indonesia's financial crisis by encouraging his family to build vast business empires, sapping the state of much of its wealth. Armed forces chief Gen. Wiranto said the nation of 202 million people should pardon Suharto because he boosted economic growth and averted chaos by relinquishing power. ``Lately, condemnation and harassment against the former president and his family have been exaggerated and, in some cases, have gotten out of control,'' said Wiranto, a former personal aide to Suharto. ``The armed forces will take necessary measures to stop it,'' Wiranto said without elaborating. The military is the most powerful institution in Indonesia, which is beset by uncertainty about its political future. It is doubtful that Habibie, who has a shaky power base, would make any policy decisions without the backing of Wiranto. In an interview with Cable News Network that was broadcast Wednesday, Habibie argued against a painful investigation of misdeeds that could divide the nation. ``You have unlimited problems in the past. Where are you going to stop?'' Habibie said. ``So I think it is not worthwhile to dip into the past. I have to look to the future and create a better life ... for the people.'' In a separate interview with the New York Times, Habibie said Indonesians should not indulge in ``Wild West'' justice against the former leader. State prosecutors have launched an inquiry into corruption under the old government, including complaints that Suharto's family abused its influence to build huge business empires. However, critics doubt they will aggressively pursue the former president.
