KUALA LUMPUR, Mon. - An average of 2,700 Iraqi children below the age of five are dying every month due to lack of medicine following sanctions imposed by the United Nations over the past eight years. Speaker of the National Assembly of Iraq, Dr Saadoun Hamadi, said the people were also going through great difficulties and suffering for no reason following the sanctions. ``I am here to brief leaders of this country on the latest developments in Iraq and to gain support on the issue of lifting sanctions against the Iraqi people. ``The 2,700 death figure is not from us but the United Nations Children Fund agency,'' he said. He said this after calling on Dewan Negara President Tan Sri Mohamed Yaa'cob at Parliament House today. He said it was time the UN Security Council lifted sanctions against Iraq as the country's leadership has complied with all requirements pertaining to the inspection of mass destruction weapons. The sanctions were prolonged after the Security Council rejected a report from head of the UN Special Commission Richard Butler earlier this month. ``We have destroyed our weapons of mass destruction under the supervision of the Special Commission and complied with all other requirements. ``It is therefore time the sanctions are lifted,'' he said, alleging that Butler's report was influenced by the US and Britain. Resolution 687 says that after Iraq has destroyed its mass destruction weapons, sanctions on its oil exports and other international commerce should be lifted. ``As we have played our part, it is now the legal requirement of the commission to carry out the resolution,'' he said. Hamadi said the Security Council was also divided on the issue. ``The United States and Britain are on one side and they are trying everything to prolong sanctions. ``Other members, Russia, China and France and non-permanent members in the Security Council, think it is time to implement the resolution and that Iraq be given the liberty to export oil,'' he said. Asked why he chose to come to Malaysia, Hamadi said: ``Malaysia is a friendly country and I came to tell about the misery faced by the Iraqi people. ``I am also here to find ways to expand our economic and trade relations,'' he said. Before coming to Malaysia, Hamadi visited India.

Precede HANOVER At least 60 dead in high-speed German train crash
URGENT Eds: COMBINES pvs; minor editing By CLAUS-PETER TIEMANN Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ A high-speed passenger train derailed Wednesday in northern Germany after it crashed into an automobile that had plunged off an overpass onto the tracks. At least 60 people were killed and 200 injured. The Hamburg-bound train struck the auto at 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour as it approached the station in Eschede, 50 kilometers (35 miles) north of Hanover just before 11 a.m., officials said. The train was carrying about 300 passengers. The accident was the worst on Germany's premier high-speed ICE line inaugurated in 1991, and the most deadly rail crash in Germany since 1975 when 41 people died in the head-on collision of two express trains in Bavaria. At least 13 cars derailed, piling into each other and crashing into the base of the overpass, collapsing it. The force of the pile-up pushed cars meters (yards) high into the air. Several of the rail cars were demolished, and splintered glass covered the scene. Luggage was piled next to the wreckage as workers struggled to pry passengers from the train. A crane was positioned to lift chunks of the bridge to reach buried rail cars. Officials said the auto had crashed through the guardrail of the bridge running over the train tracks. Although it remained unclear, evidence at the scene suggested that the car struck the train as it passed under the overpass. The nose of the train had cleared the bridge, while the cars behind derailed and jackknifed into each other. The German border patrol sent helicopters and 80 personnel to help emergency workers free passengers trapped inside the rail cars. Officials feared many inside were dead. The accident closed train traffic in both directions. Federal Transport Minister Matthias Wissmann, Lower Saxony state governor Gerhard Schroeder and German railway executives were en route to the scene. The ICE train is Germany's fastest, connecting all major cities at speed up to 280 kilometers (175 miles) an hour. The train travels from Munich to Hamburg, covering a distance of more than 950 kilometers (about 600 miles), in 5 hours and 37 minutes. Regular train service takes more than eight hours. The high-speed trains carry more than 65,000 passengers daily. (cb-aet)

CONTINUING its widespread house-cleaning in the wake of corruption scandals, the Police Department has issued more disciplinary orders against its black sheep, ranging from division commanders to police cadets. Police chief Pracha Promnok vowed that one of the biggest purges in the agency's recent history would continue. ''I know morale is important, but it's more important to save the whole force,'' said Pracha, who has been under growing political pressure to stem the tide as new bribery and extortion scandals keep unfolding. It took two days, Monday and Tuesday, to affect the disciplinary actions while Central Investigation Bureau commissioner Pol Lt Gen Seri Temiyavej announced a planned revamp of the Crime Suppression Division to boost efficiency and stop kickback demands. Police insiders, meanwhile, warn that corruption has become a deep-rooted problem, eroding the credibility of the law enforcement agencies. Cadets had to pay kickbacks in order to get into the force and police officers in turn demanded bribes to enrich themselves, with wanton disregard to justice, by tampering with evidence, they said. Pol Gen Pracha Tuesday ordered the transfer of Forensic Science Region 1 commander Pol Maj Gen Samran Nilubon and Scientific Crime Detection Division commander Pol Maj Gen Visut Suwansuthi to inactive posts, citing their failure to maintain proper supervisory standards over their units. The order came on the heels of Monday's disciplinary action against two forensic officials, Pol Col Surachai Watcharayothin and Pol Lt Col Paisal Wongwatsana, on charges of demanding kickbacks from two business operators in exchange for changing forensic reports on two fires in a department store and a business premise in their favour. The tampered reports would rule against arson as the cause of the fires and facilitate the operators' insurance claims, according to the disciplinary investigation report on the two officers. Surachai and Paisal, both removed from their active posts, were under review by the disciplinary committee which would rule on their penalties. Pracha said in his transfer order that although there was no hard evidence to link Samran and Visut to the bribery cases involving their two subordinates, the two commanders have been shunted out. ''This disciplinary action is absolutely not the last. The blacklist is still long and our investigation is going on,'' Pracha said. In another disciplinary action, inspector Pol Maj Theerachai Haruthaisodsai of Loei's Tha Li police station was dismissed on charges of negligence for allowing a female drug trafficker to escape and abuse of power for having sex with the suspect. Heads continue to roll in the wake of the Salween logging scandal. Pol Maj Gen Pitak Thienthong, former Forestry Police Division commander, and Pol Maj Gen Chalerm Sanwanangkul, another former FPD chief, were placed under disciplinary investigation on charges of accepting kickbacks from poachers. A separate disciplinary investigation was launched to probe irregularities in the administering of this year's entrance examination for police cadets. Pol Col Wattana Kritayachote, instructor at the Police Cadet Academy, Pol Lt Anucha Kotchasenee of Prachachuen Police Station and two police cadets were charged with demanding Bt200,000 from each applicant in return for getting passing grades. Speaking after chairing a meeting with the CSD staff, Seri said he warned them to shape up and stay away from graft. Although the CSD had not been tainted with corruption scandals, supervising officers should enforce stricter discipline, he said, referring to recent reports that a low ranking police official was involved in drug trafficking and that some CSD policemen had formed a racket to demand protection money in the South. The CIB commissioner also disclosed that the CSD would soon be re-structured in order to downsize its areas of jurisdiction. For example, the CSD's superintendent for region 3 has the jurisdiction over an area equivalent to the responsibilities of three provincial police commissioners, he pointed out. Meanwhile, the interior minister's advisory team is sending a draft on the new police structure to the Council of State to ensure that major changes proposed do not violate the new Constitution.

Under the contract which will be signed within two weeks, the land will still belong to the SRT and the BMA will pay Bt555 million in total fees. No time period has been stipulated. SRT State Enterprise Employee Association president Somsak Kosaisuk said the SRT underestimated the price of the land when it sought only Bt555 million in fees for the use of 375 rai because the official assessment values the land at Bt150,000 per square wah, or Bt20 billion in total. Somsak warned the Communications Ministry not to interfere by ordering the SRT to sign the deal. He said such an attempt would violate the SRT Act. He said the act stipulated that land expropriated by the SRT may be used only to expand SRT operations. SRT land cannot be transferred to other agencies unless it is to be leased for commercial or residential purposes. The SRT has been struggling financially and instead of seeking increased income by raising train fares which would greatly affect low-income earners, it should seek to raise the land lease fees, Somsak said. ''We must rally against the plan. The ministry which oversees SRT must exercise more caution in making decisions which affect the public. They should be more responsible and have far-sighted vision,'' he said. Somsak said the BMA has taken advantage of the SRT in leasing the land for the Chatuchak Weekend Market because it earns over Bt800 million per year from operating the market but pays the SRT only Bt10 million for leasing the land.Even though the SRT loses money every year, it has not raised the rent. Mahin said although the BMA's decision to spend hundreds of millions of baht on the project at a time of economic difficulties may be criticised by some members of the public, the city administration will proceed with the plan because the present BMA stresses the building of more parks. ''The city residents are in dire need of parks which are like 'city lungs' because they can breathe fresh air and exercise for their health,'' he said. Mahin said the SRT golf course is most suitable for becoming a public park because it has large trees, decorative plants and pools and the BMA needs only to improve the sidewalks.

YOUNG and male workers are the hardest hit by unemployment, according to the latest labour-market analysis by the government. In previous years, workers aged 40 and above were among the first to be laid off when employers trimmed down staff. Previously, unemployment was particularly high among female workers, most of whom were housewives. But the latest labour market situation report prepared by the Financial Services Bureau reveals a sudden change in the trend. The report, which will be discussed at today's meeting of the Taskforce on Employment, shows that 63 per cent, or 67,100 of the 106,200 who were jobless during the first quarter, were between 15 to 39. ``Analysed by age, the rise in unemployment initially occurred among the middle-age and older workers aged 40 and above, but more recently it spread to younger workers aged 15-19 and 20-29, particularly those in the distribution and catering trades,'' the report said. The number of jobless workers in the first quarter aged 40-49 reached only 23,800, almost a third of those between 15 and 39-years old. Those between 50 and above only account for 14 per cent, or 15,400. Unemployment has become much more prominent among males than females, the report says. About 67 per cent, or 71,400 of the unemployed, are male _ more than twice the 34,800 unemployed females. The rise in the unemployment rate was across the board in all major sectors. Sectors showing the most significant slackening were interior decoration, marketing, on-site construction and retail, restaurants and hotels. Analysed by educational attainment, the rise in unemployment was mainly concentrated in workers with secondary education or below, particularly those with primary education. The report also shows that males have more difficulty going back to work. Males were more prone to protracted unemployment _ out of work for 12 months or more. Former manufacturing workers suffered more from protracted unemployment despite their sector's smaller share of the workforce. Protracted unemployment is much higher for production-related workers than for managers, administrators and professionals, the report says.

MOST countries surveyed by the Foreign Ministry have agreed to allow Thai embassies and consulates to be used as polling stations during the next election, but prohibited campaigning, a senior Foreign Ministry official said Tuesday. Initial surveys indicate that about 850,000 Thai nationals presently reside overseas, deputy spokesman Karun Ruechuyothin said. Some countries, including Singapore, have yet to be surveyed. ''Thai nationals who want to cast their ballots in the election must lodge their intention to vote with the embassy or consular office in the country in which they are living,'' Karun said. At present, Thailand has 80 embassies and consular offices overseas. The embassies have asked their host governments whether they will permit Thai nationals to vote in their countries. Most agreed that polling can be conducted at the embassies, but said election campaigning is prohibited by legislation. Karun said Thai citizens who want to vote must present their household registrations and passports to an embassy. The Foreign Ministry has proposed to the Election Commission that the ballots be sent to Thailand for counting by diplomatic pouch and the ministry set up a committee to guarantee neutrality when sealing and opening the pouches. ''The voting period for Thais abroad will be prior to the election date in Thailand as it will take time for the embassies to return the ballots in time for counting on election day,'' Karun said. Voting in countries with many expatriate Thais, such as in the United States, will last several days to cope with the expected demand. The present constitution allows Thai citizens residing abroad to lodge an absentee vote. The Election Commission is collecting information in preparation for the next election, particularly regarding absentee voting, as it will be the first time this kind of voting has been permitted under the constitution. Karun said the embassies will provide voters with a list of candidates. The Election Commission will consider the preparation processes for absentee voting proposed by the Foreign Ministry.

China reports deteriorating environment
BEIJING (AP) _ In a new report on China's deteriorating environment, the government warns that water pollution and water shortages are holding back national economic growth, the state-run Xinhua News Agency reported Wednesday. The annual report, issued Wednesday, said China's seven major river systems and its lakes, reservoirs and some underground and coastal waters are suffering from pollution. Many cities suffer from serious water shortages, it said. ``The shortage of water resources and water pollution have restricted the country's economic and social development,'' the report said. Xinhua's account of the report gave few details, but noted that urban air pollution was getting worse due to the boom in the number of cars. The State Environmental Protection Administration's report said the country made ``remarkable achievements'' in cleaning the Huai River, where the government ordered the shutdown of thousands of heavily polluting small factories. Xinhua said the report also said the quality and area of arable land are decreasing, grasslands have been lost to overdevelopment, and there has been a growth of the improper use of agricultural chemicals.

The ACA started the first investigation following a report lodged by Pas Youth secretary Mahfuz Omar with the Selangor ACA in Shah Alam on Dec 29. This came in the wake of an admission by Muhammad that the money which he failed to declare at the Brisbane airport while enroute to New Zealand belonged to his three brothers, Datuk Raduan, Datuk Othman and Hassan. The second investigation was connected to the conversion of a 40-hectare forest area in Bukit Sungai Putih, Hulu Langat involving Muhammad's former aides. It was reported that the land was gazetted as a forest reserve in 1972, but the State Executive Council took a decision in 1990 to degazette it. Top crime-fighter Pol Lt-Gen Seri Temiyavej, thrust into the forefront of the battle against corruption, has plenty on his plate. The Nation's Chaiyakorn Bai-ngern takes a look at the man heading the Central Investigation Bureau. He has been the most sought-after and the busiest man in the Police Department since the Democrat Party took power last year, but the question is, will noted crime-buster Pol Lt-Gen Seri Temiyavej live up to expectations with an increasing number of arduous tasks assigned to him? Despite his unblemished record, his supporters have begun to wonder whether Seri will eventually become his own worst enemy. Critics are asking why only one person has to shoulder so many responsibilities in a force overflowing with generals. A former communist-fighter whose straightforward manner makes him unpopular among his colleagues, he was appointed Commissioner of the Central Investigation Bureau following the formation of the Chuan government. After he took the post, his first job was to investigate a bribery scandal in connection with the so-called Salween logging scandal. Interior Minister Sanan Kachornprasart personally picked Seri to handle the issue after then Royal Forestry Department director-general Prawat Thanadkha went to Government House to donate Bt5 million to the Thai-Help-Thai Fund. The money, Prawat claimed, had been given to him by a logger as a bribe to cover illegal logging operations in Salween National Forest. Seri had scarcely finished his first mission when he was ordered by Sanan to clamp down on illegal activities by influential figures, mostly with close ties to powerbrokers in the previous government. A backlash from the Democrat Party's arch rivals was inevitable, of course, with growing resentment among opposition members following the crackdown. His move to arrest New Aspiration Party MP Wichai Chaijitvanij on the last day of the no-confidence debate against the Chuan administration was seen as the last straw. Although Wichai was charged with having a smuggled vehicle in his possession, the opposition vehemently criticised Seri and branded him ''a government lackey''. But Seri, apparently buoyed by support from the Democrats, did not yield to the pressure. He came out on the offensive, attacking the opposition with scathing comments and vowing to dig for more dirt. Since then, the battle between him and the opposition has seemed to rage non-stop. Seri went on to uncover a scam in which NAP MP Premsak Piayura allegedly received Bt1 million in exchange for his commitment to assist a police officer in the annual transfers. Even though Premsak adamantly denied his involvement in the scam, he appeared to be the loser. Seri undoubtedly gained the upper hand. This proved true when the NAP MP discovered that Seri had used his former personal secretary, Pramual Aimpia, as a key witness in the allegations. Political observers said that Seri's move had virtually sealed the fate of the once promising star Premsak, but exasperated by Seri's shrewd move, the physician turned politician vowed he would never stop pursuing the top cop. To ease the mounting tension, Seri went away to the United States for a fortnight. When he came back, however, he was assigned to investigate the ''black-smoke scandal''. This scam led to the exposure of other bribery scandals, including allegations that highway police extorted protection money from truck-drivers. Once again Seri publicly declared war on the police behind the scam. Despite his overload, Seri still has to perform basic duties, such as ensuring public security. Seri faces a wide range of different cases from cleaning his own house to dealing with economic crime. Many critics say only a miracle could do it. Fighting uphill battles has become the norm for Seri, who was once mistakenly reported as killed in action during the fight against communist insurgents. But will he manage to survive this time?

SARAJEVO, Bosnia-Herzegovina (AP) _ A World Bank sister organization and the United States Agency for International development, or USAID, announced Wednesday initiation of several new investment projects in Bosnia. So far, it has already invested some 20 million German marks (dlrs 11.7 million) in Bosnian private companies, financial institutions supporting privatization and firms expected to be privatized soon. The latest contracts are expected to create 4,500 jobs across the country. ``Bosnia is a high-risk environment'' after the 3 1/2-year war that ended in 1995, said Carol F. Lee, IFC vice-president. ``But we believe that significant progress has been made.'' Also Wednesday, USAID announced the signing of contracts worth dlrs 8.6 million covering projects to reconstruct infrastructure in several regions across northern Bosnia. It took place against a backdrop of fresh uncertainties in Asia, the local woes highlighted by the liquidity crunch choking Thai business and mounting social problems, and trouble plaguing efforts to salvage banking and finance institutions. A weakening yen, among other factors, has caused sharp depreciation of the baht against the US dollar since late last week. Other details of the plan have not been disclosed yet, including the new share price. Tuesday, KTB's shares ended 60 satang higher at Bt5.80. The source said the plan would also help relieve the Financial Institutions Development Fund's financial burden incurred from injections into the three nationalised banks -- Siam City Bank, First Bangkok City Bank, and Bangkok Metropolitan Bank. US-based JP Morgan is currently studying the three banks to determine how the government can best handle them. KTB's plan came hot on the heels of signs of renewed regional financial difficulties, highlighted by the weakening yen. Most Asian stock markets closed lower Tuesday and regional currencies, including the baht, dipped further. Thai banks and financial institutions, battered by the country's worst economic crisis, have been forced to raise billions of dollars in capital from international markets to meet new provisioning and loan classification rules. Thailand's two largest banks, Bangkok Bank Plc and Thai Farmers Bank Plc, have already raised more than Bt70 billion this year. On Friday, Siam Commercial Bank's announcement of a tripling of its capital through the issue of four billion shares sparked panic selling on the Stock Exchange of Thailand. Fears over the recapitalisation reduced the bank's stock value by almost 25 per cent. Analysts attributed the selling spree to the fact that the stock market was already extremely bearish and the local economic woes are being compounded by aggravating regional uncertainties. Earlier Tuesday, Chuan said the impact of the ''second regional crisis'' was still ''manageable''. JAKARTA (JP): An education exhibition at the Jakarta Convention Center from May 7 to May 11 saw a fairly good representation from the Netherlands, with about nine universities and higher professional education institutes present. The Netherlands is one of the less favored destinations of Indonesian students seeking education abroad, with only 400 Indonesians currently studying there. In comparison, the United States has 15,000 Indonesian students, followed by Australia with 14,000. Some 2,000 are studying in Britain and 1,100 in Japan. The Netherlands clearly has more promotion do, as reflected in the Educational, Training and Technology Exhibition. Despite the crisis, according to organizers, the event was visited by 200,000 students, although the number of students who actually committed themselves to studying at the promoted institutions was not clear. The Dutch language is not the main reason why the number of students going to the Netherlands is much lower than other countries. The Netherlands offers more English programs than most European countries. The possibilities of going to the Netherlands with a scholarship is at a bottle-neck for students here because offers are very limited. Germany is now offering 300 scholarships. Some private organizations, including the Dutch Language Union, Netherlands Education Center (NEC) and Forum Nederland Indonesia (FNI), have been encouraging businesses to offer possibilities for students to study in the Netherlands. Before 1992, the Dutch government offered 600 scholarships for Indonesian students to study in the Netherlands. But political strains put an end to this in 1992, mainly because of the perceived interference of the Netherlands in domestic affairs regarding human rights. The Netherlands then chaired the Inter-Governmental Group on Indonesia. But such strains did not inhibit business between the two countries. A few years ago, some private organizations took the initiative to restart possibilities for scholarships. Among them was the Dutch Language Union, a private organization promoting study of the Dutch language in other countries. ``At the moment the Dutch Language Union offers 16 students of the Dutch language and literature a scholarship to go to the Netherlands or Belgium (the Dutch speaking part) for three weeks,'' said Kees Groeneboer, academic consultant of the Dutch Department of the University of Indonesia. Henk Mahendra said he was one student who benefited from a scholarship. He studied economic agriculture in Wageningen for seven years. Since 1995, the NEC has tried to expand possibilities. It is an independent and nonprofit organization promoting academic cooperation and mobility between Indonesia and the Netherlands. ``We want to stimulate Indonesian students to go to the Netherlands for an international study or internship to upgrade their education level and practical experience,'' said Jon Hagen, director of NEC. However, tickets and living costs are still paid by students. Since the economic crisis, a few companies related to the NEC decided to support students going to the Netherlands by offering more scholarships. The NEC has also started thinking about offering scholarships. They have started developing a program for postgraduate students in a wide scale of subjects for a study period of three months to 18 months. Another assisting organization is FNI. Graduates with two years work experience and a good knowledge of English (minimum of 475 points in the test of English as a foreign language), can be sent to the Netherlands through FNI. ``Since 1995, we have sent about 100 Indonesians to the Netherlands on internships or a combination of study and internship,'' said Suni Sudradjat, FNI's project manager. Under an invitation from a Dutch company, scholarships can be arranged through a private organization for entrepreneurs (VNO/NCF). At the exhibition, promoters of the Netherlands counters said some 400 Indonesian students asked for further information about studying in the Netherlands.

KUALA LUMPUR, Mon. - Malaysia Airlines' insistence that airfreight forwarders sign the bonded warehouse tenancy agreement while the disputed rental tariff at the Kuala Lumpur International Airport is unresolved has put many in a bind. Sensing that their pleas to MAS for a ``fair'' rental tariff has fallen on deaf ears, the Airfreight Forwarders Association of Malaysia has called on the Government to intervene. AFAM claimed MAS, one of the two appointed ground-handling agents, had issued airfreight forwarders the ultimatum last Monday to sign or risk having the warehouse offered to other parties. AFAM chairman Walter Culas said their members, who had each paid a deposit of RM5,000, were caught in a predicament. ``Our members are being forced to sign the tenancy agreement without just cause. There is still time to negotiate and resolve the matter as the warehouses (will be) ready only in mid-June.'' ``AFAM members are prepared to accept the tenancy agreement on fair terms, and move into the warehouses within two days upon signing, provided all the basic amenities like telecommunications and data lines and utilities are made available,'' he said. At its extraordinary general meeting last May 20, AFAM's 157 members unanimously endorsed the association's recommendations, including the concern of insufficient and sub-international standard warehouses. MAS is making available 68 bonded warehouses at KLIA, while the other agent, Kuala Lumpur Airport Services Sdn Bhd, is offering 27. Culas said that AFAM was contemplating obtaining a court injuction to seek legal redress should there be no progress to their pleas. He claimed that the majority of the 69 affected AFAM members were foreign-based multinational companies who appeared to be caught in a tight situation by MAS' ultimatum. Under the rental tariff of RM5.25 per square foot offered by MAS, the airfreight forwarders have to pay a minimum sum of about RM19,000 a month. The rate is an increase of 429 per cent compared with the RM1.25 per square foot tariff at the Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah International Airport in Subang. Based on a survey of 133 AFAM members, Culas said the projected monthly expenses to be incurred at KLIA would amount to RM4.538 million compared with RM1.056 million in Subang. On a dollar-to-dollar basis, the offered rates at Sepang are the highest in the world, compared with Singapore (S$2.78 per sq ft) and New York (US$1.88 per sq ft). ``This will drastically increase the operating costs at Sepang, forcing airfreight forwarders to either absorb it or pass it on to consumers. Should this happen, KLIA's competitiveness against other regional hubs will be decreased, not to mention its impact on inflation and loss of foreign revenue,'' said Culas.

THE government Tuesday backed down from pushing ahead with the Chanthaburi international airport project, resolving to put it on hold for a few years. Communications Minister Suthep Thaugsuban Tuesday asked the Cabinet to go back from its earlier resolution to allocate Bt116 million from the 1999 fiscal year for the project. But the provincial councils of Chanthaburi and Trat vowed Tuesday to campaign against the Cabinet's decision. Suthep said he decided to put the project on hold to heed public criticism. ''With respect to opinions of the public and the mass media, I've decided to delay the project because we don't have money for it,'' Suthep said before attending the Cabinet meeting. ''We don't want this trivial issue to escalate into a national conflict.'' Suthep said he made the decision on Monday night after consulting Deputy Communications Minister Pradit Pataraprasith and listening to a briefing by the Civil Aviation Department. Earlier, Suthep and several other Democrat Cabinet members, including Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai himself, had come out strongly to defend the project following much criticism. The Democrats said the Chanthaburi airport was necessary for the development of the eastern coast as well as for promoting tourism. The project came to light after the Social Action Party questioned why the government had allocated Bt116 million from the additional Bt25 billion of the 1999 fiscal year budget for the airport's construction and would not grant the SAP more money for providing health care to the public. Chuan earlier asked the Finance Ministry to allocate an additional of Bt400 million to the Public Health Ministry, which is under the SAP's supervision, but insisted on going ahead with the Chanthaburi project. Suthep said he had been monitoring public opinion on the issue and had asked Pradit and the Civil Aviation Department to brief him on the background of the project. ''In short, the project was initiated in 1995 and some money had been granted for environment study, land expropriation and design,'' Suthep said. He said he was briefed by a deputy director general of the Civil Aviation Department that the location of the airport would be 40 kilometres away from Chanthaburi, 26 km from Trat and 200 km from U-tapao navy airport in Chonburi. Suthep said the Civil Aviation Department pointed out that the airport would be useful to develop tourism in the eastern provinces and would facilitate food exports. ''I assessed the situation and decided that the country was having a lot of problems so we should not add one more with a non-issue. It will not be too late to wait until the economy improves and the government has more money,'' Suthep said. Suthep said the Bt116 million would be turned back to the central fund for financing other urgent projects. The tobacco industry has been thrown off balance by a stringent new advertising code released by ASCI It had to happen. The tobacco industry saw it coming for a long time. India's anti-tobacco lobby had been gaining momentum, propelled mainly by consumer bodies and health workers. After 18 months of deliberation, the Advertising Standards Council of India (ASCI) last fortnight released a tough new set of guidelines for tobacco advertising that will come into effect from 1 October. Even as ad agencies and tobacco companies frown over the code, consumer activists are peeved that the restrictions don't go far enough. ``We need a code that can bite, not just bark,'' says consumer activist and lawyer Shirish Deshpande. But then, as Bharat Patel, vice-chairman of ASCI (also chairman and managing director, Proctor Gamble) says, ``We simply cannot please everybody.'' In short, ASCI says that ads may not suggest that tobacco products lead to health, safety, success (in business, relationships, sports, sex), machismo, daring, courage, emancipation, testimonials from well-known personalities or heroes of the young. There's more: people featured in ads should ``clearly appear to be over 25 years of age'', no more than a third of persons featured shall be shown smoking, no tobacco ads may be released in media targeting children.... Where does this leave advertisers of tobacco products? More important, do they really have to comply with this code, especially since ASCI has no statutory powers? The industry's biggest player, ITC, says that it will comply but not overnight. It is quite clear that all the smaller companies are waiting to see how ITC reacts to the code. Not surprising, given that ITC is estimated to have a market share of about 67 per cent. Its ad budget, Rs173 crore last year, is estimated to account for over 67 per cent of all cigarette advertising. Already exposed to BAT's stringent code after its tie-up to produce and market Benson Hedges (BH) and 555 State Express, ITC has already begun to revamp its advertising pitches. Godfrey Phillips, which has a share of about 13 per cent of the market, declined to comment on the implications of the code while it is being studied by its legal department. With brands like Panama and Chancellor, GTC Ltd, with an ad budget of Rs19 crore, says it will try to comply, though total compliance will take a couple of years, and even then only ``if legislation is passed''. But, insists Ved Berry, marketing director, GTC, ``It is a voluntary code and cannot be enforced. `` The company has just 6 per cent of the cigarette market and is currently a BIFR case. VST, with 13 per cent of the market and an adspend of Rs15 crore, will be less affected. It has typically favoured more subdued advertising. A will, and many ways Tobacco monies keep virtually every ad agency in Calcutta in business. BatesClarion, for instance. Apart from ITC's Gold Flake account, the agency also handles new entrants BH and 555 (Bates' accounts internationally). BH and 555 ads are not expected to run afoul of ASCI as they are already designed to pass the UK's code, which is even more stringent. ASCI's own standards are based on the UK's code. A number of current campaigns are now going to be no-nos. Like the one that features actor Akshay Kumar in a daring rescue of damsels trapped in a cable car between puffs of his Red White cigarette. Out go macho ads like Vinod Khanna and his Baba Zarda or the recent Wills clip showing four youngsters discovering the Wills logo in a cliff amidst Aztec ruins. Philip Morris' Malboro man, in the wings for some time now, may never enter the Indian market in its current avatar. Where tobacco companies are expected to dig their heels is in their sponsorship of events. Already, an Indian court has ruled that the mere display of a logo does not constitute advertising and ASCI has reiterated this. ``Our standards have to stay within what is legally permissible,'' says Patel. ``As long as the law permits it, we will.'' The European Commission failed to ban sponsorship of events by tobacco companies when it appeared that Formula One motor racing and the World Rally Championship would collapse completely. ITC has emerged as the biggest sponsor of sporting events in India over the last decade. These include the Wills World Cup in cricket and Classic's links with equestrian events and golf, Gold Flake in tennis and billiards, and Bristol in football. What of ITC's investment in sponsoring tennis stars Leander Paes and Mahesh Bhupathi? Interestingly, Sam Balsara, chief executive, Madison Advertising, and a member of ASCI's board of governors, says this campaign is also a clear no-no, even if it does not exhort viewers to actually smoke the brand. Despite the ban on surrogate advertising, other smokescreens will pass, simply because they do not contravene the letter of ASCI's code. On sale soon will be Jack Nicklaus golf clubs from Classic and footballs from Bristol. Wills has long marketed books, diaries, videos, clothes etc. If such merchandise is produced and sold in large numbers, ASKI says it's fine. ITC's vice-president Kurush Grant maintains that the Wills brand is being advertised rather than the cigarettes in most advertising material. What will ASCI do if tobacco companies simply decide that they do not want to comply with its code? At stake is about Rs257 crore from cigarette advertisers alone. Dorab Sopariwala, chairman of ASCI, explains that 80-90 per cent of the press media are ASCI members and most often they would choose to abide by ASCI's suggestions and reject ads that go against its rules. All major TV networks are ASCI members. Even though channels like Star and Zee are beamed from outside the country, they are subject to the standards and practices of Hong Kong, from where they are beamed. A look at Hong Kong's code is telling, it even specifies that merchandise like cigarette holders, tobacco filters, etc, cannot be broadcast ``in proximity to children's programmes''. Moreover, says Sainath Iyer, Zee TV's vice-president, marketing services: ``We also follow all Indian rules and regulations.'' ``Ninety-nine per cent of the time we would reject an ad that offends ASCI's codes,'' admits the marketing director of a publishing house a little wistfully. ``True, we have no statutory authority but our members realise that if we don't regulate ourselves, somebody will regulate us,'' says Sopariwala. The rationale has worked so far, and ASCI has never really faced any major problems about compliance from its own members, but if the tobacco industry took a tough stand, the issue may well be the first real test of ASKI's mettle. Balsara admits that there have been problems with liquor advertisers, but ASCI expects tobacco companies to be more responsive. Despite ASCI's best attempts, there is plenty of scope for discretionary interpretation under the new code. Obviously, its complaints cell is in for a great deal of hair-splitting with tobacco companies and anti-tobacco lobbies interpreting the code completely differently. But then, says Sopariwala, you simply cannot write the definitive code; ``it is also open to change.'' Patel agrees that the most problems with compliance will come not from cigarette companies, but from small-time manufacturers of beedis, gutkha, zarda, kiwam, ghadaka, hand-rolled and chewing tobacco. Unlike the cigarettewallahs, such manufacturers did not even respond to ASCI's proposal to discuss formulating the code. ITC chairman Yogi Deveshwar has been at pains to point out that cigarette smokers only consume about 20 per cent of the nation's tobacco. He feels that picking on companies like ITC would be counterproductive and would drive consumption underground. So who will the government side with on the issue? A tricky question. Even as a number of states have introduced no-smoking laws for public places, the government has a healthy respect for the fact that tobacco sales account for about 10 per cent of excise collections (with cigarette sales alone contributing 90 per cent of this amount), which are more than Rs4,500 crore. The next few months promise to be interesting, for they will test the ingenuity of ad agencies, the PR of tobacco companies, the ethical compulsions of the media and the vigilance of the anti-tobacco lobby.

A TIME TO KILL (US, 1996, LD, Dolby Surround) Directed by Joel Schumacher Starring Matthew McConaughey, Samuel L. Jackson, Sandra Bullock, Kiefer Sutherland, Kevin Spacey, Donald Sutherland, Ashley Judd Running time: 150 minutes Rating: (Not suitable for children) THE themes explored in this gripping yet flawed drama about race set in the American South will remind you a bit too much of Mississippi Burning. But, despite being somewhat glib and unoriginal, the screen interpretation of John Grisham's book has enough going for it to keep you watching to the end. Maybe it is director Joel Schumacher's flair for visual pacing; whatever it is, it certainly helps to make an otherwise ordinary movie more interesting than it really should be. A black teenage girl is brutally raped by two white men. Distrusting the justice system, her enraged father Carl Lee Hailey (Samuel L. Jackson) guns them down and is charged with murder. Carl chooses the relatively inexperienced Jake Brigance (Matthew McConaughey) to defend him in court. The trial inflames racial passions, and the local Ku Klux Klan soon starts attacking those helping to free Carl, including Jake and his family. In the midst of all this trouble, Jake struggles to put up a strong defence with help from his old law school professor (Donald Sutherland) and an assertive lawyer (Sandra Bullock). So does justice prevail in a seemingly white-controlled courtroom? The latter part of the film is devoted to resolving that; it's probably the most compelling segment of the movie. The other events, like the KKK attacks, seem like they're there more to boost the action than to intensify the drama. The cast does a fairly good job, especially McConaughey and Jackson. But the film is not very convincing in its sense of time and place. TEX (US, 1982, LD) Directed by Tim Hunter Starring Matt Dillon, Jim Metzler, Meg Tilly, Bill McKinney, Ben Johnson, Emilio Estevez Running time: 103 minutes Rating: (Not suitable for children) BEFORE this teen angst vehicle, Disney wouldn't associate itself with any production that hinted at young rebellion, so Tex is worth watching if only for that. But of course, being a screen adaptation of an S.E. Hinton novel, it has more to offer, especially in Matt Dillon's persuasive characterisation of a curious and confused 15-year-old Oklahoma farm boy discovering the real meaning of life. Tex McCormick does not have the ideal home. His mom is dead, his dad's a rodeo drifter. He has only his older brother Mason (Jim Metzler) taking care of him. Like all searching and troubled teenagers, Tex goes through the rituals of rebellious behaviour but soon learns how harsh the real world can be. This is an intriguing coming-of-age tale that, despite trying to cram in too many themes - crime, love, sex, death - works rather well. It may have a dated feel to it, but the film's almost cinema verite style makes for some absorbing moments. TO WONG FOO, THANKS FOR EVERYTHING, JULIE NEWMAR (US, 1995, LD, Dolby Surround) Directed by Beeban Kidron Starring Patrick Swayze, Wesley Snipes, John Leguizamo, Ru Paul, Robin Williams, Julie Newmar, Chris Penn Running time: 108 minutes Rating: (Not suitable for children) IT may not be a laugh a minute, but this drag-queen road movie has some deliciously hilarious scenes. The story is silly, of course, but that makes it even more engaging! Three New York drag queens - Vida Boheme (Patrick Swayze), Noxeema Jackson (Wesley Snipes) and Chi Chi Rodriguez (John Leguizamo) -have just cashed in their chips and are on their way to Hollywood in a Cadillac. But along the way, they run into a homophobic smalltown sheriff (Chris Penn) who swears revenge after being knocked out by Vida. Then their car breaks down in a small town in the Midwest and the queens are faced with the challenge of convincing the conservative townsfolk that they're cool. During the three days they are there, the ``ladies'' teach the residents to really let their hair down. Pretty soon, everyone is jiving and the poor sheriff with the axe to grind finds himself in a no-win situation. What a fabulously fatuous film this is, with the entire cast really hamming it up as befits the asinine humour! You'll be disappointed only if you're expecting brainy gags. After abandoning his last hit, Richard Malone takes off to Oregon. But trouble with his car forces him to stay in a small town under the control of megalomaniac developer Charles Delany (Cliff Robertson). SCENES FROM THE CLASS STRUGGLE IN BEVERLY HILLS (US/UK, 1989, LD, Dolby Surround) Directed by Paul Bartel Starring Jacqueline Bisset, Ray Sharkey, Robert Beltran, Mary Woronov, Ed Bagley Jr., Wallace Shawn Running time: 103 minutes Rating: (Not suitable for children) SEX And Debauchery In Beverly Hills would be a more accurate title for this farce. Also there are Lisabeth's playwright brother (Ed Bagley Jr.) and his new black wife, her ex (Wallace Stevens), Clare's daughter and a stud of a male houseguest. Before the weekend is out, everybody, including the South American maid and the butler, has slept with everybody else, and in a morbid and bizarre twist, Clare's late husband (Paul Mazursky) returns from the dead to make a play for her. SOMPRASONG doesn't care whether someone watches her taking a shower naked, but the public cried foul after seeing a picture of Somprasong and other homeless women at a Public Welfare Department's rehabilitation centre lining up naked in front of a shower house. ''They asked me to take a shower, and I just did it without thinking too much. If someone likes to watch, let them. They can't take anything away from me,'' Somprasong told a TV station after the picture was splashed on Matichon's front page Tuesday. For all Somprasong said no one could take anything away from her, the Law Society of Thailand has deemed that her human dignity was taken away by the ''inhumane'' treatment of the public-welfare officials at the centre. The picture clearly demonstrated that the homeless women had stripped before they were paraded from their living quarters to the shower house. Although a concrete fence surrounds the centre, what happens inside the shower house can be clearly seen over the fence from higher buildings around the centre. Public Welfare Director Gen Irawat Chantharaprasert and Wipa Anothit, chief of the centre, did not deny that the women had been ordered to strip. But they argued that more than half of the 720 homeless women at the centre were insane and so needed ''special care'' from the officials. ''During the past few days the weather has been very hot, so these women stripped to rush and take a shower, and the officials were not able to control them,'' he claimed. Wipa said the people who climbed over the fence to see the women should be ashamed of themselves. ''These women are homeless people and beggars. Some have skin diseases and need to be taken care of by the officials,'' he said. But Sak Korsaengruang, president of the Law Society of Thailand, said insanity or being a beggar could not be cited to force women to walk naked in public. ''The picture clearly shows that the government agency treated underprivileged people without due care to their human dignity as required by the Constitution,'' Sak said. ''This is a clear violation of the human rights of the women at the centre.'' Dej-udom Krairit, a member of the Law Society, condemned the centre for its''uncivilised'' treatment of the women. He said his group would fight for the pride and dignity of the women in all public-welfare centres.

HEALTH authorities may ask Hong Kong importers of fizzy drinks to withdraw their merchandise following the recall of millions of cans of drinks in Britain over a toxic-gas scare. On Monday, traces of benzene, a chemical which causes cancer, was found in supplies of carbon dioxide used to make drinks fizzy. Cadbury Schweppes Plc recalled about one million litres of bottled Malvern sparkling water in Britain after discovering tainted samples. A spokesman for Hong Kong's Department of Health said yesterday an inspection of Hong Kong shelves found the Malvern sparking water on sale but said the Malvern batch was manufactured in April and was not part of the May-manufactured products contaminated in the UK. Technical manager Robert Pease said Malvern sparkling water was not sold in Hong Kong. Other contaminated brands such as Pepsi Max, Pepsi Diet and Seven-Up were not sold in Hong Kong, the spokesman said. But for safety's sake the department would request the importers of the fuzzy drinks to withdraw the merchandise, the spokesman said. Details on the withdrawal will be discussed with the manufacturers. Cadbury Beverages Asia claimed local products were not affected by the recall. Cadbury's products are bottled locally by Swire Coca Cola Hong Kong. A spokesperson for the company said the contamination in Britain was an ``isolated case'' due to the problems with the carbon dioxide supplied to make the drinks fizzy. About 10 million litres of Malvern sparkling bottled water is sold every year. About one million litres, or eight weeks' stock, has been withdrawn from sale. In 1990, Perrier withdrew 160 million bottles of its water worldwide at a cost of 150 million after US scientists found traces of benzene in 13 bottles of water. Smith Kline Beecham, makers of Lucozade and Ribena, said it had ceased distribution of benzene-affected products and was testing samples before deciding whether to order a recall. A spokeswoman for the London office said the amounts of benzene in the products were not a health risk, but a ``quality issue''. The Hong Kong office said Ribena available here was not imported from Britain, although Lucozade was.

EU contributes dlrs 5.5 million to Bosnian elections
BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) _ The European Union cleared a further dlrs 5.5 million Wednesday in support of upcoming Bosnian elections in September. The latest package brings to dlrs 14.2 million the total amount of funds earmarked by the EU over the past two years for Bosnia's upcoming parliamentary and presidential elections. The money will help finance the work of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe in Bosnia. The OSCE is responsible for monitoring the September polls. ``It is essential to have a genuine, transparent and fair democratic process before, during and after the election date,'' said Hans Van den Broek, the EU Commissioner for Foreign Affairs in a statement. ``International involvement is crucial in achieving this goal.'' EU foreign ministers approved the latest package in April. The EU funds will support the work of OSCE supervision personnel, of international supervisors and trainers, registration assistants and polling supervisors, a statement said. The EU is also backing the establishment of a media centre to ``help the media more effectively gather information and contribute to public debate'' in Bosnia, the statement said.

PENANG, Mon. - Malaysia must eliminate all sources of pestiferous flies in its fresh fruit commodities to boost exports of these items to quarantine- sensitive countries. Agriculture Minister Datuk Amar Dr Sulaiman Daud today called for efforts to be taken in eliminating fruit flies which had been identified as a major obstacle to the development of the fruit and horticulture industries in Malaysia and the region. ``Besides causing significant losses in production, the flies also restrict free trade and exports of fresh fruit commodities between many countries. ``Malaysian fruits cannot be freely exported to markets like the United States, Japan, Australia or New Zealand because strict quarantine regulations in these countries prohibit entry of fresh fruits unless expensive disinfestation treatments are carried out,'' he said when opening the Fifth International Symposium on Fruit Flies of Economic Importance at the Penang Parkroyal Resort. ``Our efforts to enhance the cultivation of fruits are not spared the ravages of pests, fruit flies in particular. ``Judging from the severity of damage to important money-earning crops like carambola (starfruit), mango and guava which can suffer 100 per cent damage if not protected, economic losses are estimated to run into several million ringgit annually,'' Dr Sulaiman added. The five-day symposium which ends on Friday is being attended by nearly 200 participants from 45 countries. The symposium is organised by Universiti Sains Malaysia, the International Fruit Fly Steering Committee and the Working Group on Malaysian Fruit Flies. Also present today were USM vice-chancellor Professor Datuk Ishak Tambi Kechik, International Fruit Fly Steering Committee chairman Dr Patrick J. Gomes and the event's organising committee chairman Dr Tan Keng Hong. In his welcoming address, Gomes said global thinking and action were needed to disseminate information on fruit flies to agricultural producers and consumers. ``Although world trade is expanding at a rapid rate, the mere presence of certain fruit fly species prevents the movement of fresh commodities from one country to another. ``Recent assessments on the economic and social impacts of certain fruit flies reveal that losses, direct and indirect, easily amount to millions of ringgit each year,'' he said. ``Although the Food and Agriculture Organisation estimated losses of US$60 million (RM228 million) caused by fruit flies in the Mediterranean region in 1995, a study conducted in Israel, Jordan and countries in the region revealed US$192 million in losses.

Serm and Niran, who have professed competing claims to be the ''real'' boyfriend of murder victim Jenjira Ploy-angunsri, confronted each other for the first time since the police discovery of their sweetheart's death. In an hour-long trial session, Niran stole a few nervous glances at the confessed killer who later retracted his statements in court. Niran, an engineer at the Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand, seemed to express his disbelief that the nerdy-looking, second-year medical student could shatter their love for the same girl in a macabre way. According to forensic evidence and Serm's statements, the defendant was charged with shooting Jenjira in January and later trying to get rid of the evidence by cutting up her body and flushing the pieces down the toilet and dumping the skeleton into the Bang Pakong River. Although Serm produced a series of confessions about how he executed the killing and the subsequent cover-up of evidence following his arrest in March, he had never retracted on his motive -- that of a broken heart, investigators said. In eyeing Niran's every movement, Serm seemed to show his bewilderment at the fact that the witness could really be the man who stole his sweetheart's heart. Throughout their confrontation, the defendant only diverted his eyes once to the empty walls when Niran answered a prosecutor's question saying that Jenjira confided in him that she did not love Serm. Speaking from the witness stand, Niran informed the presiding judge that he was no stranger to Jenjira and her family. He and the murder victim grew up in the same neighbourhood. They went to the same high school where his sister was a classmate of Jenjira. After a series of social meetings, the witness said he and Jenjira recognised that their friendship had blossomed into love after a New Year date during which they saw the romantic movie ''Titanic'' together. Since then, they were almost inseparable, having dinner three times a week and exchanging beeper messages several times daily. They even turned their beepers to the vibration mode and kept them in their shirt pockets so that the machines would stroke their hearts every time they exchanged messages. Serm's eyes only glowered in agony during the witness' testimony. Prior to Jenjira's disappearance, the murder victim had increasingly complained about being stalked by a male friend whom she did not love. In fact Niran paged her on the very day she was allegedly killed, the witness said. Under cross-examination by the defence lawyer, the witness clarified that Jenjira had never mentioned Serm by name as the man who tried to win her heart, and that he was unaware whether Jenjira discussed him with Serm. Defence counsel Sit Kanwat tactfully asked the witness whether he knew that he was on the list of people suspected to have caused Jenjira's disappearance, and was possibly trying to raise doubts by accusing Serm as the only suspect. GALLE, Sri Lanka (AP) _ On a wicket that produced some vicious turn for spinners, New Zealand was 96 for 4 at the end of a rain-reduced first day's play of the second cricket test against Sri Lanka on Wednesday. New Zealand won the toss and elected to bat, but wet ground conditions prevented any play during the first session. Mathew Horne was the first to be dismissed in the third over of the innings when he fell caught behind to left arm spinner Niroshan Bandaratilleke for 1, with the total at 5. New Zealand went in for tea at 16 for 1. Bowling offcutters, Kumara Dharmasena struck in the second over after tea when he had Stephen Fleming ruled out leg before for 14. But Bryan young and Nathan Astle played cautiously and punished the loose balls in a determined bid to repair the innings with a stand of 69 runs for the third wicket. Young (46) despatched six balls to the fence and went through an anxious moment when he flicked a ball from Muttiah Muralitheran into the hands of short leg Sanath Jayasuriya, who dropped the catch. When bad light stopped play eight minutes before the scheduled close, Astle was unbeaten on 30 made off 116 deliveries. Astle also saw the exit of Daniel Vettori who replaced Young as night watchman, and was out in the same over to Bandaratilleke caught at forward short leg by Hashan Tillekeratne. More than 10,000 spectators packed the Galle International cricket stadium to see the first Test match being played in the ancient port city. Another 1,500 people lined the stone ramparts of the nearby 17th century Dutch fort for a free bird's eye view. (cd/aks)

BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa (AP) _ Two South African military officials with suspected right-wing connections were arrested Wednesday in connection with two heists of military weapons, including mortars and rocket launchers, and ammunition. Police, meanwhile, found the body of a soldier who had been driving a truck carrying 200,000 rounds of ammunition that was hijacked on Monday, according to Safety and Security Minister Sydney Mufamadi. He didn't release details. The other driver was still missing. Deputy Defense Minister Ronnie Kasrils announced the arrests in Parliament but didn't the arrested soldiers' names or ranks, saying only: ``There (are) suspected to be right-wing connections.'' Mufamadi said most of the weapons and two armored vehicles stolen last month have also been recovered. There was no immediate indication whether the thefts were linked to any plans to destabilize the country ahead of next year's national elections. The two suspects were to appear in the Bloemfontein Regional Court on Thursday, 400 kilometers (240 miles) southeast of Johannesburg. The ammunition was being transported from Tempe Military Base outside Bloemfontein to another city when it was hijacked Monday. Last month, 117 weapons and two armored trucks were stolen from the 44 Parachute Brigade at the same base. In addition to the two arrests, a company commander in the base maintenance unit has been arrested and faces court martial on charges of negligence for sending the truck without an adequate escort, Kasrils said. A military inquiry into the first heist found very poor levels of security at Tempe and a ``very poor attitude of personnel,'' Kasrils said. (pr-aos)

LONDON (JP): There's been much heavy breathing from NATO this week, as the Western alliance tries to frighten Yugoslav strongman Slobodan Milosevic into restoring peace in Serbia's Albanian-majority province of Kosovo. This time, say NATO sources in Brussels, there will be ``no failure to engage early and assertively'' (as there certainly was in Bosnia). But it's probably the same empty bluff as usual, and Milosevic doesn't look the least bit impressed. The fourth Balkan war of the 1990s is now getting underway in Kosovo for the same reason as all the others: it serves Milosevic's domestic political purposes. He needs to distract the Serbs from their economic misery, and in particular he needs a crisis that will help him to impose his candidate as president in the election in Montenegro on May 31. All that's left of Yugoslavia (thanks to Milosevic's previous wars in Slovenia, Croatia, and Bosnia) is the two republics of Serbia and Montenegro. The latter has only 600,000 people to Serbia's 10 million, but it controls a big block of seats in the federal parliament, so Milosevic's own power was threatened when Momir Bulatovic, his man in Montenegro, was ousted last October. The new Montenegrin president, Milo Djukanovic, hints at secession if Belgrade does not drop the extreme Serb nationalist policies that have brought sanctions and economic ruin to both parts of the federation. But Milosevic could not survive such a change of policy, and Montenegrins are basically 'mountain Serbs'. So as part of Milosevic's effort to sway this month's Montenegrin election in favor of his loyal pawn, Momir Bulatovic, he has stirred up a new crisis in Kosovo. The idea is to return the Montenegrins to their old pro-Serb loyalties by emphasizing the threat to the 'sacred Serbian territory' of Kosovo. But surely there's more to it than that. What about all the ancient ethnic hatreds that bedevil former Yugoslavia? The 'ancient ethnic hatreds' are a myth. There was hostility between Serbs and Croats as a result of World War II, but nothing comparable between Moslems and Christians in Bosnia, nor between Albanians and Serbs in Kosovo. The lie about ancient, irrepressible ethnic hatreds was fabricated in the early 1990s by European diplomats to justify their own inaction in the face of the Bosnian genocide, and swallowed wholesale by the ignorant Western media. The 'Kosovo problem' is actually only nine years old. Serbs and Albanians lived together in peace in this southernmost bit of Serbia for a thousand years, until Milosevic discovered in 1989 that the road to power lay in appealing to the paranoid and self-pitying side of Serbian nationalism. For some centuries Albanian-speaking Moslems have been the majority in Kosovo, now making up over 90 percent of the province's 2 million people. But few people disputed Kosovo's historic ties to Serbia, because the former communist government of Yugoslavia gave the Kosovars full autonomy within Serbia, including Albanian-language education, media, and medical services. Relations only went bad after Milosevic won power in Belgrade in 1989 by playing up Serbs' fears about their minority status in Kosovo. The Serbs there were oppressed, he claimed, and promptly destroyed Kosovo's autonomy. Since 1989, all official institutions in Kosovo have been monopolized by the tiny Serb minority. The Albanian majority responded with great restraint, creating their own parallel system of unofficial schools, hospitals and services while peacefully seeking the return of self-rule. But their requests, being non-violent, were ignored by everybody. A handful of frustrated Kosovars turned to terrorism two years ago, but they were repudiated by the vast majority, and the level of violence in Kosovo was still lower than that in Spain's Basque provinces -- until March, when Milosevic sent in the Serbian special forces to massacre an entire village. Now an estimated 120,000 Albanian peasants have abandoned non-violence to enlist in the Kosovo Liberation Army, and 200 people are already dead. This is presumably the result Milosevic wanted: after the last nine years, he cannot plead ignorance. But why did he want it? Recently I found some old notes from a conference in Belgrade in 1977, and realized that I interviewed Slobodan Milosevic two decades ago. The point is that I forgot about it: he was a typical mid-level apparatchik without an idea in his head, and I didn't even use the interview. Whereas if I had met Adolf Hitler or Pol Pot early in their careers, I'm sure I would not have forgotten it. All three men came to power by exploiting a paranoid streak of nationalism that saw the Germans/Cambodians/Serbs as the innocent victims of a global conspiracy. Milosevic's wars have cost perhaps a quarter-million lives, a far smaller toll than Hitler's or Pol Pot's, but that is not the real distinction between them. It is that Milosevic is an utterly amoral careerist. Hitler and Pol Pot had an intensity of conviction that made them into forces of nature: they distilled and personified the fears and hatreds that drove their genocides. Whereas Milosevic is totally cynical about the nationalist obsessions he exploits in his fellow-Serbs. When I first met him, he was cheerfully throwing Serbian nationalists into jail for anti-communist activities. Milosevic has never sought anybody's death as a matter of principle; genocide is only desirable if it serves the higher goal of his own political survival. None of the wars that have wrecked former Yugoslavia since he came to power were inevitable. They just seemed like good tactics at the time to a sociopath in power -- a man with no fixed ideas or values beyond his own advancement, and nothing much by way of a long-term strategy either. The disproportion between atrocious means and petty ends in Kosovo is typical of Milosevic. Nor is he deterred by the prospect that this time the conflict may end in the partition of Serbia itself, so long as the Serbs blame somebody else: the main thing is that his own power survives. These tactics have worked before, and he has no reason to believe that they will not work again.

Second round of talks begins; other strikes loom
Eds: UPDATES with conciliatory comment AP Photos PAR101-3 By CECILE ROUX Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ French air and rail service faced new strike threats one week away from the World Cup on Wednesday, while Air France held new talks to end a three-day-old pilots' walkout. The strike at state-owned Air France _ the World Cup's official carrier _ was a growing embarrassment to the French government, which also faced walkouts among Paris transit workers Thursday and national railworkers Friday. Baggage handlers in a wage dispute at Charles de Gaulle Airport were on the second day of their strike, and Air France mechanics and French train engineers were also threatening their own walkouts. Talks at Air France resumed at 3:20 p.m. (1320 GMT) Wednesday, after no progress was reported from the first round Tuesday. There were some conciliatory words among the tough talk shortly before the meeting began in Air France headquarters at Charles de Gaulle Airport, offering some hope of an early end to the planned two-week strike. While predicting ``long and difficult'' bargaining, Air France President Jean-Cyril Spinetta said: ``We sincerely hope we can all understand each other.'' The head of the SNPL union that represents most of the airline's 3,200 pilots softened his tone, saying Spinetta's firmness was ``good for a boss. ``We understand a part of that talk, especially when it's about competitiveness that must be improved'' and ``controlling overall salaries,'' said the union boss, Jean-Charles Corbet. In the meantime, Air France said its Wednesday schedule included only 17 percent of its usual long-distance flights, 30 percent of its short and medium-distance routes from Charles de Gaulle Airport and 43 percent from Orly. For the pilots, among the highest paid in the world, the company wants to give them stock in exchange for 500 million francs (dlrs 83 million) in pay cuts. But it's offered to eventually do away with a two-tier salary schedule that pays less to new pilots. Air France pilots average 1 million francs (dlrs 160,000), ranging from 240,000 francs (dlrs 40,000) for new pilots to 1.2 million francs (dlrs 200,000) for 25 years' seniority, the airline said. The carrier, which managed to report a profit in the last two years, was set to lose 100 million francs (dlrs 16.7 million) per day during the strike. France's interior minister criticized the ``lack of civic-mindedness'' of the pilots, saying he felt ``sadness, almost shame.'' Because of the strike, Jean-Pierre Chevenement told Radio Monte Carlo, ``France could show itself as a nation that can't organize a world event anymore.'' The walkout disrupted training for the French national soccer team, said coach Aime Jacquet. The players had been given a three-day weekend to visit their families and were supposed to resume training Tuesday. Air France is committed to transporting teams to the 10 competition sites around France and charter other carriers to meet its obligations. The airline's mechanics threatened on Wednesday to walk off the job over pay differences between Air Inter and Air France, which have been merged. No date was set. Redefine the FM Of the finance minister's many incongruent functions, those pertaining to economic affairs must be transferred to an independent ministry So Vajpayee has been sworn in and has successfully passed the ordeal of the vote of confidence. The first batch of cabinet and state ministers is in place. The composition of this cabinet involved more political horse-trading than at any time in the past. The most sought after ministry was neither home nor external affairs nor commerce nor industry, but finance. That is rather surprising, because it is the finance minister who is likely to have the most difficult time given the present state of the economy. Even the most accomplished economist would find the task of tackling the recession, defending the rupee and controlling the fiscal deficit an unappetising menu. The chances are that even a promising political career would be ruined in less than a year in the finance ministry. Jayalalitha wanted her prot,g, Subramanian Swamy to be made finance minister, not because of his ability to help the economy but because she expected him to protect her interests in the large number of cases pending against her. Finally, the crown of thorns was put on the head of Yashwant Sinha, who earlier held the portfolio under Chandra Shekhar. In the stories of P.G. Wodehouse, one often encounters a creditor's man placed in the household of a heavily indebted lord, most often as a butler, to keep an eye on his affairs. It would appear that the international financial institutions have a man in a similar capacity at North Block. Governments may change; finance ministers may come and go; but this agent stays put in his ostensibly subordinate position. It is his word which is decisive in the choice of the finance minister. The new PM is unlikely to try any radical recasting of the jurisdiction of various ministries. But that needs to be done urgently. Agriculture, for example, is a state subject. There exists, nevertheless, a sprawling Ministry of Agriculture in Krishi Bhawan which deals with agricultural research, rural development, food procurement, and agricultural prices. The public distribution system, fertilisers and food-processing, and export and import of agricultural and related commodities come under other ministries. No minister has really succeeded in co-ordinating all these tasks effectively. All matters relating to agriculture need to be brought under a single umbrella. On the contrary, diverse subjects put under the canopy of finance need to be separated. But that would require a PM who can face the combined wrath of the babus. The present FM combines two quite different roles -- one relating to finance and the other to economic affairs. He has several incongruent functions -- collection of revenues, both direct and indirect, non-revenue receipts including foreign assistance and loans, allocation of funds to various ministries, day-to-day scrutiny, and internal audit. Apart from these, he plays a key role in planning strategies and economic policies. Since 1991, he is also the presiding deity of economic reforms, liberalisation, and globalisation. But this will have to change. The FM should continue to be in charge of the budget, including determining the nature and the rates of taxes and allocation of funds. The day-to-day control of expenditure through the network of financial advisors sitting in each ministry is entirely superfluous and should simply be abolished. There is no reason to believe that an official of the finance ministry is more careful, honest, or intelligent than his colleagues who happen to be posted in other cadres. Separate economic functions A new Ministry of Economic Affairs should be constituted. Given the enormous task of restructuring the economy, it should have functions relating to developmental planning, economic reforms, and non-revenue resources including domestic and foreign borrowings. The traditional Ministry of Finance will continue to enjoy vast powers; but its work can be managed by an administrator/technocrat. Economic affairs, on the other hand, will benefit if the presiding minister has a mass base and political clout strong enough to outweigh the deep-rooted vested interests in the licence-permit raj. Reorganisation of the finance ministry has been a long-standing need. The new PM will be in a better position to bring about this reform because it would allow him to accommodate two aspirants instead of one. It would also ensure better discipline in the cabinet. Moral: Calamity is the only other face of opportunity.

THE Pillar of Shame may end up in a transport container after 4 June, following the latest failure of its supporters to win it a permanent home. The Provisional Urban Council voted down the application by just one vote yesterday. The council standing committee sacked the application from the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China 18 votes to 19. The alliance wanted the statue permanently displayed at council-managed venues. Democrat member Szeto Wah, who is also chairman of the alliance, said after the meeting he was not surprised by the result. ``This is within our expectations. ``You can see that all appointed members of the council voted against the application. ``It reflected indirectly on why the Special Administrative Region government had to appoint members to the two councils (urban and regional) and the district boards,'' he said. He expected the motion would get more sponsors the next time it was tabled. He said the alliance might place the eight-metre bronze statue inside a container after 4 June. ``We may rent a container and put it inside until the day it can be displayed to the public,'' he added. Councillors debated the motion for about one and half hours. Appointed member Annie Wu, who voted against the motion, said Hong Kong people should not discuss matters concerning the Beijing government under the one country, two systems policy. Acting Deputy Director of Urban Services Ma Kai-loong said the government would not take sides on the matter. Outside the council chamber, alliance members and a group of tertiary college students protested against the decision. The Pillar of Shame, designed by Danish sculptor Jens Galschiot, will stand in Victoria Park until tomorrow.
