Warapatr Todhanakasem, president of Thai Ratings and Information Services Co (Tris), writes on the concept of good governance. Final of a three-part series. For many years in the past, rumours in the business circle often mentioned managers in many firms abusing their authority or reporting information which was not transparent. This has led to significant damage to shareholders as well as creditors. Especially when the economy is going through an era of crisis, these malpractices, which had been covered up, began to be re-vented from time to time. A major effort, which was becoming more of a reality in developing good corporate governance in Thailand and deserved to be mentioned, was the effort of the Stock Exchange of Thailand which has studied and published documents on this issue, for example, Internal Auditing System Manual (published in April 1996), Manual for Directors of Listed Companies (published in August 1997), and Internal Auditing Guidelines (expected to be published soon). In addition, on Jan 19 the SET released a statement requiring all listed companies to set up an Audit Committee by the end of 1999. This committee is responsible for regulating the business in order to make it more efficient and standardised. Aside from the SET, many other organisations have also been involved in this topic, such as the Association of Accountants and Certified Auditors of Thailand and Thai Rating and Information Services (Tris). It is expected that these organisations will further cooperate to speed up the development of good corporate governance in Thailand. Viewpoint There are directors and/or members of senior management in Thailand who wish to build good governance in their own companies but are not sure where to begin. Here are some suggestions that might help those who are interested in getting started. A Directors and senior management should start by fully understanding the concept and the major ideas behind good corporate governance. A good way to do this is to conduct seminars for senior staff and invite experts to speak on the topic. Adequate time should be provided for in-depth discussions to ensure that all participants have a good understanding of the concept. The emphasis here is that the participants must be of director and senior management level. (Not long ago at a seminar on this topic, the audience seemed to listen with great interest. The problem was that 90 per cent of them were middle managers. It seems doubtful that they will have enough authority to push for the development of good governance in their own organisation.) B Once an understanding of the concept and major issues of good governance has been attained, senior management should examine their own organisation to determine the current level of effectiveness, efficiency and transparency. One way of doing this is to take as an example an organisation that is considered to have good governance and use it as a comparison and benchmark. C At the end of the process, senior management should have a clear picture of what it needs to do to attain good governance and make commitments to start its development in the organisation. Framework of board The responsibility of a company's board is crucial. In order to have a board that is effective, one needs to reconsider what makes a good board. There are many key factors that define what makes an effective Board. 1 The chairman and CEO of a company should not be the same person. 2 Select professional directors 3 Have more outside directors than inside directors. 4 Allow institutional investors as directors Evidence has shown that these suggestions, once implemented, will facilitate the development of good governance. They also have the potential to cause problems and therefore must be used with caution and adapted according to each organisation's environment. Government sector versus private sector : Good governance must go together. It cannot be denied that the governing process here in Thailand has some room for improvement. The system in the past and in the present has been and still is a major obstacle to the development of the country. The political system is developing very slowly and without the level of transparency that we would like it to have. In any event, at the present time there is some progress being made. The public has begun to press for reforms which hopefully will result in changes that are effective and on-going. Good governance in the private sector will still continue. But unless Good governance in the government sector progresses at the same pace, it will be difficult for the private sector to materialise this concept at the level society would like to see. The first and second parts were published on May 27 and June 2.

The country's economic downturn has not only affected foreign capital inflow and liquidity. To reduce expenses and maximise use of staff, small and middle-sized companies have cancelled training programmes. The trend has been similar in other countries, however. ''We can't say the situation here is unique, but it is different,'' Chainarong Indharameesup, Chairman of CSN Associates, said. Before the flotation of the baht in July last year, extraordinarily high economic growth fuelled the rapid expansion of companies, which faced the urgent need for trained, experienced mid-level and upper-level personnel. Companies entered a battle to ''pinch'' staff from competitors, and salaries and perks rose to unprecedented levels. Far from easing the strain on Thailand's workforce capacity, the entry of foreign joint ventures increased pressure. New companies required sales people, accountants, translators and other mid-level personnel in numbers that the country lacked. In one case, the managing director of a long-time US-Thai joint venture told The Nation that he was pleased that his staff turnover had dropped to 12 per cent per quarter. He would not divulge how high turnover had been previously. Constant staff movement from one company to another placed a heavy burden on business. In their search for experienced staff, companies were hiring people that often lacked the necessary training and experience. A public relations trainee in one hotel in 1991, for instance, moved after one year to another hotel as a PR assistant. Every six months thereafter, she changed hotels, rising in status and remuneration with each move. At the end of two years, she had more than quadrupled her original salary and achieved the title of PR director. Because she had been moving so much, however, she had not allowed herself enough time to learn under more experienced managers. Her company was also not in a position to train her. They had ''bought'' her for her title and expected her to possess the skills required of her job. They didn't have the time to train her, either. With economic growth came opportunities that had to be seized immediately, and companies were reluctant to lose productive staff to long-term training. Staff training was not put on hold entirely. Chainarong pointed out that companies, aware of the problem, tried to break down jobs into smaller units. ''These were short-term measures,'' he said. ''They wanted people quickly. The qualifications and background of employees not up to standard, so they reduced the training process into short periods.'' As a result, payroll increased as well, with companies hiring more and more people. After the flotation, when the value of the baht fell and financial problems set in, companies looking to reduce expenditure began cutting advertising, research and outside training budgets and reducing staff numbers. Remaining staff have seen their areas of responsibility expand, but companies are still not investing in long-term training. Companies still planning to lay off additional people are reluctant to spend resources on soon-to-be former employees. ''But training also goes against attitudes,'' Chainarong pointed out. Local middle-size companies tend to rely on experience and on-the-job training. Multinational companies like Citibank train new recruits for around six months, an expense that local companies would not accept. More importantly, for training to be fully utilised, employees must be empowered to handle their own decision-making within their areas of expertise. Can Thai companies adapt their management structure to accommodate new methods and techniques? ''There is a tendency,'' Chainarong admitted, ''for local companies to reject the performance of the new generation.'' Multinationals, however, are still planning new joint ventures in Thailand or expanding their operations here, and it is in these companies that Chainarong has hope. ''They're willing to transfer knowledge and empower their employees, and local companies will have the opportunity to observe these new processes,'' he said.

UTRECHT: Teun de Nooiyer scored a last-gasp golden goal to give Holland a 3-2 sudden death victory over Spain in the men's hockey World Cup final yesterday. The decisive goal came in the 83rd minute with just two minutes of extra time remaining. The Dutch, who had fought back from 2-0 down late in the match, forced a penalty corner and although the subsequent shot by Bram Lomans was saved, the ball fell at the feet of de Nooijer who scooped past Ramon Jufresa, the outstanding Spanish goalkeeper. For a long time it looked as if the Dutch men, who beat Spain in the 1996 Olympic final, were going to follow their women's team by collecting silver medals. Spain led 1-0 after 18 minutes after breaking the length of the field for Javier Arnau to lash in a cross shot and went 2-0 up in the 55th as Victor Pujol deflected a pass past the Dutch goalkeeper. Spain, who lost brilliant forward Jaun Escarre with a pulled hamstring soon after their first goal, missed chances to make it 3-0 then saw their lead wiped out in two minutes. In the 59th, Dutch captain Stephan Veen beat Jufresa, who until then had seemed impossible to pass, with a fine cross shot. Before Spain could recover their composure, the Dutch forced their fifth corner and Lomans made it 2-2, finding a way past Jufresa with a powerful flick for his ninth goal of the Cup. The Dutch, who did most of the attacking in the game, had three more corners before the end of full time, one in the first period of extra time before they finally pierced the Spanish goal at their tenth corner of the match. The match was a repeat of the Atlanta Olympic final which the Dutch won 3-1. Like the Australian women, who won their final on Sunday, the Dutch now hold both the Olympic and World Cup titles. RIC Charlesworth, coach of the Australian women's team that successfully defended their world title here on Sunday, beating Holland 3-2 in a thrilling final, said they would only get better. The reigning Olympic and Champions Trophy holders went behind to a 46-second effort from Ellen Dubbledam-Kuiper, but goals from Annan, Julie Towers and Juliet Haslam eased them away only for Julie Deiters' goal in the 62nd minute to give them a very nervy last eight minutes. ``I am very pleased and I think that this is just reward for the girls as they are the hardest working bunch of athletes in any national Australian side,'' Charlesworth said. ``The guts they showed after the early goal, which is worth a goal to the Dutch, is indicative of how good this side is.

Lowland farmers in Doi Inthanond, suffering from a debilitating drought and a two-decade dispute with highland farmers in watershed forests, have staged protests to draw attention to their plight and to pressure the government to amend the Cabinet resolution allowing people to live in sensitive forest areas. Smansnid Svasti counters the proponents of watershed settlements. The World Rainforest Movement (WRM) is much concerned over the plight of our hill tribes, who, its members feel, are under threat of ''losing their ancestral lands and their only known way of life''. And they are rightly indignant if the facts they base their opinion on are correct. Unfortunately, these facts are a tissue of unprincipled propaganda. Having been involved for over 12 years in a lowland peoples' initiative in Northern Thailand to restore and conserve their forest and water resources, I am appalled that the international community should be exploited with such misinformation on issues of such grave concern to us all. True reports have been represented as being one-sided; biased reports exonerating wrongdoers are declared to be true. But worst of all, WRM has been fed with a shameless falsification of historical records and false records of tribal occupation in Northern Thailand and of forest clearance there. Recent settlers How long have tribal peoples been living in the highland forests? Since ''time immemorial'' as WRM has understood? The Thais, both the Tai Noi, those of us occupying present-day Thailand, and the Tai Yai of the Shan States and Mae Hong Son, have always settled in the valleys. The Karen and the Lua, our indigenous tribal peoples, generally settled in forest mid-catchment, swiddening (''slashing and burning'') rotationally and maintaining a healthy forest cover, at least while their populations didn't increase overwhelmingly. Records of the Karen presence go back to the 17th century; the Lua were present when the Thais migrated into the country 1,000 years ago. The mountains were left undisturbed; water and forest resources were plentiful. Occupation of the high-altitude forests first began when opium-growing peoples migrated from China in the 1880s (''Migrants of the Mountains'', Geddes, 1968) slashing and burning clearings to grow hill rice, maize and opium, which do not grow well at lower altitudes. By 1947 there were around 20,000 opium-growers in the hills, but Thailand still had 74-per-cent forest cover, and any damage to the headwaters of rivers was containable (Royal Forest Department records). After the Chinese revolution of 1949, three waves of refugee migration swelled the highland population, the largest being in the early 1970s. Registration of the first Hmong settlement on Doi Inthanond was in 1970; the rest followed in 1975 (Chomtong District Office). Records of the other opium-growing peoples follow the same pattern, small numbers of migrants arriving before 1950 but numbers rapidly swelling after 1970 (Chaturabhand, 1988). The Present numbers of traditional opium-growers are in excess of 315,000 (Tribal Research Institute, 1995). Since World War II Thailand has a single relatively peaceful country surrounded by neighbours at war. Vast numbers of refugees have fled and are continuing to flee from China, Cambodia, Burma, Laos and Vietnam. These people are political refugees, not indigenous tribal peoples. The historical record then is that apart from the Lua and the Karen, whose settlements in mid-catchment are not threatening the nation's forest and water resources, the great majority of highland settlements were founded no more than 30 years ago, most of them much less. This is hardly ''time immemorial'', hardly enough time for their lands to be called ''ancestral''. The WRM says: ''[Let us] allow those with the knowledge and experience to preserve that which they have been protecting for centuries.'' In their shifting cultivation, the opium-growing peoples use the long-cultivation/very-long-fallow system. ''In areas that have been cultivated in this fashion the forest almost never returns within a human lifetime'' (''Farmers in the Forest'', Kunstadter, 1978). Cultivation patterns of this kind are more suited to valley farming, true to the Hmongs' origins in the Yangtze and Yellow River basins. They have never developed forest resource-management strategies, viewing forest land as free consumer goods (Kunstadter, ibid). The reason forest cover in Mae Hong Son province is greater than in neighbouring provinces is because much of its rugged mountain terrain is difficult of access and the population is therefore much lower. Of this population the latest figures (1996) show that 55 per cent are Tai Yai, five per cent Northern Thai and 40 per cent hill tribes (Mae Hong Son Provincial Records), not the 80 per cent quoted in the The Round House's article (The Nation, June 2). The provincial office has just reported that more of the forest is being lost, whole hills being converted to cabbage fields by the Hmong. Commercial farming The WRM says: ''Their only known way of life [is] threatened.'' Roads have been constructed into the highlands and electricity now reaches into formerly remote areas. With this ease of communication, tribal communities naturally wish to share in the conveniences that the new technology they see on TV brings. This means greater market production, their ways of life changing from farming for subsistence to farming for profit. The idea of an innocent ethnic people practising their timeless traditional wisdom is an attractive one, but no group of people can remain isolated and unchanging in our rapidly ''developing'' society, and the younger generation of tribal people are especially eager for change. Farming on a commercial scale rather than for subsistence has inevitably meant greater use of soil and water resources. Ever wider areas of forest have been and are being removed for the growing of cash crops, especially in anticipation of the survey ordered by the Cabinet decisions of April 1997 giving land rights in protected forests to those who can prove occupation before 1993; such ''proof'' can be as flimsy as a neighbour's word. There is less harm in forest clearance on this scale if the clearance is in the lowlands. But it is not. It is being done in the upper watershed forests, the fragile and critical areas where the headwaters of our rivers are formed. The baseline of any decision made on the feasibility of forest settlements must be ecological sustainability, and this depends on forest type, altitude and the morphological structure of the landscape. In England there is concern, sometimes bordering on panic, when there is a two-month drought. In monsoon climates, such as that of Northern Thailand, the drought is regularly seven and sometimes nine months long. No rain falls during this time. In such situations soils have to be deep and rich enough in humus to hold the rain, controlling its flow so that watercourses continue to run, filled with rain that fell several months before. High-altitude evergreen forests (over 1,000 metres) can produce such soil. In the cooler temperatures of these forests, decomposition of organic material is slower, allowing a high build-up of organic material in contrast to the lower forests, where higher temperatures speed up decomposition. There is little chance for any build-up of humus in such conditions, and the soil remains poor -- as in a rainforest. But the soils of our high evergreen forests are deep enough and rich enough to hold the monsoon rains as they fall, releasing them as perennial streams throughout the year. This is why we advocate that these forests be kept free of human activity, not so that they can be kept in ''pristine condition for day excursions of the rich'' but so as to ensure the survival of us all. (The issue of environmental survival is simple. But the social circumstances are far more complex than appearances would suggest, not at all a case of rich versus poor or modern man versus tribal people. One of our gravest concerns over the Cabinet decisions of April 1997 is that it is yet another attempt to secure land holdings by real-estate developers and land speculators, many of whom are in every government and who have already encroached on forest lands to build golf courses and tourist resorts.) Community forestry Not all forests need be free of human habitation. Settlements in the lower forests, such as those in mid-catchment made by the Karen and the Lua, are perfectly sustainable if they hold to their traditional management practices. Settlements in reserve forests where community forestry will increase the nation's forest cover should be encouraged and supported. But the evergreen headwater forests should be areas of strict conservation, as their removal brings about environmental disaster. Heavy rains wash away the soil, which quickly silts up dams, reservoirs and rivers. With little soil left to hold the rains, the headwaters dry up, as do subsequently the streams to the valleys. Seventy-two of the 76 provinces of Thailand now suffer regularly from dried-up streams due to the destruction of their headwater forests, and in 1996 floods drowned livestock and ruined crops and property in 64 provinces. Every rainy season now lowland paddies are buried to grow their crops. In the dry season their watercourses and their wells dry up, and massive siltation has reduced reservoirs to a fraction of their planned capacity. Villagers queue with buckets to buy water from municipal trucks. In the kind of heat we have experienced this year, the suffering is unimaginable unless you have suffered similarly yourself. The Northern Farmers Network does not address lowlanders' problems, since over 95 per cent of its members are highlanders. The Assembly of the Poor deals with Northeasterner's problems. So up to now the problems of lowlanders in the North have had no exposure. They have had no voice. But their desperation has forced them to act. A recent protest by 10,000 lowland farmers to draw attention to their plight drew a startling 40,000-strong support, some people travelling 90 km to join the protest. There had been no lobbying. The spontaneous gathering showed that they too were victims of the same conditions. What the WRM was informed of as being ''a smear campaign'' is simply that after years of being suppressed, the true facts of highland forest destruction are beginning to emerge. But you should not take my word for it. Neither should you take the word of the Northern Farmers Network or their Bangkok-based support organisations. Please don't take anyone's word. The only truthful and reliable source of environmental matters is the environment itself. Drive up the rugged mountain roads of Samoeng and Mae Sariang and see the cabbages and carnations, the potatoes and the gerberas stretching across the ridges where once stood great forests. Have the courage to listen only to the shaven hills and believe only the evidence of your own eyes. This article is a response to ''Scapegoats of deforestation'' published yesterday. Yesterday's article was written by Impect, a Chiang Mai-based NGO working on hill-tribe issues, and not by The Corner House or the World Rainforest Movement as stated. The two articles are posted in the WRM homepage: www.wrm.org.uy. The Cabinet is about to debate a proposal to amend the Wang Nam Khieu resolution passed by the previous Chavalit government allowing people to live in sensitive forest areas. -----------------------------

MALAYSIA still have a long way to go before they can take their place among the top six or even eight hockey playing countries in the world. The national team need to improve in almost every aspect of the game, namely speed, fitness, tactics, mental attitude and, more importantly, finishing. Consistency is another weakness plaguing the team. They played good hockey in patches in Utrecht, which was not good enough to win matches. In the opening match against Pakistan, the former world champions faced some problems in the second half but the Malaysians could not sustain the good run. Pakistan eventually won 7-2. It was a winning game against Poland and Malaysia could have achieved their top four placing target in the group. But they threw away that chance when they drew 1-1. Chances like these, especially in the World Cup, do not come easy. If the better team do not capitalise on them, they are no better than the weaker team. Malaysia still had the chance to finish in the top four when they met England, but that too slipped from their grasp when they lost 1-3. It was a foregone conclusion that they did not stand a chance against Australia and Spain, to whom they lost 8-0 and 3-0 respectively. Malaysia hit an all-time low when they played Spain. Everything they did went wrong. They could not stop the ball, passing was not accurate and they looked like a bunch of novices. Team officials will argue that they played well against England, New Zealand and Poland and they can talk about the misses and wasted opportunities. Of course, there were so many misses and close matches but playing at world class level, no team should be missing as many chances as the Malaysian team did. Performance is important but then again, the final result is what counts. They cannot go on saying we missed our chances against Poland and England or even New Zealand in the classification match. It will go down in history that Malaysia finished 11th out of 12 teams in the World Cup. Coach Volker Knapp wasted so much of time and placed too much emphasis on penalty corners. There were some 12 or 13 variations and all that for nothing because they couldn't score from them. To say they did not receive as many penalty corners to convert would not be true. Malaysia earned a total of 32 penalty corners and scored only five, which works out to a 15.6 per cent, down from about 30 per cent during the qualifiers in Kuala Lumpur in March last year. Against Pakistan, they earned 11 penalty corners and scored only two through Nor Saiful Zaini's direct hits. Against Poland, they received eight and scored only one, and that, too, from a rebound. Malaysia played a defensive game against Australia and Spain, where there were not many penalty corners in Malaysia's favour. However, not everyone in the team played badly. Players who deserve mention are R. Shankar, Lailin Abu Hasaan and Nasihin Nubli. Nasihin played only against Poland in the 11th-12th placing match and did well. Mirnawan Nawawi and Nor Saiful Zaini, who used to be feared forwards a few years back, have dipped in performance and so has M. Kaliswaran. A lot of work needs to be done if Malaysia are to avoid another humiliation in the Commonwealth Games in September.

CONTRARY to pre-handover predictions, the judiciary has managed to retain its independence almost a year after the change of sovereignty, according to a leading academic. Richard Cullen, visiting fellow at the City University's faculty of law, said so far there had been no concrete evidence to prove that judges had been influenced either by the government or by Beijing. ``The general condition is generally much more positive than the gloomy situation forecast before the handover,'' he told a conference on comparative judicial systems at the City University. ``Judges appear to have maintained their independence despite the change of sovereignty.'' The two-day conference which started yesterday is being attended by 50 legal experts from the Department of Justice, local universities and the mainland. Four judges of the Supreme People's Court _ Judge Ge Xingjun, Judge Li Fan, Judge Liu Zhixin and Judge Wang Yanbin _ are among the participants. Mr Cullen said it was too early to tell whether local judges would be able to retain their independence in the next few years. He said the High Court decision last year recognising the legality of the controversial Provisional Legislative Council was something that should be reflected upon. ``I think keeping judicial independence is a matter for Hong Kong people to decide,'' Mr Cullen said. ``I mean, local judges and the legal profession will have to decide on the extent of judicial independence and not Beijing.'' Mr Cullen said ordinary people also had a pivotal role to play in retaining judicial independence. He said the 53 per cent voter turnout during the 24 May Legislative Council elections proved that ordinary people were willing to speak up. Professor Edward Tyler, dean of the City University's faculty of law, said he had not seen any signs of interference by the government in the work of judges. But he said the contractual arrangements for magistrates could make them vulnerable to interference.

Peter Dennis Anthony Sutch, 53, has an impressive bio-data. Chairman of the UK-based Swire Group in Hong Kong, he oversees John Swire Sons (HK) Ltd, Swire Pacific Ltd, Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd, and Swire Properties Ltd. He is also a board member of the HongKong and Shanghai Banking Corporation. Sutch, who joined Cathay Pacific Airways 28 years ago, has spent the last 14 as its managing director. He was in India recently and talked to Neera Bhardwaj of the ambitious plans the airline has been nurturing for the country. This despite it facing turbulent weather -- its profit for 1997 at $262 million was down 37.5 per cent compared to the previous year. Sutch is betting on the new, $1-billion airport at Chek Lap Kok to make Hong Kong the preferred hub for Asia QYou are visiting India after four years... A Yes, but it is no reflection on how important India is in our scheme of things. It is a reflection on how business has been in Hong Kong, leading up to the handover (to China). In fact, 1997 was a good year for India. It exceeded the target on both passenger and cargo fronts. That is extremely satisfactory considering there was no extra capacity flying through here. Q Are you planning to rectify that? A Our (flying) schedules in India have remained the same for the last 10-12 years. It is no secret that we feel there is a bigger market in India. I am hoping our ongoing dialogue with Air-India will help our respective governments to meet again on increasing frequencies. One of the difficulties for the last two or three years was [reviewing] air agreements between the two governments. That was sorted out last year. Now we can add on to that specific agenda in terms of capacity and frequency. Our airport in Hong Kong had put a restriction on growth of frequencies because of limited space. But from 6 July we will have a new airport with 24-hour operations, and by November it will have two runways. This will enable Hong Kong to take full advantage of its very strategic geographic position in Asia and act as a funnel to feed traffic. Q What is the progress on flights from Delhi? A We have been looking at Delhi for quite some time now. We hope to arrange a meeting between the Hong Kong and Indian governments. We came to Calcutta in 1950 and 48 years later we are not able to fly from Delhi. I am here to help the dialogue move forward. The Hong Kong government will be happy to give reciprocal rights to Air-India. But to work out an arrangement you need to meet. The last meeting between the governments was in 1996. Q You had a bad year last year. How are you likely to fare this year? A We had good growth in the first five months in 1997. The problems began in the second half. That kept the hotel rooms empty and the traffic to Hong Kong declined. Though our first and business class business soon understood that it was business as usual, the leisure traveller, who depends on television for news, decided to play it safe. The second problem was the Asian economy. The Thai baht devalued on 2 July and that set the dominos falling. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu wants US$1 billion from staunch ally the United States to build roads for Jewish settlers occupying Palestinian land as a condition for more withdrawal from the West Bank. It is indeed mind-boggling how further Jewish construction in the occupied territories could lead to more withdrawals. No doubt Netanyahu has good reason to build more roads: by doing that, he is blocking all roads to peace. Last Friday Netanyahu marked his second anniversary in power. He has much to celebrate, for within that short period he has successfully buried the peace process for good. That shouldn't surprise anyone. After all, Netanyahu has always been an unabashed critic of the ''land for peace'' deal. The Oslo peace accord, he believes, poses a grave danger to his vision of ''Greater Israel'', and any Israeli withdrawal from the occupied territories would imperil the existence of the Jewish state. Likewise it is not surprising that the Clinton administration has been slow to realise its Israeli friend is not too keen on striking peace with the Palestinians. Netanyahu has indeed cleverly justified his stubborness by accusing the Palestinian Authority of violating its promises to crack down on terrorism. That there has been no major terrorist attack against Israel in nine months is conveniently ignored. But it appears that Netanyahu's American allies have bought his argument. A majority in the Congress has urged Clinton not to force Israel into ''accepting something it did not want''. House speaker Newt Gingrich, a presidential aspirant, went a step further: he branded Secretary of State Madeleine Albright an ''agent of Palestine'' for her proposal to kick-start the peace process. But despite what Gingrich and his ilk would have us believe, the Albright proposal is already very much pro-Israel. If Israel now withdraws from 13 per cent of the West Bank as the US suggests, then the total pre-final-status withdrawal will amount to some 40 per cent of the West Bank. This falls short of the Oslo agreements. Under the accord, Israel should by now be turning over half of the occupied territories to the Palestinians, and the two sides should have moved to the final negotiations on a permanent settlement. The Palestinians know that they would be disadvantaged by the Albright proposal: they would have to negotiate the other 60 per cent of the West Bank and haggle over Jerusalem from a rather weak position. Yet they went along with it. In contrast Netanyahu has adamantly refused to withdraw from more than nine per cent. Any more, he said, would mean mortal danger to Israel's security. If he thinks that his measly offer marks the end of Israel's possible territorial concessions, how on Earth are the Palestinians build a state from the series of disconnected fragments forming one-third of West Bank? Then again, Netanyahu doesn't want a Palestinian state. Netanyahu has until Friday to respond to the US offer. Most likely he will be counting on his American ally to give him more time. Already the US has extended its ultimatum numerous times. There is no question that Netanyahu is seeking to buy more time, perhaps waiting for a major terrorist attack as a pretext to effectively kill the peace accord. Such a scenario is fast becoming a self-fulfilling prophesy. As more and more Palestinians become frustrated with Netanyahu's bull-headedness, critics of moderate Palestinian Authority leader Yasir Arafat are likely to resort to violence, and to add fuel to the fire, Netanyahu is himself goading the Palestinians by authorising the expansion of Jewish settlements on occupied land and in disputed Jerusalem. American and Israeli spin doctors have for years portrayed the Palestinians as a band of hard-line terrorists. On the contrary, it is the Palestinians who have made concessions: they have now agreed to give much of their homeland to the Israelis. All they want is a state of their own from the sliver of land in the Gaza Strip plus the West Bank. This is no small concession, akin to giving up the house for the right to live in the back yard. When Theodore Herzl, the founder of Zionism, spoke of ''a people without a land'' looking for ''a land without a people'', apparently he was not aware of the presence of an Arab population in Palestine. Last month Nobel Peace laureate Shimon Peres wrote: ''After 50 years, it is time for us to put right the mistake we have made: we have not taken into account the existence of another people.'' But it looks as if Netanyahu is not listening. Neither are his US backers.

MAYBE what it will take to bring down the Chuan government is a much-scorned ''farmer''. Academic Thirayuth Boonmi may be the most formidable in taking on the administration. Telecom tycoon Thaksin Shinawatra may be the most financially equipped to create political waves. Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, meanwhile, has not given up on efforts to put Chuan Leekpai out of the way. The prime minister, however, has brushed them aside with relative ease. But not Samak Sundaravej. In political limbo since most of his Prachakorn Thai MPs broke ranks late last year to support Chuan as prime minister, Samak hit back the hardest on Monday when he managed to flush the rebels out of the party's executive board. That means expelling them from the party will be a pushover. And Samak seemed to have waited for the best time to strike. If he had moved earlier, there would not have been political pressure on Chuan, who was enjoying high popularity and constitutional immunity against House dissolution. With Chuan's image being besieged by the rich-and-poor issue and the immunity evaporating following the recent passage of organic laws, the Prachakorn Thai case is beginning to have a greater impact. At first Samak made it look like the expulsion of the rebels from the party's board was a tedious process. But his systematic triumphs over them were quite comfortable, thus raising the question whether he was just dragging his feet and waiting for the right time. And the long wait enabled Samak to build a good case if the rebels, once totally expelled from the party, want to take the fight to the Constitution Court. The dissidents now have violated the party's resolutions on key legislation, including the recently-passed financial executive decrees, which would likely cost them the court's sympathy. If Samak had expelled them earlier, he would have been only equipped with charges that they had breached the party's decision against supporting Chuan as prime minister. On that matter, the rebels would have argued that the Constitution allows them to exercise their conscience. The same argument would also have applied to back their decision to vote for the government at the end of the censure debate in March. If the court rules in Samak's favour and the rebels lose their MP status, the Chuan government's parliamentary strength would be reduced to 196, a wafer-thin majority. Its stability in the eyes of the international community will disappear and Chuan may have no choice but to dissolve the House. Even if the rebels win the fight in the constitutional court, finding a new party could trigger a major political controversy. Due to serious image problems, not all of them could join the Democrats. ''Public confidence in the government might be affected,'' Chuan admitted Tuesday. ''But the government will still have majority control in Parliament.'' Samak has called himself a ''farmer'' who got bitten by ''cobras'' he had given shelter to. The rebels, who have always spoken of him in high regard, are turning increasingly aggressive. ''This party has been run as a cult. One man dictates everything,'' said Vatana Asavahame, deputy interior minister and one of the rebels. The group can use another tactic to stall Samak, by filing complaints with the civil court and the Election Commission against ''illegal'' manoeuverings by Samak when he beat them out of the party's executive board. The Democrat Party has given the rebels encouragement by saying their ministerial posts would be kept intact, and no opposition party would be brought in to boost the government's stability. ''We believe in the Democrats,'' said Man Pattanothai, another ''cobra''. ''I believe they appreciate what we have done [for the government].''

FIVE stock market players ``tricked'' watchdogs by secretly taking over a lucrative company because they could not afford to follow the rules, a jury was told yesterday. The buyout was hidden from regulators because the purchasers did not have $1 billion that would have been required to back the deal, Martin Wilson, QC, told the Court of First Instance. David Tong Cun-lin, 48, his sister-in-law Hsu Jye, 40, Arthur Lai Cheuk-kwan, 48, his brother Raymond Lai Chik-fan, 48, and Peter Mou Chi-luen, 45, deny plotting to defraud the Securities and Futures Commission and the Committee on Takeovers and Mergers between January 1990 and June 1991. Two companies connected to Tong acquired 66 per cent of Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond's company, Bond Corporation International, Mr Wilson told the court. However, only 34.5 per cent of the deal was carried out with the knowledge of the SFC and the mergers committee, the jury heard. Those shares were bought by Thomson Pacific, whose executive chairman was Tong. ``The SFC was tricked into believing that was all Thomson Pacific was acquiring,'' Mr Wilson said. But another 31.5 per cent was bought through Chin Tung, Arthur Lai's brokerage, because Tong or his four alleged accomplices could not afford to meet legal requirements set by the SFC, it was alleged. Any group which acquires more than 35 per cent of shares with voting rights in a listed company must make a ``general offer'' to buy out all shareholders, the jury heard. But this could have cost the five accused more than $1 billion _ a sum they could not muster, Mr Wilson said. So to gain control they failed to reveal to the SFC that the companies involved were working in concert. Bond Corporation International Holdings (BCIL) had been an attractive investment to Tong and Thomson Pacific because of its cash reserves, the jury heard. ``Although Bond Corporation was in trouble, BCIL was a company with substantial cash resources,'' Mr Wilson said. ``They wanted to get their hands on the cash by acquiring BCIL, but we will show they did not have the means to make a general offer. ``Therefore, they were prepared to defraud the SFC and the committee in order to acquire the cash resources. ``We say everyone of these defendants knew that.'' Arthur Lai is also accused of taking A$2 million (HK$9.4 million) and HK$26.4 million in bribes. Tong is accused of offering a $26.4 million bribe, while Raymond Lai and Mou face two counts of aiding and abetting the corrupt payments. All have pleaded not guilty. The trial, before Justice Brian Keith, continues.

NATO accelerates other plans to reinforce Albanian, Macedonia borders With Yugoslavia-Kosovo
By ROBERT WIELAARD Associated Press Writer
BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) _ The NATO allies agreed Wednesday to consider again whether to deploy combat troops in Albania and Macedonia to contain the violence in neighboring Kosovo province, but the prospect of quick action was dim. ``We all agreed we cannot proceed (with an allied force) until we have solid, well-thought out military advice,'' said a NATO official, who asked not to be named. ``We first of all want to have good, detailed military advice.'' The NATO official said getting the necessary military advice ``would take several days'' and then would have to be reviewed by the NATO defense ministers who meet in Brussels on June 11-12. Meantime, ambassadors of the 16 NATO nations agreed to accelerate other measures that included technical and military assistance for Albania and Macedonia. The first miliary advisors are to leave in a matter of days. Thousands of refugees have fled the violence in Kosovo, where Serb police and army forces have stepped-up their campaign since late May to crush the pro-independence Kosovo Liberation Army.Kosovo. More than 200 people have been killed in the southern Serb province where 90 percent of the population are ethnic Albanians. Also, NATO gave more priority to previously scheduled small-scale joint military maneuvers in Albania and Macedonia, and NATO's civil emergency and planning section was told to extend immediate cooperation with U.N. officials dealing with the exodus of Kosovo refugees. Attacks on villages, the exodus of civilians and the deaths of women and children have prompted comparisons to the ethnic war in Bosnia, where conflict spiraled into civil war in the early 1990s as NATO allies bickered over how to contain the Balkan crisis. Officials, however, rejected suggestions that NATO was again slow off the mark by taking a cautious stance on deploying a large alliance force in Albania and Macedonia. ``NATO ... cannot do things which are not guaranteed to be successful. We are going quickly, but we recognize there is a need for substantive military work,'' the NATO official said. NATO's Kosovo policy is guided by the belief the province should not become independent but be given back the autonomy it once had within the Yugoslav Republic.

FOUR Hong Kong cyclists got the fund-raising wheels rolling yesterday for the Medecins Sans Frontiers (MSF) when they flew to Chengdu for the first leg of their 10-week trip. The four pedal-pushers' adventure will take them through the world's highest motorable pass in Khardung-la at 5,600 metres. Lawyer Simon Black, 30, initiated the idea and friends Jacquetta Hayes, Frances Hopwood and David Nighy agreed to join him. All the team's equipment, clothing and food supplies will be carried on their bikes, and loads including bicycles weigh up to 30 kilograms each. ``I'm still trying to find somewhere to attach my cricket bat,'' said Mr Black. The four have been training since Christmas with a daily regime that includes a morning ride up Magazine Gap Road to The Peak. The trip from Lhasa to Kathmandu is 1,100 km. The second leg, to be undertaken by Mr Black and Mr Nighy, is a further 800 km to Ladakh. Major fears for the team are possible health hazards, bureaucracy and mechanical failures, but the team is positive. ``There is a limit to the number of repairs we can carry out, but if one of the bicycles break, we can always buy a new one,'' said Mr Black.

He feels that from birth his destiny has been international. Born in France and brought up in San Francisco of American and European parents, 44-year-old Ben Barnes' appetite for international adventure was whetted by his father's job as an oil company executive. Lacking ``a knack for desert survival'', he opted for a career in advertising which has led him to the current position of president and CEO of Foote, Cone Belding (FCB), Asia-Pacific. He graduated in International Business from the University of Oregon and did his masters at Thunderbird in Arizona. McCann Erickson LA gave him the first break in advertising, after which he moved over to Grey Advertising, working first in Venezuela and then in Japan. He then made the fateful move to Hong Kong, becoming managing director of Grey and later director of Grey SE Asia. Since the end of 1994, he has been with FCB (which has a 51 per cent stake in Mumbai-based Ulka), helping design and orchestrate the important changes that have been taking place in the agency. He spoke to Business India's Alokananda Chakraborty during his recent visit to Mumbai to ``unravel'' FCB's Blueprint Q How important is India in FCB's global scheme? A A lot of times my priorities are dictated by problems; in that sense India is not a priority. But from the point of view of future growth, India is the most important market among the 20 other countries [in which] we are present in the Asia-Pacific region. We have close to 500 people working with our Indian partner and the venture contributes significantly to our Asia-Pacific profits. And any major development at FCB will be brought to India immediately. As a matter of fact, the FCB Blueprint was launched in the US just about a month ago, and it is being launched in India before any of the Asia-Pacific countries. Q What is the core idea behind Blueprint? Why do we need a ``new planning process''? A Today, it is becoming increasingly difficult to describe consumers in the typical fashion in which we categorised them before. We now have a situation where groupings of people have become segmented more and more on the basis of certain criteria that go beyond standard demographic descriptions. The FCB Blueprint is the documentation of a new, sophisticated planning process involving tools and techniques that have been developed by FCB over 120 years of research and learning across 60 countries around the globe. The 'new planning process' -- as it is called -- is a strategy and creative development framework which help gain important consumer insights. These, in turn, increase the odds of creating ideas that sell today as well as build brand value over time. Q In recent months some of the big networks like Ammirati Puris Lintas, Dentsu Young Rubicam and McCann Erickson have been rolling out proprietary tools like LinSolutions, Brand Asset Valuator and Roadmap worldwide. Like Blueprint, these are also supposed to generate consumer insights. What makes the fcb blueprint any different from these? A The new planning process is the core of what we at FCB call 'person-to-person advertising'. As Fairfax Cone, one of our founders, said, ``Good advertising is written always from one person to another. When it is aimed at millions, it rarely moves anyone.'' In most other agencies, the creative director, the group account director, or for that matter, the senior people who have custodianship of the brand, are not one with the consumers. The FCB tools ensure that the senior people are in constant communication with the consumer in a meaningful manner. We have developed scientific techniques for doing that. Q Can you explain how these techniques work? A Blueprint is a step-by-step methodology that consistently helps develop advertising of a high quality. At the foundation of Blueprint is a process called 'Mind Mood', in which agency personnel from all disciplines have conversations with consumers in the context of their lives, as they naturally interact with categories and brands, to uncover gut-level consumer insights. If you delegate that task to someone else --even to professional research outfits -- you can at best end up with second-hand insights. And once we get an understanding of the brand, the company, the person, and the competition through Mind Mood, we do a BrandLink --which helps provide an enduring view of the relationship between the consumer and the brand. There are a host of other techniques like these and it's only after executing all of these that the perspective to formulate the briefs for creative, media, and integrated functions are gained. This does not guarantee 100 per cent success, but at least we know that if we do all these before we design a campaign, the odds against it will be minimised.

RICE exports during the first five months rose by 49 per cent to 2.79 million tonnes, worth Bt38.9 billion over the same period last year, Deputy Prime Minister and Commerce Minister Supachai Panitchpakdi announced Tuesday. Thailand exports 500,000 tonnes of rice a month. Supachai said the lower export growth in May came after importers delayed shipments, in particular, to Indonesia which is facing serious economic crisis and political turmoil, and the Philippines, which just concluded its national election and was awaiting the new government's rice policy. Moreover, low grade rice was facing severe competition because output from China, an important rival, was flooding the market. Since the Chinese sold their rice at a very competitive price compared to Thailand, buyers were placing more orders from China, he said. Although the demand for rice in the region has fallen, its trading in theworld market was still high, and is expected to reach 22.10 million tonnes. Thailand was eyeing a 27.08 per cent share of the total trade, making it the world's largest exporter. Vietnam, another major exporter, has delayed its export shipment in order to cover the domestic shortage, which has led to countries in the Middle East and Africa accelerating their imports. In addition, Japan has opened its market for rice imports under a commitment to the World Trade Organisation. Supachai revealed that Thailand's export level would be 400,000 to 500,000 tonnes in June to July this year. This will help shore up the second crop rice price. Meanwhile, the Thai Rice Mills Association has reported that rice prices in the Bangkok market were rising due to low supply. Many Iranian vessels are waiting to load rice at Bangkok Port.

THE Cabinet Tuesday added Bt50 billion to the 1998 budget deficit to compensate for losses by state-run Bangkok Mass Transit Authority (BMTA) and State Railway of Thailand (SRT). The stimulus package is aimed at boosting the expenditure of government agencies by Bt40 billion and of state enterprises by Bt10 billion to provide for the Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand's Ratchaburi power plant project and a Petroleum Authority of Thailand gas pipeline project. This will increase the 1998 fiscal budget to Bt850 billion. The plan comes ahead of expected International Monetary Fund approval on June 10 of Thailand's fourth quarterly commitment to economic reforms outlined in the US$17.2 billion multilateral rescue package. The fourth letter of intent, signed by the Cabinet last week, allows a widening of the government's budget deficit from 2 per cent of gross domestic product to 3 per cent in fiscal 1997-98. For the BMTA, the government will compensate for a Bt3.19 billion operating loss in 1996 and 1997 compared to an accumulated loss of Bt6.18 billion since 1993. In 1998, the BMTA is expected to record a Bt2.2 billion loss. A government spokesman said the government must absorb some of the BMTA's loss because it is in serious financial trouble with a massive debt burden and very little liquidity. The BMTA cannot boost its revenue to cover rising operating costs due to restrictions on raising fares. The government has not allowed the BMTA to boost its fares in line with its operating costs to avoid impacting to low-income earners. However, the financial strain has caused BMTA to default on debts and will eventually hit service quality. The government also ordered the BMTA to immediately prepare its privatisation plans for submission to the Finance Ministry. Meanwhile, the government will provide an additional Bt38 million in compensation for the SRT to Bt1.39 billion for fiscal 1998. Other expenses are Bt4.75 billion contributed to the Social Security Fund, and Bt4.73 billion in welfare payments for civil servants, which the government earlier suspended. The spokesman said this would strengthen the fund's stability to cope with the burden imposed by the Social Security Act BE 2533, such as extending compensation for unemployed workers from six to 12 months. TO prevent volatility in the financial markets, the Bank of Thailand has re-adopted a high-interest rate policy to control speculative baht trading. The repurchase rate Tuesday was jacked up by 50 basis points to 18 per cent. MR Chatu Mongol Sonakul, governor of the Bank of Thailand, said Tuesday the central bank is prepared to raise short-term interest rates to tackle exchange rate volatility. ''A high interest rate policy is still necessary. The rate needs to be raised to attract capital inflows during the period that the dollar/baht exchange rate is weakened. I believe that [one or two days after the rate is jacked up] the situation will improve,'' he said. Short-term rates would directly affect the exchange rate, he explained, as they would force swap rates up, thereby discouraging baht sales. His comments followed the sharp depreciation of the baht against the US dollar since late last week. The dollar/baht exchange rate ended morning trading at Bt42.55-Bt42.65, down from Bt40 at the end of last week. The baht ended the day at Bt42.20 per dollar, a 1.56 per cent drop from Bt41.55 on Friday. Dealers said rising fears over a regional economic recession as well as the continued depreciation of the Japanese yen dragged the Thai currency down. Chatu Mongol said the weakened baht is driven by natural causes. The cause is explicable and amid low trading volumes, the dollar/baht rate follows market expectations on the baht and other Asian currencies. He said the fall of regional currencies, particularly the Japanese yen, were due to the low and negative growths recorded throughout the region. The baht cannot fight because 40 per cent of Thailand's gross domestic product comes from international trade. Chatu Mongol said there will be intervention by the authorities only after the problem is solved as Thailand does not have sufficient reserves to fight the market whose foreign exchange trading volume is about US$1.5 trillion. ''Before intervening, we must make sure the volume is low. All would be drowned when swimming in a direction different to the tide. Similarly, we could not resist [the tide],'' he said. Yet, Chatu Mongol said the short-term rate hike would not affect the long-term rate because short-term interest rates are a means of controlling the exchange rate. Higher interest rates are expected to control speculative baht trading.

ONE reason for the government's plan to take back the job of ensuring food safety and environmental hygiene from the two municipal councils is to enhance co-ordination with international bodies. That was the explanation given by Deputy Secretary for Constitutional Affairs Maureen Chan Leung Mong-lin on a radio program yesterday. ``Public health concerns the people, the issue must be dealt with, hence we prefer it be taken care of by the government,'' she explained. It is understood that the bird flu crisis in the second half of last year and this year's red tide crisis gave rise to the move. The two crises sparked public criticism of the lack of co-ordination between the municipal authorities and the relevant government departments. On Monday Secretary for Constitutional Affairs Michael Suen Ming-yeung explained that besides the two municipal councils, the Health and Welfare Bureau, Department of Health, Agriculture and Fisheries Department and Economic Services Bureau all perform duties related to the safety of imported poultry. ``There has been so much criticism from the public that we want to centralise the work so as to improve efficiency and the ability to respond to emergencies,'' Mr Suen said. Mrs Chan said the government would also improve co-ordination with international bodies like the World Health Organisation. ``Some of the crises that happened lately showed that the proposed arrangement would be more appropriate as it could ensure faster and better assistance from some international bodies,'' she said. In reply to the demand by pro-democracy parties that all appointed seats in the regional organisations be abolished, Mrs Chan said the government had not yet reached any decision on the issue. But she stressed that some favoured the retention of ex-officio seats because the two municipal councils needed opinions from experts. Meanwhile, Provisional Urban Councillor Joseph Chan Yuek-sut said the government's formation of a Steering Committee on Healthy Living was a ``plot'' to disempower the municipal councils ahead of the government consultation. ``The reason that the government set up such a committee is because they want to withdraw our power in advance,'' Mr Chan told a council Standing Committee meeting. Councillor Lee Wing-tat asked why council chairman Ronald Leung Ding-bong was appointed a member of the steering committee. Chief Secretary for Administration Anson Chan Fang On-sang heads the panel that will promote healthy living over the next three years. ``I think you have to clarify if you are invited into the committee as our chairman or in your own personal capacity,'' he said. Dr Leung said he had no answer to the question.

THERE'S a new imperialism abroad and it is being waged through the media. The latest is a blatant attempt by the English to hijack the 2002 World Cup from Japan and South Korea. The sniping, jibing and jiving have become an intolerable threat to Asian and Third World interests. And sporting stability. The underhanded methods employed are certainly unsporting. But that is to be expected of a nation who appear to have lost all sense of propriety together with their sporting excellence and domination. The Brits are, after all, now also-rans in cricket, rugby, tennis, football and most other sport. The world has to deal with this threat before they become reckless, and irresponsible, if they haven't already made a mockery of sportsmanship. The unfair sniping at the Kuala Lumpur Commonwealth Games through exaggerated reports, often outright lies, was so bad that it appeared to be an orchestrated effort. A flagrant attack to discredit Malaysia, the first Asian nation to host the Games. The half-truths, slander and distortions about the haze, drug laws, etc, were hurtful but the truth has prevailed and the Commonwealth Games Federation (CGF) themselves have lashed out at these reports. The lie as reported by the Observer's sports editor Alan Hubbard that `British athletes will be flogged for smoking dope in KL' is just one case in point. But the latest attempt by the British Press at daylight robbery, allegedly aided and abetted by their government, to snatch the 2002 World Cup was met with outrage by Japan and South Korea, Fifa and the international community. This brings into question the very essence of British integrity and honour although their actions during the days when they ruled two-thirds of the world distinctly showed their disdain for both. Fifa, the world soccer's governing body, dismissed speculation that Japan and South Korea could pull out of staging the 2002 World Cup. The Fifa statement was released following a report in the tabloid Daily Express which quoted British Sports Minister Tony Banks as saying England were preparing to replace Japan and South Korea as 2002 host. Banks was quoted as saying he had discussed the possibility with Fifa vice president Lennart Johansson. ``This is an eventuality which Johansson has raised,'' Banks was quoted as saying. ``He thinks Japan and Korea might have difficulties. We are the only nation equipped to organise and put on a World Cup Finals at very short notice. We are ready and willing to step in and the football authorities know that.'' Johansson, chairman of the World Cup organising committee, described the speculation as `absurd and completely unfounded'. ``There is absolutely no doubt that Japan and South Korea will organise the first World Cup in Asia,'' Johansson said in a statement. ``Preparations are going ahead as scheduled and Fifa are in full agreement with both of the organising committees.'' What is it with the Brits? Can't they bear to see an Asian nation or a former colony make the grade or is it something more insidious? Banks later dismissed the report as `entirely fictitious'. He denied having discussed taking over the 2002 World Cup with Johansson. But German Football Federation president Egidius Braun strongly criticised the role he believes British Prime Minister Tony Blair himself is playing in England's bid to replace the hosts for the 2002 World Cup. Braun told German radio that he was disappointed in England's bid to take over from financially-troubled Japan and South Korea and said he suspected Blair was a key player in the move. Braun said: ``It is not a very noble and correct attitude and not very gentlemanlike. As president of a federation, I would be thinking more in terms of how to help our Japanese and South Korean friends. ``I don't know the exact reasons which are motivating them, but I know Tony Blair is behind it all.'' A damning indictment indeed. But not surprising, seeing as how the English FA reneged on an agreement with their German counterparts to support Germany's bid for the 2006 World Cup by joining in the bid themselves. Where is the much vaunted British sense of fairplay and sportsmanship? Sport, after all, is not supposed to know boundaries and prejudices. Where is the goodwill, the spirit which exemplifies the Commonwealth? Perhaps it is a myth like the Commonwealth itself. But then, it is all so typical of the jingoism practised by the English Press which, lacking a Princess Diana to hound, now pick on foreigners to sell their newspapers. Driven, no doubt, by that xenophobic smugness and insularity that makes the English think they are superior to the rest of the world. Who can forget the grossness they displayed during Euro '96 in insulting the Germans. It got so bad that the Labour and Conservative MPs had to deplore `the frenzy of jingoistic, notably anti-German nonsense in the tabloid Press'. In Germany, the broadsheet Suddeutsche Zeitung consoled its readers by explaining that The Sun and other tabloids are `read by people who don't give a toss about who runs the country, as long as she has big breasts'. That best sums up the British Press and why we should pay scant attention to them. The trouble is they act as if Britain were still a world power when it cannot even muster a decent cricket or rugby team to take on the colonial boys. Even the biggest stars in the English League today are foreigners and Premier League champions Arsenal are managed by Frenchman Arsene Wenger. And Britain pride themselves in being home of the beautiful game. Eric Cantona of France became a tabloid celebrity when he responded to xenophobic abuse by kicking a spectator in the chest. Like the rugby tour Down Under which has got the Aussies fuming. O'Neill has even threatened to review future incoming tours of British sides. So all is not fair or right with the Brits, who appear to be using underhanded methods to achieve what they cannot do on level playing fields. It's the old colonial bigotry and hypocrisy of double standards all over again. It leaves the same bad taste as it undermines mankind's ability to share sport without rancor and division.

SINGAPORE -- Arianespace, the world's leading satellite launcher, has reacted calmly to Asia's financial crisis, saying that such crises in other regions had in the end resulted in rewarding recoveries. ''Although we are not economists, we are all obliged to make economic judgments. Our judgment is that there is every reason to expect a rebound in the region's economies,'' said Jean-Marie Luton, the company's chairman and CEO in a speech at CommunicAsia 98/NetworkAsia 98 trade fair. He pointed out that Asia-Pacific had the world's largest population and that telecommunications was always going to be essential. ''People need telecommunications in their hearts,'' he said. Investment in satellite communications is a long-term plan. Some satellite providers and some countries have delayed the investment, but they still realise that it will take them at least five years to have the investment in a complete service, the top boss said. ''It makes sense to continue the satellite projects and when the economy has picked up, the service is there,'' he said. Arianespace controls the largest share of the business worldwide. Currently, it has secured orders to launch a total of 40 satellites. Seven of them are for Asia-Pacific: India's Insat 2E, Indonesia's Telkom-1, Japan's Superbird-4, Korea's Koreasat-3, Singapore's ST-1, and Laos' L-Star A B. Following the economic crisis, some projects have been put on hold, including L-Star. However, Arianspace claimed there had been no cancellations. This year, the Europe-based satellite launcher will put up two satellites -- ST-1 and Insat 2E. The L-Star satellite project, which has faced financial problems, is expected to emerge free of those problems and could be launched into space next year, according to Arianspace. ''Shareholders and the operator of L-Star are working out their plans. We will be informed of an exact date for the launch later,'' said Richard Bowles, director of the Singapore Asean office. Arianspace remains optimistic that it will be able to increase its market share in Asia-Pacific from the current 50 per cent to 60 per cent in the next seven to eight years, according to Ralph Werner Jaeger, senior vice president for commercial and international affairs. ''Our current order book shows seven for the region to be launched over the next two years. The combined order books for our competition is eight. So we have just under half of Asia's satellites currently on order,'' Luton said in his speech. The company executives said they had assisted all customers technically and financially. ''The cost for launching a satellite will not be more expensive, but the speed for getting the satellite into its orbital slot will be faster. This will help customers to use their satellite faster,'' Luton said. Launching without failures is one big advantage for customers. Luton said that such complete launches had enabled the space insurance market to become very profitable and had led to a dramatic fall in the cost of insurance. ''For our new Ariane 5, Arianspace is also offering a free re-launch in case of a failure of the new launcher,'' Luton said. In a separate development, Thailand's satellite operator, Shinawatra Satellite Plc, has introduced a new service to facilitate the Internet business, called Thaicom Direct. Also, the company is planning to launch another high-speed satellite link called Data Broadcasting Network, which will help Internet users to store all data in hard disk for instant retrieval. Russian's say no evidence Einstein friend was Soviet spy
MOSCOW (AP) _ A Russian spy agency said Wednesday it has no evidence that a woman romantically involved with Albert Einstein worked for Soviet intelligence. Nine of the scientist's recently discovered letters reveal Einstein's strong feelings for Margarita Konenkova, a Soviet woman with whom he had a wartime love affair. Konenkova was identified as a spy in ``Special Tasks,'' the memoirs of Soviet spymaster Pavel Sudoplatov, published in 1995. But the head of Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service, Gen. Yuri Kobaladze, told the Interfax news agency it has no evidence she worked with Soviet intelligence. ``Soviet intelligence had nothing to do with Einstein,'' Kobaladze said. A duty officer at the agency, a successor to the KGB, refused to comment Wednesday when contacted by The Associated Press. The letters indicate Konenkova accomplished the task she had reportedly been given in Moscow: introducing the famous physicist to Moscow's vice consul in New York. But the diplomat apparently failed to change Einstein's opinions on the Soviet Union. Sotheby's auction house plans to sell Einstein's letters, obtained from one of Konenkova's descendants, on June 26. Kobaladze said it was possible the allegations about Konenkova surfaced this week for the purpose of ``adding the element of sensation to the upcoming auction and inflating the price of the love letters,'' Interfax said. The letters were written between November 1945 and July 1946, just after Konenkova returned to Moscow. (ls/ml)

SELANGOR added another trophy to their cabinet when they retained the Carlsberg-Malaysian Cricket Association Division One title by defeating Johor at the PKNS ground in Kelana Jaya last weekend. The home team were eventually dismissed for 194. Johore replied with 102. Selangor won the second-day match by seven wickets with Ranjit Rajah scoring 24 and Ramesh Nathan 26 not out. Johor were dismissed for 82. Chew Pok Hong was their top scorer with 22 runs. NEGRI Sembilan defeated Penang in both one-day 50 overs matches in Seremban last weekend. On Saturday, Negri, chasing Penang's total of 133, reached the target with six wickets to spare. Jeevan Nair scored 52 and Anjum Shahad 46. Negri were also in a commanding position on the second day play, making 219-8. Penang were out for 109.

The struggling Kanjanapas family, Bangkok Land Plc's major shareholder, will find it difficult to revive their ambition to become Thailand's premier property developer. Achara Deboonme writes. Bangkok Land was set up in 1989 when Thailand saw the start of an economic boom which drove domestic demand to levels unseen before. The Kanjanapas family's decision was proved right later, when over 300,000 housing units were sold each year during 1990-1993. Yet, there were both real and artificial demands and all property companies including Bangkok Land realised that in late 1994. Then, not all buyers could be have completed units transferred to them, and that meant the developers could not receive the remainder of the sales price. It was normal for the highest downpayment to be just 25 per cent of the cost of a property. It was predictable what would happen: property developers would see their inventories rise and earnings shrink. Bangkok Land posted a net profit of only Bt661 million in the 1994 fiscal year ended March 1995, a sharp fall from Bt5.03 billion in the previous fiscal year, or an 87 per cent decline. Anant Kanjanapas, chief executive officer of the company, appeared at a press conference on May 6, 1995 and announced that his company would delay all development projects due to cashflow problems. The development delay was not the only thing depressing Anant, who is the key man of the family's business in Thailand. Bangkok Land was a very aggressive developer.In 1993, after most of its units launched were sold out, Bangkok Land was encouraged to forge a bigger plan. Anant announced the company would launch 10 projects in the same year requiring a total investment of around Bt10 billion or Bt1 billion for each project. Anant shocked other businessemen in the property development and other industries with an announcement that the company had fixed its advertising budget for the year at 3 per cent of total investment value. Though the percentage was not high, it still meant Bt300 million would be spent. It was an usually large amount, even for the likes of such industrial conglomerates as Siam Cement Plc. Land Houses Plc, today regarded as the strongest property developer, was at that time considered the second biggest developer to Bangkok Land, yet its advertising budget was less than Bt100 million. Colourful double-page spreads in newspapers were the norm for B-land. Billboards were also employed, but Bangkok Land spent more thriftly on television ads. Yet, the advertisements mainly brought pent-up demand, leading to a disaster for the company. In the 1996 fiscal year, though the company did not launch any new projects, its inventory rose from Bt23 billion in total value a year earlier to Bt24.4 billion. The figure climbed to Bt25 billion in 1997 as many sold units were not transferred to buyers. Bangkok Land is now in serious financial trouble. It has difficulty finding money to repay short-term loans which stood at Bt21 billion at the end of the 1997 fiscal year. Its situation looks bad with sales in the 1997 fiscal year amounting to only Bt3.17 billion compared with the cost of sales of Bt3.35 billion. Bangkok Land's affiliate Tanayong Plc is in no better position. Most of its 14 high-rise condominium buildings on Bangna-Trat Road remain unsold. The only funding source of the company comes from Bangkok Transit Service Plc, its subsidiary.Against the Kanjanapas family's ambition to become the biggest property developer in Thailand, its breathing space is being narrowed and the situation is not expected to improve in the foreseeable future.

BC-Germany-Train Derails, 11th Ld-Writethru
At least 70 dead in high-speed German train crash
URGENT Eds: COMBINES pvs By CLAUS-PETER TIEMANN Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ A high-speed passenger train derailed Wednesday in northern Germany after colliding with an automobile that had plunged off an overpass. At least 70 people were killed and 200 injured. The Hamburg-bound train collided with the auto at 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour as it approached the station in Eschede, 50 kilometers (35 miles) north of Hanover just before 11 a.m., officials said. The train was carrying about 300 passengers. The accident was the worst on Germany's premier high-speed ICE line, inaugurated in 1991, and the deadliest rail crash in western Germany since World War II. At least 13 cars derailed, piling into each other and crashing into the base of the overpass, collapsing it. The force of the pile-up pushed cars meters (yards) high into the air. Several of the rail cars were demolished, and splintered glass covered the scene. Luggage was piled next to the wreckage as workers struggled to pry passengers from the train. A crane was positioned to lift chunks of the bridge to reach buried rail cars. Officials said the auto had crashed through the guardrail of the bridge running over the train tracks. Although it remained unclear, evidence at the scene suggested that the car struck the train as it passed under the overpass. The nose of the train had cleared the bridge, while the cars behind derailed and jackknifed into each other. The German border patrol sent helicopters and 80 personnel to help emergency workers free passengers trapped inside the rail cars. Officials feared many inside were dead. The accident closed train traffic in both directions. Federal Transport Minister Matthias Wissmann, Lower Saxony state governor Gerhard Schroeder and German railway executives were en route to the scene. The ICE train is Germany'burg, covering a distance of more than 950 kilometers (about 600 miles), in 5 hours and 37 minutes. Regular train service takes more than eight hours. The high-speed trains carry more than 65,000 passengers daily. (cb-aet)
