BC-Iraq-Warheads, 1st Ld-Writethru
In protective gear, U.N. experts search for Iraqi missile warheads
Eds: UPDATES with Iraqi official's comments AP Photos planned By LEON BARKHO Associated Press Writer
Al-NIBAI, Iraq (AP) _ United Nations weapons inspectors searched through reeds and sand dunes Wednesday for missing missile parts in a bid to verify Iraq's claims that it has buried all its biological and chemical missile warheads. Wearing protective suits, masks, boots and gloves, some 27 experts under German Jean Jano used metal detectors and other equipment in their search at Al-Nibai, 45 kilometers (28 miles) north of Baghdad. Others supervised an earth-moving machine as it uncovered the nose cone of a missile warhead. ``This belongs to a conventional warhead,'' shouted an Iraqi engineer. In 1991, Iraq chose to destroy a great number of its long-range missiles and bury them rather than declare them to U.N inspectors, which has complicated the verification process. Iraq claims it has destroyed its entire arsenal, and that it is impossible to account for every warhead. The United Nations says it cannot take Iraq's word. ``We hope that this work will help to settle some of the still outstanding issues concerning the missile warheads,'' Jano, 61, told The Associated Press. It is the first time a Western news organization was allowed at a weapons search site. Jano refused to say how far his team has progressed in verifying Iraq's claims, or how many parts it has collected so far. But Brig. Ismael Saeed Ahmad, the Iraqi official who supervised the 1991 destruction and burial at al-Nibai, said U.N. monitors have so far recovered enough parts to account for 49 biological and chemical warheads. He did not say how many were buried. As for conventional warheads, only 10 remain unaccounted for, he told the AP later in Baghdad. The area where Iraq buried its missiles is vast. Experts with magnetic and electro-magnetic sensors placed small, red flags on the ground to mark the next dig. ``We've with us some of the latest state-of-the-art high-tech equipment,'' said Vincent Murphy, a 69-year-old geophysicist from Boston. ``It is all digitally recorded. The data is brought back in the recorder to one of the vehicles and downloaded to the laptop.'' Advanced equipment is needed because satellite images cannot penetrate the soil at al-Nibai, he said. Jano said inspectors found ``aluminum canisters that are used for chemical agents and some stainless steel canisters ... used for biological agents.'' The excavation is scheduled to end June 18. Jano said another team will arrive in Baghdad soon to analyze the findings, now stored at Taji, a military camp 20 kilometers (12 miles) north of Baghdad. Senior Iraqi officers looked on as the experts searched. The Iraqis refuse to wear safety gear, saying the pieces of scrap underground are non-toxic. U.N. monitors burn their suits every day, and wash their hands and feet in a bleach solution before leaving the site. Accounting for special warheads is one of the main hurdles in Iraq's efforts to declare itself clean of prohibited missiles with ranges beyond 150 kilometers (90 miles). Ahmed, the Iraqi brigadier, claimed all such missiles have now been accounted for. In addition, U.N. inspectors are believed to have accounted for 817 of the 819 Scud missiles in Iraq's arsenal. Until the inspectors certify that Iraq is rid of its weapons of mass destruction, the U.N. Security Council will not lift the sanctions slapped on Baghdad in 1990 after President Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait. lb/vj

BC-Pakistan-Nuclear-Backlash,0404
Radical Islamic group attacks anti-nuclear activists
AP Photo ISL101 By KATHY GANNON Associated Press Writer
ISLAMABAD, Pakistan (AP) _ A violent attack by 30 Muslim radicals threatening death to anti-nuclear activists outraged Pakistan's human rights groups, who issued a statement Wednesday demanding the government rein in an ``over-excited pro-bomb lobby''. On Tuesday, about 30 young men waving placards and carrying banners stormed into a room where the Pakistan-India People's Forum for Peace and Democracy _ a group pushing dialogue between the two uneasy neighbors _ was holding a news conference that ``strongly condemned'' last month's nuclear testing by Pakistan and India. Two people were hurt, including an organizer and a longtime peace activist and nuclear physicist, A.H. Nayyar. ``It was pre-planned . . . it wasn't random violence,'' said Sameena Ahmed, a defense analyst and forum member. ``Why use terror? it's an old tactic here ... to stop the process of dialogue and debate.'' ``It's not going to stop the debate ... it's not going to go underground,'' Ahmed said. Pakistan said it conducted five nuclear tests last Thursday and a sixth last Saturday _ one-upping India, which tested five devices three weeks ago. In both Pakistan and India, their respective testing was greeted with jubilation. A survey conducted by Gallup Pakistan immediately prior to the testing showed 70 percent of Pakistanis wanted their government to match India and test a device of its own. Most other countries have expressed dismay and threatened sanctions. Pakistan's right-wing religious groups denounced the West for its criticism burning U.S. as well as Indian flags. With the nuclear issue generating such strong emotions, the Human Rights Commission of Pakistan urged the government to protect freedom of expression. ``The fact that the people of Pakistan are worried about their future cannot be denied,'' said Asma Jehangir, a spokesperson for the Human Rights group. ``If there are fascist elements in society it is the responsibility of the government to keep an eye on them and not permit their crossing the limits.'' The leaders of the attack belonged to the militant wing of the Jamaat-e-Islami party, a small, powerful religious party that hardly gets 3 percent of the vote, but has significant street appeal.

Mitsubishi Motors to stop production of Jeeps in Japan
TOKYO (AP) _ Mitsubishi Motors Corp. said Wednesday that it will stop production of Jeep models 45 years after the commercial debut of the rugged four-wheel-drive vehicles in Japan. The Tokyo-based automaker will make its last Jeep in August, said a company spokesman, explaining the decision was made because the vehicles do not meet new environmental and safety standards. To commemorate the Jeep's 45th anniversary in Japan, Mitsubishi Motors plans to sell a total of 300 ``limited edition'' classic Jeep models, said the spokesman, who declined to be named. Mitsubishi has sold about 200,000 Jeeps in Japan _ mostly to the government _ since it was first granted a license to make them in 1953. The Jeep was originally developed for the U.S. military in 1940 by Willys-Overland and is now made in the United States by Chrysler Corp. Production of the first U.S. commercial Jeep began in 1946. BC-Trinidad-Amoco-Repsol,0312
Amoco, Repsol to build LNG plants
PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ Amoco's Trinidad subsidiary and Repsol of Spain have announced an alliance intended to triple liquified natural gas production in Trinidad. David Wight, president of Amoco Trinidad, said Tuesday that Atlantic LNG will build two new LNG plants by 2002, in addition to one under construction. Wight said the LNG expansion would involve an additional dlrs 3 billion in direct investment in what is already the largest single investment in the English-speaking Caribbean. Repsol will commit to purchase close to 5 million tons of LNG annually to supply its markets in Spain, while up to 25 percent of the increased production will be marketed in the United States, Brazil and the Caribbean. The deal, which must be approved by the government, gives Repsol the opportunity to purchase between 10 and 30 percent of Amoco's Trinidad assets and sets the stage for the companies to cooperate in Brazil's energy market. ``It's estimated that the (Trinidad) government could earn in the range of dlrs 6 billion over 20 years in taxes and royalty revenue'' as a result of the deal, Wight said. Repsol, through its Enagas subsidiary, had previously agreed to take 40 percent of production from a 3 million-ton per year LNG plant under construction. The other 60 percent will go to Cabot LNG's markets in New England. Cabot is a 10 percent stakeholder in Atlantic LNG. Amoco and Repsol hold 34 percent and 20 percent, respectively, of the first plant, which begins production next year. They are also partners in two hydrocarbon blocks off Trinidad's east and south coasts. As part of the alliance, Amoco will allow Repsol to purchase 10 percent of its production assets in Trinidad for an undisclosed sum.

IF you thought Sabah are a spent force in Malaysian soccer, you'd better think again. Despite a slow start, no thanks to the row between Sabah FA and the Sabah Sports Council, the Premier One team seem to have shaken off their problems and are making headway again. Under the guidance of Ken Shellito, Sabah may not be true Premier One contenders but they cannot be discounted in the race for the Malaysia Cup and FA Cup. Underestimating them would be a big mistake. When asked about their resurgence, Shellito said he is extremely happy with the way his side have been shaping up over the last two months. However, he said Sabah prefer to keep their darkhorse tag this season. ``No one gave us a chance because everyone was preoccupied with what happened off the field. But we are coming along nicely and we are out to play more consistently,'' said Shellito, after watching his side edge Selangor 1-0 at Shah Alam Stadium last Saturday. The problem for Shellito now is finding a potent striker with regular Suharmin Yusuf struggling. Suharmin has been shooting blanks. Sabah are second only to Olympic 2000 in having the worst scoring records in the League, finding the net 10 times in 11 matches. Olympic 2000 have scored only nine. David Rocastle remains Sabah's topscorer and that is only three to his credit. And the the former England international is not even a specialist striker. ``We are doing all right but there is always room for improvement. This win over Selangor was good. It will help us play better and set us in a good position as we will have more home matches in the second round,'' said Shellito. Shellito admits he is keen to continue his good run against his former side. ``I have to admit beating Selangor at home is never easy. However, I have a great record against them and that really cheers me up.''

US-BASED Amway (Thailand) Ltd, one of the world's major direct selling firms, is negotiating with an unidentified international bank to form a strategic partnership to enter Thailand's mortgage financing and leasing market, the first Asian market in the US firm's plan for diversification into financial services. Amway, which controls 140,000 sales representatives in Thailand, --one of the country's largest sales forces -- started financial services for home and automobiles in the US market and later expanded these services to Australia. Expansion into financial services is also planned for other Asian markets, including Japan, Taiwan and Hong Kong. Amway (Thailand) general manager Preecha Prakobkit said the company expects to sign a partnership contract with the foreign bank within the next two months pending a final round of negotiations. The partnership is to offer mortgages and leasing loans to Amway's customers and sales representatives. Sales agents will receive commissions and other incentives related to other Amway products. Amway's strength is its vast marketing and distribution network with more than 140,000 active sales representatives, according to Preecha, while the partnership bank will be responsible for providing consumer loans and other financial services. In the first stage, the company plans to launch a payment service using credit cards for its sales people by the end of this year in partnership with the bank. The payment system aims at providing convenience to Amway's sales representatives when paying for the goods sold. Cards will also be offered to buyers of Amway products and used in sales promotion campaigns. Campaigns similar to the Smart Loyalty programme currently involving major retailers and service stations, including the Central/Robinson and Shell groups, and banks are being considered by Amway whose products range from personal care and food to household items and apparel. Besides housing loans, items that can be purchased against leasing and instalment payments include cars, furniture, decorative items for the home, and jewellery, Preecha said. Amway has been providing mortgage and leasing services for homes and other items in the US and Australia. In Japan, Taiwan and Hong Kong, the firm has started with a credit card payment system. In the US, leasing and instalment services are provided to customers through Amway's direct-selling network. This way, it allows independent manufacturers, including carmakers, to expand their distribution channel using Amway's network as well as financial services. In Thailand, Preecha said the company plans to launch a 'plus-point' card promotion campaign to its sales representatives, who will collect points when selling Amway products in exchange with incentives and rewards. He added the company aims to provide credit cards to more than 1,000 sales representatives this year. Because of higher import costs, Amway (Thailand) Ltd plans to increase the ratio of locally-sourced products from 15 per cent to more than 30 per cent over the next five years. The company plans to provide direct-selling distribution and financial services to independent manufacturers seeking to distribute their products locally, said Preecha. The economic crisis and lower spending power of consumers has hit the direct-selling business. Preecha, who is secretary-general of Thailand Direct Selling Association, said zero growth is projected for the whole industry this year compared with 1997's Bt20 billion in total sales. Amway's 1997 sales were Bt4.8 billion. Since the July 2 baht devaluation, spending through direct-selling have dropped by 50 per cent.

ADDRESSING someone as ``old fruit'' is actually rather old hat or out-of-date these days, and it might conjure up a picture of an over-ripe banana or a dodgy durian. It was once an upper-class familiar greeting or slang form of address for a friend, though why I am not at all sure. However, I am interested in old fruit in a different sense this week, as frequently, I am about to pluck the fruits of knowledge from assorted reference books as well as the fruits of my own experiences when teaching, talking and travelling. So, since I come from the United Kingdom, let's start in London, and let's start with a few small steps, otherwise known as ``the apples and pears''. What does an orchard have to do with steps, large or small, or indeed with the city of London, you may ask? Well, naturally, steps would be a help if you are harvesting the fruit, since a step-ladder is necessary for tall trees, unless you are harvesting coconuts and you have a handy beruk. London is a bit more of a problem, and you may think that I am a trifled confused, or even as nutty as a fruit cake (a wonderful slang phrase for ``crazy''), since it is New York which is colloquially known as ``the Big Apple''. London, I regret to say, was known in earlier times as ``the Great Wen'', nothing to do with fruit unless it's an allergic reaction, as a ``wen'' is a wart or swelling on the skin. Yes, as usual, I am monkeying about with English. In fact, ``apples-and- pears'' is another example of a slang phrase, but it's a special kind, known as Cockney rhyming slang. ``Apples-and-pears'' rhymes with ``stairs'' and that's exactly what the apples-and-pears are; if you want to know what Cockneys are, they are folk born in a certain area of London, traditionally within earshot of the sound of the bells of Bow church, so that's the London connection. What on earth is a ``cockney'' when it's at home? Originally, it was a ``cocken-ey'' or a cockerel's egg, a name given to any strangely shaped or tiny hen's egg. Then it came to be used for a spoilt child, and finally it came to describe someone who lived in a big town, perhaps because city people were considered to be spoilt compared with those from the country. Indeed, to get back to the subject of fruit, it would seem that at one point in history a cockney would also be ``the apple of one's eye'', since a spoilt child is usually the darling of parents or grandparents, and the apple of your eye is a description for the thing you adore most. Apples could perhaps be called the archetypal British fruit, especially where I come from, since Worcester and Hereford (until recently a couple of English counties united by what's colloquially known as a ``shot-gun wedding'' since not everyone wanted to unite, and now once again are two separate areas) are noted for their orchards. As a result, there are plenty of phrases about apples in the English language, and when new fruits and veggies were introduced, people tended to look at them as some strange kind of apple. Take tomatoes, for instance, and I will take as many as possible, since I am addicted to them in all shapes and forms and am liable to consume tomatoes for breakfast, dinner and supper. The word tomato is of Mexican origin, probably coming into Europe through Spanish, but one of the first names for these delicious red fruits was the ``love apple''. I was somewhat taken aback to find, when I listened to a cassette of a book on 19th-century English village life, that in the 1890s none of the village children had tasted a tomato - to me they are a fact of life in both the UK and Malaysia. Going much further back in time, the potato (also through Spanish and originally batata, from the South American language Taino) was labelled the ``earth apple'' when it first appeared in England in the 16th century. To move to a more Malaysian scene, the pineapple is yet another example, though in this case, the cones of pine-trees were the original pineapples, and it was the tapering shape and the hard knobs of outer skin that gave the tropical fruit a resemblance to the cone. More dangerously, a ``pineapple'' is a nickname for a hand-grenade, once again because of the resemblance in shape. Apple puree or apple snow is a traditional English recipe for cooked apples, but please don't make too much of a puree of the spelling, or you will end up with ``appals'', and of course bad spelling appals many people. The verb ``to appal'' has little to do with fruit, and everything to do with going pale, often because you are disgusted or terrified. Making a hash of the pronunciation is not quite such a disaster; students have often asked me if they should pronounce it ``ah-pl'' or ``ep-pl'', but there's really no problem with either of these. In standard British English the ``a'' tends to come out as ``ah'', whereas in traditional Received Pronunciation (as spoken by the Queen of England) it is closer to ``ep'', and in standard American English it is more likely to be a longer version of ``ep''. Now let's go bananas. Unfortunately, I haven't yet discovered when they invaded Europe, but I am glad they did, as when I was a child it turned out to be one of the only things I felt like eating after childhood illnesses. Bananas are, of course, natives of Southeast Asia and will only grow in tropical climates; interestingly, the name comes from a place in Guinea in Africa, and has come into English through either Spanish or Portuguese. An irrelevant but fascinating pair of facts which I can't resist: while potatoes are about 75 per cent carbohydrates, bananas are roughly 75 per cent water. Pair, did I say? No, no, I meant pear, not to be confused with ``pare''. As you can see, when it comes to pears, there is a trio of homophones to be picked and sorted. A pair is two of a kind, and must be regarded as singular rather than plural, as in ``there was a pair of scissors on the table'' as opposed to ``the scissors were on the table''. One scissor cuts no ice, to coin a phrase, since you need both halves of the metal to come together before you can cut, clip, chop, or snip. As for ``pare'', well, it does have some associations with fruit. It means ``to trim small pieces'' or ``to shave'' and you can use it for vegetables as well as fruit when you carefully cut off the outside skin or cut it into slices. However, if we are talking about desserts (not just ones, but sweet ones), then there is some distinction between the fruit and the cheese when it comes to paring. If you pare an apple, then there is no strong significance, though you could try peeling the skin off in one long curl and then throwing it over your shoulder - the letter formed by the skin is traditionally supposed to be the first letter of your future spouse's name. If you are cheese- paring, though, then the only word for you is stingy. I suppose it means that you cut the cheese as close to the rind as possible in order to get the most out of your piece of Cheddar. A fruitless exercise, I should add, if you are eating soft cheese, since it has no rind - hard cheese, in fact. You can reach Susanna on e-mail for queries or comments at suchec pkrisc.cc.ukm.my

PRO-democracy legislators plan another attempt at having racial discrimination legislation included in equal opportunity laws. An effort to outlaw discrimination based on race, age and sexual orientation was defeated in the final days of the pre-handover Legislative Council. THE government will hold a urgent meeting Wednesday to solve the problem of illiquidity in the sugar and sugarcane industry, Deputy Prime Minister Suwit Khunkitti said. Suwit said he will chair the meeting with the concerned agencies in an effort to solve the problem within this month. Representatives from the Federation of Sugarcane Planters Tuesday filed a petition with Suwit, urging the government to tackle illiquidity and other problems affecting the industry, such as low prices of cane and sugar and theburden of value-added tax. Despite a lack of liquidity in the commercial banking system, Suwit said he will try to secure financial support for cane growers before the next harvest. A fall in production would have an adverse impact on exports, he added. Sugar is one of Thailand's top ten export earners. Telling cane planters that the price for the 1997-98 season could fall below Bt785 a tonne, Suwit said the government would find ways to help sugar factories reduce operating costs. Under the 70:30 benefit-sharing scheme, implemented almost 20 years ago, the sugar and cane sectors share their losses and gains. The Finance Ministry will be consulted on the VAT issue, Suwit said. Cane planters earlier called off a rally to push for an increase in the domestic sugar price after the Ministry of Commerce promised that the final price for cane would be more than Bt785 a tonne. However, the drop in international sugar prices since March to US$220 a tonne from $268 a tonne threaten the target price for the Thai market. Furthermore, the drought-hit industry has seen a plunge in cane production by one-fourth to 42 million tonnes from an earlier projection. Officials from the Industry Ministry earlier told The Nation that the industry is expected to ask for Bt10 billion as additional liquidity. ''Unless the problem can be solved in time, cane output for the 1998 season are likely to fall by 50 per cent from an earlier target of 40 million tonnes'', the official said. Among the financial institutions mentioned by the official as potential lenders to the industry are Rabo Bank, ABN Amro, Bank of Thailand, and the Government Saving Bank. Earlier, Reuters quoted shipping sources as saying that Thailand's sugar exports during the first quarter of 1998 dropped by 46 per cent to 891,846 tonnes compared with 1.67 million tonnes during the same period last year. The biggest buyer in the first quarter was Indonesia which bought 538,850 tonnes of white and refined sugar from Thailand.

JAKARTA (JP): The legal sector is trailing behind other sectors. Historically, from colonial times, the law in political life has always been employed as an instrument of devide et impera (divide and rule) and repression, while in the economic realm, the law often plays its role as an instrument benefiting businesspeople and capitalists. So the law obviously has not optimally contributed to democracy and social justice, especially considering that court jurisprudence is not always properly treated as a legal source. At this juncture, the law is not only void of neutrality, but it even takes sides with the ruling elite and businesspeople. The role of the law has not changed much since our independence in 1945, particularly because the existing legal instruments are the legacy of colonial laws. It is worthy of note, however, that many legal products in the era of independence, including those produced during the Soeharto administration, continue the colonial legal policies translated into idolization of stability, security and order, and economic growth. The oft-intimated policy of even distribution of income has turned out to be more of a political statement (wishful thinking). It is very difficult for a legal policy like this to be on the side of democracy and social justice. The resulting legal products, consequently, have shackled our civil and political rights, as we have all experienced with the enforcement of the law during general elections, the law on political parties and the functional group, the law on the structure of the People's Consultative Assembly (MPR), the House of People's Representatives (DPR) and the regional legislative assembly (DPRD), the law on mass organizations, the law on referendum and the law on principles of the press. In the economic sector, our legal products, some of which do take into account the interests of the common people, generally side with businesspeople and capitalist, such as the law on foreign investment, the law on domestic investment and the law on the capital market. Please note that deregulatory packages have also turned into legal products which, despite their legal validity, raise doubt in that they are enforceable as instruments benefiting businesspeople and capitalists. In this context, our compliance with the legal products of the World Trade Organization has made it difficult to protect the interests of small and medium-scale businesspeople and consumers. Unfortunately, the internationalization of the laws in the economic realm, which apply the principles of nondiscrimination and national treatment, will eventually make this country a mere pocket of the latest form of economic colonization. The judiciary is the most important part in the legal sector. It is no longer a public secret that our judicial institutions and judges are known to be not only restricted in their freedom and self-reliance, but are also infected by corruption, collusion and nepotism. Unless reform is carried out in the judicial institutions and in the corps of judges of all levels, legal reform will become stuck. In this context, legal products such as the law on the principle of judicial power, the law on general judiciary and the law on the Supreme Court need immediate revision and/or replacement. The main challenge is to make a judicial institution one that translates the law in all fairness and impartiality in our social life. Especially in respect to the Supreme Court, the expansion of the right to exercise judicial review of a law is absolutely necessary if we wish to see legal control over legal products of the government and the DPR, which may well violate the constitutional principles such as democracy, human rights and social justice. It is no exaggeration to conclude, then, that the right to judiciary review indicates acknowledgement of the supremacy of the law in a law-based state. Therefore, naming legislative review as the most appropriate instrument for Indonesia in this context is tantamount to subordinating the supremacy of the law to dominant political interests. The demand for legal reform is a historical necessity. The most urgent legal reform agenda in restoring civil and political rights is the revocation of repressive legal products (the Subversion Law, hatzaai artikelen, and so forth), the revision of nonfacilitating legal products (the law on general elections, the law on political parties and the functional group, the law on the structure and the position of the MPR, the DPR and the DPRD, the law on mass organizations, the law on principles of the press). Also, the issuance of reform-supporting new legal products (a law on public information and others) are equally urgent. In the economic realm, it is of great urgency to issue legal products which may better protect small and medium-scale businesspeople and consumers, such as the antimonopoly law, the law on consumer protection, and so forth). The above mentioned total legal reform would eventually lead us to political and economic reforms. The goals of our nationhood and statehood, underlined with a longing for democracy and social justice, can be reached when legal reform measures are taken in a planned, speedy and sustainable manner. The writer is a member of the Working Group of the Forum for Democracy. TOKYO (JP): Choreography and orchestration ofU.S. President Bill Clinton's upcoming trip to China and Hong Kong this month has exceeded the hopes of the Propaganda Department of the Chinese Communist Party. Indeed, their success reminds me of the slogan printed on the little slip of paper inside a fortune cookie I was served at a San Francisco Chinatown restaurant last summer: ``There can be no harm in asking.'' The Chinese have asked for -- and received approval for -- these points on the President Clinton June itinerary: Overfly No. 1 Asian-ally Japan to and from Beijing, citing that President Jiang Zemin made no extra stops during his visit last year; it would be a loss of face to Jiang if Clinton visited Japan enroute or on the way back (The White House has reacted to mounting criticism of this snub by inviting Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto to Washington in July). Visit Tiananmen Square, to indicate U.S. acceptance that the book is closed on the June 4, 1989 bloodbath crackdown on pro-democracy students which I witnessed there. No amount of propaganda or whitewash enacted by any president will dilute that from my memory; Visit Hong Kong around the July 1 first-year anniversary of the handover from Britain to China where Clinton will give his seal of approval that Hong Kong is free (even the Wall Street Journal and Heritage Foundation claim so in their annual Report on Economic Freedom), that the peg of the Hong Kong dollar to the U.S. dollar and unchanged rate of the Chinese renminbi currency are providing stability and that generally (''Are you listening, Taiwan?'')the ``one country, two systems ``formula is highly workable. Behind the scenes, however, Hong Kong is having some problems with its own economy and there is subtle erosion of its free press. A blip in the Hong Kong visit is that U.S. officials have told Martin Lee, leader of opposition forces in Hong Kong that won 60 percent of the popular vote in an election last week, that Clinton has no plansto meet with him privately during his stopover. State Department officials suggested insteadthat Clinton meet with Lee along with leaders of other political parties in Hong Kong, including several pro-Beijing parties, which won some seats in the voting. Lee's office opposes the plan because it implies that Lee is on equal footing with the pro-Beijing groups, some of which did not participate in the directly-elected segment of the ballot. A State Department officials told Lee on May 15, according to the Washington Post's John Pomfret quoting sources close to Lee (that's journalese for Lee himself), that Clinton would not meet with him alone or with otherdemocratic activists because he is worried about offending China. Talk about self-censorship. What is the U.S. promoting, democracy or communism? Clinton met alone with Lee in April 1997 for half an hour at the White House. ``It is very different to see someone in the U.S. as opposed to in their own country,'' the aide to Lee quoted a State Department official as saying. The source added that on May 11, U.S. Consul General in Hong Kong Richard Boucher proposed that Clinton meet Lee in a group. But Lee received 143,843 votes and he pointed out that Hong Kong's appointed leader Tung Chee-hwa has never stood for a genuine election. I can understand why Clinton might shy away from an individual meeting with Lee, on public relations grounds. The feisty activist takes no prisoners inone-on-one meetings and would be likely to giveClinton an earful. I was scolded by Lee once for being 20 minutes late--actually I was 10 minutesearly--for a meeting whose start time was botched by respective secretaries. Lee said he was a ``busy man'' and I believe it. Criticism of arrangements of Clinton's visit come againsta backdrop of allegations that the U.S. supplied sensitive missile technology and that political funds were funneled through the daughter of a high ranking Chinese military official. Some members of Congress have demanded that the trip be canceled. The president has mixed those demands and on May 27 it was reported that Clinton had used a newly established hotline to inform President Jiang that he was coming to Chinadespite the congressional criticism. It was the first use of the hotline on the U.S. side. Washington has signaled that there will be ``no change'' in its Taiwan policybut Clinton is likely to give some verbal stroking to China on the issue although nothing new in writing, despite Beijing's hopes. The only other thingthe State Department didn't go along with---to that establishment'severlasting credit---was the devious Chinese request that Clinton visitthe city of Nanking, scene of''The Rape of Nanking'' by Japanese troops in December of 1937. A book by that title written by Iris Chang has been the center of controversy and on the bestseller lists in the U.S in recent weeks. Beijing pointed out that President Jiang stopped at Pearl Harbor (at China's request) en route to the U.S. lastyear to underscore who the U.S. enemy in Asiareally is. A Nanking visit would have played in the U.S. as China being the true friend of the U.S against Japan. The State Department was not amused and declined. China was hoping to gain some hardball advantage going into the September visit of President Jiang to Tokyo. On May 28 the American Embassy in Japan issued a statement clarifying words attributed to Ambassador Thomas Foley by Jiji Press. The Japanese press had headlined.''U.S. to Switch to Alliance with China.'' What Foley had said was ``but as much as our individual relations are improving with China, no one should have any doubt that the 21st century, as (well as) the latter part of this century, will be marked by a strong, fundamental U.S.-Japan partnership and alliance in the Asia-Pacific region. It has maintained peace and security and encouraged prosperity for 45 years and I believe that it will continue to expand in the 21st century, and remain a great bulwark for prosperity and security in the next century.'' After weeks of treatment from the U.S. bordering on rudeness from Clinton on down, the words were a welcome reassurance to Tokyo government and business leaders as well as to the salaryman hoisting a beer in a Ginza pub after work. VOLATILE interest rates have prompted banks to adopt a wait-and-see attitude towards the newly launched Hong Kong dollar repurchase (repo) facility, bankers said yesterday. The new facility has drawn numerous inquiries from banks following its launch last Friday as a tool to ease tight liquidity in the financial market. Bankers said that no transaction has been completed yet despite the initial strong response that the facility has drawn from scores of banks. The cool response of banks is a good indication that the problem of tight liquidity would continue for a while despite calls by developers and other corporates for government to tackle this issue, they said. Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) acting chief executive David Carse, however, said that it might take about two to three months before the impact of the new facility would be felt. ``These things obviously take time to build up. But over the next two to three months, we'll see its effect in terms of easing tight liquidity in the market,'' Mr Carse said. Bankers attributed the wait-and-see attitude of banks partly to the sharp rise in Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rates (Hibor) yesterday. Interest rates of the Hong Kong dollar repurchase facility are pegged to Hibor. The benchmark three-month Hibor shot up yesterday to 9.01339 per cent compared to its previous level of 8.05804 per cent on Monday. Bankers attributed yesterday's sharp rise in Hibor to concerns over the deterioration of the local economy and fears that weakness in the Japanese yen will lead to another round of competitive currency depreciations in the region. Six banks were making quotations for Hong Kong-dollar paper _ HongkongBank, Standard Chartered, Bank of China, Hang Seng Bank, Dao Heng Bank and Bank of East Asia. HSBC Markets _ the treasury arm of HongkongBank _ was quoting 8-8.2 per cent for 3-month Hong Kong-dollar debt papers and 8-8.3 per cent for six-month Hong Kong-dollar debt paper for amounts of $100 million, said Jack Cheung of HSBC Markets. Dao Heng Bank was offering quotes of 20 basis points above three-month Hibor and 30 basis points above six-month Hibor, said Tam Ping-shing, general manager for treasury of Dao Heng Bank. Mr Tam declined to disclose the volume which Dao Heng Bank was quoting on the Hong Kong-dollar debt papers. Fuji International Finance Hong Kong assistant director Adolf Cheung yesterday said it would take about three months before the effects of the new repurchase facility would be felt.

By March 1, the doors of banks in 17 of the 48 states had been closed because the banks could not pay their depositors. The government did not have enough money to meet its March 15 payroll obligations. The largest private savings bank in the world in the nation's largest city was in danger of failing. The government estimated that 15 million men, most of them heads of households, were unemployed, and that one-fourth of the population had no income whatever, and instead survived by borrowing, begging, or in some cases stealing. The economic, banking and social crises threatening the country were terrifying. This was the Great Depression, and the United States seemed on the brink of ruin. It was in this context of national despair that Franklin Roosevelt was sworn in as 32nd president of the United States on March 4, 1933. President Roosevelt's government had taken a number of resolute acts but they did not end the Depression. Meanwhile, they broke its stranglehold on America by restoring people's faith that the government would act to cure the economic and social ills of the preceding years. Indonesia is not the United States; Indonesia's problems are different from those that faced the United States during the Depression, and the solution will be different. But there are similarities worth remembering in the conditions faced by the two countries 65 years apart. In 1933, the U.S. was on the verge of financial collapse, as Indonesia now is; some of the causes of the American Depression were also linked to corruption. Like the U.S., Indonesia is a resource-rich country that holds the seeds of its own resurgence. Though reform was needed, Americans in 1932 elected as president a man known more for his elitist, conservative background than for his reputation as a reformer, just as Indonesians today have accepted President B.J. Habibie, who has not been known as naturally reform-oriented. Let President Habibie present his hundred-day agenda to the House of Representatives as soon as possible but no later than the end of June; let other presidential candidates do the same. If there is to be a special session of the People's Consultative Assembly (MPR), let it happen not in six months, but in June. Indonesia has already lost seven months of recovery time and can ill afford the luxury of a transition-caretaker president for six months or a year longer while waiting for the perfect reform president to emerge. The threat of recurring change at the helm of the government would not inspire international confidence in the country or its currency. So let President Habibie and his challengers announce promptly their reform proposals. Then let the MPR act promptly to give the presidential and vice presidential mandates to that candidate, either President Habibie or someone else, who presents the most credible proposals for reform and recovery. A nation's ills will not be cured in the first hundred days of a presidential term, nor in the first thousand days, nor in a single generation, as President John Kennedy cautioned. The cure may not be instantaneous but the rescue needs to begin immediately.

PRIME Minister Chuan Leekpai will suspend foreign trips for three months so that he has time to meet local people, Foreign Ministry spokesman Kobsak Chutikul said Tuesday. Chuan has already cancelled a planned trip to Hong Kong where he was to deliver a speech at the 50th anniversary celebrations of the Hong Kong-based Far Eastern Economic Review magazine on June 10 and 11. The prime minister has also cancelled a trip to Manila where he was to participate in centenary celebrations marking the independence of the Philippines scheduled for June 12 and 13. Initially, the premier planned to travel from Hong Kong to Manila, Kobsak said. ''The premier has said that he will not travel overseas for three months so that he can make time to meet people in the provinces. The Chuan government has been criticised for not focusing its attention on the poor, therefore the prime minister will spend more time with them,'' Kobsak said. Thailand is facing economic difficulties which are expected to get worse in the coming months, so Chuan will be in town to take care of matters, the spokesman said. Surin to meet envoys FOREIGN Minister Surin Pitsuwan will separately meet the ambassadors of India and Pakistan on Friday to express Thailand's deep concern at the recent nuclear tests, Foreign Ministry deputy spokesman Karun Ruchuyothin said Tuesday. Karun said Surin will inform the ambassadors that the nuclear tests have badly affected security in South Asia as well as the security of the world community. The Foreign Ministry said earlier that Surin is expected to urge India and Pakistan to sign the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty as soon as possible. Crisis hits fashion-conscious BANGKOK'S women office workers have become less fashion-conscious as a result of the economic crunch and some even said their wardrobes have been swollen with recycled dresses, according to a study released Tuesday. The study was conducted on 391 women across occupations and professions. Of those surveyed, 52.2 per cent said they preferred tailored dresses while 45.6 per cent said they used ready-to-wear apparel available at department stores. A mere 2.6 per cent said they felt fine in hand-me-downs, the Thai Farmers Bank research centre survey said. Changed sartorial tastes included: 35.2 per cent said they have stopped having new dresses tailored or buying new dresses, and 33 per cent said they have fewer new dresses tailored and buy fewer new dresses. An undisclosed percentage said they had their office clothing refitted so it can be used again. Tyres blamed for break downs AN average of one car overturns in an accident every day on Bangkok's expressway, an official said Tuesday. Police warned motorists to make sure their tyres are in good condition before driving on the expressway as a number of cars break down on the expressway because of worn out tyres. Somsak Sribunrueng, an expressway traffic controller, said that of the 40 to 50 cars that break down every day, many have over- or under-inflated tyres. Many accidents occur because motorists' drive too fast and their worn out tyres explode. A man was seriously injured Tuesday after the tyre of his car exploded causing the speeding vehicle to overturn on the expressway at the Artnarong exit. The accident resulted in traffic grinding to a halt for over an hour with a tail-back as far as Bang Na-Trad Km 5.

AS the time to save endangered species gets shorter and shorter, a unique project at the Khao Khiew Open Zoo is offering a small ray of hope. Manote Tripathi reports on the use of advanced technology to save the Kingdom's precious fauna. PLACING endangered species in a freezer may sound a little brutal, but Sumate Kamolnorranath is perfectly happy seeing them stiffen at a deadly minus 196 degrees centigrade. There's nothing insane or cruel about this; quite the reverse actually. For what Sumate is doing is using the latest technique in keeping other species from going the same way as the dinosaurs. In fact, Sumate is not into herding living animals into freezing temperatures at all -- just their sperm. The intention? Preservation. The purpose? Creation. A semen bank, or ''genome resource bank''for endangered species is gradually taking shape at the Khao Khiew Open Zoo in Chonburi, which Sumate estimates is the biggest sperm storage centre in Thailand. Eventually, semen from a variety of animal species will be kept here in thousands of test tubes, which are being temporarily stored in freezers at the Dusit Zoo while construction of sperm bank facilities are underway. The conservation of endangered animals in semen banks was established worldwide in 1992, a fact better known abroad than at home at the time. The semen bank in Chonburi currently receives financial, technological and personnel assistance from the Smithsonian Institution in Washington DC. It's ultimate goal is to ensure the continuation of near-extinct species in Thailand, which include the krathing (gaur), wua daeng (red cow), tiger, maew pah (jungle-cat), lamang (brown-antlered deer), keng (barking deer), nok kra rian (flamingo), nok nguak (hornbill), and mah nai (Cuon javanicus). The flamingo, the brown-antlered deer, and the jungle cat can no longer be seen in the jungles of Thailand -- although they can be found in neighbouring countries like Laos -- and may only be seen in zoos such as Khao Khiew. Meanwhile, there are only 1000 gaurs, 500-600 tigers and 500 red cows left in the wild. ''In reality, every species in Thailand is in danger of extinction right now,'' says Sumate, the chief curator at Khao Khiew Open ZooSperm can be stored indefinately at a stable temperature, and although a minority die in the freezing process, there remain enough for either test tube breeding or in the womb of a host animal. However, the preservation of semen in test tubes needs proper care and hydrogen liquid is supplied at regular intervals to stabilise the temperature in the freezer. As natural breeding is difficult with some species because the mating season is too slow, artificial insemination is used and placing the semen in the ovary is a delicate job. The process involves the insertion of a long wire mounted with a small digital camera [which transmits the proceedings onto a computer screen] into the abdomen of the animal to ensure the injection of semen is correctly positioned at the ovary. ''Brown-antlered deer only produce one baby a year,'' says Samate, ''so we use a technique to stimulate an ovary to produce as many as 10 eggs at a time. Then, in the course of a year, we might have 10 of these deer artificially inseminated,'' Sumate explains. Wanchai Tunwattana, a staff member at the sperm bank, was concerned whether the offspring of endangered species will be able to survive after being returned to their natural habitat. ''We need to do more research to discover whether the offspring are capable of taking care of themselves, and also take into account the threats from humans -- especially the hunters,'' says Wanchai. He added that it was crucial to both select the right habitat and educate villagers about the ecological importance of the wildlife to prevent further hunting. ''It's bad enough with the human threat,''added Sumate, ''because Thailand, unlike Africa, lacks proper measures in managing the use of pasture and jungle. Sometimes, villages encroach onto the fringes of jungles, and when animals appear, villagers either scare them away or kill them -- despite the fact that their farm lands have spread into the wildlife habitat. ''Sometimes wildlife conservationists feel disheartened,'' he continued, ''I overheard some people saying that if we want to stop villagers from hunting, we should buy the villagers pork or other food. That really hurt us,'' laments Sumate. Sumate is also saddened by the fact that wildlife numbers are dwindling so fast his sperm bank project can't keep up. ''We have to speed up our conservation process. Although the Forestry Department is responsible for the protection of the jungles, there's just not enough being done. Yet wildlife numbers continue to decrease. Presently, we have very few tigers left and if they disappear, I can say that we would then have a real crisis on our hands, because it would mean the deers would have gone too -- as their food sources are the same,'' he says. ''Yes, I'm pessimistic --because of the truth.'' Is cloning a possibility? ''I've been thinking about that. But with the current funding and technology we have, cloning wildlife is years away. We simply don't have the potential yet.'' However, the zoo has already successfully cross-bred gaurs, tigers, and brown-antlered deer. Breeding animals, notes Samate, is less complicated than breeding birds -- which is costly and yields uncertain results. As an example, Phetch, (a gaur) was taken from the jungle in Ranong province when he was small and chosen for a breeding programme, as gaurs are considered superior to domestic cows in terms of immunity system, physical structure, and size. Now five-years-old, Phetch stands at nearly two metres tall and the zoo has attempted cross-breeding him with domestic cows to boost immunity in the weaker ones who invariably sustain feet infections during the rainy season. ''We can only crossbreed Phetch with cows at the moment because we still can't find Phetch a female gaur. To do so, we have to seek permission from the Forestry Department. You know what it's like with bureaucracy. All you can do is wait.'' But waiting involves time: And time is something our endangered species simply don't have.

The government's decision to release Dr. Muchtar Pakpahan and Dr. Sri Bintang Pamungkas from prison has made me both happy and sad. I am happy because it suggests that Habibie's administration is committed to total reform within the bounds of the constitution. However, one gets the impression that this good-will gesture is discriminatory. Muchtar Pakpahan is known to have leftist leanings and received great attention from the government before he was set free. In the meantime, Moslem political convicts have not received any attention, let alone been given priority for parole, despite many having been imprisoned for large parts of their lives. Community members, including those who claim to be pro-democracy and pro-reform, have enthusiastically welcomed the release of Pakpahan and Sri Bintang and treated them to the kind of reception reserved for heroes. The mass media has also been swept up in the euphoria. Let me suggest to both Muchtar Pakpahan and Sri Bintang that you don't get carried away with all this attention and begin to act like late, and therefore uncalled for, heroes. To the best of my knowledge, while in prison, these two ``figures'' (particularly Sri Bintang) spent a lot of time crying because they couldn't bear their cell conditions, which were worse than their own bathrooms. As for the mass media, it has a responsibility to report news in a balanced manner and not make a coconut tree out of a bean sprout. I also wish to call on the government not to assume a discriminatory stance. Moslem political convicts are subject to much more flagrant human rights violations than Muchtar Pakpahan and Sri Bintang ever were. The torture and suffering inflicted on Moslem political convicts has also been worse than that experienced by the kidnapped political activists, including Pius, Desmond, Heryanto Taslam, Nuku Sulaiman. Furthermore, for a large stretch of their captivity the National Commission on Human Rights did not exist. Even after the commission was established, inadequate attention was given to Moslem political convicts. The ever-so-respectable members of the National Commission on Human Rights are in fact a bunch of cowards. They do not defend human rights in earnest. They know that the ``movements'' which Moslem political convicts were imprisoned for their links to were invented by the state security apparatus, particularly during the times when Ali Moertopo, Sudomo, Benny Moerdani and Try Sutrisno were in office. The government should unconditionally release these Moslem political convicts and cease to force those already granted parole to report regularly to the authorities as is the current practice. Unless this is done, the deep feeling of injustice will persist, and this, obviously, will incur the wrath of Moslems. As a former political convict, I believe that now is the right time to square accounts with the underlings of the New Order regime because they have done many cruel things to Moslems in the course of their dirty political practices. However, the door of repentance is still open to you. But we need proof.

Ukrainian customs officials arrested on drugs charges
KIEV, Ukraine (AP) _ Two Ukrainian customs officials were arrested for stealing and trying to sell 2 kilograms (4.4 pounds) of hashish confiscated near the border, a newspaper reported Wednesday. The two stole the hashish Jan. 19 from a shipment detained in the Uzhhorod region near Ukraine's border with Slovakia and Hungary, the regional Interior Ministry department said, according to Kievskiye Vedomosti. The drugs, destined for the Czech capital, Prague, were concealed in a Czech truck under parquet wood for floors, the ministry said. The hashish was marked as glue for the parquetry, it said. The two customs officials and an accomplice planned to sell the hashish for dlrs 25,000, the newspaper said. The ministry said a large amount of foreign currency and three cars were confiscated from the three, whose names were not released. Western Ukraine has become a drug transit route. In January, police in Uzhhorod arrested a gang of smugglers who transported heroin from Central Asia to Western Europe, Kievskiye Vedomosti said. (sms/ls)

SHELL Malaysia has introduced another value-added service with the launch of an indent card system for government vehicles. Called ``SuperKad'', this ``swipe, fill and go'' system will replace the previous indent system for government agencies to pay for fuel at Shell petrol stations nationwide. The previous indent system is voluminous in paper generation, laborious in processing, time-consuming in execution and subject to human error and abuse, said Shell managing director of oil products sector Saw Choo Boon. Hence, the computerised ``SuperKad'' ensures more efficient control of fuel supply and purchases. The system has been used by Shell's commercial customers for some time. The ``Superkad'' was launched by Treasury secretary-general Datuk Dr Aris Othman at Shell's Megah Indah Enterprise Sdn Bhd's station in Bandar Utama, Selangor, yesterday. Initially, the ``SuperKad'' system or the Government Fleet Card will be used by various departments under the Ministry of Finance. The system will be extended to other ministries and agencies after six months. Besides Shell, Petronas also offers a similar service. The Government Fleet Card service by Petronas is known as ``SmartPay''. The introduction of SuperKad and SmartPay was the result of a study by the Government on the use of credit card for the supply of fuel to its agencies' fleet of vehicles in 1995. As a result of the study, Shell and Petronas were appointed as the official petrol stations for fuel supply. Transactions with Shell were handled by Southern Bank Bhd while Bank Bumiputra Malaysia Bhd handled those with Petronas. The Government, however, terminated the service on May 31 last year due to ``banking hitches'' and other technical matters, and replaced it with the paper-based indent system. However, the paper-based system caused problems as the Government had to handle about 200,000 vouchers per month and used some 11 million documents.

BC-Hong Kong-Tiananmen
Danish artist to bring Chinese dissidents to Denmark next year
HONG KONG (AP) _ A Danish artist who created a controversial sculpture honoring those slain in the 1989 bloody military crackdown in Beijing said Wednesday he will invite Chinese dissidents to Denmark for a conference next year to commemorate the massacre. The conference will coincide with the 10th anniversary of the bloody crackdown on June 4, 1989, when Chinese soldiers killed hundreds if not thousands of demonstrators around Tiananmen Square, said Danish sculptor Jens Galschiot in a statement. ``We will provide an opportunity for the Chinese democracy movement to meet for the first time since the massacre,'' the statement said. Galschiot's group, Art in Defence of Humanism, is hosting the conference. China has continued to persecute dissidents after the massacre, and many have fled to the West. Most are staying in the United States and France. Galshiot's sculpture, Pillar of Shame, has been standing in a public park in Hong Kong since Sunday as local activists prepare to commemorate the ninth anniversary of the event. On Tuesday, Hong Kong city officials refused to give activists space in any public parks or museums to display the sculpture permanently, saying it was too controversial. The sculpture depicts 50 badly twisted faces symbolizing the pain of the people, and carries a plaque reading: ``How can old people kill the youth?'' It was shipped to Hong Kong last May for the annual candlelight vigil to commemorate the Tiananmen massacre. The sculpture has been on a tour of the territory's university campuses since last June. Activists say they may have to put the sculpture in a container after Thursday night's vigil until they can find it a permanent home. Meanwhile, the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements in China, the vigil's organizer, said in a statement that it will broadcast a videotape of speeches by two prominent Chinese dissidents, Wang Dan and Wei Jinsheng. Wang, a leader of Beijing's 1989 student movement, will also speak at the vigil live by phone, the statement said. Both dissidents are on medical parole in the United States. ``Hong Kong people should try keep a cool head and protect their own little base for democracy and make it the root of democracy for the entire China,'' the statement quoted Wei as saying on the videotape. Hong Kong was returned to Chinese rule last year, and leaders have warned repeatedly that Hong Kong will not become a base for anti-China activities. But anti-government protests have remained legal in Hong Kong after the handover.

One night I could not sleep, although physically, I was dead tired from reading, or better said scrutinizing, five or six newspapers every day and listening attentively to all kinds of news broadcasts by state and private television stations. Not to mention listening to controversial gossip circulating without a clear source. Despite an educational background and experience in a number of important posts, both military and civilian, I am confused about conflicting legal interpretations and news about people asking for more freedom of mind and actions, which actually is very logical after the ironhanded leadership of the second president. Will more freedom at this time benefit the country or will it bring more confusion if we cannot restrict ourselves to the most necessary items, according to the time and situation? In my opinion, the reopening of the Marsinah, Udin and Tanjung Priok cases is important, and I fully agree to and support this effort. He was speaking at the launching of the Asean Insurance Training Fund and the inauguration of the 1998 MII Annual Lecture in Kuala Lumpur. MII has sent applications for the scholarships to the respective insurance bodies in Asean countries - Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, Myanmar, Indonesia, Vietnam, Brunei and the Philippines. For the first year, the fund will offer scholarships valued at RM13,500 each to cover the fees for the course, which is expected to begin next month. The diploma is accredited by the Chartered Institute of Insurance London. The Asean Insurance Training Fund was initiated by Malaysia at the first Asean finance ministers' meeting held in Phuket, Thailand, in March last year. It was made due to the need to increase the number of qualified and well-trained personnel to sustain the growth and progress of the insurance industry in Asean. ``The fund is provided by the local insurance industry with a ringgit-for-ringgit matching grant by the (Malaysian) Government. ``It is the Government's aspiration that the Fund will be one of the many platforms through which Asean member countries will build expertise in insurance and at the same time foster closer relationship among the insurance players in the region,'' said Ahmad. It will be providing 75 scholarships to the MII over the next five years. In addition, the Asean Insurance Training Fund will also be sponsoring short technical courses in various subjects. ``These short courses are expected to attract not less than 300 participants from the region over the five-year period,'' said Ahmad. Meanwhile, MII chairman of education committees Adrian Loh said upon completion of the diploma programme, students would also be placed in the local insurance companies to gain some experience. ``The (Asean Insurance Training Fund) scheme is just a kick-start. Hopefully we can encourage other bodies to come up with ways to create more insurance professionals,'' he said.

Germany's deadliest rail accidents
By The Associated Press
The high-speed train crash Wednesday was the deadliest in Germany in 23 years. The following is a list of serious rail accidents in the country over the past three decades: Feb. 2, 1990: Two elevated inner-city trains crash in Ruesselsheim, near Frankfurt, after train driver misses stop signal. 17 killed, 72 injured. June 8, 1975: Two express trains collide in the southern state of Bavaria. 41 killed, 122 injured. Nov. 5, 1973: Trains collide on line between Kassel and Bebra. 14 killed, 65 injured. Oct. 27, 1971: Small train carrying children on field trip collides with freight train because of signal failure. 46 killed, 25 injured. July 21, 1971: Train ``Swiss Express'' derails rounding curve near Freiburg. Technical problems blamed. 23 killed, 143 injured. Feb. 9, 1971: Train derails while rounding curve in the Allgaeu, Bavaria's Alpine region near the Austrian border. Brake failure probable cause. 28 killed, 42 injured. July 6, 1967: A half-closed barrier at a rail junction near Magdeburg strikes a rail tank car with 15,000 liters of gasoline, causing it to explode and the train to catch fire. There were 94 dead, the worst rail accident in Germany since World War II. (aet-gb)

PLAYER POWER is becoming an increasingly used phrase in Premier One this season. If Perak and Selangor's problems with their players aren't enough, Negri Sembilan, too, seem to be suffering from this as well. Word has it that a petition, initiated by some players, to remove coach M. Karathu, has been passed around to gain support. The Negri FA, who became aware of the petition, held a meeting with the players yesterday, and warned them not to indulge in politics. NSFA secretary Abdullah Sani Abdul Hamid told them that they should instead concentrate on helping the team win honours. ``We are not accusing any player, coach or others but NSFA hope the players will devote their time to the game and try to improve on the team's performance,'' he said after meeting the players at the NSFA office. ``We hope that concerned parties (involved in the petition) would leave the team alone and let them get on with their job.'' While Abdullah did not say when the petition first made the rounds, it is learnt that it was circulated after Negri's 1-0 defeat by Sarawak in Kuching on May 23. The players were so confident they would succeed in removing Karathu that a foreign coach was believed to have contacted NSFA about taking the position. The management, however, are solidly behind Karathu. Abdullah has urged Negri fans to rally behind the team. He described the banner which came up after Negri lost to Pahang on Saturday as `distasteful'. ``What the team needs is support from the fans, not calls to replace Karathu. This is putting everyone under pressure but the fact is the team aren't doing too badly. ``We are sixth and from the way we have been playing, I am confident we can improve further.'' Negri get a chance to climb up the table when they face Pahang, who were rather fortunate to walk away with maximum points on Saturday, at Paroi Stadium tonight. The good news for Karathu is that striker Scott Ollerenshaw will be back but B. Rajnikandh and Halim Jantan are both out. ``Raizuwah (Idris) will play in place of Rajnikandh while I think I will start with Isham Ismail and Ollerenshaw upfront.'' Isham scored Negri's consolation goal against Pahang last Saturday. Despite Pahang's red-hot form, it is not impossible for Negri to beat them. ``We could have pulled it off if we had converted the numerous chances that came our way on Saturday.'' Karathu hopes Ollerenshaw's return will beef up their attack. Ollerenshaw has been equally guilty of missing some crucial chances and if he can strike form tonight, Negri will have an even chance of beating the Vachislav Melnikov-powered Pahang. United States to allocate dlrs 5 million for new Georgian refugees
Eds: Leads throughout to UPDATE with Berezovsky leaving for talks with Shevardnadze, TRIMS pvs.
TBILISI, Georgia (AP) _ The United States will allocate an additional dlrs 5 million to Georgia this year to help 38,000 refugees who fled fighting in the breakaway region of Abkhazia, officials said Wednesday. U.S. Ambassador-at-Large Stephen Sestanovich announced the new aid after meeting with Georgian President Eduard Shevardnadze and other officials late Tuesday. The United States will raise its aid to Georgia this year from dlrs 100 million to dlrs 160 million, and dlrs 5 million of the new funds will be earmarked for the refugees, Shevardnadze spokesman Vakhtang Abashidze said. Abashidze did not say what the rest of the new aid would be used for. The European Union will also provide dlrs 180,000 for the refugees, said EU Foreign Affairs Commissioner Hans van den Broek, who met with Shevardnadze on Wednesday. Abkhazia, a Black Sea province in northwest Georgia, declared independence in 1992. Separatists drove out Georgian troops and 300,000 ethnic Georgian civilians in a 13-month war, and fighting erupts frequently in the region. About 38,000 ethnic Georgians who only recently returned to their homes in Abkhazia fled again during fighting May 19-25. More than 300 Abkhazians and 16 Georgians were killed in those clashes between Abkhazian armed units and Georgian guerrillas, Shevardnadze has said. Meanwhile, the executive secretary of the Commonwealth of Independent States met with Abkhazian leader Vladislav Ardzinba on Wednesday to discuss possibilities for a peace settlement. India tests naval version of surface-to-air missile
NEW DELHI, India (AP) _ India tested an indigenous naval version of the ``Trishul'' surface-to-air missile Wednesday, the Defense Ministry said. The naval version could be used as a surface-to-air missile against aircraft and as a counter to sea-skimming missiles, the ministry said in a statement. It was flight tested for the first time from naval ship INS Dronacharya in the southern city of Cochin, some 2,500 kilometers (1,500 miles) southwest of New Delhi, it said. Trishul (Trident) already has been tested several times for use by the army and the air force. The missile, which uses solid fuel, has a range of up to 9 kilometers (5.5 miles) and can carry a warhead of 15 kilograms (33 pounds). India tested five underground nuclear devices May 11-13 and is perfecting a delivery system. A.P.J. Abdul Kalam, India's top defense scientist, recently said the government has approved increasing the range of the intermediate-range Agni missile, which it tested before, but halted two years ago following pressure from the United States. Agni was tested to a range of 1,550 miles (2,480 kilometers), enough to reach Shanghai or Beijing in neighboring China. India says it needs a nuclear defense against China and its other neighbor Pakistan, both nuclear powers. In the last two years, India also has tested a short-range ballistic Prithvi (Earth) missile with a range of 150 kilometers (95 miles). A longer-range version was test-fired in January. Prithvi is believed to be ready to be deployed on the western border. India has fought Pakistan in three wars since 1948 and still engages in frequent border skirmishes. India and China fought a war in 1962.

Bank experts estimate that violence costs Latin America nations at least dlrs 15 billion annually. In 1996, there were 140,000 homicides in Latin America, a rate of 30 deaths for every 100,000 people which is the highest for any region in the world, Iglesias said. ``We are in the presence of a special theme that has major social, political and economic repercussions,'' he said. El Salvador suffers a homicide rate of more than 100 killings per 100,000 citizens. Colombia, long considered the most violent nations in Latin America, had a homicide rate of 81 per 100,000 in 1996, the latest figures available. The Inter-American Development Bank already has extended credit to Colombia and Uruguay to help fight violence. ``We are proud to serve not only as a credit agency but as a source of social promotion, Iglesias said. ``In the last few years we have dedicated more than half of our resources to fight poverty and the social problems that stem from it.'' BC-UN-Iraq,0524
Butler to lay out ``road map'' for Iraq to follow to end of sanctions
By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ With pressure mounting to speed arms inspections, the chief U.N. inspector is presenting evidence Wednesday to the Security Council to try to justify his claim that Iraq is still hiding illegal weapons. During the closed-door meeting, which began Wednesday morning and is expected to last most of the day, Richard Butler is also expected to lay out a ``road map'' of specific steps Baghdad must take to comply with U.N. disarmament orders and bring an end to nearly eight years of crippling economic sanctions. U.N. officials said Butler will provide aerial photos and technical materials to argue that Iraq has failed to account for all long-range missiles and chemical, nuclear and biological materials it is believed to have held before the 1991 Gulf War. Destroying those materials is the main condition for the council to lift sanctions imposed in August 1990 after President Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait, touching off the Gulf conflict. Officials of the U.N. Special Commission, which perform inspections, have appeared frequently before the council since 1991. But U.N. officials said Butler is expected to provide far more technical information and detailed evidence than in previous presentations because of pressure within the council to bring the program to an end. Russian, Chinese and French diplomats are expected to question him intensively and in some instance challenge his conclusions. Those countries have spearheaded a bid within the council to accelerate inspections so that sanctions can be lifted. British Ambassador John Weston said he expected the meeting to produce ``a higher level of technical literacy'' among council diplomats regarding Iraq's weapons programs. ``These are complex matters and it's important they be understood,'' Weston said. ``I think it's important that the Iraqis themselves understand what's needed.'' On Tuesday, the council listened to an Iraqi delegation, led by Foreign Minister Mohammed Saeed al-Sahhaf, argue that it has complied with U.N. orders and that sanctions should be ended. Iraq claims the United States and Britain are manipulating the inspection program to justify maintaining sanctions as long as Saddam remains in power. British and American diplomats said Iraq provided no new information about its weapons programs. Pressure has increased on Butler's teams since Secretary-General Kofi Annan signed a deal with the Iraqis in February to open Saddam's palaces and other sensitive sites to U.N. inspectors. That defused the possibility of U.S.-led military strikes to force access But the deal has also put pressure on the inspectors to declare Iraq free or weapons or prove it is not. U.N. inspectors have not visited any palaces or other sensitive sites since April 2 for fear that failure to find any weapons caches will only undermine their argument that Iraq has still not come clean.

A WAR of words flared up yesterday between the Securities and Futures Commission and Morgan Stanley Asia over the latter's alleged breach of SFC regulations. The row erupted after the SFC issued a press statement yesterday at noon, reprimanding Morgan Stanley Asia for its failure to disclose to investors information relevant to plans by China Everbright IHD-Pacific Ltd to acquire a stake in Everbright Bank of China and IHD's subsequent placement of shares. The SFC said that, in May last year, Morgan Stanley Asia failed to inform the public that relevant Beijing authorities were about to permit IHD to buy a stake in the bank. The SFC claimed Morgan Stanley Asia did not fulfil its regulatory responsibility. But late yesterday afternoon, the investment banker countered by issuing its own press statement denying it had violated regulatory guidelines. It said no such guidelines existed. ``We are of the view that we did not violate any regulatory guidelines and made all the disclosures required of it by law,'' Morgan Stanley Asia said. The denial caught the SFC by surprise as it believed the reprimand had been agreed upon by both parties. ``Frankly we're very shocked,'' said Mark Dickens, the SFC's executive director of enforcement. ``We spent this morning checking the wording of the release with them and we have no doubt that their obligation was described in the rule books.'' Mr Dickens said at no stage during the talks did Morgan Stanley Asia give any indication they were unhappy with the decision. Mr Dickens said that the negotiations with Morgan Stanley Asia took place at the company's request. ``It involved a series of meetings with them and their lawyers and it was very carefully discussed, so we're quite happy we're on firm ground,'' he said. Following Morgan Stanley Asia's decision to issue a press statement, the SFC countered with another public statement which expressed regret at the company's ``attempt at public exoneration without reference to the commission's written decision which was 14 pages in length which fully discussed the evidence gathered by the SFC, Morgan Stanley's representations and the reasons for the SFC reaching the conclusions it did''. The SFC disputed the investment banker's assertion that ``there were no regulatory guidelines for a situation similar to the one Morgan Stanley and its clients were facing''. The SFC said it has taken similar action against other firms in related situations. The watchdog has called into question Morgan Stanley Asia's fitness to remain registered and its ability to adhere to very high standards expected of financial advisers. Mr Dickens said there was no question of more regulations or getting the Financial Services Bureau involved in the issue. ``The issue it raises is: What is the point of a system where players don't respect the umpires' decision even after due process?'' he said. Morgan Stanley Asia did not indicate if it was going to pursue the issue.
