THE decision by the Government to push ahead with plans to develop the aerospace sector may seem rather incongruous at this point of time. The economy, many would argue, has just registered its first negative quarterly growth in gross domestic product in more than a decade and Malaysia Airlines, the national carrier and the foremost aviation player in the country, flew smack into the red during its last financial year. With no end to the current economic crisis in sight, many would have thought Malaysia would decide to hold back its aerospace programme until a time when the economy is back on its track again. Those favouring a rethink on the part of the policy-makers on this issue would point to the fact that aerospace is an industry that requires heavy capital investment and long gestation periods. With the economy struggling from the effects of the regional financial crisis, there are more than a few concerns more immediate to the people and the country than building airplanes or launching more satellites, some may say. Apart from that, there is also the question of how to revive the existing players in the aerospace industry. How do we turn the national carrier around? Several smaller airline companies that were created during the good times, including Air Asia, Seaega and Pelangi Air, are not in too good a shape either and would need nursing back to health. Another airline, Asia Pacific Airways, has closed shop. The country's foray into aircraft manufacturing, which had a good start with the manufacturing of the Eagle trainers, has also been affected since the financial crisis broke out last year. Even Malaysia's own satellite in the sky, the Measat, is not immune from the effects of the crisis as its owner, Binariang, seeks foreign partners to help ease its finances. The detestable ambience is taking its toll to the extent that the region, particularly the Association of South-East Asian Nations is no more conducive for foreign airlines that have already aborted their flights in and out of its major cities. The other side of the argument is that there are many benefits from developing the aerospace sector. A systematic development of the aerospace sector will certainly bear fruit in the long term. Certainly, we are not talking about competing with Boeing or Airbus Industrie to make airplanes. But we do buy a lot of aircraft and having a small industry to supply components and parts, for example, would benefit locals and save some of the foreign exchange. Even the technology of producing our own bolts and nuts for the aircraft will gradually save our foreign exchange. And at the same time, of course, we will accentuate our vision towards producing the more sophisticated components of an airplane. The technology employed in aerospace would also help us with our industrialisation aspiration. The satellite technology, for example, could take us among the forerunners in the information age. In an era where the use of satellites brings the world closer - making it smaller and more accessible - we cannot renege on such a plan to develop our aerospace industry. Neither do we have to jettison it. Ironically, it is not the competition in nuclear technology we are talking about. This is more about applying the technology to balance our economy and making the people more knowledgeable so as not to lose track when it comes to competing in its downstream sector, at least. Aerospace is a high-technology field involving scientists and experts that an ambitious country like Malaysia must have. In moving towards realising the objectives of Vision 2020, the groundwork should start now. Cyberjaya, Putrajaya, the Multimedia Super Corridor and other related developments must be well equipped with supporting satellite networks. Without technological applications such as the aerospace, the whole process will be incomplete. This programme is one of the major endeavours we have to undertake to ensure smooth passage to 2020. But of course, we need to emulate the best approach in dealing with it. Any over-zealous implementation will lead to unpleasant results. We have many dextrous eggheads who are capable of delineating the suitable aerospace programme for the nation, and for its people.

NATIONAL coach Morten Frost Hansen and five former Malaysian greats have been inducted into the inaugural Badminton Hall of Fame in a list released by the International Badminton Federation (IBF) yesterday. The ceremony to unveil the Hall of Fame at the IBF office in London will be held at the end of the year. ALL ITALS EXCEPT TBD - For years, there has been the perception in much of the public's mind that government was somehow mishandling the whole issue of petroleum products, a commodity with highly sensitive economic, social, and political implications. A bankrupt Oil Price Stabilization Fund (OPSF) and a second-attempt deregulation law later, the industry, and the related issues are still the subject of much debate. The Business Daily sought to inquire into the mechanics of the affair by asking Dr. Cecilio H. Penson, director, Philippine National Oil Co., to present his views on the matter. ALL BOLD - THE BUSINESS DAILY: For years, oil companies had protection from competition, a foreign exchange risk cover, arbitrage, and interest income, among others. Why has government been so generous to the Big 3? BOLD, NAME ONLY - PENSON - It is a long story. It is speculative to say that there has been some sort of collusion beween the management of oil companies and government lead agencies. Nevertheless, if we look at some of the practices, the first thing that comes to mind is the oil companies' prerogative to engage in arbitrage. Crude oil is bought on credit, with bills to be paid in, let's say, 180 days. In the meantime, you put the money in the bank at around 12% interest. Anyway, the OPSF covered you. While you are buying on credit you get paid in cash. Nice, isn't it? Then they got themselves dollar-denominated loans. When local interest rates were high, they borrowed dollars from abroad at 5%, converted it into pesos and got 12% interest here, all that while they were buying on credit and had the extra insurance from the OPSF. They led a privileged existence, no doubt. Why? I don't know. Whenever they filed a claim against the OPSF, they got their money -that is until the well ran dry. ALL BOLD - What about the pricing system? NORMAL - They do not explain to the country how much is their actual cost. In the meantime they charge consumers as if they were the ones who borrowed the money to buy the crude, charging them for the interest owed as well. All this, while they were covered by the OPSF, mind you. In fairness to the Filipino consumer, let us ask Petron, we being 40% owner of the company, to show us the elements of their cost. Petron is almost always the first to ask for an increase in prices. Never mind their imprudent expenses. There needs to be careful analysis of what I would call imprudent expenses. ALL BOLD - Is the consumer paying the ``right'' price? What are the problems under the current setup? NORMAL - We are not paying the right price. It all comes down to transparency with regard to their actual cost and analysis of their imprudent as well as their prudent expenses. I have been mentioning this during the past three years to the oil and format committee. Why don't we ask Petron what is the most economical way of acquiring and processing crude so that we can get lower prices? The Coalition for Energy Awareness, consumer groups, organized labor, all of them have some interesting things to say in relation to that, but nobody seems to mind them. ALL BOLD - How do local refiners compare to Singapore production in terms of price and productivity? What can we conclude? NORMAL - They are expensive. Look at ordinary oil refinery practice. For example again, let's say my partner and I own a factory for making patis. Before we start production, we have to know what kind of fish should be used, the kind of freight we use, and what kind of broiler we must get. But now my partner insists that we use a certain kind of fish that is more expensive and has to be boiled longer! And, therefore, the whole process becomes more expensive. Just look at Petron and you'll see what I mean. It is hard to believe that the Big 3 are really competing with each other when you look at the quality of their effort to make things cheaper. Singapore prices should only be used as a basis, but we are making it a god here. ALL BOLD - You have accused local refiners of wasteful practices. How did you arrive at these conclusions? NORMAL - They know exactly what crude to use. There is a comparative study of crude costing. They have laboratories to figure it out. They insist on buying Arab crude oil that is sulfur-heavy and costs a lot to process. And the consumer pays for that policy. ALL BOLD - How big a component in the pricing system are what you call ``imprudent'' expenses? NORMAL - For every P0.01 revenue, there is 3/4 of that amount in imprudent expenses. ALL BOLD - Who do you blame for the situation as you see it, and why? NORMAL - All government agencies are helpless about this, especially the Energy Regulatory Board during the heyday of the OPSF madness. ALL BOLD - What needs to be done to get the consumer the best possible price without taking reasonable profitability away from oil producers? NORMAL - We are not saying that they (the oil companies) should not make money. Let them make a profit. If they follow the right costing with regard to crude supply and processing, they will double their profits. What is happening is that the Filipino consumer is paying for their wasteful practices and mismanagement of operations and resources. ALL BOLD - Does the new oil law still have built-in clauses that somehow ensure continued domination by the larger players? Is the playing field really level now? Will competitive pressure be allowed to work? NORMAL - From the very beginning, almost four years ago, I have batted for deregulation because I was not not happy with the OPSF facility. The facility had too many loopholes and unless the government was well equiped, prepared, and knowledgeable, the industry had every chance to make a mockery of the system. Even though the deregulation law is basically a good law, there was little study made on the subject of how exactly new participants would enter the market. Without new and strong participants, it is senseless to talk about competition. There is no change. ALL BOLD - Is there any way to put a price tag, in terms of money lost or made, on what you believe has been the oil industry's non-stop party between 1985 and 1997? NORMAL - The oil companies, based on imprudent expenses alone, owe the Philippines approximately P3 billion over two decades. I don't think the whole issue should be swept under the table and be forgotten. Instead, I think it is in the interest of the public that the matter be vigorously pursued in due time. ALL ITALS - (Dr. Penson has had 30 years experience in the oil business. He just returned from Houston, Texas, where he attended a conference of oil traders discussing the impact of oil prices on the economies of developing countries. - Editor)

JAKARTA (JP): The country's financial markets lost ground yesterday with the rupiah closing lower against the U.S. dollar and stock prices on the Jakarta Stock Exchange (JSX) falling 1.5 percent, analysts and dealers said. Currency dealers said a combination of a weaker yen against the U.S. dollar, worries about the country's political stability and a gloomy economic outlook brought the rupiah down against the dollar. ``Trading in the rupiah remained thin because most operators sidelined the market,'' a dealer with a local private bank said. The dealer, however, said that the weaker yen was the dominant factor in the weakening rupiah. The rupiah, which opened at 11,250 against the dollar, closed at 11,600 on the Jakarta spot market, down on Friday's close of Rp 11.300. According to Dow Jones, the yen was trading at 139.59 against the dollar yesterday, down from 138.78 last Friday. Dealers said that because the yen was expected to fall to 140 against the dollar, the rupiah was expected to break the Rp 15,000 level against the dollar in the days ahead. ``I think the rupiah will likely test the 12,000 level tomorrow (today),'' the dealer said. Currency dealers noted that gloomy economic indicators had also put pressure on the rupiah yesterday. The central bureau of statistics announced yesterday that the country's gross domestic product shrank by 8.5 percent during the first quarter of this year and the inflation rate rose to 40.06 percent between January and May. ``Hopes for a quick release of the IMF loan package and good results on debt talks were overshadowed by these negative factors,'' the dealer said. While the rupiah was weakening, stock prices on the JSX fell 1.5 percent. The index was dragged down by blue chip stocks and stocks linked to the Soeharto clan, brokers said. The JSX Composite Index closed 6.38 points lower at 414.07 on a total turnover of 157.92 million shares worth Rp 146.27 billion (US$12.72 million). A broker with Trimegah Securindo Lestari said that trading on the local bourse remained lethargic for the whole day because most investors were still reluctant to enter the market. ``Trading activity was quiet because investors did not want to take any position,'' he said. He said that most foreign investors continued to off-load stocks linked to former president Soeharto's family and cronies on the grounds that such holdings would not bear any fruits. Shares in Bimantara Citra, controlled by Soeharto's second son Bambang Trihatmodjo, fell Rp 100 to Rp 350 on a total turnover of 9.77 million shares, while shares in toll-road operator Citra Marga Nusaphala Persada (CMNP), controlled by Soeharto's eldest daughter Siti Hardijanti Rukmana, closed unchanged at Rp 375 on a total turnover of 7.23 million shares. An analyst at Harita Securities said foreign investors did not yet feel secure enough to place funds in the country's dire market for fear that political instability would further worsen. ``Some foreign investors are still asking whether the country's political situation has returned to normal,'' the analyst said.

Any customer with a handset joining the network will receive a $480 cash coupon which can be used over 12 monthly fee instalments. Bre-X president suffers severe stroke after Bahamian court freezes assets
By JESSICA ROBERTSON Associated Press Writer
NASSAU, Bahamas (AP) _ The president of Bre-X Minerals Ltd., the Canadian company that collapsed in the world's biggest gold-mining scam, suffered a severe stroke after a Bahamian judge ordered all his assets frozen. David Walsh, 52, is comatose at a private hospital in Nassau, the Toronto Globe and Mail newspaper reported. ``His condition is very critical,'' Kelly Knowles, a spokeswoman for the private Doctors Hospital, said Wednesday. She refused to give details. On Friday, the Bahamas Supreme Court froze all the assets of Walsh and his wife, Jeanette, at the request of the trustees handling the bankruptcy. Walsh collapsed Sunday in Nassau, where he had moved to a seaside estate in March 1997, eight months before investigators discovered that claims of a dlrs 24 billion gold discovery in Borneo, Indonesia, were fake. Stock in Bre-X, which had been billed as the gold find of the century, collapsed from dlrs 206 a share. Thousands of investors lost an estimated dlrs 6 billion. Lawsuits have been filed in Canada, the United States, the Bahamas and the Cayman Islands, where Bre-X vice-president John Felderhof, who also was the company's senior geologist, moved after the scandal broke. Private investigators said the company's chief geologist, Michael de Guzman, apparently committed suicide in March 1997 by jumping from a helicopter near the Busang mine. Investigators suggested de Guzman, who ran the project site, may have masterminded the scam by secretly buying gold from local miners and using it to doctor rock samples dug up at the exploration site. Walsh and Felderhof have declared their innocence and said they want to clear their names. The chartered accountant firm Deloitte and Touche, named trustees in the bankruptcy, asked the Bahamian court to freeze the Walsh's assets to recover funds to reimburse creditors of Bre-X.

PM-US-China, 3rd Ld-Writethru,0852
Clinton proposes renewing normal trade relations with China
EDs: Combines pvs; editing to tighten; no pickup By TOM RAUM Associated Press Writer
WASHINGTON (AP) _ Opening an annual battle with Congress, President Clinton Wednesday proposed renewing normal trade relations with China, saying ``this policy is clearly in our nation's interest.'' Announcing his decision in the Rose Garden, Clinton said that failure to renew normal trade ties would sever the United States' economic and strategic relationship with Beijing. Further, he said it would amount to ``turning our back on a fourth of the world at a time when our cooperation for world peace and security is specially important in light of the recent events in South Asia.'' He was referring to nuclear tensions between India and Pakistan. Many in Congress oppose the president's policy. This year's battle is complicated by questions about the administration's technology transfers to Beijing as well as investigations in alleged Chinese campaign contributions. Clinton was joined at the announcement by Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, departing later Wednesday for Geneva for a five-nation meeting, hosted by China, on steps to prevent an escalation of nuclear tensions in South Asia. ``This is an important example of how our engagement with China serves America's interests, stability in Asia, preventing the spread of weapons of mass destruction, combating international crime and drug trafficking, protecting the environment,'' Clinton said. He said the United States continues to deal forthrightly with China on contentious issues such as human rights. ``There have clearly been some concrete results as a result of this engagement as well,'' he said. U.S. exports to China have tripled over the last decade and now support over 170,000 American jobs, Clinton said. ``But just as important, trade is a force for change in China, exposing China to our ideas and our ideals and integrating China into the global economy.'' But questions about questionable technology transfers to China are sure to color the debate. Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott and the chairmen of four Senate committees, saying they were ``deeply troubled by the national security implications'' of the administration's actions, released copies of letters to Clinton and Cabinet members seeking rafts of new documents. The letters requested ``any and all documents'' in the administration's custody pertaining to the satellite exports and Chinese proliferation activities, including phone logs, memos, tapes and electronic mail. Meanwhile, The Washington Times reported Wednesday that a previously undisclosed improper export by Hughes Aircraft of satellites containing embargoed technology was a key reason former Secretary of State Warren Christopher opposed a plan to shift authority for approving such exports to the Commerce Department. Citing a Sept. 22, 1995, classified memo, the Times said Christopher, along with the Pentagon and U.S. intelligence agencies, strongly opposed shifting the export authority from the State Department to Commerce because Hughes ``recently'' had exported two satellites with sensitive cryptographic technology without first getting a State Department munitions license. Clinton overruled Christopher and shifted the authority to Commerce, then headed by the late Ron Brown, a former head of the Democratic National Committee. ``This is a very serious matter,'' Lott told reporters late Tuesday following a closed-door meeting with the committee chairmen. Lott also suggested the controversy over satellite exports to China _ and whether they were influenced by political campaign contributions _ could make it harder for the administration to win approval this year of renewal of most-favored-nation trade status for China. Congress has 30 days to accept or reject Clinton's decision. The battle over trade with China is always fierce, but is expected to be even more so this year in light of the controversy over the administration's satellite-export decisions. But Senate Democratic leader Tom Daschle said, ``I think that there are some who are making the erroneous connection between MFN and all the other questions that have now arisen regarding our relationship with China. I think that's a mistake.'' But Lott said the allegations that have surfaced, including those of campaign contributions to the Democratic Party that originated with a Chinese military officer, creates alarm. He has already said that the revelations have caused him to reconsider his past support for extending most-favored-nation status to China. Furthermore, Lott suggested that Americans are focusing on the China controversy, particularly because of the recent nuclear weapons testing by India and Pakistan. Some Republicans have suggested a link, asserting that satellite exports to China enabled it to help ally Pakistan with its own program _ thus bringing pressure to bear on India to test its weapons.

KAJANG, Mon. - The list of students allocated places in Form Six has been sent to the schools, and students who have not received offer letters should contact their former schools. Students can also check with the state education departments. An Education Ministry spokesman said some students might not have received their letters yet via the post. ``If they have not received any letters, it does not mean they have failed to secure places. They can check with the master list at their former schools. ``If their names are not on the list, it means they have not managed to obtain places.'' Form Six classes started today. Education Minister Datuk Seri Najib Tun Razak said he would announce the number of places allocated to Sijil Pelajaran Malaysia holders in Form Six in a few days time. He said this to reporters after opening a seminar organised by the ministry and the National Association of Private and Independent Educational Institutions at Universiti Tenaga Nasional today. Najib said the Government had managed to increase the number of places for higher education in the country to accommodate the larger number of students this year. More students are choosing to remain in the country this year going by the current economic situation. The increase in the number of students seeking higher education here is also attributed to better Sijil Tinggi Persekolahan Malaysia and SPM results. Najib said the increase in places was achieved via franchise programmes between public universities and private colleges. ``Certain parties and the media have highlighted the alleged problems concerning the matriculation courses of public universities franchised to private colleges. ``They have also periodically highlighted the problems concerning the UPU Infoline. ``They should be aware that franchise programmes and the UPU Infoline are all introduced to help us cope with the increasing number of students seeking to pursue higher education in the country.'' Najib said parents should not worry about the quality of matriculation courses run by private colleges as they have been vetted by the National Accreditation Board. ``The board will constantly monitor the courses to ensure they are of the highest quality. I will also be visiting several private institutions of higher learning soon to monitor the situation.'' As for the higher fees for matriculation courses at private colleges, Najib said Mara would be awarding scholarships to students. On ``3+0'' programmes, Najib said the ministry had directed the National Accreditation Board to accord provisional approvals to private colleges which have applied to run the programmes so that the institutions can start conducting the courses as soon as possible. ``If the colleges have to wait for full approvals, it will take a long time. The board had earlier said that colleges might have to wait up to six months for full approvals.'' Najib said five private colleges had applied to run ``3+0'' programmes and to date none has received provisional approvals. ``We received the fifth application on May 16,'' he said.

BC-Iraq-Warheads, 1st Ld-Writethru,0596
In protective gear, U.N. experts search for Iraqi missile warheads
Eds: UPDATES throughout with Iraqi official's comments. No pickup AP Photos BAG101-103 By LEON BARKHO Associated Press Writer
Al-NIBAI, Iraq (AP) _ United Nations weapons inspectors searched through reeds and sand dunes Wednesday for missing missile parts in a bid to verify Iraq's claims that it has buried all its biological and chemical missile warheads. Wearing protective suits, masks, boots and gloves, some 27 experts led by German Jean Jano used metal detectors and other equipment in their search at Al-Nibai, 45 kilometers (28 miles) north of Baghdad. Others supervised an earth-moving machine as it uncovered the nose cone of a missile warhead. ``This belongs to a conventional warhead,'' shouted an Iraqi engineer. In 1991, Iraq chose to destroy a great number of its long-range missiles and bury them rather than declare them to U.N inspectors. ``We hope that this work will help to settle some of the still outstanding issues concerning the missile warheads,'' Jano, 61, told The Associated Press. Brig. Ismael Saeed Ahmad, the Iraqi official who supervised the 1991 destruction and burial at al-Nibai, said U.N. monitors have so far recovered enough parts to account for 49 biological and chemical warheads. He did not say how many were buried. As for conventional warheads, only 10 remain unaccounted for, he said later in Baghdad. The area where Iraq unilaterally buried its missiles is vast. Experts with magnetic and electro-magnetic sensors placed small, red flags on the ground to determine where the next digging should be. ``We've with us some of the latest state-of-the-art high-tech equipment,'' said Vincent Murphy, a 69-year-old geophysicist from Boston. ``It is all digitally recorded. The data is brought back in the recorder to one of the vehicles and downloaded to the laptop.'' The advanced equipment is needed because no aerial photography or satellite images will penetrate the type of soil at al-Nibai, he said. Jano, an aerodynamics expert, said inspectors have found ``for instance, aluminum canisters that are used for chemical agents and some stainless steel canisters... used for biological agents.'' But he refused to say how many missiles and warheads were buried nor would he divulge whether what they have collected so far is sufficient to verify Iraqi claims that all its long-range missiles and chemical, nuclear and biological weapons have been destroyed _ the main condition for the U.N. Security Council to end the crippling sanctions slapped on Baghdad in 1990 after President Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait. The current excavation is scheduled to end June 18. Jano said another team of experts will arrive in Baghdad soon to analyze the findings, now stored at Taji, a military camp 20 kilometers (12 miles) north of Baghdad. Accounting for special warheads is one of the main hurdles in Iraq's efforts to declare itself clean of prohibited missiles with ranges beyond 150 kilometers (90 miles). Ahmad claimed all such missiles have been accounted for. In addition, U.N. inspectors are believed to have accounted for 817 of the 819 Scud missiles in Iraq's arsenal. The Iraqis at the site refuse to wear safety gear, saying there is nothing toxic about the pieces of scrap underground. U.N. monitors' suits are burned every day, and inspectors wash their hands and feet in a bleach solution before leaving the site.

Gadhafi expected Friday in Egypt, first stop a tent
CAIRO, Egypt (AP) _ Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi is set to open a 10-day visit to Egypt on Friday, making his first stop in a tent pitched in the Western Desert, Libyan officials said Wednesday. In line with U.N. sanctions on Libya banning international flights, Gadhafi will come by car, said the officials who spoke on condition of anonymity. After resting in the tent _ in keeping with what Gadhafi calls his Bedouin identity _ he will spend Friday night at a farm he owns outside Cairo and then arrive in the Egyptian capital Saturday. It was not clear if he would drive or fly to Cairo. His tent is to be pitched 23 kilometers (14 miles) outside the northern coastal town of Marsa Matruh. Gadhafi had been expected to arrive Tuesday, but a postponement was announced the day before. During his trip, he will meet with President Hosni Mubarak, economy officials, university students, workers and intellectuals. It's his second visit in two years. ms-ggl

KUALA LUMPUR, Mon. - The Government should consider introducing provisions in the law to enable the courts to place a moratorium on claims against a debtor company to give it a chance to pick itself up. Bar Council president Dr Cyrus Das said this measure, practised in Britain and Singapore, was more advantageous than winding up companies which were still viable. He said judicial management orders were more appropriate in the current economic situation which had led to the need to keep viable companies in business. Das was responding to the Malaysian Investors Association's suggestion that a special bankruptcy court be set up. ``It would be more appropriate to amend the Companies Act to provide for the making of judicial management orders, in lieu of liquidation, to rescue companies which are viable except for their present inability to pay their debts,'' he said in a statement. He said the principal aim of judicial management orders was to place a moratorium on claims against a debtor company that qualified for such an order, in order to give it a brief respite to rehabilitate itself under a scheme. ``It is generally beneficial to all parties. It benefits the shareholders who would otherwise lose their investment, the employees who would have the chance of keeping their jobs, and the unpaid creditors who will have a chance of being paid.'' He also said a judicial management order should only be made in cases where the court was satisfied that the company could be kept alive as a going concern, and would be able to implement a scheme of arrangement to settle its debts.

Philippine exports of coconut products in the first five months increased to 971,002 tons in copra terms compared with 508,750 a year earlier, preliminary data from an industry group showed. The United Coconut Associations of the Philippines Inc. (UCAP) also said in a report preliminary data on coconut oil exports from January to May more than doubled to 569,328 tons from 279,328. UCAP said the export data was based on a survey conducted between Jan. 1 and May 27. Besides coconut oil, the Philippines exports copra meal, desiccated coconut, coconut shell charcoal, activated carbon and oleochemicals. It said coconut oil exports from May 1 to 27 hit 110,500 tons based on the survey. Actual exports for the whole month of May last year reached 27,981 tons. Vegetable oil traders attributed the high export volumes to carryover stocks from last year's harvest. ``We doubt that we can maintain high export volumes for the rest of the year because of the drought,'' one trader said, adding he expected coconut oil exports to dip to 90,000 tons this month. ``After June, we will see slower exports,'' he added. The Philippines, the world's largest exporter of coconut oil, has had below normal rains since April 1997. Scattered rains have fallen in parched coconut farms over the past two weeks but traders said they do not expect a recovery in the crop until next year. They said it would take between five and 14 months for coconut farms to recover from the drought. Philippine Coconut Authority Administrator Virgilio David has said he expected the country's coconut output in copra terms to drop by 10% this year from 2.6 million tons in 1997. Asian Exotics Regionals Going Downhill, But slowly Asian regional currencies continued to sink in early afternoon trading, with the rupiah leading the way, pulled down by a weak yen. Attention will be focused on Japan's Vice Finance Minister Eisuke Sakakibara who will attend an international symposium in Tokyo later today and may say something about the weakening yen. In Indonesia, the Central Bureau of Statistics (BPS) said the country's economy was likely to contract 10.1% this year. Inflation was seen reaching 80%-85%. The Indonesian rupiah edged lower hurt by trade and inflation figures late on Monday. Inflation in May rose 5.24% on a month-on-month basis, bringing the year-on-year rate to 52%. The March trade surplus was a huge $1.97 billion, up from $1.70 billion in February. The improvement came via a drop in imports rather than a rise in exports. Imports fell to $2.37 billion from $3.82 billion in March last year. Manpower Minister Fahmi Idris said unemployment in Indonesia would rise this year to 15.4 million or just over 17% of the workforce. The Philippine peso was off its lows. It's selldown was exacerbated by declining Treasury bill rates whose benchmark rate fell to a new 10-month low on Monday. But traders said the peso was well supported as dollar demand from commercial clients has been minimal in the past few days. In Malaysia, the ringgit was unimpressed by central bank Negara's stance to maintain interest rates at present levels. It got off its high but stayed soft following profit-taking by offshore players. Traders said it was possible for the ringgit to hit 4.00 per dollar in the near-term. The Thai baht extended its decline amid strong dollar demand from offshore players. Analysts said the delay in floating up to $2 billion of Thai sovereign bonds has a lot to do with the baht's weakness. But dealers expected the downside to be capped as some long dollar positions still needed to be unwound. The Korean won eased at the outset along with the weaker yen. Dealers said the market was already long in dollar but jitters about the yen fueled the buying of more dollar. The Taiwan dollar was easier after pulling up from a five-month low. Eds: CORRECTS to 31 years in lead By The Associated Press
The high-speed train crash Wednesday was the deadliest in Germany in 31 years. The following is a list of serious rail accidents in the country over the past three decades: Feb. 2, 1990: Two elevated inner-city trains crash in Ruesselsheim, near Frankfurt, after train driver misses stop signal. 17 killed, 72 injured. June 8, 1975: Two express trains collide in the southern state of Bavaria. 41 killed, 122 injured. Nov. 5, 1973: Trains collide on line between Kassel and Bebra. 14 killed, 65 injured. Oct. 27, 1971: Small train carrying children on field trip collides with freight train because of signal failure. 46 killed, 25 injured. July 21, 1971: Train ``Swiss Express'' derails rounding curve near Freiburg. Technical problems blamed. 23 killed, 143 injured. Feb. 9, 1971: Train derails while rounding curve in the Allgaeu, Bavaria's Alpine region near the Austrian border. Brake failure probable cause. 28 killed, 42 injured. July 6, 1967: A half-closed barrier at a rail junction near Magdeburg strikes a rail tank car with 15,000 liters of gasoline, causing it to explode and the train to catch fire. There were 94 dead, the worst rail accident in Germany since World War II. (aet-gb)

BC-UN-Iraq,0513
Butler to lay out ``road map'' for Iraq to follow to end of sanctions
By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ With pressure mounting to speed arms inspections, the chief U.N. inspector is presenting evidence Wednesday to the Security Council to try to justify his claim that Iraq is still hiding illegal weapons. During the closed-door meeting, which began Wednesday morning and is expected to last most of the day, Richard Butler is also expected to lay out a ``road map'' of specific steps Baghdad must take to comply with U.N. disarmament orders and bring an end to nearly eight years of crippling economic sanctions. U.N. officials said Butler will provide aerial photos and technical materials to argue that Iraq has failed to account for all long-range missiles and chemical, nuclear and biological materials it is believed to have held before the 1991 Gulf War. Destroying those materials is the main condition for the council to lift sanctions imposed in August 1990 after President Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait, touching off the Gulf conflict. Officials of the U.N. Special Commission, which perform inspections, have appeared frequently before the council since 1991. But U.N. officials said Butler is expected to provide far more technical information and detailed evidence than in previous presentations because of pressure within the council to bring the program to an end. Russian, Chinese and French diplomats are expected to question him intensively and in some instances challenge his conclusions. Those countries have spearheaded a bid within the council to accelerate inspections so that sanctions can be lifted. British Ambassador John Weston said he expected the meeting to produce ``a higher level of technical literacy'' among council diplomats regarding Iraq's weapons programs. ``These are complex matters and it's important they be understood,'' Weston said. ``I think it's important that the Iraqis themselves understand what's needed.'' On Tuesday, the council listened to an Iraqi delegation, led by Foreign Minister Mohammed Saeed al-Sahhaf, argue that it has complied with U.N. orders and that sanctions should be ended. Iraq claims the United States and Britain are manipulating the inspection program to justify maintaining sanctions as long as Saddam remains in power. British and American diplomats said Iraq provided no new information about its weapons programs. Pressure has increased on Butler's teams since Secretary-General Kofi Annan signed a deal with the Iraqis in February to open Saddam's palaces and other sensitive sites to U.N. inspectors. That defused the possibility of U.S.-led military strikes to force access But the deal has also put pressure on the inspectors to declare Iraq free or weapons or prove it is not. U.N. inspectors have not visited any palaces or other sensitive sites since April 2 for fear that failure to find any weapons caches will only undermine their argument that Iraq has still not come clean.

That was probably the catalyst for Rajen to delve deeper into the realm of traditional herbal medicine. In fact, already in the 1970s, Rajen sensed that there was more to the body and good health than just medicine and pain killers and injections. ``If you fall sick and go looking for a doctor, you have already failed as the body has a tremendous and innate capacity to heal itself,'' said Rajen in an interview with Business Times. ``The very day you get sick means you have defeated this capacity to take care of itself,'' said Rajen, adding that ``outside help can be radical with the use of invasive methods and toxic drugs all of which undermine the body's capacity.'' MULTIMEDIA Super Corridor software company Datek Sdn Bhd expects to invest an additional RM20 million in marketing and business development programmes within the next three months. Chief executive officer Darryl Carlton said the company had so far invested RM15 million. ``We will be focusing on the European, American and Chinese markets,'' he said. He was speaking at the company's unveiling of Solo 3270, which allows users to access IBM mainframes from their Netscape or Internet Explorer browsers. Carlton said Solo 3270 was aimed at the millions of personal computer users around the world who need to access the IBM mainframes but could not do so. ``The market for Solo 3270 is huge. Altogether there are 450,000 mainframes worldwide and they contain roughly 70 per cent of the world's data. ``These mainframes are configured to the IBM 3270 computer protocol and include those produced by computer giants such as Amdahl, Hitachi, Fujitsu and NEC,'' he added. Solo 3270 is written in pure Java programming language, which means that it can run on any operating system, regardless if one is accessing the mainframe through a computer running on Apple, Unix or Microsoft Windows. Priced at US$29.85 (RM115.22) each, Solo 3270's price is expected to be a key strategy in enabling Malaysian technology penetrate the global market. ``Our focus for the Solo 3270 will be in North Asia (China, Japan, Korea and Taiwan) as we foresee growth markets for the IT industry there...but we would need to achieve a certain level of success in the United States first.'' Carlton said Datek was now in negotiation with a computer manufacturer for the inclusion of Solo 3270 as standard software. ``We are talking to a global personal computer manufacturer to have Solo 3270 included in every machine they manufacture.If successful, it will be a step forward in getting Solo 3270 to become a market leader within the next 24 months.'' Carlton added that Datek expected to sell 13 to 15 million units of Solo 3270 a year if the deal came through. On the sales of Batavia which Datek launched in April, he said there was more interest in the product in Asia. The company had spent RM10 million developing the product and was noted as the first homegrown MSC status company to launch the all-new made-in- Malaysia software development tool. Batavia is a tool for developing large-scale applications for businesses and organisations.

BC-Sports-Tennis-French Open-Women's Semis,
Hingis, Seles at it again in French Open semifinals
By SALVATORE ZANCA Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Last year, Martina Hingis showed her youthful exuberance with a joyful leap after beating Monica Seles in the French Open semifinals. The two battle again in the semifinals Thursday, with the other women's semifinal pitting Lindsay Davenport against Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, a pair of 20-somethings occupying spots many fans thought would be taken by teenagers. The Hingis-Seles match has the appeal of a final. Will Hingis get another chance to jump for joy or will Seles, playing her first tournament since the death of her father, make it back to the final of an event she has won three times? It pits the No. 1-ranked and top-seeded Hingis, winner of four of the last five Grand Slams but no French Opens -- against former No. 1 Seles, the winner of nine Grand Slams. Hingis has won each of their five previous meetings. Last year's French Open match was the only time they have not met in a final. ``The last time I played Martina was here,'' Seles said. ``We had a very tough match.'' That 6-7 (2-7), 7-5, 6-4 victory by Hingis lasted more than two hours. Hingis called it the most satisfying victory of her career at the time. This year Hingis has rolled through the first five rounds, losing just 21 games in five matches, including seven to Venus Williams in the quarterfinals. She is 37-4 this year with four titles. Seles has played just five tournaments this year, with a 13-4 mark. Her father died of cancer May 14 and Seles has performed heroically throughout the tournament. She said tennis helps her get over the loss of her father, Karolj. ``I think about my dad every day,'' Seles said. ``But for me it's a tennis match, it's a tennis tournament. I'm doing something that I love to do.'' Seles said her game has improved with the help of new coach Gavin Hopper. ``We worked really hard with Gavin the first week of the tournament. I think I feel more comfortable now than a week ago,'' she said. The other semifinal is not quite as exciting on paper -- second-seeded Davenport, who turns 22 next Monday, against two-time champion Sanchez Vicario, 26. Davenport ousted defending champion Iva Majoli in the quarterfinals. Sanchez Vicario has a 23-6 record for the year, but her only title came in the first tournament of the season in Sydney. She has a 6-2 career mark against Davenport, including wins in their only two matches on clay. Sanchez Vicario knows her experience helps. She won her first French Open title nine years ago and has 60 victories in the French Open. ``I've been there so many years already,'' she said. ``I think the experience of being in situations like this before helps. But I also have to play well enough to win.'' Davenport knows a victory on clay is not expected from her. ``If you look at this year, I haven't been winning tournaments necessarily on clay,'' Davenport said. ``Gosh, I mean, I've surprised myself here.'' She has a 32-8 record this season, winning just one tournament. But that was a big one, handing Hingis a loss in the Pan Pacific final in Tokyo in February. Davenport said she's proud to be a part of tennis' older generation. ``I'm going to be 22 in five or six days,'' she said. ``I'm getting old for women's tennis.'' (sz/rg)

The Australian government, through the Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID) has approved a total P7 million to fund 33 community based projects in the Special Zone of Peace and Development (SZOPAD) under the Philippines-Australia Special Community Assistance (Pascats program. The 33 community projects are focused on agricultural development, micro-enterprise development and social credit. Target beneficiaries of these projects include members of the Moro National Liberation Front and other sectors of society. The projects are expected to raise the living standards of groups of poor Filipinos in the SZOPAD area and improve the working relationship among the bureaucracy, private institutions and the Non-Government Organizations (NGOs)/Peoples' Organization (POs). Projects were selected by a panel of representatives from National Economic and Development Authority Region XII, Southern Philippines Council for Peace and Development (SPCPD) and AusAID. SZOPAD is composed of 14 provinces, namely: Basilan, Zamboanga del Norte, Zamboanga del Sur, Davao del Sur, South Cotabato, Sarangani, Lanao del Norte, North Cotabato, Sultan Kudarat, Lanao del Sur, Maguindanao, Sulu, Tawi-Tawi and Palawan and the cities of Zamboanga, Dipolog, Dapitan, Pagadian, General Santos, Iligan, Marawi, Cotabato and Puerto Princesa.

THE technical know how of the Malaysian manufacturing sector is expected to be further enhanced, judging from the overwhelming response of more than 500 companies from over 30 countries expected to participate in the Industry Tradefair Malaysia 98 (ITM 98) and Machine Tool Malaysia 98 (IMX 98) exhibitions. Organised by Malaysian Exhibition Services Sdn Bhd (MES), both these exhibitions, running from June 3 to 7, are expected to boost the manufacturing sector and increase productivity, efficiency, product quality and capability. MES director Brendan Kelly, said although the size of the show has been reduced by about 30 per cent as compared to the year before, he was satisfied that ITM 98 has lived up to its billings as the country's premier manufacturing and machinery exhibition. ``Under the present economic slowdown, to maintain a more than 60 per cent success rate is itself an envious achievement for any exhibition organiser. ``This clearly reflects the strong confidence of exhibitors in our ability to attract quality trade visitors to the show to help in meeting their business objectives,'' he said. In line with the Government's push to encourage a higher volume of exports and boost productivity as well as efficiency, ITM and IMX are expected to fulfil the needs of manufacturers to remain competitive in the international arena. For manufacturers to sustain their operations competitively and be more productive, Kelly said there is a need to upgrade their operations by investing in high technology manufacturing techniques through automation processes so as to become less labour-intensive. This year's event, to be held at the Mines Exhibition Centre in Sungai Besi, will occupy an exhibition space of more than 8,500 sq m and has attracted several groups from South Korea, Taiwan, China, Spain, Indonesia, France and the UK. Among the groups, South Korea will form the largest group to be represented by 25 companies, followed by Taiwan with 16 companies and the UK with 12 companies. The wide range of exhibits on display will include latest machinery and equipment, state-of-the-art production processes and precision engineering techniques, tools and dies, parts and components, among many others. Both ITM 98 and Machine Tool Malaysia 98 are endorsed by Sirim and supported by the Federation of Malaysian Foundry and Engineering Industries Association and the Selangor and Federal Territory Mould and Die Association. At the same time, the Printing and Packaging 98 exhibition has won the endorsement of the Asian Packaging Federation. These events are expected to attract ket decision-makers, buyers, entrepreneurs and technology experts from the related industries. Some of the major local companies that have confirmed their participation at ITM and IMX '98 are SSI Schaefer Systems, Unipac Engineering, Great Wall Packaging Suppliers, Eastway Engineering and AE Automation.

ALUMINIUM Company of Malaysia Bhd is poised for expansion when the economy recovers, said chairman Tan Sri Tunku Imran Tuanku Ja'afar. Speaking after the company's annual meeting last Wednesday, he said Alcom was flush with cash having over RM9 million in the kitty and no capital debts. It was also still recording strong sales. ``We have learnt the lessons of the mid-80s when we were in a very bad financial situation just as the recession kicked in. Now, our focus is on ensuring the cash-flow position remains strong.'' He added that the company conducted most of its sales in cash terms and as such had no bad debts. Also, all raw material imports and product exports were fully hedged, resulting in virtually no risk in terms of currency fluctuations when it came to the impact on the company's bottomline. Further, the company has shifted much of its sales to the manufacturing sector to offset reduction in orders from the construction sector. ``Our exports still remain strong, making up over half of our total production. But sales in the Asian region has been affected slightly by the on-going economic problems.'' On 1998's expected performance, he said sales had dropped slightly in the first quarter but was still within expectations.

Former head of Chernobyl assails authorities over nuclear safety
KIEV, Ukraine (AP) - In an open letter to the Ukrainian president, the ousted head of the Chernobyl atomic power plant accused Ukrainian authorities of violating international nuclear safety obligations and said their behavior was immoral. Serhiy Parashin said a new Ukrainian company in charge of the country's five nuclear plants, ``cannot secure their safety.'' ``For five months, the company has been working without a license to operate nuclear reactors,'' said Parashin's letter, published Wednesday by the daily newspaper Dyen. That violates Ukraine's nuclear energy and radiation safety law and the Vienna nuclear safety convention, which Ukraine ratified last year, Parashin argued. Parashin, who opposed the creation of the state-run company, Energoatom, was dismissed from his job in early May after Energoatom officials accused him of ``gross violations of work duties and executive discipline.'' Parashin accused President Leonid Kuchma, who faces new elections next year, of pursuing political goals by forming Energoatom. ``The desire to maintain, even by violating the law, a company ... with 50,000 employees that produces 45 percent of Ukraine's electricity, can only be explained by the wish to subordinate the financial resources of the nuclear power industry to a single goal _ the president's re-election campaign,'' Parashin wrote. ``If this is true, you have no moral right to rule a country that has Chernobyl,'' he added. Chernobyl's Reactor No. 4 exploded during an April 1986 test in what became the world's worst nuclear accident. At least 32 people died in the disasters's immediate aftermath, and victims' groups say tens of thousands of others have died from radiation-related diseases. ``It is immoral to violate the nuclear energy law in Ukraine, which has suffered dlrs 120 billion in damages from the catastrophe and has three million affected citizens,'' Parashin said. Parashin worked at Chernobyl as an engineer beginning in 1977 and became plant director in 1994. Energoatom has appointed a top company official and former chief Chernobyl engineer, Vitaly Tolstonohov, as his successor. The newspaper noted that similar warnings have been issued by Olexander Smyshlyayev, Ukraine's top nuclear safety official. (sms/ml)

THE volume of Hong Kong's re-exports increased by 6.2 per cent in March over the same month last year, while domestic exports rose by 1.5 per cent, the Census and Statistics Department said. Taken together, the volume of total exports increased by 5.5 per cent while the volume of imports rose by 0.3 per cent, the department added. The volume of Hong Kong's re-exports for the first three months of 1998 increased by 2.5 per cent against the same period last year, while the volume of domestic exports decreased by 4.6 per cent. Taken together, the volume of total exports rose by 1.4 per cent for the first quarter while imports fell by 1.7 per cent. The growth in volume of trade is derived from the growth in trade value with the effect of price changes discounted. Comparing March 1998 with March 1997, both the prices of re-exports and domestic exports fell by 2.8 per cent. Import prices fell by 4.1 per cent. The statistics department said prices were based on unit values which do not take into account changes in the composition or quality of goods traded, except for some selected commodities for which specific price indices are available. On price changes in the first three months of 1998 against the same period last year, prices of re-exports and domestic exports decreased by 2.5 per cent, while import prices decreased by 3.9 per cent. Compared with the same period last year, the trade index rose by 1.3 per cent in March and 1.5 per cent in the first three months of 1998. The index is the ratio of export price index to import price index.

JOHOR BARU, Mon. - It was a dream come true for two former neighbours, meeting again on Saturday after 40 years. British national Lyn Medland, 46, who left Malaysia about 40 years ago, and her former neighbour P. Paruvathy shed tears of joy when they greeted each at the Causeway. ``It is so wonderful ... I never thought this day will come,'' said Medland when met later at Paruvathy's house in Taman Johor Jaya. ``After several unsuccessful enquiries at the Malaysian and Singapore High Commissions, the Malaysian Tourism Promotion Board and British Army office, I had almost given up meeting Paru again... we are half a world apart,'' she added. Medland and her husband Clive Percival, who are on a cruise trip to Singapore, stopped over here for a day. Now living in Southampton, Medland was staying in Johor Baru with her family from 1959 to 1960 when her father was serving with the British Army's Jungle Warfare School (now Pulada in Kota Tinggi). Her intention to catch up with Paruvathy was highlighted in the New Straits Times on April 23. Paruvathy described the meeting as a miracle. ``When I saw her at the Causeway, I was speechless ... We just gave each other a very tight hug.'' Paruvathy used to work for the Medland family. The Medlands wanted her to follow them when they moved to Seremban and then back to England. However, Paruvathy was unable to do so as she had to look after her elderly mother, brothers and sisters. They lost touch with each other as the Medlands were always on the move. Paruvathy was only told of the article in the NST on May 20. She sent a letter to Medland immediately after calling up the NST Johor Baru bureau for her address in England. Concerned that the letter might not reach Medland before she set off on her cruise, Paruvathy sent a telegram on May 22. Paruvathy also sought the help of her friends here who have connections in England to inform Medland of her telephone number. Medland said: ``I received a telephone message from a person who said she had information about Paru on the morning of May 23. That same evening, I received Paru's telegram. ``I was so excited that I called Paru immediately to arrange for a meeting here. Three days later, just shortly before my husband and I set off, I received Paru's letter.'' Paruvathy and Medland literally took a trip down memory lane when they visited Medland's previous house in Johor Baru, Pulada and the Kota Tinggi waterfalls.

Kurdish rebels kill nine passengers in attack on minibus
TUNCELI, Turkey (AP) _ Kurdish rebels stopped a minibus near this eastern city Wednesday and killed nine passengers with automatic gunfire, the Anatolia news agency said. The guerrillas, fighting for autonomy in Turkey's southeast, often target civilians, especially when under pressure from the Turkish military. Two other passengers were wounded in the attack near the village of Pertek, the agency said. The rebels fled before troops reached the scene. The army recently escalated an offensive launched against guerrillas. On Tuesday, the military claimed killing 589 rebels this year. In new clashes Wednesday, soldiers killed six Kurdish rebels in the southeastern province of Siirt, Anatolia said. The war has killed some 37,000 people since 1984. (sh/vls)

BC-Germany-Train Derails, 13th Ld-Writethru
At least 70 dead in high-speed German train crash
URGENT Eds: UPDATES with details on injuries; minor editing By CLAUS-PETER TIEMANN Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ A high-speed passenger train derailed Wednesday in northern Germany after colliding with an automobile that had plunged off an overpass. At least 70 people were killed and 200 injured, state officials said. The crash _ Germany's deadliest rail disaster in 31 years _ happened at 11 a.m. as the Hamburg-bound train was going 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour approaching the station in Eschede, 50 kilometers (35 miles) north of Hanover. The wreckage suggested that the automobile crashed through the overpass guardrails and struck the train as it sped underneath. The nose of the train cleared the bridge, while the cars behind derailed and jackknifed into each other. The train was carrying at least 350 passengers. Regional officials said 100 people were lightly injured, in addition to the 200 serious injuries. At least six survivors were taken to a public building in Hanover. The accident was the worst on Germany's premier high-speed ICE line, inaugurated in 1991. At least 13 cars derailed, piling into each other and crashing into the base of the overpass, collapsing it. The force of the pile-up pushed cars meters (yards) high into the air. A Deutsche Bahn executive Johannes Ludewig, said he was ``deeply dismayed and horrified by the proportions of this accident.'' Several of the rail cars were demolished, and splintered glass covered the scene. Luggage was piled next to the wreckage as workers struggled to pry passengers from the train. About 10 trauma surgeons were at the scene, Christian Krettek, of University Hospital in Hanover, told CNN. He said rescue workers expected the death toll to rise, and it was still unclear if there were more dead inside the shattered train cars. A crane was positioned to lift chunks of the bridge to reach cars underneath. The German border patrol sent helicopters and 80 personnel to help emergency workers free passengers trapped inside the rail cars. Officials feared many inside were dead. The accident closed train traffic in both directions. Federal Transport Minister Matthias Wissmann, Lower Saxony state governor Gerhard Schroeder and German railway executives were en route to the scene. The ICE train is Germany's fastest, connecting all major cities at speed up to 280 kilometers (175 miles) an hour. The train travels from Munich to Hamburg, covering a distance of more than 950 kilometers (about 600 miles), in 5 hours and 37 minutes. Regular train service takes more than eight hours. The high-speed trains carry more than 65,000 passengers daily. (cb-gb-aet)

Hamas says it is ready for dialogue with America
CAIRO, Egypt (AP) _ A militant Palestinian group whose suicide bombers have killed scores of civilians in Israel says it is prepared to talk to Washington, but only to ``clarify facts'' and not to take orders, according to remarks published Wednesday. ``We do not close the door in front of any dialogue with the United States, if it wants this,'' Sheik Ahmed Yassin, the spiritual leader of Hamas, was quoted as saying by the Al-Hayat newspaper. He accused the United States of supporting Israel, and warned that ``we fight our enemy and those who stand by its side.'' Yassin, who is 61-years old and quadriplegic, has so far visited Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Iran, United Arab Emirates, Kuwait, Yemen and Syria. He is expected to travel to Pakistan and Malaysia.

New England captain hopes to revive England against South Africa
By IHITHISHAM KAMARDEEN Associated Press Writer
BIRMINGHAM, England (AP) _ Alec Stewart will carry England's hopes of winning its first test series against a major power since 1985 when he leads the home side in the first of five tests against South Africa starting Thursday at Edgbaston. For Stewart, who replaces Mike Atherton as England captain, a series win against the Proteas is vital. England's last win over a power was in 1985 when David Gower led the side to a 3-1 series victory over Australia. It is South Africa's first five-test series in England since its return from isolation in 1991-92. In England in 1994, it shared a three-test series 1-1 draw and then beat England at home 1-0 in a five-match series in 1995-96. Stewart, 35, the oldest member of England's 12-man squad for the first test, is mindful of his side's predicament. He said the two sides are evenly matched, suggesting the home team might have the advantage. On paper, England has more strengths than South Africa, but the visitors' classier new ball attack could easily swing a test in its advantage. ``We have a lot of respect for (Allan) Donald and (Shaun) Pollock, and the South Africans are a well disciplined side to play against,'' Stewart said Wednesday. ``I am someone who respects the opposition but I am more concerned about how we play,'' he added. South African pace bowler Donald and his ever-improving understudy, Pollock, are no strangers to Edgbaston. Donald and Pollock played county cricket for Worcestershire and know the ins and outs of the seamer-friendly Edgbaston pitch. The pitch traditionally favors a seam bowling attack but Stewart said a spinner could be advantageous on a pitch that looked ``flat and soft underneath''. England's sole spinner, off-spinner Robert Croft, looks likely to win a test berth while three players, Mark Ealham, Dominic Cork and fast bowler Dean Headly, fight for the remaining two positions. ``It looks a good batting pitch,'' Stewart said. But, given the amount of rain lately, he intimated he would be tempted to bowl first. South Africa, fresh from a 2-0 win over Sri Lanka, is not expected to make more than two changes. Captain Hanse Cronje said tour selectors had already met and had settled on a combination. A final decision will made after the tourists have had a good look at the wicket. If conditions warrant it, the South Africans may revert to their old ploy of an all-seam attack. However, if the skipper has his way, then the unorthodox wrist spinner Paul Adams will play. ``I just don't think one can go into a five-day test without a spinner,'' Cronje said. The only obvious change to the side that beat Sri Lanka at Centurian Park in March is expected to be the return of middle-order batsman and brilliant fielder Jonty Rhodes. Rhodes, who scored a century from 74 balls in an earlier tour game, will bat No. 6. He will be making his first test appearance since January, having missed the five tests against Pakistan and Sri Lanka. Opposition leader released from jail
MINSK, Belarus (AP) _ The leader of a youth opposition group was released from prison after two months Wednesday, but officials said his case was still open. Pavel Severinets, 21, was arrested April 2 after taking part in a rally sanctioned by the authorities. Severinets heads the Young Front, the youth branch of the nationalist Popular Front. The rally in the Belarusian capital Minsk marked the first anniversary of a union agreement between Belarus and Russia. The agreement calls for closer ties between the two former Soviet republics, but fell short of Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko's goal of reintegration. The Popular Front has denounced the union treaty as a virtual surrender of Belarus' post-Soviet independence. The authoritarian Lukashenko has responded to their protests with a crackdown on his political foes and free media, but he remains hugely popular in the country of 10 million people. Belarusian authorities marked the treaty's anniversary with folk concerts. Severinets and his supporters later went to the microphones and began singing nationalist songs. Police did not intervene, but later arrested Severinets on charges of ``hooliganism and violation of public order.'' Severinets has been in a Minsk jail ever since. On Tuesday, prosecutors asked the his imprisonment be extended for another month while his case was investigated. But on Wednesday, he was suddenly freed on condition he stays in Vitebsk, his home town in eastern Belarus. Officials refused to comment on his release. Severinets' lawyer, Garri Pogonyailo, who has defended other opposition activists, was stripped of his license Tuesday on a technicality. Pogonyailo said the decision was revenge for his action. JAKARTA (JP): The government has decided to increase the floor price of unhusked rice this month by 43 percent to Rp 1,000 (10 U.S cents) a kilogram from Rp 700, Minister of Agriculture Soleh Solahuddin said yesterday. ``The increase will be formally announced Wednesday,'' he said, adding that the decision was taken in an economic, finance and industrial ministers coordinating meeting here yesterday. Soleh said the increase, the third in the last five months, was expected to increase farmers' incomes and to further encourage farmers to boost rice production. ``The main objective of the rice price increase is to improve the real incomes of the farmers amid the soaring prices of essential needs and farming materials, including pesticides,'' he said. The government announced a 17 percent increase in the producer floor price of unhusked rice to Rp 700 from Rp 600 in April in a bid to increase farmers' incomes. The government also raised the price of unhusked rice procured by Bulog from village cooperatives 16.2 percent to Rp 716 per kilogram from Rp 616 per kilogram. The price of unhusked rice procured by the State Logistics Agency (Bulog) from parties other than village cooperatives was increased 16.4 percent to Rp 710 per kilogram from Rp 610 per kilogram. The price of polished rice procured by Bulog from village cooperatives increased 15.8 percent to Rp 1,125 per kilogram from Rp 971 per kilogram and from other sources 16 percent to Rp 1,115 per kilogram from Rp 961 per kilogram. But many analysts said that the price increase failed to boost farmers' incomes because the move was followed by a rise in fertilizer prices. Soleh said the subsidy for kalium chloride fertilizer (KCl), which has been abolished, would be reintroduced again to help boost rice production. Reduction of KCl use in rice farming has resulted in a downward trend in the country's volume of production, Soleh said, attributing this to farmers no longer being able to afford the fertilizer. ``We are still discussing the amount of the subsidy,'' he said, adding that farmers needed 65kg to 70 kg of KCl fertilizer per hectare for rice farming. Soleh said that to further help farmers, the government had ordered state fertilizer producer PT Pupuk Sriwijaya (Pusri) to distribute fertilizers from its plants to retailers and cooperatives. ``The move was taken to minimize the distribution line and to reduce the soaring prices of fertilizers,'' he said.

KUALA LUMPUR, Mon. - Medical authorities do not expect any long-term health effects from haze as its presence is sporadic in nature, Health Minister Datuk Chua Jui Meng said today. Compared to air pollution in the form of smog in many industrialised countries, the constituents of haze in Malaysia were different, he said. He was speaking to reporters after opening the World Health Organisation Bi-regional Workshop on Health Impacts of Haze-related Air Pollution here. Smog, a combination of mist and smoke emissions from factories in industrialised countries, occurred daily and therefore was more hazardous than haze, said Chua. According to British media reports, an estimated 20,000 to 25,000 people died annually due to the effects of smog, he said. Chua said studies conducted by his ministry's Centre for Disease Control last year showed that although there was an increase in conjunctivitis, asthma and upper respiratory tract infections during the 1994 and 1997 haze periods, the the increase was not ``statistically significant.'' The Institute for Medical Research also carried out a similar study and its findings were similar to that of the CDC, Chua said. He said Director-General of Health Tan Sri Dr Abu Bakar Suleiman would chair a meeting on Thursday to finalise the report on the CDC's findings. He added that the recent haze episode had shown the need for countries in the region to co-ordinate research on the impact of such air pollutants on health. He said the health impact in individual communities as a result of air pollution due to extensive forest fires was not fully known or understood. The Environmental Health Research Centre in Malaysia, developed with the help of WHO, would become the regional focal point for environmental health research, he said. Chua said the EHRC, established in September 1996 at the Institute for Medical Research, would co-ordinate all such research and set up an environmental health information system. Participants attending the workshop were from member countries of the Southeast Asian Regional Office (Indonesia and Thailand) and the Western Pacific Regional Office (Malaysia, Brunei, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines and Singapore). Chua said the haze that enveloped Malaysia and the region from late July to October 1997 was mainly due to forest fires in Kalimantan and Sumatra in Indonesia. Internal sources of air pollution such as vehicular emissions, industrial activities and open burning also contributed to the haze, he said. ``Here in Malaysia, the the haze is made up of particulate matter commonly known as PM10 and definitely less deleterious than smog. ``Larger particles will be deposited close to their source while particulate matter up to 10 micrometers in diameter can be inhaled,'' he said. Chua said a study by Alam Sekitar Malaysia Sdn Bhd during the haze showed levels of sulfur dioxide, nitrogen dioxide, ozone and carbon monoxide were well within WHO air quality standards.

Eds: Recasts and UPDATES with Corretja quotes. By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Alex Corretja became the third Spanish player to reach the French Open semifinals Wednesday, defeating Filip Dewulf of Belgium 7-5, 6-4, 6-3. It will be the first Grand Slam semifinal for Corretja. He joins his good friends Carlos Moya and Felix Mantilla in the final four. All excel on the clay courts of Roland Garros. Corretja will face either the hometown hero here, Cedric Pioline, or Hicham Arazi of Morocco. ``This is history,'' Corretja said. ``I think it's really good, because normally it's not easy to have a country put three guys in the semis of a Grand Slam. We used to see the American guys in other tournaments, but not the Spanish guys.'' Deuwlf hadn't lost a set until Wednesday's straight-set loss to Corretja. The 39th-ranked Belgian has good luck at Roland Garros; last year he reached the semifinals. On Tuesday, the consensus favorite on the men's side, No. 3 seed Marcelo Rios, went the way of the other top seeds here. He was upset in four sets by Moya, losing his chance to regain the No. 1 ranking from Pete Sampras. The Chilean held that spot for a month earlier this year, and could have reclaimed it with a quarterfinal victory. But at least one predictable phenomenon remains on course: the onward march of Martina Hingis, the world's undisputed best woman player. Hingis defeated Venus Williams on Tuesday with such ease that it put to rest any talk of a great rivalry _ at least for now. Hingis next faces a newly inspired Monica Seles, a three-time champion here, in one of Thursday's semifinals. No. 2 seed Lindsay Davenport plays two-time champion Arantxa Sanchez Vicario in the other. With Davenport and Seles advancing, there are two American women in the French Open semifinals for the first time since Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert reached the final four in 1987. But there were none of the hoped-for echoes of Evert and Navratilova when Hingis and Williams took the court for their much anticipated match. In a swirling wind that hampered both players, Hingis used her deft touch and uncanny court sense to dictate play throughout. Never in the 6-3, 6-4 victory did the Swiss star appear out of control, off balance or rushed. Williams, for her part, hurt herself with 38 unforced errors. ``I don't think I was as patient as I should have been. I guess everyone knows I like to hit,'' Williams said. ``I suppose I got a little too excited, really wanted to hit a winner.'' Hingis came into the match with a 5-2 career record against the eighth-seeded Williams, but the two 17-year-olds were 2-2 this year. The match promised to be an intriguing battle between power and smarts. Despite her far greater experience, Hingis actually is 3{ months younger than Williams. But, just as in their only previous Grand Slam tournament encounter _ a 6-0, 6-4 win by Hingis in the U.S. Open final last summer _ the match turned into a one-sided affair. ``It's probably good for me to lose so I can really see what I'm doing wrong and really look at myself and say, `Venus, you're not there,''' she said. Moya, seeded 12th here, is ranked 12th in the world, but has been as high as fifth. He's hoping to crack back into the top 10 this week. He became the talk of the tennis world at last year's Australian Open _ for both his dashing good looks and his talent. He upset defending champion Boris Becker in the first round, then went straight through to the final, where he lost to Sampras. But except for that tournament, the 21-year-old Moya had never gone past the second round of any Grand Slam event. And here at Roland Garros, he hadn't gotten past the second round in two previous visits. Now Moya is the highest seed left in the tournament. On Friday he faces his good friend Mantilla. ``We're going to be friends until Friday,'' he said. ``When we get to the court, I will try to kill him.'' Tuesday's action ended on a sour note when Gustavo Kuerten, the defending champion who lost in the second round, was disqualified in doubles for throwing his racket at the chair umpire and hitting a fan in the stands, but apparently not causing injury. ``I'm so sorry for what happened and I regret what I did,'' the Brazilian said Wednesday in a statement. ``I know that this will make me a more mature guy and will make me grow. I want to make it clear that I never had the intention of hurting anyone on or off the court.''
