JAKARTA (JP): Bank Indonesia (BI) reverted to the Jakarta Interbank Offered Rates (Jibor) yesterday as the basis for determining the ceiling of bank deposit rates. BI Governor Sjahril Sabirin said the decision was made to ensure a ``flexible monetary policy''. Under the ruling, effective yesterday, the interest rate ceiling for rupiah deposit is set at 500 basis points above the preceding weekly average Jibor. The rate for foreign exchange deposits is fixed at 100 basis points above the Jibor benchmark. Saving deposits offered with rates above the ceiling will not be guaranteed by the government under the new ruling. The government in January promised to guarantee all banks' obligations to allay fears of jittery depositors following the closing of 16 banks in November and the dire state of many of the country's banks. Previously, the maximum rupiah rate was 125 percent of Bank Indonesia promissory notes (SBI). ``Using the SBI rates as a benchmark was pretty rigid,'' he told reporters yesterday following a meeting with several economic ministers. The central bank will announce the benchmark rates for rupiah and foreign exchange deposit savings every Friday afternoon, which will be valid for the following week. In the event the Friday falls on a public holiday, the bank will announce rates on the previous working day. BI has the right to make the announcement on any other days. The central bank has also set a ceiling on interbank overnight rates, which will be based on the weighted average of the overnight rates offered by the banks contributing to Jibor. Although the banks are allowed to freely set the overnight rates, BI will only guarantee principal payments and interest rates at the ceiling. Some banking analysts said BI's move on the benchmark for deposit rates might be an effort to provide banks with operating profit to increase their loan loss reserves amid the increasing amount of nonperforming loans. Based on the SBI benchmark, many banks had to subsidize their third party funds as they had to pay higher interest rates for the deposits compared to the SBI rates. In the economic crisis, most banks are choosing to put their money in SBIs as lending activities have been virtually halted and the interbank money market is considered risky in terms of safeguarding the banks' own liquidity to pay their dues. The new ruling would effectively lower the deposit rates because the Jibor rates have been unrealistically lower than the SBI rates, an analyst said. He said last week's Jibor rates were between 45 percent and 50 percent, compared to the one-month SBI rate at 58 percent. The new interest rates policy will lead depositors to turn to SBIs, which offer better rates, or to state banks which are deemed less risky. ``This will send more banks into IBRA (Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency),'' he said, adding that this would accelerate the restructuring process of the banking sector. Some analysts worry the new ruling might cause further capital flight as domestic time deposits would become less attractive compared to the looming hyper-inflation environment and amid nervousness in the banking sector following the run on the country's largest private bank, Bank Central Asia, for more than two weeks. BI director Miranda Gultom was quoted by the state news agency Antara as saying that the government would accelerate the ownership restructurization of BCA to prevent a continuing run on the bank and to improve overall confidence in the banking sector. She said no bank could withstand a sustained run, and that the only way to assist BCA was to restructure the ownership. BCA is currently controlled by the family of former president Soeharto and his long-time business associate Sudono Salim. Businesses linked to the former first family have been thrown into the spotlight recently over allegations of uncurbed cronyism in the past and unsavory business activities.

JAKARTA (JP): President B.J. Habibie appointed three senior economists as advisors yesterday and revamped the Economic and Monetary Resilience Council in a bid to accelerate revival of the country's ailing economy, a minister said yesterday. Minister/State Secretary Akbar Tandjung said former president Soeharto's two economic advisors Widjojo Nitisastro and Ali Wardhana along with former minister of finance Frans Seda would assist the president with all problems affecting the country's economy. ``The measure is designed to turn the president's intention and determination to take proactive policies to resolve the country's (economic) problems into something more concrete,'' Akbar said yesterday. The three economists were key Soeharto advisors when the former president came to power in 1967. Soeharto retained Widjojo and Ali as advisors until he stepped down last March. Both are widely respected by the international business community. Frans became a businessman after leaving the cabinet early in the 1970s. Widjojo played a key role during negotiations with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and other international financial institutions earlier this year. According to Akbar, Habibie appointed Widjojo chairman of the resilience council, while State Minister of National Development Planning/Chairman of the National Development Planning Agency (Bappenas) Boediono was appointed secretary general. He replaces Salim Group executive Anthony Salim, who recently resigned from the position. Widjojo was previously Soeharto's deputy on the council. Chairman of the Chamber of Trade and Industry (Kadin) Aburizal Bakrie and head of Indonesia's corporate offshore debt team Radius Prawiro have also been given positions on the council. The announcement of Boediono's appointment contradicts a claim made on Friday by Aburizal that he had been appointed secretary general but had not yet received official confirmation. The council was established to help monitor the implementation of a 50-point reform plan agreed between Soeharto and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in exchange for a US$43 billion rescue package. Soeharto appointed Coordinating Minister for Economy, Finance and Industry Ginandjar Kartasasmita as executive chairman of the council shortly before Habibie replaced him as the country's leader on May 21.

INTEGRATED circuits trader PCL Enterprises Holdings plans to deploy more resources to develop its market on the mainland, which has become a major production base for electronic consumer production markets worldwide. PCL will focus on building up its sales and distribution network as well as its product design capability. Executive director and general manager Anthony Cheung said the group would develop the sales and distribution channels first with a view to building a solid foundation for its business development unit. The establishment of the distribution network will be followed by mainland design centres. Mr Cheung said the group was not seeking joint ventures or co-operation opportunities on the mainland at present, but it had not ruled out such tie-ups in the future. Chairman John Seto, however, said that in Taiwan and Hong Kong the group was considering joint ventures with several foreign companies mainly on production processing. ``We are still in discussions, but we hope to finalise plans in a few months,'' Mr Seto said. He said tenants had requested downward adjustments on rental charges upon the renewal of their leases. The group is likely to offer a 10 to 20 per cent decrease in rental charges. ``But there will be only a handful of renewals by the end of the year,'' he said. The group will focus on improving its production process technology with the aim of expanding its foundry services business and value-added products, Mr Seto said.

JAKARTA (JP); Publicly listed Bank Niaga is expecting a net loss in the first quarter this year against a net profit of Rp 31.81 billion (about US$3.18 million) over the corresponding period last year, its president said yesterday. Gunarni Suworo said the predicted downturn was due to the increase in the loan loss provision to Rp 39.8 billion. ``Our income will become negative due to the increase in loan loss provision for possible bad debts,'' she said after a shareholders meeting . Gunarni declined to mention the amount of the loss. The bank, which recorded a 54.51 percent decline in net profits to Rp 44.57 billion last year, had also increased its loan loss provision to Rp 207.1 billion in 1997 from Rp 64.9 billion the previous year, she added. ``The increase of loan loss also caused our net profit to decline sharply in 1997.'' She warned that the country's economic predicament, which is expected to worsen in the coming months, would cause most companies to face problems in repayment of loans to the banking system. The inevitable result would be the likelihood of mounting bad debts. She said Bank Niaga expected bad debts to increase from between 15 percent to 30 percent this year, similar to the average growth rate of bad credits in the national banking industry. The bank's problem loans, which include doubtful and bad credits) reached 5 percent, she said, adding that bad credit alone was 0.9 percent. ``Due to this, there will be no more expansion plans this year.'' The bank, which allocated total credits of Rp 9.09 trillion by the end of 1997, is also seeking foreign investors to boost its capital. ``But it is still in the preliminary stage and hopefully it will be finalized by the end of this year.'' She declined to identify the foreign institutions involved because ``it is too early''. Gunarni said the bank had obtained approval from its shareholders to raise its capital to Rp 1.4 trillion from the current Rp 750 billion as part of its move to meet the new capital requirement set by the central bank. Bank Indonesia raised the minimum capital requirement for commercial banks to Rp 1 trillion by year-end, Rp 2 trillion in 2000 and Rp 3 trillion in 2003as part of the measures to revitalize the country's financial sector. Gunarni also denied rumors the bank was experiencing liquidity problems and was poorly managed after Hashim Djojohadikusumo's Tirtamas Group failed to make a full payment on its planned acquirement of the Tahija's family's 40 percent shares. In July last year, Tirtamas' financial holding company Tunamas Panduarta bought a 10 percent stake in Bank Niaga through a public tender offer. It also entered into an agreement with Tahija's wholly owned Austindo Teguhjaya and Austindo Nusantara Jaya to buy the latter's 75.63 million shares, or 40 percent of the bank's capital, at Rp 8,000 per share. ``I do not know about this transaction, but it is based on a 'willing buyer and willing seller' transaction,'' she said. According to the bank's 1997 financial report, Austindo Teguhjaya retains a 10.49 percent stake in the bank and Tunamas has 39.51 percent. Other shareholders are RHB Bena Sdn. Bhd. with 20 percent, life-insurer AJB Bumiputera 1912 with 5.42 percent and the public with 24.57 percent.

CALL it the mother of all pills for what men swear as the mother of all ills. Viagra has arrived, and indications are that it will soon be introduced in Malaysia. Will things finally look up for Malaysia's impotent males? In the face of intense public pressure, worldwide media frenzy and reported deaths, Health Minister Datuk Chua Jui Meng has announced that Malaysia would need at least 18 months of tests before sale of the drug would be allowed here. Known also by its generic name Sildenafil citrate, Viagra works by increasing the blood flow to the penis necessary for maintaining an erection. It is being touted as the breakthrough treatment of erectile dysfunction (ED), which is the inability to achieve a satisfying erection or to maintain it for the duration it is needed. According to Malaysian Urological Association secretary Dr Peter Ng, the intense hype surrounding Viagra is because there is now, for the first time, an oral drug for the treatment of ED, the first that fulfils the strictest standards of testing. In short, it works. ``For a long time, the treatment of ED was limited in scope to either painful surgery or administration of oral drugs that weren't very effective,'' said Dr Ng. Viagra, according to him, is revolutionary because it contains a chemical that helps restore penile blood flow and erections in response to sexual stimulation. First developed as a pill for heart problems, Viagra failed miserably but for one strange but serendipitous observation: all the male test subjects reported having extremely good erections. From then on, things were on the rise for Viagra. The first clinical trials subsequently took place, and after approval from the US Food and Drug Administration, Viagra was approved for sale in America. The drug was soon after tested in Malaysia. Dr Ng, who was part of the team of urologists who administered the local trials, is optimistic about Viagra's efficacy. ``For the first time we have an oral drug that has been proven in the true scientific technique of testing, a method known as the `placebo-controlled randomised trials (PCRT)'.'' PCRT involves the testing of a drug on two equally random groups of test subjects, with neither the doctor nor subject knowing whether the drug prescribed is the real thing or a placebo, both of which are administered in equal amounts. ``After the trials, the results were statistically analysed to determine the reponses between the group that was administered the placebo and the one given the real drug,'' said Dr Ng. The trials were administered at the Subang Jaya Medical Centre and Universiti Malaysia Sarawak late last year. ``Despite the fact that any drug tested will have a 30 per cent placebo effect, we found that Viagra worked so much better than the placebo. We could now therefore prove that the drug works,'' he added. However, Dr Ng warned of the need for strict controls on the administration of Viagra. ``As it is, you can purchase Viagra on the black market or through the Internet. The public must realise that, like all designed drugs, Viagra has side effects.'' These include a possibly lethal cocktail resulting when Viagra is taken with other medication. Dr Ng also stressed that some cases of ED are linked to other illness, such as heart problems, diabetes, or high blood pressure. There is thus a need to treat these underlying causes first. There is also the dangerous tendency to overdose on Viagra, fed by the misconception that Viagra is an aphrodisiac. ``Some want to take it just for kicks,'' said Dr Ng. Ideally, he added, Viagra, if approved for sale locally, should only be administered by a urologist - a medical expert in the evaluation and treatment of ED. ``However, I realise that this would be virtually impossible in Malaysia,'' Dr Ng added, ``because not only would it be ill-received by the rest of the medical community, but also because there aren't that many urologists in Malaysia.'' The solution? A ``happy middle ground'', which Dr Ng describes as the sale of Viagra only to physicians who have undergone a basic workshop on the management of ED. There are also other treatments for ED. They include injections (currently the most common), intra urethral injections (where a cream is injected into the urethra), and as a last resort, prosthetic surgery. As such, Viagra, although considered to be at the forefront, may not be suitable for some patients. ``Viagra is not the be all and end all in the treatment of ED,'' he said. It is important that ED patients first seek the advice of a urologist, who will evaluate and determine the best treatment for the patient. Currently, Viagra is undergoing a possibly lengthy approval process from the Ministry of Health, so it would be advisable for potential customers to hold their horses just a little while longer. Before the drug is released on the local market, it must have the approval of the Drug Control Authority and the Ethics Committee. Sources reveal that the Health Ministry will make an announcement within the next few weeks. It was once said that manners maketh the man. Now there's a pill. But, with all the wild enthusiasm for the wonders of Viagra, perhaps there would soon be a call to create that inevitable pill to end all pills: one that would facilitate celibacy, perhaps?

THE credit crunch and economic conditions in Asia may continue to worsen before any recovery emerges, Hong Kong Monetary Authority chief executive Joseph Yam says. Speaking during the Eleventh Dragon Boat Dinner in London, Mr Yam said there might be further economic casualties in Hong Kong, necessitating modifications to government policies in specific areas such as securities regulation and housing. With other Asian currencies having depreciated sharply, he indicated Hong Kong's competitive position had inevitably been affected. ``Indeed, economic growth in Hong Kong has been slowing down rather sharply since the middle of last year,'' he said. ``For the first time, since 1985, we recorded a negative growth rate in the first quarter this year.'' Mr Yam described the current tough situation which has meant home mortgage payers and other borrowers paying interest rates for their Hong Kong dollar loans of about 200 basis points, an Asian premium that was remaining uncomfortably high. Also, many Hong Kong residents faced losing their jobs. He said the painful, but evitable, economic adjustment would continue and understandably there was discontent. Britain gets new deal to speed Channel Tunnel trains
LONDON (AP) _ The government said Wednesday it is back on track with a new deal to build a high-speed rail link between London and the Channel Tunnel _ although the plans still will leave Britain lagging years behind France and Belgium. Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott said he has signed a new agreement with London and Continental Railways, the original contractor whose plans came up short of cash last winter, and Railtrack PLC, which operates Britain's railroad tracks and signaling equipment and was brought into the high-speed link project to save the deal. The slow train tracks in Britain have been an embarrassment ever since the undersea ``Chunnel'' has been open. France completed its high-speed train tracks between Paris and the Channel Tunnel five years ago, and Belgium completed its high-speed link to Brussels last year. The fast tracks allow Eurostar passenger trains to hit top speeds of 186 miles per hour (300 kph). When the trains are in Britain, however, they move much more slowly. The construction of the high-speed rail link is bogging down, too. Officials had earlier hoped to bring Britain up to speed with its neighbors across the channel by 2003, but the new plans call for the rail link to be finished about four years later. The original plans were shattered when London and Continental Railways said in January that a government grant of 1.8 billion pounds (dlrs 2.9 billion) was not sufficient and that it would need another 1.2 billion pounds (dlrs 2 billion). The government negotiated extensively and said under the new plan it will add just another 140 million pounds (dlrs 228 million) to the original grant. Prescott said Railtrack would agree to pay for any cost overruns, telling lawmakers: ``This is an agreement snatched from the ashes of LCR's collapse.'' Railtrack said it would disclose details of the deal later. (db-kg)

Farmer and food processors, traders and manufacturer will discuss with agricultural technicians and government officials ways to improve the Mindanao food industry's global competitiveness at the Mindanao Food Congress on July 23-24 in Davao City. Organized by the Mindanao Business Council (MBC) and the Philippine Food Processors and Exporters Organization Inc. (Philfoodex), the congress' theme is ''Synchronizing Strategies for Food Security.'' The event will encourage participants to work together to solve common problems. Among the discussions are: ways and means of achieving product quality standardization; assessing the adequacy of post-harvest technology such as storage and product treatment; and solving the challenge of the location of local food processing plants. Participant will also look for cost-efficient channels of distribution of Mindanao 's potential market for foods. ''This gathering of Mindanao's food producers and processors is largely aimed at helping out the oversupply of produce to the local level by projecting forward to exportation,'' says MBC Chair Sebastian Angliongto. ''In doing so, we should make our products globally competitive and conform to industry standards,'' he added. Other issues and concerns the congress will explore include: hazard analysis of critical points for food and food safety, relevance of science and technology to product standards, packaging, and market linkage -- both domestic and foreign. Mindanao's typhoon-free weather, fertile soil, and availability of vast tracts of land make it ideal for agricultural production. Yet the lack of post harvest facilities such as food preservation, packaging, and storage creates severe problems for Mindanao farmers, particularly because almost all of Mindanao's agricultural products are highly perishable. This often results in unfairly low prices for Mindanao farm goods. These problems, the Congress organizers believe, could be significantly reduced if producers switch to technologies that will achieve international standard and thus allow food procedures entry to the growing export market. The event is jointly sponsored by the USAID-funded Growth with Equity in Mindanao Program, the Department of Science and Technology, Department of Agriculture, Southern Philippines Development Authority, and the Department of Trade and Industry.

KUALA LUMPUR, Mon. - A former plantation worker who was sentenced to a total of 36 years' jail on two charges of causing the deaths of his grandparents and an aunt about four years ago, lost his appeal today. Court of Appeal judge Datuk Shaik Daud Ismail, sitting with Datuk Siti Norma Yaacob and Denis Wong, in dismissing Shaharin Selamat's appeal, said there was no reason for the court to change the sentences imposed by the Ipoh High Court on Oct 2, 1995. Shaharin, 24, of Parit Tujuh, Sungai Sumun in Rungkup, had pleaded guilty to three reduced charges of causing the death of grandparents Jaafar Abdul Jalal, 79, Hamisah Mohd Sharif, 65, and his aunt, Rohani Jaafar, 52, a teacher. He was charged with committing the offences at the victims' house in Kampung Batu Tujuh, Jalan Tanjung Tualang, Batu Gajah, between 1pm and 2pm on Dec 27, 1993. High Court judge Kang Hwee Gee had sentenced Shaharin to 18 years' jail on each charge of causing the death of his grandparents, the sentences to run concurrently from the date of his arrest on Dec 30, 1993. On the third charge, he was sentenced to another 18 years' jail which he was ordered to serve consecutively. Shaharin, represented by Naran Singh, had appealed against the consecutive sentence, saying it should run concurrently so that he would only have to serve 18 years' jail. Shaik Daud said although 36 years was a long time, it was not too long compared to the offences committed. ``If the Deputy Public Prosecutor, Kamaruzaman Abdul Jalil, had appealed to enhance the sentencing, this court might probably enhance it.'' The facts of the case stated that Shaharin went to the couple's house at 10am on Dec 27, 1993, to borrow RM100 from Jaafar to repair his motorcycle. He became angry when his grandfather refused to lend him the money. While the couple were napping, he hit them with a brick and suffocated them with a pillow. Shaharin took RM100 from a purse and also Hamisah's jewellery. On his way out, he met Rohani, who had just returned from school and followed her to her room where he hit her with the same brick while she was performing her prayers. He then strangled her with a piece of cloth after which he took her jewellery, RM50 and an automated teller card before fleeing.

THE Pacific Bank Group recorded a 67.8 per cent higher pre-tax profit of RM27 million for the first quarter ended March 31 1998. In a statement, the bank said the higher profit was attributed mainly to the significant reduction in losses experienced by its insurance subsidiary. It said the bank and all of its subsidiaries remained profitable and the balance sheet of the group, capital adequacy and liquidity positions were sound. At the bank level, despite higher interest as well as fee-based income, pre-tax profit fell 20 per cent to RM26.7 million compared with RM33.4 million in the preceding quarter. This was due mainly to higher general and specific loan loss provisions, it said. Loan provisions increased from RM35.8 million to RM44.2 million and general provision from 1.7 per cent to 1.81 per cent. The higher general provisions, which were non-tax deductible led to the bank incurring a much higher effective tax rate which in turn contributed to the lower profit after tax, the bank said. Profit after tax fell 48.4 per cent to RM11.4 million. The bank said the sharper rise in specific provisions was also attributed to its more stringent policy of providing 100 per cent of the unsecured portion of sub-standard loans. The minimum regulatory requirement is 20 per cent. The bank's net non-performing loan ratio (NPL), calculated net of specific provisions and interest-in-suspense and based on its own more stringent provision policy, increased from 2.49 per cent as at end-1997 to 4.91 per cent as at end-March 1998. In addition, it said the bank's gross loans rose by 0.6 per cent to RM7.14 billion while total deposits fell by 8.5 per cent to RM7.95 billion. The bank's loan deposits ratio rose from 82 per cent as at end of 1997 to 89.8 per cent as at end of March 1998. The group's risk weighted capital adequacy ratio declined from 11.9 per cent as at end-1997 to 11.7 per cent as at end-March 1998, still well above the minimum requirement of 8 per cent. The group's earnings per share rose to 3.39 sen compared with 1.33 sen in the previous quarter.

Eritrea, Ethiopia trade charges of attacks Eritrea with attacks; ADDS U.S. envoy has left region.
Eds: AMS. RECASTS. UPDATES throughout with Ethiopia charging AP Photos ASM101-103 of June 2 By JULIA STEWART Associated Press Writer
ASMARA, Eritrea (AP) _ Eritrea and Ethiopia, dimming hopes for a peaceful solution to their border dispute, Wednesday accused each other of cross-border attacks. Eritrea charged Ethiopia with using tanks and heavy artillery in an attack early Wednesday on the frontier village of Ambesete Geleba, 140 kilometers (90 miles) southwest of the capital, Asmara. The Eritrean Foreign Affairs Ministry accused Ethiopia of provoking ``a new and dangerous escalation'' of the border crisis, and said it was the fourth attack in less than two weeks on Eritrean positions. Hours later, Ethiopian accused Eritrean troops of attacking near Aiga and Alitena, about 20 kilometers (10 miles) on the Ethiopian side of a natural border formed by the Mereb River. ``Eritrea thought it could get away with shifting the blame to Ethiopia,'' the Ethiopian Foreign Ministry said in a statement. Both countries have consistently denied invading the other's territory. No details were available on any casualties in either attack. However, Ethiopia's state-run radio accused Eritrea of publicly executing three Ethiopian civilians it said were abducted by Eritrean troops during an earlier cross-border raid. Another 30 civilians were in the custody of the Eritrean army and their fate was unknown, said Kiros Bitow, a local official. He said about 24,700 Ethiopians had been displaced in the Badme and Sheraro areas following Eritrean invasions. Ethiopia first made public the border dispute between the two Horn of Africa neighbors on May 13, calling on Eritrea to withdraw from occupied Ethiopian territory. Ethiopia accuses Eritrea of illegally occupying a 415-square-kilometer (160-square-mile) area known as the Yirga triangle in northwestern Ethiopia, plus a half-dozen smaller areas along the border. But the underlying causes of the conflict are economic, diplomats and businessmen say. Relations between the one-time allies in a long war against the former Marxist government of Ethiopia soured when Eritrea introduced its own currency in November, triggering a trade war that has hurt both economies and reduced cross-border commerce to a trickle. Eritrea on Wednesday repeated a call for a total demilitarization of border areas and outside mediation to solve the dispute. Ethiopia said it was cooperating with peace negotiators. For the past two weeks, U.S. diplomats and regional leaders have shuttled between the two countries in a desperate effort to restore peace that has showed no signs of success. The Eritreans gained formal independence in 1993 after helping Ethiopian rebels end 17 years of harsh military rule in Ethiopia. (kjd)

YEREVAN, Armenia (AP) _ The United States will support international efforts to resolve the conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh peacefully, American officials said Wednesday. Ambassador Stephen Sestanovich and other U.S. officials discussed the conflict Wednesday with Armenian President Robert Kocharian and his officials in the Armenian capital, Yerevan. Sestanovich told reporters that the United States is ready to work with the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe to find a diplomatic solution to the conflict. Nagorno-Karabakh is a mountainous enclave populated by Armenians but located inside neighboring Azerbaijan. The two former Soviet republics have long fought for control over the area. Despite a 1994 truce, there have been occasional skirmishes. ``We have been trying to promote direct negotiations between Karabakh and Azerbaijan,'' said Sestanovich, adviser to the U.S. secretary of state for the former Soviet republics. ``This is exactly the goal that the Minsk group (of the OSCE) had in its proposals last year.'' Sestanovich and Ambassador Richard Morningstar, adviser to President Bill Clinton on the former Soviet republics, also stressed the U.S. commitment to continue helping Armenian economic reforms. As part of their whirlwind tour across the former Soviet republics, Sestanovich and Morningstar also visited Georgia on Tuesday and will visit Azerbaijan and the Central Asian country of Turkmenistan. If we are going to compete with other shipyards in each of those areas, it will be on a traditional or conventional basis such as cutting costs and the like,'' he said. ``Therefore we should seek areas where we have what others do not, and seek businesses which are in need of our expertise. That way we become a better choice. This is the direction we are steering the business towards,'' he said. Elaborating further, Abdul Rahim said the company had already identified one area of business which they are keen on developing. ``It is related to conversion projects, such as the conversion of ships into larger ones, or the conversion of ships to handle oil and gas projects like the FPSO (floating, production, storage and off loading) facility. Another example was the company's engineering projects. ``We are not just looking at the typical off-shore oil and gas projects, but are also actively looking at doing projects on-shore,'' he said. ``Currently we are developing our expertise in process equipment and have actually supplied local as well as overseas petrochemical plant projects with the equipment.'' On his aspirations for the company, Abdul Rahim said he would like to see the company make the same headway in the shipbuilding and engineering sectors as has been made in the shiprepair sector. ``I would like to see the same headway made in the international market for the other two sectors,'' he said, adding that shipbuilding has made some progress in this respect, having exported 11 or 12 ships, namely tankers and purseiner containers, or large tuna fishing vessels to the UK, Iran and Indonesia. Sixty vessels have been lifted and repaired using the largest shiplift system in the region since its commissioning in the middle of last year. Its worldwide clients come from the US, Europe and the Far East. The company celebrated its 25 years of operations on May 18 this year. It has 1,700 employees.

Khatami plans to visit New York, address United Nations
By AFSHIN VALINEJAD Associated Press Writer
TEHRAN, Iran (AP) _ President Mohammad Khatami, who has sought a more moderate course for Iran since his election a year ago, plans to go to the United States to address the U.N. General Assembly in September, a government official said Wednesday. Referring to the planned address as a ``very important speech,'' the official said Khatami would discuss the position of Muslims in the world and in the United Nations. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that Khatami would urge the United Nations to give Islamic nations a permanent seat on the Security Council. The statement was the first announcement of the planned trip, though such a visit had been rumored for days. The trip would require U.S. government permission. Breaking through nearly 20 years of hostility, Khatami called for a dialogue with Americans and more cultural and educational exchanges in a broadcast interview last January. Two previous Iranian presidents have addressed the United Nations since the 1979 Islamic revolution, but both used their speeches to attack the United States. Khatami could instead make a gesture to American leaders. Khatami will also use his trip to meet the 2 million strong Iranian community in the United States, the official said. Many Iranians fled their country to settle in the United States and other Western countries after the revolution. The United States severed ties with Iran after militants stormed the U.S. Embassy in Tehran in 1979 and held 52 Americans hostage for 444 days. av-ti-af

LONDON (AP) _ Prime Minister Tony Blair on Wednesday sent sympathy to the German government following the train derailment that killed at least 70 people in northern Germany. ``I have sent a message of condolence to the people and government of Germany about the appalling rail tragedy earlier today,'' Blair told the House of Commons. BC-Zambia-Kaunda
Kaunda to consider role as peace mediator
By ANGUS SHAW Associated Press Writer
LUSAKA, Zambia (AP) _ Former President Kenneth Kaunda said Wednesday he will consider an offer to be an African peace mediator and roving ambassador. But Kaunda, 74, freed Monday after five months under house arrest, insisted the offer brokered by regional leaders would not force him to retire from political life in Zambia. ``I will always put Zambia first and I will die fighting for my country,'' he told reporters in Lusaka. Kaunda said Wednesday he was told of an offer to revive a dormant peace foundation he started after his defeat in Zambia's first democratic elections in 1991. His role would be ambassador at large with financial backing from donors, possibly including South Africa. A similar mediating role is held by Tanzania's former President Julius Nyerere, who is believed to have intervened in getting Kaunda released, the South African Press Association reported Wednesday. ``If leaders wish to honor me this way, I will discuss it with colleagues and consider it very seriously,'' Kaunda said. In Cape Town Tuesday, South African President Nelson Mandela denied reports that Kaunda's release was based on a promise to Zambia's president by regional leaders that they would persuade Kaunda from returning to politics. Kaunda leads the opposition against Zambia's President Frederick Chiluba. But on Wednesday, Mandela said he hoped that Kaunda would be able to recognize the importance of stepping down from party politics and ``try to help Chiluba in uniting the country.'' He made the remark after lunching with former Botswana President Ketumile Masire in Cape Town. ``We all feel relieved that President Chiluba has taken this step and we hope from now on positive things will follow,'' Masire said. Kaunda was arrested on Christmas and charged with concealing prior knowledge of last October's plot by junior military officers to topple Chiluba. The attempt was quickly crushed by loyal troops. After the state dropped charges against him Monday, Kaunda said he was organizing a convention of his United National Independence Party to heal a rift in its ranks and decide on his future. Kaunda led Zambia to independence from Britain in 1964. His 27 years of dictatorial socialist rule were blamed for bankrupting one of southern Africa's poorest nations. The failed coup attempt triggered a declaration of martial law that opposition parties claimed was an excuse to crack down on opponents. (as-pr-tl)

U.S. ambassador: nuclear proliferation not only U.S. problem
TEL AVIV, Israel (AP) _ The threat of nuclear proliferation has to be confronted by the whole world, not only the United States, the U.S. ambassador to Israel said Wednesday. The ambassador, Edward Walker, was evasive when asked whether Washington's failure to prevent last month's nuclear tests by India and Pakistan was a blow to U.S. credibility and would undermine other areas of U.S. foreign policy, such as Mideast peacemaking. ``I don't follow the India-Pakistan problem closely,'' Walker said. ``I think the question of nuclear testing and so on is one that involves the whole world and not just the United States.'' An Israeli military analyst said he believed Middle Eastern countries now seeking nuclear capability, such as Iran and Iraq, would be encouraged by recent events. ``The meaning for the Middle East is that countries in region who want to have nuclear testing will know the United States may be unable to prevent them,'' said the analyst Ephraim Kam of Tel Aviv University's Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies. Other analysts said they believed the U.S. failure to prevent the nuclear tests would also spill over into Israeli-Palestinian peacemaking and encourage Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to defy the Clinton administration on a West Bank troop pullback. ``Privately, senior members of the Netanyahu Cabinet are sketching a portrait of a Clinton administration that is weak in foreign policy matters, which leads to questions about the U.S. commitment to the peace process,'' David Makovsky wrote in the Haaretz daily. dk-kl

OIL and gas consumption in Asia will continue to grow in 1998, albeit at a slower pace, an economist said yesterday. British Petroleum Plc (BP) chief economist Professor Peter A. Davies said oil consumption is expected to grow at 2 per cent or about 200,000 barrels per day (bpd) in Asia this year. ``This is lower compared with 5-6 per cent growth of oil consumption or 700,000 bpd before the economic problems started,'' he told a news conference organised by BP Malaysia Sdn Bhd. Davies, who is currently in Kuala Lumpur to attend the Third Asia Oil Gas Conference, said history has shown that energy consumption is closely linked to economic activity. ``Therefore, it is inevitable that as economic growth declines through much of Asia, growth of energy consumption will also decline,'' he added. Asia generates about one-third of the world's oil and gas. He said, however, for some economies which went through economic transitions, oil and energy consumption did not decline as much as economic growth during a period of downturn. ``Then again, as the economy recovers, energy consumption is initially less than that of the gross domestic product growth,'' he said. Davies said Asia's oil and gas industry saw a drastic drop in demand in the first quarter of this year, due to the financial disruptions in several economies. ``I suspect that would be the worst period. The future energy consumption growth of the region will now depend on how fast the region will recover,'' he said. He said the oil and gas industries in South Korea, Thailand and Indonesia, where economic changes have been greatest in recent months, are the worst hit. Davies also said oil prices for Asian brent crude have fallen from US$20 (US$1 RM3.96) per barrel in November last year to only US$14 per barrel today, down by 30 per cent. ``The cause of price decline was the coincidence of a series of negative factors: the Asian economic slowdown and El Nino both adversely affecting demand and rises in Iraqi exports, the Jakarta Opec agreement to raise quotas and the strength of oil production globally all positively influencing supply,'' he said. However, he added that there is no reason to believe that the price has to stay down. ``In the past, prices have recovered for a number of reasons - cold weather and production cuts by leading oil and gas producers. ``Nonetheless, this time, the cold weather alone will not be sufficient to rescue the market and prices as in the winter 1993/4. The market will require further production cuts for prices to recover,'' he said. Davies said currently, the world production of oil stands at 75 million bpd, with a market surplus of some 1 million bpd this year. ``It seemed clear that at the moment there is a surplus of oil production over consumption. We can see this happening based on the inventories of oil which have been rising very rapidly in all major centres across the world. ``The debate therefore within the industry is: How much production needs to be cut? The reality is that for the market to rebound, we need to have production cuts in the near future,'' he said. Davies said many oil and gas producers are expecting to see cuts enacted at the upcoming Opec meeting on June 24. However, he added, production capacity looks set to exceed demand well into 1999. ``Today's inventories of oil stand at 1 trillion barrels. This means that we would still have enough oil to last us some 40 years even if we stopped producing them,'' he said, adding that there is certainly no sign of the world running out of oil. Like other major oil and gas producers, Davies said, BP is committed to this region, ``but this is just part of our portfolio''. ``By having a global portfolio, we are protected from any slowdown or difficulties in one particular area. ``As a result, we (BP) are still posting profits and we still have very ambitious growth targets which have not been derailed by the current economic situation,'' he said. Davies said BP's future investments will be influenced by market conditions in a particular country. ``We will invest in light of opportunities ... and on a case-by-case basis. We will carry on with those commitments which we think are sound investments,'' he said.

ONE way of decreasing the number of cars on the road and hence reducing air pollution from the combustion of petrol and diesel is to use public transportation. Unfortunately, this is still not a widespread practice in our country mainly because our public transportation is unreliable. We cite an example of how difficult and frustrating it can be to get from Teluk Pulai to Bandar Sunway on a weekday in the morning using a combination of the KTM Komuter train and Intrakota bus. The KTM ride from Teluk Pulai to Subang Jaya should only take about 30 minutes. But often, because of a delay and/or breakdown, this trip can take up to an hour. The Intrakota feeder bus from the KTM station at Subang Jaya to Bandar Sunway is even more unreliable. The bus is supposed to leave the station every 30 minutes between 6.15am and 10.15pm. But most of the bus drivers refuse to leave the station on schedule if there are only a few passengers and, typically, one may have to wait an hour or two! Moreover, some drivers respond rudely if you ask them when they plan to leave. Oddly, all the drivers leave the bus engine and air-condition unit running while waiting to depart even if there are no passengers on board. This practice is not only uneconomical for Intrakota but it also generates air pollution unnecessarily. We called the Intrakota hotline in mid-March but all we got was a recording that asked us to leave our complaint and that the company would get back to us. But we have not heard from them. Neither has the bus service improved. We conducted a random survey of the buses' departure time from the Subang Jaya KTM station to Bandar Sunway from March 30 to April 2 from 7.25am. The waiting time was between 45 minutes and one hour 45 minutes. No one can afford to wait up to two hours before the bus leaves the KTM station. The only practical but expensive alternative is to take a taxi to Bandar Sunway. The taxi drivers, knowing our dilemma, are unscrupulous. They refuse to use the meter and instead charge each passenger an exorbitant amount, typically twice the metered fare. In order for public transportation to be a viable and attractive alternative to owning a car, both trains and feeder buses must run reliably in tandem. Many countries have a reliable public transportation. Why can't we? TOKYO, Tue: Japan may have its own economic worries but it also has what it takes to resuscitate the economies of East Asia, Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad said. He said Japan is the richest depressed country in the world and its capacity to grow and to be the locomotive of growth for the region is still there. It has largely cleaned up the bad practices of the past, and its Government, businessmen and people should now rehabilitate their confidence and rebuild their economy quickly. ``You have the capital, the technology, the skills and everything else needed to grow your economy. You should employ all these assets and provide the lead that the region needs,'' Dr Mahathir said at the Institute for International Monetary Affairs' symposium on ``Revitalisation of Japanese and East Asian Economies'' here today. He said Japan should buy the products of East Asian countries in order to enrich them, and help in making East Asia a market for itself and the world. ``In Malaysia we are still looking East. Many have asked us why, when it is so obvious that Japan has failed. We admit that in several areas Japan has failed. But even failures provide lessons for us. There are still many things we can learn from you. Your exceptional skills, your technology, your discipline and work ethics are still worth copying,'' Dr Mahathir said. He said what Malaysia and the rest of the region need is a revival of Japanese investments, to create jobs, to enrich the people, stimulate economic growth and incidently to create good markets for Japan. ``Some of the money the Japanese Government is pumping into your economy could very well be pumped into the troubled economies of East Asia. As before when Japanese investments created prosperity for East Asia and in turn provided good markets for Japan's products, Japanese money to revive East Asian economies would benefit these countries and Japan,'' he added. As for Malaysia, Dr Mahathir said the only way it can overcome the instability in the exchange rate and to rebuild its economy is to do away with currency in trade as much as possible. ``We will revert to bartering. We would want to balance our trade with countries which have a trade surplus with us and Japan is the country with the biggest trade surplus. Where we have to pay we will pay in the currency of the trading partner concerned,'' he said. Dr Mahathir said regionally there is agreement among the Asean economies that trade between them should be enhanced as the devaluation of their currencies is approximately at the same rate. ``We will also use our own currencies and balance our trade. This arrangement will probably be permanent, unless of course a new international financial system is put in place which will reduce violent fluctuations of exchange rate,'' he said. Dr Mahathir said Malaysia intends to revitalise its own economy through several local measures. It will take note of the various criticisms directed at it by market forces and will study their said effect on Malaysian economy including the recent devaluation of the ringgit.

I BELIEVE parents took great relief and comfort from the news ``Matriculation fees: Mara to help students'' (NST, May 28). The assurance given by the Minister of Education that most students who got places in private colleges under the universities' franchise programmes would get sponsorship of about RM8,000 a year to cover fees and living costs was a very pleasant gift. With all their financial worries now behind them, students must now show gratitude by doing well in studies and complete their tertiary education with distinction and honour. The article, however, mentioned that ``there would be students who might not get sponsorship but these would be those who were well off''. For ease of discussion I would interpret that the well-off students are those whose parents have a combined income of more than RM100,000 a year. I would like to ask whether it is fair to force these well-off students who are placed in private colleges to pay more than those students who are doing similar matriculation courses in selected boarding schools, and universities. On average, private colleges charge about RM6,000 as fees - which includes lodging (without meals) - for matriculation courses. Matriculation students in private colleges, depending on their ability, may complete their courses in two, three or four semesters. Therefore, those in private colleges will have to pay about RM11,400, RM16,800 or RM22,000 depending on how long they take. The total fees for matriculation courses in selected boarding schools, and universities are only 25 to 30 per cent of that charged by the private colleges. Students and parents were not informed of the universities' franchise programmes and the scale of fees levied by the private colleges for matriculation courses. If they had known, they would certainly have discussed with the students their ability to finance such education. Parents may encourage their offspring to take up a three-year diploma course followed by a degree later, or to do Form Six, followed by a diploma or degree course where the fees are within their budget. However, it is too late to reapply now. It is neither the students' nor the parents' fault. The so-called well-off students should not be discriminated against or made a victim of circumstances. Decisions were made based on available facts and information in the guidebook. They applied for matriculation courses at the universities, but certainly not at the private colleges, and of course were not even aware that the fees would be six to seven times higher. I understand that the purpose of franchise programmes with private colleges is to increase the number of places for matriculation students. I am grateful. I fully support it, but certainly not on the cost factor, or the manner in which it has been imposed on the students/parents. The total cost is too expensive for a foundation or pre-degree programme. The cost should have been published in the guidebook. It is material information and a deciding factor for the students and the parents. I appeal to the authorities to reduce this total cost for the franchise programme in the private colleges to a more reasonable and acceptable level. It would also be fair to inform the students on the selection criteria for a matriculation place in the universities' campuses or selected boarding schools where the fees will be much lower than the private colleges. If they do not meet the grade, they may then choose to apply for a place at private colleges under the universities' franchise programmes and pay for the higher fees as published.

TOKYO, Tues: As Asia's financial turmoil approaches a full year without signs of abating, Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad today renewed his call for a reform of the ``messy, unreliable and destructive'' international financial system. The Prime Minister told a conference of economists here that reform should aim at ensuring currency stability and check the activities of currency speculators. Dr Mahathir said with the invention of arbitrage and futures trading, the need for exchange rate stability for trading has given way to the desire of currency traders to make massive amounts of money in the shortest possible time. ``Everything points to the need for an international financial system which will bring about stability in the exchange rates among other things. ``It would be a sad commentary on the ability of the world's financial and economic geniuses if they cannot come up with proposals on a new international financial system,'' he said at the Institute for International Monetary Affairs' symposium on ``Revitalisation of the Japanese Economy and the Future of Asia''. Dr Mahathir said fixed exchange rate is no longer possible or realistic, as the political, economic and social performance of a country will have an effect on the value of its currency. He said if a country is having a revolution it is likely that its currency would be less acceptable and therefore should be devalued. As for the economy there are various indices which can be given points indicating its strength and therefore the currency. ``It is not beyond the capacity of the world's great economists to devise a measurement of the economic performance of a country using its political, economic and social indicators and then determine the relative value of its currency. ``The currency traders can still speculate but whether they buy or sell should not affect the value of the currency. ``This is of course only a suggestion. The financial experts and the economists may laugh but it will stop the currency traders from laughing all the way to the bank,'' Dr Mahathir added. Dr Mahathir said the habit of economic experts to attribute the turmoil to bad practices by governments sounds much like an apology and in defence of the currency traders. ``Money does not know whether a Government is good or bad and react by adjusting its rate of exchange. Somebody is doing that and is evidently making a lot of profit. Do we need to protect these people's interest at the expense of world trade?'' Dr Mahathir said there is nothing to indicate the need for currency trading other than the vast profits that can be made by currency traders. On the converse, the extent of the damage to the economies of whole countries and regions that currency trading can inflict is well-known. The excuse that currency trading provides market forces with the means to discipline governments is totally unacceptable, he said, as currency traders thrive on unstable currencies. ``It is ridiculous to suggest that they would discipline governments and reward them with exchange rate stability when such stability will deprive the traders of their opportunities to make money,'' he said. He said devaluation or revaluation are not the answers to the world's economic problems. Improvements in productivity can be achieved through greater skills, better management and continuous technological improvements. Dr Mahathir said as much as the East Asian region grew together by working together, they must also now work together to get out of the present economic morass. ``We must do this because we cannot allow corruptive influences to determine who supplies us with what,'' he said.

IN the treatment of rheumatic disorders the mainstay drugs are initially for pain relief. This is followed by drugs that stop the underlying disease process and reduce inflammation. Pain is the main symptom of most rheumatic disorders and pain-relieving medicines are used to control them. They include paracetamol, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and locally applied linaments and ointments. In the last five years, a better understanding of various rheumatic disorders has been created through immunology studies. That has resulted in various drugs normally used in transplant treatment being applied in rheumatic disorders, for example, cyclosporin. In the last two years, Cox-2 selective NSAIDs (meloxicam) have been introduced around the world for pain relief in rheumatic disorders. They are said to be safer than existing NSAIDs in causing less gastrointestinal complications. Up to now, all existing NSAIDs are known to cause gastric irritation. A certain herbal product has been tried in rheumatic disorders in Denmark. It is based on the patented ginger extract HMP-33 which is extracted from a special variety of ginger found only in one particular region in China. Developed over six years by a Danish team led by biochemist Dr Morten Weidner, it comes in a soft gelatin capsule. It was recently introduced here and is available over the counter. Apparently, one capsule has properties equivalent to 6,600mg of dried ginger. The largest and most recent trial to test the efficacy and safety of HMP-33 was conducted two years ago by a team of doctors from Copenhagen Municipal Hospital, headed by chief rheumatologist Dr Henning Bliddal and principal clinical investigator Dr Allan Rosetzsky. Dr Bliddal and his team had carried out a random double-blind placebo-controlled study on 56 hospital patients suffering from osteoarthritis. The findings revealed that the product can provide relief from bodily aches and seemingly without causing negative side effects. Similar clinical studies are currently being carried out in Australia and the United States. Generally, says a local doctor who requested anonymity, herbal products are not as well tested in clinical trials as medications which have to be registered for use in hospital pharmacies. He adds trials with ginger extracts in rheumatic disorders have not been actively carried out in Malaysia and local doctors are awaiting confirmatory tests before recommending such products to patients. Besides drugs to relieve pain, medication to stop the underlying disease process and reduce inflammation is also prescribed for rheumatic patients. Some patients may need disease modifying drugs to prevent fibrosis of the tissues and joints and possibly internal organ damage. Examples of such drugs include sulphasalazine, chloroquine, penicillamine, gold and methotrexate. Steroids in the correct amount and for the proper duration of treatment are given to patients to reduce inflammation which may damage the body. However, these are also the most commonly abused drugs because they are mixed illegally into herbal remedies. Rheumatic disorders cover all medical diseases of the motoric system - bones, joints, muscles and tendons - as well as those related to the connective tissue. The different diseases vary from acute backstrain and tennis elbow to osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis. That means the treatment of each rheumatic disorder is individualised and aimed at the cause and source of the pain as well as underlying inflammation. Based on Government hospital attendance records one in four Malaysians above 40 visits outpatient clinics for a rheumatic complaint. This is probably the same in private clinics.

Foreign fund managers showed concerns over the Japanese yen, which fell to 139.75 to the dollar, its lowest in seven years. The weakening yen has put pressure on other currencies in the region, with the peso slipping to 39.47. ``We are being dragged by the drop in the Japanese yen and the Hongkong market, where everyone is focused. No foreign funds are coming in,'' Jose Ricardo Garcia, an analyst at Diversified Securities Inc., said. ``Local investors just cannot prop up the market alone.'' ``Even with our gross domestic product still on the positive side, foreign fund managers are shrugging it off. They have not yet gotten over the problems of last year and are still downscaling their portfolio,'' said Grace Cerdena, an analyst at F. Yap Securities Inc. ``They are there waiting, but because of the regional drought, something is telling them not to get both their feet wet and are just waiting for stocks to again reach bargain levels,'' she said. Analysts said with the Philippines unable to isolate itself from regional developments, the composite index had yet to find a bottom. Cerdena said a good support level was at 1,800. ``There will be short-term players in the market. There might be a short rally tomorrow, with bargain-hunting on oversold issues, but any rally will not be sustainable,'' said Henry Ong of Sapphire Securities Inc. ``Foreign funds are losing their weightings on the region. Everyone is waiting for the 1,800 level, which we will likely see in the near term,'' said Allan Araullo, vice-president at Regina Capital Development Corp. ``We are looking at a recession in the region. But at these levels, there are people who started to hunt for bargains. Tomorrow, the downside may be limited considering how deep prices have gone,'' said Teresa Lee, assistant vice-president at Asiamerit Securities. Trading was very thin, with only 397.09 million shares accounting for a value turnover of P821.77 million. The selling pressure resulted in decliners swamping gainers 110 to 14, with 24 issues unchanged. Five of the six sub-indices suffered steep declines. Among the active losers were Ayala Land Inc., Meralco B, Petron Corp., San Miguel Corp. B, Ayala Corp., and Metropolitan Bank and Trust Co. Property companies shrugged off the further cut in Treasury bill rates as brokers said regional concerns far outweighed positive local news. Besides, the declining interest rates were unlikely to be sustained, they added. Diversified concern Metro Pacific Corp. fell P0.18, or 11.69%, to a three-month low of P1.36 on worries over the fate of its parent, the Salim Group of Indonesia following Suharto's ouster. ``The story behind Metro Pacific is the fear of fund managers about the Salim group now that there's a change in administration in Indonesia,'' said Carl Valentin, analyst at Asia Pacific Capital Equities Securities Corp. The rise of the Salim Group is closely associated with the rule of former President Suharto, who is a friend of the group's head Liem Sioe Liong. - With a report from Reuters

I REFER to the letter, ``Allowing anglers to fish in marine parks is not the solution'' (NST, May 22) by Wan Jamil of Alor Star. The Department of Fisheries has no intention at all, now or in future, of allowing fishing/angling to be carried out within the marine parks' waters, because these are considered critical areas where it is believed most of our marine life breed, forage or seek refuge and protection from predators. The marine parks of Malaysia are managed and administered by the Department of Fisheries, which is under the Agriculture Ministry. The department manages and administers the Marine Parks under sections 41 till 45 of the Fisheries Act 1985 (amended in 1993). Furthermore, under the same Act, the National Advisory Council for Marine Parks and Marine Reserves has been created to give advice on policy matters to the Minister of Agriculture. The council is chaired by the secretary-general of the Ministry of Agriculture and the members are from all sectors - that is, government officers (both Federal and State), representatives from non-governmental organisations, academicians from local universities and managers from the private sector. The council also acts as an overseer on actions taken by the department concerning marine parks. The department encourages the development of recreational fishing (or sport fishing), because it is a very healthy hobby and will become a very important economic activity, including providing additional income for traditional fishermen from the rural areas. However, it is believed that its development should be orderly, rational and well managed so that it is sustainable. The department has to ensure that there is no conflict between the anglers and the traditional fishermen because they could be fishing in the same areas and also that the fisheries resources are not over-exploited but are properly managed. Because of this, the Department of Fisheries has drafted a regulation for recreational fishing in Peninsular Malaysia but it has not been gazetted yet and thus not enforced. In this draft regulation, there is a provision for the Department of Fisheries to zone certain areas outside the marine park areas for certain purposes or for the use of certain fishing appliances only. There is no provision in this draft regulation to empower the department to allow fishing within the marine park areas. Section 43 of the Fisheries Act 1985 forbids any form of fishing within the marine park areas. I would like to repeat here that the department has no intention to amend any law to allow fishing within the marine park areas because they are considered as very important and critical areas for the proper usage and management of the fisheries resources of the country.

BC-Eritrea-Ethiopia, 3rd Ld-Writethru
Eritrea, Ethiopia trade charges of attacks Eritrea with attacks.
RETRANSMITTING to fix editors' note Eds: AMS. RECASTS. UPDATES throughout with Ethiopia charging AP Photos ASM101-103 of June 2 By JULIA STEWART Associated Press Writer
ASMARA, Eritrea (AP) _ Eritrea and Ethiopia, dimming hopes for a peaceful solution to their border dispute, Wednesday accused each other of cross-border attacks. Eritrea charged Ethiopia with using tanks and heavy artillery in an attack early Wednesday on the frontier village of Ambesete Geleba, 140 kilometers (90 miles) southwest of the capital, Asmara. The Eritrean Foreign Affairs Ministry accused Ethiopia of provoking ``a new and dangerous escalation'' of the border crisis, and said it was the fourth attack in less than two weeks on Eritrean positions. Hours later, Ethiopian accused Eritrean troops of attacking near Aiga and Alitena, about 20 kilometers (10 miles) on the Ethiopian side of a natural border formed by the Mereb River. ``Eritrea thought it could get away with shifting the blame to Ethiopia,'' the Ethiopian Foreign Ministry said in a statement. Both countries have consistently denied invading the other's territory. No details were available on any casualties in either attack. However, Ethiopia's state-run radio accused Eritrea of publicly executing three Ethiopian civilians it said were abducted by Eritrean troops during an earlier cross-border raid. Another 30 civilians were in the custody of the Eritrean army and their fate was unknown, said Kiros Bitow, a local official. He said about 24,700 Ethiopians had been displaced in the Badme and Sheraro areas following Eritrean invasions. Ethiopia first made public the border dispute between the two Horn of Africa neighbors on May 13, calling on Eritrea to withdraw from occupied Ethiopian territory. Ethiopia accuses Eritrea of illegally occupying a 415-square-kilometer (160-square-mile) area known as the Yirga triangle in northwestern Ethiopia, plus a half-dozen smaller areas along the border. But the underlying causes of the conflict are economic, diplomats and businessmen say. Relations between the one-time allies in a long war against the former Marxist government of Ethiopia soured when Eritrea introduced its own currency in November, triggering a trade war that has hurt both economies and reduced cross-border commerce to a trickle. Eritrea on Wednesday repeated a call for a total demilitarization of border areas and outside mediation to solve the dispute. Ethiopia said it was cooperating with peace negotiators. For the past two weeks, U.S. diplomats and regional leaders have shuttled between the two countries in a desperate effort to restore peace that has showed no signs of success. The Eritreans gained formal independence in 1993 after helping Ethiopian rebels end 17 years of harsh military rule in Ethiopia. (kjd)

French put in hard day before dinner with Les Bleus' First Fan Eds : Will be updated with president's visit
By RAF CASERT Associated Press Writer
CLAIREFONTAINE, France (AP) _ Despite a fit squad, speculation continued to surround the French team Wednesday on who will be dropped from its World Cup starting lineup. It was something even beyond the team's first fan _ President Jacques Chirac. With coach Aime Jacquet remaining quiet amidst much juggling of the team the past two weeks, rumors swirled that even leading scorer Youri Djorkaeff could be benched for France's June 12 opener against South Africa. ``You cannot just stick to what has already been set out. You need a breath of fresh air,'' Jacquet said. ``I prefer movement, even if it's not major.'' Some fear that too much movement could unbalance the team. Chirac also caused some commotion, forcing the squad to another field for training so his helicopter could land at the Clairefontaine complex for a dinner with the full team. ``We welcome the first among the French. It is a moment of pride,'' Jacquet said. ``This is super,'' Djorkaeff added. ``It's a great joy for a player to have this opportunity. Not everybody can do this.'' It was also a welcome distraction after he was mentioned as a possible ``super'' substitute, or joker, nicknamed SuperDjorker. Djorkaeff has been a key member of France's squad throughout Jacquet's four-year tenure and has scored 17 goals in 37 games. ``I'm part of the Jacquet system, I even partly created it. I can't see why I should be excluded now. Why a joker,'' he said. Jacquet's main problems have been who to select for the front, where scoring is the big headache. Offensively, the team has been built around Zinedine Zidane and Djorkaeff, but the sudden emergence of Thierry Henry and Robert Pires on the wings could alter Jacquet's plans and force him to drop a player in the middle. And since Zidane's place is beyond any reasonable doubt, Djorkaeff has become the target. ``Personally I know I will be on the team against South Africa,'' said Djorkaeff, still oozing confidence. Denmark and Saudi Arabia complete Group C. In midfield, Real Madrid's Christian Karembeu had been assumed as a certainty, especially since he should be much fitter after having played only half a season. But a disappointing few weeks have cast major doubt on his place and increased the chances of Arsenal Emmanuel Petit. Jacquet benched Karembeu for a preparation game last week. ``I was so frustrated. I wanted to play and I was on the bench, powerless,'' he said.

BC-FEA-Welcome to France,0715
France throws open her doors for World Cup, but the welcome mat is daunting AP Special Correspondent
AP Photo By MORT ROSENBLUM
PARIS (AP) _ France has thrown open her doors for the 1998 World Cup, but _ what with strikes, demonstrations and chaos _ furious visitors are having to fight their way across the welcome mat. ``This place is a catastrophe, a national humiliation,'' muttered Amer Houari, a Parisian cabbie who waited three hours for an airport fare despite long lines of passengers desperate for a taxi. ``And tomorrow is likely to be even worse,'' he added. ``It seems like the only thing we French are good at is wreaking havoc.'' Air France pilots struck Monday, canceling up to 90 percent of international flights by the official World Cup carrier a little over a week before the kickoff of a month of matches. The pilots threatened to stay out for two weeks, but talks continued in an effort to find a compromise. Meanwhile, Paris is already jammed for the French Open tennis tournament and the annual French arms fair at Le Bourget airport. Passengers who managed to find alternate flights to Charles de Gaulle Airport discovered that baggage handlers were also on strike, and luggage was dumped into a roiling sidewalk crowd outside. ``Is Paris always like this?'' asked Lily Goh, from Singapore, as her delicate orchid corsage wilted in the chaotic crush. ``We spent 13 hours flying and 10 hours waiting for our bags.'' Her husband, who had come to set up a World Cup exhibition, was seeking their luggage among a multinational maelstrom of families, business travelers, confused policemen and customs officers. Marilyn Barry, a New Yorker who had organized a canal barge trip for friends and family, gave up trying to locate a group which had come in on another airline. Her humor was wearing thin. ``What a disgrace,'' repeated Marguerite Tinguy, a Frenchwoman, as she tried to find someone to answer questions. At the airport information booth, hostesses shrugged, as bemused as everyone else. Police officers brusquely refused help, preoccupied with a snarl of buses, baggage trucks and people pushing carts. By afternoon, airlines simply gave up, and passengers had to lug their own bags from planeside while baggage handlers watched, amused. And few of the new arrivals were aware of what was in store in the days to follow. Vague threats of terrorism hang in the air. Police arrested three more people Wednesday because of intelligence that Islamic groups may try to disrupt the Cup. So far, 90 suspects have been detained around Europe. On Thursday, left-leaning unions plan a ``national day of action,'' including mass rallies at crucial points around Paris and marches that would paralyze main thoroughfares. Eight separate demonstrations were planned by workers in transport, energy, public services, health, construction and commerce. Strikes were expected to at least partially disrupt the Paris metro on Thursday and long-distance trains on Friday. In addition, railway workers called a one-day strike for June 10, the day the World Cup opens. It was not clear which trains would be affected. For most Frenchmen, ire seemed directed at Air France pilots for exploiting the World Cup to dramatize their wage complaints. As the state airline privatizes, pilots have rejected a plan to receive stock in exchange for lower wages. Some Air France captains earn more than dlrs 200,000 a year, 40 per cent more than comparable Lufthansa salaries. National political leaders condemned ``a shameful embarrassment'' after four years of planning for a trouble-free World Cup. But some French shrugged off the dispute as yet another manifestation of workers' right to strike. The popular Paris tabloid daily ``Liberation'' caught the mood, a mixture of outrage and perverse pride, with its Tuesday front page. A drawing showed a blue-white-red airplane with the grinning face of a beret-wearing Frenchman in place of the nose. The wings were formed by a long baguette sandwich clamped in his teeth. The headline read: ``Pilots: A Strike Like Only the French Can Manage.''

Does your chest go up and down when you breathe? Do you have a quick respiratory rate and little use of the diaphragm? Do you have irregular or interrupted breathing? Do you frequently sigh? If so, you have the hyperventilation syndrome, which is chronic rapid breathing. Hyperventilation is a common symptom in the seven major psychosomatic diseases like asthma, hypertension, ulcer, rheumatoid arthritis, and neurodermatitis. It is also seen in migraine, chronic pain of any origin, seizure disorders, heart disease, and among smokers. Psychiatric disorders have profound effects on both method and rate of breathing. Chronic anxiety creates, and is exacerbated by, upper chest breathing and an irregular, rapid breathing of 18.3 bpm. Panic disorder can raise the resting breath rate to 30 bpm. Researchers have also found that when psychiatric patients show clinical improvement, their breath rate often drops. Hyperventilation may be a common symptom of a disease, but it doesn't necessarily follow that it causes disease. Diseases have complex, multi-factorial origins, including physical trauma, viruses, bacteria, lifestyle, state of mind, diet, genetic predisposition, previous health history, and environment. Evidence doesn't suggest that improper breathing can be a precipitating factor in many disorders. It can also intensify or prolong pain or disease symptoms. In some cases, proper breathing can provide a cure. For inhalation to take place, the lungs, like a balloon, must be capable of expanding. The most efficient way to expand the lungs is by contracting the diaphragm and relaxing the abdomen, allowing the abdomen to expand. If the diaphragm is frozen with tension, then the chest and rib cage must move instead. The abdomen may seem to hardly move at all, creating a pattern of almost exclusively thoracic respiration. Abdominal breathing seems to have some analgesic effect. This may be due to the direct correspondence between free movement of the diaphragm and alleviation of pain. From traditional Chinese medicine's view, pain results from stuck or stagnant chi. Freedom of physical movement creates freedom of energetic movement -- chi flows and pain diminishes. Thoracic breathing doesn't allow as much air into the lungs as abdominal breathing. To compensate, the respiratory rate must increase in order to maintain the same amount of air going into and out of the lungs each minute. Hyperventilation causes the blood to lose carbon dioxide (CO2) more rapidly. Because CO2 is necessary for acid formation in the body, its loss means that the blood's acid-base (pH) balance shifts towards alkalinity (base). This decreases the ability of the blood's hemoglobin molecules to release oxygen. Normally, oxygen is a ``piggyback'' rider on the hemoglobin molecule, becoming oxyhemoglobin. During hyperventilation, the bond becomes too tight; the oxygen cannot let go. Thus, even though oxygen is in the blood, less of it is delivered to the cells, which means less energy and an impaired ability to carry on ordinary metabolic processes. The decreased levels of oxygen in the tissues have an especially pronounced effect on the heart and brain functions, as these organs require a great deal of oxygen. There is also a direct connection between hyperventilation and a tendency toward constriction and spasms in the arteries that feed both the heart and the brain. In the 1978 Journal of the American Medical Association, it was reported that hyperventilation decreases the amount of oxygen delivered to the heart's muscle or myocardium, causes abnormalities in the EKG, and increases the cardiac workload. Hyperventilation is known to be a contributing factor in ischemic (reduced blood flow) heart disease, high blood pressure, coronary insufficiency, cardiac arhythmia, and angina. The brain comprises only 2% of the body weight yet consumes more than 20% of the body's available oxygen. According to Dr. Robert Fried of Hunter College who made some intensive researches on breathing and respiratory therapies, ``Rapid breathing (i.e. hyperventilation) reduces brain blood flow, while slow, deep breathing enhances it, other factors being equal.'' Some forms of migraine are caused by chronic constriction and dilation of the arteries feeding the brain. This can be precipitated by emotional stress, diet, and rapid breathing. A loss of oxygen supply to the brain cells can also cause anxiety, stroke, and increased frequency of epileptic attacks.

Central Asian countries to meet in July
MOSCOW (AP) _ The leaders of Russia, China and three Central Asian countries will discuss regional security at a summit in Kazakstan on July 3, the Interfax news agency reported Wednesday. The meeting is intended to continue confidence-building measures started at meetings in Shanghai in 1996 and Moscow in 1997, the Kazak Foreign Ministry said. Besides Russia and China, Kazakstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan are expected to attend the meeting in Almaty, the former Kazak capital. (ls)

LIKE K. Nair (NST, May 5), I too am suffering from a high level of cholesterol. Universiti Hospital has advised me to buy Zocor. I was told the Government had decided to stop supplying expensive medicine to the public, including pensioners. A month's supply of Zocor (30 tablets) costs around RM145.00 which is far beyond the means of most pensioners.
