IN civilian society, the crime of rape is dealt with swiftly and, at most times, with appropriate justice. The perpetrator is incarcerated, the trial is set and in most circumstances, the victim is treated with respect and showered with compassion. Unfortunately, Canadians learnt recently that rape victims within the Canadian military often cannot find the same extent of justice. Often, investigations are carried out internally and the ``boys club syndrome'' inevitably applies. Shocking revelations of sexual assault and sexual harassment within the military has once again threatened the reputation of Canadian soldiers. The allegations came when Canada's premier news magazine, MacLean's, published an exhaustive investigation into alleged cases of persistent sexual harassment in the Canadian Armed Forces. The allegations are serious, involving documented cases of sexual assaults, sexual harassment, mishandling of complaints and investigations by senior officers including deliberate obstruction of investigations. Equally shocking were revelations of a culture of promiscuity in the Armed Forces, behaviour that included heavy drinking and women being treated with scant respect. The Defence Minister found himself on the defensive, unable to provide answers to such shocking claims that ``rape is commonplace in the military''. We read that these women, trained to handle rifles, grenades and machine guns, were told not to go out alone at night. Their rapists were uniformed men, entrusted with the duty and honour of protecting civilian lives. Before the publication of the MacLean's story, military brass has persistently denied that such problems exist. Now, a full-scale investigation has been launched. Bravo to responsible journalism! The Canadian Armed forces is about 6,00 strong and women account for roughly 10 per cent of the total. Although only a few courageous ones came forward with their story and grievances, it is expected that many more will do so. By coming out of the closet, these women have done an immeasurable service to other women. In particular, their profound action has potentially saved the lives of many new female recruits wanting to make a career in the military. History has repeatedly reminded us that it always takes the actions of a courageous few to change the established order in society. Take Sheldon Kennedy, for example. He was a promising hockey player who came forward with the truth about years of sexual assault by his hockey coach. It later turned out that such cases of abuse of power over young hockey players had been going on for more years than anyone had ever imagined. Sheldon Kennedy's sole act of courage has served to save the lives of countless young hockey players down the road. Today, the very fact that the crime of rape is dealt with seriously is also due largely to the courageous and persistent efforts of women who refuse to let society point a finger at them when such an inhuman crime occurs. The country salutes the actions of these unsung heroes and heroines. The Canadian Armed Forces have launched a glitzy, pricey campaign aimed at attacting more women to serve the country. Whether or not public faith can be restored into this once honourable institution will rest largely on how current investigations unfold.

THE best can be the enemy of the good. The misconceived notion that things from foreign shores are superior to local products has led to the retail industry's inclination to stuff shelves with imported goods from ice cream to apparel. Not only has this preference for foreign-made goods prejudiced our local industries to a certain extent but it has also increased the yawning gap in the balance of payments. As many have discovered during the current economic downturn, it is a costly affair to maintain such a preference. Now, those who scorned locally produced goods in the past understand the economic imperative of buying local as a means to ease inflationary pressures. But the daily grapple with escalating prices of basic food and medical charges has provoked many to question the potency of the prescription in keeping inflation at bay. Businesses defend their move to raise prices by pointing out to the burdensome operating cost due to the increase in the price of imported materials. They have a point. But it seems illogical that the cost has to be passed on to the consumers. As it is, the public is scalped in buying the food items and products since it ends up subsidising the rising operating cost of the manufacturers and the rising food bill of every service-provider from the hawker to the taxi driver. For many, continuous price hikes is an anxiety that does not dissipate despite repeated assurances to monitor prices and keep them at a reasonable level from the Domestic Trade and Consumer Affairs Ministry. Despite repeated calls from various quarters to control the prices of essential food, education fees and medical costs so as not to burden the poor, no visible effort has been taken towards that direction. In a situation when the middle-class is struggling with the price increases, one can only imagine the plight of the poor. What we find worrying is the insensitive attitude of some politicians and bureaucrats who argue that the citizenry, including the lower-income group, should adjust and shape their lives to the dictates of the current economic circumstances. True to a point. But implicit in such argument is the notion that poverty is inevitable during an economic crisis. The middle-class may wrestle with the choice of buying ikan kembung at RM8.00 per kg or imported beef at RM10 per kg but the poor cannot afford such a choice. If the price of dried ikan sepat can horrify the Domestic Trade and Consumer Affairs Minister, one can imagine the reaction of the lower-income group, particularly those who earn less than RM900 per month. The point is what is reasonable to the minister and the average middle-class may not be reasonable to the poor. Poverty is the nadir of disempowerment as illustrated by the decision of some students from poor families to discontinue studies at the tertiary level. There should be a vigorous effort to control the increases in the prices of basic food. Surely, a proactive approach is better than any hand-wringing exercise and expressions of sympathy at the price increases by the authorities. The upward changes of prices point to the lower margin of the country's self-sufficiency and the depth of its dependence on food imports. Efforts to be self-reliant in food production will bear the cumulative effect of drastically reducing our hefty food import bill of over RM11 billion. But such efforts do not obliviate the authorities' responsibility in keeping a lid on rocketing prices and in alleviating the burden of the less fortunate segment of our society.

JOHOR BARU, Mon. - It was a dream come true for two former neighbours, meeting again on Saturday after 40 years. British national Lyn Medland, 46, who left Malaysia about 40 years ago, and her former neighbour P. Paruvathy shed tears of joy when they greeted each at the Causeway. ``It is so wonderful ... I never thought this day will come,'' said Medland when met later at Paruvathy's house in Taman Johor Jaya. ``After several unsuccessful enquiries at the Malaysian and Singapore High Commissions, the Malaysian Tourism Promotion Board and British Army office, I had almost given up meeting Paru again... we are half a world apart,'' she added. Medland and her husband Clive Percival, who are on a cruise trip to Singapore, stopped over here for a day. Now living in Southampton, Medland was staying in Johor Baru with her family from 1959 to 1960 when her father was serving with the British Army's Jungle Warfare School (now Pulada in Kota Tinggi). Her intention to catch up with Paruvathy was highlighted in the New Straits Times on April 23. Paruvathy described the meeting as a miracle. ``When I saw her at the Causeway, I was speechless ... We just gave each other a very tight hug.'' Paruvathy used to work for the Medland family. The Medlands wanted her to follow them when they moved to Seremban and then back to England. However, Paruvathy was unable to do so as she had to look after her elderly mother, brothers and sisters. They lost touch with each other as the Medlands were always on the move. Paruvathy was only told of the article in the NST on May 20. She sent a letter to Medland immediately after calling up the NST Johor Baru bureau for her address in England. Concerned that the letter might not reach Medland before she set off on her cruise, Paruvathy sent a telegram on May 22. Paruvathy also sought the help of her friends here who have connections in England to inform Medland of her telephone number. Medland said: ``I received a telephone message from a person who said she had information about Paru on the morning of May 23. That same evening, I received Paru's telegram. ``I was so excited that I called Paru immediately to arrange for a meeting here. Three days later, just shortly before my husband and I set off, I received Paru's letter.'' Paruvathy and Medland literally took a trip down memory lane when they visited Medland's previous house in Johor Baru, Pulada and the Kota Tinggi waterfalls.

YEO Hiap Seng (M) Bhd, which expects its performance this year to be affected by the economic slowdown, will take measures to maintain prices and minimise passing on adjustments to consumers. He adds that the group is actively sourcing alternative raw materials and packaging materials ``to uphold our position in the Malaysian food and beverage industry''. For last year, Borhan notes that despite the need to provide for foreign exchange losses and the higher costs of materials, promotional expenses and intense competition, the group recorded a pre-tax profit of RM30.15 million from RM34.61 million the previous year. BC-Germany-Train Derails, 14th Ld-Writethru
At least 70 dead in high-speed German train crash that train derailed, hit bridge, sent car plunging.
URGENT Eds: UPDATES with new information from police on cause of crash, By CLAUS-PETER TIEMANN Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ A high-speed passenger train derailed Wednesday in northern Germany, killing at least 70 people and seriously injuring 200 as car after car of the train crumpled into the concrete base of an overpass. The crash _ Germany's deadliest rail disaster in 31 years _ happened at 11 a.m. as the Hamburg-bound train sped at 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour approaching the station in Eschede, 50 kilometers (35 miles) north of Hanover. The cause of the accident remained unclear. Police spokesman Joachim Lindenberg said it appeared that the impact of the train collapsed the overpass, sending an auto parked on the structure plunging to the tracks. The auto belonged to a rail employee who was working along the tracks, Lindenberg told German television ARD. He said that anyone that close to the accident could not have survived. Deutsche Bahn did not immediately confirm that account. Earlier reports, based on witness accounts to authorities, suggested that the auto had plunged into the train causing it to derail. Views of the wreckage offered no clear clues as to what caused the accident. The nose of the train had cleared the bridge, while the cars derailed and jackknifed into each other. At least 13 cars derailed. The force of the pile-up pushed the cars meters (yards) high into the air. The train was carrying at least 350 passengers. Regional officials said 100 people were lightly injured, in addition to the 200 serious injuries. Survivors were taken to hospitals throughout the region. The Red Cross had chartered six buses to take most of the uninjured to Hamburg, spokesman Harald Krueger said. A Deutsche Bahn executive Johannes Ludewig, said he was ``deeply dismayed and horrified by the proportions of this accident.'' The accident was the worst on Germany's premier high-speed ICE line, inaugurated in 1991. Several of the rail cars were demolished, and splintered glass covered the scene. Luggage was piled next to the wreckage as workers struggled to pry passengers from the train. More than 800 rescue workers were at the scene, including trauma surgeons and border patrol personnel who helped free passengers trapped inside the rail cars. Christian Krettek, of University Hospital in Hanover, told CNN that rescue workers expected the death toll to rise, and it was still unclear if there were more dead inside the shattered train cars. A crane was positioned to lift chunks of the bridge to reach cars underneath. The accident closed train traffic in both directions. Federal Transport Minister Matthias Wissmann, Lower Saxony state governor Gerhard Schroeder and German railway executives were en route to the scene. The ICE train is Germany's fastest, connecting all major cities at speed up to 280 kilometers (175 miles) an hour. The train travels from Munich to Hamburg, covering a distance of more than 950 kilometers (about 600 miles), in 5 hours and 37 minutes. Regular train service takes more than eight hours. The high-speed trains carry more than 65,000 passengers daily. (cb-gb-aet)

ASIAN stock markets, especially those of Singapore, Malaysia and Hong Kong, accounted for the three weakest performers among regional indices with all feeling the ripple effects from the Indonesian crisis and the drying up of liquidity. It was another poor month for Malaysian stocks, culminating with a larger-than-expected loss posted by national airline Malaysian Airline System Bhd due to heavy foreign exchange losses and decline in regional travel. The local bourse lost 17.8 per cent, according to Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI)'s latest indices used to measure the performance of international securities. Comprising over 2,600 securities in 23 developed markets and 1,600 securities in 28 emerging markets, the MSCI database reflects about 80 per cent of the world's equity market capitalisation. In Singapore, the weak Japanese yen and Wall Street's downturn contributed to a negative investment environment, with the property sector especially hit hard by fears of a possible upcoming recession, said MSCI. The island republic's stock market lost 19.0 per cent in the MSCI index. Hong Kong's bourse was down 14 per cent amid a 2 per cent drop in its gross domestic product in the first quarter of the year, the first economic contraction in 13 years, said MSCI. With unemployment rate at a historic high and falling property prices, stocks have followed their regional counterparts in a downward spiral. Troubles in Asia took place while most European developed markets continued to advance in May. The top performing developed markets were Germany (up 7.1 per cent), Belgium (up 5.9 per cent), and Austria (up 5.5 per cent). German and Belgium stocks gained on speculation of merger activities, while positive analyst comments on Austria's under-valuation relative to other European countries prompted several key shares to rise. All three countries are confirmed members of the European Monetary Union. The Russian stock market was the worst MSCI country performance in May, with economic and political problems combined to drag local stocks down 39.4 per cent. Pakistan's bourse was down 37.9 per cent as its nuclear tests brought the country's financial markets to a standstill as investors await the outcome of threatened foreign economic sanctions.

BC-Sports-Soccer-World Cup Briefs, 1st Ld
Includes items on Just Fontaine; England's drinkers; Blatter conciliatory toward Johansson; Yugoslavia beats Japan; Star Trek cure; Blatter promises 2006 World Cup to Africa
Eds: LEADS with new items
PARIS (AP) _ A lot will happen at the biggest ever World Cup, but Just Fontaine need not worry, just yet. Despite Ronaldo, Batistuta, Shearer and a slew of other prolific strikers, it is unlikely his record of 13 goals in one World Cup tournament will fall. Forty years after setting the record at the 1958 World Cup in Sweden, Fontaine is a star all over again. ``I'd better enjoy it, because the next time it's in France, I'll be in my coffin,'' the 64-year-old Frenchman said. No one has come close since, and the top-scoring title is now regularly going to a striker who gets a half dozen goals. And to think Fontaine wasn't even considered the best French forward going into the 1958 tournament, where France lost to eventual champion Brazil in the semifinals. He even scored them all with a pair of soccer boots on loan because his shoes fell apart days ahead of the finals. ___ LONDON (AP) _ Paul Gascoigne wasn't the only drunken England soccer player the night before coach Glenn Hoddle announced he was dropping the controversial midfielder from the World Cup team. England's No. 1 goalkeeper David Seaman said ``quite a few'' other England internationals were also drunk at a team party at their training base in southern Spain. Hoddle cut the 31-year-old midfielder Sunday because he said he was out of shape, setting off a controversy about whether one of England's best midfielders should have made the team. Gascoigne later admitted he was drunk at the party and then said he was drinking beer during a golf game Sunday just hours before Hoddle gave him the bad news. ___ ZURICH, Switzerland (AP) _ Swiss FIFA presidential hopeful Sepp Blatter had conciliatory words for his Swedish rival Lennart Johansson in a magazine interview published Wednesday. ``Personally I have no problem with him, but people around him are putting him under pressure,'' FIFA general secretary Blatter was quoted as saying in the Swiss weekly Schweizer Illustrierte. That pressure was leading UEFA President Johansson, the only other candidate to take over the presidency of world soccer's governing body, to say things that ``have nothing to do with fair play,'' he continued. The 198-member FIFA Congress, meeting Monday in Paris, will choose a successor to Joao Havelange, the Brazilian who has directed the sport through 24 years of unprecedented commercial success. The election brings to an end a bitter battle between the two rivals. ___ LAUSANNE, Switzerland (AP) _ Defender Sinisa Mihajlovic's second-half goal gave Yugoslavia a 1-0 victory over fellow World Cup qualifier Japan in an evenly balanced friendly match Wednesday. Hidetoshi Nakata of Bellmare Hiratsuka missed two good chances for Japan before Sinisa, who plays for Italian club Sampdoria, scored for Yugoslavia in the 71st minute. It was Japan's final warm-up match against another national side. Yugoslavia plays non-qualifier Switzerland in Basel Saturday. ___ CLAIREFONTAINE, France (AP) _ The French team is premiering the Cryo'One at the World Cup, a gun that sprays a freezing gas on a player's injury. It looks like it's right out of Star Trek, but apparently it works. ``It gets them healed a lot quicker. They're back in 48 hours,'' said French coach Aime Jacquet. Some teams still swear by the trusty sponge, others use gas canisters, but the Cryo'One is by far the most sophisticated devise so far. ``It's medical science of the modern era,'' said Jacquet. It doesn't take care of serious injuries, but it should soothe any hard knocks and have a player back in no time, the French team hopes. France is the only one of the 32 teams using the device. ___ MONROVIA, Liberia (AP) _ FIFA presidential hopeful Joseph Blatter took to the campaign trail in battle-scarred Liberia, repeating his pledge to award the 2006 World Cup to an African country. Blatter, who met with local soccer officials and Liberian star George Weah, also promised to increase funding to sport programs in this West African country which in 1996 emerged from seven years of civil war. Blatter, who is currently FIFA secretary general, was invited to Liberia by Weah, who has been one of his most outspoken supporters. ``I will not give you all of my programs for Africa right here,'' Blatter said. ``What I can promise is that if elected president of FIFA on June 8, I will give the 2006 World Cup to Africa.'' ___ MUNICH, Germany (AP) _ Whether Austrian, (scw)

BC-Sports-Soccer-World Cup-Survivors,0519
Del Piero makes it but Boksic is out AP Sports Writer
By ROBERT MILLWARD
PARIS (AP) _ Alessandro Del Piero is on Italy's squad but Alen Boksic of Croatia won't play his country's first World Cup. Del Piero's thigh injury has repaired enough for him to join Italy's bid to score a record-tying fourth triumph. But Boksic, his former Juventus colleague, won't be in the lineup because he needs knee surgery. When World Cup organizers announced the rosters for the June 10-July 12 championship, there was relief around the Italian camp and dismay among the Croatians. Del Piero suffered an injury to his right thigh during La Juve's loss to Real Madrid in the European Champions Cup final against Real Madrid two weeks ago. When Italian coach Cesare Maldini announced his provisional squad, Del Piero's name wasn't on it. But Maldini kept a place free and the nation's soccer fans, who know how important the star is to the team's chances of winning the trophy, had an anxious wait while Del Piero proved his fitness. ``It's true I feel good, but on a scale from 1 to 10, right now I am at 5,'' Del Piero told reporters Wednesday at Italy's training headquarters. ``It is clear that to play I have to be in good form. I don't want to take risks. There is no room for false steps,'' the striker said. ``The World Cup is long; it certainly does not end with the (first) game against Chile. ``The healing process is going well. It's all going according to plan,'' said Del Piero, 23. ``But I can't say any more than that. We'll wait until the work intensifies and we will see how I hold up.'' While Del Piero is getting there, Boksic will take no part in his country's first ever World Cup. The Croatians, who have a good chance of making it to the second round along with Group H favorite Argentina against debutants Japan and Jamaica, will have to do without their lanky striker. Boksic helped Juventus win the Italian league title in the 1996-97 season and contributed to Lazio's triumph in the Italian Cup in the season just ended. Described by Lazio coach Sven Goran Eriksson as ``irreplaceable,'' Boksic twisted his knee in a Serie A game April 26 and hasn't played since. The Croatians will make do with Real Madrid star Davor Suker and Goran Vlaovic of Valencia, backed up from midfield by AC Milan's Zvonimir Boban and Robert Prosinecki, who has returned from Spanish soccer to play for Croatia Zagreb. Boksic joins some big names on the World Cup sidelines. Romario, whose goals helped Brazil to a record fourth title four years ago, wept as he announced Tuesday he had not recovered from a calf muscle injury. England will be without 1990 star Paul Gascoigne, who was not considered fit enough for a gruelling championship like the World Cup and was dropped from the squad. Italy lost its first-choice goalkeeper, Angelo Peruzzi, who suffered a calf injury in a training accident on Sunday and was told he would be sidelined for a month. (rjm)

BC-South Africa-Botha Trial, 5th Ld-Writethru
Apartheid killer turns on former master at Botha trial
EDS: (AMS) RECASTS, ADDS fresh Tutu testimony AP Photos GEO 101, 102 103 By PAUL HARRIS Associated Press Writer
GEORGE, South Africa (AP) _ Police death squad commander Eugene de Kock killed and maimed for years to defend apartheid, leaving a trail of misery that earned him a 212 year jail sentence. But on Wednesday he turned on white-run South Africa's last hardline president P. W. Botha, branding him a coward who sold out the men who did apartheid's dirty work. Testifying in Botha's trial for ignoring a summons by a panel probing apartheid era crimes, de Kock was asked by state prosecutor Bruce Morrison how it felt to be in jail while top politicians and generals remained free. ``They want to eat lamb but they don't want to see the blood and the guts,'' said de Kock, whose ruthlessness earned him the nickname Prime Evil. ``They are cowards. They will remain that.'' Botha has refused to testify in person before the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, submitting instead thousands of pages in answer to written questions. He also ignored pleas last year by panel chairman Nobel Laureate Desmond Tutu that he and other apartheid era leaders should apply for amnesty from the commission. But this week he is being confronted with evidence of his complicity in atrocities. The commission has submitted dozens of documents suggesting the State Security Council, which Botha headed, sanctioned killing black liberation fighters. Wearing a blue pullover and jeans, de Kock said he never doubted his killing spree was approved by the highest echelons of the state. Minutes from SSC meetings that described how opponents should be ``neutralized'' or ``eliminated'' have been submitted as evidence. Botha and other top government officials claim they meant people should be detained. Speaking softly but firmly, de Kock said he interpreted the words more harshly. ``In the terminology that they used it means killing,'' he said, peering at the packed courtroom through thick-lensed rectangular spectacles. Botha, 82, wearing a grey business suit, looked on impassively. De Kock commanded the Vlakplaas police unit that assassinated black anti-apartheid activists. Tutu also took the stand on Wednesday, saying it pained him to appear in court and adding that it was not too late for Botha to halt the court case. ``I tried to reach out to Mr. Botha. I reached out to him out of deep compassion,'' said the retired Anglican Archbishop. ``Even now I hope reason will prevail.'' However, Tutu attacked Botha and other apartheid leaders for covering up crimes during their rule. ``I told our people, `Don't worry. A lie such as this thing will not prevail forever','' he said.``I have been vindicated in the most spectacular way.'' Much of the trial has focused on the 1988 bombing of Khotso House, the Johannesburg headquarters of an anti-apartheid group. A former head of South Africa's police has said Botha ordered the bombing and de Kock carried it out. Botha denies he ordered the bombing. Botha's defense team declined to cross-examine two witnesses to the bombing. The trial is being held in the southern coastal city of George, near Botha's retirement home. He faces up to two years in prison and unspecified fines if convicted. Apartheid ended after Botha's successor, President F.W. de Klerk, negotiated with the African National Congress for the first all-race elections in 1994. The ANC won the election. (phs-pr-tl)

BC-Ukraine-US
U.S. ambassador urges Ukraine to push ahead with economic reforms
By SERGEI SHARGORODSKY Associated Press Writer
KIEV, Ukraine (AP) _ U.S. Ambassador Steven Pifer urged Ukraine on Wednesday to push ahead with economic reforms, saying the country faced a fierce battle with the rest of the world for foreign investment and had no time to lose. ``Time is growing short, and fundamental reforms are needed to gain market confidence,'' Pifer told a business development forum in Kiev. Resource-rich Ukraine, the third-largest recipient of American aid, has been relatively slow in implementing economic reforms. The country of more than 50 million people has attracted only dlrs 2 billion in direct foreign investment since the 1991 Soviet collapse. It has resorted to heavy foreign borrowing and is struggling to meet the terms for a major International Monetary Fund loan. Pifer noted such achievements as Ukraine's democratic transition of power, growing links with the West, stable currency and successful fight against hyperinflation. But ``the years since Ukraine regained its independence have also been years of disappointment, of decline and stagnation, of unrealized potential, particularly in the economic field,'' Pifer said. ``People are starting to associate democracy, freedom and a market economy with poverty and corruption.'' Pifer said business and investment were stifled by Ukraine's ``complex, confusing and high taxes,'' over-regulation, arbitrary decisions by mid-level officials and inability to enforce contracts. ``The message to the foreign investor all too often is that he should go elsewhere,'' he said. The ambassador warned that Ukraine is facing a ``fierce and immediate ... competition with the entire world'' for the investment dollar. ``The sad fact is that Ukraine is losing this competition, and losing badly,'' Pifer said. Pifer said Ukraine needed to adopt and enforce business laws, tackle widespread corruption, support small- and medium-sized enterprises, pursue de-regulation, slash its heavy foreign borrowing, and implement fundamental reforms in the huge energy and the potentially rich agricultural sectors. The ambassador also urged Ukraine's new, leftist-dominated parliament, the Verkhovna Rada, to set aside political infighting and differences with President Leonid Kuchma and ``support a program that serves Ukraine's future.'' ``Ukraine must help itself by pressing ahead with reform,'' Pifer said. ``The international community stands ready to help. There is little time to lose.'' (sms/ls)

BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo, 3rd Ld-Writethru
Precede PADESH As Kosovo Albanians flood over border, their leaders plead for help officials in Pristina, seeking intervention, villages shelled and aflame, NATO considering deploying troops, other new material. Changes dateline, byline.
Eds: AMs. UPDATES with ethnic Albanian leaders meeting with Western AP Photos By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Ethnic Albanian leaders pleaded with Western officials Wednesday for military intervention to halt what they said is a deliberate Serb strategy of forced expulsions from Kosovo, as more refugees poured over the border to Albania. The request came with no sign of a letup in the Serbs' offensive aimed at smashing resistance to their authority in the secessionist province of southern Serbia, where ethnic Albanians outnumber Serbs 10-to-1. According to Albanian sources, Serb forces shelled at least five villages Wednesday in an area of western Kosovo near the Albanian border, sending more residents fleeing. Houses were set ablaze in the attack by Serb police and paramilitary units, backed by Yugoslav army tanks. New casualty reports from the sealed-off area were not available. Dozens are believed dead since the start of a stepped-up campaign last week by the Serbs, who want to wipe out the pro-independence Kosovo Liberation Army. At least 80 people were killed in a similar crackdown in March, and well over 200 people have died this year in clashes. Top aides to Ibrahim Rugova, the president of the Albanians' self-described independent government, met with a European delegation in Kosovo's capital Pristina on Wednesday. They told the officials that ``ethnic cleansing and massacres carried out by Serb forces in western Kosovo are a part of a planned-out scheme of ethnic cleansing throughout the province.'' The situation is dramatic and NATO must intervene, they told the delegation of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, headed by Javier Ruperez. They said world powers also must pressure Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, who is determined to keep Kosovo from breaking away from Serbia, one of two remaining republics in Yugoslavia. ``Unless there is significant international pressure on Belgrade, chances for a peaceful solution to the crisis will be lost forever,'' Alush Gashi said. But NATO allies, with 34,000 troops already in neighboring Bosnia, are reluctant to commit another big contingent to the Balkans. Meeting in Brussels on Wednesday, they agreed to consider again whether to deploy combat troops to Albania and Macedonia on Kosovo's borders, but indicated a decision is not imminent. ``We all agreed we cannot proceed until we have solid, well-thought out military advice,'' said a NATO official who asked not to be named. Ambassadors of the 16 NATO nations did agree to accelerate other measures, including technical and military assistance for Albania and Macedonia. Besides thousands of displaced Kosovo residents who have sought shelter in border highlands, several thousand others have streamed over the border into Albania. OSCE spokesman Bill Foxton confirmed at the Albanian border that at least two refugees had died as a result of the arduous trek over the mountains _ a 60-year-old man of a heart attack and a 4-year-old girl who died when her mother, who was carrying her, slipped and fell on a rocky path. International monitors near the border said houses could be seen in flames in the besieged village of Junik, and Konoshevac was being shelled. Both are in Kosovo's targeted Decani region. A spokesman for the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees said 2,000 refugees crossed overnight into Albania, bringing the total to some 3,700 since the Serb assault was launched late last week. Most are women, children and elderly who are ``exhausted mentally and physically,'' spokesman Kris Janowski said in Geneva. Albania's state-run ATA news agency said about 3,000 more refugees were approaching the border. Local authorities in northeastern Albania, site of most of the crossings, said that with more refugees arriving by the hour, the 25 tons of aid sent Tuesday by the U.N. refugee agency was inadequate. In a report documenting growing reluctance to die for Kosovo, the daily Telegraf, published in Belgrade, reported that about 100 policemen had been fired for refusing to go fight in the province. TEHRAN, Iran (AP) _ An outlawed Iranian opposition group claimed responsibility Wednesday for a bomb and two mortar attacks on government buildings that killed at least three people. In the Iraqi capital, Baghdad, a spokesman for the opposition group, the Mujahedeen Khalq, warned of more attacks. ``Our units inside Iran will escalate attacks against the regime,'' Mohammad Mohaddessin told The Associated Press. The official Islamic Republic News Agency denied the bombing was the work of the Mujahedeen, but Tehran's Governor General Mohammad Reza Ayatollahi was reported by state-run television Wednesday as saying the opposition group was behind the attack. In a statement Wednesday, the Mujahedeen said it carried out the bombing as well as two mortar attacks Tuesday on the Central Command Headquarters of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps and the Defense Industries Organization in the capital. The Mujahedeen statement said the three attacks were in retaliation for the killing of its members by the Iranian government in recent months. ``In the surprise attack, several Revolutionary Guards were killed or wounded and the headquarters' buildings were damaged,'' the group said in a statement faxed to The Associated Press in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. It did not claim any casualties for the attack on the defense industries building. However, Iranian radio said security men foiled an attempted attack by ``saboteurs'' at the Revolutionary Guards headquarters Tuesday and the perpetrators fled. Official media did not speak of an attack on a Defense Industries building, but they did report a bomb explosion at an unidentified government building in northern Tehran late Tuesday. It was not known if this property belonged to Defense Industries. There was no report of casualties in this bombing. The Iranian newspaper Farda had reported Tuesday that 50 Mujahedeen fighters had sneaked into Iran across the largely unguarded border with Afghanistan. In Baghdad, Mohaddessin said the Mujahedeen military camps in Iraq, close to the Iranian border, were on alert for expected reprisals from the Tehran government. Also Wednesday, police evacuated guests and staff at the Ferdowsi Hotel in central Tehran following a bomb threat made by a caller, sources said. Three government-controlled newspapers said five people were killed, and one added that another nine people were injured. av-fsa/av-jbm

Russian government prepares to tackle 2000 computer Problem
MOSCOW (AP) _ The Russian government has ordered its computer experts to develop ways to resolve the so-called Year 2000 problem, a news agency reported Wednesday. Government technicians have three months to analyze their systems and determine how much software needs to be changed, and what hardware, if any, needs to be replaced, Interfax said. The Year 2000 problem, arises because many computers, originally programmed to recognize only the last two digits of a year, may be unable to distinguish between the years 2000 and 1900 because their codes represent those years as simply 00. Some computers can be reprogrammed through tedious review of their software code, but many devices have embedded microchips that must be physically replaced. (ad/ls)

ALPE DI PAMPEAGO, Italy (AP) _ Pavel Tonkov edged overall leader Marco Pantani by one second Wednesday to claim the 18th stage of the Tour of Italy after the race's top two riders made a late breakaway on the final climb in the Alps. The tough, 115-kilometer (71.3-mile) stage ended at an altitude of 1,760 meters (5,808 feet) above sea level. Pantani finished second for the second straight stage, and held onto the pink jersey heading into the last four days. The Italian leads Tonkov, the 1996 Giro champion and runner-up last year, by 27 seconds in the overall standings. ``I'm not made of steel. I'll give my all again tomorrow, but my adversaries are strong,'' Tonkov said. ``Marco Pantani was in brilliant shape. He pedaled strongly going uphill.'' Favorite Alex Zuelle, who had dominated the cycling classic until it headed into the mountains, lost more time Wednesday. He faltered on the final uphill pass and was fourth, 58 seconds behind Russia's Tonkov. Nicola Miceli was third Wednesday. Zuelle now trails Pantani by more than two minutes overall. Colombia's Chepe Gonzales rode alone at the lead for more than 40 kilometers (25 miles), but was eventually caught by a pack of 22 riders heading into the final climb. Zuelle tried to take off ahead of the leaders but was reeled in, setting the stage for Tonkov and Pantani to break away with 4 kilometers (2.5 miles) left. Tonkov was clocked in 3 hours, 36 minutes, 54 seconds. Nicola Miceli was third, 44 seconds off the pace. Pantani, sidelined for the entire 1996 season with a broken leg, vaulted from fourth to first place Tuesday. The 22-stage race ends Sunday in Milan. ``If I want to reach Milan with the pink jersey, I need to gain some minutes, but it won't be easy,'' said Pantani, who rides for the Mercatone Uno team. ``We'll have to see what happens tomorrow. I think the man in the best condition will emerge victorious. Tonkov looked in good form.'' Thursday's 19th stage is the toughest of the race, with grueling climbing during the 239 kilometers (148 miles) from Cavalese to Plan di Montecampione. (hjf)

ANKARA, Turkey (AP) _ Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz said Wednesday he would resign at the end of the year to pave the way for early elections in April. Yilmaz said April 18 was a likely date for the elections. ``A caretaker government will be formed to take us to the elections,'' Yilmaz said, adding that he would discuss with President Suleyman Demirel the composition of the new government. Yilmaz's fragile coalition relies heavily on the support in Parliament of the 56 CHP deputies. Yilmaz came to power last year in a coalition of three parties -- his center-right Motherland Party, the Democratic Left Party and the Democratic Turkey Party -- after the military forced the previous, Islamic-led government out of power. At issue are land sales in the West Bank, Gaza Strip and east Jerusalem, areas captured by Israel in the 1967 Mideast war and claimed by the Palestinians for a future state. Blair accused the Scottish Nationalists of being ``irresponsible and extreme.'' ``There is absolutely no evidence whatever to back up the suggestion ... that any material has been stolen or fallen into terrorist or foreign government hands,'' Blair said in the House of Commons. ``No such material has ever been sent from Dounreay for use for UK weapons purposes.'' SHARI BASURKH, Afghanistan (AP) _ Afghanistan's deposed President Burhanuddin Rabbani says the international response to the deadly earthquake was too slow, as survivors in some of the remotest regions still waited Wednesday for help to arrive. Rabbani arrived by helicopter in Shari-Basurkh _ one of the hardest hit areas _ on Sunday to see the devastation wreaked by Saturday's 6.9 quake and to settle a dispute between feuding commanders. The northern-based alliance established to stop the Taliban religious army from consolidating its hold on Afghanistan has been fraught with internal disputes. Several of them have turned violent. The feuding comes as residents of the area were trying to dig themselves out from beneath the rubble caused by the deadly quake that killed as many as 5,000 people, wiped out entire villages and left as many as 60,000 people homeless. The U.N. and the Red Cross have been coordinating their relief efforts attempting to make several many helicopter runs a day from Faisabad to remote villages to pick up the wounded, drop off blankets, plastic sheeting and tents. ``We are trying to get in more helicopters ... this is where the bottleneck has been,'' said Philip Spoerri, a Red Cross spokesman in neighboring Pakistan. Until now he said the priority has been to get the wounded out and medical supplies to the hardest hit areas and it hasn't been easy. He said 3.5 tons of medical supplies were to be sent to Faisabad from Pakistan today. Much of the area is inaccessible by road. In Shari Basurkh, near the epicenter, half the village was flattened by the violent shaking. The quake struck during the late morning when most of the men were in the fields, which is why aid workers say the bulk of the wounded are women, old men and children _ all of whom had been in their homes at the time of the trembler. In a makeshift clinic set up in an elementary school, a baby on an intravenous drip lay screaming next to a woman whose face was covered by yellow bruises. Most people here had not eaten since the earthquake hit, Most of the injured _ fearing aftershocks _ wanted to stay outside. Some slept on bare ground. ``They really worry about the future ... because they don't have any shelter, any food, I think they have a very bad future,'' said Abdul Rahim, a local doctor. A toddler lay with his head wrapped in thick layers of gauze, staring listlessly. Inside the school a few women and children lay under coarse hair blankets, as their relatives tried to comfort them. A woman lay sleeping with an intravenous drip draped over two-brightly colored bracelets on her arm and a bottle on a nail in the cracked wall. Nearby a mother waved one hand over her ailing daughter trying to create a breeze, while trying with the other hand to keep her child from fiddling with the intravenous needle stuck in her wrist. Valerie Purcell, a nurse with Merlin humanitarian aid agency, sat in a tent outside the clinic encouraging an injured woman to drink water to produce more breast milk for her tiny baby cradled against her knees. ``Many people are very badly traumatized,'' she said ``They are telling me their stories ... they all need to tell.'' The United Nations has put out an appeal for helicopters worldwide saying it has the aid ready to distribute to the victims of the earthquake but limited means to get it to them. The rugged mountain region has no roads leading from the Badakshan capital of Faisas 2,300 people and leaving thousands more homeless.

BC-Germany-Train Derails, 15th Ld-Writethru
At least 70 dead in high-speed German train crash
Eds: ADDS reference to 1967 accident, deadliest since World War II By CLAUS-PETER TIEMANN Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ A high-speed passenger train derailed Wednesday in northern Germany, killing at least 70 people and seriously injuring 200 as car after car of the train crumpled into the concrete base of an overpass. The crash _ Germany's deadliest rail disaster in 31 years _ happened at 11 a.m. as the Hamburg-bound train sped at 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour approaching the station in Eschede, 50 kilometers (35 miles) north of Hanover. The cause of the accident remained unclear. Police spokesman Joachim Lindenberg said it appeared that the impact of the train collapsed the overpass, plunging an auto that had been parked on the structure. The auto belonged to a rail employee who was working along the tracks, Lindenberg told German television n-tv. He did not say whether the rail employee was hurt. Earlier reports, based on witness accounts to authorities, suggested that the auto had plunged into the train causing it to derail. Views of the wreckage offered no clear clues as to what caused the accident. The nose of the train had cleared the bridge, while the cars derailed and jackknifed into each other. At least 13 cars derailed. The force of the pile-up pushed the cars meters (yards) high into the air. The train was carrying at least 350 passengers. Regional officials said 100 people were lightly injured, in addition to the 200 serious injuries. Survivors were taken to hospitals throughout the region. The accident was the worst on Germany's premier high-speed ICE line, inaugurated in 1991. Ninety-four people were killed in a 1967 rail accident, Germany's deadliest since World War II, when a barrier closed on a rail tanker filled with gasoline, causing it to explode setting the train on fire. A Deutsche Bahn executive Johannes Ludewig, said he was ``deeply dismayed and horrified by the proportions of this accident.'' Several of the rail cars were demolished, and splintered glass covered the scene. Luggage was piled next to the wreckage as workers struggled to pry passengers from the train. More than 800 rescue workers were at the scene, including trauma surgeons and border patrol personnel who helped free passengers trapped inside the rail cars. Christian Krettek, of University Hospital in Hanover, told CNN that rescue workers expected the death toll to rise, and it was still unclear if there were more dead inside the shattered train cars. A crane was positioned to lift chunks of the bridge to reach cars underneath. The accident closed train traffic in both directions. Federal Transport Minister Matthias Wissmann, Lower Saxony state governor Gerhard Schroeder and German railway executives were en route to the scene. The ICE train is Germany's fastest, connecting all major cities at speed up to 280 kilometers (175 miles) an hour. The train travels from Munich to Hamburg, covering a distance of more than 950 kilometers (about 600 miles), in 5 hours and 37 minutes. Regular train service takes more than eight hours. The high-speed trains carry more than 65,000 passengers daily. (cb-gb-aet)

BC-Iraq-Warheads, 2nd Ld-Writethru
In protective gear, U.N. experts search for Iraqi missile warheads
Eds: CORRECTS misspelling of name in graf 19, no pickup AP Photos planned By LEON BARKHO Associated Press Writer
Al-NIBAI, Iraq (AP) _ United Nations weapons inspectors searched through reeds and sand dunes Wednesday for missing missile parts in a bid to verify Iraq's claims that it has buried all its biological and chemical missile warheads. Wearing protective suits, masks, boots and gloves, some 27 experts under German Jean Jano used metal detectors and other equipment in their search at Al-Nibai, 45 kilometers (28 miles) north of Baghdad. Others supervised an earth-moving machine as it uncovered the nose cone of a missile warhead. ``This belongs to a conventional warhead,'' shouted an Iraqi engineer. In 1991, Iraq chose to destroy a great number of its long-range missiles and bury them rather than declare them to U.N inspectors, which has complicated the verification process. Iraq claims it has destroyed its entire arsenal, and that it is impossible to account for every warhead. The United Nations says it cannot take Iraq's word. ``We hope that this work will help to settle some of the still outstanding issues concerning the missile warheads,'' Jano, 61, told The Associated Press. It is the first time a Western news organization was allowed at a weapons search site. Jano refused to say how far his team has progressed in verifying Iraq's claims, or how many parts it has collected so far. But Brig. Ismael Saeed Ahmad, the Iraqi official who supervised the 1991 destruction and burial at al-Nibai, said U.N. monitors have so far recovered enough parts to account for 49 biological and chemical warheads. He did not say how many were buried. As for conventional warheads, only 10 remain unaccounted for, he told the AP later in Baghdad. The area where Iraq buried its missiles is vast. Experts with magnetic and electro-magnetic sensors placed small, red flags on the ground to mark the next dig. ``We've with us some of the latest state-of-the-art high-tech equipment,'' said Vincent Murphy, a 69-year-old geophysicist from Boston. ``It is all digitally recorded. The data is brought back in the recorder to one of the vehicles and downloaded to the laptop.'' Advanced equipment is needed because satellite images cannot penetrate the soil at al-Nibai, he said. Jano said inspectors found ``aluminum canisters that are used for chemical agents and some stainless steel canisters ... used for biological agents.'' The excavation is scheduled to end June 18. Jano said another team will arrive in Baghdad soon to analyze the findings, now stored at Taji, a military camp 20 kilometers (12 miles) north of Baghdad. Senior Iraqi officers looked on as the experts searched. The Iraqis refuse to wear safety gear, saying the pieces of scrap underground are non-toxic. U.N. monitors burn their suits every day, and wash their hands and feet in a bleach solution before leaving the site. Accounting for special warheads is one of the main hurdles in Iraq's efforts to declare itself clean of prohibited missiles with ranges beyond 150 kilometers (90 miles). Ahmad, the Iraqi brigadier, claimed all such missiles have now been accounted for. In addition, U.N. inspectors are believed to have accounted for 817 of the 819 Scud missiles in Iraq's arsenal. Until the inspectors certify that Iraq is rid of its weapons of mass destruction, the U.N. Security Council will not lift the sanctions slapped on Baghdad in 1990 after President Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait. lb/vj

BC-Iran-Khatami,0280
Khatami plans to visit New York, address United Nations
By AFSHIN VALINEJAD Associated Press Writer
TEHRAN, Iran (AP) _ President Mohammad Khatami, who has sought a more moderate course for Iran since his election a year ago, plans to go to the United States to address the U.N. General Assembly in September, a government official said Wednesday. Referring to the planned address as a ``very important speech,'' the official said Khatami would discuss the position of Muslims in the world and in the United Nations. The statement was the first announcement of the planned trip, though such a visit had been rumored for days. The trip would require U.S. government permission. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Khatami would urge the United Nations to give Islamic nations a permanent seat on the Security Council. Breaking through nearly 20 years of hostility, Khatami called for a dialogue with Americans and more cultural and educational exchanges in a broadcast interview last January. Two previous Iranian presidents have addressed the United Nations since the 1979 Islamic revolution. But both used their speeches to attack the United States. Khatami could instead make a gesture to American leaders. Khatami will also use his trip to meet the 2 million strong Iranian community in the United States, the official said. Many Iranians fled their country to settle in the United States and other Western countries after the revolution. The United States severed ties with Iran after militants stormed the U.S. Embassy in Tehran in 1979 and held 52 Americans hostage for 444 days.

BC-Africa-EU
EU leaders visit Burundi
BUJUMBURA, Burundi (AP) _ A European Union delegation expressed optimism Wednesday that neighboring countries will at least suspend an embargo against Burundi. The resumption of peace talks in Arusha, Tanzania on June 15 ``should lead, at least, to a suspension of sanctions,'' said Tony Lloyd, British Foreign Office Minister responsible for Africa and leader of the three-member delegation. ``The evolution of the situation inside the country will progressively eliminate the reasons for the embargo,'' he said. With Lloyd were representatives from Austria and Luxembourg, plus Aldo Ayello, the European Union's special envoy to the Great Lakes region. They later left for Kinshasa, Congo. African countries imposed an embargo against Burundi to pressure Pierre Buyoya, who took power over the central African country in a coup in July 1996, to negotiate with the majority Hutu opposition. Buyoya argued he was the only one capable of halting fighting between minority Tutsis and majority Hutus that has claimed more than 200,000 lives since 1993. The violence has not stopped. Hutu rebels are trying to oust Buyoya's Tutsi-led government and army and reinstate a Hutu as president. Tutsi paratroopers assassinated the country's first democratically elected president, a Hutu, in October 1993. Tutsis, who make up just 14 percent of Burundi's population of 6 million, have controlled the country for all but four months since independence in 1962. Hutus make up 85 percent of the population. KUALA LUMPUR, Mon.- Deputy Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim called for efforts to remove deep-seated suspicions and hostility between nations. He said in conflicts, it is the people who pay the price, not the state, and it is the poorest and the weakest who bear the brunt of suffering. Speaking at the opening of the 12th Asia Pacific Roundtable -Confidence Building and Conflict Reduction, Anwar said: ``We must arrest this drift to violence and nuclear adventurism. ``We must oppose opportunistic politicians who fan the flames of jingoism, be it in the name of religion or state.'' Anwar, alluding to an Asia with at least three nuclear powers despite grappling with poverty, said only a civil society could provide a framework for the removal of suspicion and distrust and heal the wounds of history. ``Thus, the promotion of civil society must be the prime concern of diplomacy in Asia. A healthy state-civil society relationship will contribute to the reduction of differences in political practices, strengthen the marketplace and promote freedom. ``A culture of democracy, founded on universal principles of liberty, is the sine qua non (an essential requirement) for peace in this world. In all this, persuasion must be our greatest weapon.'' The speech also dissected what Anwar saw as ``cold reasoning of realpolitik'' of conducting affairs among nations according to calculations of power and national interest. He also discussed how science and knowledge had exploded into minute branches. ``New disciplines of knowledge are being born every day.'' He said ethics and morality were scoffed at as intrusions of the unrealistic and the impracticable into the cold-blooded affairs of the state. ``As for the interest of the state, more often than not, neither the fate nor the welfare of the ordinary people enters into the equation.'' The roundtable which started yesterday and due to end on Wednesday, is being attended by policy makers and academicians from the United States, Australia, Brunei, Cambodia, Canada, China, the Philippines, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, North Korea, Laos, Malaysia, Mongolia, New Zealand, Russia, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam. Held at Hotel Nikko, it is organised by Asean-Isis and Isis Malaysia. The New Straits Times is one of the sponsors. Among the notable panelists are Thai Foreign Minister Dr Surin Pitsuwan, former South Korea Foreign Minister Prof Hang Sung-Joo, Andrew Sheng who is deputy chief executive of Hong Kong Monetary Authority, former Foreign Minister Tan Sri Ghazali Shafie, acting director of Japan Insitute of International Affairs, Makoto Katsura, and Associate Professor Dr Anthony Bergin of Australian Defence Studies Centre, University College, Australian Defence Force Academy. Among the topics of discussion were Currency Turmoil in Asia: The Strategic Impact, The Threat from the Haze: What Must Be Done?, The Strengthened Non-Proliferation Treaty Review Process and The 1999 Non-Proliferation Treaty and Preparatory Committee, and The United States and China : A New Era of Relations. Anwar also said that the global economy was rushing into the third industrial revolution - from the age of steam engine, followed by the automobiles and aeroplanes and now the information revolution. ``We have to reinvent our economic policies to bring them in line with the information age. A new economic age brings with it new challenges, to which we have to respond. The road to destruction is paved with stubbornness in sticking to old modes of thinking.''

WHEN it comes to the interior design of hotels or office complexes, the name AxisNetwork Design Consultant Sdn Bhd keeps coming up these days and for good reason. The company's special touches at hotels in Kuala Lumpur and Port Dickson and office complexes recently won it ISO 9001 certification, a badge of merit for quality in design, development, production, installation and servicing. The company's ``Midas touches'' can be seen at the Ming Court Vista Hotel in Jalan Ampang which had its new look launched in December last year. Other hotels include the Radisson Plaza Hotel, Equatorial Hotel, Swiss Garden Hotel, Dynasty Hotel and Stanford Hotels in Kuala Lumpur. The company has also designed the interiors of several resorts outside Kuala Lumpur such as the Guoman Resort and Avillion village resort in Port Dickson and Cherating. It has also done work at other establishments like the Gleaneagles Hospital, Jalan Ampang, and the PhileoAlied corporate office in Kuala Lumpur. Its managing director Foo Fatt Chuen said the company was undertaking the refurbishment of Hyatt Regency Saujana Hotel in Subang due for completion next month. He said the interior design created by the company would greatly depend on factors like requirements stated by the building owner. ``From the building owner/operator's design brief, we plan our design,'' he said. For offices, he said the design would have to take into consideration the client's corporate image. ``Take for instance our design for PhileoAllied. Since its concept is people oriented, we designed a simple interior to enable interaction between people,'' he said. ``The concept of simple interior also applies at the company's bank.'' Creating interior designs for hotels is, however, different as there will be more than one concept used. ``Different types of space will need different designs to create the required atmosphere although we will try to link as much as possible the design of the public area such as the lobby with the private area such as the room,'' he said. Nonetheless, some of the space in a hotel need to have its individual design, for example, the restaurants where the design should reflect the themes that they are carrying. He said AxisNetwork was established in 1991 with only three staff including himself. However, with the booming economy of the country then, the company did not take long to progress in the business. From three, the workforce grew to 38 when the construction industry was at its peak last year. The company's capability in delivering beautiful interior design has won the confidence of corporate clients such as IGB Berhad, Mycom Bhd, Olmpia Land Bhd, Reliance Pacific Bhd, Lion Corporation Bhd, Hong Leong Corporation Bhd, YTL Industries Bhd, Tan Tan Development Bhd, Malaysian Tobacco Co. Bhd, Uniphoenix Corporation Bhd, MBf Finance Bhd, Phileo Allied Bhd, Phileo Allied Bank, Parti Gerakan Rakyat Malaysia, Mulpha International Bhd and Konsortium Perkapalan Bhd. ``Now that the economy has slowed and the volume of projects we receive have also declined, we have to retrench some of the staff but the retrenchment was carried out voluntarily,'' he said, adding that the company now had about 20 staff only. Being closely connected to the construction industry, Foo said AxisNetwork was badly affected by the economic downturn as its revenue depended greatly on clients' ability to pay for the services. The economic slowdown, however, does not mean no business at all for the company as there are still more good projects currently being carried out. ``Among the projects being carried include the refurbishment of Hyatt Regency Saujana Hotel in Subang which will be completed in July, The Westin Kuala Lumpur, Novotel Hotel Kuala Lumpur and Century Hotel Kuala Lumpur; the Deputy Prime Minister's house in Putrajaya and Putrajaya JW Marriott Hotel on which we will start soon,'' he said. He said gaining ISO 9001 certification, besides being an assurance of good quality service to its customers, was also a stepping stone to better and bigger business opportunities locally and abroad. He said the company had started exporting its services abroad, like to Singapore and Thailand for the past five years or so. That is in line with the company's objective of being internationally acknowledged by its customers.

The Land Bank of the Philippines (LandBank) will push for the alliance of agricultural cooperatives into larger, more stable blocs to enhance their capabilities in undertaking bigger economic activities and prepare them for unrestricted global trade. Atty. Jesus Diaz, acting LandBank president, said the move would help farmer and fisherfolk cooperatives cope with the challenge of developing into self-sustaining business units. ``In view of globalization and market liberalization, we want to encourage the cooperatives to upgrade their existing capabilities and maturity level, and help them become competitive and highly innovative in their respective trade or business,'' Diaz said. On the local front, the inter-agency Tariff and Related Matters (TRM) committee is currently reviewing the tariff structure of sensitive agricultural products, which include rice and corn, as part of adjustment measures in line with the country's regional trade commitment. In keeping up with the realignment of economies toward global integration, an increasing number of companies, including the biggest names in their respective industries, have resorted to merger, buy-outs, and alliances primarily to keep their operations afloat in a tightening field of competitors. LandBank wants to cut down the number of cooperative units from the present 8,000 to between 2,500 and 3,000 by integrating forces and establishing at least one strong cooperative in every municipality. Moreover, such mergers will enable the cooperatives to become more stable suppliers of goods and services, and provide training and financial intermediation to members of other cooperatives, aside from promoting better bargaining power and economies of scale. As an initial step, government agencies such as Department of Agriculture, Department of Agrarian Reform, the Cooperative Development Authority, and the Technology and Livelihood Resources Center should initiate the merger of differently registered but overlapping cooperatives to consolidate their functions. Last month, LandBank brought together top cooperatives in a Cooperative Alliance Congress to explore the concept of forming umbrella groups and to identify areas where assistance can be extended to smaller cooperatives. State owned LandBank is a full service universal bank catering to the financial and technical needs of agricultural cooperatives throughout the country. As of end 1997, LandBank's outstanding loans to small farmers and fisherfolk cooperatives stood at P12.3 billion.

KOTA BARU, Mon. - Menteri Besar Datuk Nik Abdul Aziz Nik Mat has called for reforms and formulation of dadah rehabilitation programmes to suit the spiritual needs of addicts. He said this was in view of the ineffectiveness of the current programmes which were mostly copied from other countries with similar dadah abuse problems. He said dadah rehabilitation centres should emphasise religious lessons. There should also be more programmes to illustrate dadahs' destructive effects on the human body so as to instil fear among the addicts, he added. ATHENS, Greece (AP) _ Employees of Greece's fourth-largest bank refused Wednesday to scale back a three-week strike despite the government's concession to one of their main demands. Ionian Bank workers walked off the job May 8 protesting government plans to sell off the state-run bank, part of a broad plan to streamline the economy in view of European monetary union. Socialist Premier Costas Simitis initially insisted no concessions could be made and that Ionian's privatization was an essential part of plans to trim the inflated public sector. But the government backed down to one of the unionists' main demands Tuesday _ providing current Ionian employees with a guaranteed job until the retirement age of 62. National Economy Minister Yannos Papantoniou was quoted by Greek media saying a clause will be included in the bank's sale contract that forbids the new owner from firing Ionian workers. Speaking after a meeting with unionists, Papantoniou said the new proposal should not create any problems in the bank's privatization prospects. He added that ``everything will be solved when the bank begins operating normally,'' local media said. But Ionian workers' union president Yiannis Markakis vowed the strike would continue until the government revoked the sale plan altogether. Independent deputy and former national economy minister Stephanos Manos said the government's concession wiped out all benefits from Ionian's privatization, and called on its customers to withdraw their funds and deposit them in private or foreign banks. ``Only if the majority of citizens begin reacting against deals between politicians and unionists ..., only then will there be hope for something to change in this place,'' Manos was quoted by local media as saying. Any further concessions in privatization plans could jeopardize the government's efforts to join the EU's single currency club by 2001. In an interview with the Sunday Eleftherotypia newspaper, central bank governor Lukas Papademos said Ionian's sale will ``accelerate the restructuring of the banking sector and the creation of a competitive environment ... That is the reason why it's necessary to sell the bank before the end of the year.'' (eb-pq)

A former central bank official criticized yesterday government's efforts to prop up the peso through non-deliverable forwards and currency swap arrangements with foreign banks. In an interview, former Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) Treasurer Sergio Edeza said while non-deliverable forwards protected the peso from wild fluctuations, these instruments failed to provide a sufficient cover for most businessmen. A non-deliverable forward contract is an instrument that borrowers use to cover their dollar liabilities. The central bank and banks shoulder exchange rate differentials through these instruments while conserving the country's international reserves. The BSP allowed exporters to open non-deliverable forward contracts as long as they sold the same amount of dollars in the spot market. For every one dollar exporters sold, the central bank provided currency protection up to one dollar of their outstanding dollar obligation. Edeza also said the currency swap arrangements between the BSP and some foreign banks were also ineffective. ``It gives you time to delay the risk but there will be a demand for dollars at some future time unless there are inflows. But currently there are none so the dollar demand is just delayed,'' he said. While it has not been actively intervening in the financial market, the central bank has been reported to be quietly engaging in swap arrangements with some foreign banks to prop up dollar liquidity in the system. Industry sources said government had entered into dollar swap arrangements with Bank of America, The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corp., and Standard Chartered Bank to prop up the peso.

I have often asked myself that question and each time manage to somehow convince myself that there is still a lot of juice left in me. Just what does being burned out mean? I suppose there would be some medical description of this condition, but in more practical terms, this means that you have ceased to be productive since you have used up all of your creative fuel, hence, burned out. Thinking about it, does everyone qualify to get burned out? This may be so since different people have different levels of responsibility and capability. Therefore, as an individual's capability is overwhelmed by his responsibility or what is expected of him, he starts feeling the pressure and eventually gets burned out. I guess this is the reason why a job burn out is more commonly talked about among executives rather than by their drivers. While being totally burned out is not good since there is nothing left, the process of getting there is what makes us more productive. To shine a light, you need to burn fuel and the more fuel you burn, the brighter the light gets. The trick is to find a way to burn the fuel efficiently and to keep on getting a supply of fuel. How does one burn the fuel efficiently? Simple -- by keeping the friction factors down to a minimum. What I call friction factors are some negative characteristics normally associated with geniuses who are under a lot of pressure, or people who are just obnoxious. These would include irritability, paranoia, detachment, a superiority complex ,and very likely, all of the above. A person becomes irritable when there is a great deal of pressure to meet deadlines or to deliver something that borders on being impossible. The person in question does not want to be bothered with minor details given the tremendous challenge he is facing. He also gets irritated by things that seem so obvious to him, yet need to be explained to others. Paranoia also sets in when he feels that no one else seems to be able to relate to the problems he is facing. Every question is supposed of being a trick question, every action is viewed with suspension and every person is out to get our man. Detachment becomes a defense mechanism, there is no time to get bogged down by emotions or unproductive discourse. This detachment also leads to a short attention span. The mind identifies priorities and when it realizes that the current conversation has a low yield in achieving the goal, it uses its mental ability to think about something else, leaving the body behind on auto pilot. While a superiority complex may not be entirely without basis, it is nonetheless a friction factor. After all, chances are the most productive and capable people are given the difficult tasks because they have the best chance of getting the job done. Everyone else is viewed as an idiot or someone in the way. Keeping the friction factors in check, the pressure and our ability to cope with it gives us the cutting edge, keeping us on our toes and heightening our sense and abilities. Having covered the efficiency factor while we are burning a maximum, how then do we keep the flame alive? Different things motivate different people and whatever motivates us is the fuel that keeps us burning bright. It could be money, recognition, personal satisfaction, curiosity, honor, or ego that fuels our burning desire to do more. This may seem so simple but it is true. Once the reason for doing something is removed, the fuel flow stops and the flame dies. So, the next time you or someone else asks you: Are you burned out? The best answer you can give is: No, but I'm on my way. Comments can be sent to gschua wpi.webquest.com. Finex can be reached at finex portalinc.com

JERUSALEM (AP) - A former PLO guerrilla chief who mastermined the 1985 murder of an American Jew during the Achille Lauro cruise ship hijacking does not pose a threat to Israeli security, the attorney general ruled Wednesday. Attorney General Elyakim Rubinstein wrote that Israel doesn't plan to seek the arrest of Mohammed Abbas, who is currently visiting in the Palestinian-controlled Gaza Strip. Rubinstein responded to a petition by two Israelis and Dov Hikind, a New York State Assemblyman from Brooklyn, who have asked the Supreme Court to order the Israel to arrest and try Abbas for murder. The court has not said when it would issue a decision. In a statement to the court on, Rubinstein said Abbas ``does not pose a security threat'' and that an arrest ``would probably cause real friction with the Palestinian side.'' Guerrillas acting on Abbas' orders seized the Italian cruise ship off Egypt in 1985. They shot an elderly American passenger in a wheelchair, Leon Klinghoffer, and threw his body overboard. The hijackers surrendered to Egyptian authorities, who put Abbas and his men on a flight for Tunisia, where the PLO was headquartered at the time. But the U.S. Navy forced the flight down in Italy and the Italian authorities allowed Abbas to flee. An Italian court later convicted Abbas and two other PLO guerrillas in absentia and sentenced them to life in prison. In 1996, Israel allowed Abbas, also known as Abul Abbas, to return to the Gaza Strip to attend a session of the Palestine National Council. Since then he has returned to Gaza three times and has described the current stay as an extended one. `` We had always said that what took place on the ship had not been planned and had not been organized and I wasn't on the ship,'' Abbas told The Associated Press from Gaza. Under a 1993 peace agreement with the Palestinians, Israel allowed thousands of PLO guerrillas to return from abroad and enter the new autonomous Palestinian areas. Rubinstein wrote that ``it would not be reasonable to prosecute (Abbas) for acts which he committed before Sept. 13 1993.'' jk-dl

NATO accelerates plans to boost Albanian, Macedonia borders
With BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo Eds: TOPS with NATO chief insisting it keeps ``all options open'' By ROBERT WIELAARD Associated Press Writer
BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) _ NATO Secretary General Xavier Solana reiterated Wednesday the alliance was keeping ``all options open,'' including a military reply to Serbia's violent crackdown on a separatist movement in Kosovo. ``The news from Kosovo is not good. The situation is deteriorating,'' Solana told reporters. Therefore, he said, the allies agreed to accelerate plans to help Albania and Macedonia seal their borders with Kosovo. Also, at a meeting here, the NATO ambassadors reiterated they will consider sending combat troops to those nations. ``We are keeping all options open,'' Solana said at a brief press conference. In Kosovo, thousands of refugees left their villages and towns, fleeing Serb security forces. Solana rejected an analogy with Bosnia in 1991-92 saying NATO was not asleep at the wheel as Kosovo spiraled into ever more violence and chaos. In Kosovo, ``we are trying not only to respond to events, but we are trying to prevent events,'' he said. The allies have asked military planners to study the possibility of military intervention. ``We all agreed we cannot proceed (with that) until we have solid, well-thought out military advice,'' said a NATO official, who asked not to be named. Getting that advice ``would take several days'' and get a first review by the NATO defense ministers who are to meet here June 11-12, the official said. Meanwhile, the NATO allies accelerated technical and military assistance for Albania and Macedonia to help them secure their borders with Kosovo. The first military advisors are to leave in a matter of days. Also, previously scheduled small-scale joint maneuvers in Albania and Macedonia were given more priority and NATO's civil emergency and planning section was told to contact U.N. officials dealing with the exodus of Kosovo refugees. ``There is a great sense of urgency to get these things organized,'' said the NATO official. In the months leading up to the war in Bosnia in 1992, the NATO allies waffled over how to contain that Balkan crisis. Officials said history was not repeating itself in Kosovo. ``NATO ... cannot do things which are not guaranteed to be successful. We are going quickly but we recognize there is a need for substantive military work'' before a decision to deploy many thousands of troops is taken, said the NATO official . There have been no reports in Kosovo like those in Bosnia of massive civilian roundups or massacres by Serb forces. But attacks on villages, the exodus of civilians and the deaths of women and children have prompted comparisons to the ethnic war in Bosnia. More than 200 people have been killed in the southern Serb province where 90 percent of the population are ethnic Albanians. NATO's Kosovo policy is guided by the belief the province should not become independent but be given back the autonomy it once had within the Yugoslav Republic. (rw)

The Supreme Court has junked a suit filed by the Kalookan city government over a land occupied by Grand Central Ever Gotesco, allowing retailer Jose Go to use the property as a collateral to bail out Orient Commercial Banking Corp. ``That's what they (Go family) told us,'' Alberto Reyes, deputy governor of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), told The Business Daily. ``The Supreme Court has allowed the sale of the property so we can use it as a collateral.'' The high court decision was promulgated last week, he said. The central bank has required Go to submit more collateral to cover over P6 billion worth of bad debts saddling Orient Bank. Titles to prime properties submitted earlier by the Chinese-Filipino businessman were considered insufficient to cover Orient Bank's non-performing loans. Go founded Orient Bank and was said to have gotten a majority of the bank's non-performing loans. Some 316 titles, including those covering Go's personal assets, have already been submitted to the BSP to set in motion the rehabilitation of Orient Bank. Vicente Valdepeas Jr., a member of the Monetary Board, said the value of Grand Center Ever Gotesco was ``very substantial.'' He said it would be enough to cover loans acquired by Orient Bank's owners, officers and shareholders. ``It is the jewel of the crown, which plays a critical role,'' said Valdepeas. Orient Bank has been on holiday since Feb. 13. Bad debts extended mostly to its owners and stockholders led to the bank's closure. Asian Appraisers, one of three companies government hired to assess Orient Bank's assets and liabilities, completed its evaluation last week. The Development Bank of the Philippines and Cuervo Far East Ltd. had yet to submit their reports. Depositors of Orient Bank earlier agreed to keep some P1.5 billion in the bank's vaults. The BSP has asked Orient Bank to hold on to at least 60%, or P2 billion, of the money deposited in its vaults to ensure a smooth rehabilitation. Orient Bank has been asking its depositors to sign a statement assuring they will not withdraw their money when the bank re-opens. The BSP earlier agreed to restructure P3.4 billion worth of pending claims provided depositors keep their money with Orient Bank to make the bank more attractive to prospective investors.
