America is not necessarily the Promised Land. For all the talk of progress and enlightenment in the Modern Twentieth Century, racism and discrimination still exist in the Land of the Brave and the Home of the Free. And the Filipinos who've relocated to Uncle Sam and made a permanent living there are not all rich and happy. Flipzoids, a play written, directed, and produced by Filipino-Americans that deals with the Filipino immigration experience in America, will definitely shatter some popular myths. A special presentation of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in cooperation with the New York-based Ma-Yi Theater Ensemble, it goes onstage this week at the Tanghalang Batute from June 3-7, 7:30 p.m., with weekend matinees at 3 p.m. This three-man, one-act play dramatizes the immigrant's perennial struggle between assimilation into the American culture on one hand, and the desire to retain his unique identity on the other. It is a subject continually explored and plumbed into greater depths by the Ma-Yi Theater Company. Founded in 1989, part of Ma-Yi's vision is to present for the theater original works about the Fil-Am experience or Filipinos' experience in America. Chatting in between rehearsals at the CCP, playwright and Ma-Yi founder Ralph Pea elaborates how this vision came about. ``The Fil-Am story occurs, basically, from the time that the Filipinos immigrated to the US which is turn of the century, 1920s, 1930s...That story. The bone of contention is that Fil-Am or Filipinos in America have their own set of dynamics and their own set of concerns [that are] as legitimate as any ethnic group in the US, [and which is] an integral part of the American fabric. The argument is, should we just take plays from Manila and stage them for our audience in New York? And our answer to that is `no'. Because the writers here [in Manila] are not writing for Filipino-Americans, they're writing for Filipinos. Our concerns, the dynamics of the Fil-Am community, are completely separate from what's here in Manila. We took plays by Filipinos and presented them to our audience in New York, and they didn't mean anything, because their lives are so completely different from the realities being presented by the plays. And what happens is that we end up doing museum pieces for them which we don't want. We want theater that is meaningful to our audience, that affects their lives and reflects their realities. How do you do that? You start writing about them.'' Back in New York over the past 10 years, Ma-Yi has found its audience. Since its founding, it has produced original works written by such writers as Jessica Hagedorn, Nicky Paraiso, Louella Dizon, Chris Millado, Han Ong, and, of course, Pea. While 50% of its audience come from the Fil-Am community, Ma-Yi has been successful in reaching out across other cultural and ethnic barriers. Pea maintains, ``We have a very good audience. We have survived for 10 years and that's not easy. Especially in New York where the cost of producing is astronomical. The average production cost is $75,000 per show. That's not easy. So if you think about that, if you don't have a firm audience base, there's no way you can make that up in grants. The mere fact that we've lasted this long goes directly to the heartening fact that we have very good support from our community and from the New York theater audience.'' What would the Manila theater audience find interesting in Flipzoids? Pea replies, ``Flipzoids gives the Manila audience an insight into what it means to be a Filipino in America. There are a lot of misconceptions about that. Like being rich and happy. That is the prevalent conception in the streets, about us who are there -- we're earning dollars, we're happy. But it's not true. It depends on how you view the promised land. I think this play speaks directly to that issue, on what we have to go through. It's Fil-Am in the way it's told, but it's the universal immigrant story of the US. Every immigrant goes through this experience. Flipzoids asks the questions: What do I give up? How do I fit in? The thorny issues of compromise that go along with assimilation. ``The US has a way of prescribing what an American is -- it has its own definition -- and unless you fit that mold... The US is run by white people. Ma-Yi is based in New York, which is an entirely different animal by itself, but if you go to the Midwest, we Fil-Ams are still thought of as Chinks, and not even Filipinos. There's racism in the US -- I think everywhere -- and Flipzoids deals with that. The US is still a racially motivated country. Actually, Flipzoids is an appropriation of two words. The first is `Flip', which is derogatory American for us. Filipinos are called Flips in the US, and `Flips' actually means F---ing Little Island People. `Zoids' come from schizoids. This is jumbling three agendas together. It's cultural and psychological and schizophrenia. `Flip' and `zoids.' ``This play will shatter myths. Not just one, but several. This is a multi-layered play, we're not cut black and white here, we're exploring gray areas of what it means to be Americans, and as Fil-Ams specifically.'' Pea cautions to add, however, ``In Flipzoids, we're not presenting archetypes here that generalize the whole experience. Flipzoids presents three unique individuals who go through a journey and they speak directly to the experience of assimilation. But we're not out to say, `This is what being Fil-American means.' But rather, this is an experience of a Fil-Am. ``Because this Fil-Am theater aesthetic is a nascent form, the most prevalent theme now is assimilation. No Fil-Am theater company has really explored that yet, whereas most other ethnic theater groups have written about blending into the American mainstream for years and years. So now all the Fil-Am playwrights are talking about blending into the American society, of an outsider blending in, which is what Flipzoids is all about. Predominantly, Fil-Am writers are writing about having to blend into American society.'' All the Ma-Yi members would certainly have their own unique experiences concerning integration and assimilation -- and finding and affirming one's self -- in an adapted culture. Pea was born in the Philippines, grew up as a child in the US, returned to the Philippines during his high school to college years, graduated from the University of the Philippines, then finally returned to the US for good. An active member of two UP theater companies, he was awarded a Birch Foundation Fellowship to study at Circle in the Square Professional Actor's School in New York City. He counted among his classmates thespians like Michael Moriarty, Joanna Gleason, and Maria Tucci. As an actor, he appeared in Tomorrow was War directed by Vanessa Redgrave, Three Sisters, and Our Town, among others. Asked to define a ``true Fil-Am identity,'' Pea answers, ``It's multi-faceted. As it is, Filipinos are a hodge-podge of different psyches. Influences from Spain, America, and all these things. Then add to all that is the idea of having to blend into American society, which kind of creates this multi-faceted thing, which is a problem for our community. Because if you look at the US, you'll see how ethnic groups have sort of formed community centers and cultural centers. We Fil-Ams don't have that. We don't have a `Filipino-town' [as in Chinatown] in the US. San Francisco is our closest to an idea of a Fil-Am community, but elsewhere we like to blend. We don't like to stick out.'' He emphasizes, ``By appropriating our stories and putting them on stage in some way, we validate what we are as Americans. This is who we are and it's OK to be who we are, we can be who we are in this country and still be part of America. We don't have to be white. We don't have to re-invent ourselves to be white. We don't have to compromise to be Americans. We don't have to forget that we are Filipinos. We don't have to hide our cultural uniqueness/eccentricities. We blend in. There's room for everybody. That's the point.'' That point, hopefully, will get across to the Manila audience as powerfully as it did to the Fil-Am community. Pena mentions the possibility of bringing in more Fil-Am plays into Manila in the future. One example is Chris Millado's Periginasyon, loosely based on America's in the Heart written by Carlos Bulosan. Another plan is to set up a six-month exchange internship program, wherein Filipino artists would go to the US, and vice-versa. Flipzoids is Ma-Yi's first presentation in Manila. It need not be the last.

BC-Sports-Tennis-French Open, 4th Ld-Writethru,
Corretja, Pioline advance to men's semifinals
Eds: UPDATES with Pioline advancing to semifinals By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Frenchman Cedric Pioline became the only non-Spaniard in the men's semifinals of the French Open, battling through five exhausting sets Wednesday to defeat Hicham Arazi. As French flags waved in the stands, Pioline broke the Moroccan's serve for a 4-2 lead in the final set and then held on _ fighting off a break point in the last game _ for the victory. Pioline's 3-6, 6-2, 7-6 (8-6), 4-6, 6-3 win put him in the semifinals with Spaniards Alex Corretja, Carlos Moya and Felix Mantilla. The Pioline-Arazi match was 3 hours, 42 minutes of error-filled, often tedious tennis _ the two players combined for 149 unforced errors. But French fans hardly seemed to notice, yelling ``Oui'' on his points and booing loudly when Arazi questioned line calls. Corretja reached his first Grand Slam semifinal by defeating Filip Dewulf of Belgium 7-5, 6-4, 6-3, joining close friends Moya and Mantilla in the final four. ``This is history,'' Corretja said. ``I think it's really good because normally it's not easy to have a country put three guys in the semis of a Grand Slam. We used to see the American guys in other tournaments, but not the Spanish guys.'' Deuwlf hadn't lost a set until his straight-set loss to Corretja. The 39th-ranked Belgian was a semifinalist at Roland Garros last year. On Tuesday, No. 3 seed Marcelo Rios went the way of the other top seeds in Paris. He was upset in four sets by Moya, losing his chance to regain the No. 1 ranking from Pete Sampras. The Chilean held that spot for a month earlier this year, and could have reclaimed it with a quarterfinal victory. But at least one player remains on course _ Martina Hingis. The undisputed best woman player defeated Venus Williams on Tuesday with such ease that it put to rest any talk of a great rivalry _ at least for now. Hingis next faces a newly inspired Monica Seles, a three-time champion in Paris, in one of Thursday's semifinals. No. 2 Lindsay Davenport plays two-time champion Arantxa Sanchez Vicario in the other. With Davenport and Seles advancing, there are two American women in the French Open semifinals for the first time since Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert in 1987. But there were no echoes of Evert and Navratilova when Hingis and Williams took the court. In a swirling wind that hampered both players, Hingis used her deft touch and uncanny court sense to dictate play. Never in the 6-3, 6-4 victory did the Swiss star appear out of control, off-balance or rushed. Williams hurt her cause with 38 unforced errors. ``I don't think I was as patient as I should have been. I guess everyone knows I like to hit,'' Williams said. ``I suppose I got a little too excited, really wanted to hit a winner.'' Hingis came into the match with a 5-2 career record against the eighth-seeded Williams, but the two 17-year-olds were 2-2 this year. The match promised to be an intriguing battle between power and smarts. But, just as in their only previous Grand Slam tournament encounter _ a 6-0, 6-4 win by Hingis in the U.S. Open final last summer _ the match turned into a one-sided affair. ``It's probably good for me to lose so I can really see what I'm doing wrong and really look at myself and say, `Venus, you're not there,''' she said. Moya, the No. 12 seed who has been ranked as as high as fifth, is hoping to crack back into the top 10 this week. He became the talk of tennis at last year's Australian Open _ for his dashing looks and talent. He upset defending champion Boris Becker in the first round, then went to the final, losing to Sampras. But except for that tournament, the 21-year-old had never gone past the second round of any Grand Slam event. And at Roland Garros, he hadn't gotten past the second round in two previous visits. Now Moya is the highest seed left. On Friday he faces Mantilla. ``We're going to be friends until Friday,'' he said. ``When we get to the court, I will try to kill him.'' Tuesday's play ended with Gustavo Kuerten, the defending champion who lost in the second round, disqualified from doubles. He threw his racket at the chair umpire, hitting a fan in the stands, but apparently not causing injury. ``I'm so sorry for what happened and I regret what I did,'' the Brazilian said today. ``I know that this will make me a more mature guy and will make me grow. I want to make it clear that I never had the intention of hurting anyone on or off the court.''

``Pay your just and fair share of taxes, because this is your duty, and because your taxes will be spent well,'' said incoming President Joseph Estrada at a recent meeting with business leaders. One of the highlights of Estrada's 10-point agenda is a strong stance against tax evasion, particularly by big businesses and ``fat cats'' who are thought to have long been cheating the system. Amnesties will be granted to accelerate collection of past due taxes, but after that, tax evaders are told, they will be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law. Finance Secretary-designate Edgardo Espiritu further disclosed a plan to assign government examiners to monitor financial operations of the country's major corporations. The monitoring scheme would include utilizing records from the Securities and Exchange Commission, Insurance Securities Commission, Department of Trade and Industry, Board of Investments, Credit Information Bureaus, and various private sector sources. Espiritu said, ``this action is designed to remove the policy of discretion on the part of examiners so that there can be no under-the-table transactions.'' Tax remittances from the country's top 10 firms during the first three months suffered a steep drop of 33.5% to P2.113 billion from P2.598 billion recorded during the same period last year, according to a government report. This represents a 43.3% under-achievement against the target set by the Department of Finance and the IMF. Major corporations account for 43.6% of annual tax collection. While the economic setback was one cause for the sharp decline in fiscal revenue, nobody can deny the possibility that the country's blue chip companies shortchanged the national government. While making allowance for the effects of the slowdown in the country's economy, a ranking Finance official in an interview with The Business Daily nevertheless said tax evasion was suspected to be another major reason for the revenue shortfall. Are top flight corporations having pangs of conscience? How disgraceful it would be if they were actually trying to feather their own nests without regard to public duties and obligations! In the world's more mature economies, tax evasion is a serious crime entailing heavy punishment as well as societal sanctions. How many tax dodgers are serving time in prison in the Philippines? The new administration should indeed tighten supervision of major tax payers' obligations. The Ramos administration tried to balance fiscal budgets by simply auctioning off one state asset after another in the name of privatization, while doing next to nothing to scrutinize or prosecute flagrant cases of tax evasion. The idea obviously was not to rub big business the ``wrong way.'' With an overwhelming public mandate behind him, ``Robin Hood'' Estrada is expected to crack down on tax evaders with an iron fist. Once a case has been established, the names of large scale culprits should be published. Once convicted, hefty penalties could then serve as an effective deterrent to others. Consumers could be called on to boycott the products and services provided by tax cheaters. Why be so fussy about taxes? Evading taxes is not just unfair to honest citizens, but it is largely responsible for public sector deficits. In order to cover the deficit, government is forced to borrow money by issuing Treasury Bills. The larger the need of government for money, the higher the rates are that it has to pay to its creditors. The law of supply and demand sees to that. That again results in a higher benchmark rate which banks use to determine the interest they charge when lending money to among others -- you and me! What happens if banks start charging prohibitively high interest rates of 30%? It is a devastating damper on business activity. At such loan shark levels, only the very privileged, the very smart and the very crooked can make money. Balanced budgets are possible, however, if government cuts spending. That is easier said than done and usually results in cuts in areas where spending is needed most, e.g., basic infrastructure, social welfare services, among others. As the economy is slowing, raising taxes is definitely out for a ``populist'' administration. Under Erapnomics, sufficient revenue must be secured by increasing tax collection. How the incoming president deals with the issue would be a first litmus test to measure his seriousness in pursuing a hard-line policy. Should he succumb to the allure of traditional politics, disenchanted masses might turn their back on him. Mr. Estrada himself reminded business leaders the other day that it was his job to level the playing field by enforcing the rules. I've heard the tale of a famous Spanish-Filipino tycoon who was refused a visa to Japan several years ago. The Japanese Embassy turned down his visa application because his tax record showed an annual income that was deemed insufficient. A certain Chinese-Filipino business magnate is well-known for his anti-disclosure stance with regard to his company's financial situation. He has long opted for paying fines instead. Respectable corporate citizenship should be promoted. While Ramos is credited with turning the economy around, his pro-business stance pampered corporate interests. An Estrada administration is expected to fulfill the dual functions necessary for the nation's economic progress by being both driver and regulator. Another daunting task for Estrada is the abolition of the so-called ``pork barrel'' fund. Each congressman is entitled to a share of the Countrywide Development Fund of at least P12.5 million per year for various projects in his/her constituency. Senators enjoy an annual lard-scoop of a least P18 million. In addition, there is more pork to be accessed from the Congressional Initiative Allocation funds given to various agencies. Legislators have the power to direct how, where and when these particular appropriations are to be disbursed. ``Pork and Other Perks'' by the Philippine Center of Investigative Journalism indicates that senior committee chairs have a final say on CIAs worth P100 million a year. No wonder candidates have millions to spend in campaigns. This is a huge vested interest on the part of congressmen and senators and the last thing they would want to part with. It is reported that except for a few, even Lammp members are for the pork barrel. Mr. Estrada announced that he would do away with the pork, once installed in Malacaang, but some believe it would be a quixotical attempt, much like fighting windmills. For Mr. Estrada, it is an uphill battle to rewrite legislation against so much opposition. What would be his game plan? A presidential decree? He proposes to transfer the appropriation jurisdiction directly to local governments. Cynics retort, ``what if local governments are corrupt?'' Pointed out is the malpractice in the Department of Public Works and Highways, where kickbacks for high ranking officials are said to be worth more than 30% of project cost, a far cry from the 15% during the notorious Marcos era. No institutional or legislative reform seems fit to eradicate the misuse and abuse of public funds supposed to be used for the facilitation of provincial development. One way to ensure effective and appropriate use of these funds is to set up an oversight committee. Putting in place this kind of monitoring mechanism would help reduce arbitrary misappropriation and wastage. The committee in each locality could be composed of citizens representing various sectors. Hongkong has an independent law enforcement agency against graft and corruption among public servants. Legislatures are elected to make laws, while the bureaucracy is to administrate. Thus, pork barrel should be abolished once and for all. But that's not enough. We need to have an agency under the direct supervision of the President to exercise stringent surveillance over the conduct of government officials. The Ramos administration was very lax in this respect, to say the least. As not much is expected from appealing to the conscience of publicservants, the only alternative is something more painful than slapping their wrists. Chances are that severe punishment would effectively reduce temptation for graft and corruption. But this kind of get-tough approach can never be a sure winner. Strict rules should be accompanied by the incentives. We need to establish an impartial evaluation system for government workers. Those achieving higher scores should be rewarded with substantially higher salaries and promotions, while redundancies are rigorously shed. Decent stipends for qualified government workers permit them to be less dependent on kickbacks and under-the-table commissions. Poverty dulls the sense of honor and dignity. Paying meager salaries and demanding high moral standards is simply asking too much. Mr. Estrada's challenge is daunting. Any one of his avowed tasks is a tall order. But the people will rally behind him if he really tries as good as he can to make dramatic changes in the way our society functions.

BC-Germany-Train Derails, 16th Ld-Writethru
At least 70 dead in high-speed German train crash buses
URGENT Eds: ADDS details of ICE model, RESTORES reference to Red Cross By CLAUS-PETER TIEMANN Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ A high-speed passenger train derailed Wednesday in northern Germany, killing at least 70 people and seriously injuring 200 as car after car of the train crumpled into the concrete base of an overpass. The crash _ Germany's deadliest rail disaster in 31 years _ happened at 11 a.m. as the Hamburg-bound train sped at 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour approaching the station in Eschede, 50 kilometers (35 miles) north of Hanover. The cause of the accident remained unclear. Police spokesman Joachim Lindenberg said it appeared that the impact of the train collapsed the overpass, sending an auto parked on the structure plunging to the tracks. The auto belonged to a rail employee who was working along the tracks, Lindenberg told German television ARD. He said that anyone that close to the accident could not have survived. Deutsche Bahn did not immediately confirm that account. Earlier reports, based on witness accounts to authorities, suggested that the auto had plunged into the train causing it to derail. Views of the wreckage offered no clear clues as to what caused the accident. The nose of the train had cleared the bridge, while the cars derailed and jackknifed into each other. At least 13 cars derailed. The force of the pile-up pushed the cars meters (yards) high into the air. The train was carrying at least 350 passengers. Regional officials said 100 people were lightly injured, in addition to the 200 serious injuries. Survivors were taken to hospitals throughout the region. The Red Cross had chartered six buses to take most of the uninjured to Hamburg, spokesman Harald Krueger said. The accident was the worst on Germany's premier high-speed ICE line, inaugurated in 1991. A 1967 rail accident near Magdeburg in then-East Germany, killed 94 people in the deadliest rail accident since World War II. A crossing barrier closed on a rail tanker filled with gasoline, causing it to explode and spreading fire into passenger cars. The worst accident in western Germany was in 1971, when a train carrying children on a field trip collided with a freight train, killing 46 people. A Deutsche Bahn executive Johannes Ludewig, said he was ``deeply dismayed and horrified by the proportions of this accident.'' Several of the rail cars were demolished, and splintered glass covered the scene. Luggage was piled next to the wreckage as workers struggled to pry passengers from the train. More than 800 rescue workers were at the scene, including trauma surgeons andear if there were more dead inside the shattered train cars. A crane was positioned to lift chunks of the bridge to reach cars underneath. The accident closed train traffic in both directions. Federal Transport Minister Matthias Wissmann, Lower Saxony state governor Gerhard Schroeder and German railway executives were en route to the scene. The ICE train is Germany's fastest, connecting all major cities at speed up to 280 kilometers (175 miles) an hour. The train travels from Munich to Hamburg, covering a distance of more than 950 kilometers (about 600 miles), in 5 hours and 37 minutes. Regular train service takes more than eight hours. The train that crashed Wednesday was a first-generation ICE model powered by two electric-powered locomotives pulling up to 14 passenger cars with a capacity of 759 passengers. At top speed the train requires 2.8 kilometers (1.7 miles) to come to an emergency stop. The high-speed trains carry more than 65,000 passengers daily. (cb-gb-aet)

A SIMILAR occurrence to the 1980s collapse of 24 deposit-taking cooperatives (DTC) may be the bitter medicine that Malaysia needs to swallow to turn around the economy, said Hanifah, Teo Associates chairman Datuk Hanifah Noordin. He was speaking at a conference on credit credibility and financial distress, organised by Mentor Centre for Business Research Sdn Bhd. Hanifah added that the economy had not bottomed out yet. ``A lot of corporate results are not out yet and there is a lot of delay in these. We should be expecting some more bad news,'' he added. He also said regional problems had not manifested itself fully, citing Indonesia as an example. Hanifah said that until the collapse of the 24 DTCs - the first real sign of recession - there appeared to be a lack of urgency in the general public's approach towards the recession. ``It appeared that the urgency of bottoming out of the (1980s) recession was greatly enhanced by the experience (DTC collapse),'' he said. The authorities acted timely over the DTCs, Hanifah said, adding that they successfully steered the economy back on track. He said that although the sign of the times affected businesses in the 1980s, the excesses of business administrators and the vagaries of the businesses themselves were the main causes of the downfall. ``If anything, these excesses and vagaries, born out of greed, were the catalyst for the economic downturn of the 1980s.'' He also pointed out that some auditors currently go in a roundabout manner to inform shareholders that the accounts are qualified. Even though the companies assessed are their clients, auditors should be firm with their customers, Hanifah said.

POST-consumer waste in plastics is a problem facing Malaysian plastics manufacturers as a result of the increasing use of plastics in packaging and post-consumer products. Plastic packaging and post-consumer products constitute between 10 and 15 per cent of Malaysia's solid waste, said Department of Environment (DOE) director-general Rosnani Ibrahim in her speech at the seminar on ``Towards a Better Understanding of Waste Management in Malaysia'' in Petaling Jaya yesterday. She said based on a report by the WorldWide Fund for Nature, Malaysia is expected to generate seven million tonnes of solid waste by the year 2000 compared to 5.5 million tonnes in 1995. ``This is equivalent to 19,000 tonnes generated daily in the year 2000 compared to 13,500 tonnes in 1995,'' she said, adding that daily per capita waste generation will stand at 0.7kg. She added that based on a study by the US Environmental Protection Agency, plastics constitute a large part of packaging, that is, 10 per cent by weight and 20 per cent by volume. Plastics have become a significant part of consumers' daily lives as they are used widely in car parts and household items. ``The question is where will these plastics finally end up. Therefore there is a need to look at ways to better manage waste,'' she said, adding that consumers themselves have to change their habits and lifestyle towards plastic consumption. Chairman of the organising committee for the seminar, Mr Thye Hong Kuen said industrial waste and post-consumer waste are two areas of waste management faced by plastics manufacturers. He said as a result of competition and the need to have efficient and cost-effective products, manufacturers are constantly looking for ways to produce plastics with better properties and strength. Turnover of manufactured plastics stood at RM6 billion last year, he said, adding that it will augur well for the industry if 1 per cent of this amount could be spent on research and development. Earlier in her speech, Rosnani said since 1995, work has begun on the review of the Environmental Quality (Scheduled Waste) Regulations 1989 to improve its implementation. ``Among the areas being reviewed include the list of scheduled wastes which will enable all parties concerned with their handling to have a clear understanding of the categories of wastes as covered in the legislation,'' she said. This she added, will avoid any ambiguity that may arise, for example, while plastic products turned into wastes are not considered hazardous wastes, uncured resin from a resin manufacturing plant is categorised as one and must be appropriately handled under this law. The review of the scheduled wastes list is also in line with the Basel Convention's new list. She said the review was taking some time as there is a need to look at the new wastes being generated which are not on the current list.

THE journey of life can be described as a series of mountains and valleys. And Mr Edouard Malbois, General Manager of TAG Heuer Malaysia echoed this sentiment when he said inner strength is about mental values. ``One has to find inner strength to overcome problems and obstacles and it is important then to believe that mental values are more important than physical values,'' he said at the launch in Kuala Lumpur last week. He added that with Inner Strength, TAG Heuer takes a daring step inward into the essence of sports and sporting excellence, into the mind that is. ``Inner strength is a universal concept. Becker joins the list of athletes chosen by TAG Heuer to illustrate its new advertising campaign. Other athletes include Leonardo and Colin Jackson. Featuring Becker takes on two-fold implications, firstly, it highlights that TAG Heuer continues to build partnerships with successful athletes and also because Becker represents the epitome of inner strength. He is legendary not only for his strong tennis skills, but for his outstanding mental strength that saw him win his first Wimbledon title in 1985, making him the youngest winner, said Malbois. Becker himself said,'' The difference between winning and losing in major championships is your mind, your concentration and in your whole approach to that important game, and that comes from your brain.'' ``There are many difficult moments on the court ... there are moments when I double fault, and this is when I have to search deep within myself to find inner strength. ``And I find that this campaign fits so well with my character and personality,'' he said. The investment in Malaysia, he said is between RM300,000 to RM400,000. ``It is not a tactical campaign and as such will run for one or two years,'' he said adding that the aim of the campaign is to associate the brand with key players in sports. ``For a long time TAG Heuer was considered as a brand that is not human enough and it was difficult for people to associate themselves with the brand,'' he said. He added that through the campaign, present and potential customers will be able to identify with the strength is characterised by the make of the watch. ``We believe in excellence and the importance of being in control where the high standard that is asscociated with TAG Heuer watches is ensured at all times,'' he said. Study predicts outer space will become tourist destination
LISBON, Portugal (AP) _ France may be the world's most popular tourist destination now, but within 20 years it will be competing with places like the polar ice caps and even outer space, tourism experts said Wednesday. A study by the Madrid-based World Tourism Organization, called ``Tourism 2020 Vision,'' forecast that in 20 years' time people will be traveling to outer space after having exhausted the possibilities of Earth. The WTO opened a two-day international conference in Lisbon to try and predict the way the tourism industry is headed. Based on the study, tourism officials from 84 countries were to look at ways of broadening vacations to new market niches. The study predicted that by 2020, 1.6 billion people will be taking annual vacations. ``By then, tourists will have visited all possible destinations around the globe and ... will have turned to space tourism,'' the study said. France was the most popular tourism destination last year with 66.8 million visitors, followed by the United States with 49 million, according to the WTO. JAKARTA (JP): Senior journalists welcomed yesterday the recent advent of greater press freedom and called on the government to revoke all rulings which repressed the media and even threatened their survival. Susanto Pudjomartono, editor in chief of The Jakarta Post daily, said the reform movement had given the press favorable momentum to free itself from decades of oppression from former president Soeharto's repressive government, thus allowing it to help revive democratic principles in the country. He then urged all government rulings which restrict either press freedom, freedom of opinion or freedom to form unions to be lifted. The day-long discussion was organized by the Association of Independent Journalists (AJI), an underground union of journalists banned by the Soeharto administration. According to Susanto, among rulings which should immediately be revoked is Ministerial Decree No. 1/1984 on publishing licenses and the decree that recognizes the Indonesian Journalists Association (PWI) as the only union for journalists and the Newspaper Publishers Association (SPS) as the only union for newspaper publishers. Atmakusumah, a senior journalist and executive director of the Dr. Soetomo Press Institute, said the government should also substitute the restrictive law on publishing licenses with a more positive one which supports and guarantees press freedom. ``I agree with the idea that the government should not have the authority to revoke publishing licenses. The Criminal Code can be used to impose sanctions against violations by the mass media. ``The government should be able to take a newspaper, or a TV station, to court. But it's unfair to revoke publishing licenses,'' he said. He further described the current press laws which were issued in 1966 and 1982 as unfavorable, illusive and impractical. AJI chairman Lukas Luwarso expressed hope that in this era of reform, the mass media could go back to its original function as an independent presenter of public information. ``Let the courts, as the legal mechanism in society, rule on problems caused by mass media reports,'' he said, pointing to charges of libel as a legal avenue which could be pursued. Prison Susanto said one of the most encumbering remnants of the old regime on the press was the ``mental prison'' often faced by journalists who had a self-censorship mechanism embedded within their psyche after years of strong control. ``The press should now be brave and replace the excessive use of euphemism and slogans with direct, frank journalism,'' he said. According to him, the government should play a limited role in the media in order to prevent a new form of oppression in the press. ``Control of the press should be carried out by the press itself ... Violations committed by the press should be tried by a court which is free of government interference,'' he remarked. Susanto, former journalist of the banned Tempo weekly, suggested an independent team of experts be established to regularly evaluate the press' credibility so the press could continually improve itself. Atmakusumah concurred, adding that the public should be another important element in controlling the press by ensuring it adheres to a code of ethics.

THERE were mixed reactions from financial market and analysts on the funding source of the proposed Asset Management Company (AMC), which was formed to take over troubled loans and assets in the banking sector. Some analyst said there must be foreign fund injection to help the company to buy up loans off commercial banks, others seems to think that the sources of the funding will not determine the success of AMC. Goldman Sachs Asia regional economist Donald Hanna said the participation of the foreign funds and the private sector is to demostrate that AMC is ``truly market oriented programme and not a bailout''. Yesterday, Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad had said that the Government may finance up to 60 per cent of the capital needs of AMC while the private sector will fork out the balance. The funds, Dr Mahathir had added will be drawn from the Government's consolidated accounts, and not through taxation or the central bank. Hong Kong-based Hana is quick to add that AMC is part of the solutions to Malaysian economic problem as banks will be able to concentrate on lending and injects much-needed liquidity into the system to finance productive sector activities and not the collection of loans. The AMC will acquire non-performing loans and assets of local financial institutions at market prices with a view to revive and then sell them at a profit. The objective is to free the banks to concentrate on financing economic activities. ``The idea of pulling problem loans off the books of the banks is crucial in the solution for the credit movement in Malaysian banking system. ``AMC is part of the solution but problem will arise when loans rises rapidly as the economy slows down, making it difficult to sell problem loans at a market price,'' he said adding that the slowdown is from the impression given by the negative 1.8 per cent growth in the gross domestic product. However, he said the Government has given an impressive guarantee and question arise on the mechanism of the guarantee, especially during a period when asset quality deteriorates making it difficult for banks to book loans. However question arise on the capitalistion of the banks and mechanism of the guarantee. When asked on the non-performing loan, Hanna said, that he expects it to peak over 25 per cent in 1999. ``There are other steps to be taken if our feel on the NPL ratio is correct. These includes greater clarity on deposit guarantee in order to ensure that people continue to hold deposits in banks,'' he said. Analysts had expect the Government to provide the start-up funds including a bond issue with a government guarantee. However, there were no speculation on the amount to be raised as it will only be determined only after AMC has assessed the situation. Mr Mohamed Azman Yahya, who has been appointed as chief executive of AMC had said earlier that full disclosure and transparency in the agency's operations. The operational structure of the agency is currently being worked out together with Bank Negara and other consultants. The AMC has also been given a timetable by the Finance Ministry.

BC-Iran-Bombings, 3rd Ld-Writethru,0637
Opposition group claims three attacks, at least three killed spokesman in Baghdad; No pickup
Eds: RECASTS, UPDATES with quotes from speaker, opposition By AFSHIN VALINEJAD Associated Press Writer
TEHRAN, Iran (AP) _ An outlawed Iranian opposition group claimed responsibility Wednesday for a bomb and two mortar attacks on government buildings that killed at least three people. In the Iraqi capital, Baghdad, a spokesman for the opposition group, the Mujahedeen Khalq, warned of more attacks. ``Our units inside Iran will escalate attacks against the regime,'' Mohammad Mohaddessin told The Associated Press. In the first high-level response to the attacks, Parliamentary Speaker Ali Akbar Nateq-Nouri said Wednesday that Iran's enemies were seeking to exploit apparent differences among Iran's top leadership. ``Unity of expression is essential for revolutionary forces ... (who) must stand against those who want to fish in muddy waters,'' said Nateq-Nouri, a leading hard-liner in the government who is known to be opposed to the moderates led by President Mohammad Khatami. A bomb exploded Tuesday at the Revolutionary Prosecutor's office in Tehran. Official sources, speaking on customary condition of anonymity, said at least three people were killed and two injured. The official Islamic Republic News Agency denied the bombing was the work of the Mujahedeen, but Tehran's Governor General Mohammad Reza Ayatollahi was reported by state-run television Wednesday as saying the opposition group was behind the attack. In a statement Wednesday, the Mujahedeen said it carried out the bombing as well as two mortar attacks Tuesday on the Central Command Headquarters of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps and the Defense Industries Organization in the capital. The Mujahedeen statement said the three attacks were in retaliation for the killing of its members by the Iranian government in recent months. ``In the surprise attack, several Revolutionary Guards were killed or wounded and the headquarters' buildings were damaged,'' the group said in a statement faxed to The Associated Press in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. It did not claim any casualties for the attack on the defense industries building. However, Iranian radio said security men foiled an attempted attack by ``saboteurs'' at the Revolutionary Guards headquarters Tuesday and the perpetrators fled. Official media did not speak of an attack on a Defense Industries building, but they did report a bomb explosion at an unidentified government building in northern Tehran late Tuesday. It was not known if this property belonged to Defense Industries. There was no report of casualties in this bombing. The Iranian newspaper Farda had reported Tuesday that 50 Mujahedeen fighters had sneaked into Iran across the largely unguarded border with Afghanistan. In Baghdad, Mohaddessin said the Mujahedeen military camps in Iraq, close to the Iranian border, were on alert for expected reprisals from the Tehran government. Also Wednesday, police evacuated guests and staff at the Ferdowsi Hotel in central Tehran following a bomb threat made by a caller, sources said. No bomb was found at the hotel, which is close to the Foreign Ministry and military offices. A police officer at the prosecutor's office said a bomb in a briefcase caused the explosion. However, the official news agency said the explosion was caused by explosives which went off accidentally as they were being brought into the building as evidence for a case. Newspapers published higher casualty tolls than given by officials. Three government-controlled newspapers said five people were killed, and one added that another nine people were injured.

LONDON (AP) _ The government said Wednesday it is back on track with a new deal to build a high-speed rail link between London and the Channel Tunnel _ although the plans still will leave Britain lagging years behind France and Belgium. Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott said he has signed a new agreement with London and Continental Railways, the original contractor whose plans came up short of cash last winter, and Railtrack PLC, which operates Britain's railroad tracks and signaling equipment and was brought into the high-speed link project to save the deal. The government's new arrangement will see a group including British Airways taking over the operation of the Eurostar passenger trains that take passengers under the sea on the London-Paris and London-Brussels routes, beating out archrival Richard Branson's Virgin companies. Branson warned of ``astronomically high'' fares, saying that British Airways was the dominant airline flying between London and Paris. Branson noted that one of British Airways' partners in the train venture, National Express, is the biggest bus company on the London-Paris route, and charged they will have the ability to control the market with a ``cartel approach.'' The slow train tracks in Britain have been an embarrassment ever since the undersea ``Chunnel'' has been open. France completed its high-speed train tracks between Paris and the Channel Tunnel five years ago, and Belgium completed its high-speed link to Brussels last year. BC-Russia-Start II
Parliament rejects motion to postpone START II hearings
MOSCOW (AP) _ Russian lawmakers rejected a proposal by ultranationalist leader Vladimir Zhirinovsky on Wednesday to postpone hearings on the START II treaty, a news agency reported. Zhirinovsky wanted the hearings held this fall, as originally planned. But parliament announced Tuesday that it had decided to hold closed-door hearings on the treaty next week. The State Duma stuck to that timetable Wednesday, ITAR-Tass said. However, Speaker Gennady Seleznyov has warned that the hearings set for June 9 would be shelved if President Clinton continues to put pressure on Russia to pass the treaty. Clinton has said he doesn't want to come to Moscow for a summit with Yeltsin until after the treaty has been ratified. START II was ratified by the U.S. Senate in 1996, and Russian President Boris Yeltsin has been urging the Duma to take quick action. But the Communists and nationalists who dominate the Duma have stalled, saying that reducing Russia's nuclear arsenal would further weaken the country's security. The treaty would cut Russian and American nuclear arsenals to 3,500 warheads each. (ls)

BC-Poland-Communist Collaborators
Parliament debates screening of former communist collaborators
By ANDRZEJ STYLINSKI Associated Press Writer
WARSAW, Poland (AP) _ Rightist and leftist deputies were divided Wednesday over how to screen Poland's top officials to put an end to unproven allegations of past collaboration with the communists. In an effort to bring to life an April 1997 screening law that remains largely on paper after judges refused to sit on a screening panel, parliament discussed a proposal to assign another body the task. Most speakers stressed the need for a viable legislation that would allow screening officials nine years after the communist system collapsed. ``Screening is not a solution to the communist past,'' said Jan Litynski of the junior government partner, Freedom Union. He stressed that recent allegations that the interior minister collaborated with the communist secret service proved the procedure was still badly needed. Last month, minister Janusz Tomaszewski was accused in media reports of failing to admit in a screening declaration that he was an agent of the communist secret police. The screening law requires all Cabinet members and top state officials to make a written statement whether or not they collaborated. The rightist government coalition of Solidarity and Freedom Union, along with the Polish Peasants' Party, supported the Senate's proposal to appoint a public interest watchdog and assign the Warsaw Appeals Court to review the declarations. The former communists of the Democratic Left Alliance were strongly critical, arguing that collaboration should be limited to activities against human rights, the former democratic opposition and the powerful Roman Catholic church, while intelligence and counterintelligence agents should be excluded from the procedure. This law could damage state security, if names of secret service agents get revealed, said ex-communist deputy Janusz Zemke. ``So far we have had a lame law. Today we are getting a draft which is completely sick,'' he said. During the current session ending Friday, parliament will decide whether to accept the draft for fine tuning or take a final vote. But the current proposal does not seem to revive the screening procedure since President Aleksander Kwasniewski, a former communist, has indicated he would veto the Senate-proposed amendments. Most Poles would like to see the screening law implemented. Three-quarters surveyed in a January government poll said they supported the idea of screening. Just 12 percent were against it. The margin of error was 3 percent. (ajs-gb)

Facts about Germany's high-speed ICE train service
With BC-Germany-Train Derails By The Associated Press
Some facts about Germany's premier high-speed ICE train, which derailed Wednesday. ___ HISTORY: Developed in 1980s by German consortium including electronics giant Siemens. Contracted by federal Deutsche Bundesbahn. ICE prototype in 1985 was first rail vehicle in world to exceed 400 kilometers (248 miles) per hour on test track. Regular service started in 1991 with 23 trains. Cut travel time for 850 kilometer (475 mile) Munich-Hamburg trip by more than two hours, to 5 hours 37 minutes. ___ POWER: First-generation ICE models, such as train that crashed Wednesday, have two electric-powered locomotives, front and rear. Can carry 14 passenger cars, each 29 meters (95 foot) long. Maximum total capacity: 759 people. Top speed: 280 kilometers (175 miles) an hour. Takes 2.8 kilometers (1.7 miles) to come to emergency stop. ___ SERVICE: ICE trains carry average 65,000 passengers per day, mostly business people traveling between Germany's major cities. Four routes connect 150 cities, covering 3,500 kilometers (2,175 miles) of railroad tracks. Trains run hourly from early morning to late at night. (gb-aet-cb)

As Kosovo Albanians flood over border, their leaders plead for help that fighting spreading eastward
Eds: UPDATES with NATO chief insisting all options open, report AP Photos By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Ethnic Albanian leaders pleaded with Western officials Wednesday for military intervention to halt what they said is a deliberate Serb strategy of forced expulsions from Kosovo, as more refugees poured over the border to Albania. The request came with no sign of a letup in the Serbs' offensive aimed at smashing resistance to their authority in the secessionist province of southern Serbia, where ethnic Albanians outnumber Serbs 10-to-1. According to Albanian sources, Serb forces shelled at least five villages Wednesday in an area of western Kosovo near the Albanian border, sending more residents fleeing. Houses were set ablaze in the attack by Serb police and paramilitary units, backed by Yugoslav army tanks. New casualty reports from the sealed-off area were not available. Dozens are believed dead since the start of a stepped-up campaign last week by the Serbs, who want to wipe out the pro-independence Kosovo Liberation Army. At least 80 people were killed in a similar crackdown in March, and well over 200 people have died this year in clashes. Top aides to Ibrahim Rugova, the president of the Albanians' self-described independent government, met with a European delegation in Kosovo's capital Pristina on Wednesday. They told the officials that ``ethnic cleansing and massacres carried out by Serb forces in western Kosovo are a part of a planned-out scheme of ethnic cleansing throughout the province.'' The situation is dramatic and NATO must intervene, they told the delegation of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, headed by Javier Ruperez. They said world powers also must pressure Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, who is determined to keep Kosovo from breaking away from Serbia, one of two remaining republics in Yugoslavia. ``Unless there is significant international pressure on Belgrade, chances for a peaceful solution to the crisis will be lost forever,'' Alush Gashi said. But NATO allies, with 34,000 troops already in neighboring Bosnia, are reluctant to commit another big contingent to the Balkans. Meeting in Brussels on Wednesday, they agreed to consider again whether to deploy combat troops to Albania and Macedonia on Kosovo's borders, but indicated a decision is not imminent. ``We all agreed we cannot proceed until we have solid, well-thought out military advice,'' said a NATO official who asked not to be named. NATO Secretary-General Xavier said, however, ``We are keeping all options open.'' Ambassadors of the 16 NATO nations did agree to accelerate other measures, including technical and military assistance for Albania and Macedonia. Besides thousands of displaced Kosovo residents who have sought shelter in border highlands, several thousand others have streamed over the border into Albania. OSCE spokesman Bill Foxton confirmed at the Albanian border that at least two refugees had died as a result of the arduous trek over the mountains _ a 60-year-old man of a heart attack and a 4-year-old girl who died when her mother, who was carrying her, slipped and fell on a rocky path. International monitors near the border said houses could be seen in flames in the besieged village of Junik. The pro-Albanian Kosovo Information Center said the fighting was spreading east of Djakovica, one of the hotpots for the last several days. A spokesman for the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees said 2,000 refugees crossed overnight into Albania, bringing the total to some 3,700 since the Serb assault was launched late last week. Most are women, children and elderly who are ``exhausted mentally and physically,'' spokesman Kris Janowski said in Geneva. Albania's state-run ATA news agency said about 3,000 more refugees were approaching the border. Local authorities in northeastern Albania, site of most of the crossings, said that with more refugees arriving by the hour, the 25 tons of aid sent Tuesday by the U.N. refugee agency was inadequate. In a report documenting growing reluctance to die for Kosovo, the daily Telegraf, published in Belgrade, reported that about 100 policemen had been fired for refusing to go fight in the province. BC-Germany-Train Derails, 17th Ld-Writethru
At least 80 dead in high-speed German train crash
URGENT Eds: RAISES death toll to 80 from 70; ADDS photos, box With BC-Germany-High Speed Train AP Photos By CLAUS-PETER TIEMANN Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ A high-speed passenger train derailed Wednesday in northern Germany, killing at least 80 people and seriously injuring 200 as car after car of the train crumpled into the concrete base of an overpass. The crash _ Germany's deadliest rail disaster in 31 years _ happened at 11 a.m. as the Hamburg-bound train sped at 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour approaching the station in Eschede, 50 kilometers (35 miles) north of Hanover. The cause of the accident remained unclear. Police spokesman Joachim Lindenberg said it appeared that the impact of the train collapsed the overpass, sending an auto parked on the structure plunging to the tracks. The auto belonged to a rail employee who was working along the tracks, Lindenberg told German television ARD. He said that anyone that close to the accident could not have survived. Deutsche Bahn did not immediately confirm that account. Earlier reports, based on witness accounts to authorities, suggested that the auto had plunged into the train causing it to derail. Views of the wreckage offered no clear clues as to what caused the accident. The nose of the train had cleared the bridge, while the cars derailed and jackknifed into each other. At least 13 cars derailed. The force of the pile-up pushed the cars meters (yards) high into the air. The train was carrying at least 350 passengers. Regional officials said 100 people were lightly injured, in addition to the 200 serious injuries. They said they expected the death toll to rise as rescue workers pulled apart the wreckage. Survivors were taken to hospitals throughout the region. The Red Cross had chartered six buses to take most of the uninjured to Hamburg, spokesman Harald Krueger said. The accident was the worst on Germany's premier high-speed ICE line, inaugurated in 1991. A 1967 rail accident near Magdeburg in then-East Germany, killed 94 people in the deadliest rail accident since World War II. A crossing barrier closed on a rail tanker filled with gasoline, causing it to explode and spreading fire into passenger cars. The worst accident in western Germany was in 1971, when a train carrying children on a field trip collided with a freight train, killing 46 people. A Deutsche Bahn executive Johannes Ludewig, said he was ``deeply dismayed and horrified by the proportions of this accident.'' Several of the rail cars were demolished, and splintered glass covered the scene. Luggage was piled next to the wreckage as workers struggled to pry passengers from the train. More than 800 rescue workers were at the scene, including trauma surgeons and border patrol personnel who helped free passengers trapped inside the rail cars. Christian Krettek, of University Hospital in Hanover, told CNN that rescue workers expected the death toll to rise, and it was still unclear if there were more dead inside the shattered train cars. A crane was positioned to lift chunks of the bridge to reach cars underneath. The accident closed train traffic in both directions. Federal Transport Minister Matthias Wissmann, Lower Saxony state governor Gerhard Schroeder and German railway executives were en route to the scene. The ICE train is Germany's fastest, connecting all major cities at speed up to 280 kilometers (175 miles) an hour. The train travels from Munich to Hamburg, covering a distance of more than 950 kilometers (about 600 miles), in 5 hours and 37 minutes. Regular train service takes more than eight hours. The train that crashed Wednesday was a first-generation ICE model powered by two electric-powered locomotives pulling up to 14 passenger cars with a capacity of 759 passengers. At top speed the train requires 2.8 kilometers (1.7 miles) to come to an emergency stop. The high-speed trains carry more than 65,000 passengers daily. (cb-gb-aet)

European Union reaches out to its Mediterranean partners
Eds: UPDATES with meeting open, Cook, Dini quotes; TRIMS By JEFFREY ULBRICH Associated Press Writer
PALERMO, Sicily (AP) - The European Union came together with its Mediterranean partners Wednesday, trying to get the economic cooperation process back on track after last year's derailment by Mideast issues. Despite the will to refocus on economic issues, however, the increasing violence in the Serbian province of Kosovo and the impasse in the Middle East peace talks threatened to push their way on to the agenda of the 15 EU foreign ministers and their 12 Mediterranean colleagues Wednesday and Thursday. A year ago in Malta, the Euro-Mediterranean ministers tried to talk trade and investment, only to see their meeting blown away by the turbulent winds of the Mideast peace process. Even at the inaugural meeting of the Euro-Med conference in Barcelona in 1995, heady ideas also fell victim to disputes, that time over human rights. The Palermo meeting is an informal session with no set agenda. Organizers hoped it would bring the conference back to its original idea of creating a European-Mediterranean free trade and security zone by the year 2010. Nonetheless, Farouk Kaddoumi, head of foreign affairs for the Palestine Liberation Organization, wanted to keep the Middle East peace process alive. ``We want a clear statement which shows the Europeans stand in support of the process of peace and expresses their willingness to revive the process,'' he said. ``And they have to refer to those who stand as a detriment to this process.'' Israel views the EU as pro-Arab and wants no significant role for Europeans in the peace process beyond supplying funding. ``France and Britain have supported Israel since its creation,'' Kaddoumi said. ``Now, they claim the Europeans are friends of the Palestinians. I hope that is true ... and that they cut all economic assistance to the Israelis.'' No direct Palestinian-Israeli contacts are expected here, however. With violence on the rise in Kosovo, Italian Foreign Minister Lamberto Dini said Europe ``has to reconsider the entire picture.'' ``We certainly deplore the fact that there should be these attacks ... contrary to the spirit of conciliation,'' Dini said. NATO, he said, is studying the possibility of throwing up a ``shield'' of troops between Kosovo and its neighbors. ``It has to be recognized that it is from the southern countries that there is a flow of weapons into the area,'' he said. British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook repeated the EU's ``deep concern'' for the situation and once again called on Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosovic ``to halt the killing'' in Kosovo. ``Dialogue cannot prosper unless there is an end to the violence,'' he said. Both issues will be discussed on the sidelines of the Euro-Med meeting. Joining ministers from the European Union are officials from Algeria, Cyprus, Egypt, Jordan, Israel, Lebanon, Malta, Morocco, Syria, Tunisia, Turkey and the Palestinian Authority. (ju-fd)

The president of the Foreign Investors Chamber of Commerce and Industry (FICCI), AKM Shamsuddin, has called upon the government to take steps to improve infrastructure facilities and eliminate corruption for attracting foreign investments. ``We have a good and liberal policy to attract foreign investment compared to that of India and other countries in the region, but there should be initiatives in making the administration free of corruption,'' the FICCI President said in a pre-budget interview with The Independent. ``Besides, we also have our goodwill for the foreign investors. Urging the government to expedite the privatisation process, AKM Shamsuddin said it was not the government's duty to do business. ``All State-Owned Enterprises (SOEs) should be sold to the private sector and the government should not waste the money that will come from the sale of the SOEs, by paying the salaries of the oversized bureaucracy,'' he said with a suggestion to create a special fund to help the private sector to make fresh investments and take up different programmes including development of human resources. ``Small-scale engineering industries can also be supported with the funds in which India is doing very well,'' he said. Eds: TOPS with NATO chief insisting it keeps ``all options open'' By ROBERT WIELAARD Associated Press Writer
BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) _ NATO Secretary-General Xavier Solana reiterated Wednesday that the 16-member alliance was keeping ``all options open,'' including a military reply to Serbia's violent crackdown on a separatist movement in southern Kosovo province. ``The news from Kosovo is not good. The situation is deteriorating,'' Solana told reporters. The NATO ambassadors reiterated they will consider sending combat troops to those nations. They also agreed to accelerate plans to help Albania and Macedonia seal their borders with Kosovo. Thousands of refugees have fled the violence in Kosovo, where Serb police and army forces have stepped-up their campaign since late May to crush the pro-independence Kosovo Liberation Army.Kosovo. More than 200 people have been killed in the southern Serb province where 90 percent of the population are ethnic Albanians. Attacks on villages, the exodus of civilians and the deaths of women and children have prompted comparisons to the ethnic war in Bosnia, where conflict spiraled into civil war in the early 1990s as NATO allies bickered over how to contain the Balkan crisis. Solana rejected the comparison. In Kosovo, ``we are trying not only to respond to events, but we are trying to prevent events,'' he said. The allies have asked military planners to study the possibility of military intervention. ``We all agreed we cannot proceed (with an allied force) until we have solid, well-thought out military advice,'' said a NATO official, who asked not to be named. ``We first of all want to have good, detailed military advice.'' The NATO official said getting the necessary military advice ``would take several days'' and then would have to be reviewed by the NATO defense ministers who meet in Brussels on June 11-12. Meantime, NATO agreed to accelerate other measures that included technical and military assistance for Albania and Macedonia. The first miliary advisors are to leave in a matter of days. Also, NATO gave more priority to previously scheduled small-scale joint military maneuvers in Albania and Macedonia, and NATO's civil emergency and planning section was told to extend immediate cooperation with U.N. officials dealing with the exodus of Kosovo refugees. Officials, however, rejected suggestions that NATO was again slow off the mark by taking a cautious stance on deploying a large alliance force in Albania and Macedonia. ``NATO ... cannot do things which are not guaranteed to be successful. We are going quickly, but we recognize there is a need for substantive military work,'' the NATO official said. NATO's Kosovo policy is guided by the belief the province should not become independent but be given back the autonomy it once had within the Yugoslav Republic.

Yeltsin seeks postponement of meeting with Ukrainian leader
MOSCOW (AP) _ Russian President Boris Yeltsin asked Ukrainian President Leonid Kuchma to postpone their scheduled June meeting until July, a news agency reported Wednesday. Yeltsin needs to devote time to Russia's current financial problems and has received urgent requests from governors to visit some of the country's far-flung regions, presidential spokesman Sergei Yastrzhembsky told Interfax. The two leaders were to have held informal talks in the Crimea on June 20. Outstanding issues between the two neighbors include the division of the former Soviet Black Sea Fleet and the status of the Crimean Peninsula, populated mostly by ethnic Russians. Kuchma left Wednesday for the Crimean resort of Yalta where leaders of 11 countries are to hold talks on transportation and environmental issues related to the Black Sea. The Black Sea Economic Cooperation forum includes the six countries that border the sea, Azerbaijan, Bulgaria, Moldova, Russia, Turkey, Armenia and Greece. Participants are also expected to discuss transportation of Caspian Sea oil from the huge deposits in Azerbaijan. Ukraine is pushing for some of the oil to be carried by tankers to a terminal at the Black Sea port of Odessa and then on to Europe. Kuchma is due to hold a series of bilateral meetings, said his spokesman Olexander Maidannik, and a tripartite meeting with Moldovan President Petru Lucinschi and Romanian President Emil Constaninescu. They will discuss last year's agreement on a free economic zone around the junction of the three countries' borders at the mouth of the Danube River, a spokesman for Lucinschi told the ITAR-Tass news agency. While Angel ``El Divino'' Rodriguez rested comfortably in his Mexico City mansion, federal deputies and senators agreed Tuesday that Mexico needs stronger measures against white-collar crime, Notimex reported. National Action Party (PAN) Deputy Jorge Lopez Vergara said the Federal Attorney General's Office (PGR) should train personnel especially to fight the crimes committed by upper class entrepreneurs. Lopez Vergara also criticized the National Banking and Securities Commission (CNBV) for failing to wield adequate control over banking activities in Mexico. The anger of Lopez Vergara and the other legislators was prompted by the situation of ``El Divino.''Accused of several counts of bank fraud, ``El Divino'' arrived in Mexico from Spain on Monday after a 22-month extradition process. Although there are four warrants for his arrest, the banker remained free due to various legal injunctions preventing his arrest or imprisonment. If ``El Divino'' evades justice, Lopez Vergara said, ``it will be because of the poor work'' of PGR officials. ``We have to clean up the laws so that banking authorities can detect whether or not a banking official is committing multi-million dollar frauds,'' said the panista. Lopez Vergara also called on the PGR to conduct a detailed review of how ex-bankers Rodriguez, Carlos Cabal Peniche and Jorge Lankeau -- all of whom are accused of fraud -- ran their businesses. In addition to reforming the powers of banking authorities, PAN Deputies Fauzi Hamdan and Felipe de Jesus Cantu Rodriguez and Marcelo Ebrard, an independent, added that white collar crimes need to be considered serious crimes. Ebrard stressed that legal reforms ``urgently'' needed to be made so that white-collar crimes could be considered ``serious,'' a move which would make the provisional liberty that ``El Divino'' enjoys harder to win. In the Senate, Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) Senator Dionisio Perez Jacome said the Senate will examine modifications to several laws in order to increase the sentences for white-collar crimes. Perez Jacome said that changes to the financial package sent to Congress by President Ernesto Zedillo could be made in order to avoid situations like that of ``El Divino.''Although current legislation sanctions white-collar crimes with severe penalties, the priista said, criminals like Rodriguez had succeeded in making a mockery of Mexico's justice system. However, the ``Ley de Amparo,'' or Injunction Law, -- which Rodriguez and other high-profile criminals have used to avoid imprisonment -- should not be reformed, Perez Jacome insisted. Secretary of the Council a KM Khorshed Alam, in the report, also said that the problems in the slums were already acute due to lack of minimum facilities needed for livelihood but it would increase 10 folds by the year 2020. ''These problems will go far beyond control by the year 2020,'' he said. The report said the number of slum dwellers by the year 2020 would be around 1 crore in Dhaka city alone. Local Government Engineering Department (LGED) is implementing a Taka 40 crore project of poor rehabilitation through improving the livelihood of slum dwellers and their employment. Besides, the Local Government Ministry with the assistance of the UNDP has undertaken a Taka 60 crore project in four city corporation areas for slum development. Yet another project of Taka 330 crore with the assistance of the Asian Development Bank is being implemented in 22 cities and towns of the country for spread of education among the slum children as well as skill development and employment of slum people, the sources said. Corretja, Pioline advance to men's semifinals
Eds: ADDS quotes, details By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Frenchman Cedric Pioline became the only non-Spaniard in the men's semifinals of the French Open, battling through five exhausting sets Wednesday to defeat Hicham Arazi. As French flags waved in the stands, Pioline broke the Moroccan's serve for a 4-2 lead in the final set and then held on _ fighting off a break point in the last game _ for the victory. Pioline's 3-6, 6-2, 7-6 (8-6), 4-6, 6-3 win put him in the semifinals with Spaniards Alex Corretja, Carlos Moya and Felix Mantilla. Pioline, who has played three five-set matches so far in the tournament, will have a day to rest before facing Corretja in Friday's semifinals. ``I've got to be in shape for that, because Corretja is a good baseline player who makes his opponent run a lot,'' said Pioline, a former finalist at Wimbledon and the U.S. Open who made the French Open semifinals for the first time. Pioline became the first Frenchman to reach the semifinals at Roland Garros since Henri Leconte in 1992. Just two French men have won the French Open title since World War II, with Yannick Noah the most recent in 1983. The Pioline-Arazi match was 3 hours, 42 minutes of error-filled, often tedious tennis _ the two players combined for 149 unforced errors. But French fans hardly seemed to notice, yelling ``Oui'' on his points and booing loudly when Arazi questioned line calls. Arazi, who played most of the match with a blister on his left foot, converted only five of his 21 break points in the match. ``I'm going to jump into the Seine,'' he joked. ``The thing that really did me in is that I stayed too much on the baseline. I should have gone to the net. I should have volleyed more.'' Corretja reached his first Grand Slam semifinal by defeating Filip Dewulf of Belgium 7-5, 6-4, 6-3, joining close friends Moya and Mantilla in the final four. ``This is history,'' Corretja said. ``I think it's really good because normally it's not easy to have a country put three guys in the semis of a Grand Slam. We used to see the American guys in other tournaments, but not the Spanish guys.'' Deuwlf hadn't lost a set until his straight-set loss to Corretja. The 39th-ranked Belgian was a semifinalist at Roland Garros last year. On Tuesday, No. 3 seed Marcelo Rios went the way of the other top seeds in Paris. He was upset in four sets by Moya, losing his chance to regain the No. 1 ranking from Pete Sampras. The Chilean held that spot for a month earlier this year, and could have reclaimed it with a quarterfinal victory. But at least one player remains on course _ Martina Hingis. The undisputed best woman player defeated Venus Williams on Tuesday with such ease that it put to rest any talk of a great rivalry _ at least for now. Hingis next faces a newly inspired Monica Seles, a three-time champion in Paris, in one of Thursday's semifinals. No. 2 Lindsay Davenport plays two-time champion Arantxa Sanchez Vicario in the other. With Davenport and Seles advancing, there are two American women in the French Open semifinals for the first time since Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert in 1987. But there were no echoes of Evert and Navratilova when Hingis and Williams took the court. In a swirling wind that hampered both players, Hingis used her deft touch and uncanny court sense to dictate play. Never in the 6-3, 6-4 victory did the Swiss star appear out of control, off-balance or rushed. Williams hurt her cause with 38 unforced errors. ``I don't think I was as patient as I should have been. I guess everyone knows I like to hit,'' Williams said. ``I suppose I got a little too excited, really wanted to hit a winner.'' Hingis came into the match with a 5-2 career record against the eighth-seeded Williams, but the two 17-year-olds were 2-2 this year. The match promised to be an intriguing battle between power and smarts. But, just as in their only previous Grand Slam tournament encounter _ a 6-0, 6-4 win by Hingis in the U.S. Open final last summer _ the match turned into a one-sided affair. ``It's probably good for me to lose so I can really see what I'm doing wrong and really look at myself and say, `Venus, you're not there,''' she said. Moya, the No. 12 seed who has been ranked as as high as fifth, is hoping to crack back into the top 10 this week. He became the talk of tennis at last year's Australian Open _ for his dashing looks and talent. He upset defending champion Boris Becker in the first round, then went to the final, losing to Sampras. But except for that tournament, the 21-year-old had never gone past the second round of any Grand Slam event. And at Roland Garros, he hadn't gotten past the second round in two previous visits. Now Moya is the highest seed left. On Friday he faces Mantilla. ``We're going to be friends until Friday,'' he said. ``When we get to the court, I will try to kill him.'' Tuesday's play ended with Gustavo Kuerten, the defending champion who lost in the second round, disqualified from doubles. He threw his racket at the chair umpire, hitting a fan in the stands, but apparently not causing injury. ``I'm so sorry for what happened and I regret what I did,'' the Brazilian said today. ``I know that this will make me a more mature guy and will make me grow. I want to make it clear that I never had the intention of hurting anyone on or off the court.''

Russia doubts North Korea has nuclear weapons
MOSCOW (AP) _ Russia does not believe that North Korea has nuclear weapons, a spokesman for the Atomic Energy Ministry said Wednesday. ``If North Korea has a nuclear bomb, it would have to test it,'' but no tests have been conducted, spokesman Georgy Kaurov said, according to the ITAR-Tass news agency. A senior North Korean diplomat recently accused the United States of delaying a deal that froze his country's suspected nuclear program, hinting that communist state could restart the program. North Korea's ambassador to China, Chu Changjun, said a U.S.-led group was lagging behind in building two nuclear reactors. North Korea has also said promised U.S. deliveries of fuel oil are behind schedule. Under a 1994 pact between the longtime foes, Washington pledged to help build the reactors and provide the oil in exchange for North Korea dismantling a reactor believed to have produced plutonium that could be used for bombs. Kaurov said Russian specialists ``are closely watching'' the situation in North Korea. Countries thought to harbor nuclear aspirations have come under closer scrutiny since India and Pakistan conducted nuclear tests last month. (ls)
