Mexico began the process which may lead up to an official extradition request for U.S. agents who allegedly broke national laws during the controversial Operation Casablanca sting which netted Mexican bankers involved with money laundering, Foreign Relations Secretary Rosario Green said Tuesday from Caracas. Green is currently participating in the Organization of American States general assembly in Venezuela. In a telephone interview with the Mexican radio news program ``Para Empezar,'' which was reported by Notimex, Green said she met with U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright Monday night and gave her a document listing alleged crimes committed by U.S. authorities. Sting operations are considered in Mexico to be a form of entrapment and are illegal. The three violations listed in the document are: initiating a commission of a crime (entrapment); money laundering (U.S. authorities admitted that illegal transactions were allowed in order to capture the suspects); and supplanting Mexican authority (an alleged violation of treaty agreements). Green said Albright appeared surprised when she was informed of what laws were violated by U.S. agents. Citing a recent extradition agreement with the United States, Green implored the northern neighbor to attend to these charges. ``In the same way that we have extradited agents that have committed crimes -- when it has been proven, when the judge has given us the arrest order and when we have made all legal recourse -- the return is also expected. (The treaty) works both ways.''''I know it is causing stress ... but this will not be the first time Mexico defends its rights in front of the United States,'' she added. Mexico's foreign relations chief said all necessary protocol will be carried out before her country submits the extradition request. ``I don't know how much time it will take, but I know I have precise instructions from the president that we not restrain ourselves; we are not going to give up, we are going to insist on an investigation.''Albright disagreed with how the operation was carried out without notifying the Mexican government and that ``a notification should have gone out from the State Department,'' according to Green. She added that U.S. citizens need to learn that legal boundaries exist in other countries which are as solid as there own and they should be respected. ``In this respect, in the maintenance of the accords that we have signed, we have to educate (the United States); probably it will take a lot of time, but I believe that we have to keep trying.''

Capital flowed back into emerging markets Tuesday spurring a moderate 1.51-percent recovery in the stock market (Bolsa) and a release of some of the downward pressure that has recently plagued the peso. The Bolsa's main IPC index closed at 4,480, up 66.49 points after its biggest rally since April 28. The peso strengthened 1.4 percent on the day, closing at 8.82. ``The main issue now is whether the depreciation in the peso will translate into inflation,'' said Santander currency analyst, Jorge de Gotari. If this is just over speculation and the central bank, Banco de Mexico (Banxico) will modify its inflation target based on the peso's weakness, then let the markets decide where the peso lands. Analysts fear Banxico will tighten the monetary policy to help keep inflation in check. A weak currency usually means import prices rise, causing inflation to climb. The current government inflation target is 12 percent but the market expects over 13 percent. The recovery comes on the heels of Clinton's promise Sunday to mobilize more aid for Russia to help revive its battered economy. Recently, emerging markets have suffered the ripple effects of Asia's economic crisis as foreign investors opted for the safe-haven economies of Europe, Canada and the United States. ``All indications are that money is starting to flow back into emerging markets,'' said Felipe Garcia an economist with IDA in New York. ``I don't know whether it is just bottom fishing, but prices are depressed so we are at good levels to build positions back up again.'' Brazil's benchmark index recovered 5.6 percent from Monday's 2.5-percent loss after the government intervened to lower interest rates. The Russian index also made a comeback, rising 12 percent. This was extremely encouraging, said Jorge de Gotari, a currency analyst with Mexican brokerage firm Santander in New York. ``It implies that investors are finally starting to differentiate among emerging markets.'' Analysts have been complaining that investors were lumping all emerging markets into the same asset class without looking closer at the individual countries' fundamentals. In Mexico's case, though yields in the short-term treasury bills (cetes) rose for the fifth consecutive week, the high level of foreign interest - particularly in the longer term bonds - implied investors maintain a positive outlook for Mexico's longer-term fundamentals. BC-UN-Macedonia,0451
With Kosovo Annan recommends strengthening UN military presence in Macedonia
By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ Because of increasing violence in Kosovo, U.N. chief Kofi Annan on Wednesday suggested keeping U.N. peacekeepers in neighboring Macedonia until at least next year and raised the possibility of sending more U.N. troops to the area. The 750-member force, which includes nearly 340 Americans, was sent to the Balkans in 1992 to prevent the spread of the ethnic conflict in other parts of the former Yugoslavia. Last December, the Security Council granted a ``final extension'' of the mandate until Aug. 31, and Russian Ambassador Sergey Lavrov said at the time there ``could be no question'' that the troops would leave thereafter. But in a report to the council, Annan said that in light of increased violence in Kosovo and discussions within NATO about an ``expanded international presence in the region,'' it would be ``premature to proceed with a decision to withdraw'' the force. Annan suggested the council consider maintaining the force in Macedonia until at least Feb. 28, 1999. He said he would submit a report next month with ``specific proposals on a possible strengthening of the force's overall capacity.'' He did not say whether that might include additional troops or new equipment. But Annan said the peacekeepers had already increased its patrols along the Macedonian border with Kosovo, a province of the Serb republic of Yugoslavia, and had established 24-hour observation posts. ``Such intensive monitoring, however, cannot be sustained over a long period of time with the current troop strength,'' he said. Annan also noted that the host government, officially known as The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, had asked that the troops remain. Last month, NATO foreign ministers also recommended the U.N. troops stay in Macedonia At their meeting in Luxembourg, the NATO ministers agreed on increased cooperation to help Albania and Macedonia patrol their borders and joint-exercises with forces from the two Balkan nations. The ministers also agreed to step up assistance programs under which NATO has been sending small teams of military advisors to help them secure their borders with Kosovo. They also decided to hold maneuvers in Albania with land and air forces in August. Planned joint-exercises September in Macedonia will be upgraded. The U.N. operation, formally known as the United Nations Preventive Deployment Force, includes troops from six nations. They are Denmark, Finland, Indonesia, Norway and Sweden in addition to the United States.

Aeromexico has suffered a 15-percent fall in sales due to its conflict with the National Flight Attendants' Union (ASSA), Director General of Aeromexico Alfonso Pasquel said Tuesday. The flight attendants' strike for better pay and working conditions, due to start last Monday, would have grounded flights but was averted at the last minute by the Transport and Communications Secretariat's temporary takeover of Aeromexico. The secretariat justified the move, which allows it to hire replacement workers if they strike, on the grounds that the strike would severely disrupt services to parts of the country where Aeromexico is the only carrier. Flight attendants are wearing black and red armbands and have plastered Aeromexico offices in the city center with black and red banners in protest. Union leaders were expected to meet senior management to start talks Tuesday night. Both sides have said that they will offer no new proposals. The Secretary General of ASSA, Alejandra Barrelas, slammed what she called the government's ``unconstitutional'' behavior Tuesday and reaffirmed the union's rejection of the deal offered by Aeromexico. She announced that the union is exploring the legality of the government action under Mexican and North Atlantic Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) law. However, an analyst who wished to remain anonymous doubted its chances of success, ``I think the requisition is totally legal and in line with the constitution,'' he said. ASSA had demanded a 19-percent pay rise and been offered 18 percent by Aeromexico but differences over working conditions and benefits prevented a settlement. Pasquel said the union's demands were unreasonable and were equivalent to a 103-percent increase once benefits had been taken into account and Aeromexico's offer represented a 23-percent rise in real terms. The analyst said that this is in line with wage inflation of about 20 percent for the past year. Aeromexico already has the third highest costs in the world, Pasquel said, and claimed such an increase would cripple the company. The dispute comes at a time when Cintra, Aeromexico's holding company, is only just recovering from a shaky period. Although Cintra reported profits of 1.88 billion pesos in 1997 but first quarter earnings for 1998 were down by 68 percent to 147.9 million pesos compared to the same period in 1997 due to a fall in sales, Aeromexico said. Aeromexico has also been investing in new and renovating old planes, the anonymous analyst said, and their seat occupancy has increased by about 6 percent - a high figure. The Cintra holding group was formed in 1995 to take over the heavily-indebted and near-bankrupt Aeromexico and Mexicana airlines. Debt was swapped for shares and a coalition of banks became the new shareholders --the government being the majority owner through Fobaproa (the bank bailout fund). The government had announced plans to sell off its 50-percent stake before the end of 1998 now that the companies have been restructured.

Dlrs 250 million pledged to support Rwanda's reforms
STOCKHOLM, Sweden (AP) _ Rwanda's efforts to restore social stability through economic reforms were boosted Wednesday when donor nations and international institutions pledged dlrs 250 million in support. The funding for the small central African country where some 500,000 people died in ethnic slaughter in 1994 was negotiated at a two-day meeting in the Swedish capital organized by the World Bank and the Rwandan government. The funds are not targeted for specific programs, said Nils Tcheyan, the World Bank's country director for Rwanda. They are intended to give Rwanda the capacity to follow through on a variety of programs ranging from privatization to improving the health and education systems. BC-Turkey-Drink Privatizing
Turkey's beloved national drink to be privatized
ANKARA, Turkey (AP) _ Raki, Turkey's powerful, anise-flavored alcoholic drink, may soon be produced by brewers other than Turks. The government plans to end the 66-year-long state monopoly on the production of alcoholic beverages, and a draft bill, submitted to Parliament this week, has already attracted the attention of some 30 foreign and Turkish producers, news reports said Wednesday. Among those reportedly interested are the Montreal-based Seagram Co., France's Groupe Pernod Ricard and Britain's UDV. All have applied to the government to produce Raki along with wine and beer, the daily Sabah reported. The privatization of the state-run Spirit and Tobacco Administration is aimed at complying with a customs union deal with the European Union, EU, that requires the elimination of state monopolies. The 1995 customs deal is designed to make Turkish firms more competitive within the EU. Along with the privatization of spirit factories, the government also moved to lift the state monopoly on tobacco production. To protect the drink's reputation, the government registered its name as a trademark. The Turks spent dlrs 536 million on Raki and dlrs 923 million on beer last year. (sh-sf-fd)

BC-Northern Ireland
Candidates set for assembly elections in Northern Ireland
BELFAST, Northern Ireland (AP) _ Northern Ireland's parties completed nominations for their new assembly Wednesday, with the leading foes of compromise eagerly bidding for influence in the new body. Elections of 108 assembly members on June 25 will be a key step in implementing the agreement reached among eight parties and the British and Irish governments in April, and ratified by voters across Ireland on May 22. Within the Protestant majority, the election shapes up as a rerun of the bitter referendum campaign in which Protestant ``unionists'' were evenly split between supporters and opponents of the agreement. Having lost the referendum battle, opponents now hope to win enough seats to gain a strong say in how the assembly works _ or fails. The Rev. Ian Paisley, leader of the Democratic Unionist Party and the chief campaigner against the accord, will be running for a seat. Among his opponents will be Joe Cahill, a reputed former commander of the Irish Republican Army in Belfast and now a senior figure in the IRA-allied Sinn Fein party. To protect the interests of the Catholic minority in Northern Ireland, the assembly will not legislate by a simple majority. Any issue designated a ``key question'' cannot be passed without backing of a majority from both Catholic ``nationalist'' and Protestant ``unionist'' politicians. The largest party in the assembly is likely to be the Ulster Unionist Party, led by David Trimble, a supporter of the agreement. Trimble said Wednesday that his party would campaign under the slogan ``Together Within the Union,'' stressing that Northern Ireland remains under British rule while regaining a measure of local autonomy. ``We are moving together into this new situation and we are saying to the people of Northern Ireland, `This is our chance to actually achieve something. This is for real,' '' Trimble said. Referring to Paisley's forces, Trimble said unionists were fed up with a ``permanent position in the trenches, surviving on a drip feed of old rhetoric, redundant fears and laughable stunts.'' While the Ulster Unionists battle against Paisley's side, interest on the Catholic nationalist side will focus on the competition between Sinn Fein and the Social Democratic and Labor Party, led by John Hume. Sinn Fein's support has grown significantly since the first IRA cease-fire in 1994, and there has been speculation that it is primed to overtake Hume's party. (rb-kg)

Tonkov edges overall leader Pantani at end of tough climb

ALPE DI PAMPEAGO, Italy (AP) _ Pavel Tonkov edged overall leader Marco Pantani by one second Wednesday to claim the 18th stage of the Tour of Italy after the race's top two riders made a late breakaway on the final climb in the Alps. The tough, 115-kilometer (71.3-mile) stage ended at an altitude of 1,760 meters (5,808 feet) above sea level. Pantani finished second for the second straight stage, and held onto the pink jersey heading into the last four days. The Italian leads Tonkov, the 1996 Giro champion and runner-up last year, by 27 seconds in the overall standings. ``I'm not made of steel. I'll give my all again tomorrow, but my adversaries are strong,'' Tonkov said. ``Marco Pantani was in brilliant shape. He pedaled strongly going uphill.'' Favorite Alex Zuelle, who had dominated the cycling classic until it headed into the mountains, lost more time Wednesday. He faltered on the final uphill pass and was fourth, 58 seconds behind Russia's Tonkov. Nicola Miceli was third Wednesday. Zuelle now trails Pantani by more than two minutes overall. Colombia's Chepe Gonzales rode alone at the lead for more than 40 kilometers (25 miles), but was eventually caught by a pack of 22 riders heading into the final climb. Zuelle tried to take off ahead of the leaders but was reeled in, setting the stage for Tonkov and Pantani to break away with 4 kilometers (2.5 miles) left. Tonkov was clocked in 3 hours, 36 minutes, 53 seconds. Nicola Miceli, 10th graf pvs (hjf)

BC-UN-Iraq, 1st Ld-Writethru,0522
Butler to lay out ``road map'' for Iraq to follow to end of sanctions Richardson says Butler delivered ``devastating blow'' to Iraq's credibility; TRIMS
Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with morning session over, By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ Dealing what the U.S. ambassador called a ``devastating blow'' to Iraq's credibility, the chief U.N. inspector used photos, charts and records to press his claim Baghdad is still hiding illegal weapons. Richard Butler presented his evidence before the Security Council in an effort to convince the 15 members that Iraq has still failed to comply with U.N. orders to destroy all long-range missiles and chemical, nuclear and biological weapons. That is the main condition for the council to lift sanctions imposed in August 1990 after President Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait, touching off the Gulf conflict. Iraq says it has destroyed illegal materials, and Russia, France, China and others have been pressuring the U.N. Special Commission, or UNSCOM, which Butler heads, to back up his claims to the contrary. ``UNSCOM has dealt a devastating blow to Iraq's credibility,'' U.S. Ambassador Bill Richardson said after the morning session. ``UNSCOM has produced documents, charts that catalogue the gaps and inconsistencies in Iraqi claims in the chemical, biological and other fields.'' Richardson said the evidence showed a ``pattern of concealment'' by Iraq and that Baghdad still has ``a long way to go'' to satisfy conditions for ending sanctions. ``Iraq has a lot of explaining to do,'' he said. British Ambassador John Weston said it was clear ``there are a number of unanswered questions'' even in the field of missiles, one of the areas where the United Nations said progress in disarmament had been made. The council was to resume its closed-door session later Wednesday. Iraq claims the United States and Britain are manipulating the inspection program to justify maintaining sanctions as long as Saddam remains in power. Butler and his staff have appeared frequently before the council since inspections began in 1991. But U.N. officials said Butler is expected to provide far more technical information and detailed evidence than in previous presentations because of pressure within the council to bring the program to an end. On Tuesday, the council listened to an Iraqi delegation, led by Foreign Minister Mohammed Saeed al-Sahhaf, argue that it has complied with U.N. orders and that sanctions should be ended. British and American diplomats said Iraq provided no new information about its weapons programs. Pressure has increased on Butler's teams since Secretary-General Kofi Annan signed a deal with the Iraqis in February to open Saddam's palaces and other sensitive sites to U.N. inspectors. That defused the possibility of U.S.-led military strikes to force access But the deal has also put pressure on the inspectors to declare Iraq free or weapons or prove it is not.

BC-Air France-Strike, 6th Ld-Writethru
Second round of talks begins; other strikes loom organizer, recasts, trims
Eds: UPDATES with quotes from President Chirac, World Cup AP Photos PAR101-3 By CECILE ROUX Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ The prospect of a World Cup undermined by travel chaos grew Wednesday, with Air France pilots striking for a third day, and other pay disputes threatening to paralyze the transport sector. Baggage handlers stayed off the job, forcing passengers to carry their own luggage for a second day at Paris' biggest airport. The capital's subway workers planned a metro strike and national railworkers prepared a walkout, as did airline mechanics. Top French government ministers and World Cup officials appeared embarrassed by the labor unrest, which could derail the world's biggest international sporting event. ``For a few days France will be the focal point of the world. The welcome must be truly exceptional, even perfect,'' said President Jacques Chirac while visiting the French squad at their training camp outside Paris. ``I hope everybody will show a spirit of responsibility.'' Interior Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement criticized the pilots' ``lack of civic-mindedness,'' saying he felt ``sadness, almost shame.'' Chevenement told Radio Monte Carlo, ``France could show itself as a nation that can't organize a world event anymore.'' Jacques Lambert, director of the World Cup organizing committee, said he hoped reason would prevail. ``If not, it will be a serious setback for all the work we've been doing for five years to stage the tournament as well as possible,'' Lambert said. Talks at Air France resumed at 3:20 p.m. (1320 GMT) Wednesday, after no progress was reported from the first round Tuesday. Air France President Jean-Cyril Spinetta predicted ``long and difficult'' bargaining. But the head of the union that represents most of the airline's 3,200 pilots softened his tone, saying the pilots understood the need to cut costs to make the company competetive. In the meantime, Air France said its Wednesday schedule included only 17 percent of its usual long-distance flights, 30 percent of its short and medium-distance routes from Charles de Gaulle Airport and 43 percent from Orly. The company wants to give the pilots, among the highest paid in the world, stock in exchange for 500 million francs (dlrs 83 million) in pay cuts. And it's offered to eventually eliminate a two-tier salary schedule that pays less to new pilots. Air France pilots average 1 million francs (dlrs 160,000), the airline said. The carrier, which reported a profit in the last two years, could lose 100 million francs (dlrs 16.7 million) per day during the strike. Lambert, the World Cup official, said Air France could guarantee travel throughout the tournament for all participating teams. The airline's mechanics threatened Wednesday to walk off the job over pay grievances. Paris subway drivers with the Communist-led CGT union were to walk off the job Thursday. At the national railway SNCF, conductors with three unions were to strike Friday night though Sunday evening. Its engineers announced plans for a June 10 strike, the day the World Cup opens. (dgs-ip)

The teachers of the non-government primary schools continued their hunger strike unto death for the third consecutive day in the city's Osmani Uddyan on Tuesday. The Bangladesh Non-government Primary Teachers Association launched the action programme since Sunday last pressing for the realisation of their five-point demands. The demands of the teachers include nationalisation of all the registered primary schools and payment of salaries similar to that enjoyed by the government primary school teachers from July, 1996. The government on Tuesday initiated an informal dialogue with the leaders of the Association. The dialogue lasted for about three hours from 3 pm at the Central Office of the Awami League at Bangabandhu Avenue. The talks between the leaders of the non-government primary school teachers and ruling party ended without any result, said an insider of the meeting. A source said that the government side at the talks requested the Association leaders to withdraw their action programme first. Then they would arrange a meeting between the Prime Minister and the Association leaders, the source added. Most of the striking teachers opposed the proposal and expressed their opinion in favour of continuing the action programme, it further added. The Association was represented, among others, by Shamsul Alam, Akkas Ali Sheikh, Hasanuzzaman Ratan and Khairul Kabir while Amir Hossain Amu, Mofazzal Hossain Chowdhury Maya and Nurul Islam Nahid represented the Awami League at the talks. On the third day of their hunger strike programme on Tuesday, a total of 102 teachers participated. Of them four fell ill. Three of them were taken to the ICDDRB while another was admitted to the Dhaka Medical College Hospital, said the Organising Secretary of the Association Mriganka Mohan Saha. Jatiya Party Chairman Hussain Muhammad Ershad and Secretary General Naziur Rahman Manjur visited the striking teachers in the morning. They expressed solidarity with the action programme of the teachers. Besides, former Chairman of the Bangladesh Red Crescent Society Shahidul Huq Jamal, Joint Secretary General of Islami Shashantantra Andolan Hemayetuddin, leaders of Ganotantrik Chhatra Oikya and Bangladesh Chhatra Union also visited the teachers on Tuesday.

BC-Afghanistan-Quake-Relief, 1st Ld-Writethru,0669
UN, Red Cross trying to get food to hungry quake victims helicopters. With Afghanistan-Quake; Afghanistan-Fighting
Eds: UPDATES with weather hampers efforts. US offers to find two AP Photos ANG102, 104-105; SBD109 By JUDITH INGRAM Associated Press Writer
FAISABAD, Afghanistan (AP) _ Rainstorms and a shortage of helicopters and fuel hampered international efforts Wednesday to get aid to survivors of a deadly earthquake in northern Afghanistan that killed as many as 5,000 people. Food appeared to be the biggest need after urgent medical supplies. The extent of the damage caused by Saturday's 6.9 magnitude earthquake still was unclear Wednesday as helicopters located remote devastated villages not even on the aid agency's maps. The earthquake triggered landslides, sending mountain villages into the valleys and obliterating others. In the village of Regi perched on a peak at the end of a deep valley, about half of the 110 houses had been completely destroyed. In the ruins, the bodies of 11 people lay buried. Medical teams treated the wounded. More health problems lay ahead in part because landslides buried the villages' fresh water supply and the nearest source of clean water is now 20 kilometers (12 miles) away. With dwindling food stocks, villagers were cooking grass, said journalists aboard the helicopters. The World Food Program has managed to get 1.5 tons of wheat, vegetable oil and high-protein biscuits by helicopter to remote Shari Basurkh, very close to the epicenter. As many as 10,000 people could be facing serious food shortages, said Rupert Collevile, a U.N. spokesman in Faisabad, the provincial capital. In Rostaq _ heavily damaged by Saturday's quake and the site of an earlier earthquake in February that killed 2,300 people _ the United Nations will be setting up bakeries to feed the hungriest. Temporary shelter and clean water also were high priorities for humanitarian workers. ``There is plenty of water,'' said Chris Johnson, a water quality specialist with the Oxfam charity, during a brief respite in the steady rain that turned roads in the Faisabad region into fordable rivers. ``The majority of it is filthy.'' The earthquakes, about three months apart, highlighted severe public health problems that already existed in the remote poverty stricken regions of Afghanistan. Many of the people who sought medical treatment from the aid helicopters that touched down appeared to be suffering from diseases for a long time. But the quake has worsened already dismal public hygiene. In Regi the stench of the carcasses of dead animals hung heavy in the air, said journalists who visited the village on Wednesday. Many human bodies had yet to be recovered from the rubble. In the village of Rostaq, where the quake had crushed 140 students in a school run by the Swedish-Afghan Committee, founded by Olaf Palma, 40 men with horses and donkeys were trying to dig out the dead. Logistical problems continued to plague aid workers scrambling to get the considerable supplies of food, blankets, tents and plastic sheetings they have for the victims. The United Nations and the International Red Cross together have three helicopters, but the United Nations has put out an appeal for more helicopters. However, heavy rains forced several flights to return to Pakistan still laden with their supplies. The relentless rain in the area has increased the need to hurry emergency tents and plastic sheeting for thousands of people sleeping outdoors _ too frightened of another earthquake to go inside, said Sarah Russell, a spokesperson in neighboring Pakistan. The United States has offered to find two 20-ton cargo helicopters to assist in the relief efforts. ``If the U.S. succeeds in finding these helicopters, it will be fantastic news,'' said Alfredo Witschi-Cestari, U.N. Coordinator for Afghanistan.

BC-South Africa-Amnesty,0279
Inkatha members, right-wing Nazis, get amnesty
CAPE TOWN, South Africa (AP) _ In a dark night shortly before South Africa's historic first democratic elections, black Zulu nationalists and right-wing white Nazis raided a police station in KwaZulu-Natal to steal firearms. During the raid in March 1994, they killed one policeman, wounded two others and stole weapons, the five men told the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which is investigating apartheid-era crimes. On Wednesday, the panel chaired by Nobel Laureate Desmond Tutu granted amnesty to four applicants. The fifth, James Zulu, was killed earlier this year in an unrelated event. Zulu and Morton Christie were members of the Inkatha Freedom Party, a black Zulu nationalist group, that collaborated with the Afrikaner Weerstandsbeweging (AWB, Afrikaner Resistance Movement), a right-wing white group, for political convenience. The panel also granted amnesty to AWB members Harry Jardine and Christo Brand. Morton Christie was a member of both Inkatha and AWB, the panel said. The four men told the panel that their intent in raiding the police station was to arm themselves against African National Congress operatives in political infighting that has claimed more than 10,000 lives in the last decade. With recent weapons thefts from an army base in Bloemfontein, the government is nervous about a resurgence of similar violence prior to next year's national elections. The ANC won the April 1994 elections. To obtain amnesty, applicants must convince the panel they are telling the truth and that they acted out of political motives.

JAKARTA (JP): The government will soon ratify an International Labor Union (ILO) convention on the freedom of association and protection of the right to organize, Minister of Manpower Fahmi Idris promised yesterday. Fahmi is scheduled to announce Indonesia's new stance on workers' rights to assemble during his address, planned for next Tuesday, during the ILO's three-week convention in Geneva. President B.J. Habibie will sign a presidential decree to adopt ILO Convention No. 87. Given the short time available, the decree will then be submitted to the House of Representatives for deliberation and final ratification, Fahmi said. ``Up to now we have been regarded as a country which does not support the protection of human rights, fails to give freedom for workers,'' Fahmi conceded in a media briefing after he met with President B.J. Habibie at the Bina Graha presidential office. Fahmi was accompanied by Coordinating Minister for Economy, Finance and Industry Ginandjar Kartasasmita. ``With this ratification Indonesia now adopts the policy that any labor organizations are allowed to operate as long as they abide by the prevailing laws,'' he said. During former president Soeharto's 32-year tenure, the government only recognized the Federation of All Indonesian Workers Union (FSPSI). With the adoption of the convention, the government will allow at least two more trade unions, including the hitherto banned Indonesian Prosperous Labor Union (SBSI), Fahmi said. Another new union will also be formally recognized, he added, but did not elaborate. Muchtar Pakpahan established SBSI in 1992; it was banned two years later. Pakpahan was also sentenced to a four-year prison term for allegedly instigating a labor riot in Medan, North Sumatra in 1994. The ILO annual meeting in Geneva has in previous years been marked by an international call to the government to release Pakpahan and to recognize the independent labor union. Soeharto's administration persistently ignored the call. Soeharto even turned down U.S. President Bill Clinton's appeal to him in November to allow Pakpahan to travel abroad for medical treatment. Habibie released Pakpahan and another government critic, Sri Bintang Pamungkas, from jail last month. Fahmi informed Pakpahan Monday of the government's decision to recognize SBSI. Pakpahan will accompany Fahmi at the Geneva meeting and will act as one of his advisors, along with FSPSI leaders. ``The labor union (representatives) will act as advisors, including Pakpahan,'' said the minister. SBSI and FSPSI jointly urged the ILO on Monday to press Indonesia to adopt ILO conventions in order to ensure the protection of workers' rights. FSPSI's Ali Samioen hoped the government would agree to adopt and ratify Convention No. 87, Convention No. 105 on the abolition of forced labor, Convention No. 111 on the discrimination of employment and occupation and Convention No. 138 on minimum wages. The minister, a successful businessman, also called on financially able companies to voluntarily raise their workers' wages although Soeharto froze minimum regional wage levels following the collapse of many companies in the economic slump. ``There are several sectors which are actually able to increase wages including the plantation, cigarette, tobacco and food and beverage sectors,'' the minister noted, adding that he would directly persuade companies to improve workers' welfare. He estimated that at least 15.4 million people would be unemployed by the end of this year as the economy is expected to contract by up to 10 percent. ``The Ministry of Manpower is facing an extraordinary problem, and we will adopt several policies (to solve it),'' Fahmi said.

BC-Russia-Economy, 2nd Ld-Writethru
Russian market rallies; government says it's not seeking emergency aid Kiriyenko arriving in France, government announcing utility price cuts. CHANGES byline.
Eds: AMs. RECASTS and UPDATES throughout with market results, AP Photos planned By MITCHELL LANDSBERG Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ The Russian stock market rallied for a second day Wednesday, buoyed by rumors that the country's flailing economy might soon be rescued by a hefty international aid package. However, Prime Minister Sergei Kiriyenko, arriving in Paris for talks with French officials, continued to play down the rumors, and a Finance Ministry spokesman reiterated that Moscow hasn't sought emergency aid _ at least not formally. ``The Russian government hasn't officially turned to foreign financial institutions with a request for emergency aid,'' spokesman Oleg Zhukov said. However, he did say the government is negotiating about new borrowing from Western commercial banks, and possibly from the International Monetary Fund. Kiriyenko and other top government officials have been insisting that Russia can pull itself out of its financial chasm with only minimal help from the West. To that end, the government issued rare one-week treasury bills in a desperate attempt to bolster its treasury and stabilize its turbulent financial markets. The government sold most of the issue by midday, agreeing to one-week yields of an average 40 percent. ``This indicates reasonably strong demand,'' said Robert Devane, head of fixed income at Moscow brokerage Troika-Dialog. The Kremlin also announced that it would be cutting natural gas, electricity and railroad freight rates in an effort to stimulate the economy. It didn't say how much the prices would fall. The moves are aimed at ending a crisis that began last week with a steep drop in the Russian stock market and has threatened to trigger a costly devaluation of the ruble. The stock exchange has regained significant ground in the past two days, rising 12 percent Tuesday and 8 percent Wednesday, largely on the assumption that aid from the West was on its way. ``Traders were more sure today that there will be help,'' said Mikhail Dorfman, a trader at the ATON brokerage in Moscow. Moreover, the ruble has been steady in recent days without major support from Central Bank, which says it has plenty of reserves left to prevent a run on the currency. Altogether, the Russian stock market is down about 50 percent from the beginning of the year _ the world's worst performance and a sharp change from the previous year's record growth of 98 percent. The new treasury bills offered Wednesday are designed to raise quick cash so Russia can keep up with payments on its existing debt and reassure investors that it will not default. There had been speculation that Kiriyenko's trip to Paris _ his first trip abroad as prime minister _ would lead to an announcement of an emergency bailout plan by the IMF or the Group of Eight industrialized nations. Speaking to reporters after his arrival, the prime minister said Russia needed to improve its economic integration with the West, but said he had not come to France primarily to see financial aid. ``The issue is not aid concretely for Russia,'' Kiriyenko said responding to a question about whether he would ask French leaders for support of a bailout package. He also called on the European Union to give Russia freer access _ ``equal conditions and equal opportunities''_ to its markets. (ml/ls)

BC-FEA-Welcome to France, 1st Ld-Writethru,0843
France throws open her doors for World Cup, but the welcome mat is daunting controversy AP Special Correspondent
EDS: ADDS quote from President Chirac, details of World Cup ticket AP Photo By MORT ROSENBLUM
PARIS (AP) _ France has thrown open her doors for the 1998 World Cup, but _ what with strikes, demonstrations and chaos _ furious visitors are having to fight their way across the welcome mat. ``This place is a catastrophe, a national humiliation,'' muttered Amer Houari, a Parisian cabbie who waited three hours for an airport fare despite long lines of passengers desperate for a taxi. ``And tomorrow is likely to be even worse,'' he added. ``It seems like the only thing we French are good at is wreaking havoc.'' Air France pilots struck Monday, canceling up to 90 percent of international flights by the official World Cup carrier a little over a week before the kickoff of a month of matches. The pilots threatened to stay out for two weeks, but talks continued in an effort to find a compromise. President Jacques Chirac, visiting the French squad Wednesday at its training camp outside Paris, called for all concerned to show ``responsibility.'' ``For a few days France will be the focal point of the world. The welcome must be truly exceptional, even perfect,'' he said. Meanwhile, Paris is already jammed for the French Open tennis tournament and the annual French arms fair at Le Bourget airport. Passengers who managed to find alternate flights to Charles de Gaulle Airport discovered that baggage handlers were also on strike, and luggage was dumped into a roiling sidewalk crowd outside. ``Is Paris always like this?'' asked Lily Goh, from Singapore, as her delicate orchid corsage wilted in the chaotic crush. ``We spent 13 hours flying and 10 hours waiting for our bags.'' Her husband, who had come to set up a World Cup exhibition, was seeking their luggage among a multinational maelstrom of families, business travelers, confused policemen and customs officers. Marilyn Barry, a New Yorker who had organized a canal barge trip for friends and family, gave up trying to locate a group which had come in on another airline. Her humor was wearing thin. ``What a disgrace,'' repeated Marguerite Tinguy, a Frenchwoman, as she tried to find someone to answer questions. At the airport information booth, hostesses shrugged, as bemused as everyone else. Police officers brusquely refused help, preoccupied with a snarl of buses, baggage trucks and people pushing carts. By afternoon, airlines simply gave up, and passengers had to lug their own bags from planeside while baggage handlers watched, amused. And few of the new arrivals were aware of what was in store in the days to follow. Vague threats of terrorism hang in the air. Police arrested three more people Wednesday because of intelligence that Islamic groups may try to disrupt the Cup. So far, 90 suspects have been detained around Europe. On Thursday, left-leaning unions plan a ``national day of action,'' including mass rallies at crucial points around Paris and marches that would paralyze main thoroughfares. Eight separate demonstrations were planned by workers in transport, energy, public services, health, construction and commerce. Strikes were expected to at least partially disrupt the Paris metro on Thursday and long-distance trains on Friday. In addition, railway workers called a one-day strike for June 10, the day the World Cup opens. It was not clear which trains would be affected. For most Frenchmen, ire seemed directed at Air France pilots for exploiting the World Cup to dramatize their wage complaints. As the state airline privatizes, pilots have rejected a plan to receive stock in exchange for lower wages. Some Air France captains earn more than dlrs 200,000 a year, 40 per cent more than comparable Lufthansa salaries. National political leaders condemned ``a shameful embarrassment'' after four years of planning for a trouble-free World Cup. For many, just getting to the World Cup was a non-starter after most tickets were sold to French supporters, infuriating foreign fans and prompting a lawsuit from members of the European Parliament. ``It's the World Cup, not the France Cup,'' howled Philip Jenkinson, the MEPs' chief counsel. Extra tickets were put on sale to curb the anger _ but one number was for French callers, the other for the rest of Europe. Some French shrugged off the transport dispute as yet another manifestation of workers' right to strike. The popular Paris tabloid daily ``Liberation'' caught the mood, a mixture of outrage and perverse pride, with its Tuesday front page. A drawing showed a blue-white-red airplane with the grinning face of a beret-wearing Frenchman in place of the nose. The wings were formed by a long baguette sandwich clamped in his teeth. The headline read: ``Pilots: A Strike Like Only the French Can Manage.''

JAKARTA (JP): President B.J. Habibie urged the people yesterday to put aside differences about his administration's legitimacy to work with the government to restore the country's economy. Promising his Cabinet would do its utmost to carry out reforms in all spheres of life, he said it would not be able to finish its tasks overnight. Habibie also assured the nation that he would always position himself as the leaderof the country's 202 million people, although he realized that not everybody supported him. ``Without any previous plan or expectation, I received the honor to lead the Indonesian people, including those who are not happy with me, and even lead those who possibly plan to kill me,'' he said in a meeting with 45 leaders of the Indonesian Buddhist Council (Walubi) and Indonesian Hindu Dharma Council (PHDI) at Bina Graha presidential office. People should focus their energy and attention on the future and not waste time rehashing the past, he said. ``Total reform is for the future, not for the past... The new government will prioritize assistance for small and medium companies as 70 percent of employment is provided bythis sector, he said. ``I do realize during this monetary crisis small and medium scale businesses are in fact the most economically resilient.'' The President said he was confident the country's reform policies were on track and had even won praise from the international community, including the International Monetary Fund's Asia Pacific director Hubert Neiss. ``We'll just wait for the realization of his statement about the organization's (plan) to assist Indonesia in overcoming the crisis.'' Habibie also expressed his concern about groups of people who claimed they spoke on behalf of people when they were only seeking to further their personal agendas. ``I am not blind, and not deaf, my friends are not only national leaders but also ordinary people,'' he said. BC-Sports-Canada-Sports Violence,0600
Psychiatrists see sports violence as dangerous influence on kids
Eds: Moving also on general news lines. By DAVID CRARY Associated Press Writer
TORONTO (AP) _ Psychiatrists have become increasingly worried that when pro athletes lash out _ with fists, baseballs aimed at opposing players or a chomp of their teeth _ they are setting the wrong example for children. About 17,000 mental-health professionals tackled problems ranging from abusive coaches to gang rapes by athletes during a symposium Tuesday night at the American Psychiatric Association's annual meeting in Toronto. Panelists acknowledged that violence has existed in sports throughout history, but contended there is new cause for alarm because children see so much of the misconduct depicted, and often glorified, on television. ``It seems every week something horrible is happening in the world of athletics, something that goes over the line, and that our kids see over and over again on TV,'' said Dr. Ronald Kamm, a specialist in sports psychiatry who organized the symposium. ``Television has made athletes larger than life,'' Kamm said. ``When kids see the violence in sports, they copy the behavior of these role models.'' Incidents discussed at the workshop included Latrell Sprewell's attack on his basketball coach and boxer Mike Tyson's ear-biting outburst, but panelists have plenty of fresh ammunition for their arguments. They mentioned defending champion Gustavo Kuerten's disqualification from the French Open this week for throwing his tennis racket, and the May 19 baseball brawl between the New York Yankees and Baltimore Orioles, provoked when pitcher Armando Benitez drilled Tino Martinez in the back with a fastball. Panelists suggested a range of remedies, including increased emphasis on sportsmanship in youth leagues, alcohol bans at stadiums to reduce fan misconduct, and tougher penalties for athletes who engage in violence. The down-to-earth hand-wringing about sports violence was mingled with some highly technical terminology. Dr. Antonia Baum, a psychiatrist from the University of Rochester in the U.S. state of New York, spoke about ``intermittent explosive disorder'' _ a seemingly apt description for much of the behavior under discussion. Kamm suggested that animal behavior studies could provide useful insights into sports violence. For example, he said Benitez _ in throwing at Martinez after surrendering a home run to Bernie Williams _ was trying to reassert his territorial dominance. Kamm said some research has suggested that certain athletes may be genetically predisposed to violence. He cited one study linking violent tendencies among hockey players to their testosterone levels. Dr. Robert Burton, a Northwestern University psychiatrist who has served as consultant to the Chicago Bears football team, discussed the problem of verbal abuse in sports. Screaming coaches, jeering fans, trash-talking athletes _ all contribute to an environment conducive to sports violence, he said. ``Sports is such a big part of peoples lives, and there's no organized group out there to oppose abuse,'' Burton said. ``As psychiatrists, we can say it's just plain wrong.'' The panelists said psychiatry in underutilized by the sports establishment, in large part because of resistance by coaches, owners and parents. Baum said coaches and parents often do not want to hear any suggestion that a young athlete may be suffering emotional damage because of participation in a sport.

URGENT Eds: UPDATES WITH locomotive apparently decoupling before accident, With BC-Germany-High Speed Train AP Photos By CLAUS-PETER TIEMANN Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ A high-speed passenger train derailed Wednesday in northern Germany, killing at least 80 people and seriously injuring 200 as car after car of the train crumpled into the concrete base of an overpass. The crash _ Germany's deadliest rail disaster in 31 years _ happened at 11 a.m. as the Hamburg-bound train sped at 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour approaching the station in Eschede, 50 kilometers (35 miles) north of Hanover. The cause of the accident remained unclear. Klaus Rathert, a regional official, told a news conference that the front locomotive apparently decoupled from the passenger cars, causing them to derail and crash into the overpass. The train's driver told officials he realized he'd lost the passenger cars when the train jerked and a brake signal came on, Rathert said. The account conflicted with earlier reports suggesting that an auto had plunged into the train from the overpass, causing the derailment. Police said an automobile was crushed beneath the wreckage, but it was unclear where the car was parked at the time of the accident. They said it was probably sitting along the tracks, not on the overpass. Police spokesman Joachim Lindenberg told ARD television that the auto belonged to a rail employee who was working along the tracks. He said that anyone that close to the accident could not have survived. Neither Rathert nor Deutsche Bahn immediately confirmed that account. Views of the wreckage offered no clear clues as to what caused the accident. The nose of the train had cleared the bridge, while the cars derailed and jackknifed into each other and the overpass, collapsing it. At least 13 cars derailed. The force of the pile-up pushed the cars meters (yards) high into the air. The train was carrying at least 350 passengers. Regional officials said 100 people were lightly injured, in addition to the 200 serious injuries. They said they expected the death toll to rise as rescue workers pulled apart the wreckage. Survivors were taken to hospitals throughout the region. The Red Cross chartered six buses to take most of the uninjured to Hamburg, spokesman Harald Krueger said. The accident was the worst on Germany's premier high-speed ICE line, inaugurated in 1991. A 1967 rail accident near Magdeburg in then-East Germany, killed 94 people in the deadliest rail accident since World War II. A crossing barrier closed on a rail tanker filled with gasoline, causing it to explode and spreading fire into passenger cars. The worst accident in western Germany was in 1971, when a train carrying children on a field trip collided with a freight train, killing 46 people. A Deutsche Bahn executive Johannes Ludewig, said he was ``deeply dismayed and horrified by the proportions of this accident.'' Several of the rail cars were demolished, and splintered glass covered the scene. Luggage was piled next to the wreckage as workers struggled to pry passengers from the train. More than 1,100 rescue workers were at the scene, including trauma surgeons and border patrol personnel who helped free passengers trapped inside the rail cars. Christian Krettek, of University Hospital in Hanover, told CNN that rescue workers expected the death toll to rise, and it was still unclear if there were more dead inside the shattered train cars. A crane was positioned to lift chunks of the bridge to reach cars underneath. The accident closed train traffic in both directions. Federal Transport Minister Matthias Wissmann, Lower Saxony state governor Gerhard Schroeder and German railway executives were en route to the scene. The ICE train is Germany's fastest, connecting all major cities at speed up to 280 kilometers (175 miles) an hour. The train travels from Munich to Hamburg, covering a distance of more than 950 kilometers (about 600 miles), in 5 hours and 37 minutes. Regular train service takes more than eight hours. The train that crashed Wednesday was a first-generation ICE model powered by two electric-powered locomotives pulling up to 14 passenger cars with a capacity of 759 passengers. At top speed the train requires 2.8 kilometers (1.7 miles) to come to an emergency stop. The high-speed trains carry more than 65,000 passengers daily. (cb-gb-aet)

PARIS (AP) _ Russian Prime Minister Sergei Kiriyenko insisted he wasn't looking for handouts following a meeting Wednesday with French President Jacques Chirac. After arriving in Paris at the start of a two-day visit _ his first overseas trip since becoming Prime Minister in April _ Kiriyenko twice told reporters an economic rescue package was not on his agenda. ``Neither on the official program nor outside the official program is that (aid) a question,'' Kiriyenko said after his meeting at the Elysee Palace with Chirac. A small man in a blue suit who at times appeared lost among the delegation of husky Russian businessmen and bodyguards who accompanied him, Kiriyenko nevertheless projected confidence. Russia's ongoing financial crisis has fueled speculation that some kind of aid package from the world's leading industrialized nation may be needed, primarily to prevent a collapse of the ruble. Kiriyenko did say ``relations between G-7 countries and Russia have reached a new stage.'' He didn't elaborate but said it is vital for the European Union to open its markets to Russian goods. Finance officials from the G-7 are to meet in Paris next week, with the slump in the yen against the dollar and Russia's economic troubles among the issues high on their agenda. Speaking to reporters at Charles de Gaulle airport, Kiriyenko said Russia must further integrate into the world economy in order to be able to better withstand financial shock waves like those that have shaken Asia and Russia itself recently. The Russian stock market has fallen about 50 percent from the beginning of 1998, a dramatic change from the previous year's record growth of 98 percent. ``We should be more integrated in the industrial process and the entire array of economic relations with other countries,'' Kiriyenko said. In addition to Chirac, Kiriyenko was to meet with Prime Minister Lionel Jospin and leading French lawmakers and businessmen. France is a modest trading partner, just eighth among Western European nations, and Russia would like to increase ties with aerospace, nuclear and automobile manufacturers. However, France traditionally enjoys good political relations with Russia and could be expected to support an eventual economic aid package. (dgs-ip)

JERUSALEM (AP) _ Israel's armed forces chief of staff postponed a visit to New Delhi to avoid appearances that Israel is siding with India against Pakistan, an Israeli official said Wednesday. Tensions between traditional rivals India and Pakistan have grown considerably since both carried out nuclear tests last month. India was the first to conduct the tests, and Pakistan reportedly suspected Israel of plotting to launch an air strike against the Pakistani nuclear reactor with India's help to thwart Pakistani tests. Israeli officials have dismissed the allegations as baseless. Israel has relations with India, but not with Pakistan, the first Islamic nation to go nuclear. Lt. Gen. However, after India carried out its nuclear tests, the Indian government was informed that Shahak would like to postpone the visit, said an Israeli official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Yediot Ahronot daily said no new date for a Shahak visit has been set. India's ambassador to Israel said the visit had been canceled due to scheduling problems. Israeli officials feared that a Shahak visit at this time would encourage baseless speculation in the Islamic world that Israel and India are cooperating on the development of nuclear weapons, Yediot said. Israel is widely believed to be an undeclared nuclear power. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's senior adviser, David Bar-Illan, declined comment on the Yediot Ahronot report. India's ambassador Ranjan Mathay said that India had not consulted Israel before carrying out its tests last month and denied nuclear cooperation. ``We have ongoing official level meetings with various departments of government, the Israeli government and Indian government,'' Mathay told Israel's Channel 2 TV. Foreign reports said Israel and India have set up projects in several defense research areas, including guidance technology, special materials and electronic warfare. The Defense Ministry said Wednesday it would not discuss military ties with other countries. Vengeance While fully supporting the establishment of a commission to look into Soeharto's alleged power abuses, Marzuki also urged the government to act quickly in order to prevent the current mood from deviating from a search for justice into full-blown vengeance against Soeharto and his family. ``The government needs to step in quickly and decisively to avoid possible reprisals,'' Marzuki said. STOCKHOLM, Sweden (AP) _ Rwanda's efforts to restore social stability through economic reforms were boosted Wednesday when donor nations and international institutions pledged dlrs 250 million in support. The funding for the small central African country where some 500,000 people died in ethnic slaughter in 1994 was negotiated at a two-day meeting in the Swedish capital organized by the World Bank and the Rwandan government. Rwanda, which has an estimated dlrs 35 million gross domestic product, is almost exclusively dependent on donors' aid, which subsidizes half of its annual budget. Exports of tea and coffee, mostly to Germany, are the main source of hard currency. Industry employs only 3 percent of the working population. The funds are not targeted for specific programs, said Nils Tcheyan, the World Bank's country director for Rwanda. They are intended to give Rwanda the capacity to follow through on a variety of programs ranging from privatization to improving the health and education systems. Rwanda currently has debts of some dlrs 1.3 billion, Rwandan Finance Minister Donald Kaberuka said at a news conference. At least dlrs 34 million of the funds pledged on Wednesday is earmarked to help Rwanda service that debt, Tcheyan said. Kaberuka on Monday had appealed for more than dlrs 750 million in support, but said the amount pledged on Wednesday was a substantial step forward ``in the struggle for development and national reconciliation.'' Most of the money is to be disbursed within the next 12 months, Tcheyan said. The meeting included representatives from Austria, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Norway, the Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland, Britain and the United States. Multilateral institutions at the talks included the African Development Bank and the Arab Bank for Economic Development in Africa.

JAKARTA (JP): The State Logistics Agency (Bulog) estimated yesterday that its domestic rice procurement may fall to 250,000 metric tons this year, the lowest level in 20 years, due to a decline in rice production. Bulog chairman Beddu Amang, however, said that the agency would be able to meet the domestic demand with imports estimated to reach three million tons this year. He said Bulog would import 3.1 million tons of rice if its procurement reached only 250,000 tons. ``But if the agency could purchase 500,000 tons from local farmers, imports would be cut to around 2.85 million tons,'' he told reporters after a hearing with the House of Representatives' Commission III for agriculture, forestry and plantations, transmigration and food affairs. Bulog said its rice procurement in the January-to-May period plunged 94 percent to 96,512 tons from 1.55 million tons in the same period last year. ``This year's procurement will likely reach only 250,000 tons. It is the lowest level in 20 years,'' Beddu said, adding that domestic procurement reached 1.95 million tons last year and 1.43 million tons in 1996. He said Bulog initially planned to buy about one million tons locallythis year but the decline in production caused by the drought made it impossible to meet the procurement target. Bulog's rice stocks on May 28 stood at 2.5 million tons, sugar at 592,686 tons, wheat flour at 325,000 tons and soybeans at 102,596 tons. He said the rice stocks were sufficient for three months while those for sugar and other commodities could last up to 28 months. Beddu, however, ruled out a possible rice shortage in the coming months. ``Don't worry, our stocks will increase because our rice imports continue to flow in from Thailand, China and Vietnam and we are still receiving rice aid from other countries.'' He added that Japan has pledged to supply 500,000 tons of rice in soft loans with a 30-year maturity and 100,000 tons as a grant, Taiwan would sell 200,000 tons, China 250,000 tons and Vietnam 10,000 tons and Thailand would give 5,000 tons in a grant. The government is still negotiating for another 400,000-ton rice grant from Japan and 100,000 tons from Taiwan, Beddu said. Recent reports have said Thai rice and sugar exporters have stopped accepting Indonesia's letters of credit (L/Cs) for rice and sugar orders due to the uncertain conditions here. But Beddu said that Thai exporters had agreed to take Indonesia's L/Cs if they were opened by state banks and endorsed by foreign banks in Singapore. Beddu also said yesterday that Bulog planned to invite local and international tenders to buy commodities for the agency. ``We will no longer go to the international market quietly. We will invite foreign suppliers through international tenders if necessary. This will apply to any commodities,'' Beddu said. Beddu added that the subsidies on basic commodities would remain until the economic situation improved to help remedy the pains of the common people. ``The International Monetary Fund has agreed on the subsidies which will amount to Rp 5.3 trillion (US$460 million) to import basic commodities. The IMF has asked us to gradually remove the subsidies but this depends on the economic conditions,'' he said. The government's agreement with the IMF stipulates that subsidies on all commodities, except rice, must be abolished by Oct. 1. ``But if we are not able to scrap the subsidies, then we don't have to. We understand that the subsidies will burden our state budget, but on the other hand we have to help our people,'' Beddu said.

Israel: Mastermind of Achille Lauro hijacking no security threat
By JACK KATZENELL Associated Press Writer
JERUSALEM (AP) _ A former PLO guerrilla chief who mastermined the 1985 murder of an American Jew during the Achille Lauro cruise ship hijacking does not pose a threat to Israeli security, the attorney general ruled Wednesday. Attorney General Elyakim Rubinstein wrote that Israel doesn't plan to seek the arrest of Mohammed Abbas, who is currently visiting in the Palestinian-controlled Gaza Strip. Rubinstein responded to a petition by two Israelis and Dov Hikind, a New York State Assemblyman from Brooklyn, who have asked the Supreme Court to order the Israel to arrest and try Abbas for murder. The court has not said when it would issue a decision. In a statement to the court, Rubinstein said Abbas ``does not pose a security threat'' and that an arrest ``would probably cause real friction with the Palestinian side.'' Guerrillas acting on Abbas' orders seized the Italian cruise ship off Egypt in 1985. They shot an elderly American passenger in a wheelchair, Leon Klinghoffer, and threw his body overboard. The hijackers surrendered to Egyptian authorities, who put Abbas and his men on a flight for Tunisia, where the PLO was headquartered at the time. But the U.S. Navy forced the flight down in Ital,y and the Italian authorities allowed Abbas to flee. An Italian court later convicted Abbas and two other PLO guerrillas in absentia and sentenced them to life in prison. In 1996, Israel allowed Abbas, also known as Abul Abbas, to return to the Gaza Strip to attend a session of the Palestine National Council. Since then he has returned to Gaza three times and has described the current stay as an extended one. '' We had always said that what took place on the ship had not been planned and had not been organized and I wasn't on the ship,'' Abbas told The Associated Press from Gaza. Under a 1993 peace agreement with the Palestinians, Israel allowed thousands of PLO guerrillas to return from abroad and enter the new autonomous Palestinian areas. Rubinstein wrote that ``it would not be reasonable to prosecute (Abbas) for acts which he committed before Sept. 13 1993.''

Emergency fund for Siberian tiger makes first move
GLAND, Switzerland (AP) _ A new fund to help the endangered Siberian tiger is moving to aid fire-fighting efforts at two nature reserves in eastern Russia, the World Wildlife Fund said Wednesday. An allocation of some dlrs 20,000 is intended to buy and repair fire-fighting vehicles and other equipment in the Lazovsky and Sikhote-Alin reserves, home to the most of the surviving 425 to 475 wild Siberian tigers. Unusually dry weather conditions in the area, near the Sea of Japan, have led to forest fires which ``have already destroyed over 2,000 hectares (4,900 acres) of prime tiger land,'' the WWF said in a statement. Dry weather is set to continue through the summer, with a high risk of more fires, it added. ``It is better to move now when the situation has not reached gargantuan proportions than to wait and witness a serious environmental catastrophe,'' said Jean-Pierre d'Huart, manager of WWF's International Species Unit. The Tiger Emergency Fund was set up in January by the WWF and the World Conservation Union. It is intended as a ``rapid-response mechanism'' for dealing with any events increasing the threats to the tigers' survival. (gm)

JAKARTA (JP): To raise the question of the legitimacy of Habibie's presidency is not mere political wrangling. By contrast, however, constitutional debate on the legality of the transfer of power to Habibie is an irrelevant and worthless exercise. The circumstances that led to Soeharto's resignation are not provided for in the constitution, or in any other existing legislation. To the very end, Soeharto never once expressed a readiness or desire to step down. He once said that as a soldier he would never ``shirk his responsibility'', whatever that meant, but in the end he was forced by circumstances to do so. He finally had no choice but to bow to the continuous pressure of student demonstrations which gave voice to the desires of the masses. Although there are provisions in the constitution and existing legislation designed to cover the event of the president resigning or becoming incapacitated, the circumstances which they postulate bear no resemblance to the events which unfolded last month. The existing laws and procedures largely cover death in office, not voluntary resignation. A provision in the constitution does however state that in the event of the president's resignation, he or she shall be replaced by the vice president. Unfortunately, how the transfer of power should take place is not explained and it is left open to debate whether a simple transfer ceremony is sufficient, or if a special session of the People's Consultative Assembly (MPR) is actually required to reissue the presidential mandate. At the heart of the matter is the fact that the President did not resign of his own accord or will, but was in effect forced out by the people. This makes the problem relating to his resignation political in nature, and not a legal conundrum. Furthermore, it is a political problem in an emergency situation and the need for a swift solution is therefore of paramount importance. Here we run onto the horns of a dilemma. On the one hand, we have demanded total and comprehensive reform of the political system and forced drastic change in the national leadership through somewhat ``revolutionary'' means, while at the same time calling for greater democracy. A dangerous vicious circle beckons, promising ever greater repetitions of the events of the last few months. To avoid this, emergency political steps must be taken. The nationwide demand for a special session of the MPR and a fair and free election in the shortest time possible is an expression of democratic aspirations and a determination to adhere to the principles of the 1945 Constitution. However, to ensure that the MPR is representative of society at large, a shake up in the present membership is required. Some members have already resigned while more must surely follow because of the nepotistic nature of their appointments. Of no lesser significance is the fact that Golkar, the largest and ruling political organization, appears to be disintegrating. The arguments for rejuvenating the MPR membership are therefore very powerful. There is good reason to doubt if we have either the time or the money to hold an immediate election, because the economic crisis has rapidly gone from bad to worse. But a fair and free election is an internationally accepted and democratic means of solving a political crisis of this nature. Announcing and executing definite plans to hold an election would go a long way to restoring confidence, both at home and abroad. Above all, however, a simple announcement by President Habibie or the MPR stating that the current presidency is provisional or transitional in nature is absolutely necessary to reassure our citizens and the international community of the current government's good intentions. The choice of vice president was a calculated political maneuver on the part of Soeharto, as was the selection of MPR members and those who sit on other representative bodies. His presidency was the lynchpin in the system which the nation is now demanding be totally reformed. What is so difficult about making such a simple but decisive statement, if President Habibie honestly has no ulterior motive? More than anything else, honesty and humility breed trust and confidence. An honest and humble admission on the part of the present government would go along way to ensuring that the present crisis will shortly be consigned to history, and this despite the new government having in its ranks a number of political turncoats not entirely free from suspicion of corruption. We also badly need the confidence of the international community. An emergency rescue operation lead by the international community is perhaps the only way to save the country from collapse. Will our new leaders be honest, modest, and humble enough to admit this sobering fact and swallow their often misplaced national pride? Habibie -- Page 2

The group also petitioned for an early congress to elect a new chairman. The Golkar congress is currently scheduled for October. Iskandar Mandji, a member of the group which go by the name of the Team of Golkar's Saviors, told The Jakarta Post that Harmoko had ``lied'' when he told former president Soeharto that the public wanted him to run for a seventh consecutive term as president earlier this year. Soeharto's reelection in March was greeted by massive demonstrations across the country. Political tension then rose, leading eventually to last months massive outburst of anger, rioting and looting which forced Soeharto to resign. In his response, Harmoko said that only a congress could dismiss a chairman. He said all members had to comply with the organization's statutes, which state that a congress is the correct forum to elect and dismiss a chairman. Golkar has a collective leadership whose term in office is determined through a consensual agreement between members, he added. ``We'll call a meeting with the leaders of Golkar's regional chapters to listen to members' opinions and discuss what steps we can take,'' he said. Critical Iskandar said Golkar was now facing a critical time given that political reform was proceeding quickly and new political parties were being established. ``Golkar is still a valid medium through which to campaign for democracy. The group calling for Harmoko's resignation consists of founding members Sudarko Prawirojudo and Bambang Warrih Koesoema, and senior Golkar members Farid Akhwan, Syaiful M.D. and Tadjoeddin Noer Said. Iskandar said Golkar had been under intense scrutiny because its legislators were considered to be hand-picked Soeharto ``yes-men'', especially during the general session of the People's Consultative Assembly (MPR) which reelected Soeharto in March. ``As the whole nation can now see, (Harmoko's claim that a majority of people still wanted Soeharto at the nation's helm) was wrong because there have been strong and continuous demands for Soeharto to step down since he was reelected,'' he said. OAU names former presidents, judges to Rwanda inquiry
OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso (AP) _ The Organization of African Unity on Wednesday appointed a seven-member panel to investigate the role of foreign powers and individuals in the 1994 Rwandan genocide. OAU Secretary General Salim Salim of Tanzania said the investigation team would also examine measures to prevent a re-occurrence of the massacres which resulted in about 500,000 deaths, mainly of ethnic Rwandan Tutsis. Tutsi rebels based mainly in Uganda won power in Rwanda in July 1994 and ended the killings, which occurred several months after a U.N. peacekeeping officer warned his superiors in a fax of the danger of massacres planned by Hutu extremists. OAU officials did not immediately provide details about the terms of the new investigation. Also appointed to the panel are former Mali president Gen. Toumani Toure; Algeria's ex-chairman of the International Court of Justice Mohamed Bedjaou; former U.N. official and Liberian presidential candidate Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf; one-time U.N. Development Program chief Lisbet Palme of Sweden; former Indian Supreme Court chairman H. Bagwati and UNICEF deputy chief Stephen Lewis of Canada. The investigation team was first suggested by Ethiopian Prime Minister Ato Meles Zewani in November 1997. A U.N. tribunal on Rwanda has indicted 35 people with genocide crimes. Rwanda, frustrated by the slow pace of the U.N. tribunal, has started its own trials of 125,000 suspects. So far, 144 of 337 convicted have received death sentences. (bro-gam/ids)

BC-Kazakstan-Oil
No oil production cuts in Kazakstan despite lower prices
MOSCOW (AP) _ Kazakstan does not plan to cut oil production, despite the fall in world oil prices, the president of the Kazakhoil national oil company said Wednesday. Nurlan Kapparov told the Interfax news agency in Kazakstan that it would not be profitable to close wells, because reopening them would entail huge expenses. ``Even if a well is not unprofitable, it would be better left in production,'' he said. Kapparov said the government considered reducing excise duties or taking other measures to help oil companies, but ``budget possibilities are limited'' in the Central Asian country. Kazakstan expects to extract 26 million to 36 million metric tons (7.35 billion to 7.64 billion gallons) of oil this year, Kapparov said. Kapparov also said that the Tengizchevroil joint venture _ in which Chevron has a 45-percent stake and Mobil 25 percent _ plans to increase oil production this year. (ls)

Eds: New thruout with Indian prime minister offering dialogue with AP Photo DEL102 By KRISHNAN GURUSWAMY Associated Press Writer
NEW DELHI, India (AP) _ India on Wednesday offered to hold bilateral talks with rival neighbor Pakistan in a meeting with Iranian Foreign Minister Kamal Kharrazi. Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee, however, rejected the possibility of a third party in the mediation between the two hostile neighbors. India and Pakistan, which have fought three wars, last month conducted nearly a dozen nuclear tests that has set off an arms race in the region. There has been speculation that Western leaders meeting Thursday in Geneva to discuss how to defuse nuclear tension between India and Pakistan would take up the disputed region of Kashmir as the root of their rivalry. Emerging from the meeting with Vajpayee, Kharrazi urged India and Pakistan to talk to reduce tensions after earlier praising Pakistan's ``Islamic bomb.'' ``We believe in a nuclear weapons-free zone in the region,'' he said. Kharrazi is the first foreign dignitary to visit the region after India conducted five tests May 11-13 and Pakistan responded two weeks later with what it said were six tests. He flew into New Delhi on Tuesday night from Islamabad. Vajpayee said India is willing to take part in the negotiations on the Fissile Material Cutoff Treaty at a Geneva disarmament conference. India already has announced a moratorium on further nuclear testing and agreed to discuss a no-first use agreement with either Pakistan or with other nuclear weapons states, he said. ``These issues cannot be placed in an exhaustive South Asian context,'' Vajpayee said. ``There are other issues which relate to India-Pakistan relations. These issues, which include confidence building measures, can only be addressed bilaterally.'' A top Indian foreign ministry official said India found international concerns about the situation in South Asia were exaggerated. ``Life is normal. There is no ground for exaggeration and dramatizing the situation,'' said Foreign Secretary K. Raghunath. Japan's fears over how a nuclear arms race in South Asia could affect global disarmament efforts prompted it to propose an international nonproliferation forum _ possibly to be held in Hiroshima, a city devastated by an American atomic bomb at the end of World War II. A formal announcement of the proposal will be made Thursday, according to a Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman. Iran, Kharrazi said, has been very concerned about developments in South Asia following the nuclear tests. But he welcomed the Pakistani tests. ``The development of a nuclear bomb by a Muslim country can act as a deterrent for Israel,'' said Kharrazi. Israel is considered an undeclared nuclear power. Iran has repeatedly denied U.S. and Israeli allegations that it is close to building a nuclear weapon. In another development, Indian army chief Gen. V.P. Malik has called off a visit to London following Britain's role in formulating the European Union's condemnation of its nuclear tests, United News of India news agency reported. It quoted unnamed defense officials as saying Malik called off his visit last month, days before naval chief Vishnu Bhagawat also canceled his trip to Britain.
