BC-Russia-Stock Exchange
Russian exchange seeks to expand business, link with Chicago trade board
MOSCOW (AP) _ The Moscow Stock Exchange is hoping to snap up the business of an ailing rival and start cooperation with the Chicago Board of Trade, exchange president Victor Sakharov said Wednesday. That might be a boon for Russia's shaky futures market, which suffered a setback earlier this week when one futures exchange, The Russian Bourse, collapsed. Sakharov wants to bring in Russian Bourse traders and their business and tie up with the Chicago Board of Trade, although the plans are still preliminary. The Moscow Stock Exchange currently doesn't offer futures. A Russian Bourse spokeswoman said the exchange is trying to figure out what led to its collapse and what to do next. Market participants said the exchange couldn't meet margin calls earlier this week, amid a roughly 50 percent drop in the market since the beginning of the year. About dlrs 18 million was lost in the collapse, Russian Bourse officials said. The exchange's daily volume was around dlrs 120 million, they said. Futures allow investors to purchase a contract on an underlying asset for future delivery. But the instruments are little used in Moscow and St. Petersburg trading, mostly because their exchanges are unsophisticated and the regulatory structure almost nonexistent. (dj/ls)

Many Chinese Indonesians can tell stories of how their assets were destroyed or in some cases their safety targeted by the mobs in the recent riots that hit Jakarta and several other cities in Indonesia. So, I found Sumarsono Sastrowardoyo's letter criticizing Chinese Indonesians that fled the country during the rioting to be unfair. After all, nobody knew at the time that the transfer of power was going to take place peacefully. On the other hand, I would support the calls by others for Chinese Indonesians to put more effort into assimilating with indigenous people. I also call on the authorities to take more concrete steps to address the issue. Furthermore it is important to improve national security because if people do not feel safe they will not return to do their business as usual. There have been accounts of loss of lives, assets and jobs due to the riots. However, few have mentioned the long-term impact of the loss of confidence and higher risk perceived by people. This will result in more capital and even skilled people leaving and fewer coming to Indonesia at a time when the country badly needs the expertise and capital. Even when things stabilize further, investors in general will be less inclined to put their money into businesses which are long-term in nature. This will significantly handicap Indonesia in its bid to be a competitive economy in the 21st century. The stakes are just too big for the issue to be ignored.

BC-Sports-Olympics-IOC Meetings
Samaranch tells U.S.: win medals in 2002 to ensure Salt Lake success AP Sports Writer
By STEPHEN WILSON
SEVILLE, Spain (AP) _ A large medal haul by U.S. athletes is necessary to ensure the success of the 2002 Winter Games in Salt Lake City, the head of the International Olympic Committee said Wednesday. IOC president Juan Antonio Samaranch said American athletes need to improve on their performance from this year's Nagano Olympics, where they won 13 medals, in order to boost public enthusiasm for the games in the host country. Samaranch delivered his message during a meeting with U.S. Olympic Committee president William Hybl and Salt Lake City organizers. ``Concern was expressed by the president about the performance of the U.S. team in 2002,'' said Frank Joklik, president of the Salt Lake organizing committee. ``He feels the home team doing well is an essential element of a successful Olympic Games. He is very anxious to see a performance of a U.S.A. team that will be an advance on what was achieved in Nagano.'' Samaranch noted that the success of the home team had played a big part in generating excitement at the 1992 Barcelona Games, the 1994 Lillehammer Games and the 1998 Nagano Games. Hybl reported to the IOC executive board on the work of the USOC's ``athlete's performance group,'' a panel set up 10 months ago to improve America's medal chances at the 2000 Sydney Olympics and the Salt Lake City Games. The 13 medals from Nagano, including six gold, matched the United States' best ever performace at a winter games. But the total was still below expectations. Hybl said the Americans will definitely do better in 2002. ``Based on what we know now, the USOC and myself are convinced we will exceed the 13 medals we won in Nagano by some magin,'' he said. On another issue, Salt Lake officials confirmed their Olympic mascot won't be ready before early 1999, a year later than originally planned, but said there was no reason to panic. ``I don't think it's a hangup at all,'' Joklik said. ``It's one of the issues that everyone wants a little input on. If we come up with something early next year, we'll be in good shape.'' Joklik said Salt Lake was determined to avoid the experience of Atlanta's much-maligned mascot. First called ``Whatizit,'' the computer-generated blue mascot was presented to the world at the closing ceremony in Barcelona in 1992 and was widely ridiculed as a blob, slug, maggot and worse. Stung by the response, Atlanta organizers redesigned the mascot into a more child-friendly creature with a new name, ``Izzy.'' While popular with kids, the mascot continued to be the butt of jokes and criticism in the world's media. ``Definitely, we don't want to do that,'' Joklik said. ``I hope we come up with a better name than `Whatizit.' And we hope it will be very plain what (the mascot) is.''' On the sports program for 2002, SLOC vice president Dave Johnson said discussions were continuing on the possible inclusion of women's bobsledding. But he said there now appeared little chance of adding women's ski jumping and indicated that skeleton _ a head-first version of luge _ may not be included as previously expected. On Tuesday, the IOC approved the addition of men's and women's pursuit events in biathlon and increased the number of women's ice hockey teams from six to eight. The changes mean there are now 70 medal events in seven sports for 2002. As of now, Salt Lake City is planning to receive 2,365 athletes and accomodate 3,547 competitors and officials in the Olympic village. Joklik told the IOC that Salt Lake had recently hired a senior vice president for human resources, Ed Eynon, and a director of alpine sports, Herwig Demschar. But Salt Lake still has no sports director, a key role the IOC has repeatedly pressed organizers to fill. ``We continue the search and are hopeful of filling the position in the next few weeks,'' Joklik said. Meanwhile, IOC officials expressed concern at high ticket prices proposed for the Sydney Olympics. While no figures were released, news reports in Australia have suggested that organizers are proposing prices as high as dlrs 1,000 for premium seats at the opening ceremony. The most expensive tickets for Atlanta's opening ceremony cost dlrs 650. The IOC set up a four-man working group to study Sydney's ticket proposals. The package is expected to be finalized before the next Olympic meetings in Seoul, South Korea, in September. (sw)

Eds: UPDATES with proposal to suspend Western Sahara's OAU
OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso (AP) _ Morocco's delegates to the Organization of African Unity failed to appear at preliminary meetings this week and may boycott next week's summit, an OAU official said Wednesday. Delegates attending the pan-African OAU preparatory meetings this week in Burkina Faso's capital, Ouagadougou, discussed the summit agenda, which may include a debate on membership for Western Sahara. Speaking on condition of anonymity, the official from the OAU secretariat said Morocco, which has boycotted the OAU since 1984 when Western Sahara was admitted as an independent member, is not expected to attended the summit meetings. However, a number of African countries _ including summit hosts Burkina Faso _ propose suspending Western Sahara's OAU membership until the results of an independence referendum there later this year, officials said. Many member states of the OAU have individually dropped their recognition of Western Sahara although OAU Secretary General Salim Salim said his organization continued to recognize it as independent state. The issue could be decided in a vote by OAU members on the final day of the summit next Wednesday. Morocco has administered Western Sahara since 1976 when the territory as abandoned by its colonial ruler Spain. Morocco is trying to quash an independence movement in Western Sahara and has boycotted past OAU functions in protest over discussions on the territory's sovereignty. Moroccan flags flying next to those of other OAU member states have been removed from Ouagadougou's streets, indicating their delegates will not attend the summit meetings. U.N. observers have been deployed in the region since 1991 to oversee a cease-fire between Moroccan forces and Western Saharan rebels. (var/ids)

JAKARTA (JP): The death of four Trisakti University students last May 12 motivated students to escalate their campaign for total reform. In the same way as Arief Rachman Hakim, a University of Indonesia student who was shot to death by the military in 1966, the four became martyrs and heroes for political reform. In the two days after the shooting, there were massive riots in Jakarta and its surrounding satellite towns of Bekasi and Tangerang. These were the worst riots in Indonesia's modern political history. Rumors making the rounds were plenty. One said the riots were the work of some military officers who wanted to imitate what their predecessors did during the Malari Affair in 1974, when they ordered hoodlums to loot and burn shopping centers in Senen, Central Jakarta. Their intention was to deceive the public into believing that the riots were committed by students; thus, the public would condemn students and would not support their demonstration for total reform. The politics of scapegoating the students was unsuccessful. Another rumor said they were organized by the military as an excuse for their chief commander, Gen. Wiranto, to stop student demonstrations. Others speculated the riots were part of a power struggle among the military elite. Another story had it they were organized to demolish symbols of development of Soeharto's regime. The deaths of the students and the riots did not quash the students' determination to topple Soeharto as a precondition for total reform. For the second time in Indonesia's young history, a student movement succeeded in forcing the president out of office. This time it was the most powerful man in Indonesia who had ruled with an iron fist for 32 years. Several factors forced Soeharto to make the decision: The occupation of the House building by thousands of students. They were willing to sacrifice their lives rather than leave the building without Soeharto's resignation. The Armed Forces (ABRI) accommodative attitude toward students during their demonstrations boosted their spirit to topple Soeharto. Soeharto failed to reshuffle his Cabinet in time, and 14 of his ministers resigned. It seems probable Gen. Wiranto told Soeharto that ABRI could not support him any more. There may have also been several external factors which contributed to expedite Soeharto's downfall, such as the delay in disbursement of International Monetary Fund's bailout contribution for Indonesia and the indirect support for student movements in the country. In a way, these May student demonstrations in Indonesia can be regarded as a middle class revolution. Compared to previous student movements, this year's student movements were supported by almost all sections of society, particularly the middle class. Their support came in the form of money, food, printing materials, T-shirts, encouraging public opinion, organizing short courses to enhance students' critical ability, musical entertainment and others. The middle class' help for the students can be divided into five categories: First, those who had genuine motives for political and economic reforms or the true believers. They spent a lot of money to assist student demonstrations, without any political or economic interests except total reforms. Second, former student activists who had tried to topple Soeharto's regime for more than 24 years and who were eager to end the dictatorship in Indonesia. Third, those who were unhappy with the Soeharto's family business activities since the beginning of the economic crisis in July 1997, either because they lost their jobs or they could not compete with crony capitalists who were close to Soeharto's family. Fourth, the newcomers or ``free riders'' who jumped on the bandwagon just before Soeharto's downfall. Fifth, former Soeharto's cronies and aides who wanted to ``wash their hands'' to show to the people that they were clean and eager to dissociate themselves from corruption, nepotism and collusion. Students call this group ``last-minutes heroes'' or ``eleventh hour heroes''. Although Soeharto has lost his power, students and civilian political elites still continue their demands for total reform. Many have never accepted Habibie as Soeharto's successor, because Habibie was very close to Soeharto and he is still considered part of the problem, a leader whose managerial capability to handle the present political and economic crisis still needs to be tested. Some legal experts believe the transfer of power from Soeharto to Habibie was illegal or unconstitutional. In other words, the nation shows increasing signs of polarization over Habibie presidency and his cabinet. Students are also divided between those who support Habibie and those who still oppose him. The aftermath of Soeharto's resignation can be regarded as a period of struggle for powers among political elites, without considering social and economic conditions. Today, many former Soeharto cronies are forming new political parties as if, in this new era of political reform, people are free enough to do that without any consideration that their actions will endanger the nation's unity and stability. It seems their understanding of the liberal democratic system was very limited. Unless statesmanship grows at the heart of Indonesia's political elite, this country will inadvertently be torn to pieces. The present situation also sees a psychological war between military and civilian elites. While the civilian political elite is still screaming about total reform without any agreement on the future reform agenda, the military are preparing drafts of political development after Soeharto. The military elite is also trying to show to the people that they are humble and accommodative toward the civilian elite who demand total reform. Minister of Information Yunus Yosfiah's handling of the problem of the free press in Indonesia is an example of how ABRI approaches journalists. In addition, ABRI Chief of Sociopolitical Affairs, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, showed the accommodative approach in dealing with the people and political elite. The elite can still discuss political reform in cafes and hotels. The elite can also afford to think about ``what menus will we pick to eat from today?'', while the common people who live from one day to another ponder ``what will we eat today?''. Unless the civilian elite take the people's stomachs into consideration, it is possible the grassroots groups will shift their allegiance from the civilian to the military elite in the next six months or so. Although it is hard to believe at present, it is not impossible that the military will dominate the government because the civilian political elite cannot cope with the present economic and political crisis. The writer is a researcher at the Center for Political and Regional Studies, Indonesian Institute of Sciences. Umpire throws the book at Kuerten
By STEPHANIE VAN DEN BERG
PARIS (AP) _ Gustavo Kuerten lost approximately a quarter of his prize money at the French Open for his outburst Tuesday. Kuerten, frustrated in the tie-break of his doubles match, threw his racket at the umpire, landing him a fine of dlrs 7,000 on Wednesday. This fine takes a big chunk out of his prize money at the French Open this year. Kuerten's pocketbook was already suffering in comparison to last year when he won the tournament and made around dlrs 617.000, more than twenty times what he made this year. --- LOST AND FOUND: The Williams sisters are out of the tournament but their trademark beads have more staying power on the court. It's not unusual to see a bead or two fall unto the clay court during a match but in Venus' fourth round match against Henrieta Nagyova ball girls and boys even found an entire string of beads. The string of beads was added to the pile of rackets and T-shirts left on the courts by the players. At the end of the tournament all the lost and found treasures are raffled off among the ball girls and boys. --- A DOG'S LIFE: An unusual sight Tuesday when Arantxa Sanchez Vicario's mother was seen running with her daughter's Yorkshire terrier Roland in a quiet corner of the stadium just before Arantxa's match against Patty Schnyder. The object of the exercise was to tire the dog so it would stay quiet during the match reported the French sports daily, L'Equipe. The top dog, named after Roland Garros, can get into the stadium and has its own pass with name and ID-picture for the duration of the tournament. --- STAY OFF THE GRASS: What's wrong with grass ? Quite a lot if you believe some of the French Open players. Spanish players are notorious for saying that grass is for cows. Marat Safin, the Russian surprise who lost to Cedric Pioline in the quarterfinals, said he ``didn't step on the grass. Never, no step in my life.'' Wednesday Belgian Filip DeWulf gave yet another reason for not playing tennis on grass. ''On grass, I'd rather play soccer,'' he said. --- REMEMBERING NOAH: When asked to name a past winner of the French Open nearly half of the people polled, 46 percent, named 1983 winner and Frenchman Yannick Noah. Bjorn Borg was also well remembered with 29 percent. 16 percent named John McEnroe. Current French quarterfinalist Cedric Pioline was named by 4 percent. Over on the women's side French nationalism did not reign. Respondents most remembered Martina Navratilova (30 percent). Surprisingly French national Mary Pierce came next with 26 percent before multiple titleholders Steffi Graf (26 percent) and Chris Evert (14 percent). Current favorite Martina Hingis was named by 4 percent. The poll was carried out over phone on a cross section of the French population over 15 years old by a French polling agency at the request of one of the tournaments sponsors. (sab-sz)

Brazil starts post-Romario era with easy 3-0 victory
EDS: UPDATES with detail; WILL be UPDATED with quotes. By PETER MUELLO Associated Press Writer
ST. OUEN, France (AP) _ Brazil worked through its dramatic loss of 1994 World Cup hero Romario but failed to get a stern final test for France '98 Wednesday, getting first-half goals from Giovanni and Rivaldo in an easy 3-0 victory over Andorra. Giovanni and Rivaldo scored in the 26th and 27th minutes and Cafu completed the scoring in the 53rd minute as Brazil coasted in its final warm-up match before the World Cup opener against Scotland June 10. Bebeto took the place in the starting lineup for Romario, who was cut from the squad Tuesday after re-injuring his right calf last weekend. After a tearful farewell, the players were in low spirits in practice Tuesday. The Brazilians hardly looked themselves as they sleepwalked through the opening minutes, failing to press an Andorran team that seemed awed to be on the same field as the four-time world champions. Andorra took nine minutes to cross the midfield stripe and never seriously threatened Brazilian keeper Taffarel. But Brazil wasted countless chances as Andorran defenders repeatedly turned over the ball and forced goalkeeper Koldo Alvarez into several dramatic saves. The first of many misses came in the eighth minute, when Giovanni took a cross from Cafu and fired a header point blank that Alvarez knocked away with a reflex save. Two-time FIFA Player of the Year Ronaldo had a long and frustrating afternoon. Alvarez seemed to have the shaven-headed 21-year-old figured out, twice foiling him one-on-one on breakaways as Brazil repeatedly caught the Andorran defense flat-footed. Mistakes caught up with Andorra in the 26th minute, when the defense failed to clear a Bebeto corner and the ball squirted loose in the goal box. Giovanni, unmarked, simply tapped the ball into the goal. A minute later, Ronaldo sent Rivaldo in alone and the FC Barcelona star had time to stop, choose his corner and shoot to make it 2-0. Ronaldo's frustrations grew in the 38th minute when a cross from Cafu found him alone in front of Alvarez, but his header hit the post. Bebeto didn't help his chances to retain the starting spot with an ineffective afternoon. His best chance came in the 44th minute when Roberto Carlos and Ronaldo combined to leave him free at the top of the penalty area, but his shot went high and wide. In the second half, Doriva replaced captain Dunga, who is recovering from a leg injury and was only expected to play 45 minutes. Leonardo also came in for Giovanni. Brazil's dominance grew in the second half as the team attacked with as many as nine players, something it only does in practice _ which it at times seemed like it was. In the 53rd minute, Cafu completed the scoring on a brilliant individual effort. He escaped up the right side and, as Alvarez as raced out to smother an expected cross, the defender feinted around him and shot with almost no angle to make it 3-0. The rest of the afternoon was a personal show by Ronaldo, who successive runs through the Andorran defense drew ``oohs'' and ``aahs'' from the crowd. But again he was disarmed at the last second. Brazilian coach Mario Zagallo substituted freely, sending in Carlos Germano for Tafarrel, Goncalves for Aldair, Ze Carlos for Roberto Carlos, and Denilson for Rivaldo.

Megawati Soekarnoputri, the eldest daughter of Indonesia's founding president Sukarno and chairwoman of the unrecognized Indonesian Democratic Party, has managed to impress many of us again by calling on all Indonesians to stop defiling fallen president Soeharto. Speaking at a ceremony commemorating the day on which the nation's state philosophy Pancasila was born -- June 1, 1945 -- Megawati said defiling former leaders of the state runs against Pancasila which, among other things, advocates ``just and civilized humanitarianism''. ``Do we have to replace our state leaders through such treatment every time?'' Megawati asked her audience of several thousand, obviously referring to her own father's ouster by Soeharto in 1966. To be fair, Megawati is not the only, or even the first, opposition leader to have called for temperance in the public airing of anti-Soeharto sentiments following the strongman's forced retirement on May 21. Moslem leader Amien Rais made a similar appeal two days earlier and we can be sure that the same spirit of moderation and forgiveness exists among many others of the more reasonable and more mature of Indonesia's opposition leaders. What makes Megawati's appeal for moderation worth noting is the fact that it was made by the daughter of the deposed president Sukarno, a victim of almost identical circumstances which led to the birth of the New Order, headed by Soeharto. Unlike other opposition figures who have made similar appeals, Megawati and her family endured the same agony of being publicly defiled when her father, Sukarno, was ousted in the wake of the communist coup of 1965. Even after so many years, a sense of injury, perhaps even more than magnanimity, can be detected in the question she asked her audience: ``Do we have to treat former president Soeharto's family the way the nation treated us, Sukarno's family, in 1965?'' But apart from deep personal insight coming from experience, Megawati probably also remembered and appreciated the way Soeharto had in public always continued to accord Sukarno the respect he deserved as a founder of the nation. 'Mikul duwur mendem jero', which literally means carry your elders high and bury them deep, is a saying that is still honored by many Indonesians, the Javanese in particular. Megawati could only be observing this dictum when she made her appeal for Indonesians to stop bashing Soeharto. Indonesia's younger generation could see in this old tradition of chivalry a useful modern guide to engaging in politics without abandoning morality -- a useful general principle to remember if democracy is to survive and bloom. It is important, however, at this point to remember that civility must not stand in the way of justice. At this stage of developments, the public clamor concerns the wealth which Soeharto and his family are widely reported to have amassed during his more than three decades in power. The public's demands that this wealth be returned to the state in as far as it has been illegally acquired must in this context be given the proper attention they deserve. Just as much as the Soeharto clan, or their associates, have a right to be treated fairly, so the people have a right to reclaim what belongs to them. Indonesians at this stage of their country's history need the guidance of leaders who are not only sincerely committed to the cause of overall reform, but who are also mature and sensible enough to see the nation safely through these critical times. It is in this context that the calls for Indonesians to stop the Soeharto bashing must be seen as a welcome development.

Residents rush to German train crash to help bloodied victims With AM-Germany-Train Derails
By CLAUS-PETER TIEMANN Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ There was a boom. An explosion. Then a horrible crushing sound. Hannelore Domkewitz saw the train speed past from her kitchen window where she stood peeling potatoes. She had just a moment to reflect that it was moving much faster than usual. ``Then there was a loud boom, a dust cloud, and then silence,'' Domkewitz said. The silence didn't last long. There were screams from the tracks. Domkewitz ran 100 yards (300 feet) toward the mangled wreckage of Germany's deadliest train crash in more than three decades. People with bloodied hands staggered toward her. Behind them was a ghostly scene of passenger cars wedged into each other, some sticking up several yards (meters) into the air and others buried under a collapsed overpass. The train, holding up to 350 passengers, had been speeding along at 200 kph (125 mph) when cars derailed and jack-knifed, killing scores of people. Domekewitz ran back to get blankets and bed sheets to cover the injured and dead. ``But there were also survivors who went by with their luggage. They were all in shock,'' Domkewitz said, her voice breaking. Mark Draeger heard it too. ``It was like an explosion! Yet very different, because it was a terrible crushing sound,'' said the 20-year-old aid worker who lived nearby and rushed to the wreckage. Within an hour, the rails were swarming with rescue workers and helicopters carrying the injured to hospitals. Residents along the tracks rushed to the scene with small wagons to offer help. Manfred Thiel was on his way to work when the train crashed. He grabbed a ladder and helped the injured to safety. He stood by as rescuers pulled a 10-year-old girl from the wreckage alive. Color Sergeant Phil Forsyth and 20 soldiers from the 2nd Battalion of the Royal Fusiliers, based at Celle in Germany, were among the first to arrive at the site. Sgt Forsyth, speaking in a BBC interview from the regiment's base just minutes from the crash scene, said: ``On arrival we were met by an horrific site. ``Some five or six carriages were piled up on top of each other. Once we got nearer it became quite clear the bridge had totally collapsed on to the second and third carriages, and the remainder of the carriages had piled up on top of that. ``All the carriages were absolutely mangled; it was a mess and very sad to see. ``My heart can do nothing but go out to those people who were caught up in it and those who were waiting to find out what had happened.'' Sgt Forsyth, who has been in the Army for 13 years and fought in the Persian Gulf war, added: ``It is definitely one of the worst scenes I have ever seen, if not the worst.'' (gb/cb/im)

As a man of performing art, I always look forward to seeing good performance, let it be theatre, dance, mime or music. Of late, such a desire of mine, my thirst for a good artistic performance, has more than been satisfied. It was Leela Samson and her troupe's dance performance which I had the opportunity of watching on the 27th May evening at the comfortable auditorium of Dhaka Museum. This was Leela's third visit to Bangladesh. I have had the opportunity of watching Leela's solo performance a few years ago at a posh hotel of the city, which I kept nourishing for quite sometime. This time Leela Samson came to Dhaka with her repertory company named Spanda on invitation from a local front-ranking Dance Group called Shadhana who deserve unequivocal appreciation for their relentless struggle to establish classical and neo-classical dance form in the country.Leela Samson is one of the great exponents of Bharat Natyam, a highly acclaimed aesthetic dance form of the sub-continent. Leela has been recognised within and outside her country India for her exquisite and sensitive handling of the medium with new to newer interpretation of the thematic content of the respective dance numbers. Leela has been awarded the ``Sanskriti Award'' in 1982 and the ``Padma Shree'' in 1990 which are quite rated in India. She has also written a book on dance, titled Rhythm in Joy. This time Leela came to tour Bangladesh with a 9-member team including herself. Out of 9 performers, two are male and seven are female dancers. Out of 9 performers, 6 are extraordinarily gifted artists. They are Anusha Lall, Aditi Jaitly, C.A. Joy, Mahalakshmi Narendra, T.M. Thiru Chelwam - and of course, Leela herself is there. Of the dancers, excluding Leela, to my mind, Anusha Lall stands out from the rest of the team with her deft movement and gait, rhythmic foot work and highly expressive but thrifty gestures which tend to give a philosophical insight into the medium. Generally speaking, all the members of the team are endowed with these qualities with only variations of degree. The team also included Aditi Rao, Ayeshe Sadr and Kamal Jit Malik who are talented young dancers now studying Bharat Natyam under Leela's able guidance.The troupe performed 6 drama pieces including a solo piece by Leela Sampson, the choreographer of the entire presentation. First presentation was AAKASH meaning the Universe. The theme of the dance drama is that, a person who knows that he or she is endowed with the same strength outside and within, he or she attains prosperity. The performance was beautifully harmonised by vocal songs and instruments like flute, Mridangam, Chenda and Maddalam. Then was presented the piece SPANDA-MATRIK. This was rather a long piece, but never boring, with lots of variations in ``Mudra'' (gestures and postures). SPANDA-MATRIK expresses the essence of motion through adavus' which constitutes the core gestures and postures of Bharat Natyam. This composition attempts to internationalise the consciousness of the dancer in one level and on the other level, it creates an awareness in the dancer about the external surroundings. SPANDA-MATRIK is based on time cycles of 4, 3, 7, 5 and 9 depicting ``Panchajaties''. The audience had a recess of 10-minutes after the performance of SPANDA-MATRIK. After recess, the performance resumed and the curtain was drawn with the presentation of 4 relatively small pieces of dance drama, namely DVASUPARNA, SURYA NAMASHKAR, ABHINOY and CHARISHNU, DVA-SUPARNA depicted the life cycle of two birds leaving together on a branch of tree with their joy and sorrow which attempted to give an inner-view of our own life cycle. Then came the SURYA NAMASKAR (Bow to sun) with extraordinary varieties of rhythm and composition which, I thought, one would like to cherish for a long time to come as a happening of pure joy. Next piece was ABHINOY, a solo performance by Leela Sampson, an articulate and over-stretched movement of hand and face which tend to remind Japanese ``Kabuki' form. The performance concluded with CHARISNU which expressed the joy of the journeying.' In the bare stage of Dhaka Museum auditorium covered with black back-drop and black wings and boarder, the performances of the Repertoire of Leela Samson was spell-binding with immaculate outfit of the dancers assisted by meaningful use of lights. I would not say that the Repertoire's presentation was spectacular but it was obviously suave, profound, intense, sensitive, thought-provoking and above all, artistically meaningful. By being suave it did not lack vigour and splendour of dance performances. It was indeed a new experience for me and I am at loss to use a proper attribution. I met Leela Samson briefly the morning following the May 27 evening's performance of her troupe. She told me, a pure art form never becomes a museum piece if one can practice it with sincerity and earnestness. If one has a heart for it, it keeps on living and moving with all social relevance. For that an artist does not need to modify, change, contemporise or update the medium. Leela claimed that she did not deviate a bit from the basics of Bharat Natyam, she only created themes to be enacted through Bharat Natyam. Is it, what is called re-creation or new interpretation? I kept on pondering. Leela lastly told me that Bangladeshi enthusiasts will one day succeed in breaking the barrier of obstacles and be able to establish artistically rich dance form in the country, if they can live upto their present zeal and endeavour. May be, the field will be limited but an art form spans finite to infinite. In fact, a pure art form never dies. I am inspired to quote two lines from Upanishad the spirit of which is the driving force of Leela's Repertoire: ``Who would breathe, who would live, if there were not this bliss in space.''

Appreciation of fine arts, especially paintings, denotes the spiritnal edification of a nation. The study of history informs us that most ancient civilisations that upheld the values that compliment the finer qualities of life, attained cultural fulfilment. Painting is a section of art that is a vivid expression of the refinement of the soul. Breaking all cultural barriers, it is one language that the hearts of millions of people understand and relish. ``Beauty in itself is a language that is capable of silent lucidity'' - espousing this belief, an exhibition of paintings by Korean artists was inaugurated last week at the Divine Art Gallery at the Sonargaon Hotel. In the rich tradition of 5000 years comes the animated works of the orient. Korean painting is as old as her ancient civilisation that often is an unknown fact. 'To introduce our works and their richness to the Bangladeshi culture and to create a bridge of friendship is our objective here,'' remarked the leader of the Korean delegation. The distinct style that the works present is a combination of intricate strokes blessed by a mesmerising, often metaphysical effect. The works unveil the oriental definition of the word beauty'. Sending a feeling of stillness through the colours and their shades, these works open another world where magnificence is somewhat different. The mountains graced by waterfalls, the oriental-style bungalow within the impeccable wilderness, the composed nature - flawless and free from any sort of artificial element - make the paintings a treat for the beauty-starved mind. The exhibition also features a trend called Korean Powdered Jewel style. This form of art - not familiar to us - exposes a new dimension of painting capable of arresting one's rapt attention. ``This is vivid, eloquent and somewhat more lively than something I have ever seen before,'' remarked a bedazzled Mehdi. In this category comes the almost hypnotical piece called Forest. Standing in front of it, one tends to substitute the cool surrounding of the Sonargaon lounge with that of the lonely forest. The eyes are caught, the body stands still as deep within the picture the enraptured soul travels to the cold forest. Looking at the Powdered works is experiencing a soul-flight that leaves one satisfied, appreciative of the beauties still left in this mechanical world. This exhibition reveals a new trend of art exuding a magical aura. The works have been done with great intensity as each piece narrates the cultural modes of a Far Eastern society. The centre-piece of the paintings is the vibrant, colourful Waves at Sunset - a stirring and animated expression of the rough beauty of the seawaves seen through the eyes of a painter spellbound by the twilight. The wonderful synthesis between the nature and life is presented artistically, invigorating the finer senses. This initiative to introduce Korean art will prove to be fruitful as interchange of ideas will result in the advancement of this field in both countries. A lovely experience and a dip into the Oriental elegance, this exhibition is a laudable step.

NattojoAn Production staged its new drama Ghritang Pibet at the Guide House auditorium on May 30. Adopted from Promothnath Bishi's work, the play is directed by Tabibul Islam. Ghritang Pibet is a comedy. Sarbeswar was a poor man. He lived in a modest house. He was very keen to betroth her only one daughter, Pramira, to a rich person. He took on rent a big house named, Sunny Villa, in an aristocratic area. He thought that if he lived in a place like this, some handsome person of a wealthy family would be attracted to her daughter. He wanted to show himself as a rich man to others. Tridib was a chauffeur. He also wanted to marry a daughter of a rich person. One day, he went to the Sunny Villa and introduced himself as the son of a Zamindar. Pramira and Tridib felt in love at a first sight. Sarbeswar didn't want to lose this chance. He decided to give Pramira in marriage to Tridib. Thus Sarbeswar and Tridib both cheated each other. After marriage, the truth came out. They didn't apologise to each other, but both realised that money is not the only thing to be happy.This is the story of Ghritang Pibet. Monir Khan Shimul as Tridib, Ahsanul Haque Minu as Sarbeswar, Farzana Hosain Kongkon as Malobika, Tazin Ahmed as Pramira, and Chittrolekh Guho as Bijoya have done justice to their roles. It is the second production of Nattojoan. The direction is good. The director has used some old melodious songs to create the right atmosphere for some scenes, such as: Vishmadev Chattapadhya's Bhala mora man bhabe murali bajae; Ram Kumar Chattapadhya's Oi dekha jai bari amar chwdike malancha bera and Jabo natun sasur bari, Allahde jai garagori; K. L. Saigal's Ekhoni uthibe chand adho alo adho chhayate; and Ganendraprasad Goswami's Baje mridanga buia baje murali. Professor Anisuzzaman was the chief guest at the premiere show. He congratulated Nattojoan Production on staging Promothnath Bishi's Ghritang Pibet, an almost forgotten but once well known drama. Borisho dhara majhe shantiro barii was the opening song of the show. The audience enjoyed the play. Eds: ADDS in 4th graf investigation led by former Botswana
OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso (AP) _ The Organization of African Unity on Wednesday appointed a seven-member panel to investigate the role of foreign powers and individuals in the 1994 Rwandan genocide. OAU Secretary General Salim Salim of Tanzania said the investigation team would also examine measures to prevent a re-occurrence of the massacres which resulted in about 500,000 deaths, mainly of ethnic Rwandan Tutsis. Tutsi rebels based mainly in Uganda won power in Rwanda in July 1994 and ended the killings, which occurred several months after a U.N. peacekeeping officer warned his superiors in a fax of the danger of massacres planned by Hutu extremists. OAU officials did not immediately provide details about the terms of the new investigation, which will be led by newly-retired Botswana president Ketumile Masire. Also appointed to the panel are former Mali president Gen. Toumani Toure; Algeria's ex-chairman of the International Court of Justice Mohamed Bedjaou; former U.N. official and Liberian presidential candidate Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf; one-time U.N. Development Program chief Lisbet Palme of Sweden; former Indian Supreme Court chairman H. Bagwati and UNICEF deputy chief Stephen Lewis of Canada. The investigation team was first suggested by Ethiopian Prime Minister Ato Meles Zewani in November 1997. A U.N. tribunal on Rwanda has indicted 35 people with genocide crimes. Rwanda, frustrated by the slow pace of the U.N. tribunal, has started its own trials of 125,000 suspects. So far, 144 of 337 convicted have received death sentences. (bro-gam/ids)

TANGERANG (JP): At least 75 youth activists visited the local council here to demand that Mayor Djakaria Machmud resign immediately from his current post. Calling themselves the Tangerang Rescuers Forum (FPT), the youths told councillors on Monday that Djakaria had visibly failed to carry out his duties. The group spokesman T.B. Mahdi Ardiansyah cited the mayor's failure to curb the levy of illegal fees on the issue of identity cards as an example of his incompetence. Payments required to obtain an ID card in the mayoralty are now Rp 75,000 per card, 10 times higher than the official rate of Rp 7,500, he said. He also pointed to the Tangerang forest park, developed to provide a recreation site for families in the heart of the municipality, but which has become notorious for prostitution, crime and dating teenagers, Ardiansyah explained. ``The city forest park has provided more bad things than good things,'' he said. The group insisted councillors sign a statement promising that they would not support any attempt by Djakaria to stand for a second term in office later this month. After listening to the youths' requests, councillors -- led by speaker Dedy Moeljono -- requested permission to retire to hold an internal discussion so that they could come to a consensual agreement. The youths finally agreed to give them 15 minutes. Later, Dedy and fellow councillors Rusman Umar and Syafruddin --respectively from the Armed forces, Golkar and United Development Party factions -- came out to meet the protesters again. The councillors claimed that Djakaria's term had come to an end earlier that day and he had submitted his resignation letter six months previously, as required by the law. Dedy did not reveal whether or not Djakaria had stated an intention to stand for reelection in the letter. He announced that the council would begin an investigation into the allegations leveled at Djakaria by the protesters, but he and his fellow councillors refused to sign the protesters' statement, arguing that it was unconstitutional. However, group leader Ahdiansyah persisted with his demand, revealing at the same time his knowledge of rumors, rife in the town, that each council member had received ``security fees'' worth Rp 200 million from the mayor. Ahdiansyah's remarks turned the councillors' faces red. ``That's slander. We did not receive any bribes. We don't want to sign the statement because it's unconstitutional,'' Rusman Umar said emotionally. Meanwhile, mayoralty spokesman Harry Mulya Zein said that all charges associated with the issue of identity cards had been stopped as of Monday. The service is now free, he said. ``We call on our officers in the districts and subdistricts to uphold the policy,'' Harry added. Regarding the forest park, he said the mayoralty would continue their joint operation with local security forces in an attempt to improve the park's image. ``We are also waiting for a report on the alleged role of the mayor in corrupt, collusive and nepotistic practices which occurred during his term in office,'' Harry said. The law requires that an outgoing mayor be examined by a special committee at the end of his or her term.

BC-Tiger Fund, HFR
Emergency fund for Siberian tiger makes first move source.
RETRANSMITTING TO ADD EMBARGO Eds: EMBARGOED until 0001 GMT Thursday, June 4, time set by
GLAND, Switzerland (AP) _ A new fund to help the endangered Siberian tiger is moving to aid fire-fighting efforts at two nature reserves in eastern Russia, the World Wildlife Fund said Wednesday. An allocation of some dlrs 20,000 is intended to buy and repair fire-fighting vehicles and other equipment in the Lazovsky and Sikhote-Alin reserves, home to the most of the surviving 425 to 475 wild Siberian tigers. Unusually dry weather conditions in the area, near the Sea of Japan, have led to forest fires which ``have already destroyed over 2,000 hectares (4,900 acres) of prime tiger land,'' the WWF said in a statement. Dry weather is set to continue through the summer, with a high risk of more fires, it added. ``It is better to move now when the situation has not reached gargantuan proportions than to wait and witness a serious environmental catastrophe,'' said Jean-Pierre d'Huart, manager of WWF's International Species Unit. The Tiger Emergency Fund was set up in January by the WWF and the World Conservation Union. It is intended as a ``rapid-response mechanism'' for dealing with any events increasing the threats to the tigers' survival. (gm)

JAKARTA (JP): West Jakarta Police chief Lt. Col. Timur Pradopo and 17 other police and military members face prison terms of between seven and 12 years if convicted of their alleged roles in last month's Trisakti shooting, an officer said yesterday. National Military Police Corps Commander Maj. Gen. Syamsu Djalal said yesterday that the West Jakarta Military District commander, Lt. Col. Amril Amir, whose name had been among the 19 alleged suspects, was eventually excluded from the list and released on technical grounds. ``We have to release him because we did not have enough evidence to put him on trial,'' Syamsu told a media conference at his office in Gambir subdistrict, Central Jakarta. ``However, if fresh evidence is found, there is a chance that he will also face the same charges,'' he added. Syamsu refused to give the precise names and units of the other 17 suspects. He only identified them as first lieutenants AH, WR, SR and ATH; second lieutenants PY, EKS and BY; second sergeants DP, JE, TI, AY, CN and PD; and second privates ST, SP, LS and IM. He said that all of the 18 suspects would be brought before a military court on Saturday and charged under Article 170 of the Criminal Code for assaulting people with violence. Four Trisakti University students were shot dead in the May 12 incident. Dozens of others were injured by bullets and batons. The incident ignited public anger which became manifest in massive riots, looting and burnings the next day. Nine days later, president Soeharto resigned after 32 years in power. Jakarta Military Police Commander Col. Hendardji, who also attended yesterday's meeting, said that among the suspects, 10 admitted that they had fired their guns without authorization. ``There was an order to shoot, but only warning shots, ricochet shots,'' he said. ``They opened fire on their own initiative, but not upon a direct order from the field commander. The motive was merely to herd the students back to the campus,'' he added. He also said that one of the student fatalities, shot in his neck, was the victim of ricochet shots. He, however, said that the investigators were now seeking testimony for why the firing began after the students had ended their protest. Hendardji also hinted at the possibility of procedural violations while loading the troops' ammunition. ``That's the reason why we also checked the line of distribution of ammunition,'' he said, adding that the troops (dispatched at the scene) were trained with live ammunitions at their base in Kelapa Dua in Depok. Hendardji was asked about when the officers took possession of their live ammunition because reports showed that they had been deployed at the campus for a whole week. He said: ``There were times when they returned back to their base at Kelapa Dua.'' Asked about the National Police Chief Gen. Dibyo Widodo's statement that the police officers did not commit procedural violations during the incident, Hendardji suggested Dibyo crosscheck his findings with other findings. Syamsu said that the investigation had been conducted in line with the legal procedure stated in Article 74 of the Armed Forces Chief Decree No. 31/ 1997 on military procedures when handling unrest. He said that the team did not try to find scapegoats who would be held responsible for the incident. ``Only the court will decide on the responsible parties. We (military investigators) always apply the principle of presumption of innocence,'' he said. Syamsu denied reports of a two-star general's involvement in the shooting, as mentioned by several mass media. ``I've never said that a two-star general was involved,'' he said. He, however, called for the public's active participation to help the investigators reveal the truth of the case. ``Anybody who witnessed officers from other units opening fire, please inform us,'' he said.

BANGLADESH
Ustad Alauddin Khan: The story of a simple village lad who reached the heights of musical excellence, THE INDEPENDENT xfdws USTAD-ALAUDDIN-KHAN sked Emerging Markets Datafile June 03, 1998 THE INDEPENDENT ENGLISH COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. AND WORLD TIMES, INC. NO PORTION OF THE MATERIALS CONTAINED HEREIN MAY BE USED IN ANY MEDIA WITHOUT ATTRIBUTION TO WORLDSOURCES, INC.
To trace the lineage of Alauddin Khan, one will have to unfold several generations of musicians, but the name of Safdar Hossein Khan is the great link in the chapter. He was born in Brahmanbaria's Shibpur village. His father's name was Madai Hossain. Safdar Hossein Khan, whose pet name was Shudokhan, had a fascination for music since his boyhood, and grew up in an atmosphere steeped in classical music. Safdar Hossein Khan became a disciple of Ustad Qasim Ali Khan, rabab maestro, who was attached to the Tripura Raja's court. After some time Safdar Hossein Khan also received the patronage of the Raja of Tripura, and gained considerable fame. Safdar Hossein Khan had five sons, namely, Sonauddin Khan, Aftabuddin Khan, Alauddin Khan, Naib Ali Khan and Ayat Ali Khan. Among the five sons, three made great names in the field of classical music. Aftabuddin Khan was a spiritualist and, like a wandering minstrel, used to roam from place to place without any fixed abode. One day he was visible in some remote village and another day he was seen in Comilla and other towns. He used to frequent the akhras of Baul singers. Aftabuddin Khan was adept to the musical instruments, tabla, flute and harmonium. He could also play the dotara like a Baul. There is a story that one day Aftabuddin Khan visited the house of Maharaja Jogindranath at Natore Bhaban in Bhawanipur, Calcutta. It was early morning and the Moharaja welcomed Aftabuddin Khan and seated him in his jalsa ghar. After a while Aftabuddin Khan dressed in fakir's robes took out his flute from the folds of his alkhalla and began to play some notes. It was seen that gradually flocks of birds flew into the large hall and settled on the pillars and window sills. The birds remained calm and there was pin-drop silence in the room. Only when he finished playing the flute did the birds fly out and went away. It was an eye-witness account by Maharaja Jogindranath, reflecting the spiritual powers of the maestro.It was at the feet of such a great man that Alauddin Khan received his initial training. His father had affectionately named him Alam (the world) and gave him much attention. One day he decided to leave Shibpur and went to Dhaka where he joined a professional jatra troupe. He spent some time here and also joined the Lion Theatre in old town, Dhaka. Not content with the small world of Dhaka, he moved on to seek the gurus of Calcutta. One famous vocal musician was Nolu Gopal alias Gopal Krishna Bhattacharya, who had a good following, and Alauddin begged him to accept him as his disciple. The guru said he would take him into his tutelege provided Alauddin agreed to spend at least 12 years with him. He devoted himself to his teacher and spared no pains in following his every instruction. After the elapse of seven years unfortunately the guru passed away and Alauddin was heart-broken. He gave up his vocal training and later took up instrumental music. For a time he was employed in Minerva Theatre of Calcutta, but took the opportunity to learn western-style behala under the guidance of a Mr Lobo, and the local style of behala from Mr. Amar Das. He learnt pakhawaj under the expert hand of mridang musician Mr. Nanda Babu. In this way he furthered his knowledge of a variety of instruments and even learnt the clarinet from Mr. Habu Dutt and shenai from Hazari Ustad. In short, he became master of many instruments and could handle each one with ease.At this time he attended the court of Raja Jagat Kishore and received accolades from the raja. He also had the opportunity to meet Ustad Ahmed Ali Khan in the court and heard him play. Alauddin Khan entreated the Ustad to make him disciple, and through the recommendation of Raja Jagat Kishore, he was bestowed with the honour.For the next four years he learnt sarod at the feet of Ustad Ahmed Ali Khan. Alauddin Khan harboured a deep desire to visit Rangpur and very soon he fulfilled his wish. In the beginning, despite his efforts to meet the famous Ustad Wazir Khan he could not make headway, the guards turning him away on many occasions. One day he was so depressed that he decided to commit suicide and even purchased two tolas of opium. By chance a sympathetic maulvi who used to live in his quarters prevented him and showed him a way-out. He offered to write a petition to the Nawab of Rampur, asking for an opportunity to become student of the famous court ustad. As the Nawab was proceeding to a theatre, Alauddin Khan threw himself in front of the car, forcing it to stop. He could hardly express himself in Urdu and with difficulty he picked up the courage to say: ``Sir, I beg you to help me. I wish to learn sarod from Ustad Wazir Khan.'' The Nawab brushed him aside and ordered the car to move on, Alauddin Khan quickly took out the opium chunk from his pocket and desperately showed it to the Nawab saying: ``I will die right here, if you do not help me.'' He pushed the petition into the hands of the Nawab begging him to read it. The Nawab read and then said ``All right, come to my court tomorrow and make your presentation. We will hear it.''Next day he played several of the instruments in which he attained some excellence and the listeners were impressed with the talent he displayed. The Nawab expressed his approval and Ustad Wazir Ali Khan accordingly tied the nara, the sacred thread given as token to a disciple, on the wrist of Alauddin Khan. He learnt for 12 years in the gharana' of Wazir Khan and his devotion became proverbial.In 1918 the Nawab of Rampur sent him to the state of Maihar, where he was employed as a state musician. The Raja of Maihar was a very generous man, and spent lavishly on patronising new talent. His state was not very large but had gained status as an important centre for classical music, all over India. He established a deep and close relationship with the Raja of Maihar, who reciprocated whole-heartedly their friendship, respect and admiration for each other lasted till the death of Ustad Alauddin Khan.It is worth noting that Alauddin Khan created new ragas and raginis, for instance, hemant, prabhat keli, hem-behag, madan-manjali. The British government bestowred the title of Khan Sahib and the Biswa Bharati gave him Deshi-Kottam while Dhaka University gave him honorary degree of Doctors of Law. He also received Padma Bhushan and Padma Bhibushan from the Indian government. He had among his disciples many who became famous students of his gharana. Among them were Timir Baran, Panna Lal Ghosh, Ali Akbar Khan, Ravi Shankar and his own daughter Roshanara Begum alias Annapurna, Saran Rani and others to name a few. He was the guru of Uday Shankar and helped him with his orchestra for several years.In 1950 I went to Maihar to become the Ustad's disciple and stayed for a short while, but as the Ustad was returning to Dhaka soon after, I also returned. Eventually he handed me over to Ustad Khadim Hossain Khan, his loved disciple. As our family had a close association with Ustad Alauddin Khan, my father and uncle being patrons of music, I was fortunate to sit at his feet on many occasions. One of the Ustad's violins was in the house of my chacha Mirza Abdul Qadir in Islampur, which he used to play when he visited that house on some occasions.I remember one incident when Ustad Alauddin Khan came to Dhaka from Comilla and I and several friends took initiative to request Mr. Osman Ghani Khan, the Provost, to hold a function at Salimullah Muslim Hall. On the evening of the function, a large crowd of students gathered and the Ustad went up to the stage and sat with his shagrids. But there was a lot of commotion in the hall, some students were shouting, gossiping and smoking cigarettes. It appeared that the function would be disturbed and spoilt. But gradually as the Ustad settled down and began the first few notes on his sarod, the whole atmosphere became changed, and the magic of his notes spread over the listeners. Along with the Ustad were Bahadur Hossein on the sarod, and Khadim Hossein Khan on the sitar while Abid Hossein was on the taanpura. Two great maestros were on the tabla: Phuljhari Khan and Mohammd Hossein Khan. They played for two hours, and the enrapt audience gave calls of encore. The maestro stood up, took his violin and like a conductor, led the orchestra to play tilak kamod, a very favourite raag of his. Such a beautiful and over-powering presentation has hardly ever been seen since then. The whole hall was acclaiming with praise and clappings the brillant performance.After the show Ustad Alauddin Khan came to our Islampur house at 11 pm for dinner. He said his prayers and then sat down in the mehfil, saying: ``I am going to enjoy Kabuli (a Dhaka dish of renown) with you all, but I also have something to give you. I will present raag hemant for your pleasure.'' He played for about twentyfive minutes, to an enraptured audience.I would like to also narrate an incident which took place in Paris around 1935 or 1936 when he accompained Uday Shankar's troupe. Ustad Alauddin Khan recalled the event himself recorded in Mubarak Hossein's book on the Ustad. To quote the maestro: ``It was May 5, a beautiful spring evening, when several European and American dancers and musicians came to my hotel to hear me play. I began lightly, playing five or seven taan in bilambit taal, whey I glanced up at their faces and saw tears in their eyes. Instantly I shook away my lethargy and realised that my listeners were very sensitive. I began playing with great depth and concentration and found that they continued to be deeply moved. I played Bhimpalasi and Pilu for over three hours, so deep was the communication between them and me.''At the end of his life he became paralytic and confined to bed for several years. On 6 Setptember, 1973, he died at the age of 103 in Maihar. His guru Wazir Ali Khan's gharana' will be eternally remembered through this extraordinary musician who came as a simple village lad from Comilla to Maihar, and through his dedication and sacrifice reached the heights of musical excellence.It is known that Uday Shankar went bare-footed in the presence of Alauddin Khan, reflecting the devotion and honour of the disciple for the Guru.

JAKARTA (JP): City councilors urged the city administration yesterday to quickly reconsider its massive projects, most of which have ground to a halt. They said the administration should look into whether the investors and developers of projects such as the triple-tier transit system, the Jakarta Bay reclamation project and the subway project could continue despite the crisis. Fatommy Asaari, head of the Golkar faction, said investor and developer commitment was very important for the quick completion of the projects. ``They postponed construction work as soon as the monetary crisis hit the country. But we can't wait for too long,'' he told The Jakarta Post yesterday. Ali Wongso Sinaga, head of Commission D for development, told the Post that project contracts must be thoroughly reassessed with the crisis in mind. ``If the contracts produce more profit for the developers or investors, then they (contracts) must be revised because the administration is actually the one which owns the assets,'' he said. Ali said the administration should find new investors with strong financial and technical backgrounds to manage the projects if the current companies backed out. ``But first we must allow the current developers to appraise us of the situation,'' he added. Fatommy shared Ali's view, saying that it was important for the administration to quickly complete its projects since they were very important for Jakarta's future. ``Foreign investors and developers should be welcomed to participate in the projects,'' he said. The triple-tier transit system project, which is to connect Bintaro in South Jakarta to downtown Kota, is managed by PT Citramoda Margakencana Persada, a joint-venture company of PT Citra Lamtorogung Persada, owned by former president Soeharto's eldest daughter Siti Hardijanti Rukmana, state railway company Perumka and the state-owned highway corporation, PT Jasa Marga. Construction for the project, which is not included in the city's 1985/2010 revised urban spatial plan, started in March with the opening of some work sites in Bintaro and the controversial cutting down of some trees along Jl. Bendi Raya in Tanah Kusir, also in South Jakarta. Construction was postponed in April due to financial problems. The Jakarta Bay reclamation project issues the rights to a total of 2,700 hectares to several companies, including PT Manggala Krida Yudha, owned by Soeharto's youngest daughter Siti Hutami Endang Adiningsih. Open bid Ali said the project, which was backed by Presidential Decree No. 52 issued in 1995, was not awarded through an open bid. Only few of the earmarked locations have been reclaimed, he added. The US$1.5 billion subway project to connect Blok M in South Jakarta and the downtown Kota area is handled by a consortium in which Soeharto's second son Bambang Trihatmodjo's company is involved. Fatommy said the city and the companies in the consortium had welcomed Bambang's involvement in the project, which was originally the administration's idea. ``They hoped that Bambang's involvement could help them get approval from the central government. But it turned out that the Presidential Decree was not issued specifically to support the subway but rather to cover Hardijanti's triple-tier project,'' he said. Fatommy said the administration should not review the projects just because they were handled by companies owned by the family of former president Soeharto. ``Let's not look into who were behind the projects. I think it would be better to see the importance of the projects for the public. But, if there is proof that the companies are using the projects to make huge profits, then we have to take strict action,'' he said.

World Cup qualifiers draw 0-0 in unattractive exhibition
EDS: UPDATES with detail; WILL be UPDATED with lineups.
CRETEIL, France (AP) _ Fellow World Cup qualifiers Mexico and Saudi Arabia played to an unattractive 0-0 draw Wednesday, with North Americans having most of the possession and the Saudis the better scoring chances. Playing before a crowd of 5,000 in a small venue, the Saudis opened the game with an opportunity in the first minute when Khalid al-Muwalid shot wide from one yard. And in the 22nd, Sami al-Jaber couldn't head a ball from good position, with Mexican goalkeeper Osvaldo Perez beaten. Luis Garcia troubled the Saudis the most, but failed on three chances. He shot high from 10 yards in the first half and wasting two more opportunities in the second. On the first he shot wide after receiving a pass from Luis Hernandez and was blocked by Saudi Mohammed al-Dayea. Mexico used an experimental lineup in which Garcia started up front along side Ricardo Pelaez while regular strikers Hernandez and Cuauhtemoc Blanco played wide midfield. Azerbaijan protests French vote on Armenia
MOSCOW (AP) _ Azerbaijan objected Wednesday to a vote in the French parliament to recognize the 1915 killings of ethnic Armenians in Turkey as a genocide. The motion, unanimously approved by the National Assembly on Friday, now goes to the Senate. If it passes there, France would become the first major European country to use the term ``genocide'' to describe the deaths of an estimated 1.5 million Armenians in Ottoman Turkey between 1915 and 1923. Turkey denies that the deaths constituted genocide, insisting instead that they were the result of a civil war. Genocide is the systematic annihilation of a racial, political or cultural group. Azerbaijan shares ethnic, linguistic, Islamic and cultural ties with Turkey and has a longstanding animosity toward its mainly Christian neighbor, Armenia. President Gaider Aliev expressed his disapproval of the French action at a meeting with a French government delegation in the Azerbaijani capital, Baku, the Interfax news agency said. He said the resolution evoked protests and anxiety in Azerbaijan, especially given France's membership in a group trying to resolve the dispute with Armenia over the enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh. Azerbaijan's Turan news agency said more than 150 people picketed Wednesday outside the French Embassy in Baku. When dispersed by police, the protesters moved on to the Turkish Embassy, where they shouted slogans of support, Turan said. (ls)

BC-Germany-Train Derails, 19th Ld-Writethru
At least 100 dead in high-speed German train crash passengers and injured and details of accident
URGENT Eds: UPDATES with 100 confirmed dead, discrepancies in numbers of With BC-Germany-High Speed Train AP Photos By CLAUS-PETER TIEMANN Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ A high-speed passenger train derailed Wednesday in northern Germany, killing at least 100 people and seriously injuring scores as car after car of the train crumpled into the concrete base of an overpass. The crash _ Germany's deadliest rail disaster in 31 years _ happened at 11 a.m. as the Hamburg-bound train sped at 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour approaching the station in Eschede, 50 kilometers (35 miles) north of Hanover. The cause of the accident remained unclear, and authorities were unable to account for discrepancies in the number of injured. The Lower Saxony state Interior Ministry spokesman Frank Lukashweski confirmed 100 bodies had been recovered and stood by reports of up to 300 injured. However, rescue coordinators, speaking at a news conference, reported 40 injured. Klaus Rathert, the chief regional rescue coordinator, told the news conference that the front locomotive apparently decoupled from the passenger cars, causing them to derail and jackknife into the overpass. The front locomotive traveled at least 500 meters (yards) from the scene of the derailment, through the Eschede train station, before the driver realized he'd lost the passenger cars, Rathert said. The station chief engaged the emergency brake, stopping the locomotive about two kilometers (more than a mile) from the scene, and thereby alerting the driver to the accident. The account conflicted with earlier reports suggesting that an auto had plunged into the train from the overpass, causing the derailment. Police said an automobile was crushed beneath the wreckage, but it was unclear where the car was parked at the time of the accident. They said it was probably sitting along the tracks, not on the overpass. Police spokesman Joachim Lindenberg told ARD television that the auto belonged to a rail employee who was working along the tracks. He said that anyone that close to the accident could not have survived. Neither Rathert nor Deutsche Bahn immediately confirmed that account. Views of the wreckage offered no clear clues as to what caused the accident. The nose of the rear engine stuck from under the bridge, and three derailed cars were piled on each other beneath the collapsed overpass. At least 13 cars had derailed. The force of the pile-up pushed cars meters (yards) high into the air along an embankment. Survivors were taken to hospitals throughout the region. The Red Cross chartered six buses to take most of the uninjured to Hamburg, spokesman Harald Krueger said. The accident was the worst on Germany's premier high-speed ICE line, inaugurated in 1991. A 1967 rail accident near Magdeburg in then-East Germany, killed 94 people in the deadliest rail accident since World War II. A crossing barrier closed on a rail tanker filled with gasoline, causing it to explode and spreading fire into passenger cars. The worst accident in western Germany was in 1971, when a train carrying children on a field trip collided with a freight train, killing 46 people. A Deutsche Bahn executive Johannes Ludewig, said he was ``deeply dismayed and horrified by the proportions of this accident.'' Several of the rail cars were demolished, and splintered glass covered the scene. Luggage was piled next to the wreckage as workers struggled to pry passengers from the train. More than 1,100 rescue workers were at the scene, including trauma surgeons and border patrol personnel who helped free passengers trapped inside the rail cars. Christian Krettek, of University Hospital in Hanover, told CNN that rescue workers expected the death toll to rise, and it was still unclear if there were more dead inside the shattered train cars. A crane was positioned to lift chunks of the bridge to reach cars underneath. The accident closed train traffic in both directions. Federal Transport Minister Matthias Wissmann, Lower Saxony state governor Gerhard Schroeder and German railway executives were en route to the scene. The ICE train is Germany's fastest, connecting all major cities at speed up to 280 kilometers (175 miles) an hour. The train travels from Munich to Hamburg, covering a distance of more than 950 kilometers (about 600 miles), in 5 hours and 37 minutes. Regular train service takes more than eight hours. The train that crashed Wednesday was a first-generation ICE model powered by two electric-powered locomotives pulling up to 14 passenger cars with a capacity of 759 passengers. At top speed the train requires 2.8 kilometers (1.7 miles) to come to an emergency stop. The high-speed trains carry more than 65,000 passengers daily. (cb-gb-aet)

BC-Germany-Train Derails-Scene
Residents rush to German train crash to help bloodied victims
RETRANSMITTING to fix slug With BC-Germany-Train Derails By CLAUS-PETER TIEMANN Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ There was a boom. An explosion. Then a horrible crushing sound. Hannelore Domkewitz saw the train speed past from her kitchen window where she stood peeling potatoes. She had just a moment to reflect that it was moving much faster than usual. ``Then there was a loud boom, a dust cloud, and then silence,'' Domkewitz said. The silence didn't last long. There were screams from the tracks. Domkewitz ran 100 yards (300 feet) toward the mangled wreckage of Germany's deadliest train crash in more than three decades. People with bloodied hands staggered toward her. Behind them was a ghostly scene of passenger cars wedged into each other, some sticking up several yards (meters) into the air and others buried under a collapsed overpass. The train, holding up to 350 passengers, had been speeding along at 200 kph (125 mph) when cars derailed and jack-knifed, killing scores of people. Domekewitz ran back to get blankets and bed sheets to cover the injured and dead. ``But there were also survivors who went by with their luggage. They were all in shock,'' Domkewitz said, her voice breaking. Mark Draeger heard it too. ``It was like an explosion! Yet very different, because it was a terrible crushing sound,'' said the 20-year-old aid worker who lived nearby and rushed to the wreckage. Within an hour, the rails were swarming with rescue workers and helicopters carrying the injured to hospitals. Residents along the tracks rushed to the scene with small wagons to offer help. Manfred Thiel was on his way to work when the train crashed. He grabbed a ladder and helped the injured to safety. He stood by as rescuers pulled a 10-year-old girl from the wreckage alive. Color Sergeant Phil Forsyth and 20 soldiers from the 2nd Battalion of the Royal Fusiliers, based at Celle in Germany, were among the first to arrive at the site. Sgt Forsyth, speaking in a BBC interview from the regiment's base just minutes from the crash scene, said: ``On arrival we were met by an horrific site. ``Some five or six carriages were piled up on top of each other. Once we got nearer it became quite clear the bridge had totally collapsed on to the second and third carriages, and the remainder of the carriages had piled up on top of that. ``All the carriages were absolutely mangled; it was a mess and very sad to see. ``My heart can do nothing but go out to those people who were caught up in it and those who were waiting to find out what had happened.'' Sgt Forsyth, who has been in the Army for 13 years and fought in the Persian Gulf war, added: ``It is definitely one of the worst scenes I have ever seen, if not the worst.'' (gb/cb/im)

Asked about the possibilities that the building owners pay penalties for the violation, Andi said he would study the matter first. ``We haven't gone that far,'' he said. Andi also said he was looking into projects closely related to Soeharto's family in the mayoralty. ``We'll study the projects' legal basis first before taking action against their owners,'' he said. Andi also insisted that the mayoralty would continue the beautification of the Monas area. Commenting on the opposition to the beautification project from street vendors forced by the project to relocate to a site further from the Monas area, the mayor said he would urge them to abide by the existing order. ``I've repeatedly asked the administration to provide proper lighting at the relocation site to help attract the vendors, but up to now there has been no response,'' he said. Many of the vendors who were told to relocate to the new site have reoccupied their former selling spots, including the monument's gateway where visitors of the park enter. The vendors strongly rejected the relocation plan because it significantly reduced their daily incomes.

THE Asean Gas Pipeline Grid - mooted in 1988 - is now expected to be ready only in 2016 as the region's economic problems have caused work on some of the key components to be deferred. This projection was made by Petronas vice-president for gas business Muri Muhammad at the 3rd Asia Oil Gas Conference in Kuala Lumpur. The two-day conference ended yesterday. While the impact of the Asian economic problems on the Asean Gas Pipeline Grid is still a major concern, ``... it is foreseen that the pipeline development will be temporarily delayed rather than altogether halted''. Muri said despite the economic problems, work on several components for the Asean project was continuing as scheduled. The gas grid will eventually link up Malaysia, Thailand, Singapore, Indonesia, Brunei as well as the Philippines. Malaysia's Peninsular Gas Utilisation system - due for completion later this year - has the potential to become the backbone of the gas grid, he added. ``Nevertheless the development of one of the most important link of the Asean Gas Pipeline Grid which is the Natuna gas pipeline to Thailand has been postponed due to massive budget cuts.'' ``The postponement of the Natuna development has also caused the delay on the work of the Trans-Java pipeline which will source gas from Natuna field (located in the Gulf of Thailand) for the Javanese gas market.'' Touching on the demand for natural gas, Muri said demand for the energy resource is projected to grow at 3.7 per cent annually worldwide until 2005 compared with 2.3 per cent per annum for oil and two per cent annually for coal. ``Within Asia-Pacific, natural gas accounted for 9.2 per cent of the primary energy used in 1996. In 1996, 11 per cent of the world gas demand came from the Asia-Pacific region.'' In 1996, Asia-Pacific countries consumed nearly eight trillion cubic feet of natural gas, double the demand in 1986. A large portion of natural gas is used for generating electricity.

Plane crash kills seven in northern Mexico
MEXICO CITY (AP) _ A single-engine air taxi flying through smoky skies crashed in the mountains of northern Mexico, killing seven people, Durango state officials said Wednesday. ``According to the reports we have, there was null visibility because of smoke... caused by fires,'' said Durango state's communications director, Hector Partida. The Cessna 206 was approaching a landing field in Topia, about 55 miles (88 kilometers) northeast of its base in the western city of Culiacan, when it crashed at 1:50 p.m. on Tuesday, Partida said. The victims were identified as pilot Manuel Herrera, his son Manuel Herrera, attorney Pascual Estevez Guzman and his sister Magda, 22, Juana Gutierrez and two children, aged 13 and 14. Many parts of the rugged mountain zone have no access by highway and air taxis are a common method of transportation. ``The pilots in this case ... have a lot of experience in flying in that part of the Sierra,'' Partida said.

Volkswagen, Porsche to team up on sports utility vehicle
STUTTGART, Germany (AP) _ Taking aim at a market long dominated by U.S. car manufacturers, Volkswagen AG and Porsche AG of Germany are teaming up to build a sports utility vehicle. The two automakers, in a joint statement released Wednesday, said they hope to launch the new vehicle in the year 2002. Each company will sell its the vehicles under its own name. Porsche will oversee the development of the vehicle, while Volkswagen will be in charge of producing it. The companies expect annual sales of about 100,000 vehicles. Company officials said they were optimistic about entering the sports utility market, one of the hottest segments of the auto industry. ``Our new sports utility vehicle will tap new growth potential,'' Porsche Chairman Wendelin Wiedeking said. ``It will also limit our dependency on the traditional market segments of sports cars, convertibles and roadsters.'' Robert Buechelhofer, VW board member and in charge of marketing and sales, said: ``This car targets an extremely dynamic segment _ there is no other area which grows faster than sports utility vehicles.''
