JAKARTA (JP): Several prominent artists and art students demanded yesterday the immediate dismissal of Salim Said and other members of the Jakarta Arts Council (DKJ), as well as the Jakarta Academy of Arts and Culture (AJ), the board which elects DKJ members. They made the demand in a meeting organized by DKJ at Taman Ismail Marzuki art center in Central Jakarta, to discuss reforms within the arts and cultural community. Poet and writer Sitok Srengenge read the written statements which contained demands for reform at local and national levels. ``Free the arts from licenses to perform, bureaucracy, censorship and banning of plays, exhibitions and general performances,'' Sitok said. This included the freeing of art centers from bureaucratic red tape and the rebuilding of art councils and cultural centers in all provinces. At a local level, artists and students ``advised with full respect for the recently elected DKJ board for the 1998/1999 period to declare its self-dismissal.'' They demanded a new electoral voting system to select members of the DKJ board that required the city's artists to vote and was free of the governor's influence. DKJ head Salim Said, recently reappointed for a third three-year term, faced most of the heat in silence. The observer of military affairs told The Jakarta Post that the board members just happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time. ``They (the artists and students) were holding a monolog,'' Salim said. ``It was useless for us to tell them that we were the ones who allocated funds outside the meager funding of Rp 1 billion (US$85,500) for DKJ's six arts and culture committees by the National Development Planning Board and the city administration,'' he said. ``They are just excited about the downfall of Soeharto ... they don't realize that without us, neither Ratna Sarumpaet's play nor Emha Ainun Najib's show would have been staged here.'' Ratna Sarumpaet's play Marsinah Menggugat (Marsinah Accuses) was staged at TIM and several other places before it was banned in some cities. Salim said that a general meeting of the DKJ board members would be held Friday to discuss further the possibilities of reform within the arts community and dismissal of the DKJ board. Salim added that the dismissal of the board was a matter to be decided by the board members themselves. ``They talked. We respected them and kept silent. But the dismissal of the board will be done on our terms and our's alone,'' Salim said. Ratna Riantiarno, organizer of Teater Koma and DKJ member, stressed that despite a 1970 gubernatorial decree making the AJ appointees lifetime members of the body that elects the DKJ, the dismissal of the AJ board was only a matter of time.

DESPITE the economic downturn, National Panasonic (Malaysia) Sdn Bhd still hopes to maintain its record-breaking sales performance for the current financial year. To this end managing director Bunroku Morioka said the company would maximise its efforts to match the RM1 billion in sales that it had achieved in the last two years. The company broke its own record when it chalked up RM1 billion in sales in 1996, up 103 per cent from the previous year, and kept the momentum going the last financial year notching sales of RM1.05 billion. Morioka, however, acknowledges the economic scenario has changed dramatically since then. ``Sometimes, no matter how hard you swim against the current, the forces may be stronger so you have to be humble. Our market is estimated to be down between 15 and 20 per cent, but we would still like to maintain our sales,'' he told reporters after a visit to Balai Berita yesterday. ``That is why we are not reducing our advertising and promotions budget. We will do our best.'' When asked how Japan's own economic troubles were affecting the company's operations, Morioka said the impact was not significant. Corporate losses have been mounting in Japan as the yen slides against the US dollar. ``We are lucky, we buy a lot of our goods locally. The yen is down but so is the ringgit, so the impact is small overall,'' he said, adding National Panasonic products now had an average 70 per cent local content. Morioka noted that the Malaysian home appliance market was unusual as, besides Japan, it was the only country that was receptive to innovative and high-tech products. ``There is a very high standard of living here and consumers are very quality conscious, so they are willing to use products that improve their lifestyle. ``Elsewhere, even in the United States, home appliances are relatively low-tech and the same ones stay in the market for years,'' he said.

BC-France-Russia, 2nd Ld-Writethru
New Russian prime minister makes first foreign trip
EDS: UPDATES in grafs 5-6 with quotes from Chirac's spokeswoman, NEW photo number AP Photos PAR108-109,PAR117 By DEBORAH SEWARD Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Russian Prime Minister Sergei Kiriyenko insisted he wasn't looking for handouts following a meeting Wednesday with French President Jacques Chirac. After arriving in Paris at the start of a two-day visit _ his first overseas trip since becoming Prime Minister in April _ Kiriyenko twice told reporters an economic rescue package was not on his agenda. ``Neither on the official program nor outside the official program is that (aid) a question,'' Kiriyenko said after his meeting at the Elysee Palace with Chirac. A small man in a blue suit who at times appeared lost among the delegation of husky Russian businessmen and bodyguards who accompanied him, Kiriyenko nevertheless projected confidence. For his part, Chirac told Kiriyenko that he had ``confidence in Russia's capacity to carry out its reform policies,'' presidential spokeswoman Catherine Colonna said. Chirac urged Kiriyenko to improve tax collection, create a modern and transparent banking system as well as a judicial and fiscal framework for business, Colonna told reporters. Russia's dismal record in collecting taxes has left the government with a huge fiscal hole, enormous debts, an inability to pay state workers and is at the heart of the current crisis. The ongoing Russian financial crisis has fueled speculation that some kind of aid package from the world's leading industrialized nation may be needed, primarily to prevent a collapse of the ruble. Kiriyenko did say ``relations between G-7 countries and Russia have reached a new stage.'' He didn't elaborate but said it is vital for the European Union to open its markets to Russian goods. Finance officials from the G-7 are to meet in Paris next week, with the slump in the yen against the dollar and Russia's economic troubles among the issues high on their agenda. Speaking to reporters at Charles de Gaulle airport, Kiriyenko said Russia must further integrate into the world economy in order to be able to better withstand financial shock waves like those that have shaken Asia and Russia itself recently. The Russian stock market has fallen about 50 percent from the beginning of 1998, a dramatic change from the previous year's record growth of 98 percent. ``We should be more integrated in the industrial process and the entire array of economic relations with other countries,'' Kiriyenko said. In addition to Chirac, Kiriyenko was to meet with Prime Minister Lionel Jospin and leading French lawmakers and businessmen. France is a modest trading partner, just eighth among Western European nations, and Russia would like to increase ties with aerospace, nuclear and automobile manufacturers. However, France traditionally enjoys good political relations with Russia and could be expected to support an eventual economic aid package. (dgs)

SURABAYA (JP): Hundreds of students marched yesterday afternoon to the private SCTV television station here demanding their demonstration for reform be broadcast and refused to budge until the station managers yielded. Traveling in two big buses and other personal vehicles, the students first went to the state-owned TVRI television station but were prevented from entering. They then went to SCTV, which is located nearby in the Darmo Permai housing complex. While several of their leaders negotiated with station manager Ris Anggono, the other students from, among others, Petra Christian University, Wijaya Kusuma University and Surabaya Teachers' Training Institute, held a free-speech forum under the watchful eyes of security personnel. One of the students, Sapardi, said their demand to be broadcast was meant to help disseminate the students' call for total reform. The students defined reform as including the revocation of the five laws that govern the country's political system, and revision of the Armed Forces' dual function that enables the military to be not only security forces but also a political player. They also demanded the revocation of the subversion law, the release of political prisoners, general elections, the lowering of prices of essential goods, and an investigation into alleged corruption by officials. SCTV finally agreed to air the student demonstration on its 6 p.m. news bulletin yesterday. The students' move echoed that of another group of student protesters who last month took over the RRI radio station and broadcast a protest against former president Soeharto. Yesterday's demonstration called for the convening of a special session of the People's Consultative Assembly (MPR) to elect a new president and for Soeharto to be tried for corruption. The same demands were made by another group of students who staged a rally at the East Java provincial legislative council. They demanded the local legislators endorse their call for the MPR special session. In Medan, the capital of North Sumatra, 200 students from the Medan Teacher Training Institute continued with their demonstrations. They marched to the provincial police headquarters and demanded to meet police chief Brig. Gen. Sutyono to discuss the alleged sexual harassment committed by his men toward female student protesters last month. The students failed to meet with the police chief. Officials Also yesterday, demonstrations were held by students and other groups against certain officials they considered to be corrupt. At the Ministry of Education and Culture office, staff members demanded the resignation of Director for Vocational Senior High Schools Jorlin Pakpahan for allegedly ``cultivating practices of corruption, collusion and nepotism'' at the ministry. Antara reported that yesterday's was the second protest held by the same group of civil servants; the first was held last week during the transfer of duty from outgoing minister Wiranto Arismunandar to Juwono Sudarsono. Then, the staff members demanded that the new minister fight the rampant corruption and collusion prevalent in the education ministry. In Padang, the capital of West Sumatra, 25 students continued their sit-in at the provincial legislative council and claimed they would not budge until State Minister of Agrarian Affairs Hasan Basri Durin resigned because of alleged corruption. Yesterday's was the students' fifth day at the complex. Supporters have been supplying the student protesters with food. Basri Durin is the former West Sumatra governor. Intervention Also yesterday, two groups of students demonstrated in Surabaya and Jakarta against what they called the United States' meddling in Indonesia's internal affairs. Seventy Jakartan students rallied outside the U.S. Embassy in Central Jakarta, while 200 colleagues marched to the U.S. consulate on Jl. Dr. Soetomo in the East Java capital. Both demonstrations passed without incident after delegations were received. In Jakarta, protesters calling themselves the Defenders Front for National Sovereignty criticized U.S. aid to local Indonesian groups. ``We reject all types of American intervention and condemn those sons and daughters of the nation who have already become the stooges of America,'' the group said in a statement. The Surabaya protest, by the unknown Indonesian Saviors Forum, also criticized the reported presence of a number of U.S. naval ships close to Indonesia during last month's political turmoil and violence.

WORLD oil prices are expected to pick up through another round of production cutbacks by members of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries to check the current excess supply which has pushed prices down in recent months, British Petroleum Plc chief economist Professor Peter Davies said yesterday. He expected the Opec summit meeting on June 24 to agree on further cutbacks in production to allow prices to recover from a 30 per cent fall since last November. With production outstripping world consumption, Davies said Asia had also experienced lower oil consumption since financial problems hit the region last year. Current Asian oil consumption stands at about 200,000 barrels a day, down from about 600,000 to 700,000 barrels a day experienced before the onset of the financial problems. However, Davies said oil consumption in any country slowed to a lesser extent in tandem with economic growth. He was confident that Asian oil consumption would pick up again in the near future with the recovery of emerging Asian economies. ``For Asian oil consumption, we saw the worst during the first quarter of this year and it will pick up again as the region shows good economic fundamentals. ``For oil prices, there is no reason to believe it will stay down as we expect more cutbacks in world production after the Opec meeting,'' he told newsmen in Kuala Lumpur. Current world oil production stands at about 75 million bpd resulting in a daily surplus of one million barrels while prices per barrel since last November have fallen to about US$14 (RM54.60) from US$20. ``Many oil producers do not want to add on to their already rapidly rising stocks. We can expect further cutbacks after the Opec meeting but the issue is by how much,'' Davies said.

French team doctor calls for blood tests
CLAIREFONTAINE, France (AP) _ The chief doctor of the French team called for blood doping tests in soccer as quickly as possible to counter any spread of the use of the EPO drug at the World Cup. ``The risk of doping exists. EPO can be of help during the preparations of a World Cup,'' French team doctor Jean-Marcel Ferret said. The drug EPO, a synthetic form of the hormone erythropoietin, is considered the +drug+ of choice in endurance sports because it allows the blood to stock oxygen. Several deaths of athletes have already been linked to EPO. ``I'm 100 percent in favor of blood testing in soccer, just like in cycling,'' Ferret said. There will be no such tests during the World Cup competition that opens June 10. EPO has its most beneficial effects in endurance sports. But because of the fatigue on World Cup player during the month-long World Cup, the drug could prupotedly also have advantages there. ``So far, doping remains anecdotal in soccer,'' said Ferret.

Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina in a high-level meeting of the Communications Ministry stressed the paramount importance of improving the roads and railways infrastructure of the nation, and directed the Ministry officials to speedily implement the ongoing projects in that sector, for the sake of national development. She asked the Railway authorities to attend to the needs of commuters from suburbs to the city for taking traffic loads off the roads, and at the same time instructed the Roads and Highways authorities to undertake construction of by-passes and fly-overs to relieve traffic jam in the metropolis. Indeed as Dhaka city is rapidly growing, the inner-city road network along with parking space for motorised and non-motorised traffic taken together is proving critically inadequate. There is very little room for expansion of individual modes of transport. Unless bulk transport facilities are increased, not only suburban commuters but also inner-city residents will find it increasingly difficult to move from one part to another, and time wasted on roads will be prohibitive for the working population in the city.While by-passes and fly-overs could ease the traffic pressures at same road-junctions, the inevitable growth of private vehicles, rickshaws and autorickshaws is bound to create traffic troubles on roads like in Bangkok. The government has taken a wise decision by sanctioning import of 200 double-decker buses for bulk-carriage, 40 of which have arrived already. A more efficient and environment-friendly mode of bulk transportation could be a metropolitan inner-city and suburban train network. On hindsight, the railway tracks that have been turned into roads as the Fulbaria Station moved to Kamalapur ought to have been retained by the Railways for a possible role in inner-city traffic. Even a circular railway around the periphery of the inner-city could be of immense help in relieving transportation burden.Indeed the Railway offers the best mode of bulk-transportation in a least-developed country like ours. It is a pity that since independence, we have not added to our railway tracks, and indeed may have lost some to slum-encroachments on sparsely used or unused railway property. As a result, the improvement that we enjoy in faster inter-city trains takes a toll of the regular passage of many district trains using the same tracks. What is needed is a more comprehensive planning and investment for an all-embracing railway network.

No oil production cuts in Kazakstan despite lower prices metric tons
Eds: SUBS 5th graf to CORRECT estimated production of 25-26 million
MOSCOW (AP) _ Kazakstan does not plan to cut oil production, despite the fall in world oil prices, the president of the Kazakhoil national oil company said Wednesday. Nurlan Kapparov told the Interfax news agency in Kazakstan that it would not be profitable to close wells, because reopening them would entail huge expenses. ``Even if a well is not unprofitable, it would be better left in production,'' he said. Kapparov said the government considered reducing excise duties or taking other measures to help oil companies, but ``budget possibilities are limited'' in the Central Asian country. Kazakstan expects to extract 25 million to 26 million metric tons (172 million to 182 million barrels) of oil this year, Kapparov said. Kapparov also said that the Tengizchevroil joint venture _ in which Chevron has a 45-percent stake and Mobil 25 percent _ plans to increase oil production this year. (ls)

ELECTRONIC commerce and smart cards, while not new to the man in the street, had only a minimal impact on everyday life in the form of a telephone card or the SIM card in cellular phones. Their use so far has been limited because the smart card is vendor or issuer-dependent and is inflexible and expensive. As a result, users still have to carry numerous cards in their wallets from different issuers for different purposes such as for a department store's shopping loyalty programme. This is about to change. In a move that sets a standard for the use of smart cards in payment technology, Standard Chartered Bank in Singapore yesterday launched the world's first Visa open platform smart card based on Java technology. And it is set to propel e-commerce even further. The launch, a joint effort with the bank's business partners - Visa International, Sun Microsystems and Gemplus - was done by Singapore Finance Minister Dr Richard Hu. The Visa open platform is non-proprietary, thus allowing the card to work anywhere in the world and card issuers to have total independence in choosing a smart card vendor. At the same time, use of the Java programming language allows banks to mix and match applications and to customise their services to meet the demands of different customers. Most of all, the versatile Java-based open platform addresses the critical issue of upgrades by ensuring that infrastructure investments made yesterday and today will continue to work with emerging systems tomorrow. Standard Chartered head of chip and debit card services (consumer banking) Nicholas Fung said the benefits to banks were huge as the chip allows them the flexibility to customise products and services offered to customers. It gives greater security, improves risk management by preventing unauthorised tampering of data, allows for updates to the functions of the cards and overall increased efficiency with reduced costs. To consumers, the Standard Chartered smart card offers convenience, flexibility, and security for their virtual shopping needs. Customers can also choose what products and services to put on the card before or after issue. This means fewer cards to carry and more value-added services. Fung said Standard Chartered planned to have at least 100 kiosks or sites in Singapore by the end of the year where users could shop using the smart card. Fung said the bank was waiting for Bank Negara and the Malaysian Government to issue directives and guidelines on the use of the card.

The violence unleashed against those who resist toll collectors has taken an even more disturbing trend. Last Monday morning as reported in the media, three boys aged 12 to 15, gunned down a garments factory supplier in broad daylight. What is of grave concern about this particular incident is the involvement of juveniles in street crimes. This trend needs to be nipped immediately and our misguided juveniles restored to normalcy. Recreational opportunities are not lacking. In fact, the juveniles may be suffering from a surfeit. What is required is character-building activity.Incidentally, in the recent past it is mostly young entrepreneurs who have been killed by toll collectors for refusing to pay up. Perhaps these budding businessmen felt that part of what they earn by the sweat of their brow should not go into the hands of those who do no labour. Others, however, take threats more seriously and regard toll payment as just another incidental expense in running a business. It is not the acquiescence of these silent majority of businessmen which is giving indulgence and emboldening the toll collectors but the protective umbrella of those who exercise their influence from behind the scenes. If a culprit is booked, a cumbersome procedure will probably be initiated, serving neither the ends of justice nor having any deterrent effect on those stalking the streets with deadly weapons. The law seems to have its hands tied. Politicians - of all hues - who can make the first and definite move, do not appear to be concerned. Ultimately, it is the citizens that must gird themselves to squash the toll collecting menace and similar activities by being actively vocal. A beginning has been made in Chittagong, which has been most hard hit by lawlessness. If the Chittagong and similar movements are to reap any harvest, the hand of the law needs to be empowered as is the norm in countries where crime has been kept at bay. We cannot bestow responsibility divested of the necessary quantum of authority to the law enforcement agency and expect desired results. To ensure peace and order the power to implement needs to be present.

BC-Israel-Holocaust Insurance
Generali, Israel's Holocaust museum begin computerizing names of victims
By DAFNA LINZER Associated Press Writer
JERUSALEM (AP) _ An Italian insurance company being sued for failing to payout thousands of policies of Holocaust victims, began assisting Israel Wednesday in computer archiving details of war victims. Last week, Assicurazioni Generali provided Yad Vashem, Israel's national Holocaust museum with a computerized list of 300,000 names of Jewish and non-Jewish policy holders they insured between 1920-1945 in eastern and central Europe. Yad Vashem will sort through the list to identify Jewish victims. ``For us, the documentation of names is of vital importance,'' said Yad Vashem director Avner Shalev. Six million Jews were killed in the Nazi Holocaust and some 300,000 survivors live in the Jewish state founded after the war. Wednesday Generali and Yad Vashem began a joint task force to upgrade means for locating Holocaust victims' names and set up a computerized repository which will include archives from Yad Vashem and other world archives. ``The working relationship between Yad Vashem and Generali result from the very tragic period in Jewish history,'' said Guido Pastori, vice-president of Generali, in a press statement. ``I am grateful that Generali has the opportunity to support and to be involved in the efforts made by Yad Vashem to perpetuate the legacy of the Holocaust all over the world,'' Pastori said. Generali, founded by Italian Jews in 1831, has said it is not liable for the unpaid policies because many of its offices were taken over by communists after World War II. The company was sued last year along with 15 other insurers, in federal court in New York. Another suit was filed in February in a Los Angeles Superior Court by family members of Holocaust victims. The state of California is investigating Generali records relating to Holocaust victims and has threatened to ban the company and other insurance carriers if they fail to honor the old claims. Israel has also made similar threats to boycott Generali, based in Trieste, Italy, and its Israeli subsidiary, Migdal Insurance which was founded in the 1930s. But Jewish leaders have praised Generali for keeping commitments such as gathering the long list of World War II claimants. Generali has expressed support for an international commission to investigate claims by victims and their families. Last year, Generali established a dlrs 12 million fund which is to be distribute with discretion to beneficiaries or families of insured victims. The fund is managed by a board of trustees and chaired by a retired justice of Israel's Supreme Court. dl

Although words like legend' are apt to be misused on sentimental occasions like this one, Brojen Das indeed created a legend in his small field - swimming. Back in the fifties he had put this poor country on the world map of swimming.As the first Asian to cross the English Channel, he gave a new pride to the people of this country. He crossed the Channel faster than his Egyptian predecessor Abdur Rahman had done. And it was not just one chance achievement; he was totally dedicated to swimming and brought many more credits to Bangladesh in the field of this aquatic sport. He set new record in crossing time and crossed the Channel six times, making a daunting athletic event look like an everyday affair. The icy and fierce waters of the English Channel seemed as natural to him as the hard and bouncy turf to an experienced cricketer. Brojen Das was our star swimmer who gave international dimension to a sport which had hitherto been a local activity.Brojen Das has left us. The athletic world has been sadly diminished by his passing at a nursing home in Calcutta. We owe it to our national legacy not to let this hero of the athletic world depart unsung. Both President Justice Shahabuddin Ahmed and Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina have mourned Brojen Das' death. The country can befittingly honour him by giving swimming a rigorous thrust in the country's sporting perspective. Although this riverine land has produced star swimmers, swimming is not our national passion. Opportunity for swimming has also shrunk greatly in recent years, especially in urban areas. As swimming is becoming more internationally competitive, we need to be inspired all the more with the work and vision of pioneers like Brojen Das.

IN the wake of the regional economic slowdown, local companies are being forced to hone their skills to survive. Most have introduced pay cuts among senior management while some are retrenching staff. At the start of the problem late last year, national car maker Perusahaan Otomobil Nasional Bhd scaled down production in tandem with the slowdown in demand. However, the slowdown did not stop Proton from continuing to plough back its earnings into research and development which the company considers important in ensuring a competitive edge in the global market. Vice-chairman for strategy and operations Tengku Mahaleel Tengku Ariff said Proton invested RM460 million on its RD this year despite the downturn. ``I believe we must continue to invest in RD to prepare ourselves for the recovery. The business of car-making involves long-term planning, even developing a prototype takes a lot of manpower and funds,'' he said in Kuala Lumpur yesterday. He was addressing a group of top-level public relations officers at a forum on ``Managing for survival in a crisis'' organised by the International Association of Business Communicators. Tengku Mahaleel said at Proton, he spent a lot of time on dialogues with his staff, a practice which he introduced when he joined the company in 1996. ``I have always made it a point to listen to their views and problems. These days, whenever I meet them, their main concern is whether they will be retrenched. ``And I assure them that will not be Proton's option. Once they know this, they can concentrate on their work without worrying about losing their jobs. ``And because we conduct this dialogue at every level once a week, the staff are kept up-to-date on the happenings in the company. Therefore, they are more willing to make small sacrifices such as a cut in overtime,'' Tengku Mahaleel. He said at Proton, ``we don't like to retrench because it takes such a long time and effort to train someone new to acquire a skill. We'd rather keep the ones that we have.'' Apart from dialogue, Tengku Mahaleel said he also called up dealers and suppliers for their feedback. ``We try to assist them in whatever way we can. For instance, some of them are unable to hold their stock (of auto parts), which can cost up to RM30 million a month. We buy it off them to help them keep their business going,'' he added. Another speaker, Lester Technology Group chief executive officer Jerry Wu said he also believed in an open line between top management and workers. ``One always hears of company heads who say that their people are the company's greatest asset. ``I really believe in that because if a worker is unclear about the company's goals or does not know what is happening with the rest of the company's operations other than his job specification, than we can't expect them to work hard for the company,'' Wu said. According to Wu, the economic situation had made the company, which provides total Internet and Intranet security solutions, more resilient. ``As a relatively new company, we started off our operations on a Titanic mode. It's like we either swim or sink,'' Wu added. Paddy Schubert Sdn Bhd managing director Datuk Paddy Bowie said in the wake of the slowdown, she believed part of the country's problem in restoring investor confidence was in ``issue management''. ``Perception does not have to be factual to be powerful. Therefore, if we do not do a good job of getting the good stories of the country out to foreign investors, they tend to believe the negative news in the foreign media written by parachuting journalists,'' she added. Although the perception that the situation in Malaysia was as bad as that in neighbouring Indonesia and Thailand was slowly fading away, Schubert said more needed to be done to send a louder message that ``Malaysia really has what it takes to come out of this crisis''.

The Global Environmental Facility (GEF) is one of the concrete results of the UN Conference on Environment and Development held in Rio in 1992. It still remains the only multilateral mechanism which provides financial support for projects that aim to deal with some of the most urgent global environmental problems facing humankind today. There can, however, be no doubt the 21st century will have to see such a facility built on new and more dynamic principles of global environmental cooperation that the new century and new millennium will demand. Instead of aid being the principle underpinning this cooperation, we will have to move towards sharing of the benefits of common global property resources like the atmosphere and the oceans, internalisation of environmental costs in the pricing of internationally traded commodities and national liabilities for international ecological damage built on the ``Polluter Pays'' principle. In 1972 Barbara Ward and Rene Dubos had told the Stockholm Conference that there is only one Earth. The need to share the earth equitably, peacefully and sustainably has never been greater than now. Sooner or later multilateral financing mechanisms will have to be built on new and emerging principles of global international cooperation. However, we do see GEF in its current shape and form as an important step forward. Recognising the importance of GEF in nudging the world towards a sustainable world, nongovernmental organisations from various countries who make up the GEF-NGO network have presented this assembly with a statement entitled The GEF in the 21st Century: A Vision for Strengthening the Global Environment Facility. The statement draws on the experience of NGOs in interacting with GEF at many levels and makes several key recommendations for strengthening and improving the performance of GEF. First, the resolution of the issue we are dealing with is going to be a very challenging task. Resolution of environmental problems must take into account the related social, economic and cultural issues as well. Therefore, GEF must have a genuine learning culture. In order to do this, the monitoring and the evaluation programme of GEF should be strengthened, its institutional independence maintained, and civil society groups ought to be involved in its work in a more effective and sustainable manner. Second, GEF must do more to ensure that global environmental concerns are integrated into the non-GEF operations of its three implementing agencies (IAS). By themselves, the resources of GEF are far too small to effect the current development trajectory of the planet. There should be periodic detailed reporting on the concrete steps undertaken by IAS to mainstream the global environmental objectives of GEF. Third, the number of IAS need to be expanded beyond the existing three, to increase the involvement of NGOs and community-based organisations. GEF should be a place where the best project ideas and the most promising implementers with genuine comparative advantage can compete. Fourth, GEF should become a mechanism to catalyse and support better funding cooperation and coordinating among multilateral and bilateral funding agencies and supporting activities with global environmental objectives. A funding-coordination-dialogue process for the global environment should be started. In addition, there is a need to evaluate in depth, which of the various financing modalities used till now have been most effective in order to understand which financing modalities should be given higher priorities for the GEF programming, with the aim of improving overall GEF effectiveness. Among the modalities that need to be considered further are national environmental funds, endowments and trusts, enterprise programmes, expansion of small and medium grants, concessional or contingent loans to help start projects with negative incremental costs, debt conversion options and micro-credit programmes. A key message of the Rio conference was the importance of civil society in sustainable development. The key to sustainable development is building partnerships --partnerships between the government, research institutions, the private sector, NGOs and communities. GEF is focussing mainly on government institutions and underemphasising the role of small or local NGOs and community groups and the role of the small and medium grants that are needed to support their activities. The role of NGOs as a watchdog on GEF projects, specially where they have negative social impacts, also needs to be appreciated, supported and formalised, to the extent possible and necessary. But apart from strengthening of GEF, there is a need to look beyond the current narrow mandate of GEF. It is a sad fact that the post-Rio period has seen a fragmentation of the global environmental agenda rather than the development of a strong, well coordinated global programme. GEF as an institution should play a greater role in developing an integrated global environmental agenda in the years to come. For the South too, the challenge of environment is the challenge of sustainable development. The world today is struggling to implement two equally critical global action programmes, namely the Rio agenda and the Copenhagen agenda. But each programme is following a separate track. GEF cannot allow the global environment to become an isolated issue. On the contrary, GEF should play a key role in the integration of the Rio and the Copenhagen agendas.Many global environmental issues like climate change, biodiversity-and desertification, are deeply connected with the problem of global -poverty. In addition, there is need for greater synergy between the programmes of different environment conventions. It is impossible to de-link local environmental problems from global environmental issues. When does biodiversity conservation stop being a local environmental issue deeply connected with the livelihoods and knowledge of innumerable, poor rural communities of the world and when does it start becoming a global issue, is very difficult to define.

European Union reaches out to its Mediterranean partners
Eds: UPDATES with Cook, Kinkel quotes, EDITS to conform; TRIMS By JEFFREY ULBRICH Associated Press Writer
PALERMO, Sicily (AP) - The European Union came together with its Mediterranean partners Wednesday, trying to get the economic cooperation process back on track after last year's derailment by Mideast issues. Despite the will to refocus on economics, however, the Middle East peace process pushed its way onto the agenda of the 15 EU foreign ministers and their 12 Mediterranean colleagues, and the increasing violence in the Serbian province of Kosovo threatened to do the same during the two-day meeting. A year ago in Malta, the Euro-Mediterranean ministers tried to talk trade and investment, only to see their meeting blown away by the turbulent winds of the Mideast peace process. ``We are all conscious that the political background of our work here is the present deadlock in the Middle East peace process,'' British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook told his fellow ministers, speaking for the presidency of the EU. Developing a prosperous Euro-Mediterranean region, he said, can foster an atmosphere conducive to peace. Organizers hope the Palermo meeting, with no set agenda, will bring the conference back to its original idea of creating a European-Mediterranean free trade and security zone by the year 2010. Farouk Kaddoumi, head of foreign affairs for the Palestine Liberation Organization, was looking for a stronger European position. ``We want a clear statement which shows the Europeans stand in support of the process of peace and expresses their willingness to revive the process,'' he said. ``And they have to refer to those who stand as a detriment to this process.'' Israel views the EU as pro-Arab and wants no significant role for Europeans in the peace process beyond supplying funding. ``France and Britain have supported Israel since its creation,'' Kaddoumi said. ``Now, they claim the Europeans are friends of the Palestinians. I hope that is true ... and that they cut all economic assistance to the Israelis.'' With violence on the rise in Kosovo, Italian Foreign Minister Lamberto Dini said Europe ``has to reconsider the entire picture.'' ``We certainly deplore the fact that there should be these attacks ... contrary to the spirit of conciliation,'' Dini said. NATO, he said, is studying the possibility of throwing up a ``shield'' of troops between Kosovo and its neighbors. ``It has to be recognized that it is from the southern countries that there is a flow of weapons into the area,'' he said. Cook once again called on Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosovic ``to halt the killing'' in Kosovo, while German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel called for ``stronger measures against Milosevic.'' If the escalation of violence continues, Kinkel said, ``then there has to be a cutoff of investments, and the freezing of Yugoslav money abroad has to be enforced.'' Joining ministers from the European Union are officials from Algeria, Cyprus, Egypt, Jordan, Israel, Lebanon, Malta, Morocco, Syria, Tunisia, Turkey and the Palestinian Authority. (ju-fd)

Jamaican leader gives plots of land to World Cup team
By CAROLL ORR Associated Press Writer
KINGSTON, Jamaica (AP) _ No matter what their fortunes in this month's World Cup playoffs, Jamaican national soccer team players all will have plots of land to call home when they return to the Caribbean. Jamaican Prime Minister Percival Patterson presented sales agreements for parcels of land to each of the team's 22 players Wednesday during an official send-off. Called the Reggae Boyz, it is the first Jamaican team to win a berth in the international competition, and the first from an English-speaking Caribbean nation. ``We have created history and excitement but we are going to create even more history and excitement by what we achieve by our performance in France,'' Patterson said. ``There are more miracles yet to be revealed.'' He praised the players, their Brazilian coach Rene Simoes and the Jamaica Football Federation, which turned the team from a volunteer squad into a full-time professional team through heavy marketing and sponsorships. Patterson likened Simoes' dedication to that of Jesus Christ, despite Simoes' announcement last month that he would leave the team in October. He made the decision after a national newspaper reported he was being paid dlrs 18,300 a month, more than any Jamaican public official. Simoes also has drawn criticism for replacing native-born Jamaicans with players born in Britain to Jamaican parents. ``Whatever our outcome, you have served us well,'' Patterson told Simoes. ``We are proud of you and we can say no more than to pay the highest tribute: to say that we see you as a true and outstanding (honorary) Jamaican.''

BC-Sports-Soccer-World Cup-Romania-Paraguay
Qualifier Romania struggles to beat Paraguay
BUCHAREST, Romania (AP) _ A penalty kick gave Romania a narrow 3-2 victory over Paraguay Wednesday in a warm-up game for the World Cup in France. The match was of particular importance for the Romanians as their first game at the tournament is against Colombia whose play is considered similar to that of Paraguay. Romania's star player Gheorghe Hagi scored the winner in the 83rd minute from a penalty kick after Gheorghe Craioveanu conveniently fell in the penalty area. Although Romania looked more confident and controlled the game most of the time, its defense had often problems with stopping Paraguay's fast counterattacks. The Romanians scored only four minutes after kickoff in Bucharest's Steaua stadium. It was Valencia's star Adrian Ilie, nicknamed ``Cobra'', who scored from inside the penalty area with a ball centered from the right by his future teammate Gabi Popescu. Popescu was transferred last week from Salamanca to Valencia. In the 27th minute, a Paraguayan counterattack found Jose Cardozo free at 16 meters (yards) from the goal. Romanian goalkeeper Bogdan Stelea warded off his shot, but Cardozo scored on the rebound. Romania looked strong after change of sides, and in the 57th minute, Hagi made brilliant use of a free kick from 25 meters by serving Ilie who scored the second goal. Only seven minutes later, Roberto Acuna beat the Romanian goalie with a spectacular shot from about 20 meters in far-right position. Paraguay also lost very good opportunity to take the lead in the 44th minute when Acuna fired from 30 meters (years) but hit the crossbar. In France, Romania plays in Group G together with England, Colombia and Tunisia, while Paraguay meets in Group D Spain, Bulgaria and Nigeria. BC-Iran-Retrials
Iranian judges order retrials for journalist, German on death row
Eds: INCORPORATES BC-Iran-German; ADDS retrial for journalist
TEHRAN, Iran (AP) _ Iranian judges have ordered retrials for a German businessman and an Iranian journalist who were condemned to death, state-run media reported Wednesday. The retrials mean that the death sentences against Helmut Hofer, a German businessman convicted of having sex with an Iranian woman, and Morteza Firoozi, an Iranian journalist convicted of espionage and adultery, have been set aside. New courts will issue their own verdicts and, if necessary, sentences. The chief justice's spokesman, Ali Abbassifard, said a new trial had been ordered for Hofer because he contends he had converted to Islam before the incident occurred, state-run radio reported. The retrial has already started. In the case of Firoozi, Abbassifard said the supreme court had ``major objections'' to his conviction, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. In January, an Iranian court sentenced Hofer, 54, to death after convicting him of violating Iranian law by having sex with a 26-year-old medical student, who was Muslim while he was not. The Bonn government warned Tehran that if Hofer were executed, German-Iranian relations would deteriorate. Germany is Iran's biggest trading partner in the Europe Union. Last month, the chief justice, Ayatollah Mohammad Yazdi, said Hofer's case would be reviewed by the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court refused an appeal by Firoozi on May 10, the Iran News reported. Few details of Firoozi's case have emerged in the press, but Yazdi said earlier this year that the journalist had been convicted of spying and several sexual offenses. Adultery and espionage are punishable by death under Iranian law. Firoozi, 40, is a former editor of the Iran News. He has been detained since May 1997. While there is no evidence that the government has influenced the decisions to retry Hofer and Firoozi, President Mohammad Khatami, a moderate who took office in August, is known to favor fewer death sentences than were carried out under previous governments. av-jbm

IF forests are removed, people cannot survive. This is the opinion of French primatologist Marc Ancrenaz, who has been in and out of Kinabatangan for the past four years with fellow researcher and wife Isabelle. ``Maybe they could fish, but with the removal of forests, even fishing will become impossible,'' he says. For Ancrenaz, the depleting forest is something that has to be looked into on a long-term basis. He feels that a management plan is needed because of rapid changing habitats. ``This is a natural resource. If we do not pay attention, it will become extinct one day. Once a habitat is gone, it is gone forever. There is no way to recreate it,'' he says. And if nothing is done to preserve what the Kinabatangan has to offer in terms of wildlife, we might not be able to see orang utans in the next century. Calamities such as droughts and fires affect the orang utan population in the long term because they cannot settle down. This will affect their reproduction. The prolonged drought has made it difficult for orang utans to find fruits and they have to move around a lot every day. ``Parts of forests have been logged, leaving patches or pockets of bare land. These orang utans then have to cross non-forested land like oil palm plantations to seek food,'' he says. According to Ancrenaz, orang utans eat young oil palm shoots which are not more than three years old when they enter plantations. Estate owners then call the Wildlife Department to catch these orang utans so that they can be sent to the Sepilok Orang Utan Sanctuary in Sandakan. If more land is cleared for timber and oil palm plantations, the future of orang utans and other wildlife is going to become even bleaker. Driving through Labuk Road and then the road leading to Kota Kinabatangan, one could see oil palm plantations stretching into the horizon on both sides of the road. Patches of forested timber land could also be seen. ``Find a way to exploit timber in a wise way because the Kinabatangan floodplain is one of the richest eco-systems in the world,'' says Ancrenaz. World Wide Fund for Nature scientific officer Reza Azmi says there is a high density of orang utans in Kinabatangan because of the diversity of vegetation in the area. Besides the many different fruit trees, figs such as the tangkul (Ficus racemosa) are a reliable food source for orang utans, macaques, hornbills and even fish. ``Fires will make it difficult for wildlife to obtain food.'' On the long-term effects, Reza says that once a peat swamp burns, its natural cover will eventually be replaced by lalang. ``Once that happens, natural vegetation cannot be recreated and the place becomes grassland. It happened to one area next to Pin Supu during the 1983 drought,'' he says. Reza also fears that when the next drought season comes, the issue of drought-induced fires on wildlife will resurface if no action is taken now. WWF scientific officer Martin Paul Vogel, who is based in Batu Putih near the Pin Supu Forest Reserve, says that there is a need to create awareness among locals on the importance of conserving wildlife sanctuaries and forest reserves. By creating such awareness, they will be able to benefit from natural resources ``which creates a win-win situation for both locals and the eco-system''. ``Batu Putih is surrounded by forest reserves. However, locals in the area are involved in fishing or doing part-time contract jobs. Others work in nearby plantations. ``Then there are others who are involved in illegal logging activities,'' Vogel says. ``We want to create an alternative economy for them,'' he adds, ``through local participation in tourism.'' ``We want locals to know how important tourism can be. They have to bring the market to their produce, making it vital for them to come up with products,'' he says. Vogel feels that as there is no example of how tourism has benefited the local community, it can be difficult convincing the villagers. While many parties are doing what they can to help save forest reserves and sanctuaries in Kinabatangan, more needs to be done and one way is by creating awareness. Increased conservation efforts and creating permanant fire-fighting units in forested areas are among the measures taken by the Government.

NUMECH Engineering (Malaysia) Sdn Bhd is negotiating with an Italian manufacturer to produce palletisers that form an integral part of the conveyor system. If the deal materialises, its chief executive officer Michael K.P. Siew said the company would acquire new technology for expansion of the integrated raking production line. Numech Engineering is involved in the manufacture and fabrication of conveyor systems and components for the manufacturing and automotive industries as well as other equipment assembly lines. The company, which utilises over 90 per cent local contents, manufactures and fabricates components like press bearings gravity roller and chain driven rollers. Plans are also afoot to explore the Asean region for exports. Siew said the company had also taken a forward synergistic step by venturing into the production of integrated racking systems for hypermarkets, retail sectors, warehouses and also the automotive industry. ``With the strong local demand for integrated racking systems, the potential for the materials handling industry look extremely bright,'' he said in a statement. ``As compared to the imported systems, our locally produced ones are competitively priced and would be at least 30 per cent cheaper.'' Numech Engineering, which invests more than RM100,000 annually in research and development, registered an annual turnover of RM8 million last year. Taking a positive approach to maintain its workforce of about 70 people, the company has taken the initiative to provide in-house training on CAD- CAM techniques to improve their skills. At the same time, it is also adopting new marketing strategies to build a wider networking of smart partnerships with its dealers natiowide. Numech Engineering will be among more than 500 exhibitors from over 30 countries taking part in the Industry Tradefair Malaysia, or ITM '98 exhibition, to be held from June 3 to 7 at the Mines Exhibition Centre in Seri Kembangan, Selangor. The ITM '98 exhibition, which is organised by Malaysia Exhibition Services Sdn Bhd, will be opened by International Trade and Industry Minister Datuk Seri Rafidah Aziz.

LOCAL furniture designers should focus on the mid-range to high-end products to tap the markets in the US, Japan and Europe. Primary Industries Minister Datuk Seri Dr Lim Keng Yaik said the industry should steer away from manufacturing low-end products which were facing stiff competition from countries like China and Vietnam where production costs were low. ``By embarking on high-end furniture products, we can hope to increase our furniture exports which are doing well now despite the economic downturn,'' he said, when speaking at a national seminar on product finishing using Ultra-Violet/Electron-Beam technology in Kuala Lumpur yesterday. Furniture exports totalled RM2.6 billion last year and the ministry hopes to achieve the target of RM4 billion by 2000. It expects to export RM3.5 billion worth of furniture this year. Dr Lim said a Malaysian design centre would be set up to encourage Malaysians to go into furniture designing. ``We then hope to produce a new group of furniture designers who design for the competitive international market,'' he said, citing outlets like High Point in the US and Harrods in the UK as examples. ``If we keep on designing what people want, then the market will be flooded with standard designs whereas if we were to create our own designs, we'll soon have our own market willing to pay more for the exclusive made-in-Malaysia designs.'' The Malaysian Timber Industry Council has been asked to engage reputable international furniture designers to design furniture for Malaysia. On complaints by Bumiputera furniture manufacturers of not getting export credit refinancing facility, Dr Lim said he would be meeting them next week. He said the ``umbrella concept'' which Bumiputera furniture makers come under, would have to be revised. ``Instead of concentrating only on the lowest end of furniture-making for schools and government departments, they should be more competitive by competing with the rest,'' he said, adding that the creativity of the Bumiputera furniture-makers had yet to be tapped. Bumiputera furniture- makers constitute about four per cent of the total 2,500 furniture factories in the country. Palm oil and furniture are among two resource-based industries which the Government is pushing now to increase exports and find new markets. ``For instance in the case of furniture, we found new markets in the Middle East countries.'' A mission from his ministry will be heading for these countries later this year. The one-day seminar was organised jointly by the Malaysian Nuclear Society, Malaysian Institute for Nuclear Technology Research, Malaysian Timber Industry Board and the Malaysian Furniture Industry Council. The seminar is designed to provide a broad overview of radiation curing chemistry, equipment and applications in various industries in particular wood-based and printing industries. Radiation curing technology has been used on a commercial scale in developed countries since the 1970s. It is a non-thermal process by which the wet coatings are converted into 100 per cent solid coatings by polymerisation or cross-linking by exposing them either under an electron-beam or an ultra-violet radiation.

Public causes, private funding Fifty villages around Dhaka in Bangladesh are now in touch with the outside world. They have recently acquired cellular phones. GrameenPhone, a non-government organisation's project in the country, has ensured that these villages are connected for basic communication. And Iqbal Qadir, finance director of GrameenPhone, says the rest of the villages in Bangladesh will be similarly linked up in the next five years. Circumventing land lines and hence the delays in putting a communication system in place, GrameenPhone has definitely succeeded in this unique experiment. An interesting aspect of the project is that it was funded largely by private agencies -- it is 51 per cent owned by Telenor of Norway, Grameen Telecom holds 35 per cent, Japan's Marubeni 9.5 per cent and Gonofone of the US 4.5 per cent. Sourcing private funds for public projects is gaining ground the world over. In India too, a recent endeavour got encouraging response. In January this year, the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation floated India's first public issue of municipal bonds to raise Rs100 crore. The purpose: to modernise its water and sewerage system. Municipal commissioner B.K. Sinha recalls that the bond issue was oversubscribed. ``We received tremendous public participation in building better roads, and ensuring adequate water supply and effective fire-fighting facilities for the city,'' he says. Rio de Janeiro has conducted similar exercises. Luiz Villela, financial and economic advisor at the city's municipal finance secretariat talked about similar successes in attracting large-scale private funding for public projects. The experience, recounted at a two-day World Times (publishers of WorldPaper) International Inquiry -- Enabling or Enslaving: Money Matters and the Information Imperative -- held in Delhi late last month, highlighted the realities of today's funding of public projects. With national and trans-border public funding agencies finding it increasingly difficult to finance sustainable social development across the world, private funding agencies, particularly venture capitalists, are expected to play a larger role in the years ahead. The seminar combined the issue with that of the information revolution. The global summit examined the impact of both information and capital flows on nations, enterprises, and communities. The inquiry was held in association with ATT, State Street, United Nations Development Project (UNDP), and Nasscom, with Business India as the media sponsor. In fact, World Times has recently devised a Wealth of Nations Index (WNI), measured in terms of a set of economic, information, and social indicators. Wiford Welch, director of global research, World Times, presented the WNI at the seminar. ``Gross domestic product (GDP) and gross national product (GNP) only measure activities which involve exchange of money. However, future wealth of a nation will depend on its ability to take advantage of the information revolution,'' he explained. Viewed along these lines, Taiwan, Israel, Czech Republic, South Korea, and Malaysia occupy the top five slots among 40 countries worldwide. The common factors binding the top five countries are: export-oriented market economies, relatively limited natural resources, and small populations. The Indian government is planning initiatives in the area. In his inaugural address, Union minister for power Rangarajan Kumaramangalam confirmed the government's commitment to information technology (IT) and revealed that India's administration was planning to provide an Internet connection in every school across the country. Kumaramangalam said since the service sector had come to contribute a predominant share in the national economy, it was certain that IT will play a crucial role. With emphasis on measuring wealth creation on the basis of economic, information, and social indicators, it becomes imperative for nations to allow free flow of capital and labour. Ashok Advani, publisher of Business India, said such freedom does not exist. He pointed out that developed countries like the US are actually restricting the free flow of capital and labour to further their own interests. ``A foreign national cannot buy out an American or a US-registered company unless he or she is an American citizen,'' said Advani. The free flow of labour, a factor crucial for wealth creation besides capital, is further hindered by the prevalent visa system, he added. Reducing barriers in wealth creation and involving private agencies in the process definitely appears to be the way to go.

ON May 17, the top brass of India's defence and atomic research released a video film of the nuclear blasts set off earlier in the week. The clip was shown by most international television channels that evening, and experts were called in to comment on what it revealed of the tests. What they missed was the strain of a song in the soundtrack. Few outside the Indian subcontinent would have been able to tell that the song was bande mataram, a patriotic hymn from the 1882 novel Anandamath by Bankimchandra Chatterjee, a pioneer of modern Bengali prose as well as of the nationalistic discourse of colonial Bengal. At the same time, most Indians, and not a few in Pakistan and Bangladesh, will have recognised the tune. The song, written in a strange mixture of Bengali and bastardised Sanskrit, was set to music by the poet Rabindranath Tagore, and for a while it was India's national anthem although seldom sung on State occasions. Muslims resented its Hindu imagery, and it was replaced (State records say ``supplemented'') by the other Bengali song that the world knows as India's official anthem, one for which Tagore wrote the words as well as the score. Bankimchandra was an immensely learned man and an astonishingly complex thinker. One of the first batch of graduates from the University of Calcutta, he served as a civil magistrate in colonial Bengal. After a minor novel in English, he went on to fashion, almost single-handedly, the language of modern Bengali prose fiction. He also wrote satires and essays on theology, history, literature and politics. The strange synthesis of ancient Eastern learning, European Enlightenment philosophy, and the sociology of Comte and Spencer which marked the nationalist discourse in late 19th-Century Bengal owed an enormous lot to this one writer. It might seem that the makers of the televised text of the blasts cared little for this context or for that in the novel in which the song appears. They were splicing on to a documentary footage, to a trace of ``real'' life, the affective charge of a piece of imaginative writing which had become, since the first nationalist ripple in 1905, the slogan of patriots and martyrs. It was planted as an interpretant with an instant affective reference, not unlike the canned laughter in sitcoms or the Mozart phrases in health food ads. Sadly, the image-makers seem to lack the cultural innocence of the vulgar. Anandamath tells the story of a band of political ascetics who had led an uprising against the Muslim rulers of Bengal in the 18th Century. The setting offers Bankimchandra the scope to formulate an idea of the nation state and of resistance in which the Hindus were the natural heirs to the pre-Muslim empires. The song speaks of 70 million sons of the mother, and statistically this count should include Muslims. The song thus carefully reinvents the idea of a composite nation, and co-opts Muslims as part of a predominantly Hindu idea of nationhood. That idea is defined in opposition to British occupation although the story is presumably about Muslim oppressors. One of the ascetics in the novel shows a novice three images of the goddess - the mother as she was in the past, the mother as she is in the present, and the mother as she will be in the future. The icons are three aspects of shakti, or the female divine principle, which Hindus worship in images such as Durga and Kali. What emerges from this unorthodox transformation of Hindu iconography is what one recent critic has called a Durkheimian goddess of social cohesion, a mother who is fertile, resplendent and comforting, a fallen deity awaiting resurgence through the heroic sacrific of her sons. The appeal of this goddess for political ascetics deprived of physical resources of struggle under colonial rule is easily understood. Its import was not lost even on the imperial secret service which saw the song and the novel as a source of dangerous inspiration for terrorists in later decades. Outsiders would find the import of all this for the recent nuclear blasts less easy to follow. The recent tests were codenamed Shakti 98, the Sanskrit word meaning the female principle in the cosmos, the consort of Siva the destroyer, as well as energy and power. Already there are extremist political groups talking of constructing a shrine or shaktipeeth at the blast site, which would be one added to the 52 centres of pilgrimage thus known over which the dismembered body of Sati, another mythical incarnation of shakti, was supposedly scattered by a frenzied and mourning Siva. It is not just coincidence that the first three blasts took place on the birth anniversary of the Buddha, the original apostle of non-violence who had challenged brahminical orthodoxy in northern India. The major Hindu nationalistic party in power today used, with a fine eye for irony, the same coded message to inform the Prime Minister's Office of the blasts' success that had been used by their secular rivals after the first test in 1974. The message read, ``Lord Buddha smiled.'' The choice of the tune on the soundtrack had thus the function of jogging the collective memory of a nation forged under the sign of shakti during the incipient phase of a militant Hindu nationalism which the present rulers of India are unembarrassed to claim as their historical legacy. Aurobindo Ghosh, the leader of the early terrorist resistance in Bengal, wrote in 1905: ``For what is a nation? What is our mother country? ... It is a might Shakti composed of the millions of units that make up the nation ... The Shakti we call India ... is the living unity of the Shaktis of three hundred million people ...'' The clever conflation of the senses of shakti as mother goddess and as power or energy was one which had sought to unite a ``nation'' ridden with contradictions. The conflation is the same as that which the present ruling coalition seeks to exploit in the text of the blast remixed for the teletechnomedia. Such methods are not the monopoly of any particular ideology. A little over a decade back, Satyajit Ray, in his film version of Tagore's novel Home and the World had used the slogan bande mataram as part of a musical motif to signal all that was destructive and exclusionist in the ``nationalist'' movement of 1905. Destruction and exclusion in the name of nation, as Tagore and Ray would have agreed, can still find plenty of uses for other people's words and other people's tunes. The irony of that exclusionist enterprise was brought home just the other day as Pakistan first detonated five nuclear devices in pyrrhic answer to the ``Hindu bomb''. Semantic limits are known to adjust themselves to political boundaries. How many, given the gruesome history of India's partition, would care to recall that the Muslims of undivided India were taught to claim Bankimchandra's song as their own? And who would have thought the song could be made to indigenise a technology which by necessity must remain international? Last year, a Japanese multinational recording company released a hit album by one of India's most talented composers, A.R. Rahman. Rahman is a recent convert to Islam, but he celebrated the golden jubilee of India's independence by a pop rendering of a rewritten version of bande mataram. The promotional video of the song shows Indian villagers on camels and elephants converging to receive the national tri-colour lowered from an army helicopter. It is a complex image of a superceded and dismembered nation, and its superceded anthem, reclaiming their place in history through the high-tech achievements of its scientists and techno-pop composers. However transparent, this was perhaps less cheap than the slogan jai vigyan (victory to science) that the Indian Prime Minister coined during his visit to the blast site. Is there a lesson in all this for literary theory? The use of the song on the soundtrack reminded me of the conclusion of Anthony Burgess' novel End of the World News, where we see a group of privileged humans, or rather Western humans, leave the destroyed planet on a spaceship stacked with provisions for an indefinite period. The ship zooms into orbit while a recording of Mozart's Jupiter Symphony is played for those on board as a token of the highest cultural achievements of the ruined civilisation they leave behind. What `meaning' could we salvage for this apocalyptic version of a text spinning endlessly in a context-free orbit? Surely such an effort would involve the memory of what other people had tried to say in another time and place as much as what the text could say only to us, the survivors on board? Surely, it would be justified as much by reconstructed histories of intention as by contingent circumstances of reception? There is just so much we have the right to do with other people's words. Fixing the referent may be a more important condition of freeing the meaning of texts than a blind celebration of the unchecked exorbitance of language. When the sound of a fiddle is added to a videotape of Rome's destruction it is dangerous to be seduced by the endless possibilities of relevance one could invent for Nero's score. For, as we have recently learnt in India, a song celebrating the beauty of a piece of our planet can make us feel tearfully proud even as we acquire the means of destroying it.

New bars on bills In Taratola, south Calcutta, working hours have become a lot less stressful for employees of the Calcutta Electric Supply Corporation (CESC). Early last year, this R.P. Goenka-owned company decided to introduce bar-coded bills, the first time ever for an Indian utility. As hoped for, this minimised keyboard entry and reduced errors, delays, and long customer queues. Says Samiran Ghosh, CESC's deputy general manager (treasury and payroll administration): ``In this office we cater to about 8,000 people daily. Earlier, it took the whole day to accept payments. Now we wrap up by the close of banking hours (3 pm).'' Of the CESC's 35 offices in Calcutta, 10 already have all the infrastructure in place. That is, hardware like a point-of-sale (POS) computer (costing Rs1.5 lakh) at the cash collection point, together with a scanner and a printer (for issuing receipts). These in turn are connected to the company's billing server, which keeps customer records. With a total investment of about Rs5 crore, the benefits are immense. As the bar code contains the consumer number and the amount paid, this data flows from the POS to the centralised billing centre, where ledgers can be updated immediately, thus cutting down the payment-to-reconciliation cycle. Though several utilities use electric cash registers, this does not enable online data transfer. Multiple entries leave ample scope for mistakes. In fact, most utilities have had to create a ``suspense account amount'' for money that lies idle due to the inability to reconcile payments. Taking its cue from CESE's experience, the Mahanagar Telephone Nigam Limited (MTNL) in Delhi and Mumbai also recently opted for bar-coding. Beginning last year, this government-owned telephone company has been issuing only bar-coded bills and has installed about a dozen POS machines in both metros. ``We have a total of 200 collection points and hope to put up machines at almost 80 of these in the next three months,'' says T.R. Wadhwa, general manager, MTNL, Delhi. In Mumbai, one of the company's nine area offices has been wired up. Since the infrastructure is not completely in place, all bills also carry all the information contained in the bar code separately. The need for efficiency has always existed. Says Tanmoy Chakrabarty, country manager (POS) for Siemens Nixdorf Information Systems: ``Most utilities are increasing their subscriber base by at least 10-15 per cent annually. There is an urgent need to enhance customer satisfaction and to streamline revenue collection management, especially as government subsidies are reducing.'' Siemens Nixdorf has been a part supplier to both utilities. And now, Delhi Vidyut Board, BEST in Mumbai, and the telephone companies in Calcutta, Chennai, Bangalore, Ahmedabad, and Secunderabad are also reported to be considering a switchover. But like most automation plans at age-old companies, the transition is not entirely seamless. At CESC, for instance, there has been some employee resistance on account of fears that it may result in staff retrenchment. ``It will create some people surplus at our collection centres, but they will all be gainfully employed in the company,'' stresses Ghosh, who has a target of March 1999 to complete the programme. With most other utilities still government-owned, cutting through the bureaucracy may take longer.

Study finds dementia in most 100-year-olds AP Science Writer
By MALCOLM RITTER
TORONTO (AP) _ A new study suggests if you make it to age 100, you can expect to leave a good chunk of your mental abilities behind. Dutch researchers tracked down every centenarian in three towns and found at least 12 of the 17 were moderately to severely demented, and three more had mild dementia. They weren't able to test the two others. Not one of the tested participants who was capable of conversation could draw a clock face that indicated a given time. The results are gloomy, said Dr. Ben Blansjaar, who presented the study Wednesday at the annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association. He said that he suspects the findings will apply to American baby boomers when they, too, reach 100, but that medications might help. An American expert said he believes the finding reflects a bleak truth about extreme old age. But others had doubts. And nobody has a solid answer for how common dementia is among centenarians. Finding out is important because centenarians are a rapidly growing group, and planners want to know what their health care needs will be. In 1995, the United States had about 45,000 white citizens age 100 or older. By the year 2050, that figure will grow to 607,000. Among blacks, it is projected to grow to 116,000 from 7,000. Researchers are just starting to look at the mental status of the oldest of the old, those 85 and above. One big question: ``If you live to be an old enough age, will everybody become demented? We really don't know,'' said Neil Buckholtz, chief of the dementias of aging branch at the National Institute on Aging. Blansjaar is a psychiatrist at the St. Joris Gasthuis psychiatric hospital in Delft, the Netherlands. He and colleagues found all the centenarians in three towns with a combined population of 250,000. The group they identified had an average age of 101, and 15 of the 17 were women. Five of the centenarians examined were in an almost vegetative mental state. Of the 10 others, only one knew the year, month, date and day of the week. Only two could adequately explain what two out of three familiar proverbs mean. Still, the woman who scored best on a battery of tests ``would have fooled everyone who isn't experienced in the diagnosis of dementia,'' Blansjaar said. Buckholtz said the Dutch study is too small to give a reliable estimate of the prevalence of dementia among the very old, and it's not clear whether the numbers would apply to other populations. He said that he knows of unpublished research that suggests 20 percent to 30 percent of centenarians are demented, but that there are no solid figures.

World Cup qualifiers draw 0-0 in unattractive exhibition
EDS: UPDATES with lineups.
CRETEIL, France (AP) _ Fellow World Cup qualifiers Mexico and Saudi Arabia played to an unattractive 0-0 draw Wednesday, with North Americans having most of the possession and the Saudis the better scoring chances. Playing before a crowd of 5,000 in a small venue, the Saudis opened the game with an opportunity in the first minute when Khalid al-Muwalid shot wide from one yard. And in the 22nd, Sami al-Jaber couldn't head a ball from good position, with Mexican goalkeeper Osvaldo Perez beaten. Luis Garcia troubled the Saudis the most, but failed on three chances. He shot high from 10 yards in the first half and wasting two more opportunities in the second. On the first he shot wide after receiving a pass from Luis Hernandez and was blocked by Saudi Mohammed al-Dayea. Mexico used an experimental lineup in which Garcia started up front along side Ricardo Pelaez while regular strikers Hernandez and Cuauhtemoc Blanco played wide midfield. The experiment didn't seem particularly successful, but Mexican coach Manuel Lapuente said he was ``satisfied'' with his team's performance. ``We made several changes in our lineup and played well at the end,'' he said. ``During the World Cup you'll see a very different team. Against South Korea (Mexico's first opponent) you'll see the result of our job.'' ___ Lineups Mexico: Oscar Perez, Isaac Terrazas, Raul Lara, Joel Sanchez, Salvador Carmona, German Villa, Marcelino Bernal, Luis Hernandez (Jesus Palencia-69) , Cuauhtemoc Blanco (Jesus Arellano, 69th minute), Ricardo Pelaez (Ramon Ramirez, 52nd), Luis Garcia.
