IN his Foreword, Rehman Rashid is quite generous in his praise of the three youngish writers whose essays are collected in this book. In fact, he positively gushes as he ends with the following line: ``Personally, I think they're quite wonderful.'' It must be difficult to write a foreword for a book like this. You are forced to say nice things about all three writers and you must choose your words carefully so as not to appear to favour one over the other two. I must say Rehman's Foreword is a peerless specimen of diplomatic nicety. He has nice things to say about all three writers. His reference to Stothard's ``iron-fisted political consciousness'', Kam's ``velvet-gloved, golden-hearted social commentary'', and the ``precocious'' and ``peerless'' ease of Amir's prose, highlights their respective strengths, and indeed, nicely summarises the essential qualities of each writer. On the other hand, the obligation to be equally nice to all three writers has led Rehman to generalise in a way that glosses over their strengths and weaknesses, especially the latter. A reviewer fortunately does not have to labour under such an obligation, and I can, for example, point out that the following passage appears to me to describe not all three writers, but just one of them: They all write very well; these pieces sparkle with literary felicity and thoughtful craftsmanship. Yet, these skills are rarely indulged to the point where style outshines substance. I am, of course, referring to Amir. Amir's prose sparkles; that of the other two writers do not. It's as straightforward as that. Both Kam and Stothard have done themselves a great injustice by allowing their pieces to appear in the same volume as Amir's. Their weaknesses stand out in starker relief when their pieces are put beside Amir's, and their strengths are overshadowed by the overwhelming burst of energy that characterises Amir's writing. Stothard's essays, for example, are marked by a strong sense of commitment towards her subject. If you were to read them on their own, with nothing else coming before or after to influence, however slightly, your impression of them, you might think her writing sincere, down-to- earth, committed, and even passionate, on occasion. Put beside Amir's pieces, however, you cannot help but think how stodgy her prose is in comparison to Amir's fluent writing. You can't help but think that she tries too hard, that she belabours her point, that she loads her prose with too much unnecessary baggage. This baggage sometimes comes in the form of extended allusion to literary texts. In fact, you would hardly call them allusions, for what you get are synopses of large chunks of various texts. In `Law and Order', for example, where she makes a very cogent point about abuse of power and perversion of justice, she gives you a description of the character of Angelo, from Shakespeare's play Measure for Measure, and holds him up as an example of someone who abuses his position of authority. Not only do you get two whole paragraphs given over to this treatment of Angelo, you get in addition one footnote telling you that Measure for Measure is one of Shakespeare's later plays, and that it is usually grouped together with three other plays which she proceeds to list. Finally, she supplies you with the date of the first performance. She also quotes four lines from the play and you get another footnote telling you where exactly in the text they come from. Shakespeare turns up again in `Umno the Bard', which is little more than a list of Shakespeare plays and characters and brief synopses of three plays. Take `Hope Hypocrisy' as another case in point. The piece begins with a description of the subject matter and theme of F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Great Gatsby and the writer goes on to attempt to establish parallels between the novel and contemporary Kuala Lumpur. You never lose sight of the novel and the whole piece could possibly have passed off as a Sixth Form or even an undergraduate essay on The Great Gatsby. This all smells very fishy and appears as if the writer is using all these opinion pieces as so many excuses to fob off some `literature' on you, or, worse, to educate you. The writer sometimes shoulders her literary and intellectual baggage in a more subtle, but perhaps equally uncomfortable manner, at the verbal level. In a piece talking about the possibility of an Islamic Renaissance in Malaysia, she points to positive signals put out by the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister in two separate speeches and then concedes that ``two speeches do not a renaissance make''. There is an uncomfortable marriage here of the traditional maxim -''two wrongs do not make a right'' - and an inversion of word order (putting the verb last) which used to be common in poetry and which is still sometimes used as a means of making something sound grand. What you sense here is not style outshining substance, but style flopping on its belly. Amir sometimes gets dangerously close to letting his style eclipse his substance but let's see what happens when he lets a literary echo slip into his prose. In a piece about journalistic sycophancy, he refers to the Prime Minster as ``the voice that launched a thousand editorials''. Now, this is a direct allusion to a line from Shakespeare's contemporary, Christopher Marlowe, referring to Helen of Troy as the cause of the quarrel that led to the launch of ``a thousand ships'' headed for the siege of Troy. You don't of course need to know any of this to understand the phrase as Amir has it in his piece or even to appreciate the humour. At the same time, the humour deepens for you if you notice the mock-heroic discrepancy between Helen and Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad as well as that between the thousand ships laden with war-hungry Greek warriors and the thousand sycophantic editorials. In complete contrast to Stothard, Kam travels light. In the first place, he does not deal with issues nearly as weighty as those which Stothard likes to sink her teeth into. With the exception of two pieces near the end, all the pieces of his which appear in this book were first published in Men's Review and Day Night, which presumably have fewer intellectual pretensions than The Sun, in which all but three of Stothard's essays first appeared. You do indeed sense the touch of a velvet-glove in most of Kam's pieces, but at the same time, you will also realise after reading a few of them that it is not so much society that he is caressing with a velvet-gloved hand, but himself. What comes through in these pieces, once you get over the disarming effect of the mildly bluff manner and the coy prose, is the overwhelming sense of someone trying to foist not his intellectual baggage on you this time, but himself. He goes on about his insecurity over his spotty education; he talks about his imminent 30th birthday the way Madonna, say, might talk about her impending menopause; he talks about his father; he tells us what he would do if he were Prime Minister; he talks about his mother's attempts to marry him off. The most interesting of Kam's pieces in this volume are the very two that come near the end of the book and, as it happens, it is in these two pieces that you would find those rare occasions where he stops caressing Kam Raslan for a bit and reaches his velvet-gloved hand out to stir things up in the world at large. Both, we are told, have not been previously published and one of them, a footnote informs us, was ``spiked'' - newsroom jargon for copy that has been rejected. Innocent as this piece may seem to be to unreformed liberals like you and me, it is quite obvious why the editor shied away from seeing this go to print: it takes a mildly ironic look at the Internal Security Act. The other previously unpublished piece is a series of loosely connected reflections on the four days the writer spent in a police lock-up. There is no indication in the piece as to the occasion behind this extraordinary event; not even a hint in a footnote. Clearly, one last coy gesture to end a whole string of them. Stothard however writes about what is presumably the same event in an article conveniently placed a dozen pages prior to Kam's and a comparison of the two shows up the different qualities of the two very nicely. Stothard begins her piece with a stark account of the demonstration organised by 600 men against APCET II, an NGO seminar on the East Timor issue held in Kuala Lumpur in November 1996 and her arrest along with other participants of the seminar. Yes, the very event which sent shudders down the spine of unreformed liberals like you and me. Her spare prose here and the starkness of her account brings out the dark irony of the situation very nicely. The rest of the piece is a reflection on the event. She draws parallels between the 600 men calling themselves Barisan Bertindak Rakyat Malaysia and the Nazi youth movement and Mao's Red Guards and then quotes at length from a German intellectual who was harassed to his death by Hitler's secret police. Of course, you get a proper footnote here documenting the source of the quotation. Her references to Nazism, the Red Guards and Walter Benjamin take up more than half the article and in my opinion overwhelms the piece. The chilling point that she makes about the spectre of extreme right-wing forces rearing its head in this country loses its force under the weight of all that intellectual baggage, and all the verbiage spent in filling in the historical background for her readers. Not to be left out, Stothard lets us know in a footnote that this piece was ``spiked'' by two publications before Aliran published it. Amir Muhammad has no ``spiked'' article to offer us in this volume but he has absolutely no need to wear this badge of honour. He reaches such outrageous heights in the pieces here (he has a foolhardy editor perhaps?) that only a very obtuse person would question his credentials. In contrast to the intellectual and literary baggage which overwhelms so many of Stothard's pieces, you will find bits of popular culture, current affairs trivia, bons mots or just plain wickedness strewn artlessly all over Amir's pieces. Unlike the rather woolly social consciousness that occasionally comes through in Kam's pieces (when he's not talking about himself that is), both Amir and Stothard make very cogent, often hard-hitting and usually definite statements about politics and society. The difference between Stothard and Amir lies in the fact that the latter is completely at ease with his medium and effortlessly bends his prose to serve his purpose, while the former gets too involved with her prose and lets her knowledge of weighty things overwhelm her subject.

The smart option A growing industry dependent on emerging markets doesn't sound very promising, right? Wrong, say the major players in the nascent smart (or chip) card industry in India. France-based Gemplus India Pvt Ltd and $10-billion global utilities giant Schlumberger contend that markets in Asia and the Pacific are growing fast and that explains their entry into India. Gemplus set up a wholly-owned subsidiary last June, and is now poised to establish an RD centre at Bangalore and invest $20 million over the next three years. And by the end of 1999, Gemplus plans to set up a hi-tech smart card manufacturing facility. Says Philippe Carrere, director, ``The Indian market is definitely opening up to smart card products and we see increasing large-scale integration of this technology in applications such as telecommunications, health, transportation, and access control.'' Schlumberger, which entered the market earlier, set up a 100 per cent subsidiary in India in December 1996 for the smart card business. Schlumberger Measurement System India Ltd (SMSIL) focuses on electronic transaction products like smart cards, terminals, and complete systems. Says Deepak Ghai, director (business development), SMSIL: `` We set up an RD centre at Gurgaon in February 1997 and further investment will depend on requirements. We have projected a turnover of Rs25 crore for next year.'' The initial investment it proposes to make in India is $10 million. However, is the enthusiasm well-placed? A survey by Gemplus Technologies Asia last year showed that Asia accounted for just 14 per cent of the smart card business, while Europe and the Middle East accounted for 76 per cent. The figures, it says, will change drastically by AD 2003, with a 40 per cent share for Asia and 35 per cent for Europe. The number of smart cards is expected to go up from 600 million in 1996 to around three billion by 2000, and Asia's contribution is expected to be significant. And the main applications for smart cards are seen in telecom, banking, transportation, and healthcare. One market that has remained largely untapped is credit cards, where magnetic stripe cards still rule the roost. Says Ghai, ``Indian banks need to invest in the infrastructure for smart cards since there is a demand for efficient and convenient banking.'' The potential is huge. ``There are six lakh cards users and if all the magnetic stripe cards can be converted into smart cards, the market is substantial,'' comments an industry source. However, it should be noted that smart cards are in use in only a handful of countries in Europe, among them France and Germany. Smart cards emphasise convenience and security. ``It has the potential of a computer and is as innovative as the human mind,'' says one industry observer. They are being touted as an effective alternative to the magnetic stripe cards as they reduce the cost of communication (off-line transactions are possible), reduce bank fraud, and offer greater security. Magnetic stripe cards are currently more popular mainly because they are less expensive (industry sources say there is a difference of about Rs150 per card) and also due to lack of awareness about smart cards. In the meantime, however, the duo are waiting for some firm government policies on basic telecom services and the shift to smart cards in the credit card industry. Adds Ghai, ``We are also waiting for some pilot project to take off in the Indian market.'' Both companies are working on projects with local companies and are upbeat about them. Schlumberger is doing a project with Escorts Finance for developing E-cash, a prepaid card for departmental store Nanz's outlets and other merchants establishments. The company is also working on a pilot project with Verifone, the Reserve Bank, the State Bank of India, and Canara Bank at IIT Mumbai to educate them about smart card applications. Gemplus worked with Calcutta-based Elecom to launch a passbook application based on a microprocessor smart card. Says Carrere, ``This off-line solutions allows cardholders to withdraw money or make deposits at any branch in India. It enables banks to track transactions on the card.'' Gemplus is working on another major project with IIT Mumbai to develop an electronic debit card for E-purse applications. Canara Bank and SBI will be the issuers of this card. For the smart card providers, the challenges lies in the multiple applications of these cards, including utility payments and purchases of petrol or diesel. With the players confident that the market in basic services will open up this year, they feel things can only change for the better. GANGA SUBRAMANIAM

BC-Britain-Mechanical Elephant
Giant mechanical elephant will travel - for the right price
With AP Photos LON109, LON110
LONDON (AP) _ For those with eccentric taste in transport - or who can never remember where they have parked the car - an auctioneer is offering for sale a life-size mechanical elephant. The one and a half ton jumbo, powered by a 10-horsepower Ford engine, was built in 1949 as a fairground attraction for Blackpool pier in northwest England. It was designed to carry up to 12 children, and has three forward and one reverse gear. It's top speed is 12 mph (19 kph). Just to prove it is in working order, antiques dealer Emma Hawkins, 25, took the motorized elephant for a drive outside west London's Olympia exhibition center Wednesday, where it is the star attraction at an antiques fair. ``Wonderful, very comfortable, far more comfortable than a real elephant,'' said Ms. Hawkins said after clambering off the elephant. The 8 foot (2.4 meter) high, steel framed machine is covered in hide-like cloth and comes complete with flappable ears and resin tusks. Ms. Hawkins' father John bought the elephant from restorer Hew Kennedy last month, and wants to sell it for 100,000 pounds (dlrs 160,000). ``It is unique and it is wonderful but only someone who was rather eccentric would want to own such a thing,'' said John Hawkins. Kennedy agreed. ``Once you've got it going, what is the point in owning it? You would have to be quite deranged to own it,'' he said. (rs/eml)

KUALA LUMPUR, Tues. - Sixteen former workers of a golf club will receive an average of two months salary in addition to retrenchment benefits following the intervention today of Human Resources Minister Datuk Lim Ah Lek. The workers had brought their grievances to the minister's attention as they were unhappy at being retrenched by the management of Kuala Lumpur Golf and Country Club when it employed 40 foreign workers. The 16 laid-off workers who earned between RM550 and RM850 per month were employed as field workers. ``After negotiations, the KLGCC management has agreed to increase the retrenchment benefits by paying 25 days salary for each year of service for those who had worked less than five years and 30 days salary for each year of service for those with more than five years service,'' Lim told reporters. Under the Employment Act 1955, those working for less than five years should be paid 15 days salary for each year of service while those working more than five years must be paid 20 days salary for each year of service. ``I am very grateful to the KLGCC management for paying more than the statutory requirement. ``It did not take much effort for me to convince the management,'' he said, adding that they (the management) had cited the economic problems for the retrenchment. KLGCC is owned by Solarvest Sdn Bhd, a wholly owned subsidiary of Sime Darby Group. Later, Lim met the workers, among others, asking them whether they were interested to be reinstated. However, workers' representative V. Indrani said they only wanted higher retrenchment benefits and were not interested to be reinstated because some of them were old (above 50 years).

Sustainable art Raghu and Gopal live in Chikaldhara and Badvane tahsils of Madhya Pradesh, in an area that will be submerged once the Sardar Sarovar dam is built. Between them, Raghu and Gopal will lose 65 acres of land which provides them their livelihood -- they grow cotton, jowar, maize, sugarcane, and bananas on it. With a stay order from the Supreme Court, work on the dam is at a standstill. But the construction already stands 82 metres high, enough to cause damage to the nearby areas. During the monsoon season, the nearby areas get submerged up to five metres. When there is heavy rainfall and the Narmada river is in spate, things get worse and the villagers have to find shelter a kilometre away. The government is promising to relocate their families in Gujarat. ``But the land in Gujarat is not as fertile. The government has also said that there is enough drinking water and electricity for 40 million people in Gujarat, but no drinking water scheme has been finalised,'' says Raghu. The Narmada movement has been fighting against a big dam in western India. As a fundraiser for the people of the Narmada valley, the movement held an art exhibition in Mumbai recently. The proceeds of the sale are to be used towards development work in the Narmada valley and to help those who are affected by the construction of the dam. Over a 100 artists from all over the country participated in the exhibition. In fact the response was so good that four art galleries had to be commissioned for the exhibition. Inspired by the Narmada movement, well-known names such as Laxman Shrestha, Manjit Bawa, and Nalini Malini, to mention a few, are gifting their works for the cause of the environment. Not all have painted to the theme. While Anju Dodiya has painted a head, her typical style, husband Atul Dodiya has done a canvas aptly titled Crossing the Narmada -- 1930, a scene depicting Gandhi crossing the Narmada. The paintings are priced between Rs1,500 (Arpan Mukherjee and Suranjan Basu's lithographs) and Rs2 lakh (Gogi Saroj Pal's oil on canvas). BHAKTI CHUGANEE

JAKARTA (JP): State firm PT Krakatau Steel (KS) confirmed yesterday that the government had agreed to sell up to 51 percent of the company's shares to Netherlands-based Ispat International. But the company's executives said that they were not consulted about the deal. Krakatau Steel's acting president, Djoko Subagyo, said he and members of the company's board of directors and commissioners were only invited to attend the May 7 signing of the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the government and Ispat. ``Please note that we were there to witness the signing ceremony, but we, the board of directors and commissioners, never got reports on the deal, not even a copy of the MOU,'' Djoko told reporters, adding that the decision seemed ``illogical''. He referred reporters to State Minister of the Empowerment of State Enterprises Tanri Abeng, who signed the agreement, should there be more questions regarding Krakatau Steel's privatization. According to the MOU, the Indonesian government has agreed to sell 49 percent of Krakatau Steel's shares but will allow Ispat to buy up to 51 percent if the offer is attractive. The sales of Krakatau Steel's 49 percent will be worth about US$400 million, or half of the company's estimated assets of $800 million. The MOU also says that Ispat will complete all due diligence by June 21 and the binding and sales purchases agreement will be executed by June 30. It says Krakatau will not disclose any nonpublic information concerning the deal to a third party without the former's written consent until July 7. Krakatau Steel, the country's largest steel producer, is one of the seven state companies to be privatized by the government either through initial public offerings or private placement by inviting strategic investors. The company's former president, Soetoro Mangoensoewargo, who resigned from his job Monday, questioned the legitimacy of the MOU deal, which he called ``mysterious''. ``I was present at the ceremony. After signing the agreement Tanri pocketed the MOU and took it away with him,'' Soetoro said yesterday. ``Neither I nor (Krakatau's chief commissioner) Tunky Ariwibowo was informed about the deal, prior to or after the signing.I even got the copy of the MOU from someone else,'' he said. Both Soetoro and Djoko said there had not been any due diligence following the agreement signing. Soetoro said the MOU violated earlier strategic agreements about Krakatau's privatization. The government had previously planed to sell 25 percent to 30 percent of the company's shares during the first phase of privatization. After that, a further 15 percent to 19 percent of the shares were to be offered to the public, leaving the state owning the remaining 51 percent. Soetoro said that if Ispat owned 49 percent of Krakatau's shares, there would a new monopoly in the domestic wire rod market, as Ispat's fully owned local subsidiary, the Surabaya-based PT Ispat-Indo, is currently the largest producer of wire rods, producing 450,000 metric tons annually. If Ispat owns Krakatau Steel, which now produces 300,000 tons of wire rods a year, both companies' production would account for 80 percent of the domestic capacity. Soetoro also said he objected to the fact that Krakatau Steel was to fall into the hands of Ispat, which he called ``a company whose specialty is buying bankrupt companies''. ``Krakatau Steel has been performing well, and has not suffered losses since 1986,'' he added. Producers of nails, welded wires, iron wires and wire mesh told reporters yesterday they disapproved of Ispat's purchase of Krakatau Steel. ``We are worried that it will spur unhealthy competition, a monopoly in the wire rod industry for Ispat-Indo,'' said Supri Handono, the chairman of the association of smelting wire industries. The company expects its net profit to rise to Rp 200 billion from Rp 182 billion last year, and its sales to increase to Rp 3.5 trillion from Rp 3 trillion, due to a drastic rise in exports which now total 80 percent of the production.

Mexican newspaper runs interview with alleged kidnapper of 20 people MEXICO CITY (AP) _ Accusing his victims of greed, a man identifying himself as the kidnapper of some 20 people told a Mexican newspaper he had cut off his victims' ears and vowed he would never surrender. ``I believe I am going to hell,'' a man claiming to be Daniel Arizmendi said in a long telephone interview published Wednesday in the newspaper Reforma. The man gave details of Arizmendi's background to prove his identity. The federal attorney general's office said it had no immediate comment on the authenticity of the interview. Police across Mexico have been hunting for Arizmendi since they captured his wife, son and daughter in a May 21 raid on safehouses in Cuernavaca, 35 miles (60 kilometers) south of Mexico City. Some authorities have blamed the former Morelos state policeman for as many as 200 kidnappings in the past few years, but the interviewed man confessed to about 20. All victims were either released or killed and police say they have seized about dlrs 946,000 U.S. and 32 million pesos (dlrs 3.5 million) from Arizmendi's safe houses and bank accounts. In the interview, the man denied ``that I treated them badly, that I beat them.'' But did he cut off ears? ``That, yes,'' he said. ``Their relatives, in spite of having so much money, did not want to give it to me. It was like I told them: God is going to punish you for avarice,'' the man said. ``I believe I am going to hell, no? And the relative who did not want to give the money, how would you judge that person?'' The man denied prosecutors' claims that agents of at least four police forces were on Arizmendi's payroll. ``I swear that nobody ever protected me.... I don't trust anybody beyond myself and the people I invite to work with me. ... The government or some government agent or some judicial policeman? No. They would sell you themselves.'' The man claimed that officials were fabricating kidnapping charges against Arizmendi's relatives, though he admitted they helped him launder money and obtain false documents. ``I told them, `Look, take money, buy a house, go someplace I don't know because the day something happens to me with you, they are going to blame you','' the man said. The man said police had offered to free his family in return for his surrender. ``They are also kidnapping my family,'' he said. ``I kidnap for money, put pressure so they will give me money. They are putting pressure so that I will surrender. I take somebody innocent. They are also taking somebody innocent. We are the same.'' He said he loved his family but would ``definitely not'' surrender for them. ``If there is one thing I fear, it is prison and poverty. Death, no.'' Asked if he had a message for police, the man replied: ``I wish them luck and I hope that the day they catch me they detain me and kill me.''

JAKARTA (JP): The catalytic cracking unit of the state oil and gas company Pertamina's refinery in Balongan, West Java, is expected to resume operation early next month after almost a month-long stoppage. The residue catalytic cracking (RCC) unit, which produces liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and Premium, Super TT and Premix gasoline, ceased operation May 11 due to technical failures. Designed with a processing capacity of 125,000 barrels per day, has another production unit, the refinery has another crude distillation unit (CDU). This remains in operation to produce naptha, kerosene, automotive diesel oil and low sulfuric wax residue (LSWR). ``We hope the RCC unit will resume operation early next month,'' company processing director Samto Utomo told The Jakarta Post and Bisnis Indonesia. The US$2.4 billion Balongan refinery has attracted unwanted media attention due its repeated production problems. Its RCC unit is guaranteed by its designer, U.S. designing and engineering company Universal Oil Product, to be able to operate full time for two years before a 40-day break. But the unit has twice experienced mechanical failures over the past four months even though its last periodic break was in February 1997. Sources at Pertamina attribute the repeated failures to substandard construction. They said Pertamina officials used low quality construction materials but marked up prices to meet the project value of $2.4 billion. ``We hope the Attorney General's Office will investigate the corruption at the refinery,'' the sources said. They estimated the actual cost of the refinery at less than $1.9 billion. Minister of Mines and Energy Kuntoro Mangkusubroto has ordered Pertamina to conduct technical auditing of the refinery. Samto said Pertamina was currently reexamining the RCC unit's design together with Universal Oil and the British Petroleum.

WHERE is the market headed? How can we prepare to change with it to meet our customers' needs? These are arguably the two most vital questions for a business to answer and act upon. In today's business environment, it is vital to be able to anticipate trends correctly and consistently. Moreover, a business has to establish suitable procedures for handling them. Stand out and stay afloat. In Pathways to Agility: Mass Customization in Action (John Wiley Sons, 263 pages), John D. Oleson shows us how to deliver strategies for applying these concepts of agility. The first section, Industrial Direction - Agility and Mass Customization, goes into the history and background of agility. The author defines what he means by agility: ``the ability to respond with ease to unexpected but anticipated events''. He attempts to illustrate it in action in specific circumstances. He describes the necessary strategic changes to put agility and mass customisation into operation. Chapter 1 provides a fascinating historical overview of how humanity has evolved, and the part which agility has played. As we have evolved from hunter-gatherers to farmers to knowledge workers, so the ever-present uncertainty has shifted from nature's impact (notwithstanding El Nino) to market variations. Mass production technology lasted more than half a century, resulting in the highest productivity in the industrialised world. That was until Toyota's production system revolutionised the approach to manufacturing with what is now known as lean production. This took time to take root in the West, but still continues to be the wave of industrial improvement. Not for much longer, though. The next wave, according to Oleson, involves agility and mass customisation. Yet agility is not new - it can be seen in all stages of industrialisation, from the crafts worker to mass, lean and now custom manufacturing. In a way, we will be reverting to crafts workers, adapting products to customer requirements. And agility will continue to be key in the drive towards mass customisation. The author is adamant: ``This ability to agilely and speedily adapt the product to customer needs is a capability that must be developed.'' Why? ``The success of the firm is at stake so remedy must be swift.'' Oleson quotes Motorola as a company which realised early on the benefits of a shift to agility. It saw ``the shadow of the gallows'' lengthening. Now rapid change and six sigma quality are a part of its culture, as is training. Yet how many companies will be able to practise this? I recently queried a bill from a well-known service provider. I was told that there was only one customer service person who could deal with my enquiry, but that she was on M.C. When I called back later in the week she was on leave. Next time she had ``just stepped out''. (Don't you just love that phrase? It covers so many eventualities, from a trip to the loo to an extended breakfast.) Next time she was in a meeting with the CEO. I was left in no doubt that the CEO was more important than customers. When I did finally get to speak to her, my simple request for a refund was met with: ``It's not our company policy.'' This is not a company that responds with ease to the expected, let alone the unexpected. And it is not an isolated case. Customer focus and responsiveness? Fahgeddabardit. Agility? Fragility, more like. But Section 2, Operational Agility and Mass Customization, provided the key to understanding how to apply agility to an organisation's operations. Build the capability and the operational support to respond quickly to change. Central to this is the supply chain. But how does it operate, and what practices do you need to change to improve effectiveness? Optimise use of material, information and cash. What role does Oleson see for technology in all this? Integrated information systems - a vital element in operating an extended supply chain - is the subject of Chapter 5. We learn how electronic interchange along the supply chain allows it to operate as one entity. Chapter 7 is particularly valuable in demonstrating the support given by automation. Section 3 covers the needs of new processes, products and markets in the context of changing capability in the modern enterprise. Here it began to get too technical for me, so I skimmed onwards. The final section gets to the crux of the matter, that is pathways to agility and the change process, emphasising people. Even relationships, it seems, must be agile for a firm to function effectively. Drawing on the experiences of a broad variety of companies, Oleson succeeds in his intention of bridging the concept and the practice of agility in the industrial context. The pathway metaphor is very useful in following what an industrial firm should do to integrate agility properly into its activities. It helps to read the book with a view to how you would interpret the concepts in relation to your own company's processes and context. The principles apply to most situations, as the author says. Although he looks at manufacturing, the lessons are applicable to whichever trade we are in. Obviously, though, manufacturing managers and engineers will find these pathways of most value. All the same, I found some of Oleson's case studies, individual perspectives and benchmarks extremely interesting. The chapter on processes, for example, contains an account of how the German company Porsche used Japanese methods to become a world-class manufacturer of defect-free cars. Similarly, the chapter on products sets out examples of standards of customer satisfaction. These are standards which others will one day have to follow, e.g Levi Strauss and its personal fit jeans. And plenty more instances which held out a dream of customer service - involving employees, integrating computers, and including automation: ``Telephone communication is with people who truly are service oriented ...''; ``friendly and no-hassle service''; ``There is no question that these companies are working to have satisfied customers''. I awoke from the dream to the reality of the enraging ``service'' provider: ``She's - not - in. Call back later.'' Compelling and concise, however, Oleson is not. The dense text, overly- long paragraphs and uninspiring graphics see to that. He competently explains agility basics and, commendably, ends each chapter with a summary of what has just gone, and what will be following. However, ``This chapter discussed ...'' and ``The next chapter deals with ...'' are repeated ad nauseam. Top marks for agility in manufacturing industry, but not quite agile enough in writing for the general reading public. The second book under review this week is a veritable tome. Fifteen chapters and 520 pages make International MA, Joint Ventures and Beyond (John Wiley Sons) a formidable piece of work. Being a source of information on ``the globalisation of the deal process'' it is heavy content, heavyweight. Indeed, it is intended for corporate principals, legal and financial advisers, government officials, investment and commercial bankers, and business school professors. Authors David J. BenDaniel and Arthur H. Rosenbloom intend it to be a roadmap, and you don't have to read roadmaps from beginning to end. So, as I scanned the contents page I decided to look around `Human Resource Issues in International Mergers and Acquisitions'. In this chapter, Russell H. Demers cites the value of current employees' inherent knowledge, skills and expertise. What if, as a result of a merger, you lose their motivation and commitment? A terribly undervalued factor in the race to restructure. Demers argues in favour of involving the human resource team from the outset. What are the expectations for the venture? For change to meet business plans? For staffing needs? He looks at issues to consider in the pre-acquisition evaluation -issues which relate to the partnership, local and company culture, government regulations and availability of necessary infrastructure. He then goes on to discuss staffing strategy, compensation, and integration of personnel information systems. He finishes with a succinct round-up of support mechanisms - communication, training, acculturation and staff morale. As is so often the case, though, a degree of cultural bias prevails. For example, the guidelines for a post-transition assessment assume the merger or acquisition is between a United States and a non-US company. Also, a detailed checklist has ``pending lawsuits'' prominently featured as an issue relating to the target company. On the other hand, the final chapter, on post-merger integration, highlights cultural differences between the US and other cultures and how this affects management issues. The checklist, too, concisely encapsulates factors to consider regarding national and organisational culture. Apart from Human Resources Issues and Postmerger Integration, which are treated as ``Special Topics'', BenDaniel and Rosenbloom's contributors range over Critical Issues in Planning and Implementation, Valuing Companies and Negotiating Transactions, and Joint Ventures, as well as Legal, Financial, Accounting and Tax Aspects. Growing numbers of companies, including middle-market and smaller ones, are looking outward at transactions beyond their national borders. This trend will definitely continue. At the same time, the need to work through the complications and ``potential deal stoppers'' associated with cross- border transactions will become more of an issue. In helping readers around these pitfalls, this book proves to be the real deal.

THE Government may finance 60 per cent of the capital requirements of the Asset Management Company which will be set up soon to manage non-performing loans in banks and finance companies, Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad said. The Prime Minister said the Government expected the rest to be financed by the private sector. He said this in response to a question from the Press after speaking at a symposium on ``Revitalisation of the Japanese Economy and the Future of Asia'' at the Okura Hotel yesterday. Asked whether the Government would draw on taxes or Bank Negara, he said financing would ``come from the Consolidated Fund''. ``Anyway, we have some money,'' he said. On the possibility of raising part of the funds by issuing government bonds, Dr Mahathir replied: ``We have not decided on that.'' Earlier, during a question-and-answer session after his address, Dr Mahathir was drawn to the AMC when a participant asked him about Malaysia still looking East, lessons to be learnt from Japan's mistakes and the percentage of Malaysia's non-performing loans in June last year, just before the region's ``bubble'' burst. He was also asked about Malaysia's stand on recommendations of the International Monetary Fund for the troubled economies of East Asia. Dr Mahathir said in handling Malaysia's banking system problem, the country actually ``looked very far East'' to the United States given that Japan did not handle this problem very well. He said Malaysia decided to take the NPLs out of the system in the way the US did so that banks could get on with their operations. Dr Mahathir also said Malaysia did not do the same thing as Indonesia, which had to close 16 banks in compliance with IMF conditions. He said taking action against one troubled bank was not an isolated thing in a banking system. ``You mishandle one bank's problem and we will have a whole banking system problem.'' Dr Mahathir said in Malaysia's case, the Government took measures to prevent the collapse of the banking system. On Malaysia's seeming compliance with IMF policies, Dr Mahathir said: ``Frankly, we feel threatened'' and added that if it did not comply with certain conditions, then the country's currency would depreciate further. ``We try to follow (the IMF's conditions), but it is very damaging to us.'' Dr Mahathir cited having to increase interest rates, a standard formula for troubled countries, which could lead to companies going bankrupt. ``When companies go bankrupt, the Government will eventually go bankrupt because we depend on corporate taxes in order to sustain us. So while we do follow the IMF, we are very hesitant about going the full way.'' He said some IMF conditions, like opening up markets would hurt the economy and bring it to a standstill. Dr Mahathir said he understood why ``some people are now criticising the IMF'', adding that there was basis for fearing the ``medicine doled out by the IMF''. He remarked that although the patient was very sick and in need of medicine, ``some medicine would kill''. ``And I am speaking as a doctor,'' he said to applause. He was also asked where he derived confidence that an international financial system could successfully deal with the financial crisis in the region given his strong views about the IMF's prescription. Dr Mahathir replied that he got this confidence from ``history'' from the time after the Bretton Woods agreement was drawn up that helped regulate exchange rates which in turn helped countries like Japan and Germany rebuild and prosper. In the wake of this, the world economy prospered too as the exchange rates of currencies stabilised. ``That is until people decided to be more competitive and started to fiddle with exchange rates.'' He said it was ``most important'' to remove the ``very violent fluctuation in the exchange rate where a currency could move from 100 per cent devaluation to 600 per cent''. ``You become bankrupt. Do we want to bankrupt the world? Certainly not. If we can find a formula to reduce the volatility in the exchange rate, I am quite sure the world will recover.''

SANG TAHANAN (The Prisoner, 1997, 365 pages) appeared a week after its author, Abdullah Tahir, died in 1997. However, he managed to check the proofs, even help improve the cover. In this collection of 21 short stories, Abdullah reveals fragments of himself with wit, courage, even self-irony. In `Tokoh', he portrays a middle-aged literary activist who reluctantly accepts the status of tokoh that young people have bestowed upon him. Holding an administrative post at a university, he plans to write a massive memoir and a first-rate novel. So highly is he regarded that he is often swarmed with invitations to give ceramah, called to testify in court over copyright cases, interviewed for his literary judgment. Over time, his remarks show a discernible slant. He praises young writers whom he expects to praise him in return. This leads to a charge being thrown at him in one of his well attended ceramah by a resentful young scribe who also accuses him of failing to heed his own words of advice. Humiliated, the tokoh, who has written nothing in the last 20 years, replies that people should follow what he says, not what he has (not) done. And with wounded pride, he promises to write his great novel about the struggles of a family spanning three generations, something along the lines of Marquez's One Hundred Years of Solitude. However, upon retiring, the tokoh is at a loss as to what to do with his time. Restless, despondent, he drives around aimlessly, spends hours reading newspapers and watching TV. Still, he refuses to admit that his creative juice has dried up. The typewriter on his desk is a painful sight to behold. Once, after the subuh prayer, he is miraculously inspired and starts hitting the keys as ideas pour forth. He works so hard that he finally collapses due to exhaustion, compounded by the symptoms of the Dreaded Triple: diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure. Before he dies, he tells his story to someone who promises to write the masterpiece for him. `Terperangkap' exposes the world of unscrupulous publishing. A tauke relentlessly pursues a cikgu to produce a couple of bestselling manuscripts, to be published immediately, bound and printed in Singapore, quality guaranteed. The Cikgu is reluctant to commit himself because he is trying to finish a teenage love novel for another publisher who is involved in a project sponsored by the World Bank, of which 8,000 copies would be bought outright and distributed free to school libraries. The Cikgu has already finished three novels, 140 pages each, now in the hands of another publisher who is honest, clean, and who pays royalties promptly. He is also editing a book of stories by women which he hopes would be included in the World Bank project. And because he is an established writer, the Cikgu's books sell very well - KBSR, notes on required reading, textbooks, exercise books, collections of short stories, novels - bringing in so much money that he is compelled to hire an accountant to help him fill his income tax forms. Famous for producing pornography, the Tauke promises the Cikgu that he will print 10,000 copies of his novels. He has reprinted the Cikgu's books originally brought out by other publishers; one has gone through 14 printings. There is already a Standing Order for 5,000 copies. The Tauke insists that the Cikgu's books would be clean, a promise the Cikgu is sceptical about. A day before, the Cikgu had received an anonymous letter from someone charging the Tauke of swindling his stable of writers. Realising he is getting nowhere, the Tauke uses his good-looking secretary to deal with the Cikgu. Soon the Tauke gets the two manuscripts. Printed in Segambut on cheap newsprint, the Cikgu's novels have been mutilated with heavy sex scenes. Furious, the Cikgu rushes to the Tauke's office, ready to burn it down. But he is received by the alluring secretary whose job is to cool him down in the secret hideaway with a door remotely controlled. Pettiness in Malay politics catches Abdullah's attention. `Broker' tells of disagreement between Salim and Mat over whether the village should be levelled to make way for an industrial zone. Salim is in favour while Mat is not. By selling five hectares of his own dusun land, Salim makes tons of money. Mat has no land to speak of but his argument is that once a village is wiped out, there is no replacement. And what is a Malay without his kampung? At the warung, Salim would belanja the people from the nearby villages nasi lemak, roti canai and kueh-mueh to promote himself as a generous leader who can count on being elected to the branch committee of the ruling dominant party. Believing that Salim's money is haram, Mat joins a peripheral party, whose bosses swoop down from Kuala Lumpur to officiate the opening of a branch office in the village. With such backing, Mat calls a meeting that is well attended because on the agenda is the issue of how to become millionaire. As a middle man, Salim charges between two and five per cent commission on land sold to the Japanese and Korean multinationals. Soon he is the proud owner of the one and only Honda Accord in the village. Quietly Mat induces one Encik Wong to invest, becoming a broker who charges only 0.5 per cent. Many who have signed up with Salim leave him and deal with Mat instead. But in the end, a new Menteri Besar cancels the whole project, leaving everybody back in square one. A very complicated family relation is told in `Tukmak', about a pious old mother who knows the dispositions of her sons, daughter, in-laws, grandchildren all too well. Of them all, she loves Li the most, the son who is taciturn, dominated by a fiery wife Nik, a spendthrift with expensive tastes who is critical of other people's slightest indiscretions. When Tukmak's daughter, Yam, is about to have an operation, Tukmak is flown to Kuala Lumpur, bringing with her a sack of rice, a box of spices, a bundle of dried fish, 14 pounds of glutinous rice, to be served during the special kenduri to pray for Yam's recovery. Upon arrival at Yam's house, Tukmak notices that no one is waiting to greet her. She bears the slight with motherly dignity. Li and his wife Nik drop by only the day after. Arrogant, Nik does not even bother to ask how her mother-in-law is or shake her hands. Li wants to stay five minutes longer to perform his maghrib but Nik signals Li to leave immediately. At the gate, Tukmak hands Li one wrapper of his favourite marinated fish, and asks him to deliver another wrapper of rice to Aya, Tukmak's adopted son, who could only come in a day or two. Nik's reaction is that Tukmak favours Aya more than her own sons or daughters. Tukmak likes Aya because he is very respectful. During the last Ramadan, Aya presented Tukmak with a gold ring as a token of his love and loyalty. Tukmak was quick to let everybody know. Insulted, Nik gave only a piece of batik and 10 ringgit. After Yam's successful operation, Tukmak falls sick, and she lets on that her soul has already been knocking her gullet, ready to depart. `Dendam' is a surreal story about a murder in which the characters are named after their roles. The victim is Wanita Muda who soon changes to Wanita Mangsa, then there are the Penganu and Pencerita, the narrator. In between scenes, there are directorial commands: Cut. Retake. The author gets in the actors' minds and records the victim's final monologue as she studies the knife buried in her chest. The line between illusion and reality is obliterated. Penganu wonders if the victim is showing signs of narcissism, admiring the beauty of her own pain. Or could he himself be the next victim, the result of revenge. The narrative is far from clear: ``Tidaklah terfikir wanita Mangsa akan menggunakan senjata yang sama dan cara yang sama untuk pertama berlaku adil, dan kedua untuk membalas dendam, atau cara ketiga untuk membuat satu sejarah tragedi yang akan dikenang atau akan meniti dari bibir ke bibir generasi akan datang berabad-abad lamanya.'' Finally, the director reviews the film on the screen. He sees an endless stretch of blanks, and orders an immediate retake. Perhaps Abdullah is naughtily spoofing people who hold that reality imitates art. What is being imitated, or whoever is doing the imitation, doesn't matter, because in the end life is nothing, nada. `Sang Tahanan' is the mindless monologue of a remand prisoner mulling over the death of his lover. He addresses his perceptions of the events to the judge, the jury, lawyers, clerks, and other members of the court. He stands as the accused, his own defence lawyer, and his own witness. He claims that she is the one who is guilty of murder. Her weapon is this string of words: ``Tomorrow is today, actually.'' He argues that compared to the knife he had stuck in the woman's heart, her words are deadlier. He doubts there is justice in the world because he suffers more than she. His knife killed her instantly but the sting of her words stay. Pleading leniency, he claims to have had enough dignity to give her a proper burial, a factor the jury must consider before making the verdict. Many of these stories are hard to follow because the voice of the author and that of his characters are at odds. At times, the reader is unsure who is speaking. A thick fog of miscellaneous and unrelated details delays many endings. The impressive descriptions and tough prose are overshadowed by concern for atmosphere. Abdullah indulges in little diversions, useless anecdotes, unfocused dialogue. Things get repeated, too, due to verbal zealousness.

THE notion that ``West is best'' comes under question in Khadijah Hashim's 19th and latest novel, Mencari Azizah. Her premise of a young woman of mixed parentage who heads for America in search of her missing father, and her identity, is anchored in the culture of two continents. The divergent threads are then knotted with the challenges facing a woman careening towards the 21st century. The seed for Mencari Azizah was sown in Iowa in 1995, during a three-month writing fellowship. Khadijah's stay opened the window to life as it is lived on the street, not the screen, and made her rethink values expounded by the likes of Dallas, Dynasty and Chicago Hope. ``Asians' view of life in the US is coloured by television and the movies. In reality, there are good and bad things which we can imitate or reject. ``Our mistake lies in assuming that everything from the West is good. So much so that we are ashamed of what we have, and will not admit it could be better than theirs. We should not hesitate to say - `This is our heritage. It's good and we appreciate it.''' On this note, Khadijah feels that the emphasis on buying local should extend to Malaysian literature. Readers hesitate to spend RM10 on a book by, say, a local laureate, but readily fork out double that amount for a foreign title, she observes. ``We need to change this attitude. A country's reserves and economic strength do not reflect how civilised it is. The better measures are the quality of its writing and the excellence of its arts and culture, which determine the identity of a race.'' Since Iowa, Khadijah has brought out a novel (Fasa Kedua) and a book of pantun (808 Pantun Baru), released under `K' Publishing. She is working on an expanded edition of the latter, to be called 1001 Pantun Baru. There are no deadlines for this author, who prefers to mull over images and meanings, giving them time to gel. This slow-and-steady approach applies to her research, which can stretch longer than the three months she takes to complete a book. ``I need everything to be there so I won't be stuck once I start writing.'' She also takes pains over authenticity, based on her belief that fiction must rest on fact to withstand scrutiny. ``For Mencari Azizah, I collected pamphlets on Iowa and Chicago, and information on ticket prices, places and distances. All these are important to draw people to a story. My books may be fiction but I take facts from here and there.'' Khadijah considers her job well done when readers ask, ``Is that a real story?'' On that basis, she does not place much store by what the literary critics have to say about her writing.

The tough measures that the RBI took to protect the rupee have been partially rolled back, bringing relief to bankers It was the 16th day of the first month of circa 1998. The country's apex banker, the redoubtable Bimal Jalan, made his toughest move to check the falling rupee. The Reserve Bank announced that the bank and repo rates would be hiked by 200 basis points each to 11 and 9 per cent, respectively. What's more, the banks' cash reserve ratio (CRR) requirement was pushed up by 50 basis points to 10.5 per cent. These measures managed to contain the rupee at Rs39 against the dollar. Though currency rates settled, bank chiefs were genuinely unsettled. For, the RBI's action caused yields on government securities to go up by over 200 basis points to considerably depreciating the banks' gilt investment portfolio. The RBI, for fiscal 1997-98, increased the banks' mark-to-market valuation of the statutory liquidity ratio (SLR) requirements to 70 per cent of their portfolio investments instead of 60 per cent a year back. Besides, on an aggregate year-end deposit of approximately Rs5,85,000 crore, an SLR provisioning of around Rs1,46,250 crore would have to be made. According to an estimate by I-Sec, the banking sector's actual SLR portfolio is much higher, in the region of Rs1,82,000 crore. As a result, banks, which were all set for windfall profits from this portfolio valuation till early December 1997, suddenly faced the prospect of a loss of over Rs 1,500 crore on gilts thanks to the rupee rescue operation. Says Ashish Pitale, who heads the fixed income research wing of ICICI Securities and Finance Company (I- Sec), ``The net increase in the banks' holding of government securities till 16 January was around Rs26,000 crore. While, for example, they acquired the ten-year government papers at a coupon rate of 10.08 per cent in October 1997, thanks to the RBI action, the yields firmed up to 13 per cent in January suddenly translating into a notional loss of Rs1,350 crore for banks. There was another Rs160-crore loss on account of depreciation in PSU bond investments of around Rs4,000 crore.'' The RBI governor justified the measures as necessary for protecting the rupee from the currency speculators, following the turmoil in South-east Asia. He promised that the measures were purely temporary in nature, to be rolled back once the storm in the forex market was over. And now that Jalan has kept his word to some extent, the banks suddenly find themselves once more in the black. After the rupee remained static at Rs 39 for three consecutive months, on 17 March, the RBI brought down the repo rate by one percentage point to 8 per cent. On 18 March, the bank rate came down by 50 basis points to 10.50 per cent. On 23 March, Jalan made his intentions clearer by reducing the CRR by 50 basis points in two phases to 10 per cent. While a 25-basis point cut will be effective from 28 March, the second tranche of an equal reduction will take effect from 11 April. Sudden gains The CRR cut increased the lendable funds in the banks' kitty by a total Rs2,600 crore. This, coupled with a lower repo rate, moved the yields on government securities southwards in the secondary market. And that is when the gilts portfolio began to appreciate. Bank chiefs, who sulked in January anticipating losses on their investments, turned euphoric on the last day of 1997-98. That the ecstasy will last long was confirmed when the RBI did not alter the list of gilts put on its purchase-sales window -- which is part of its open market operations (OMO) -- on 24 March. The yield to maturity (YTM) for the ten-year papers suggested that all the ten-year stock is likely to be pegged at around 12.15 per cent. Bankers say that the RBI gave two signals in the last week of March for a mark-to-market valuation. On 24 March, the RBI apparently decided that the OMO list would be kept unaltered till 31 March, which was a little surprising considering the fact that the first phase of CRR cut, effective from 28 March, would have released Rs1,300 crore in the banking system. And the RBI showed no intention of mopping this up. Secondly, on 26 March, the government privately placed Rs 6,000 crore worth of government stocks with the RBI. Six-year papers worth Rs4,000 crore were placed at a coupon rate of 11.57 per cent along with a ten-year paper worth Rs2,000 crore at a coupon of 12.15 per cent. ``Interestingly,'' says S.R. Kamath, deputy general manager, Securities Trading Corporation of India (STCI), ``the YTMs to both the papers fitted in the yield-curve announced on 24 March. That was a signal sent out by the RBI that the yields to the gilts on the OMO list were indicative of the valuation of banks' gilt portfolios. Says Pitale, ``If the YTMs indicated on 24 March are considered to be a benchmark for valuation, then the banks would stand to book a bumper profit of over Rs 5,100 crore in their gilt portfolio apart from a few hundred crores on account of other SLR securities.'' But banks take the RBI governor's year-end bonus with a pinch of salt as they feel that the apex bank is more concerned with the government's borrowing programme for the next fiscal than the banking sector. The RBI governor, bankers say, has been stingy while promising to roll back the stringent measures. According to the October 1997 Monetary Policy, the CRR should have been 8 per cent by 28 March, whereas it still remains as high as 10.25 per cent. Likewise, the bank rate was 9 per cent before it was hiked to 11 per cent, and despite a reduction it stands at 10.5 per cent. To top it all, the repo rate was at 5 per cent on 2 December, 1997 -- the actual period of commencement of the retrograde measures -- and it is 8 per cent now. ''This,'' according to a senior executive in a foreign bank, ''clearly shows that the measures were half-hearted.'' Although they have come as a blessing for the banks, the bottomline is that Jalan, in his bid to make the borrowing programme cheaper for the centre, is moving the rates down, according to some bankers. Says B.S. Raghutham, head of money market, Global Trust Bank, ``What is required at the moment is status quo before the new borrowing programme begins next fiscal. This will vindicate the RBI's position that the measures were purely temporary.'' Case for a CRR cut In the interim budget announced by Yashwant Sinha on 25 March, the Centre has programmed market borrowings of Rs 86,000 crore for 1998-99 vis-a-vis its actual borrowing of Rs 64,563 crore in 1997-98 against a gross borrowing target of Rs 55,899 crore. Moreover, the finance minister's announcement of increasing the expenditure on large infrastructure projects will only make funds for corportaes more scarce unless the RBI resorts to further CRR cuts. A quick calculation supports this. Aggregate deposits stood at around Rs5,05,000 as on 31 March, 1997, and is slated to be around Rs5,85,000 crore -- an estimated increase of Rs 80,000 crore. Even assuming that the deposits grow by an equal amount in 1998-99, the government's claim will be Rs86,000 crore, leaving hardly any leftover for industry. Explains Pitale of I-Sec, ``Last year, banks accounted for a major portion of investments in corporate papers. But the government's borrowing programme will take away most of the bank funds at low rates, which will result in another credit off-take problem unless the RBI undertakes a massive CRR cut.'' April is always the cruelest month for banks when the Centre kick-starts its market borrowing programme, taking away a huge chunk of its lendable resources. This year the banking system would be flush with liquidity, as apart from the Rs2,600 crore released on account of CRR cuts, a further Rs9,000 crore would move into the banks' coffers on account of CRR interest, treasury bills and government stock redemptions, and interest thereon. But all this is expected to be sucked away by the government's borrowing machine. Meanwhile, a section of bankers defend Jalan's cautious reversal of measures. The RBI has the task of containing the broad money supply (M3) growth rate at 15 to 15.5 per cent, which is hovering around 16 per cent in mid-March. Any further reduction in CRR in this fiscal will expand the M3, resulting in an upward pressure on the inflation rate. Even the RBI governor's attempts at raising money from the market at a low interest rate is justifiable as a high interest rate would only increase the repayment burden in subsequent years, says a senior official of a nationlised bank. Which means that Jalan, with all the control he enjoys over the economic future of the country, would have to ensure that he gives adequate support to industry and banks as well in fiscal 1998-99.

JAKARTA (JP): The Indonesian economy will continue to contract and will bottom-out this year before the first green shoots of the recovery spring up next year, but pre-crisis growth rates will not be recovered until 2002, economists predict. Mari E. Pangestu, executive director of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, forecast yesterday that the country's gross domestic product (GDP) would shrink by between 10 percent and 20 percent this year. The industrial sector is expected to contract by 10 percent to 12 percent this year, the service sector by between seven percent and 10 percent, while the agricultural sector is expected to grow by 0.5 percent. She predicted that the economy would remain stagnant next year while the country held a general election, and would register annual growth of 2 percent in 2000 and 4 percent in 2001. ``So, we need at least five years to return to the level real GDP was at in 1997,'' Mari said at a media conference on the economic outlook in the Pacific region held by the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council (PECC). Suhadi Mangkusubroto, a PECC economist, predicted that Indonesia's economy would contract by 4.5 percent and inflation would rise to 32 percent during this year. However, he said the effects of major political and social unrest or other destabilizing forces had not been included in the analysis and the forecasts were therefore no longer valid. The forecasts were last revised in March when Soeharto was still in power, he added. ``The situation now is much worse than a few months ago when the analysis was carried out. Therefore all of our forecasts are inaccurate. For the time being, we should rely on the Central Bureau of Statistics projections for growth and inflation,'' Suhadi said. The bureau predicted on Monday that the country's GDP would contract by 10.1 percent and inflation would soar to 80 to 85 percent this year. Raden Pardede, a senior economist with state-owned Danareksa Sekuritas, told The Jakarta Post yesterday that the bureau's projections for economic growth and inflation were still too optimistic. ``I think our economy could contract by as much as 20 percent this year with inflation surpassing the 85 percent level projected by the bureau,'' he said. He said the economy would continue to contract because levels of domestic and foreign investment were still declining. Domestic investment would continue to fall because of high interest rates and a decline in the savings rate to 18 percent from 30 percent two years ago, he explained. Foreign investment is continuing to avoid Indonesia because of the all-pervading uncertainty in the country. Raden said inflation could surpass the 85 percent level because the central bank would have to print more money, employers would face pressure to raise wages, their product prices would continue to rise and the rupiah would further weaken. Suhadi said the current situation resembled the dire economic circumstances of 1966/1967 after the fall of the country's first president Sukarno. ``It is very similar to the situation in 1966/67 when we could not finance our development programs. The government did not even have enough money to finance routine spending,'' Suhadi said. Luckily, he said, the government received soft loans from friendly countries to help see them through those difficult years. Suhadi suggested that the government work closely with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) so that the agency would quickly approve disbursement of loans to the country, which would in turn encourage friendly countries to grant Indonesia further bilateral aid. ``Only with foreign loans will the government be able to finance its operation, continue subsidies and stimulate the economy,'' he said. Miranda S. Goeltom, a Bank Indonesia director, agreed with Suhadi's suggestion and said the government would use some of the funds available to help existing businesses to expand.

TIMIKA, Irian Jaya (JP): Possibly, probably, maybe, perhaps and more such words and sentences that indicate anything but solid certainty. If you were to read an account on Irian Jaya's background, say, as a foreword to a more detailed essay on that part of the island of New Guinea, you would notice that it rather teems with such words: probably 200 languages; some 1,800 species of insects; perhaps most are barely unknown; maybe this, possibly that. Will Irian Jaya ever be fully revealed? Of course, but your guess is just as good as anyone else's as to when this will occur. A lot is already known about Indonesia's easternmost province, but there is vastly more that is not, and it covers practically every aspect of the place: flora, fauna, customs, people, their languages. Did you know that as recently as 1987 two never-before-known groups of people emerged out of isolation? Who is to say that these are the last ethnic groups in Irian Jaya to step out of the jungle? Yet New Guinea has not escaped the notice of the world outside. There exist accounts from the distant past of some of the products of the island such as seafood, medicinal bark, plumes of the birds of paradise and other things, which made their way to other parts of Indonesia as well as China and even France. But apart from a vague ``from the far east'', those on the receiving end could not be expected to have a clear picture of products' place of origin. Trade has been going on for quite a long time, as did some mixing between native Irianese and ethnic groups from other parts of Indonesia. But, by and large, the island remained an enigma for quite a long time. Gradually, however, the shrouds of mystery began to lift, not least because of the voyages from Western countries -- Portugal in particular --that started about halfway through the second millennium. The purpose of these voyages in Indonesia is well known: the Spice Islands. New Guinea then became a more concrete entity to these seafarers from Portugal (and later, the English, Spanish and Dutch), but though it loomed large in the region, attention was focused on a handful of minuscule spice producing islands, among others Ambon and Banda, located a stone's throw west of Irian. Sightings and landings were made by Portuguese and Spanish seafarers during the third decade of the 16th century, Dutchman Jan Carstensz sighted the snow-covered mountain range that runs through central Irian in 1632, and in 1770 Captain Cook's landing party at the Asmat territory ``was sent packing with volleys of arrows''. There was contact, but apart from the mingling in coastal areas with peoples from other islands, there seemed not to have been any deliberate move to occupy New Guinea. Attempts by the British and Dutch during the late 18th and early 19th century to establish a more permanent presence met with failure, but the turn of the century saw the beginning of just such a presence taking shape in the area. At that time there were three Western powers sharing the island, the Netherlands, Britain and Germany, so colonial politicking would certainly be a major consideration, more than whatever the island could offer for international markets. Kamoro Today numbering about 16,000, the Kamoro tribe occupies a portion of an area located more or less in the middle of Irian Jaya's southern coastal area, stretching about 300 km from Etna Bay eastwards to the Otokwa river. The river runs some 40 km east of the port of Amamapare, the exit point of copper, gold and silver concentrate mined by PT Freeport Indonesia Company. The area occupied by the Kamoro belongs to a larger group known as the Mimika. The tribe has had contacts with the outside world as far back as the 17th century but until missionaries arrived in the 19th century, these were far and few between. The missions were, at least during that era, the only established presence in New Guinea. Administrative order (i.e. the tools of Dutch, British and German colonial rule) came about during the first years of the 20th century, and helped intensify proselytizing activities. Some benefits may have resulted from time these activities, but they also brought about a far more serious consequence: the loss of many features of Kamoro culture and traditions, among others those connected with rites of passage. Longhouses, the traditional living quarters of the Kamoro, were destroyed and they were made to live in houses for individual families. Another highly developed talent of the Kamoro is wood carving, but this art, too, began to languish because of the bans imposed by missionaries, and later by government regulations after Irian Jaya became part of Indonesia. For much more than half a century, Kamoro art, culture and traditions teetered on the brink of extinction. But times change, and so did attitudes on the part of the missionaries and authorities. PT Freeport Indonesia, which operates in the area which includes the traditional area of the Kamoro, claims that reviving the culture of the native tribes in the contract of work area is part of the company's social development program. The company, a target of much criticism regarding its environment practices and relations with local communities, also claims it has to rely for its workforce on the tribes whose homeland lies in the company's area of operations. In fact, the company has reaped benefits from the knowledge of the Kamoro. When the environmental department was at a loss about how to stem subsiding of dikes and berms in the experimental ponds, it was the Kamoro who came up with the idea of using sago tree trunks instead. But more than any other activity, it is artistic expression that helps restore or rediscover one's cultural identity. Lately, there has been a wave of efforts to revive many aspects of native Indonesian artistic expressions, most prominent of which would be the series of recordings produced by the Masyarakat Seni Pertunjukan Indonesia (Indonesian Society for the Performing Arts) of the myriad variety of musical styles in this country. Assistance for this project came from the Smithsonian Institution and the Ford Foundation, whilst for the revival of Kamoro arts. PT Freeport Indonesia showed their interest in the project by organizing the first Kamoro Arts Culture Festival, that ran recently at the village of Hitipau, some 30 kilometers southwest of the town of Timika. Participants came from all 42 Kamoro villages in the area. A dance festival, canoe races and an art auction were the major programs of the festival. Canoes play an important part in the lives of the Kamoro whose villages are near either a river or the sea. The canoe has been and probably still is the most important mode of transport for them. Like the Asmat tribe, the Kamoro certainly do not suffer from a lack of creativity and imagination. At this stage the Asmat and Kamoro appear to be the only tribes that stand out as carvers, with the former enjoying wider appreciation around the globe since more than thirty years. But after this first Festival it will be only a matter of time for the art of the Kamoro to achieve equal prominence in as well as outside Indonesia.

OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso (AP) _ The Organization of African Unity on Wednesday appointed a seven-member panel to investigate the role of foreign powers and individuals in the 1994 Rwandan genocide. OAU Secretary General Salim Salim of Tanzania said the investigation team would also examine measures to prevent a re-occurrence of the massacres which resulted in about 500,000 deaths, mainly of ethnic Rwandan Tutsis. Tutsi rebels based mainly in Uganda won power in Rwanda in July 1994 and ended the killings, which occurred several months after a U.N. peacekeeping officer warned his superiors in a fax of the danger of massacres planned by Hutu extremists. OAU officials did not immediately provide details about the terms of the new investigation, which will be led by newly-retired Botswana president Ketumile Masire. France and Belgium have both been accused by Rwanda of aiding the architects of the genocide, and other Western powers have been charged with ignoring the massacres. Kenya and the former government of the late dictator Mobutu Sese Seko in Zaire, now Congo, have also faced accusations of harboring genocide suspects. It was not clear whether any of these countries would be under investigation from the OAU panel. The United Nations Security Council in April re-opened a 1995 investigation into alleged illegal arms sales to Rwanda, where sympathisers of the country's former military are believed to be fighting a low-level guerilla war against the Tutsi-led government. Also appointed to the OAU panel are former Mali president Gen. Toumani Toure; Algeria's ex-chairman of the International Court of Justice Mohamed Bedjaou; former U.N. official and Liberian presidential candidate Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf; one-time U.N. Development Program chief Lisbet Palme of Sweden; former Indian Supreme Court chairman H. Bagwati and UNICEF deputy chief Stephen Lewis of Canada. The investigation team was first suggested by Ethiopian Prime Minister Ato Meles Zewani in November 1997. A U.N. tribunal on Rwanda has indicted 35 people with genocide crimes. Rwanda, frustrated by the slow pace of the U.N. tribunal, has started its own trials of 125,000 suspects. So far, 144 of 337 convicted have received death sentences. (bro-gam/ids)
