IF my mother were ever to ask my brother to sweep the floor or have him scrub the bathroom, I know I'll have a heart attack. Yet, she will never hesitate to let me know that the laundry needs to be done, or that the table needs to be cleared. Unfair? I'm sorry, but that is the way life is like when you lack the ``Y'' chromosome. The biggest threat to gender equality, unfortunately, shows up worst in most maternal figures. I don't think I am the only female member of any family to feel this way. I am not a 16-year-old brat griping about having to do more chores than my brother. I am a young, professional adult griping about the problem of gender inequality that begins in the family unit. The girl child is raised to believe that if she does not learn to perform the household chores of cleaning, washing and cooking (we'd like to say that we don't do windows, but that's too much of a fantasy), then she isn't raised right. Sure, we get to go to school and come home with degrees, but we've still got to make sure there are no dirty dishes in the sink. I am not accusing my mother of making a Cinderella out of me (actually she can probably make two slender Cinderellas out of me!). My mother has a job and she still has to take care of the housework. Small wonder! Her mother raised her to endure the responsibility of keeping the house from falling apart, and if she were lucky enough to find a husband who could lift a finger to help - the Almighty be praised. Our male siblings are not really spared housework. It includes the occasional lugging of heavy furniture and weekly washing to the family car. And of course they have responsibilities. They involve making sure the computer, television, radio and other electrical equipment perform their respective functions satisfactorily (something, presumably, us technically-challenged females cannot comprehend). Again, male children are raised to lounge before the idiot-box or pursue their computer game fantasies while dinner is delivered right before their faces. After all, Daddy gets to do nothing... and still his plate is cleared for him when he leaves the dinner table. Perhaps this facet of life isn't apparent in families that have maids to take care of the chores. But then, isn't it up to the mother to make sure the maid does her job well? (The issue of the maid being female is, of course, something else we have to look into.) No, regardless of family and racial backgrounds, I have friends who agree with me that their brothers get away with murder while we are sentenced to hard labour. An ex-classmate of Indian origin, now with a law degree, had to help prepare dinner while her brothers played football. A close Chinese friend of mine has to complete her share of housework despite already having a long, hard day at work while her brother takes a shower and gets ready for a television marathon. There are probably other sisters who have a lot more responsibilities to shoulder within the family unit, while the male sibling is out at the nearest mamak stall with his buddies (who probably also have sisters at home doing a mundane but absolutely necessary chore). Therefore, before we complain about men giving us a hard time -pushing us to give our professional best and then going home to give our personal best, let's think about women giving women a hard time because we can't get the boys to do anything right. They've never been taught to! It's time to get mothers to give their sons some household responsibilities and make real men out of them (not weenies who are afraid of hot oil splattering on them when frying fish). We daughters need to get our hands out of the dish-washing detergent and into a vat of baby lotion.

New Russian prime minister makes first foreign trip and drastic measures needed to right Russian economy. Trims
EDS: UPDATES with Kiriyenko meeting Jospin, telling Chirac urgent AP Photos PAR108-109,PAR117 By DEBORAH SEWARD Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Russian Prime Minister Sergei Kiriyenko insisted he wasn't looking for handouts during meetings Wednesday with French President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin. After arriving in Paris at the start of a two-day visit _ his first overseas since becoming Prime Minister in April _ Kiriyenko twice told reporters an economic aid package was not on his agenda. ``Neither on the official program nor outside the official program is that (aid) a question,'' Kiriyenko said after his meeting at the Elysee Palace with Chirac. A small man in a blue suit who at times appeared lost among the husky Russian businessmen and bodyguards who accompanied him, Kiriyenko nevertheless projected confidence and determination. For his part, Chirac told Kiriyenko he had ``confidence in Russia's capacity to carry out its reform policies,'' presidential spokeswoman Catherine Colonna said. Chirac urged Kiriyenko to improve tax collection, create a modern and transparent banking system as well as a judicial and fiscal framework for business, Colonna told reporters. Russia's dismal record in collecting taxes has left the government with a huge fiscal hole, enormous debts, an inability to pay state workers and is at the heart of the current crisis. Spokeswoman Colonna said Kiriyenko told Chirac ``urgent and drastic'' measures were needed to right the Russian economy and that he would push them through. The ongoing Russian financial crisis has fueled speculation that some kind of aid package from the world's leading industrialized nation may be needed, primarily to prevent a collapse of the ruble. Kiriyenko did say ``relations between G-7 countries and Russia have reached a new stage.'' He didn't elaborate but said it is vital for the European Union to open its markets to Russian goods. Finance officials from the G-7 are to meet in Paris next week, and Russia's economic troubles among the issues high on their agenda. Before meeting Chirac, Kiriyenko said Russia must further integrate into the world economy to better withstand financial shock waves like those that have shaken Asia and Russia recently. The Russian stock market has fallen about 50 percent from the beginning of 1998, a dramatic change from the previous year's record growth of 98 percent. France is a modest trading partner, just eighth among Western European nations, and Russia would like to increase ties with aerospace, nuclear and automobile manufacturers. However, France traditionally enjoys good political relations with Russia and could be expected to support an eventual economic aid package and easing of EU restrictions on Russian market access. TEL AVIV, Israel (AP) _ The United States expects Israel to reach a decision on a West Bank troop withdrawal within days, not weeks, as suggested by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, the U.S. ambassador to Israel said Wednesday. Ambassador Edward Walker said that while the United States has not given Israel a deadline to accept a U.S. proposal for a troop withdrawal from 13 percent of the West Bank, ``there is a very short time frame.'' Netanyahu told lawmakers Tuesday that he expected to have made a decision on an Israeli troop pullback by the end of July, before parliament goes into summer recess, according to legislator Yehuda Harel of the centrist Third Way party. ``I am sure we can reach an agreement that will bring full security to Israel and will also compel the Palestinian Authority to fulfill its commitments,'' Netanyahu said at a ceremony later Wednesday. However, far-right coalition partners have warned Netanyahu that they would bring down his government over a 13 percent troop pullback, and Netanyahu is reluctant to accept the U.S. plan. But Shaul Yaahalom, a member of the right-wing National Religious Party which holds nine key seats in Netanyahu's 61-120 majority in parliament, told Israel TV that a coalition collapse could be avoided. Yaahalom, who serves as transportation minister, said that his party could vote against the withdrawal in Cabinet but abstain from a no-confidence vote in parliament, in order to keep Netanyahu in power while voicing their opposition to the withdrawal. Walker said Wednesday that the United States will soon make a decision on whether to pursue its peace initiative. If a failure is announced, Israel would bear the brunt of the blame because the Palestinians have accepted the U.S. plan. ``It (the decision) is in a matter of days rather than weeks, but precisely what day and what hour and so on I have no idea exactly. It depends how the progress goes,'' Walker said. Last month, Israel already ignored one U.S. deadline, and Palestinian Higher Education Minister Hanan Ashrawi said Wednesday that Washington displayed ``a lack of will to stand firm in the face of Israel's intransigence.'' On Tuesday, U.S. envoy Thomas Pickering asked Jordanian and Saudi Arabian leaders to delay plans for an Arab summit for another week to allow the American initiative to play itself out. The Palestinians are pushing for an Arab summit that would conclude with an announcement that the Arab world is suspending the normalization of ties with Israel as long as Netanyahu does not carry out the peace agreement already signed. Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat traveled to Oman on Wednesday to lobby for support among Gulf State leaders to convene an Arab summit. Palestinians have said that they will push for the summit even if Israel does accept the U.S. proposals. In London, U.S. Mideast envoy Dennis Ross met Wednesday with two top Palestinian officials to discuss the troop withdrawal. According to Maariv, Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai and Infrastructures Minister Ariel Sharon declined an invitation to attend the meeting because the government has not yet decided on the scope of a troop pullback. kl-dl

I DREADED going through, sorting out and eventually throwing away my old stuff that had been collected through the years and was packed neatly in boxes and big paper bags. It has been more than a year since my family and I moved into the house which we are in now but my boxes and bags remained untouched in my room, that is, till recently. Perhaps that should have indicated to me of the use I will still have for those things which have been put away. I had finally exhausted all excuses so I resigned myself to the horrid task of battling dust-mites and old memories. I knew old memories would come flooding back as soon as I opened those boxes and bags but the things I found surprised even me. First, there was this funny Valentine and some poems given to me by a good friend during our university days who believed that I had somehow encouraged him in his writing. These made me smile, knowing full well what he is today. Among the volumes of books I had stored up, I found a local male magazine that had the autograph of the editor. The words he wrote brought me back to 1994 when he came to speak to us at the university. The way we had gawked at him, absolutely mesmerised by his easy charm and good looks, now made me blush. I thought I had soaked in every word he said but for the life of me, I could not even recall one. Those were the days. While I was flipping through old foolscap pads to see if there was anything written in them which would prevent me from throwing them away, a small piece of paper flew out and on it was scribbled the following: ``I had thought that by cutting my long hair, I would be able to erase some memories and hopes but all I was left with from that impulsive act was a physical reminder of a broken heart and shattered dreams.'' This was dated Aug 14, 1994. The thought which came instantly to mind was, ``I wrote that?'' I had only very recently cut my hair and I probably sport a similar hairstyle to the one I had four years ago but the broken heart and shattered dreams were now a thing of the past. According to Cicero, there is no sorrow or pain which time does not soften and lessen and I sincerely believe that time had done just that. I crumpled up that piece of paper and threw it away, confident that I had moved on and I no longer want to be reminded of that part of my past. Funny how the importance of certain things diminishes though, like my secondary school report book, for instance. I had kept it faithfully for the last six years. How I used to dread those teacher-meeting-parent sessions where my grades and performance in class were discussed. My mother never failed to attend these sessions. Did I actually believe that it would have any significance at all later in life? I threw it away. I had collected materials for teaching purposes such as newspaper articles, coloured charts and graphs, interesting anecdotes from magazines, comic strips - in short, whatever I had believed would come in handy -since the first year of university. When I went through those boxes and bags, I realised that I had accumulated such a lot of stuff in those three years! Mum and sis helped a great deal too as they would ask me if I had wanted any of the above before discarding them. My reply would always be, ``Sure, why not?'' Thus, besides being the ``bag lady'' (I collect bags of different colours, sizes and shapes too) of the house, I was also the ``junk collector'' of the house. I was so reluctant to throw away all these things which I had so meticulously collected and stored but I knew I had to put them away because they had served their purpose. If only memories can be discarded like the way I discarded these things. Among the things that were meant for the dumpster, I found things which could still be used, like a beautiful pair of silver earrings from Peter Hoe's collection which was tucked away in a smart-looking clutch purse. I had probably meant it for somebody but had forgotten all about it. I also found a ceramic plaque with the words ``God bless our home'' written on it which I had intended to give a couple on their wedding day but was not able to as they had rushed off immediately after the ceremony. Now that seemed so long ago. They probably have two children by now. (Julie, if you happen to read this, call me.) My task would have been greatly simplified if all the things I had come across could be grouped into two categories - useful and no longer useful. And not whether they had sentimental value or not. I believe I spent more time reading through and reminiscing about the past than actually throwing things away. After filling up two boxes and three garbage bags, I was still left with a floor full of odds and ends - a pewter key-ring, magic coloured pens, old story books, old cassettes, cards and bookmarks. Unless you have a big house with a huge attic and plenty of room to spare, clearing away old things is as natural and inevitable as putting away old clothes to be given away. Some things like calendars and festive greeting cards - though given by special people - lose their use and simply take up space. Little did I know that day that by throwing away some old things of mine, I was in effect eliminating some memories. If I do not see that particular item again, I probably will not recall the events associated with that particular item. I threw a lot of memories away that day but I know that new ones are being collected every day and before I know it, Mum will be on my back again. By looking through my old things, I saw how much I have grown and matured as an individual through the years and all those memorabilia from the past simply reminded me of the phases of life which I had to go through to get to where I am and the people who have in one way or another contributed to making me the person I am today. For those who have nothing to do at home, just spend one afternoon clearing your old things and you will learn more about yourself than you ever will by watching movies in a lifetime.

MOTHERS! When we were very young, Mother was the most important person at home. For the meals, the clothes, the bedroom things, when we fell and hurt ourselves, when we lost a fight... she was there for us. She was the answer, she was the consolation, she was the anchor. Then, as we grew up, we became a little deaf to all her ``nagging'' about good manners, tidiness, punctuality. We didn't like being reminded that we were too young for this and that. When we were not-so-young, we had to think up all sorts of excuses to cover up for girlfriend/boyfriend outings so that she wouldn't probe and pry too much. Then, after we got married, which we thought must be one of her three most important wishes for us, she had to cry at our weddings! Then, when we produce grandchildren for her, thinking that's another important wish of hers, and we try to discipline them the way she did with us, we get scolded for being too strict with our children. Ordinarily, a mother has several battles to fight on her own. The battle of the bulge - from finishing leftovers on the plates; clearing obstacles - from the mountains of laundry and dishes after a meal; her menstrual cycle, which is supposed to explain her emotional outbursts; and later on, menopause, which is supposed to explain her idiosyncrasies. When I backtrack to my younger days, I recall that the only automation that got most of the work done for an average family of eight was something called ``Mother''. Today, with my electric rice-cooker, my washing machine and my microwave oven, I still can't catch up with all my household chores - and there are only two of us left at home! We marvel at the things mothers talk about - their children's fevers, fights, falls, scars, bad test results, allergies and dental appointments... what do they talk about if all these do not happen? So how does one understand a mother? Don't try. Let her complain why you haven't come to see her for so long; and when you do it too often, let her complain (to others) that your visits give her too much clearing up to do. It is said that ``the hand that rocks the cradle is the hand that rules the world'' - and as we grow more appreciative, we perceive its resilience, love and forgiveness. She is there for breakfast time, lunch time, tea time, dinner time... is there some compensation for overtime?

UNIQUE. That best describes the lower Kinabatangan floodplain on the east coast of Sabah. A slow boat ride along the 560-kilometre long Kinabatangan River, which flows into the Sulu Sea, reveals diverse forms of vegetation and animals. Wildlife such as the orang utan, the proboscis monkey, macaque, Asian elephant, hornbill and wild cattle are just some of God's creations along the Kinabatangan. Because of their beauty and uniqueness in Nature, the time has come to give due consideration to conserving wildlife in forest reserves and wildlife sanctuaries not only in the Kinabatangan floodplain but also in the rest of the country. Recent fires affecting many parts of Malaysia and Indonesia have posed a threat to our wildlife and the eco-system. For now, we may still be able to steal glimpses of orang utans and proboscis monkeys but for how long? Will future generations get to see Asian elephants on river banks? The fire that broke out in the Pin Supu Forest Reserve in Kinabatangan on April 13 were a threat to wildlife. About 300 hectares of the reserve were razed out of the total 4,696 hectares. While it may seem relatively insignificant since some 40 per cent or 368,436 hectares of the 921,089 hectares in the Kinabatangan Forestry District are forest reserves, there are reasons to be concerned. Kinabatangan Forestry district officer Fadzil Yahya believes that the fire, which broke out in the middle of the reserve, was caused by hunters. ``We suspect hunters started the fire because the area that was burnt is in the middle of the reserve. Normally if a fire breaks out on the reserve's fringe, it is caused by open burning at nearby plantations,'' he says. Putting out the fires in Pin Supu is no easy task as the soil is peat. Officers from the Kota Kinabatangan Forestry Department, the District Office, the police, locals and environmental group World Wide Fund for Nature have all played their role in keeping the fires under control. The fires were first reported by WWF scientific officer Martin Paul Vogel, who is doing a study in Batu Putih, located close to the reserve. With help from the various parties, the men, including a handful who received house training in fire fighting, started manually making fire breaks. With limited equipment such as water pumps, parang and water sprays, they managed to make a fire break within a week. They also dug a 1.8-metre pond to retain water from the Kinabatangan River, which flows five kilometres away. After a week, they managed to obtain two excavators to dig one-metre deep trenches within a 2.5-km radius of the affected area. Tractors were used as peat is very soft. Peat fires are difficult to suppress as they could go on burning underground. The recent showers brought a brief respite to the area which had been experiencing a water shortage due to the prolonged drought and land-clearing activities from nearby oil palm estates. However, if fire breaks out again both in Pin Supu and in the surrounding areas, a grimmer picture can be expected as there is limited staff to conduct surveillance, enforcement and patrolling for the 20 forest reserves. Kota Kinabatangan wildlife officer Rashid Saburi fears that big fires - such as the one which broke out in the Kulamba Forest Reserve resulting in 1,000 hectares going up in smoke - will endanger the rare and wild cattle, known locally as tembadau, in the long run. He estimates that there are no more than 50 such cattles within Kulamba. In the whole of Sabah, they number about 500. Slow-moving mammals and reptiles, he says, are also under threat. Fast- moving animals like squirrels and birds have a better chance of escaping. In fact, Rahid found charred remains of snakes and terrapins when putting out the fires. ``There is a need,'' he insists, ``to make people aware of the hazards of open burning on the environment and wildlife.'' In the 20,000-hectare Kulamba, the fires were believed to have been started by fishermen who cook by the beach. Rashid suspects that charred logs dumped on the beach led to fires spreading to nearby Kulamba. Using the limited resources available, the fire fighters at Kulumba used a 1.6-kilometre-long hose to pump in sea water. Water bombing was also deployed with the help of the Royal Malaysian Air Force as a last resort. WWF environmental pollution analyst Rick Gregory says there is no special unit to fight fires in Kinabatangan. ``Everyone is learning on the job,'' he says, ``and many are ill-trained.'' He adds that many people are still practising open burning, especially to clear land next to forest reserves and wildlife sanctuaries. ``One of our roles in WWF is to make an impact assessment study using helicopters and conducting ground surveys on how fires have threatened existing habitats,'' he says.

Paraguay also lost very good opportunity to take the lead in the 44th minute when Acuna fired from 30 meters (years) but hit the crossbar. Kompas of May 30 carried a thought-inspiring caricature depicting a bunch of hilarious, merciless-looking men who raise posters identifying their respective political parties, while others hold up still blank posters. A trampled, injured man in rags lies dying on the ground, personifying the battered national economy. In a corner, a modest image of a common man displaying a poster signals the Sembako Party. Sembako is an acronym for the nine basic commodities. The striking satirical message elicited by the caricature reflects first the escalating breakaway of certain groupings from some existing political parties, other than the justifiable moves of former repressed opposition leaders to set up new political parties. Second, the image of the dying man and the innocent common man wielding the Sembako Party sign fitly depicts the callous disregard on the part of the political movements of vested interest groups vis-a-vis the poor economic state of the country and the people's suffering in the current economic crisis. In my view, the caricature should serve as a reminder that the existence of a multitude of political parties, with rampant, incessant antagonism raging between them, as prevailed in the 1950s, did not provide political stability, nor economic development, to the country and people. Cabinets survived less than a year. It resembled the political instability in France which held sway in the 1950s in the pre-De Gaulle era. A university professor of constitutional law in a talk show on SCTV on Sunday evening (May 31) stated that in the 1950s no antagonism existed between political parties in the matter of their programs. But it must be recalled that the antagonism between the parties in 1958 reached such a stage as to end up in a stalemate of the Provisional People's Consultative Assembly, which undertook to lay down a new constitution. This stalemate angered president Sukarno, who at that time went on record with the warning ``I will bury the political parties''. He finally revived the 1945 Constitution. The antagonism between the political parties which caused the failure of the Assembly in 1958 must serve as a lesson for retrospection and introspection to the leaders who are intent on founding new political parties and accordingly participating in the coming general election.

Jamaican leader gives plots of land to World Cup team
By CAROLL ORR Associated Press Writer
KINGSTON, Jamaica (AP) _ No matter what their fortunes in this month's World Cup playoffs, Jamaican national soccer team players all will have plots of land to call home when they return to the Caribbean. Jamaican Prime Minister Percival Patterson presented sales agreements for parcels of land to each of the team's 22 players Wednesday during an official send-off. Called the Reggae Boyz, it is the first Jamaican team to win a berth in the international competition, and the first from an English-speaking Caribbean nation. ``We have created history and excitement but we are going to create even more history and excitement by what we achieve by our performance in France,'' Patterson said. ``There are more miracles yet to be revealed.'' He praised the players, their Brazilian coach Rene Simoes and the Jamaica Football Federation, which turned the team from a volunteer squad into a full-time professional team through heavy marketing and sponsorships. Patterson likened Simoes' dedication to that of Jesus Christ, despite Simoes' announcement last month that he would leave the team in October. He made the decision after a national newspaper reported he was being paid dlrs 18,300 a month, more than any Jamaican public official. Simoes also has drawn criticism for replacing native-born Jamaicans with players born in Britain to Jamaican parents. ``Whatever our outcome, you have served us well,'' Patterson told Simoes. ``We are proud of you and we can say no more than to pay the highest tribute: to say that we see you as a true and outstanding (honorary) Jamaican.''

A NEW prototype toilet block designed by the Housing and Local Government Ministry is set to replace existing public toilets by the end of the year. Its Deputy Minister Datuk Azmi Khalid said the RM200,000 block consisting of toilets for males and females and one for the disabled can be part of any building. The toilets will initially be introduced in Kuala Lumpur and later extended to other parts of the country. Azmi said the toilets could also be free-standing. Speaking to reporters after visiting public toilets at Dataran Merdeka, the Klang bus station and the Puduraya bus terminal, he said the new concept was the outcome of a series of studies and brainstorming sessions between Kuala Lumpur City Hall and the ministry. Also present was Deputy Minister in the Prime Minster's Department Datuk Dr Ibrahim Saad. Asked about the need for the standard toilet, Azmi said the public was generally confused by different maintenance systems for toilets. ``People are finding it difficult getting used to different forms of facilities in public toilets such as the flush system which differs from toilet to toilet,'' he said. Azmi said the standard toilet would be built at a site earmarked by the ministry and City Hall. He said the men's section would have four cubicles and the women's six. ``This is because women tend to bring children with them into toilets. ``This is why we have two cubicles for children. There will also be space for changing of diapers,'' he said. The toilet floors will have non-slip tiles which are easy to dry and safe for children and the aged. ``Despite the fact that the equipment in the toilets would be exposed to theft, we will not compromise on quality and all facilities and fixtures will be heavy-duty material,'' Azmi said. Asked if the standard toilet would be privatised, Azmi said it was up to City Hall to work out the details. ``I believe, if it is viable, City Hall will not dismiss the idea of privatisation as a possible form of providing better-serviced toilets,'' he said. He said existing City Hall public toilets would be torn down and replaced with the standard toilets.

Battling Belgians win 2-0 to compound Colombia's woes
By PAUL AMES Associated Press Writer
BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) _ Belgium demolished Colombia 2-0 Wednesday with a display of rugged determination and tight teamwork that added to the South American's pre-World Cup woes. Defeat in a rain-soaked King Baudouin Stadium followed Colombia's 3-1 mauling by Germany Saturday and disappointing draws against Scotland and Chile. By contrast, Belgium, going into its fifth consecutive World Cup finals, is looking better with every game. The Belgian defense blunted the attacking thrust of Faustino Asprilla and Freddy Rincon and flashes of brilliance from Luc Nilis and Marc Wilmots belied the dour reputation of the ``Red Devils.'' ``The goals are coming,'' said Wilmots. ``We're playing very fast, we're playing very well.'' Wilmots, who plays his club soccer at Germany's Schalke 04, supplied the best moment of the match. Roaming the wide, open spaces left by his Colombian markers, the stylish midfielder picked up a loose ball some 25 meters (yards) and rifled in a right foot shot that soared into the top corner of the net beyond Oscar Cordoba's despairing dive for 2-0 in the 31st minute. Danny Boffin had already shown up the porous Colombian defense in the 16th minute racing in unmarked to head home a Luis Oliveira pass from pointblank range for 1-0. Colombia struck back with more conviction early in the second half. Asprilla was particularly dangerous, twice forcing diving saves from goalie Filip de Wilde. But the Belgians soon reestablished control of a bad-tempered match that saw four Belgians and two Colombians receive yellow cards. In a battle of midfield veterans, the wild-haired Colombian Carlos Valdarama, heading for this third World Cup, was largely outshone by Enzo Scifo, on his way to his fourth. WITH no contentious issues to distract them, the national delegates to the one-day MCA 45th annual general assembly on Saturday kept their focus on the party's direction in helping the country tackle its economic problems. Is this the lull before the storm in view of the party elections next year? Judging from the proceedings, the delegates seemed to be sending a strong signal of their endorsement to party leaders for adopting several measures and commitment to maintain a strong, stable and united MCA. Political observers believe that under the leadership of Datuk Seri Dr Ling Liong Sik and his team, the party is united and will be able to weather and stave off a serious challenge from the Opposition in the next general elections. Having achieved its best electoral results in 1995, when the party won 31 parliamentary and 73 State seats (including one in Sabah), Dr Ling is expected to retain the team, or at the most opt for only minor changes. He said in an interview that the mandate given by the people to MCA candidates in the last general election had been proven correct. ``Look at our elected representatives, they are working full time to handle varied problems faced by the people and even bring them up in parliament and State assemblies,'' Dr Ling said. He took a dig at the DAP as a party which ``is consistently critical, negative and destructive (CCND) and no action, talk only (Nato)''. He said the DAP thrived on issues associated with the present economic downturn to survive. Dr Ling also has a simple message to the party's elected representatives: ``Work hard and even harder for the people who have given you their support.'' As for the party elections, MCA deputy president Datuk Lim Ah Lek had said at the MCA Youth assembly, held a day earlier, that there should be minimal contests next year. However, this did not mean that there should be no contest, he said. His message to the party members is to retain elected leaders who have worked hard and to weed out those non-performing leaders through the democratic process. At the party's assembly, what was even more conspicuous this time, were the unity and the attendance of political friends and foes of yesteryears. Such acts of conciliation and letting bygones be bygones were obvious with the presence of past party leaders, who were engaged in the infamous party crisis of the early 80s. Among those who came were party life president Tan Sri Lee San Choon, Tan Koon Swan, Datuk Dr Neo Yee Pan, Datuk Lee Kim Sai, Datuk Kee Yong Wee, Tan Sri Chong Hon Nyan, Datuk Wong Seng Chow, Tun Omar Yoke Lin Ong, Tan Sri Lee Siok Yew, Datuk Tan Cheng Swee, Datuk Lew Sip Hon, Datuk Chan Kit Chee, Datuk Dr Tan Tiong Hong, Datuk Kam Woon Wah and Datuk Yeoh Kian Teik, a former Perak Youth chief and father of James Bond girl, Michelle Yeoh. Their presence even prompted the guest-of-honour Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad, who is also the Barisan Nasional chairman, to make some comments before he delivered his speech. His remark that most politicians faded away when they no longer held party or government positions (Umno not excluded), has given much food for thought. Lest we forget, Dr Mahathir had on many occasions reminded such politicians that they were given the opportunity to continue playing their role in national development through political vehicles. Besides this show of unity by the MCA, there also appeared to be a total absence of lobbying among the elected representatives in preparations for the party elections next year. Issues related to the economic problems stole the limelight. Even Dr Ling's presidential address was focused on the premise of the party's political agenda to help the country overcome the economic problems in the shortest possible time. The MCA chief reiterated the party's commitment to continue the ``Love Malaysia, Buy Local Products'' campaign and the need to keep our ringgit from leaving the country with his repeated exhortations of study locally, save in local banks, visit local tourist destinations and buy local products. The assembly also saw the smooth passage of four amendments to the party constitution which included the increase in the number of Wanita delegates to the general assembly, expand the central committee and endorsing a formula to keep the number of national delegates at a manageable number.

TEHRAN, Iran (AP) _ President Mohammad Khatami, who has sought a more moderate course for Iran since his election a year ago, plans to go to the United States to address the U.N. General Assembly in September, a government official said Wednesday. Referring to the planned address as a ``very important speech,'' the official said Khatami would discuss the position of Muslims in the world and in the United Nations. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that Khatami would urge the United Nations to give Islamic nations a permanent seat on the Security Council. The statement was the first announcement of the planned trip, though such a visit had been rumored for days. The trip would require U.S. government permission, but this is never refused to a head of state. Breaking through nearly 20 years of hostility, Khatami called for a dialogue with Americans and more cultural and educational exchanges in a broadcast interview last January. Two previous Iranian presidents have addressed the United Nations since the 1979 Islamic revolution, but both used their speeches to attack the United States. Khatami could instead make a gesture to American leaders. Khatami will also use his trip to meet the 2 million strong Iranian community in the United States, the official said. Many Iranians fled their country to settle in the United States and other Western countries after the revolution. DEPUTY Minister in the Prime Minister's Department Datuk Dr Ibrahim Saad has joined Bandar Tun Razak MP Datuk Tan Chai Ho in calling for a separate water authority for the Federal Territory. He said although the city's water supply came from dams in Selangor, a separate authority would mean better service to the public. ``There must be a separate body to oversee the distribution and supply of water in the Federal Territory especially when there is a shortage.'' Ibrahim said the absence of an authority in the Federal Territory to co- ordinate the distribution of water and to liaise with the Selangor Waterworks Department was especially felt in times of crisis. Tan had earlier urged the authorities to establish an independent water authority in Kuala Lumpur to facilitate water distribution. On building owners in the city who ignored City Hall's call to paint their premises, Ibrahim said he deplored their lackadaisical attitude. He said City Hall had issued letters of appeal and request notices to building owners to spruce up their premises for the Commonwealth Games. ``But after today's tour of the city, I feel that not many have taken our appeals to heart,'' he added. He said that if building owners were unable to repaint due to financial contraints, they should at least white-wash the exterior so that it looked presentable. Ibrahim also said preparations for the Games were not just the responsibility of City Hall or the Federal Government but also that of the general public. Asked what form of action would be taken against defiant building owners, Ibrahim said there was nothing much City Hall could do but plead for co-operation.

Many Chinese Indonesians can tell stories of how their assets were destroyed or in some cases their safety targeted by the mobs in the recent riots that hit Jakarta and several other cities in Indonesia. So, I found Sumarsono Sastrowardoyo's letter criticizing Chinese Indonesians that fled the country during the rioting to be unfair. After all, nobody knew at the time that the transfer of power was going to take place peacefully. On the other hand, I would support the calls by others for Chinese Indonesians to put more effort into assimilating with indigenous people. I also call on the authorities to take more concrete steps to address the issue. Furthermore it is important to improve national security because if people do not feel safe they will not return to do their business as usual. There have been accounts of loss of lives, assets and jobs due to the riots. However, few have mentioned the long-term impact of the loss of confidence and higher risk perceived by people. This will result in more capital and even skilled people leaving and fewer coming to Indonesia at a time when the country badly needs the expertise and capital. Even when things stabilize further, investors in general will be less inclined to put their money into businesses which are long-term in nature. This will significantly handicap Indonesia in its bid to be a competitive economy in the 21st century. The stakes are just too big for the issue to be ignored.

READY, GET SET, GO ... Kuala Lumpur mayor Datuk Kamaruzzaman Sharif flagging off participants in the ``Midnite Run'' commemorating the 100-day countdown to the Kuala Lumpur 1998 Commonwealth Games at City Hall last night. About 500 participants, including 200 trainees from the Police Training Centre in Jalan Gurney, ran the four kilometres from Jalan Raja Laut heading towards Chow Kit before turning back to Jalan Tuanku Abdul Rahman and finishing at the starting point. Also present were Sukom Ninety-Eight Berhad chief operating officer Datuk Seri Abdul Manaf Ibrahim and Sukom's director of communications Tunku Maziah Mukhtar. Kamaruzzaman said Kuala Lumpur was set to receive the athletes and spectators due for the Games starting on Sept 11. ``The Midnite Run is to remind Malaysians that the Games are only 100 days away. ``This is among many events that we hope will ignite the Games fever and create a festive atmosphere as we await this historic event.'' He also hoped Malaysians would play their part in keeping the city clean and receive the visitors warmly to make the Games a success. ``All Malaysians must play their part to make the Games a success, especially in keeping the city clean and presentable,'' Kamaruzzaman said.

Israeli, Syrian negotiators meet for first time in two years
Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Rabinovitch in final graf
JERUSALEM (AP) - Israeli and Syrian negotiators met for the first time in more than two years this week in the United States, Israel TV reported Wednesday. The TV said three Israeli negotiators and three Syrian representatives including the Syrian ambassador to Washington Walid Moualem held four days of meetings at a think tank run by former U.S. Secretary of State James Baker III in Houston, Texas. ``There was never any meeting. There wasn't even a handshake,'' Moualem said in Washington. ``I just gave a lecture in which I spoke about the necessity of resuming the talks (with Israel) from where we left off.'' Israel TV said Baker and U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Martin Indyk were both present at the meetings which dealt with a return to the negotiating table both sides left over two years ago. Syria wants the Golan Heights back, which Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast war, in exchange for a peace agreement. Talks on a territorial compromise with Israel's previous Labor-led government broke off in March 1996 and never resumed. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has called on Syria to returned to talks by has also said that Israel should retain control over the strategic heights for security reasons. Israel TV said the secret talks this week in Houston were attended by Netanyahu's chief policy aide Uzi Arad, Itamar Rabinovitch, a former ambassador and negotiator with Syria and reserve general Uzi Sagay. dl

KUALA LUMPUR, Tues. - The decision by the Kelantan Government to ban dikir barat performances may affect tourist arrivals to Malaysia as arts and culture are among the main attractions. Culture, Arts and Tourism Minister Datuk Sabbaruddin Chik said though it was too early to determine the impact of the ban, many foreigners came to Malaysia because of her mix of culture. ``Logically, if the attractions are no longer available, they will not come,'' he said after launching Mystical Malaysia, a local travel, leisure and lifestyle magazine at Menara Kuala Lumpur. The magazine, published by BN Associates, will be circulated monthly with about 280,000 copies. The Kelantan Government imposed the ban last week on grounds that some quarters were found to have abused the permits issued to them to hold dikir barat performances by including other forms of entertainment which contradicted Islamic teachings. However, Sabbaruddin said promotions carried out by the ministry would still have references to dikir barat as the performance was not banned in other States. On the huge outflow of funds through tourism, Sabbaruddin said he was confident the amount, at RM7.6 billion last year, could be reduced following various measures taken by the Government, including promotions to encourage domestic tourism. He said the depreciation of the ringgit had made travelling overseas more expensive and this might lead more Malaysians to spend their holidays in the country. Sabaruddin agreed that packages to some foreign destinations like Medan in Indonesia were much cheaper than domestic ones like Kota Kinabalu, and this had to some extent discouraged Malaysians from visiting local destinations. However, to ensure fairness, he said several factors needed to be taken into account when comparing the prices of local and overseas tour packages. ``For instance, the locals are willing to travel in groups to benefit from discounted fare when going overseas but choose to travel alone when holidaying locally. ``They are also willing to put up at apartments when abroad but elect to stay in five-star hotels when in the country.'' Earlier in his speech, Sabbaruddin said Malaysians often perceived holidaying abroad as being more ``glamorous'' than visiting local destinations. Despite the many beautiful and historical attractions the country had to offer, he said some Malaysians had never gone to such places like Batu Caves and the National Park. He added that publications like Mystical Malaysia would help Malaysians realise their role in the country's tourism development.

THE Subang Jaya Municipal Council yesterday re-opened two major openings at dividers along Jalan Tujuan which had been closed earlier following complaints from SS18 and SS19 residents. Subang Jaya State Assemblyman Lee Hwa Beng said the closure, which was implemented from May 25, had caused massive jams as motorists had to go further up Jalan Tujuan to make U-turns. The dividers located at the SS19-SS17 and SS19-SS18 junctions were removed to provide for a smoother flow along Jalan Tujuan which is linked to the exit near the KFC outlet. Motorists were not allowed to make right turns at these junctions. The council had wanted to reduce the openings along the road to allow for a smoother traffic flow but the decision backfired when motorists clogged up other parts of the road to make quick U-turns. The council is also studying the feasibility of constructing a RM1.5 million ramp to link Jalan Tujuan to SS19. A firm had been appointed to make a study and design the ramp.

BC-Sports-Basketball-Bulls Dynasty,0694
Seven-year stretch: Bulls eye second three-peat AP Sports Writer
By RICK GANO
SALT LAKE CITY (AP) _ Seven years ago, Michael Jordan sat weeping at his father's side, cradling his first National Basketball Association championship trophy as if it were a long-lost child. He couldn't and he wouldn't let it go. Losing seasons were behind him. So were the bruising losses to the Detroit Pistons, who for years denied the Chicago Bulls a shot at the title Jordan needed to define his career. ``I'm very proud for the team. I'm very proud for my family,'' he said through tears that summer day in 1991 after vanquishing the Los Angeles Lakers. ``We finally capped it off after seven years.'' Now, in what might be his final season, Jordan wants another title. At the team's practice facility in suburban Chicago, the Bulls built a case to hold their trophies. Five _ three straight before Jordan went away for most of two years to play baseball, and now two more in a row _ and counting. Most of the names have changed. Will Perdue, Bill Cartwright, John Paxson, Scott Williams, Horace Grant and B.J. Armstrong are gone. Paxson, whose outside shooting helped conquer the Lakers, made the 3-pointer that sank the Phoenix Suns in 1993, clinching the first three-peat. Grant blocked a last-second shot to preserve the victory. A little-used reserve named Bobby Hansen made a 3-pointer to begin an amazing fourth-quarter run as the Bulls rallied from 15 down to polish off Portland in 1992. That was ``the shrug'' series, a gesture Jordan made after hitting six 3-pointers in one half. Even he couldn't believe it. Now, Jordan and longtime sidekick Scottie Pippen lead a new supporting cast _ Luc Longley, Steve Kerr, Jud Buechler, Toni Kukoc, Bill Wennington and Randy Brown. ``You just continue to try to build on your legacy and hopefully one day you can look back and cherish it and realize something you did was very special,'' Pippen said. ``But as you go through it, you don't look at it and weep over it. Just try to carry on. I don't see this happening again in the near future.'' Kerr, like Paxson, hit the game-clinching shot last season _ on a pass from Jordan _ as the Bulls outlasted Utah in six games. The season before, Dennis Rodman provided the spark as the Bulls beat Seattle, capping the best regular-season record ever, 72-10. The victory over the Sonics marked Jordan's first championship since his comeback and his first without his father, who had been murdered two years earlier. When the buzzer sounded and the series was over, Jordan collapsed on the floor, again in tears, as he clutched the ball. Appropriately, it was Father's Day. Facing the Jazz again this season, the Bulls see similarities to their matchup against the Suns. They are shooting for a third straight championship, they are without home-court advantage and they are facing a talented opponent. There are contrasts, too. ``The '93 team was totally different. We had a team together seven or eight years,'' Jordan said. ``We went basically from bottom and got to the top. This team is built on three specialties (Jordan, Pippen and Rodman) and everyone else complements that. We haven't been together as long but yet we've had this much success,'' he said. ``This is different. The reliability is not quite the same, although it's good now. You can't compare it to the '93 team.'' But the Bulls can be compared to the greatest teams. They can't match the 16 titles of the Boston Celtics or 11 from the Minneapolis-Los Angeles Lakers. But they have dominated the '90s when Jordan played. ``What we tried to do is keep thinking each one is unique and special and not get wrapped up in the idea that `ho-hum, it's another finals,''' Bulls coach Phil Jackson said. ``We savor it and make it a unique feeling. It is something we will value and treasure. It's something that is done once in a lifetime. It's happened to us six times, so for us it's six times in a lifetime.''

PRECEDE Asmara Eritrean villages hit by Ethiopian artillery villages; details, RAISES context.
Eds: LEADS throughout to RECAST, UPDATE with attacks on Eritrean AP Photos ASM101-103 of June 2 By JULIA STEWART Associated Press Writer
SENAFE, Eritrea (AP) _ Ethiopian artillery fire echoed in Eritrean valleys Wednesday, and black smoke curled from villages abandoned by frightened farmers and their families. Officials in both Horn of Africa countries accused each other of cross-border attacks, dimming hopes for a peaceful solution to their border dispute. Hundreds of Eritrean soldiers marched towards defensive positions, while pickup trucks loaded with lightly wounded troops returned from the front to a village near Senafe, about 80 kilometers (50 miles) southeast of Asmara. No other details were available on casualties from Wednesday's attacks. Ethiopia first made public the border dispute on May 13, calling on Eritrea to withdraw from occupied Ethiopian territory. Ethiopia accuses Eritrea of illegally occupying a 415-square-kilometer (160-square-mile) area known as the Yirga triangle in northwestern Ethiopia, plus a half-dozen smaller areas along the border. But the underlying causes of the conflict are economic, diplomats and businessmen say. Eritrea accused Ethiopia of using tanks and heavy artillery in an attack early Wednesday on the frontier village of Ambesete Geleba, 140 kilometers (90 miles) southwest of the capital, Asmara. The Eritrean Foreign Affairs Ministry accused Ethiopia of provoking ``a new and dangerous escalation'' of the border crisis, and said it was the fourth attack in less than two weeks on Eritrean positions. Hours later, Ethiopian accused Eritrean troops of attacking near Aiga and Alitena, about 20 kilometers (10 miles) on the Ethiopian side of a natural border formed by the Mereb River. ``Eritrea thought it could get away with shifting the blame to Ethiopia,'' the Ethiopian Foreign Ministry said in a statement. However, Ethiopia's state-run radio accused Eritrea of publicly executing three Ethiopian civilians it said were abducted by Eritrean troops during an earlier cross-border raid. Another 30 civilians were in the custody of the Eritrean army and their fate was unknown, said Kiros Bitow, a local official. He said about 24,700 Ethiopians had been displaced in the Badme and Sheraro areas following Eritrean invasions. In the Eritrean village of Forpo, examinations were canceled because students were too frightened by distant explosions to concentrate, said their teacher, Sampson, who gave no last name. Villagers, who declined to be named, reported hearing incoming and outgoing heavy artillery fire. Eritrea on Wednesday repeated a call for a total demilitarization of border areas and outside mediation to solve the dispute. Ethiopia said it was cooperating with peace negotiators. For the past two weeks, U.S. diplomats and regional leaders have shuttled between the two countries in a desperate effort to restore peace that has showed no signs of success. Both countries have consistently denied invading the other's territory. The Eritreans gained formal independence in 1993 after helping Ethiopian rebels end 17 years of harsh military rule in Ethiopia. Relations between the one-time allies in a long war against the former Marxist government of Ethiopia soured when Eritrea introduced its own currency in November, triggering a trade war that has hurt both economies and reduced cross-border commerce to a trickle.

IPOH-born singer Manivvanan never dreamt that he would one day be considered one of the most popular Indian singers here. After all, he was more interested in making it big as a sportsman. Back then as a pupil in Sekolah Menengah Sultan Abdul Samad, he was, in fact, in awe of friends who could sing. ``One day, while watching a school concert, I got drawn by the whole thing and decided to give it a go by entering a singing contest held in conjunction with Teachers Day,'' said Mannivvanan, eldest among four children. The song, Zuraidah (popularised by veteran Azman Idris) got him the top prize in the contest, much to his surprise, and it was then that he started to think of taking up singing as a career. His parents, who were singers themselves, fully supported his dream. After completing his SPM, Manivvanan attended an RTM audition in Ipoh. ``My first radio appearance was in the Tamil musical programme Isei Kadhambam, back in 1991. I sang a duet with popular singer Susheela Menon.'' This opened the door for him to appear in radio and television shows as well as in shows performances. ``One of the memorable moments of my career was when I released a compilation of popular Tamil numbers with a different music arrangement.'' Manivvanan sang five solo songs in the album which was released by Fantasia Music City in 1995. They included songs Style Style, Oh Priya and Rakku Muthu Rakku. ``Another significant event was when I was selected by RTM to deliver Malaysia Sejahtera and Dunia IT. The songs, screened every night by TV1 and TV2, also features Siti Nurhaliza, Amelina, Sughanti Perumal, Nassier Wahab, Nora and Rahmat. I really cherish the experience,'' he said. Mannivvanan's future plans include recording a sentimental pop album. ``Recording a Malay album will also prove that I am equally capable of singing such songs,'' he said. He is now working on a Tamil album with another singer, Jeeva. ``I had wanted to do this album for some time. We are still finalising details like the concept, producer, composers and the distribution company. ``I known Jeeva for a long time and our voices are compatible. The album will feature two of my own compositions,'' he said. Manivvanan will be appearing at two big concerts in Petaling Jaya and his hometown Ipoh, at the end of the year. The concerts, organised by his close friend K. Radhakrishnan, will also feature Jeeva, Sughanti Perumal Shobana Nair, Ramani, Ismail and Sashi. Manivvanan has received several offers for television dramas in Tamil and Bahasa Malaysia, but is waiting for the right time before making his TV debut.

JAKARTA (JP): The death of four Trisakti University students last May 12 motivated students to escalate their campaign for total reform. In the same way as Arief Rachman Hakim, a University of Indonesia student who was shot to death by the military in 1966, the four became martyrs and heroes for political reform. In the two days after the shooting, there were massive riots in Jakarta and its surrounding satellite towns of Bekasi and Tangerang. These were the worst riots in Indonesia's modern political history. Rumors making the rounds were plenty. One said the riots were the work of some military officers who wanted to imitate what their predecessors did during the Malari Affair in 1974, when they ordered hoodlums to loot and burn shopping centers in Senen, Central Jakarta. Their intention was to deceive the public into believing that the riots were committed by students; thus, the public would condemn students and would not support their demonstration for total reform. The politics of scapegoating the students was unsuccessful. Another rumor said they were organized by the military as an excuse for their chief commander, Gen. Wiranto, to stop student demonstrations. Others speculated the riots were part of a power struggle among the military elite. Another story had it they were organized to demolish symbols of development of Soeharto's regime. The deaths of the students and the riots did not quash the students' determination to topple Soeharto as a precondition for total reform. For the second time in Indonesia's young history, a student movement succeeded in forcing the president out of office. This time it was the most powerful man in Indonesia who had ruled with an iron fist for 32 years. Several factors forced Soeharto to make the decision: The occupation of the House building by thousands of students. They were willing to sacrifice their lives rather than leave the building without Soeharto's resignation. The Armed Forces (ABRI) accommodative attitude toward students during their demonstrations boosted their spirit to topple Soeharto. Soeharto failed to reshuffle his Cabinet in time, and 14 of his ministers resigned. It seems probable Gen. Wiranto told Soeharto that ABRI could not support him any more. There may have also been several external factors which contributed to expedite Soeharto's downfall, such as the delay in disbursement of International Monetary Fund's bailout contribution for Indonesia and the indirect support for student movements in the country. In a way, these May student demonstrations in Indonesia can be regarded as a middle class revolution. Compared to previous student movements, this year's student movements were supported by almost all sections of society, particularly the middle class. Their support came in the form of money, food, printing materials, T-shirts, encouraging public opinion, organizing short courses to enhance students' critical ability, musical entertainment and others. The middle class' help for the students can be divided into five categories: First, those who had genuine motives for political and economic reforms or the true believers. They spent a lot of money to assist student demonstrations, without any political or economic interests except total reforms. Second, former student activists who had tried to topple Soeharto's regime for more than 24 years and who were eager to end the dictatorship in Indonesia. Third, those who were unhappy with the Soeharto's family business activities since the beginning of the economic crisis in July 1997, either because they lost their jobs or they could not compete with crony capitalists who were close to Soeharto's family. Fourth, the newcomers or ``free riders'' who jumped on the bandwagon just before Soeharto's downfall. Fifth, former Soeharto's cronies and aides who wanted to ``wash their hands'' to show to the people that they were clean and eager to dissociate themselves from corruption, nepotism and collusion. Students call this group ``last-minutes heroes'' or ``eleventh hour heroes''. Although Soeharto has lost his power, students and civilian political elites still continue their demands for total reform. Many have never accepted Habibie as Soeharto's successor, because Habibie was very close to Soeharto and he is still considered part of the problem, a leader whose managerial capability to handle the present political and economic crisis still needs to be tested. Some legal experts believe the transfer of power from Soeharto to Habibie was illegal or unconstitutional. In other words, the nation shows increasing signs of polarization over Habibie presidency and his cabinet. Students are also divided between those who support Habibie and those who still oppose him. The aftermath of Soeharto's resignation can be regarded as a period of struggle for powers among political elites, without considering social and economic conditions. Today, many former Soeharto cronies are forming new political parties as if, in this new era of political reform, people are free enough to do that without any consideration that their actions will endanger the nation's unity and stability. It seems their understanding of the liberal democratic system was very limited. Unless statesmanship grows at the heart of Indonesia's political elite, this country will inadvertently be torn to pieces. The present situation also sees a psychological war between military and civilian elites. While the civilian political elite is still screaming about total reform without any agreement on the future reform agenda, the military are preparing drafts of political development after Soeharto. The military elite is also trying to show to the people that they are humble and accommodative toward the civilian elite who demand total reform. Minister of Information Yunus Yosfiah's handling of the problem of the free press in Indonesia is an example of how ABRI approaches journalists. In addition, ABRI Chief of Sociopolitical Affairs, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, showed the accommodative approach in dealing with the people and political elite. The elite can still discuss political reform in cafes and hotels. The elite can also afford to think about ``what menus will we pick to eat from today?'', while the common people who live from one day to another ponder ``what will we eat today?''. Unless the civilian elite take the people's stomachs into consideration, it is possible the grassroots groups will shift their allegiance from the civilian to the military elite in the next six months or so. Although it is hard to believe at present, it is not impossible that the military will dominate the government because the civilian political elite cannot cope with the present economic and political crisis. The writer is a researcher at the Center for Political and Regional Studies, Indonesian Institute of Sciences. Megawati Soekarnoputri, the eldest daughter of Indonesia's founding president Sukarno and chairwoman of the unrecognized Indonesian Democratic Party, has managed to impress many of us again by calling on all Indonesians to stop defiling fallen president Soeharto. Speaking at a ceremony commemorating the day on which the nation's state philosophy Pancasila was born -- June 1, 1945 -- Megawati said defiling former leaders of the state runs against Pancasila which, among other things, advocates ``just and civilized humanitarianism''. ``Do we have to replace our state leaders through such treatment every time?'' Megawati asked her audience of several thousand, obviously referring to her own father's ouster by Soeharto in 1966. To be fair, Megawati is not the only, or even the first, opposition leader to have called for temperance in the public airing of anti-Soeharto sentiments following the strongman's forced retirement on May 21. Moslem leader Amien Rais made a similar appeal two days earlier and we can be sure that the same spirit of moderation and forgiveness exists among many others of the more reasonable and more mature of Indonesia's opposition leaders. What makes Megawati's appeal for moderation worth noting is the fact that it was made by the daughter of the deposed president Sukarno, a victim of almost identical circumstances which led to the birth of the New Order, headed by Soeharto. Unlike other opposition figures who have made similar appeals, Megawati and her family endured the same agony of being publicly defiled when her father, Sukarno, was ousted in the wake of the communist coup of 1965. Even after so many years, a sense of injury, perhaps even more than magnanimity, can be detected in the question she asked her audience: ``Do we have to treat former president Soeharto's family the way the nation treated us, Sukarno's family, in 1965?'' But apart from deep personal insight coming from experience, Megawati probably also remembered and appreciated the way Soeharto had in public always continued to accord Sukarno the respect he deserved as a founder of the nation. 'Mikul duwur mendem jero', which literally means carry your elders high and bury them deep, is a saying that is still honored by many Indonesians, the Javanese in particular. Megawati could only be observing this dictum when she made her appeal for Indonesians to stop bashing Soeharto. Indonesia's younger generation could see in this old tradition of chivalry a useful modern guide to engaging in politics without abandoning morality -- a useful general principle to remember if democracy is to survive and bloom. It is important, however, at this point to remember that civility must not stand in the way of justice. At this stage of developments, the public clamor concerns the wealth which Soeharto and his family are widely reported to have amassed during his more than three decades in power. The public's demands that this wealth be returned to the state in as far as it has been illegally acquired must in this context be given the proper attention they deserve. Just as much as the Soeharto clan, or their associates, have a right to be treated fairly, so the people have a right to reclaim what belongs to them. Indonesians at this stage of their country's history need the guidance of leaders who are not only sincerely committed to the cause of overall reform, but who are also mature and sensible enough to see the nation safely through these critical times. It is in this context that the calls for Indonesians to stop the Soeharto bashing must be seen as a welcome development.

Iranian judges order retrials for journalist and German on death row
Eds: UPDATES lead with journalist also getting retrial
TEHRAN, Iran (AP) _ Iranian judges have ordered retrials for a German businessman and an Iranian journalist who were condemned to death, state-run media reported Wednesday. The retrials mean that the death sentences against Helmut Hofer, a German businessman convicted of having sex with an Iranian woman, and Morteza Firoozi, an Iranian journalist convicted of espionage and adultery, have been set aside. New courts will issue their own verdicts and, if necessary, sentences. The chief justice's spokesman, Ali Abbassifard, said a new trial had been ordered for Hofer because he says he converted to Islam before the incident occurred, state-run radio reported. The retrial has already started. In the case of Firoozi, Abbassifard said the supreme court had ``major objections'' to his conviction, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. In January, an Iranian court sentenced Hofer, 54, to death after convicting him of violating Iranian law by having sex with a 26-year-old medical student, who was Muslim while he was not. Bonn has warned Tehran that if Hofer is executed, German-Iranian relations would deteriorate. Germany is Iran's biggest trading partner in the Europe Union. Last month, the chief justice, Ayatollah Mohammad Yazdi, said Hofer's case would be reviewed by the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court refused an appeal by Firoozi on May 10, the Iran News reported. Few details of Firoozi's case have emerged, but Yazdi said earlier this year that the journalist had been convicted of spying and several sexual offenses. Adultery and espionage are punishable by death under Iranian law. Firoozi, 40, is a former editor of the Iran News. He has been detained since May 1997. While there is no evidence that the government has influenced the decisions to retry Hofer and Firoozi, President Mohammad Khatami, a moderate who took office in August, is known to favor fewer death sentences than previous presidents.

JAKARTA (JP): The Indonesian Rowing Association pledged yesterday to soldier on with preparations for the 13th Asian Games despite financial and practice facility deficiencies. Head coach Budiman Setiawan said his 16 recruits had trained in a modest course at Jatiluhur reservoir in Purwakarta, West Java, since mid-February, but he was delighted by their enthusiasm and achievements. ``Some rowers managed to clock their best time of six minutes and 33 seconds in double sculls, a few seconds faster than their strongest opponents from China,'' an elated Budiman said after a meeting with the National Sports Council's training director Muhammad Hindarto. He added that in general the rowers improved on marks they set en route to winning last year's Southeast Asian Games by 10 seconds. ``To row in an undefined course is difficult but our athletes proved they could manage to clock fine times. Budiman said they would compete in more regattas in August. He predicted his team would dominate the competition thanks to the absence of the continent's rowing powerhouses China, South Korea and Kazakhstan. Earlier, Hindarto asked the national rowing team to take full advantage of the tryout to build their belief in themselves. ``Many of our athletes have failed to win in international competitions because they lack self-confidence.'' Indonesia has named rowing as one of the sports it will compete in at the Asian Games in Bangkok in December.

PETALING JAYA, Tues. - Industries can ask for exemption from stringent compliance in handling certain harzardous wastes if they can prove it would not pose a threat to the environment. Thus, they can ask for the removal of certain substances from the scheduled wastes list under proposed amendments to the Environmental Quality (Scheduled Wastes) Regulations, 1989. A Department of Environment officer said specific requests would be approved where justified, and confined to certain processes under a new concept of petition proposed under the amendments. There will be no blanket approval. If a request is granted, the industry does not have to go through stringent compliance procedures when handling and disposing of hazardous wastes. The handling, storage and movement of all scheduled wastes listed under the regulations are controlled and monitored by the Department of Environment. The regulations are being reviewed for the DOE to introduce more stringent control over hazardous waste management. The officer said the petition concept was being practised in the United States and that even the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and their Disposal had a review mechanism for listed wastes. ``Experience has shown that certain things need to be excluded. For instance, sludge is a scheduled waste because it contains heavy metal. ``If tests revealed that the content of heavy metal is insignificant, it need not go through stringent procedures,'' he said in an interview at the Towards a Better Understanding of Waste Management in Malaysia seminar. The half-day seminar is organised by the Malaysian Plastics Manufacturers Association's Plastic Waste Management Task Force. The DOE is also planning to create a new list under the regulations for wastes deemed ``less hazardous'' such as asbestos, low heavy metal sludges and calcium hydroxide sludge. The movement of these wastes will still be controlled but they do not have to be disposed of at a secured landfill, like other scheduled wastes. ``They can be disposed of at landfills of lower standard. ``Some of these wastes can be sent to recovery facilities. One example is gypsum, a new scheduled waste, which can be recycled to make partition boards,'' said the officer. Other amendments include imposing a time limit on factories wanting to store scheduled wastes on their premises. The DOE is proposing to limit the duration to 180 days, after which the factories will have either to treat the wastes or send them for disposal at secured landflls such as Kualiti Alam Sdn Bhd's integrated scheduled waste management plant at Bukit Nanas. Factories are currently permitted to store self-generated scheduled wastes, with no time limit, provided they have a licence from the DOE. DOE director-general Rosnani Ibarahim who launched the seminar said the department was also reviewing the existing list of scheduled wastes to harmonise it with the Basel Convention list. The convention's Fourth Conference of Parties (COP) in Kuching in March came up with new lists of wastes which clearly defined hazardous materials that needed to be banned. She said the proposed amendments would take several more months before they could be implemented. DOE will have to discuss the matter with Kualiti Alam before enforcing the amendments as the treatment plant has limited capacity. Other aspects to consider include existing accumulated waste and the amount generated annually. There is a backlog in the amount of scheduled waste that needs to be cleared and industries must be given time to comply with the new amendments. Rosnani said the construction of the Bukit Nanas treatment plant was on schedule and it would be launched next month.

Battling Belgians win 2-0 to compound Colombia's woes
By PAUL AMES Associated Press Writer
BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) _ Belgium demolished Colombia 2-0 Wednesday with a display of rugged determination and tight teamwork that added to the South American's pre-World Cup woes. Defeat in a rain-soaked King Baudouin Stadium followed Colombia's 3-1 mauling by Germany Saturday and disappointing draws against Scotland and Chile. By contrast, Belgium, going into its fifth consecutive World Cup finals, is looking better with every game. The Belgian defense blunted the attacking thrust of Faustino Asprilla and Freddy Rincon and flashes of brilliance from Luc Nilis and Marc Wilmots belied the dour reputation of the ``Red Devils.'' ``The goals are coming,'' said Wilmots. ``We're playing very fast, we're playing very well.'' Wilmots, who plays his club soccer at Germany's Schalke 04, supplied the best moment of the match. Roaming the wide, open spaces left by his Colombian markers, the stylish midfielder picked up a loose ball some 25 meters (yards) and rifled in a right foot shot that soared into the top corner of the net beyond Oscar Cordoba's despairing dive for 2-0 in the 31st minute. Danny Boffin had already shown up the porous Colombian defense in the 16th minute racing in unmarked to head home a Luis Oliveira pass from pointblank range for 1-0. Colombia struck back with more conviction early in the second half. Asprilla was particularly dangerous, twice forcing diving saves from goalie Filip de Wilde. But the Belgians soon reestablished control of a bad-tempered match that saw four Belgians and two Colombians receive yellow cards. In a battle of midfield veterans, the wild-haired Colombian Carlos Valdarama, heading for this third World Cup, was largely outshone by Enzo Scifo, on his way to his fourth. JAKARTA (JP): Shares and the rupiah continued to lose ground for the second consecutive day yesterday, with stock prices on the Jakarta Stock Exchange (JSX) down 3.4 percent. Currency dealers said trading of the rupiah remained thin as most market operators were discouraged by the country's political uncertainty. ``Some operators are questioning when and how the country will hold its next poll next year,'' a chief dealer with a local private bank said. He said the rupiah closed at 11,650/11,850 to the U.S. dollar in the spot market after touching a day low of 11,900 in the morning session when a demonstration was held at the U.S. embassy here. It was slightly lower than the 11,600 close the previous day. Dealers said there was no reason for the rupiah to strengthen against the dollar in the near future due to the country's gloomy economic outlook and political uncertainty. The rupiah is expected to weaken to 14,000 levels with positive incentive in the market. ``Trading activities were thin as most people are still waiting for the release of the IMF-brokered loan package,'' the dealer said. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is expected to disburse the next US$1 billion part of its total $43 billion bailout package this month to help the country in its dire economic situation. ``The IMF loan is the only positive news for the country's market,'' the dealer said. The IMF's director for Asia Pacific, Hubert Neiss, was scheduled to submit his report to the IMF executive director Michel Camdessus last Monday. The fund's executive board will make a decision based on the report. Mirroring the sinking rupiah, stock prices on the Jakarta Stock Exchange (JSX) fell to 399.59 points on a total turnover of 148.48 million shares changing hands on the regular market worth Rp 175.45billion (US$15.25 million). A broker with Bali Securities, Hendra Sunarto, said trading activities remained sluggish throughout the day investors were still worried about entering the country's market for political and economic reasons. He said stocks of companies linked to former president Soeharto's family and the giant Salim Group conglomerate remained under heavy selling pressure amid a backlash against the Soeharto clan. ``Most investors continued to discard the stocks to cut the likelihood of more possible losses.'' He said foreign fund managers remained on the sidelines as major foreign brokerage houses like SBC Warburg, WICarr and Merrill Lynch securities continued to place large selling orders on the stocks. The stock price of Bimantara Citra, controlled by Soeharto's second eldest son Bambang Trihatmodjo, fell Rp 25 to Rp 325 on a total turnover of 5.93 million shares, toll road operator PT Citra Marga Nusaphala Persada (CMNP) closed unchanged at Rp 375 on 4.40 million shares, stock prices of noodle maker PT Indofood Sukses Makmur shed Rp 425 to Rp 1,150 on a total turnover of 9.13 million shares and the stock price of cement maker PT Indocement Tunggal Perkasa slid Rp 25 to Rp 2,875 on 442,000 shares. An analyst with a local securities firm said the country's persistent political and economic uncertainty led most foreign fund managers to keep their distance. ``There is no reason for foreign fund managers to enter the market. All they can do now is watch our political and economic situation.''
