JERUSALEM (AP) - Syrian and American officials denied an Israel TV report Wednesday that negotiators had met for the first time to discuss a resumption of Syrian-Israel peace talks. The TV said three Israeli negotiators and three Syrian representatives including the Syrian ambassador to Washington Walid Moualem held four days of meetings at a think tank run by former U.S. Secretary of State James Baker III in Houston, Texas. ``There was never any meeting. There wasn't even a handshake,'' Moualem said in Washington. ``I just gave a lecture in which I spoke about the necessity of resuming the talks (with Israel) from where we left off.'' Israel TV said Baker and U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Martin Indyk were both present at the meetings which dealt with a return to the negotiating table both sides left over two years ago. Edward Djerejian, who served as a U.S. ambassador to both Israel and Syria said both sides attended a conference at the James A. Baker Institute for Public Policy at Rice University. ``It did not constitute direct negotiations between the parties. It was an opportunity for experts to look at the past, look where we are now and explore options to move this Israeli-Syrian track forward,'' he told The Associated Press in Houston. A senior U.S. administration official, who asked that his name not be used, said the event was an ``exchange of views on the peace process.'' ``It's true that for the first time in a long time Syrians and Israelis were in the same room, including government officials but there was no negotiations,'' the official said. Syria wants the Golan Heights back, which Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast war, in exchange for a peace agreement. Talks on a territorial compromise with Israel's previous Labor-led government broke off in March 1996 and never resumed. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has called on Syria to returned to talks by has also said that Israel should retain control over the strategic heights for security reasons. Israel TV said the secret talks this week in Houston were attended by Netanyahu's chief policy aide Uzi Arad, Itamar Rabinovitch, a former ambassador and negotiator with Syria and reserve general Uzi Sagay. Djerejian said the policy institute would release an analysis of the Israeli-Syrian relationship and prospects for the future at the end of the month. JAKARTA (JP): Bank Indonesia (BI) announced yesterday that its net international reserves (NIR) as of May 29 totaled US$14.63 billion, a decline of $61.8 million from the previous week's level. The central bank said in a statement the NIR position was still higher than the minimum level allowed by the International Monetary Fund. BI added that its gross foreign assets as of the same date totaled $19.03 billion, a slight decrease from the previous level of $19.10 billion. The decline was mainly due to investment in foreign exchange, it said. BI also said its net domestic assets (NDA) were valued at minus Rp 34.44 trillion (US$2.94 billion), indicating a monetary contraction of Rp 1.86 trillion against the previous level. It said the contraction was caused by open market operations, net claims on the government and increasing net claims on the Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency (IBRA) and credit liquidity. The May 29 level was still within the IMF limits, the bank said. An open market operation mainly done through the selling of Bank Indonesia's short-term promissory notes (SBIs) and rupiah intervention resulted in a significant contraction of Rp 20.95 trillion compared to the previous week's level, it said. BI added the bank liquidity withdrawal primarily came from the state-owned banks and foreign and joint-venture banks. The contraction sent the net position of the open market operation as of May 29 to a negative Rp 64.21 trillion. BI's net claim on the government during the same period contributed to an expansion of Rp 1.41 trillion, causing a negative of Rp 36.41 trillion, mainly for the payment of government employees' salaries, the bank said. BI's net claim on IBRA was Rp 124.63 trillion, an increase of Rp 22.08 trillion compared to the previous week's level. This was mainly related to the increase in liquidity injection to several banks under IBRA including Bank Central Asia, BI said. It added that the amount of liquidity credit increased by Rp 1.24 trillion, compared to the previous week's level, to reach Rp 19.14 trillion on May 29. The increase was primarily used to support the government's program to provide essential food items by the State Logistics Agency (Bulog), BI said. With the above development, reserve money fell by Rp 2.30 trillion, compared to the previous week's level, to Rp 67.96 trillion, the bank said. THE introduction of a corporate management code is vital to safeguard the credibility of the local bourse, Deputy Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim told the Dewan Negara yesterday. The guidelines, which include undertaking restructuring, would be able to curb the strong speculation element in the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange. He stressed the Government's seriousness in creating viable corporate governance would help protect the interest of both local and foreign investors. Deputy Finance Minister Datuk Wong See Wah had told the House last Monday a high-level financial committee on corporate management had been formed to draw up the best corporate practices and training programmes for board of directors of companies and their shareholders. Led by Treasury secretary-general Datuk Dr Aris Othman, the committee is scheduled to submit a report to Anwar who is also Finance Minister by the end of this month. Anwar said: ``We are concerned that the current trend of share trading is closely associated with gambling and speculative activities, thus failing to portray the actual value of the listed companies. ``Although the sales and purchase of shares are open to everyone, we should not treat our stock market like a casino. ``The move (to introduce the management code) is inevitable because there were instances in the past where public-listed companies conspired with broker firms in the trading of their shares. ``This has eroded the confidence of investors,'' he said in reply to Senator Mastika Junaidah Husin. ``I expect the Securities Commission to continue taking action or pursuing their investigations on broker firms which are not ethical in their trading conduct,'' added Anwar. To the original question by Senator Tan Swee Hueng, Anwar said as of last April, disciplinary action had been taken against 16 KLSE-registered remisiers for non-adherence of its rules and regulations. ``Among their offences were not working full time with the member stockbroking firms, getting involved in other businesses, becoming directors or shareholders of other broking firms, not being efficient and honest, and abusing their clients' accounts. ``To counter all these, our economy needs an effective corporate governance with emphasis on good management ethics'' he said. Anwar said the remisiers concerned had been fined between RM3,000 and RM6,000 each. ``Apart from being fined, they can also have their licences suspended or revoked from the dealers' list.'' There were 7,351 remisiers registered with the KLSE as of May 12. Asked by Datuk Abdul Aziz Abdul Rahman what action could be taken against broking firms which misappropriated deposits of their remisiers, Anwar said: ``The matter has been brought up by the remisiers' association, and is being probed by the SC and KLSE. ``Our initial investigation revealed that there was carelessness on the part of the broking firms.''

KUALA LUMPUR, Tues. - The Education Ministry today issued a stern warning to undergraduates not to carry out ragging activities. Its Minister Datuk Seri Najib Tun Razak said the ministry viewed cases of excessive orientation acts seriously and would take disciplinary action against those found to have participated in them. On a student in Universiti Putra Malaysia who had dropped out after claiming to be a victim of ragging, Najib said the ministry would investigate the case after receiving a report from the university. ``We will take action only after investigations have been conducted,'' Najib told reporters after launching a book Masyarakat Madani: Satu Tinjauan Awal at Universiti Malaya. Written by several academicians, among them UM lecturers, the book expounds the meaning of the word ``civil society''. On May 26, 20-year-old R. Prasath from Ipoh, Perak left UPM after a ragging incident on May 22. Prasath alleged that five youths, whom he believed to be seniors, had pulled down their pants and instructed him to perform oral sex. UPM vice-chancellor Professor Datuk Dr Syed Jalaluddin Syed Salim had appealed to the student and his parents to come forward to assist the university in its investigations. He said Prasath had informed the university authorities of the alleged incident without leaving any forwarding address. Prasath had also not filed a report. A first-year student in Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia had also claimed to be a victim of ragging. UKM vice-chancellor Professor Datuk Dr Anuwar Ali had said that the university's student affairs department would investigate the case and take disciplinary action against those responsible. On matriculation courses franchised to private colleges, Najib said if it was found that the colleges did not meet the standards set by the National Accreditation Board, they could be ordered to suspend their courses. Najib said the criteria used in selecting private colleges for franchise programmes were sufficiency of infrastructure and adequate finances. He added that one benefit of matriculation courses conducted by private colleges was the size of classes. ``The size of classes at colleges is small, about 40 students per class, and this allows lecturers to give more attention to each student.'' Najib also announced that UM would be conducting an elective subject on civil society for Social Science and Pengajian Islam students.

BC-Germany-Train Derails, 20th Ld-Writethru
At least 100 dead in high-speed German train crash
Eds: AMS; RECASTS, UPDATES with details CHANGES BYLINE. With BC-Germany-High Speed Train AP Photos By TONY CZUCZKA Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ Germany's fastest train derailed Wednesday after the lead locomotive uncoupled from passenger cars, killing at least 100 people as the cars hurtled into an overpass and piled one on top of the other. Traveling at a speed of 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour, the passenger cars crumpled into each other and collapsed the bridge spanning the tracks. Houses just 50 meters away were unscathed, protected by an embankment. The cause of Germany's worst train accident since World War II remained unclear late Wednesday, and officials were unsure how many people were actually aboard Hamburg-bound ICE 884. Lower-Saxony state officials said 100 bodies had been recovered and at least 300 people were injured. But rescue coordinators, speaking at a news conference, reported 40 injured. The accounting of dead and injured was hampered by the severity of the mangled mess. Rescue workers picked through the wreckage with a crane, and pried open the metal siding with blow torches. Survivors were found among the tangle of metal, including a 10-old-girl pulled from the wreckage an hour and a half after the 11 a.m. crash. All 13 cars and the rear engine derailed, and splintered glass covered the scene. Luggage was piled next to the wreckage, and residents who described the crash as an explosion reported survivors wandering away in shock. Passengers knew something was wrong 10 minutes before the impact, according to one survivor's account. ``There was an uncomfortable rattling and I had the feeling that maybe something was lying on the tracks. People looked at each other, shocked, and then it was as if `That's over now,''' Wolf-Ruediger Schliebener, who was seated in the rear of the train, told German television SAT 1. ``Then it (the noise) started up again and I held on and ducked down because one had the feeling of being thrown through the air, and then thank God it came to a standstill.'' Schliebener, who was seated in one of three cars thrown to the side, exited through a door with other passengers. The locomotive driver, oblivious to the catastrophe behind him, continued driving through the small train station at Eschede, 50 kilometers (35 miles) north of Hanover. The station master engaged the emergency brakes, bringing the engine to a halt two kilometers (more than a mile) from the overpass. The gravity of the accident brought condolences from leaders worldwide. Chancellor Helmut Kohl, informed of the tragedy after arriving in Italy for meetings with Premier Romano Prodi, appeared shaken by the news and called his visit short. ``So many dead ... It's a tragedy,'' Kohl, his face tight, said in Bologna with Prodi at his side. ``Excuse me, but I must return home right away. ``It could be the biggest rail tragedy that ever happened in Germany. Do you realize what that means? So many dead, hundreds of injured.'' The accident was the worst on Germany's premier high-speed ICE line, inaugurated in 1991 and prized for both its speed and safety. The worst previous ICE crash was on Oct. 12, 1991 when a train ran into six workers repairing tracks who did not hear its approach. A 1967 rail accident near Magdeburg in then-East Germany, killed 94 people when a crossing barrier closed on a rail tanker filled with gasoline, causing it to explode and spreading fire into passenger cars. The worst accident in western Germany was in 1971, when a train carrying children on a field trip collided with a freight train, killing 46 people. An account of the lead locomotive decoupling, given by chief regional rescue coordinator Klaus Rathert at a news conference, conflicted with earlier reports suggesting that an auto had plunged into the train from the overpass. Police said an automobile was crushed beneath the wreckage, but it was unclear where the car was parked at the time of the accident. They said it was probably sitting along the tracks, not on the overpass. Police spokesman Joachim Lindenberg told ARD television that the auto belonged to a rail employee who was working along the tracks. That account was not confirmed by Rathert or Deutsche Bahn officials. Views of the wreckage offered no clear clues as to what caused the accident. The nose of the rear engine stuck from under the bridge, and three derailed cars were piled on each other beneath the collapsed overpass. Survivors were taken to hospitals throughout the region. The Red Cross chartered six buses to take most of the uninjured to Hamburg, spokesman Harald Krueger said. More than 1,100 rescue workers were at the scene, including trauma surgeons and border patrol personnel who helped free passengers trapped inside the rail cars. Hundreds of people, moved by word of the tragedy, gathered at Red Cross stations across the country to donate blood. The ICE train connects all major cities at speed up to 280 kilometers (175 miles) an hour, cutting travel time from Munich to Hamburg - a distance of more than 950 kilometers (about 600 miles) by more than two hours. The Munich-Hamburg train that crashed Wednesday was a first-generation ICE model powered by two electric-powered locomotives, one at front and one at rear, pulling 14 passenger cars with a capacity of 759 passengers. At top speed the train requires 2.8 kilometers (1.7 miles) to come to an emergency stop. (cb-gb-aet)

BC-Germany-Train Derails-Scene, 1st Ld-Writethru
Survivor recalls ``rattling'' just before train crash
Eds: AMS, UPDATES throughout with quotes from survivor, details. With BC-Germany-Train Derails By CLAUS-PETER TIEMANN Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ One survivor said heavy ``rattling'' shocked passengers about 10 minutes before Wednesday's train derailment in northern Germany. The rattling subsided, then restarted a moment before train cars jumped the tracks at 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour and jackknifed into the base of an overpass, killing at least 100 people in Germany's deadliest train wreck in three decades. ``I held on and ducked down because you had the feeling you'd be thrown through the air,'' Wolf-Ruediger Schliebener, a passenger from a rear car, told SAT 1 TV. ``Thank God, it came to a standstill,'' Schliebener said. ``Then I saw in the distance to the front where all the cars were chaotically laying all over.'' Then, he heard the screaming. Several passenger cars had wedged together, some sticking up at various angles and others buried under the overpass, which had collapsed. Tallies of the injured ranged from dozens to hundreds. Within an hour the nearby small, red-brick town of Eschede _ about 50 kilometers (35 miles) north of Hanover _ was swarming with fire trucks, rescue workers and volunteers. Helicopters carried the injured to hospitals. Rescue workers blasted through wrecked cars with blow torches in their search for bodies and trapped survivors. Officials said the locomotive had decoupled from the high-speed inter-city train on a straight stretch of track near Eschede. But it remained unclear what caused the accident. Schliebener said that ``ten minutes before (the crash) there was an uncomfortable rattling and I had the feeling that maybe something was lying on the tracks.'' ``People looked at each other shocked, and then it was as if: `That's over now.''' But then the rattling ``started up again.'' Hannelore Domkewitz saw the train speed past from her kitchen window where she stood peeling potatoes. She had just a moment to reflect that it was moving faster than usual. ``Then there was a loud boom, a dust cloud, and then silence,'' Domkewitz said. The silence didn't last long. There were screams from the tracks, about 100 yards (300 feet) away. Domkewitz ran toward the wreck as people with bloodied hands staggered toward her. Domkewitz ran back to get blankets and bed sheets to cover the injured and dead. ``But there were also survivors who went by with their luggage. They were all in shock,'' Domkewitz said, her voice breaking. Mark Draeger heard it too. ``It was like an explosion! Yet very different, because it was a terrible crushing sound,'' said the 20-year-old aid worker who lived nearby and rushed to the wreckage. Manfred Thiel, who was on his way to work, grabbed a ladder and helped the injured to safety. He stood by as rescuers pulled a 10-year-old girl from the wreckage alive. Sgt. Phil Forsyth and 20 other British soldiers from the 2nd Battalion of the Royal Fusiliers, based at the nearby German town of Celle, were among the first to arrive at the scene. Forsyth, speaking in a BBC interview, said: ``On arrival we were met by an horrific site ... All the carriages were absolutely mangled; it was a mess and very sad to see.'' Forsyth, who was in the British military for 13 years and fought in the Persian Gulf war, added: ``It is definitely one of the worst scenes I have ever seen, if not the worst.'' (gb-cb-im)

THEIR mission is to feed but the people whom the African Diplomat Women's Group are helping to feed are not ordinary members of society. They are drug addicts, prostitutes, alcoholics, abandoned children and the homeless. This was proved during a fund-raising and charity show at the Royal Commonwealth Club in Damansara last Saturday. These groups of people are usually looked upon with disgust and hate by the majority of the more fortunate ones. The ADWG wants to change all this and it has started a Street Evangelism Ministry, which works with the Gospel of Salvation Mission Society and also J's Corner. J's Corner co-ordinator Roko Rothmund said the ministry undertakes the feeding programme every Saturday and Sunday. The programme is currently operating in Chow Kit in Kuala Lumpur. The group plans to spread its wings to other States which are facing the same problem. Their mission is to provide a ministry to broken and destitute people, to provide rehabilitation, promote discipline as well as reconciliation for those who are in need of love and care. ``Many come not only for the food and clothing, but also because it is one of the rare places where they are treated with love and care,'' Rothmund said. She said in view of the increasing number of destitutes, and the rising demand for the services provided by the programme, the mission is seriously contemplating the establishment of a permanent Home for Destitutes. The ADWG has raised RM2,400 for this purpose and the amount was presented to Rothmund. At the charity show, the African women paraded their traditional clothing while their children performed an African dance that symbolises joy and merriment while guests had the chance to enjoy African food. Among the participating African countries were Mauritius, South Africa, Namibia, Guinea, Zimbabwe and Fiji Island. Also present were Namibia High Commission counsellor and deputy head of mission Henry Simon Line and wife Madeline.

KUALA LUMPUR, Tues. - Malaysia will host the Commonwealth Press Union's biennial conference themed The Eye of the Tiger and the editors' forum preceding it in October. The conference, expected to be attended by over 150 delegates from the 53 Commonwealth countries, will be opened by Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad. Commonwealth Secretary-General Chief Emeka Anyaoku will also address the conference to be held at the new Mandarin Oriental Hotel. The editors' forum will be held at Universiti Sains Malaysia in Penang from Oct 21 to 23, and the conference in Kuala Lumpur from Oct 26 to 29. CPU's executive director Mark Robinson said the decision to hold the two events at different venues was to enable the editors to see the attractions of Malaysia. ``The first editors' forum was successfully held in Capetown, South Africa two years ago and we decided to repeat it in Malaysia this year,'' he said at a Press conference at the National Press Club today. For the conference, the opening day will focus on the problems and achievements of Southeast Asia including the economic situation, socio-political issues, the environment and information superhighway. The rest of the conference will see discussion on Press freedom and human rights, the Press union's future role, and the future of news and traditional media. Its Malaysian section chairman Datuk A. Kadir Jasin said Malaysia was proud to host the conference for the first time. ``It's an important conference as it brings together the media of countries which have a shared history. The Press union is a component of the co-operation within the Commonwealth,'' said Kadir who is also New Straits Times Sdn Bhd group editor. A major sponsor of the conference and forum is Malaysia Airlines which will provide free passage for 20 delegates from developing countries and special rates for the others.

TEARS welled up in the eyes of Farahida Mohamed Farid. The project manager of the National Cancer Council (Makna) wiped them away before she could speak about Mohammad Shafiq Sabaruddin, the four-year-old cancer patient who died on May 25. It was an emotionally-touching interview with a woman who organises fund-raising campaigns to establish the Makna Cancer Institute, the first of its kind in Malaysia, by the year 2000. To date, about RM25 million has been raised towards the RM100 million target. ``Shafiq was supposed to be one of the first patients to use the facilities at our new institute,'' said Farahida. Shafiq's story is a sad one. He never knew his father and his mother, a prostitute and drug user who abandoned him after birth. Shafiq was taken in by a drug-addict couple but they neglected him. No one knew this little boy was suffering from neuroblastoma (cancer of the nerves in his brain which resulted in a tumour). After his foster parents were arrested, he was cared for by a good Samaritan who took pity on him. All this while, Shafiq was getting sicker. Then on Aug 3 last year, he was admitted to hospital and doctors confirmed that he had a brain tumour. The Welfare Department referred him to the cancer centre, but his condition deteriorated rapidly. The pressure from the tumour caused his head to swell and his eyes to bulge and he was constantly crying and in pain. Despite treatment, Shafiq died last week. Makna is organising a charity film premiere of City Of Angels at Smile- UA Cineplex in the new UE3 Plaza (Plaza Uncang Emas 3) in Cheras on June 14 (four days before its nationwide opening). It is dedicating the show to the memory of Shafiq. ``We had planned to bring him for the screening,'' said Farahida. Seats have been allocated for cancer patients, underprivileged children and invited guests at the premiere. The screening is also dedicated to one of the film's producers, Dawn Steel, who died of breast cancer last December. The project was made possible when Warner Bros (M) Sdn Bhd approached the organisation and offered its assistance after learning of its fund-raising project. Smile-UA Cineplex Holdings Sdn Bhd and UE3 Plaza were roped in later. Makna, set up on Nov 10, 1994, is a non-governmental and non-profit organisation with the sole purpose of providing assistance to cancer sufferers. ``Cancer treatment isn't cheap,'' says Farahida. ``On the average, a patient will have to spend at least RM20,000 once he or she has been diagnosed with cancer. With the setting up of the institute, we hope to help more people, particularly those who cannot afford the cost of treatment.'' The institute will also organise seminars and talks on cancer prevention, educate the public about early detection, and be involved in cancer research. The patron of the charity screening is Datin Seri Dr Wan Azizah Wan Ismail, wife of Deputy Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim. She is also Makna patron.

BC-Israel-Palestinians, 1st Ld-Writethru,0592
U.S. ambassador: announcement on U.S. peace initiative in days minister in grafs 5-6
Eds: UPDATES with comment from Netanyahu graf 4, transportation By DINA KRAFT Associated Press Writer
TEL AVIV, Israel (AP) _ The United States expects Israel to reach a decision on a West Bank troop withdrawal within days, not weeks, as suggested by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, the U.S. ambassador to Israel said Wednesday. Ambassador Edward Walker said that while the United States has not given Israel a deadline to accept a U.S. proposal for a troop withdrawal from 13 percent of the West Bank, ``there is a very short time frame.'' Netanyahu told lawmakers Tuesday that he expected to have made a decision on an Israeli troop pullback by the end of July, before parliament goes into summer recess, according to legissday. However, far-right coalition partners have warned Netanyahu that they would bring down his government over a 13 percent troop pullback, and Netanyahu is reluctant to accept the U.S. plan. But Shaul Yaahalom, a member of the right-wing National Religious Party which holds nine key seats in Netanyahu's 61-120 majority in parliament, told Israel TV that a coalition collapse could be avoided. Yaahalom, who serves as transportation minister, said that his party could vote against the withdrawal in Cabinet but abstain from a no-confidence vote in parliament, in order to keep Netanyahu in power while voicing their opposition to the withdrawal. Walker said Wednesday that the United States will soon make a decision on whether to pursue its peace initiative. If a failure is announced, Israel would bear the brunt of the blame because the Palestinians have accepted the U.S. plan. ``It (the decision) is in a matter of days rather than weeks, but precisely what day and what hour and so on I have no idea exactly. It depends how the progress goes,'' Walker said. Last month, Israel already ignored one U.S. deadline, and Palestinian Higher Education Minister Hanan Ashrawi said Wednesday that Washington displayed ``a lack of will to stand firm in the face of Israel's intransigence.'' On Tuesday, U.S. envoy Thomas Pickering asked Jordanian and Saudi Arabian leaders to delay plans for an Arab summit for another week to allow the American initiative to play itself out. The Palestinians are pushing for an Arab summit that would conclude with an announcement that the Arab world is suspending the normalization of ties with Israel as long as Netanyahu does not carry out the peace agreement already signed. Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat traveled to Oman on Wednesday to lobby for support among Gulf State leaders to convene an Arab summit. Palestinians have said that they will push for the summit even if Israel does accept the U.S. proposals. In London, U.S. Mideast envoy Dennis Ross met Wednesday with two top Palestinian officials to discuss the troop withdrawal. According to the Maariv newspaper, Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai and Infrastructures Minister Ariel Sharon declined an invitation to attend the meeting because the government has not yet decided on the scope of a troop pullback.

BC-Tiger Fund, HFR,0238
Emergency fund for Siberian tiger makes first move The World Wildlife Fund is known as the World Wide Fund for Nature outside the U.S.
Eds: EMBARGOED until 0001 GMT Thursday, June 4, time set by source.
GLAND, Switzerland (AP) _ A new fund to help the endangered Siberian tiger is moving to aid fire-fighting efforts at two nature reserves in eastern Russia, the World Wildlife Fund said Wednesday. An allocation of some dlrs 20,000 is intended to buy and repair fire-fighting vehicles and other equipment in the Lazovsky and Sikhote-Alin reserves, home to the most of the surviving 425 to 475 wild Siberian tigers. Unusually dry weather conditions in the area, near the Sea of Japan, have led to forest fires which ``have already destroyed over 2,000 hectares (4,900 acres) of prime tiger land,'' the WWF said in a statement. Dry weather is set to continue through the summer, with a high risk of more fires, it added. ``It is better to move now when the situation has not reached gargantuan proportions than to wait and witness a serious environmental catastrophe,'' said Jean-Pierre d'Huart, manager of WWF's International Species Unit. The Tiger Emergency Fund was set up in January by the WWF and the World Conservation Union. It is intended as a ``rapid-response mechanism'' for dealing with any events increasing the threats to the tigers' survival.

As Kosovo Albanians flood over border, their leaders plead for help Albanian official.
Eds: UPDATES with Red Cross requesting access; comments from ethnic AP Photos By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Ethnic Albanian leaders pleaded with Western officials Wednesday for military intervention to halt what they said is a deliberate Serb strategy of forced expulsions from Kosovo, as more refugees poured over the border to Albania. The request came with no sign of a letup in the Serbs' offensive aimed at smashing resistance to their authority in the secessionist province of southern Serbia, where ethnic Albanians outnumber Serbs 10-to-1. UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ In a move that could have far-reaching effects, North Korea has agreed to a plan to decentralize some of its agricultural sector and allow small farmers to sell a portion of their crops wherever they can find the best price. ``They are going into what they call `modernization' but it cannot happen overnight. But Lemaire said the North Koreans were reluctant to take steps which might endanger the system of social controls and benefits which has been the hallmark of its communist system. The plan, formally presented last week at a two-day conference in Geneva, allows greater autonomy in decision-making for rural agricultural cooperatives, allows cooperatives to develop trade among themselves, creates a system of small-scale credits and permits private households to develop small-scale commerce. ``So they have private plots and they sell the produce to whichever gives the best price _ the cooperative or these farmers' markets,'' Lemaire said. ``Once you start injecting money at that level, it can only go one way.'' Lemaire said the degree of cooperation between North Korean and U.N. officials had improved dramatically over the last two years as more international attention, generated by the food crisis, has been directed at the North. ``People are also much more open, people go to the markets, it's a tremendous change,'' he said. But he said international agencies are still denied regular access to about 20 percent of the country _ mainly military zones along the borders with South Korea and China.

ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ Hurtling with a momentum that piled train cars one atop another in twisted heaps of steel, Germany's fastest passenger train derailed and jackknifed Wednesday when the lead locomotive broke loose. State officials said at least 100 people were killed. Traveling at a speed of 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour, car after car slammed into an overpass, bringing the bridge crashing down upon the wreckage and the dead and wounded. Houses just 50 yards (150 feet) 150 feet away were unscathed, protected by an embankment. The cause of Germany's worst train accident since World War II remained unclear late Wednesday, and officials were unsure how many people were aboard Hamburg-bound ICE 884. Lower-Saxony state officials said at least 100 people were killed and at least 300 people injured. But rescue coordinators, speaking at a news conference, reported 40 injured. Police at the scene said 90 people had been hurt. Police spokesman Joachim Lindenberg said 73 bodies were recovered and three more located. He said more bodies ``will certainly'' be found in two coaches still buried beneath the collapsed overpass. The accounting of dead and injured was hampered by the severity of the mangled mess. Rescue workers picked through the wreckage with a crane, and sliced open the metal siding with blow torches. Survivors were found among the tangle of metal, including a 10-old-girl pulled from the wreckage an hour and a half after the 11 a.m. crash. But as rescue efforts continued into the night, officials said the chance of finding new survivors was slight. Twelve passenger cars and the rear engine derailed, and splintered glass covered the scene. Luggage was piled next to the wreckage, and residents who described the crash as an explosion reported survivors wandering away in shock. Passengers knew ...10th graf pvs

BC-Mexico-Chiapas Raid,0528
Mexican police, army raid rebel-supporting town; arrest 141
AP Photos planned By ALEJANDRO RUIZ GUZMAN Associated Press Writer
NICOLAS RUIZ, Mexico (AP) _ One thousand police officers and soldiers swarmed into this small southern Mexican town early Wednesday, firing tear gas, breaking down doors and arresting 141 rebel sympathizers they said had ``held the town hostage.'' People scattered through the streets and hundreds fought police with poles during a raid that Gov. Roberto Albores Guillen insisted was intended only to ``bring the town into conformity with the law.'' ``We don't care if they're sympathizers of the Zapatista National Liberation Army or if they're Muslims. All we care about is that they respect the law,'' he said in a telephone interview from the state capital, Tuxtla Gutierrez. The governor said the raid was peaceful, but television images showed state police kicking people and beating them with wooden poles. One image showed the face of a villager covered in blood. Authorities said no one was injured, but townsfolk said dozens of people were hurt, most of them by tear gas. Some of the officers carried assault rifles, and they broke down doors to drag suspects from their beds in the early morning raid. Helicopters flew overhead. The raid was similar to two others carried out in the last two months in the villages of Taniperlas and Agua Tinta, both sympathetic to the Zapatistas. Twelve foreigners were arrested and deported during the Taniperlas raid, and a group of Italians who denounced alleged human rights abuses during the raid were later deported for visiting the village without permission. Albores Guillen denied that Nicolas Ruiz supported the rebels, blaming a ``small minority'' of the town's residents for intimidating the rest of the town of 8,000 people, 60 miles (100 kilometers) east of Tuxtla Gutierrez. He said that group didn't allow others to choose their political parties, denied them religious freedom, made unilateral decisions and wouldn't allow the government into the town to build a road and a health clinic. He said they also ``very violently'' expelled 33 families from the town who ``didn't agree with their ideas.'' Most of the people arrested were supporters of the leftist opposition Democratic Revolution Party. Albores Guillen said the raid came only after they refused to negotiate. ``Hopefully we won't have to conduct any more raids, as long as these groups understand that we're in a new Chiapas,'' he said. The governor was appointed in January after his predecessor was forced to resign over alleged government complicity in the massacre of 45 men, women and children in another village that sympathized with the rebels. Like his predecessor and all other governors in Chiapas' history, Albores Guillen is a member of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party. The rebels staged a brief uprising in 1994, demanding greater rights for Mexico's poor Indians. Peace talks stalled after the government backed off of a treaty the two sides had signed on greater Indian autonomy.

BC-Sports-Soccer-Brazil-Romario,0319
Romario returns to Brazil
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil (AP) _ Greeted by a large crowd of cheering fans and friends, striker Romario returned to Brazil on Wednesday after being dropped from the Brazilian World Cup squad because of an injured right calf. ``I went to France full of happiness and surrounded by friends,'' Romario said shortly after arriving at Rio de Janeiro's international airport. ``I return alone and full of sadness.'' ``My dream of helping Brazil win its fifth world cup was shattered, he added. ``There was a lack of patience. I know how my body functions and I know I would have the physical conditions to play.'' Romario said he plans to be fully recovered in 15 days when he expects to resume playing for Rio's Flamengo. Some of the fans cried when they saw Romario. Others shouted invectives against Zico, the team's coordinator whom they said was responsible for Romario's exclusion from the squad. But Romario refused to blame Zico, saying the decision to drop him from the team was taken jointly by the team's technical commission. A poll conducted by the O Globo newspaper showed that 50 percent of Rio de Janeiro's residents agrees that Romario should have been dropped from the team. Another 45.5 percent said he should have remained. The poll also showed that 50.1 percent of those interviewed believed that without Romario the national squad has less chances of winning the World Cup. A total of 407 people were interviewed in eight different regions of the city. No margin of error was given. O Globo's sports commentator Renato Mauricio Prado said the decision to drop Romario was a hasty one. ``I would have given him more time to recover so that he could at least play in the second round - the moment of truth when his absence will be most felt.''

FRANKFURT, Germany (AP) _ Condolence letters from world leaders poured into Germany in the wake of Wednesday's train accident that left at least 100 people dead. Chancellor Helmut Kohl broke short an official visit to Italy. ``So many dead. It's a tragedy. Excuse me, but I must return home right away,'' a rigid-faced Kohl said after dining with Premier Romano Prodi. Prodi told Kohl that Italy felt close to Germany in its moment of grief. The high-speed, Hamburg-bound train derailed Wednesday, hurtling into an overpass, with passenger cars crumpling together like an accordion. Officials were unsure how many people were on board. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu also offered his condolences to Kohl. ``In the name of the state of Israel and myself I wish to express to you and the German people my deep heartfelt sorrows for the loss of life in this tragic accident,'' Netanyahu wrote in a telegram. ``We sympathize with the the bereaved and mourning.'' Japanese Emperor Akihito, on a three-day visit to Denmark, expressed his ``deepest sympathy to Germany,'' spokesman Kazuo Chiba said. British Prime Minister Tony Blair and French President Jacques Chirac also sent condolences. Chirac said his deepest sympathies were with the families of the victims. (me/im)

BC-Philippines-American Airlines,0221
Philippine Airlines, American Airlines Code-Sharing Approved
MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ Philippine Airlines said Wednesday the U.S. Department of Transportation has approved its code-sharing agreement with American Airlines. The approval paves the way for the launching of joint services by the two airlines as early as August, an arrangement that would likely result in cost savings for both, PAL said. PAL said the two airlines will jointly operate scheduled services between Manila and five major U.S. points _ Chicago, Dallas/Fort Worth, Miami, New York and Washington D.C. _ via either Los Angeles or San Francisco. PAL will fly passengers on the Manila-Los Angeles and the Manila-San Francisco legs, while American Airlines will operate flights to the five U.S. points from Los Angeles and San Francisco. It would mean seamless travel between Manila and the five U.S. points for transpacific passengers, PAL said. The two airlines are working out the operational aspects of the code-sharing agreement, particularly those dealing on the automation enhancements necessary to ensure the transition of passengers between the carriers' respective services, PAL said. Financial details of the agreement weren't disclosed.

Spain drubs Northern Ireland 4-1 in World Cup warmup

BC-Sports-Golf-LPGA-Michelob Light,0419
Sorenstam happy to be headed for St. Louis
By ED SCHAFER Associated Press Writer
ST. LOUIS (AP) _ Annika Sorenstam, defending champion at the dlrs 600,000 Michelob Light Classic, is happy to be headed back to this year's tournament. She likes the people, she likes the golf course. But mostly, she's happy to return because she needs a win, and she's won the St. Louis event twice before. Droughts are uncommon for Sorenstam, 28, who won six tournaments in 1997, when she was the LPGA's leading money winner with earnings of dlrs 1.2 million. This year has been harder, as Sorenstam has yet to post a win and stands fourth on the earnings list at dlrs 288,400. But Sorenstam is not frustrated, because she knows it's the increased competition that's kept her from winning. ``My scoring average is going down and I'm still not winning,'' she said. ``I think there will be a lot of new winners this year.'' Two young women who will be trying to join that category are this year's sponsor's exemptions, NCAA Player of the Year Marisa Baena of the University of Arizona and Cindy Mueller of Belleville, Illinois. Mueller, a golf instructor, made the cut here last year. Among the 144 players in this year's field trying to keep the youngsters down, however, are seven of the top 10 money winners on the tour _ Sorenstam, Karrie Webb, Donna Andrews, Pat Hurst, Lorie Kane, Danielle Ammaccapane and Meg Mallon. But Sorenstam has a comfort factor at Forest Hills that none of the other players can match. She has won two of the three times she has played here, in 1995 and last year. She said just being here gives her a boost. ``I know I can play this course,'' she said. ``It gives me a lot of confidence. I know every hole. I can play it in my sleep.'' The par 72 layout fits her game, Sorenstam believes. The fairways are tight, often lined with large trees. She is annually among the LPGA leaders in hitting fairways and greens. ``It's a course where you have to think a lot,'' she said. ``A lot of players run out of patience. I have a lot (of patience) and I think that's why I play so well here.'' Despite her struggles, Sorenstam hasn't made any changes in her swing. And she doesn't believe in even trying to make changes while she is playing. ``If I hit a fade in practice,'' she said, ``then I play to my fade that day. There's nothing wrong with a fade.''

BC-Sports-Commonwealth Games-Marijuana,0335
Marijuana not banned substance for Commonwealth Games tests
VANCOUVER, British Columbia (AP) _ Athletes competing at this year's Commonwealth Games in Kuala Lumpur will not be stripped of their medals if they test positive for marijuana. ``We are not interested in marijuana because it isn't a restricted drug in any of the Commonwealth sports, so we don't take any notice of it,'' Dr. Geoffrey Haigh, honorary medical advisor for the Commonwealth Games Federation, said Wedneday. ``It's not an issue.'' Marijuana testing and concerns over pollution in the Malaysian capital were two topics discussed during a Commonwealth Games Federation meeting Haigh attended last week in Kuala Lumpur. Asked if an athlete testing positive for marijuana would be stripped of their medal, Haight said: ``No. Never was.'' Marijuana became an issue at this year's Winter Olympic Games when traces of pot were found in Canadian snowboarder Ross Rebagliati's urine sample. The International Olympic Committee stripped the Whistler, British Columbia, resident of the gold medal he won in the men's giant slalom even though Rebagliati claimed he was a victim of second-hand smoke. The IOC's decision was later overturned and the medal reinstated by the Court of Arbitration for Sport, which ruled there was no clear provision for marijuana testing at the Olympic Games. Embarrassed by the fiasco, the IOC's executive board agreed in April to draft new provisions in the Olympic Charter and the IOC medical code. IOC officials said marijuana would be added to the banned list and any athletes testing positive for the drug would be disqualified. Haigh said the Commonweath Games Federation follows the IOC rules, but to date marijuana has not officially been named a banned substance. ``Since it is not at present listed as a banned substance, we are following last year's list, if you like,'' he said.

BC-Norway-Strike
Mandatory arbitration for Norwegian nurses' aides
OSLO, Norway (AP) _ 20,000 striking Norwegian nurses' aides were ordered back to work Wednesday by the government. Minister of local government, Ragnhild Queseth Haarstad, imposed mandatory arbitration after a week's strike, arguing that the strike, which had gradually been expanded, threatened patients' lives. About 5,000 members of the Academics' Union, including some teachers, a few nurses and civil servants, and about 4,000 nurses' aides organized by the Norwegian Health and Social Services union, went on strike after rejecting pay raises averaging about 6 percent. The unions rejected one of the highest raises offered public employees in recent years, arguing that they needed even more to close a pay gap between public and private workers. Only the nurses' aides were ordered back to work Wednesday, since the few nurses on strike are not considered to be a threat against patients' lives. Also on strike in Norway are about 10,000 transportation workers, who have paralyzed bus services in several parts of the country. (nfm-tg)

BC-Hamas-US,0290
Hamas says it is ready for dialogue with America
CAIRO, Egypt (AP) _ A militant Palestinian group whose suicide bombers have killed scores of civilians in Israel says it is ready to talk to Washington, but only to ``clarify facts'' and not to take orders. ``We do not close the door in front of any dialogue with the United States, if it wants this,'' Sheik Ahmed Yassin, the spiritual leader of Hamas, said in remarks published Wednesday by the Al-Hayat newspaper. He accused the United States of supporting Israel, and warned that ``we fight our enemy and those who stand by its side.'' While there was no chance of talks with Israel, Hamas could discuss matters with the United States, he was quoted as saying. But the dialogue must be to ``clarify facts and not to receive orders and dictations,'' he said. Hamas opposes the U.S.-sponsored peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians. It advocates the total destruction of Israel and it has claimed responsibility for several suicide bombings that killed some 80 civilians in Israel in 1996-97. ``We are talking with Israel by arms and force until it knows who is strong (and) right. We will continue to talk to it (Israel) by this method until we liberate all Palestinian territories and not part of it,'' he said. Al-Hayat, a leading Arabic-language newspaper published in London, interviewed Yassin in the Sudanese capital of Khartoum. It was his latest stop on a tour of Muslim countries to win support for Hamas. Yassin, who is 61-years old and quadriplegic, has so far visited Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Iran, United Arab Emirates, Kuwait, Yemen and Syria. He is expected to travel to Pakistan and Malaysia.

BC-Sports-Boxing-De La Hoya,0460
De La Hoya focused, healthy heading into first fight of '98
By EDUARDO MONTES Associated Press Writer
EL PASO, Texas (AP) _ After six months off to rest and heal, WBC welterweight champion Oscar De La Hoya said Wednesday he is approaching his first fight of the year with renewed focus and dedication. De La Hoya said he feels good coming off an injury-free training camp and is eager for a June 13 title defense against No. 1-ranked WBC contender Patrick Charpentier. The fight has been postponed twice. ``It's getting me excited more than it would be to fight a big-name fighter because of so many people being there,'' he said. ``That's what is keeping me alive in the sport, having the people respond and be behind me.'' The bout is expected to draw more than 50,000 spectators to the Sun Bowl and could be the biggest fight in terms of attendance since 71,000 people saw Muhammad Ali take on Leon Spinks in the Superdome in 1978. ``That really attests to Oscar's tremendous popularity,'' said promoter Bob Arum, who joined De La Hoya on a conference call with reporters. Despite being heavily favored, the undefeated De La Hoya (27-0, 22 knockouts) called Charpentier (27-4-1, 23 KOs) a dangerous opponent. ``He's a game fighter,'' De La Hoya said. ``He's going to come at me and try for the knockout. I'm just going to have to stick and move, on my toes. He can be dangerous if I stay right in front.'' He said he's seen Charpentier before and found him to be a strong and aggressive fighter who is predisposed to use his head. ``With this guy, the key is going to be the jab, jab, stick and move and a lot of feints to try to confuse him,'' De La Hoya said. De La Hoya was scheduled to fight Charpentier in a mandatory defense twice before. The bout was first set for Feb. 28, but postponed because De La Hoya suffered a left-wrist injury while sparring. It was rescheduled for March 14, but postponed again when doctors diagnosed a cartilage tear and ordered his wrist placed in a cast. De La Hoya's last fight was Dec. 6. Asked about the boxing world's desire to see him fight against big-name opponents, De La Hoya said he plans to take on the best fighters of his era and is patiently awaiting an agreement that will have him face IBF welterweight champ Felix Trinidad of Puerto Rico. Arum and De La Hoya said they're hoping a fight with Trinidad can happen in May. ``With my name and his name in boxing, it's going to create a big event for the sport,'' De La Hoya said. ``That's the only thing that excites me. Fighting Trinidad does not really excite me, it's just another big fight for me.''

BC-Britain-Diana Program
TV show probing Princess Diana's death criticized as ``nonsense''
LONDON (AP) _ Politicians and royal experts criticized a TV show broadcast Wednesday which cast doubt over whether the Paris car crash that killed Princess Diana on Aug. 31 was an accident. The program, ``Diana - The Secrets Behind The Crash,'' featured witnesses saying that chauffeur Henri Paul, who was killed in the accident along with Diana's companion, Dodi Fayed, may have been linked to the French secret service, and may have been blinded by an anti-personal flash gun seconds before the crash. The program also said that Paul's blood tests, which showed that the chauffeur was legally drunk, may not have been reliable. It also interviewed Diana's former lover, James Hewitt, who said that there could have been a plot to threaten Diana's life. ``The program does not suggest that Diana was murdered, but it raises important new information which questions whether this was an ordinary accident,'' said Steve Anderson, head of factual programs for Independent Television. Critics said that the program, which makers Granada TV said was a documentary, was poorly researched and offered no strong evidence. ``It seems to be speculation; a lot of theories put forward by interested parties, and I deplore it,'' royal writer Hugo Vickers said in a television news interview after the program aired. Rupert Allason, former Conservative lawmaker and security services expert, said the TV show was ``nonsense.'' The program quoted a witness, Francois Levistre, who drove through Paris' Pont de l'Alma tunnel seconds after the accident. He said he saw a bright flash in the tunnel seconds before the accident, which the show reported may have been an anti-personal flash gun, designed for military use to stun victims. A rival film maker, whose documentary on Diana's death dismissing conspiracy theories is due to air Thursday, said that French police concluded that Levistre was an unreliable witness. In a February interview in The Mirror Dodi Fayed's father Mohamed Al Fayed, who owns Harrods department store in London and the Hotel Ritz in Paris, said that he was ``99.9 percent certain'' that the deaths of Diana and Dodi Fayed were not an accident, and that the two were engaged. He has offered no independent evidence, and has been strongly criticized by some in Britain for his claims. French Investigators have focused on several factors that may have caused the crash: that the Mercedes car Diana and Dodi were in was traveling at a high rate of speed while Paul sought to evade photographers, and that Paul was legally drunk. Authorities have also sought a car that may have collided with the Mercedes shortly before the crash. (rs)

BC-AP Top Financial News,0728
EDITORS:
A summary of financial and business news from The Associated Press at 0000 GMT. Stories carry ``f'' or ``i'' category codes and move on this circuit in expanded form: NEW YORK (AP) _ Stocks slid into the close Wednesday, once again failing to sustain an early advance as the market remained handcuffed by worries about company profits. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 87.44 points _ or 1 percent _ to 8,803.80, turning lower late in the session for the second straight day. Broader stock indexes also surrendered early gains and then fell sharply over the final 90 minutes. (US-CLOSING STOCKS) SEATTLE (AP) _ The Boeing Co. is halting production of the MD-11 jetliner because of insufficient demand for the triple-engine plane. ``Despite our best marketing efforts, it became clear to us that there simply was not enough customer interest in either the passenger or freighter versions of this airplane to justify keeping the production line open,'' Ron Woodard, president of the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group, said Wednesday in a news release. Production of the MD-11 will be phased out with the delivery of orders now on hand, with the last delivery scheduled for February 2000. As of April, there were 22 commitments, including firm orders, options and reserves for the triple-engine jet that can be made for cargo or passenger usage. (US-BOEING-MD11) PARIS (AP) _ The prospect of a World Cup undermined by travel chaos grew Wednesday, with Air France pilots striking for a third day, and other pay disputes threatening to paralyze the transport sector. Baggage handlers stayed off the job, forcing passengers to carry their own luggage for a second day at Paris' biggest airport. The capital's subway workers planned a metro strike and national railworkers prepared a walkout, as did airline mechanics. Top French government ministers and World Cup officials appeared embarrassed by the labor unrest, which could derail the world's biggest international sporting event. (AIR FRANCE-STRIKE) MOSCOW (AP) _ The Russian stock market rallied for a second day Wednesday, buoyed by rumors that the country's flailing economy might soon be rescued by a hefty international aid package. However, Prime Minister Sergei Kiriyenko, arriving in Paris for talks with French officials, continued to play down the rumors, and a Finance Ministry spokesman reiterated that Moscow hasn't sought emergency aid _ at least not formally. ``The Russian government hasn't officially turned to foreign financial institutions with a request for emergency aid,'' spokesman Oleg Zhukov said. However, he did say the government is negotiating about new borrowing from Western commercial banks, and possibly from the International Monetary Fund. (RUSSIA-ECONOMY) PALERMO, Sicily (AP) _ The European Union came together with its Mediterranean partners Wednesday, trying to get the economic cooperation process back on track after last year's derailment by Mideast issues. Despite the will to refocus on economic issues, however, the increasing violence in the Serbian province of Kosovo and the impasse in the Middle East peace talks threatened to push their way on to the agenda of the 15 EU foreign ministers and their 12 Mediterranean colleagues Wednesday and Thursday. The Palermo meeting is an informal session with no set agenda. Organizers hoped it would bring the conference back to its original idea of creating a European-Mediterranean free trade and security zone by the year 2010. (EU-MEDITERRANEAN) STUTTGART, Germany (AP) _ Taking aim at a market long dominated by U.S. car manufacturers, Volkswagen AG and Porsche AG of Germany are teaming up to build a sports utility vehicle. The two automakers, in a joint statement released Wednesday, said they hope to launch the new vehicle in the year 2002. Each company will sell its the vehicles under its own name. Porsche will oversee the development of the vehicle, while Volkswagen will be in charge of producing it. The companies expect annual sales of about 100,000 vehicles. Company officials said they were optimistic about entering the sports utility market, one of the hottest segments of the auto industry. (GERMANY-VOLKSWAGEN-PORSCHE)

BC-AP News Summary,0671
A summary of late news from The Associated Press. Some items have moved on this circuit in expanded form with ``i'' or ``f'' category codes: ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ Hurtling with a momentum that piled train cars one atop another in twisted heaps of steel, Germany's fastest passenger train derailed and jackknifed Wednesday when the lead locomotive broke loose. State officials said at least 100 people were killed. Traveling at a speed of 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour, car after car slammed into an overpass, bringing the bridge crashing down upon the wreckage and the dead and wounded. Houses just 50 yards (150 feet) away were unscathed, protected by an embankment. The cause of Germany's worst train accident since World War II remained unclear late Wednesday, and officials were unsure how many people were aboard Hamburg-bound ICE 884. Lower-Saxony state officials said at least 300 people injured. (GERMANY-TRAIN-DERAILS) BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) _ NATO Secretary-General Xavier Solana reiterated Wednesday that the 16-member alliance was keeping ``all options open,'' including a military reply to Serbia's violent crackdown on a separatist movement in southern Kosovo province. The NATO ambassadors reiterated they will consider sending combat troops to those nations. They also agreed to accelerate plans to help Albania and Macedonia seal their borders with Kosovo. Thousands of refugees have fled the violence in Kosovo, where Serb police and army forces have stepped-up their campaign since late May to crush the pro-independence Kosovo Liberation Army. More than 200 people have been killed in the southern Serb province where 90 percent of the population are ethnic Albanians. (NATO-KOSOVO) WASHINGTON (AP) _ Opening an annual battle with Congress, U.S. President Bill Clinton on Wednesday proposed renewing normal trade relations with China, saying ``this policy is clearly in our nation's interest.'' Announcing his decision in the Rose Garden, Clinton said that failure to renew normal trade ties would sever the United States' economic and strategic relationship with Beijing. Further, he said it would amount to ``turning our back on a fourth of the world at a time when our cooperation for world peace and security is specially important in light of the recent events in South Asia.'' He was referring to nuclear tensions between India and Pakistan. Many in Congress oppose the president's policy. This year's battle is complicated by questions about the administration's technology transfers to Beijing as well as investigations in alleged Chinese campaign contributions. (US-CHINA) SENAFE, Eritrea (AP) _ Ethiopian artillery fire echoed in Eritrean valleys Wednesday, and black smoke curled from villages abandoned by frightened farmers and their families. Officials in both Horn of Africa countries accused each other of cross-border attacks, dimming hopes for a peaceful solution to their border dispute. Hundreds of Eritrean soldiers marched towards defensive positions, while pickup trucks loaded with lightly wounded troops returned from the front to a village near Senafe, about 80 kilometers (50 miles) southeast of Asmara. (ERITREA-ETHIOPIA) GEORGE, South Africa (AP) _ One of apartheid's most notorious killers testified Wednesday in former President P.W. Botha's trial that white-led governments ordered black activists killed. He denounced his former leaders as ``cowards.'' Former police Col. Eugene de Kock arrived in an armored personnel carrier at the courthouse, where Botha is on trial for refusing to appear before a panel probing apartheid crimes. The case has turned into an examination of Botha's possible complicity in state-sanctioned killings and violence when he was head of state from 1978-1989 and presided over the State Security Council, which coordinated the crackdown against opponents of white rule. (SOUTH AFRICA-BOTHA TRIAL)

WARSAW, Poland (AP) _ Warsaw's Marriott hotel proved to be an easy target for stunt climber Alain Robert, who avoided security agents Wednesday and scaled the 41-story glass tower using only his bare hands. Robert, dubbed the Spiderman for his worldwide climbing exploits, climbed up to the roof of the 146-meter (480-foot) hotel in about 20 minutes. Upon reaching the top, he was detained for two hours by police, then released. After his first attempt on Tuesday was foiled, Robert kept his plan secret and did not inform the media of the attempt. On Tuesday, police and security agents prevented Robert from making the stunt and stopped him when he appeared on the roof of a shopping center surrounding the hotel. Robert, 35, of Valance, France, makes his living scaling tall buildings as publicity stunts. He uses only his bare hands and no cords or rigging. He has climbed more than 30 skyscrapers, including the world's fifth-tallest _ the Empire State Building in New York City. Robert, making his first appearance in eastern Europe, was invited by a Polish company that makes climbing gear. ___ TORONTO (AP) _ Grammy-winning singer Anne Murray and her husband, Bill Langstroth, have separated after 23 years of marriage. ``It was by mutual consent and there are no plans for a divorce,'' spokeswoman Marlene Palmer said Tuesday. ``They're still the best of friends.'' The couple have a 20-year-old son and a 17-year-old daughter. Ms. Murray's hits include ``Snowbird,'' ``Danny's Song,'' ``You Needed Me'' and ``Could I Have This Dance.'' ___ ST. OLAF, Iowa (AP) _ What's a lefse hurling contest without the lefse? Politically correct, say the organizers of the Uff-Da Daze celebration at St. Olaf. The traditional paper-thin bread is considered nearly as sacred as a Communion wafer among Norwegians, said Dave Doerscher, event co-chairman in the town of 140. ``I'll tell you what,'' said expert baker Phyllis Thurn of St. Olaf. ``Around here, anybody who makes lefse is not about to let anybody throw it.'' This will be the fourth year for Uff-Da Daze, a benefit for the city-owned, Depression-era St. Olaf auditorium. Uff-da, said Thurn, is an all-purpose Norwegian expression denoting anything from joy to disgust. But what about the lack of lefse? Doerscher said flour tortillas will work just fine. ``We put 'em in the refrigerator, and at our planning meeting the other night they sailed real well. Sorta like a Frisbee,'' he said. ___ NEW YORK (AP) _ A city effort to force most of New York's X-rated businesses to move got the go-ahead Wednesday from a federal appeals court. The dispute started with city efforts to clean up Times Square. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said all the legal issues had been sufficiently argued in state court. The ruling opens the door for enforcement of a zoning regulation requiring sex businesses to be at least 500 feet away from each other and not be near schools or houses of worship. As many as 150 of the city's 177 sex businesses could be forced to move. Strip club owners, patrons and employees argued the new zoning law violated their First Amendment rights. They took their case to federal court after the state's highest court upheld the rule in March. ___ LAWRENCEVILLE, Georgia (AP) _ A 65-cent candy bar wound up costing James Holcomb dlrs 1,000. A Gwinnett County jury handed up the final bill on Tuesday, deciding that Holcomb must pay for tossing the last two bites of his Baby Ruth out of his van and striking a cyclist in the leg. ``I saw him, but I didn't think it would hit him,'' Holcomb, 20, said after the two-day trial. ``He had every right to feel it was dangerous. I definitely learned from this.'' Cyclist Brendan Kerger swerved when the bit of candy struck him, but he didn't fall. His leg was bruised and he missed a few days of work, but Kerger didn't decide to sue until Holcomb tried to make a joke of the incident with police. ``It was a matter of principle,'' said Kerger, 47. ``I wasn't very seriously injured, but I could have been killed.'' Jurors awarded Kerger dlrs 200 for medical bills, dlrs 180 for lost wages for missing three days of work and dlrs 620 for pain and suffering.

BC-Today In History,0602
Wednesday, June 10
By The Associated Press
Today is Wednesday, June 10, the 161st day of 1998. There are 204 days left in the year. Highlights in history on this date: 1560 - Mary of Guise, Queen Dowager of Scotland, dies. 1610 - First Dutch settlers in America land on Manhattan island. 1719 - Holy Roman Emperor Charles VI expels Spaniards from Sicily. 1794 - Power of French revolutionary tribunals is increased, leading to mass executions. 1848 - Austrian forces are victorious at Vicenza in Italy against Sardinians. 1868 - Michael III, king of Serbia, is murdered and is succeeded by Milan IV. 1891 - L. Starr Jameson becomes administrator of South Africa Company's areas. 1898 - U.S. Marines invade Cuba in Spanish-American War. 1903 - King Alexander I and Queen Draga of Serbia are murdered. 1907 - Japan and France agree to preserve ``open door'' in China. 1916 - Emir Hussain Bin Ali of Mecca revolts against Turkish rule. 1917 - Sinn Fein riots break out in Dublin, Ireland. 1940 - Italy enters World War II against France and Britain as Germany's ally. 1942 - German Gestapo kills male residents of Lidice, Czechoslovakia, in retaliation for assassination of a German official. 1967 - Israel agrees to U.N. cease-fire with Egypt, with Israel holding conquered territory four times its own size. 1967 - The future Danish monarch, Crown Princess Margrethe marries a French diplomat, Henrik de Laborde de Monpezat, in Copenhagen. 1970 - At least 100 people are killed in fighting between government forces and guerrillas in Jordan. 1971 - United States lifts 21-year-old embargo on trade with China. 1973 - Fighting in South Vietnam gains momentum as each side jockeys for more territory under cease-fire agreement. 1988 - Riot police in South Korea block thousands of students trying to march to North Korea for reunification talks. 1989 - China and Taiwan open direct telephone links. 1989 - Police arrest 1,000 people in Seoul, South Korea, as radical students battle riot police in demand for overthrow of President Roh Tae-woo. 1990 - Former U.S. National Security Adviser John Poindexter sentenced to six months in prison for his role in Iran-Contra affair. 1991 - Iran television reports that explosions heard across the Iraqi border are the beginning of attacks by Iraqi troops on Shiite Muslim rebels. 1993 - Thousands of Somalis face a fifth day without food aid as U.N. soldiers battle snipers, and relief workers stay off the streets fearing U.N. retaliation. 1994 - An explosion destroys an international aid organization's office in Port-Au-Prince, two hours after U.S. President Bill Clinton announces new sanctions against Haiti's military government. 1996 - Chechen separatists and Russian officials sign agreements that could lay the groundwork for ending the 18-month war in Chechnya. 1997 - Top Khmer Rouge lieutenant Son Sen and his family is executed on the orders of leader Pol Pot. This later leads to a coup against Pol Pot, who is placed under house arrest. Today's Birthdays: Gustave Courbet, French artist (1819-1877); Sir H.M. Stanley, English explorer of Africa (1840-1904); Britain's Prince Philip (1921--); June Haver, U.S. actress (1926--). Thought for Today: History is worth reading when it tells us truly what the attitude toward life was in the past _ Dorothy Canfield Fisher, American author (1879-1958).

AMSTERDAM, Netherlands (AP) _ Advertising executives are refusing to show a film protesting Nigeria's human rights record during the half-time break of Friday's live television broadcast of Nigeria's World Cup warm-up match with the Netherlands. The 30-second film, made by human rights group Amnesty International, was judged too violent to be shown at half-time of the nationally-televised match, Amnesty spokeswoman Karin Buschman said Wednesday. ``It shows a goalkeeper standing in goal waiting and instead of saving a shot, he is executed,'' Buschman said. Amnesty is among a number of Dutch groups using the match as a platform to protest Nigeria's human rights record. Announcements placed in Wednesday's Dutch national newspapers drew the public's attention to an ``alternative Nigerian team'' of 12 imprisoned or harassed human rights, environmental or trade union activists. The announcement was sponsored by Dutch environmental and human rights groups but also trade unions and religious organizations. The friendly is being played eight days before the Netherlands takes on Belgium in its first match in World Cup qualifying Group E and Nigeria takes on Spain in Group D. ___ PARIS (AP) _ A lot will happen at the biggest ever World Cup, but goal-scoring record holder Just Fontaine need not worry _ just yet. Annan recommends strengthening UN military presence in Macedonia
Eds: RECAPS previous By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ With violence escalating in Kosovo, U.N. chief Kofi Annan is recommending U.N. peacekeepers stay in neighboring Macedonia until at least February and is raising the possibility of more U.N. soldiers heading to the region. The 750 U.N. troops, including nearly 340 Americans, is scheduled to leave Macedonia at the end of August. They were sent there in 1992 to prevent the spread of the ethnic conflict in other parts of the former Yugoslavia. In a report Wednesday to the Security Council, Annan said that in light of increased violence in Kosovo and discussions within NATO about an ``expanded international presence in the region,'' it would be ``premature to proceed with a decision to withdraw'' the force. Annan suggested the council consider keeping the force in Macedonia for another six months. He also said he would submit a report next month with ``specific proposals on a possible strengthening of the force's overall capacity.'' Although he did not specifically say that ``possible strengthening'' should include more troops, Annan noted that the peacekeepers were overstressed. He said the troops had already increased its patrols along the Macedonian border with Kosovo, a province of the Serb republic of Yugoslavia, established 24-hour observation posts and begun boat patrols in the Ohrid and Prespa lakes on the Albanian frontier. ``Such intensive monitoring, however, cannot be sustained over a long period of time with the current troop strength,'' he said. Annan also noted that the Macedonian government had asked that the troops remain. Last month, NATO foreign ministers also recommended the U.N. troops stay in Macedonia. At their meeting in Luxembourg, the NATO ministers agreed on increased cooperation to help Albania and Macedonia patrol their borders and joint-exercises with forces from the two Balkan nations. The ministers also agreed to step up assistance programs under which NATO has been sending small teams of military advisors to help them secure their borders with Kosovo. They also decided to hold maneuvers in Albania with land and air forces in August. Planned joint-exercises September in Macedonia will be upgraded. The U.N. operation, formally known as the United Nations Preventive Deployment Force, includes troops from six nations. They are Denmark, Finland, Indonesia, Norway and Sweden in addition to the United States.

BC-Sports-Tennis-French Open,0757
Semifinals showcase four very different women
Eds: RECAPS previous By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Four women, all with different stories. There's Aranxta Sanchez Vicario, the sturdy Spaniard who's had a long career at the top of women's tennis, but hasn't won a Grand Slam title since 1994. There's Lindsay Davenport, the American girl next door who describes herself as ``just an ordinary girl playing tennis. A boring story.'' There's Martina Hingis, sitting at the very pinnacle of the tennis world, with only the French Open missing from her collection of titles. And, with the most poignant story, there's Monica Seles, playing two weeks after the death of her father, mentor and coach, Karolj Seles. She's managed to channel her grief into a renewed determination to win here. The four women play Thursday in a semifinal round that's one of the most compelling in years. In the first match, Sanchez Vicario will be trying to recapture the form that brought her to three Grand Slam titles: the 1989 and 1994 French Opens, and the 1994 U.S. Open. She's already demonstrated her well-known grit this week. Against Serena Williams in the fourth round, she was down one set and losing 2-5 in the second. Yet she hung in long enough for Williams to start falling apart, and played shrewdly to take the match. She also showed her competitive fire. ``I taught her a lesson,'' she said angrily afterwards, saying Williams hadn't shown respect during an on-court encounter. She faces Lindsay Davenport, maybe one of the most modest semifinalists ever. Asked earlier in the week if she felt overlooked here, she replied, ``If I were a betting person or a journalist, I'd overlook myself also.'' But Davenport is the No. 2 seed here, and may be ready to prove she can win a big one on clay. Hingis has little left to prove. The 17-year-old Swiss star is at the top of her game, and her innate court sense and impeccable timing have served her well this week. Her swift victory over Serena Williams' big sister, Venus, in the quarterfinals only outlined the gap between the two, despite hopes for a new rivalry in women's tennis. Hingis has rolled through the first five rounds, losing just 21 games. But it is Seles, a nine-time Grand Slam champion, who is the emotional favorite this year at Roland Garros. Playing with her father's ring around her neck, she says she came here so soon after his death because the memories at home were just too painful. And, of course, because ``my dad would have loved me to play.'' Beating Novotna in the quarters, she clenched her fist and scrunched her face into a victory grimace that made it clear how much she wants this title, which she's won three times before. But the crowd's emotional support won't be enough; she has to be at her very best. Hingis has defeated Seles all five times they've played. The men have a day off Thursday, which is a relief for the weary Cedric Pioline. The Frenchman withstood five sets of sloppy and often tedious tennis Wednesday to became the only non-Spaniard in the men's semifinals. His 3-6, 6-2, 7-6 (8-6), 4-6, 6-3 win over Morocco's Hicham Arazi _ a match marred by 149 unforced errors _ put him in the semifinals with Alex Corretja, Carlos Moya and Felix Mantilla. ``I was so tired and I had break points against me practically in every game. I saved some of them by miracle,'' Pioline said. He became the first Frenchman to reach the semifinals at Roland Garros since Henri Leconte in 1992. Just two Frenchmen have won the title since World War II, with Yannick Noah the most recent in 1983. Arazi, who played most of the match with a blistered left foot, converted only five of his 21 break points. ``I'm going to jump into the Seine River,'' he cracked. ``The thing that really did me in is that I stayed too much on the baseline.'' Pioline, who has played three five-set matches in the tournament, will have a day to rest before facing Corretja in Friday's semifinals. Corretja made just 18 unforced errors while reaching his first Grand Slam semifinal by defeating Belgium's Filip Dewulf 7-5, 6-4, 6-3. ``This is history,'' Corretja said. ``It's not easy to have a country put three guys in the semis of a Grand Slam. We used to see the American guys in other tournaments, but not the Spanish guys.''
