While others finally arrive, French flee their own country
Eds: RECAPS previous By RAF CASERT Associated Press Writer
CLAIREFONTAINE, France (AP) _ While the other World Cup nations are glad to finally make to France, the French flee. Coach Aime Jacquet and his 22 players fly to Finland early Thursday, much more to escape the pressure and commotion of being the host nation than to play the Finish national team. Even after Friday evening's final preparation game, the team will enjoy the relative peace of their lakeside hotel close to Helsinki for another two days before returning to the pressure-cooker at home. ``It's always refreshing to travel,'' said Jacquet, stressing the daily drone of monotony would finally get the players down. France's first game is June 12 against South Africa in Marseille. Denmark and Saudi Arabia complete Group C. With their flight to Finland, some of the French stars are just happy to get away from the fans and media. ``We'll be able to walk the streets in peace. Our friends won't call us all the time and,'' said defender Marcel Desailly, eying the throng of journalists around him, ``you won't be there.'' The last dinner was spent with French President Jacques Chirac, who assured the team he had a ``strong intuition'' he would be able to present them the World Cup on July 12. Meanwhile, the media has started speculating heavily on the starting lineup, even suggesting star forward Youri Djorkaeff will be benched. Jacquet has not been much help to smooth the waters, refusing to give away any clue. Goalkeeper will be Monaco's Fabien Barthez and the defense is almost cast in stone with a back four of Lilian Thuram, Laurent Blanc, Marcel Desailly, Bixente Lizarazu. Captain Didier Deschamps is defensive midfielder and Zinedine Zidane the playmaker. That leaves four places open for discussion, including Djorkaeff's. Jacquet's main selection problems have been up front, and the sudden emergence as potential starters Thierry Henry and Robert Pires on the wings could alter plans at the last moment, forcing out a player in the middle. But Djorkaeff's mind is set. ``I have no doubts on the field. I have confidence.'' In midfield, Real Madrid Christian Karembeu long looked a certainty, especially since he should be much fitter after having played only half a season. But a disappointing few weeks have cast major doubt on his place and increased the chances of Arsenal Emmanuel Petit. Jacquet already benched Karembeu for a preparation game last week. ``I was so frustrated. I wanted to play and I was on the bench, powerless,'' he said.

Five months after daring escape, El Duque makes big league debut AP Baseball Writer
By BEN WALKER
NEW YORK (AP) _ He risked his life on a flimsy boat, fleeing Cuba the day after Christmas and floating toward an uncertain future. And on Wednesday night _ thanks to a dog bite _ El Duque completed another sort of journey. Now pitching for the New York Yankees, Orlando Hernandez. Cheered on by Cuban flags and encouraged by his half-brother, World Series MVP Livan Hernandez of the Florida Marlins, ``The Duke'' made his U.S. major league debut against the Tampa Bay Devil Rays. Hernandez, wearing his navy socks nearly up to his knees, showed off his impressive assortment of pitches from the start, striking out Quinton McCracken to begin the game. He then retired Miguel Cairo and Wade Boggs on fly balls, finishing off a perfect first inning on just 10 pitches. ``I know he's got to be thinking about what he went through the last year of his life,'' Yankees manager Joe Torre said before the game. ``When he boarded that boat, he wasn't sure what was ahead. It takes a lot of bravery.'' One of the most heralded pitchers in Cuban history, Hernandez got his chance when Wednesday night's scheduled starter, David Cone, was bitten on his right index finger by his mother's 4-month-old Jack Russell terrier. Hernandez already was in town because the Yankees thought they might need him Tuesday night to start in place of David Wells, who had a sore shoulder. ``I wish him luck and congratulate him on his big league debut,'' said Livan, the losing pitcher Wednesday in the Marlins' 5-1 defeat at Chicago. ``I'm very happy. I hope he doesn't do as bad as I did today. ``I talked to him last five days ago. I have been calling him, but he must have turned off his cell phone,'' he said. The Marlins, as it turned out, left Wrigley Field to take a flight to New York, where they play the Yankees in an interleague series this weekend. The team was scheduled to arrive on Wednesday night and Livan was hoping to hustle to the park to see Orlando pitch. Since his defection from Cuba, where he earned about dlrs 10 a month as a physical therapist, Hernandez signed a dlrs 6.6 million, four-year contract with the Yankees and proved he could pitch in the minors. At Triple-A Columbus, Hernandez was 6-0 with a 3.83 ERA in seven starts, striking out 59 in 42 1-3 innings. He last started for the Clippers on Thursday, beating Ottawa 9-6. Torre said he was looking to get six innings from the right-hander in his first major league outing. No matter how well he pitches, however, Hernandez is likely headed back to Columbus, for now. ``This is why he's here, to make one start,'' Torre said. ``His future is tonight. Maybe we'll see more of him later this year.'' More uncertain is Hernandez's age. The Yankees had been saying he was 28, although there was speculation he might be older. Inside the ballpark, even his opponents were eager to see him. That included his friend, Tampa Bay pitcher Rolando Arrojo, who defected from Cuba in 1996. ``It is hard for me to explain how I am feeling tonight,'' he said through an interpreter. ``This is my first time to see Yankee Stadium, and now I am seeing a Cuban pitch here. ``I still want Tampa Bay to win,'' he said. ``But if El Duque wins, I would like to go out and celebrate with him.''

Nikko Securities to reduce overseas presence
TOKYO (AP) _ Major brokerage Nikko Securities Co. will close about two-thirds of its overseas subsidiaries and representative offices by the end of this year, a Japanese newspaper reported Thursday. Operations of the 20 units will be transferred to Salomon Smith Barney, the securities unit of New York-based Travelers Group Inc., the Nihon Keizai business newspaper reported, quoting Nikko President Masashi Kaneko. The decision comes on the heels of Monday's announcement that Travelers would take a one-quarter stake in Nikko, Japan's third-largest brokerage house. Reducing its overseas network will save Nikko more than 100 billion yen (dlrs 721 million), which will be used to reinvigorate domestic operations focusing on individual investors, the daily reported. Nikko Europe PLC and other major foreign units in the U.S. and Europe will likely be closed, while about 10 of the brokerage's offices in Asia and elsewhere will take over operations and staff from branches of its U.S. unit, the daily reported. ``We'll compare the overseas operations of Nikko and Travelers with the stronger ones likely absorbing the weaker ones on a practical basis,'' Kaneko told the daily. Nikko also plans to renovate its existing domestic outlets and open small retail branches, with the number of domestic outlets possibly increasing to 300, or about 2.5 times the current amount, in the medium-term, the paper reported. BC-Brazil-Human Rights,0351
Organization of American States raps Brazil for Human Rights Violations
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil (AP) _ The Organization of American States has condemned Brazil for human rights violations in connection with the 1985 murder of a union leader, relatives of the victim and rights groups said Wednesday. According to James Cavallaro, director of Human Rights Watch Brazil, the Inter American Human Rights Commission of the OAS will present its charges Thursday at a meeting in Washington. The Brazilian government is charged with failing to protect Joao Canuto, a union leader in the Amazon city of Rio Maria who had been receiving death threats for some time. On Dec. 18, 1985 Canuto was shot to death in Rio Maria, some 1,300 miles (2,100 kms) northwest of Rio de Janeiro, by two gunmen believed to have been working for local farmers and politicians. Following a seven-year-long investigation ending in 1992, five people _ including the city's mayor and a local rancher _ were accused of participating in the murder but not a single defendant gone to trial. ``The government had more than enough time to investigate the murders. It's been 12 years and no one has been punished and during that time my father's killers have killed again,'' said Luiza Canuto, who had two of her brothers murdered in 1990. The OAS is an association of 34 countries who work for peace and democracy in the Americas. Its powers are purely on the level of diplomatic persuasion. While, in practical terms, the condemnation is little more than a slap on the wrist, Cavallaro believes the international attention of such violations might lead to changes in the government's human rights policy. ``Besides being the first time the organization has condemned Brazil for Human Rights violations, the condemnation is important because it comes from the only body Brazil recognizes in the area of human rights.'' said Cavallaro. According to Human Wrights Watch there have been 683 politically motivated murders of in the Amazon state of Para in 20 years.

BC-ANALYSIS-Yugoslavia-Another War?,0544
War in Kosovo: How will world react to new Balkan challenge? With Yugoslavia-Kosovo, UN-Macedonia
By ALISON SMALE Associated Press Writer
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia (AP) _ The world may have another Balkan war on its hands in the Serbian province of Kosovo, and how the United States and other foreign powers respond will test what they learned from the years of hesitation over Bosnia. The risks are higher in this round of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic vs. the world. For 3 1-2 years starting in 1992, war consumed Bosnia. Kosovo, with its ethnic Albanian majority, would suck neighboring Albania and Macedonia's Albanian minority into the conflict. That could touch off an all-out Balkan war if Macedonia, already a fragile neighbor, disintegrates into conflict between its Albanians and Slavs. Others in Europe, including NATO members Greece and Turkey, would end up on different sides. That's one reason NATO has sounded much more urgent about Kosovo than it did when war began in Bosnia. NATO officials met Wednesday to discuss dispatching alliance troops to Albania and Macedonia to contain Kosovo's war. War in Kosovo has been predicted for so long that it began to sound like Balkan scaremongering. Now, with shell-shocked refugees, an increasingly fierce assault on civilians, talk of ethnic cleansing and escalating force on both sides, it is sounding on the ground like war. The Kosovo Liberation Army, the clandestine group seeking an independence neither Serbia nor the world want to grant, has grown since Serbian police began a March crackdown. The KLA claims to control about 40 percent of the province. Fighting already has shut down Pristina airport and some major roads. The KLA is just 12 miles (19 kilometers) west of Pristina, and perilously close to the main Pristina-Belgrade road, where heavily armed police patrol constantly against attacks from hills just west. The Yugoslav army is trying to break the KLA by razing villages and giving militants no place to hide. Traditionally, Serbs regard Kosovo as the cradle of their culture and say they would do anything to defend it. But most have never been there, and are demoralized after 11 years of Milosevic rule, which has brought war, sanctions, hardship and decay. A report in Wednesday's Belgrade daily Telegraf said 100 city policemen have been fired for refusing to go to Kosovo and fight. Still, Milosevic traditionally is at his wily best when waging a war. He also long has killed in Kosovo without provoking much Western response: In 1989, at least 25 Albanians died in one day when he stripped the province of its autonomy. No foreign government protested. But Milosevic's hold on power is increasingly stretched. Serbia's sole remaining partner in Yugoslavia, Montenegro, is now led by an anti-Milosevic man and could break away from the federation. Such tension may produce increasingly erratic responses from Milosevic _ and begin a new chapter in Yugoslavia's bloody disintegration. ___ EDITOR'S NOTE _ Alison Smale, Vienna bureau chief for The Associated Press, has covered the Balkans since 1986.

BC-Battle for Jerusalem,0721
Jewish settler group stakes claims to Arab Jerusalem
AP Photos JRL101-102 By HILARY APPELMAN Associated Press Writer
JERUSALEM (AP) _ Yellow stars spill across an aerial photograph of Jerusalem's Old City, beachheads in a Jewish settler group's long campaign to ``reclaim Jerusalem.'' Each of the 30 stars marks a building in the Muslim and Christian quarters taken over by the group, Ateret Cohanim, and now occupied by Jews. Ateret Cohanim stormed back into the public eye last week when it set up seven tin sheds just inside the Muslim Quarter's walls, setting off scuffles with Palestinian legislators. City workers demolished the unauthorized sheds, but a Jerusalem city planning commission on Wednesday heard a proposal from Ateret Cohanim to build high-rise apartments and a school there, Israel's Channel Two television reported. Leading a tour of American supporters on Wednesday, Ateret Cohanim tour guide Bracha Slae called the Muslim Quarter ``the new up-and-coming Jewish neighborhood of Jerusalem.'' Ateret Cohanim's campaign to move Jews into Jerusalem's Arab neighborhoods threatens to push tensions in the divided city to the boiling point. Palestinian leader Faisal Husseini called this week for mass street protests, saying diplomacy alone was not enough to block Jewish settlement in Jerusalem. Over the past 18 years, Ateret Cohanim has moved more than 65 families into 40 to 50 buildings scattered throughout the Old City's Muslim and Christian quarters, according to Slae. Ateret Cohanim owns many more buildings it has not yet been able to move into, she said. The group, heavily funded by Florida multimillionaire Irving Moskowitz, says its goal is to restore the Jewish presence to parts of Jerusalem where it disappeared following Arab riots in the 1920s and `30s. In the 1980s and early 1990s, Ateret Cohanim received secret funding from right-wing Israeli governments. The idea of Jews living in Arab neighborhoods _ and vice versa _ seems unremarkable to an outsider. But in practice, mixed neighborhoods are virtually unheard of in Jerusalem, and any change to the character and makeup of the city's neighborhoods has been an explosive issue, with both sides fearing land grabs before Jerusalem's final status is determined in peace talks. The Palestinians claim east Jerusalem, which Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast War, as capital of a future state. Israel insists the city must remain undivided under Israeli sovereignty. ``They don't want to be neighbors,'' Ibrahim Mohammed, a maintenance worker who lives in the Muslim Quarter, said of Ateret Cohanim. ``They want to get rid of everybody else. ``They're willing to pay huge amounts of money for any little corner, and then keep expanding until they take over the whole city.'' Ateret Cohanim said it set up the sheds in the Muslim Quarter last week in retaliation for last month's stabbing death of a student from the group's religious seminary. Another Cohanim student was killed in November. Palestinian militants were suspected in both attacks. After each of the deaths, Ateret Cohanim vowed to step up its campaign. ``We are making an effort to bring in massive numbers of people,'' Slae said Wednesday. Slae insisted that Ateret Cohanim believes in coexistence, and works within the law. But because Palestinians who sell to Jews face retribution _ and possibly death _ at the hands of fellow Arabs, she said the group works secretly, sometimes helping sellers relocate out of the area, or agreeing to take possession of a property only after the seller dies. ``The difficulties are very great,'' Slae said. ``We get a lot of bad publicity.'' Afghan quake survivors sleep under pounding rains, awaiting aid
Eds: RECAPS Afghanistan-Quake-Relief AP Photos FBD101-109 By JUDITH INGRAM Associated Press Writer
FAISABAD, Afghanistan (AP) _ Pounding rains that turned roads to muck have grounded aid helicopters carrying urgently needed food and medical supplies to survivors of a massive earthquake in northern Afghanistan that killed as many as 5,000 people. The extent of the damage from Saturday's 6.9-magnitude quake remained unclear Thursday, with helicopter crews locating devastated villages that hadn't appeared previously on aid agencies' maps. From helicopters, aid workers could see entire villages that had been flattened _ some buried under landslides and others sent tumbling into valleys below by the shaking earth. In the village of Regi, perched on a peak at the end of a deep valley, about half of the 110 houses had been destroyed. The bodies of 11 people lay in the ruins, while medical teams treated the injured. Dozens of men used horses and donkeys to dig out the dead in the village of Rostaq, where the quake killed 140 schoolchildren. Most urgently needed by survivors were medical supplies and food: With dwindling food stocks, some villagers were cooking grass, said journalists aboard aid helicopters. As many as 10,000 people could be facing serious food shortages, said a spokesman for the United Nations in Faisabad. The World Food Program managed to get 1.5 tons of wheat, vegetable oil and high-protein biscuits by helicopter to remote Shari Basurkh, very close to the quake's epicenter, where half the village was flattened. The quake struck during the late morning, when most of the men of Shari Basurkh were in the fields, aid workers said, explaining why most of the wounded were women, old men and children who had been in their homes at the time of the temblor. Most people hadn't eaten since the earthquake hit. ``They really worry about the future ... because they don't have any shelter, any food. I think they have a very bad future,'' said Abdul Rahim, a doctor in the village's clinic. In Rostaq, also the site of an earlier quake in February that killed 2,300 people, U.N. aid workers were setting up bakeries to feed the hungriest. There also was a desperate need for water there: The nearest clean water was 12 miles (19 kilometers) away after landslides buried the villages' fresh spring. Wary of more aftershocks, thousands of people slept outdoors in heavy rainstorms while waiting for supplies and medical attention Wednesday. The rain increased the need for emergency tents and plastic sheeting, even as it forced several aid flights to return to Pakistan still laden with supplies. Two Red Cross and one U.N. flight carrying medical workers and supplies got through Wednesday. Saturday's earthquake and the previous quake in February also highlighted severe public health problems in Afghanistan's remote poverty-stricken regions. Many of those who sought medical treatment from aid helicopters that had touched down appeared to suffer from diseases predating the earthquake.

Nuclear powers gather in Geneva to discuss South Asian fears
Eds: Meeting is scheduled to begin at 1530 GMT. By ALEXANDER G. HIGGINS Associated Press Writer
GENEVA (AP) _ The world's five original nuclear weapons powers are hoping a high-level meeting here will put forth a united stand against a South Asian arms race threatened by Indian and Pakistani nuclear tests. As he sent off U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright from Washington, U.S. President Bill Clinton promised to work to end nuclear competition between the Asian rivals. Clinton said the tit-for-tat spate of nuclear tests was ``self-defeating, wasteful and dangerous.'' Albright said they were an immediate threat to peace and security. In Washington a top official said in the Geneva meetings Thursday, Albright would seek common ground among the five original nuclear powers, but would stop short of calling for joint sanctions on Pakistan and India as that could be counterproductive. ``We want to defuse the current tensions,'' Karl F. Inderfurth, assistant secretary of state for South Asian affairs, told a Senate hearing. Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan, who is chairing the meeting, arrived in Geneva on Wednesday afternoon. Joining him and Albright will be Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov, already in Switzerland on a previously planned visit, British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook and French Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine. The ministers were expected to hold one-on-one meetings before their session in the European headquarters of the United Nations. Albright was to see Tang in the morning and Primakov in the afternoon, diplomatic sources said. Experts on disarmament from the five countries met in Geneva on Wednesday to prepare for the meeting, officials said. Tang will try to stop the arms race between China's neighbors, fearing that it could encourage other countries to obtain nuclear weapons, Chinese officials said in Beijing. ``We should urge them with one voice and make them realize it's not in their interest,'' said Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhu Bangzao in Beijing. The powers are the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council and best positioned to apply diplomatic pressure on top of already imposed economic sanctions. They also are all charter members of the nuclear club, the only countries in the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty permitted to have nuclear stockpiles, a situation that has long irked India. Neither India nor Pakistan have signed the treaty. Inderfurth said the United States was adamant that neither India nor Pakistan would join the club. ``There is no disposition to reward any nation for blasting its way into that nuclear-state category,'' he said. Earlier in the day the room is to host the 61-nation Conference on Disarmament for a speech by Iranian Foreign Minister Kamal Kharrazi, fresh from visits to India and Pakistan. Kharrazi, who earlier expressed pleasure over Pakistan's developing an ``Islamic bomb,'' urged India and Pakistan to work out their differences and ease tensions in the region. ``We believe in a nuclear-weapons-free in the region,'' Kharrazi said Wednesday in New Delhi.

BC-MED-US-Powerful Bacteria,0895
Growing concern over antibiotic use on farms AP Medical Writer
With BC-MED-Bacteria-Glance By LAURAN NEERGAARD
WASHINGTON (AP) _ Worried scientists say farmers using antibiotics in chickens, cattle and fruit orchards are creating drug-resistant germs that can wind up in the food people eat, a disturbing twist on the growing concern that antibiotics are fast losing their power. Scientists have long suspected that farming was adding to the problem of antibiotic resistance, but now they're finding the first strong evidence: A salmonella strain impervious to five antibiotics is rampant in Britain. U.S. scientists this month reported it has sickened thousands of Americans, too _ including nearly killing a Vermont dairy farmer. Chickens sold in Minnesota were contaminated with another germ, campylobacter, resistant to a powerful antibiotic. The U.S. government is about to impose stiff new requirements on makers of new animal antibiotics, and the World Health Organization is calling experts to Geneva to search for other solutions. ``We're at the point right now where we ... have got to do something,'' said Minnesota epidemiologist Michael Osterholm, who discovered the campylobacter risk. ``This can't continue.'' ``We know there is a problem,'' agreed WHO's Dr. Klaus Stohr. The question is, How big a problem? Some industry groups deny there's proof that antibiotics on the farm harm human health. ``We don't know if it's true or not,'' said Kenneth May of the National Broiler Council. Others acknowledge some risk _ but insist it must be balanced with the realization that antibiotics are vital to animal health. If farm antibiotics are restricted, ``the real question is, 'What will it do to the world's food supply?''' said microbiologist Gail Cassell of Eli Lilly and Co. ``My plea is that we need more data.'' But the Food and Drug Administration considers the threat serious enough that it is preparing stiffer rules for new animal antibiotics, including requiring manufacturers to track treated animals for early resistance signs. ``There will be predetermined conditions of when the drug cannot be used anymore,'' said FDA veterinary chief Stephen Sundlof. The requirements ``may just be too unpalatable for drug companies to accept.'' Antibiotics are fast losing their power against numerous germs, particularly those spread in hospitals. Most to blame are doctors who overprescribe drugs and patients who take them improperly. But scientists say antibiotics on the farm are helping foodborne germs mutate, too, even as the government is under pressure to approve more agricultural drugs. Almost half the 50 million pounds (23 million kilograms) of U.S.-produced antibiotics is used in animals _ 80 percent to help animals grow faster, not treat disease _ and 40,000 pounds (18,000 kilograms) are sprayed onto fruit trees. Take fluoroquinolones, powerful antibiotics reserved for severely ill people until 1995, when the FDA approved two of them for poultry. They're put into chicks' drinking water to prevent a flock-destroying disease, not kill the campylobacter also in poultry _ the leading human food poisoner. Constant fluoroquinolone exposure caused campylobacter to rapidly mutate, said Osterholm. He tested 76 chicken products sold in Minneapolis-St. Paul grocery stores last year. Seventy-nine percent were contaminated with campylobacter, and 20 percent of those were fluoroquinolone-resistant. People didn't catch this resistant campylobacter before 1995, said Dr. Frederick Angulo of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. But 13 percent of human cases tested last year were fluoroquinolone-resistant, and the number is rising. Then there's the salmonella strain that almost killed a Vermont dairy farmer last summer, killed 14 of her cows and sickened eight of the farmer's relatives. The CDC says the family caught salmonella DT104 _ resistant to five popular antibiotics _ by drinking unpasteurized milk and handling sick cows. Nobody knows how the cows got sick or how DT104 spread here. It's been widespread in Britain for a decade, causing outbreaks from sausage and chicken. The CDC estimates the strain now infects 68,000 to 340,000 Americans annually. Worse, salmonella DT104 in Britain appears to be losing its susceptibility to fluoroquinolones, raising concern it might become untreatable, Sundlof said. The FDA is weighing this data in debating Bayer Inc.'s request to expand fluoroquinolones' use into cattle. And the CDC is urging the Environmental Protection Agency to refuse a Mexican company's request to treat blighted fruit trees with gentamicin, a widely used human antibiotic. Meanwhile, Europe last year banned an antibiotic used to spur animal growth. Avoparcin is closely related to the most carefully guarded human antibiotic, vancomycin. Since the ban, preliminary evidence suggests vancomycin-resistant germs in poultry have dropped, said WHO's Stohr. But antibiotics do promote animal growth, important for producing food, Stohr said. ``It's public health as well as an economical question. It will be up to the countries to decide what is more important.''

BC-MED-US-Bacteria-Glance,0278
How germs become resistant to antiobiotics With MED-US-Powerful Bacteria
By The Associated Press
Antibiotic resistance is a growing problem, as doctors run out of medicines that kill dangerous bacteria. When antibiotics are used against germs, they may not kill all the bacteria. Germs that survive can mutate into new strains that the most commonly used antibiotics can't fight anymore. Thus, doctors over time must try stronger and stronger antibiotics. Misuse of antibiotics is the biggest problem. Experts caution that antibiotics don't treat viruses like colds, just bacterial infections like strep throat, so doctors must be careful in prescribing them. And patients must take them properly, not quitting early just because they feel better. Bacteria in food sicken some 33 million Americans every year. The vast majority recover without any medical treatment. But 9,000 die and thousands of others, particularly people with weak immune systems because of organ transplants or diseases, are sick enough to need antibiotics; hence, the concern about drug resistance in the food supply. The government has begun new efforts to keep dangerous bacteria out of food in the first place, which would make drug resistance a moot point. Consumers can help protect themselves: Thoroughly cook meat and poultry to kill salmonella and campylobacter. Thoroughly cook eggs, which also can carry salmonella. Wash cutting boards, knives and other surfaces in contact with raw meat and poultry _ before using the implements on any other food. And wash raw fruits and vegetables.

BC-SCI-US-Surprising IDs,0891
Chewed gum, worn jeans whisper secrets to criminal investigators AP Science Writer
AP Photo NY308 By MALCOLM RITTER
NEW YORK (AP) _ The bank robber wore a mask, a parka and blue jeans. The pants told Richard Vorder Bruegge of the FBI everything he needed to know. Just like a wad of gum spoke to Dr. Dennis Asen. And a piece of weatherstripping helped a prosecutor nail a rapist. To the untrained eye, none of these items looked unusual. But they revealed enough to play a part in criminal cases that concluded within the past year or so. They show it doesn't take a dramatic bloody glove or a high-tech DNA analysis to put somebody at a crime scene. Sometimes it just takes a close look. Try this: Notice the string of dark and light blotches that runs along the leg seams of well-worn jeans. The pattern looks like a bar code. Vorder Bruegge thinks it's as distinctive as fingerprints. The pattern arises from the way jeans are made. When jeans are stitched, the operator pushes fabric through the sewing machine by hand, a bit at a time. The material on the bottom puckers, so when the sewing is done, it ends up in an irregular, undulating pattern of ridges and valleys. As the jeans wear, the dye fades faster from denim that's stitched over a ridge than over a valley. The result: light and dark blotches with irregular spacings and widths. Vorder Bruegge hopes to do mathematical analysis and compare a lot of blue jeans to see if that bar code pattern really is distinctive. He used his observations last year, testifying in Spokane, Washington, against the bank robber. The finely detailed 35-mm film of the bank's camera offered him an eyeful. Beside the bar code pattern on the outside of the right pants' leg, he saw other traits like an H-shaped wear pattern near the left cuff. The overall collection of traits matched one of 26 pairs of jeans seized from the homes of several suspects, and none of 34 pairs offered by defense lawyers. ``The bank robber depicted is wearing this pair of pants,'' he testified while holding up a pair of Plain Pockets. ``I'm 100 percent certain.'' The suspect was convicted, although the verdict is on appeal. Prosecutor Tom Rice called the blue jeans testimony pivotal. The cases involving weatherstripping and chewing gum are unusual uses of a standard forensic practice, analyzing bite marks. Dr. Norman ``Skip'' Sperber, chief forensic dentist for San Diego and Imperial Counties in California, had his doubts about the piece of weatherstripping an investigator handed him early last year. A 16-year-old girl had been kidnapped by a man who drove her to a secluded grove in his pickup. While she was outside the truck and bent over near one of the doors, she bit the door's weatherstripping in hopes of leaving evidence behind. Eventually, the man was arrested. The truck had been sold, and authorities didn't find it until three days before the trial. The girl identified it, remembered her bite and pointed out the spot. By the time Sperber got the yard-long piece of weatherstripping, it had been two years since the girl bit it. Peering closely in the sunlight, Sperber saw four tiny rectangles, the marks of four lower teeth. One was slightly out of line with the others _ a standout trait that makes a forensic dentist smile. Sperber quickly turned to a cast of the girl's teeth. ``I noticed one of her lower teeth in the model sticking out,'' he said. ``I saw it was the same tooth. ... At that point I was really kind of exhilarated.'' Sperber later demonstrated the match to a jury. The man was convicted. The verdict is on appeal, although the bite marks are not at issue. The weatherstripping ``was probably very crucial evidence for the jury,'' said prosecutor Kimberly Smith, deputy district attorney for Tulare County in Visalia, California. Like Sperber, Asen, the forensic dentist from Allentown, Pennsylvania, was skeptical when a cop called last year about a wad of gum. Police had found it near the body of a murdered 13-year-old girl, and soon after arrested a suspect. Could Asen match the gum to the man? Gum is easily distorted when it's chewed, handled and spat, making it a lousy bet for bite marks. But Asen found that this wad had definite marks from four upper and four lower teeth. Before long, he was in a prison to make a mold of the suspect's teeth. Later, he duplicated the teeth and the piece of gum. Then he put the models together, placing the bogus gum in a spot where one of the teeth was noticeably out of line. ``It just went, Boom, right into position,'' Asen said. A match. The suspect pleaded guilty in April, so Asen never had to testify. If he had, his evidence would have run up against a different identification tool: Lab tests of the gum found DNA that didn't come from the suspect. Two conflicting messages from one wad of gum. What's a prosecutor to do? ``It was sort of a double-edged sword,'' said John Morganelli, district attorney for Northampton County. ``If the case had gone to trial, we decided we were going to give this all to the jury,'' he said, ``and let them figure it out.''

BC-SCI-Hopi Artifacts,0700
Indians reclaiming their religious artifacts from museums
AP Photo NY383 By STEVEN K. PAULSON Associated Press Writer
DENVER (AP) _ Display cases at the Denver Museum of Natural History are going dark as American Indians assert their rights to religious and sacred objects under a law passed by Congress. Among the latest items taken down were 164 pieces, including religious masks, reclaimed by the Hopi tribe of Arizona. ``We pray for all Americans that they have a long, happy life for no sickness. We pray for rain because we're in a dry farming area. We need these items to keep our culture going,'' said Lee Lomayestewa, research assistant for the Hopi tribe in Kykotsmovi, Arizona. In addition to the ceremonial masks, dolls and feathers used in tribal rites also were returned by the museum. Lomayestewa said that, without the artifacts, the tribe has been unable to perform some of its important dances. The Denver museum also removed Navajo ``broken nose'' fabric masks after the tribe told officials the masks were religious artifacts. It replaced them with a sign saying ``Specimen temporarily removed.'' Tim McKeown, Washington-based federal team leader for implementation of the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act, said more than 700 tribes have claimed more than 300,000 objects from museums and agencies since the act was passed in 1992. The figures include more than 10,000 human remains and 562 sacred objects. Robert Pickering, chairman of anthropology at the museum, said he has mixed emotions about removing items from the display cases. On the one hand, he wants visitors to be educated about American Indian cultures, while on the other he wants to protect their religious freedom. ``These things are part of the American culture, not just the Indian culture. There are things that will go away and no one will have access. That apparently is what the law intended,'' he said. He said some of the items that have been returned by museums have been buried or ritually destroyed. ``The curator side of me hates to see that happen. The anthropologist in me says if this object is important in their religion, it's their business,'' he said. Pickering said it's hard to understand a culture without understanding its religion. Under the act, museums must notify tribes of any object they have that may have religious, funeral or patrimonial significance. The Denver museum, which has more than 80,000 Indian artifacts, including the original Folsom arrowpoint that forced scientists to push back the timeline for American Indians on this continent by 10,000 years, had to do a complete review and notify more than 400 tribes. Tribes then claim the objects they want returned, often after visits to view the collection. Once an item is claimed, it is immediately removed from display. Any disputes are resolved by a seven-member arbitration committee. Pickering said the act generally has worked well and promoted greater cooperation between scientists and tribes. Tribe elders have even helped correct historical mistakes. For instance, the Hopis examined some religious regalia on display in Denver and told curators it was wrong. Curators had mixed up two sets. Another mistake was pointed out by members of the Lakota tribe of the Pine Ridge Reservation, who noted that a beaded hat labeled as coming from Wounded Knee had been mislabeled. ``We do have errors, and as an educational institution, we want to reduce our mistakes,'' Pickering said. ``This act has caused us to ask questions we never asked before. Not only has it caused the museum to review what it has in its collection, but it also has caused the tribes to ask themselves what they consider sacred, and what is the proper thing to do with remains.'' Lomayestewa said some Indian tribes have lost their religious fervor, and are just now getting it back as they try to re-establish their culture and reassert their rights. ``We kept ours going,'' he said. ``We never lost touch with our religion.''

Asteroid named for Silicon Valley city
SAN JOSE, California (AP) _ An asteroid discovered in 1975 was officially renamed ``San Jose'' in honor of the city that has kept street lights dim in an effort to aid astronomers. The asteroid is one of more than 2,000 rocky objects that have been discovered circling the sun between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter. Chancellor M.R.C. Greenwood of the University of California at Santa Cruz and Lick Observatory director Joseph Miller recently presented the San Jose City Council with an honorary plaque. It includes a digital image of the asteroid and a tribute declaring, ``Through the city's understanding and efforts, the whole universe is still visible from Lick Observatory.'' The cooperation began a generation ago when astronomers at the Lick Observatory atop Mount Hamilton, just east of San Jose, worried that the glow from street lights in the swiftly expanding city below would virtually blind their most powerful telescopes. They brought their concerns to city officials, who developed ordinances over the years to control light levels across San Jose's 171 square miles (440 square kilometers). Most asteroids are named after mythological characters, so the name San Jose is a bit of an anomaly. The newly-named asteroid was discovered by Schelte J. Bus, now a graduate student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. A large, irregularly shaped chunk of rock, it is only faintly visible in powerful telescopes. Fuzzy images reveal it to be about 10 or 15 miles (16 to 24 kilometers) across _ a relatively small one compared to Ceres, the largest known asteroid, which is more than 60 miles (95 kilometers) across. ___ Study: bungee jumping a strain, but not a risk WASHINGTON (AP) _ A healthy man or woman can go take a flying leap, according to researchers who studied injuries among bungee jumpers. ``A jump, if performed under carefully controlled conditions, appears to be relatively safe and causes only minor, transient medical complaints,'' said a report in the medical journal The Physician and Sportsmedicine. It's the first wide-ranging look at injuries in this activity, said Dr. Craig C. Young, the lead author. The research found 42 jumpers had a total of 59 minor medical complaints. All the injuries healed in a week, with the exception of lacerations to one jumper who tried to grab the platform as he was going down. ``The guy was just launching, and decided he didn't want to go, and reached back to the platform and got scraped,'' Young said. The study was done at the Wisconsin State Fair in 1994 by researchers at the Medical College of Wisconsin in Milwaukee. They asked 200 jumpers to take part, and 100 agreed. The average age was 26; 74 were men and 26 were women. Strictly speaking, the study's findings would only apply to young, healthy adults, Young said. But the jumps seemed to be safe enough to go a bit beyond that, he said. ``If a person is healthy, with no disease processes, they would not have a problem no matter what their age was,'' he said. ___ Cholesterol-lowering drugs can also help people with moderate levels CHICAGO (AP) _ Six million healthy Americans with ordinary cholesterol levels might benefit from taking cholesterol-lowering drugs, researchers say. Healthy men and women taking lovastatin, sold as Mevacor, reduced their risk of serious heart trouble 37 percent, according to a five-year study in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association. Currently, national guidelines recommend cholesterol-lowering drugs only for people with high cholesterol. ``We estimate that 6 million Americans not recommended for drug treatment may benefit'' from lovastatin, said the authors, led by Dr. John R. Downs of Wilford Hall Medical Center at Lackland Air Force Base in San Antonio. The findings were also released in November at an American Heart Association meeting and were reported by The Associated Press at the time. The study involved 6,604 men and postmenopausal women ages 45 to 73 whose average total cholesterol was 221, higher than the recommended cutoff of 200 but typical for Americans. ``Good'' cholesterol, or HDL, levels averaged 36, lower than the recommended cutoff of 40. ``Bad'' cholesterol, or LDL, averaged 150, higher than ideal but also typical. Half of the participants got lovastatin, half got dummy pills. Overall, there were 299 instances of heart attack, serious heart pain or fatal cardiac arrest. Women taking lovastatin had 46 percent lower risk of heart trouble than the other women. Men on the drug had a 37 percent lower risk. However, an accompanying editorial noted that that cholesterol-lowering drugs _ lovastatin is the first of five similar ``statin'' drugs _ cost dlrs 900 to dlrs 1,800 a year at the levels used in the study. The drugs also must be taken for life.

Five months after daring escape, El Duque makes big league debut AP Baseball Writer
Eds: RECAPS previous to update with final score By BEN WALKER
NEW YORK (AP) _ He risked his life on a flimsy boat, fleeing Cuba the day after Christmas and floating toward an uncertain future. And on Wednesday night _ thanks to a dog bite _ El Duque completed another sort of journey. Now pitching for the New York Yankees, Orlando Hernandez. Cheered on by chanting fans waving Cuban flags and encouraged by his half-brother, World Series MVP Livan Hernandez of the Florida Marlins, ``The Duke'' made a dazzling U.S. major league debut, holding Tampa Bay to one run in seven innings in the Yankees' 7-1 victory. Hernandez, wearing his navy socks high and his cap pulled down low, showed off his impressive assortment of pitches from the start, striking out Quinton McCracken to begin the game. Hernandez allowed five hits, including a homer by Fred McGriff, struck out seven and walked two. Mixing fastballs, slow curves and sidearm deliveries, he shut down the expansion Devil Rays and left with a 7-1 lead to a standing ovation from the crowd and congratulations from his teammates. ``I know he's got to be thinking about what he went through the last year of his life,'' Yankees manager Joe Torre said before the game. ``When he boarded that boat, he wasn't sure what was ahead. It takes a lot of bravery.'' One of the most heralded pitchers in Cuban history, Hernandez got his chance when Wednesday night's scheduled starter, David Cone, was bitten on his right index finger by his mother's 4-month-old Jack Russell terrier. Hernandez already was in town because the Yankees thought they might need him Tuesday night to start in place of David Wells, who had a sore shoulder. ``I wish him luck and congratulate him on his big league debut,'' said Livan, the losing pitcher Wednesday afternoon in the Marlins' 5-1 defeat at Chicago. ``I'm very happy. I hope he doesn't do as bad as I did today. ``I talked to him last five days ago. I have been calling him, but he must have turned off his cell phone,'' he said. The Marlins, as it turned out, left Wrigley Field to take a flight to New York, where they play the Yankees in an interleague series this weekend. Since his defection from Cuba, where he earned about dlrs 10 a month as a physical therapist, Hernandez signed a dlrs 6.6 million, four-year contract with the Yankees and proved he could pitch in the minors. At Triple-A Columbus, Hernandez was 6-0 with a 3.83 ERA in seven starts, striking out 59 in 42 1-3 innings. He last started for the Clippers on Thursday, beating Ottawa 9-6.

Jason Christiansen pitched the ninth for his first save of the season. Reed dropped to 6-3. Expos 3, Phillies 2 In Philadelphia, Robert Perez's two-out RBI single in the eighth snapped a tie and helped Carlos Perez get his sixth straight victory as Montreal beat Philadelphia. Carlos Perez (6-3) gave up seven hits and two runs, walked none and struck out four in his second complete game of the season. He hasn't lost since April 27 at St. Louis. Wayne Gomes (4-2), who relieved starter Matt Beech in the eighth, took the loss. Gomes allowed three hits and one run in two-thirds of an inning. The Expos scored the winning run in the eighth when Vladimir Guerrero singled, stole second and came home on Robert Perez's single to left. Guerrero was 3-for-4 with a homer, and Rondell White also homered. Braves 5, Brewers 2 In Milwaukee, Tom Glavine joined Atlanta teammate Greg Maddux and Pittsburgh's Jason Schmidt as the National League's only eight-game winners , allowing only one run in 6 1-3 innings against Milwaukee. Glavine (8-2) allowed six hits and had six strikeouts in his fourth straight victory. Mark Wohlers pitched the ninth for his eighth save, completing the Braves' three-game sweep. Ryan Klesko doubled in two runs off Jeff Juden (5-4) in the first inning. Bobby Hughes homered for the Brewers.

TOKYO (AP) _ Reflecting Japan's sluggish economy, sales of imported cars, buses and trucks fell 15.6 percent in May from the year-earlier month to 19,335 units, the Japan Automobile Importers Association said Thursday. BC-Germany-Train Derails
Victims still buried in smashed German train; at least 100 dead
Eds: RECAPS, adds details on rescue efforts early Thursday AP Photos By TONY CZUCZKA Associated Press Writer
ESCHEDE, Germany (AP) _ Rescuers at Germany's deadliest postwar train wreck worked with cranes and floodlights early Thursday to uncover victims buried when a high-speed train derailed, jackknifed and smashed broadside into an overpass. State officials said at least 100 people were killed in Wednesday's accident at Eschede in northern Germany, along the Munich-to-Hamburg line. Scores were injured. The lead locomotive of the Inter-City Express broke loose at 200 kilometers (125 miles) an hour, leaving behind 12 passenger cars and another locomotive that jumped tracks and crunched together like an accordion. The pileup undermined the bridge, and two first-class cars were wedged underneath when the concrete structure crashed down during the chaotic accident. Other cars were stacked lengthwise in front of the collapsed overpass. As dawn broke Thursday, emergency workers still struggled with the delicate task of lifting huge chunks of the overpass with cranes to reach the two buried cars, where rescuers expected to find more bodies. Police at the scene said 78 bodies had been recovered, and that 120 people were hurt. Military tanks pulled the rear locomotive away from the wreckage, as search dogs sniffed through other train parts for remaining survivors. It remained unclear why the first locomotive, which went through the bridge unscathed, had decoupled and why the rest of the train derailed. One passenger from a rear car told SAT 1 TV that he felt a jarring rattle ahead of the accident, which subsided but then restarted just before the impact. ``I held on and ducked down because you had the feeling you'd be thrown through the air,'' Wolf-Ruediger Schliebener said Wednesday. ``Thank God, it came to a standstill.'' As screams rang out from the wounded, dazed survivors had staggered with bloodied hands toward residents who came running out of houses just 50 yards (150 feet) away. Splintered glass covered the ground after the late-morning accident. Within an hour, rescue workers swarmed to the scene, and helicopters began bringing the wounded to regional hospitals. The accident was the worst on Germany's premier high-speed ICE line, inaugurated in 1991 and prized for both its speed and safety, and the country's deadliest train accident since World War II. The Lower Saxony state interior ministry, which said at least 100 people were dead, had earlier estimated that as many as 300 or more were injured. The accounting of dead and injured was hampered by the severity of the mangled mess and because authorities were unsure how many people had been on board the train. Chancellor Helmut Kohl, informed of the tragedy after arriving in Italy for meetings with Premier Romano Prodi, appeared shaken by the news and called his visit short. ``So many dead ... It's a tragedy,'' Kohl, his face tight, said Wednesday in Bologna with Prodi at his side. ``Excuse me, but I must return home right away. Hundreds of people, moved by word of the tragedy, gathered at Red Cross stations across the country to donate blood. More than 1,100 rescue workers were at the scene, including trauma surgeons and border patrol personnel who helped free passengers trapped inside the rail cars. The locomotive driver, oblivious to the catastrophe behind him, had kept driving through the small train station at Eschede, 35 miles north of Hanover. The station master finally hit the emergency brakes, bringing the engine to a halt more than a mile from the overpass. The ICE train connects all major cities at speed up to 280 kilometers (175 miles) an hour, cutting travel time from Munich to Hamburg - a distance of more than 950 kilometers (about 600 miles) by more than two hours. The Munich-Hamburg train that crashed Wednesday was a first-generation ICE model powered by two electric-powered locomotives, and with a capacity of 759 passengers. At top speed the train requires 2.8 kilometers (1.7 miles) to come to an emergency stop. (tc-im)

TOKYO (AP) _ The U.S. dollar rose against the yen Thursday morning as many traders adjusted dollar positions amid continuing uncertainty over Russian financial markets. Stock prices bounced back moderately. The dollar bought 138.08 yen, up 0.32 yen from late Thursday in Tokyo but below its late New York level of 138.75 yen overnight. The benchmark 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average rose 150.35 points, or 0.98 percent, to 15,497.35 points at the end of the morning session. On Wednesday, the index lost 207.45 points, or 1.33 percent. ``Position adjustment is the order of the day, although there's no change in the overall dollar buying trend against the yen,'' said Minoru Shioiri, deputy foreign exchange manager at Nippon Credit Bank. Japanese institutional investors bought the dollar at 138.00 yen, keeping the currency from falling below that, traders said. Worries that Russia may be the next victim of the financial turmoil that has swept through many Asian economies have hung over world financial markets in recent days. Investors are assuming that the Russian situation will be the prime topic of discussion at the Paris meeting of finance officials from the Group of Seven industrialized nations next week. Meanwhile, share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange headed into positive territory following a rise in futures prices at midday Thursday, causing investors to think that public pension funds would be among buyers. ``The market appears to have confirmed its floor at 15,000 points,'' said Yoshio Watanabe, a manager in the derivatives section of Toyo Securities. Shares were also supported on buying from foreign investors. The broader Tokyo Stock Price Index of all issues listed on the first section was up 6.39 points, or 0.53 percent, to 1,211.72. The TOPIX lost 7.64 points, or 0.63 percent, the previous day. Prices had slipped at the start of Thursday's trading amid persistent worries that Japan's stagnant economy is getting worse. The yield on the benchmark No. 182 10-year Japanese government bond edged up to 1.165 percent from Wednesday's finish of 1.150 percent, driving its price down to 112.31 yen from 112.43 yen. (km-dj)

The puck took a little hop on the soft ice and beat Chris Osgood on his stick side. Guy Carbonneau's wrist shot into the upper left-hand corner of the net beat Osgood on his glove side to tie the game 2-2 with 1:25 left. Carbonneau was knocked to the ice and got up just in time to receive a perfect pass from Sergei Zubov. Igor Larionov's goal at 16:20 in the second period appeared to be the game-winner until the 38-year-old Carbonneau, playing in his 190th playoff game, caused the sellout crowd of 16,928 fans to go wild over his critical shot. Larionov scored when he scrambled to his skates after being knocked down by Craig Muni. He took a pass from Niklas Lidstrom and ripped a 30-foot slap shot from the top of the left circle by goalie Ed Belfour, who looked at his glove in disbelief as the puck ripped into the net. The Stars also thought they had scored in the second period on a shot by Mike Modano. Osgood made an acrobatic save with his blocker, just keeping the puck out of the net. Although Dallas fans booed and pelted the ice with objects, referee Kerry Fraser ruled no goal. Dallas scored first on a rebound shot by Mike Keane late in the opening period. A shot by Craig Ludwig was stopped by Osgood, but the goalie couldn't control the puck. Keane beat Osgood to the stick side with a quick wrist shot just outside the crease.

BC-Japan-Pokemon Jets
Japanese airline to fly jets painted with ``Pokemon'' characters
AP Photos Planned
TOKYO (AP) _ A Japanese airline will soon be flying two jumbo jets painted with characters from the enormously popular ``Pokemon'' television cartoon, an airline spokesman said Thursday. Kazutoshi Tsujimura of All Nippon Airways Co. said the airline decided to paint two of its B747-400s to provide children with ``a bright dream.'' ``Pokemon,'' an abbreviation for ``pocket monsters'' in Japanese, made headlines in December when nearly 700 Japanese viewers _ mostly young children _ suffered blackouts, convulsions and nausea after watching one 30-minute episode of the hit TV series. Broadcaster TV Tokyo stopped airing the show for four months, but resumed broadcasts in April with a toned down version accompanied by warnings to viewers not to sit too close to the screen. A TV Tokyo investigation found that flashy special effects may have caused the sudden illnesses, but now says the problem has been fixed. ANA, which in the past has flown a passenger aircraft painted with a large whale, said it was spending 50 million yen (dlrs 362,000) to draw the cartoon characters on the two aircraft. Cabin attendants aboard the two jets will also wear aprons designed with some of the cartoon's characters, Tsujimura said. The introduction of the painted jets will also coincide with the scheduled release of a ``Pokemon'' movie in Japan, Tsujimura said. The two jets, each capable of carrying 569 passengers, will be flown only on domestic routes from July 2 through late August, Tsujimura said. ``Pokemon'' tells the story of a young boy leading a group of friendly critters against a gang of animals trained by villains. The television show is slated to make its debut in the United States and Canada in September. (km)

BC-Indonesia-Troubled Airlines
Report: Indonesia's private airlines face collapse
JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ All of Indonesia's major private airlines will collapse soon if the nation's battered currency does not strengthen, an airline industry official has warned. Earlier this week, the country's number three airline Sempati announced it was closing its operations because of Indonesia's prolonged monetary crisis. The official Antara news agency Thursday quoted Benny Rungkat, secretary general of the Indonesian Air Carriers' Association, as saying others were also in danger. ``I think all national airlines are now in the same situation. If Sempati Air has gone bankrupt, I think Bouraq, Mandala and Merpati are also on the brink of bankruptcy,'' Rungkat said. Rungkat suggested the airlines combine their funds and forces and conduct commercial flights jointly. He also suggested that Indonesia's cash-strapped government might try to help Merpati, the second largest carrier. The report did not elaborate and there was no immediate comment from officials. Indonesia's airlines have registered big losses because of Asia's economic crisis and the weak rupiah, which has lost more than 70 percent of its value since July 1997. Most of them, including state-owned Garuda, have drastically cut services. Much of the costs borne by the airlines are in dollars, but their revenue is mainly in rupiah. Sempati was run by Hutomo ``Tommy'' Mandala Putra, the youngest son of ex-President Suharto, who resigned on May 21 following a wave of protests and riots. Indonesia's economy is expected to contract by at least 10 percent this year. Unemployment is soaring and some predict inflation could reach 85 percent by year's end. (gs)

BC-Taiwan-Airlines
Three airlines set for consolidation
TAIPEI, Taiwan (AP) _ Meeting a government drive to boost profits and improve safety, Taiwan's UNI Airlines said Thursday it is merging with two other carriers. The government's Fair Trade Commission gave its approval Wednesday for UNI to absorb Formosa and Taiwan airlines. The move will give UNI 32 planes on 23 domestic and five foreign routes, said Paul Cheng, UNI's senior vice president. Merging the airlines will cut costs by 10-15 percent, giving the airline a competitive edge in the crowded industry, Cheng said. ``The deal is particularly efficient because there is very little overlap in routes between the airlines now,'' Cheng said. ``Now everywhere in Taiwan, we can fly.'' Taiwan's government pushed for consolidation following a string of accidents this year, including the crash of a China Airlines Airbus on Feb. 16 in which 202 people died. Few carriers make money in the domestic market, and a profusion of airlines and types are blamed for maintainence and safety problems. EVA Airlines, which is owned by the Evergreen Group, will control a roughly 60 percent stake in the expanded UNI, Cheng said. EVA now holds 75 percent of UNI and Taiwan Airlines, and 26 percent of Great China, Cheng said. He said UNI expects approval from the Securities and Futures Commission and Transportation Ministry by June 30.

BC-Sports-Baseball-AL Roundup,0557
Blue Jays beat Tigers 5-1; Orioles defeat Red Sox 3-0
By The Associated Press
TORONTO (AP) _ Roger Clemens pitched a four-hitter for his first complete game of the season and Shawn Green drove in two runs as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Detroit Tigers 5-1 Wednesday night. Clemens (6-6), who had lost three of his previous four starts, struck out 10 and walked none as the Jays ended a three-game losing streak and handed the Tigers their fourth consecutive loss. Seth Greisinger (0-1) lost in his major-league debut, giving up five runs and eight hits in 6 1-3 innings. Orioles 3, Red Sox 0 In Boston, Doug Johns allowed four hits over 7 1-3 innings and Eric Davis had an RBI double as the Baltimore Orioles won for the eighth time in 11 games. Johns (2-1), back at full strength after a stint on the disabled list because of insomnia, didn't give up a hit until Damon Buford's leadoff single in the sixth. He has allowed only four earned runs in 24 2-3 innings in his last three starts. Arthur Rhodes completed the shutout _ the first against Boston this season _ with one-hit relief for his second save. Yankees 7, Devil Rays 1 In New York, Orlando Hernandez, who risked his life in defecting from Cuba on a flimsy boat, pitched seven strong innings in his major-league debut as New York beat Tampa Bay. Cheered on by a crowd of 27,291 waving Cuban flags, ``El Duque'' limited the Devil Rays to one run and five hits. The half-brother of World Series MVP Livan Hernandez of the Florida Marlins struck out seven and walked two. Scott Brosius supported Hernandez with a pair of two-run doubles. The Yankees won their third in a row, defeating the expansion Devil Rays in their first-ever meeting. Twins 3, Indians 2 In Minneapolis, Marty Cordova's two-out, two-run single in the eighth inning gave the Twins a victory over the Cleveland Indians. The loss was just the second in nine games for the Indians, who still lead the second-place Twins by 7 1/2 games in the AL Central. Cleveland took a 2-1 lead in the seventh when David Justice led off with his 11th homer of the season. But the Twins rallied in the eighth, when Otis Nixon drew a walk from Bartolo Colon (4-4) and moved to third on Paul Molitor's two-out single. Paul Assenmacher relieved Colon and walked pinch-hitter Alex Ochoa to load the bases before Jose Mesa came in and allowed Cordova's single on his first pitch. White Sox 10, Royals 5 In Kansas City, Missouri, one night after brawling with the Anaheim Angels, the Kansas City Royals went down without a fight. Wil Cordero went 4-for-5 with three doubles and Magglio Ordonez had a career-high four RBIs as the Chicago White Sox beat the Royals for their 10th straight victory in Kauffman Stadium. There were no beanballs or brawls like the ones that marred Kansas City's 7-5 loss to Anaheim on Tuesday night. There were 12 ejections in that game and more penalties are expected to be announced Friday by AL president Gene Budig, who attended the fight-filled game. Robin Ventura had three of Chicago's 15 hits and Cordero drove in three runs and scored three times, making a winner of Carlos Castillo (2-4) in relief of Jason Bere. Castillo pitched 3 2-3 scoreless innings. MORE
